ACKNOWLEDGMENTS

My sincerest appreciation to Terry and Kathleen Wetzel for their patience and gracious assistance in correcting my terrible spelling, grammar and punctuation, thank you both.  Hope I haven't botched it up to badly with my unedited revisions.  And my thanks to Michel Blair of The Camera Castle for his technical expertise and patients in assembling bits of my art work and various photographic elements to create the book's digital cover image.

Also, thanks to Neil Gaiman and Charles Vess in appreciation of their illustrated fantasy, "Stardust"; though originally acquired for the illustrations, one of the very few books I've ever actually read.  Thus, to spark a curious notion, composing a fairy tale might be fun, and though far more time consuming than I suspected, it was.

Note: A character's thoughts are expressed in italics and also underlined for clarity.

IMPORTANT INFORMATION FOR MY READERS

Fantasy Games required 4 years to create for your entertainment.  If you purchased it, the cost was less than that of a Big Mack and fries, or it may have been free, part of a launch promotion.  Either way, Fantasy Games is licensed strictly for your personal use ONLY.  If you choose to dishonor my efforts by violating this license and my copyright, passing it along or otherwise distributing it in any way whatsoever including lending by libraries or to those who have not purchased it, you are violating my copyright and guaranteeing this will be the end of the story.  Though a sequel is approximately 20% along no one will ever know the rest of the story as I will scrap the project and it will never be published.

MOTH TAILS  (Unrelated Poetry)

PROLOGUE
In a quiet meadow,
In a maiden's dream,
Might the sent of flowers
Be prelude to a scream?

Wind swept waves of viridian
May soon to crimson be,
With sinew cut and bone to crack
For those who fail to flee.

From heart to mind blood rushes,
Hence... to will a wicked deed.
Thus, upon this fertile soil
Now let the vanquished bleed.

Her mettle cast and tempered 
That never shall it rust.
For is this not a trial
That act alone she must?

Compelled to counter treachery
And man's desires of lust,
Hence... for some this day to end 
in glowing ember, smoke and dust.

When feudal wealth and privilege wed
'tis not a noble man they make.
Contempt and arrogance their children.
Of that... make you no mistake.

For some 'tis an aphrodisiac,
An opiate of bliss;
For others trials of torment,
Best... the sooner to dismiss.

Stay the sands of time
That this Regal charade may proceed.
To save friend and fool alike
For valor there shall be great need.

In this... once a quiet meadow
Where not all is as it seems.
For dragons there are, or so they say,
And witch's silent screams.

Nymphs and Fairies who seduce,
Then beg a penny to set the stage.
And relentless men who pursue
Then loose their dogs vile with rage.

The Jester and Harlot are lovers
though yet they know it not.
And three stout assassins also 
Are there to thicken the plot.

For an honorable boon secured
Another much greater shall be wrought.
All ever by the Minnon beheld
That to deceive one may not.

Adventure, if that it is,
Beyond one's wildest dreams.
A fabric woven of illusions
And fantasy's transcendent themes.

Gold and clay the same element,
Fire and water the same potion,
Pain and pleasure the same sensation,
Love and hate the same emotion.

Virtue wins no treasure here,
Patience... no accord,
Loyalty, a sign of weakness,
Brutal strength... of no reward.

The depths of pain and sorrow
bequeath to those stilled by fright.
Thus, does mayhem rule the day;
Demons and sorcery... the dark of night.

With stone, iron, fire and lead,
A fury none till now have known;
A grand turmoil not unlike 
Lucifer himself... might condone.

Sly of mind and quick of hand,
Hers the will of dragon's lore.
With tooth and nail by hook or crook
Now comes a maiden to wage war.

Yet all the while a father watches,
A daughter lost, his to redeem.
That soon upon the throne of Durer
May sit a licit pagan queen.

CHAPTER-1

A REUNION OF FRIENDS 
AND FOND MEMORIES OF THE GAMES THEY HAVE PLAYED.

Springtime in the burbs of Concord, a light shower just ending has left the air clean and sweet with the scent of blossoms.  The lunch time rush and carnival enthusiasm of burgers and soft drinks charges the atmosphere at a popular fast-food dispensary.
Beth, a mousy young lady of exquisite architecture approaches the table where her husband, Hale, and 6-year-old son anxiously anticipate their lunch, the all-American salt, sugar, and grease combo deluxe.  Hale's a big easygoing guy raised on grits, country ham and Southeastern Conference Football.  Beth is accompanied by her 3-year-old daughter Susana, who clings to the two most important things in life; the hem of mommy's skirt and a brightly decorated promotional lunch box.
Thus, through the wonders of mass media and the devious aspects of targeted advertising, this emerging little darling knows a giant chocolate chip cookie is in there along with a highly anticipated toy.  Corporate marketing strategists have defined her as being within that critical envelope from first light to age 4.  They're grooming her for their future, hoping to create another gatherer of worthless knickknacks--"collectibles" as they've come to be known.  In every realm, be it real or imagined, the rich and thus powerful shall impose their will upon the peasants--some with sword in hand under pain of death, others, as in this time and place, with an eye toward the more subversive, bloodless techniques.
Just as Beth is about to rejoin her family, she freezes.  Her eyes light up, her jaw drops, the tray drops, flipping off the table's edge, and she drops, thankfully, into her waiting chair, more or less.  Susana crouches warily in a protective stance over her prized lunch box somewhat unsure of her cookie's status.  She had thought only little persons like her dropped things; it's a relief to know mommy is clumsy, too.
Hale turns, concerned as to what has caused his wife's frantic reaction.  He jumps to his feet.  "Hooolly shit!"
Hale Jr. seizes the opportunity; climbing upon the seat of his chair with a devilish grin.  He feels perfectly justified to mimic his father, proclaiming with a sly smile.  "Holly sit!"
The crash of the tray draws considerable attention.  From the manner in which Beth plopped to the chair one could imagine the poor girl had a heart attack, or saw a ghost!  A detachment of concerned cleanup persons quickly descends upon the disaster area along with a mid level manager wondering if she need dial 911.  Beth is silent, stunned, flushed as a beet.
The ghost in question, a young woman of athletic stature and confident stride is taken by surprise also.  Beth! Oh crap! What are they doing way up here?  Leona's hair is different now, close-cropped and sun bleached; a diamond in the rough by any standard.  Silent alarms are flashing in the back of her mind.  If she's been followed, a chance reunion as this could place a friend at risk.  But, there's no way to disavowal that Beth is here and has recognized her.  So, for now she must plead ignorance, weave tall tales, and hope she doesn't appear too arrogant or get caught in a lie.  Never had she imagined coming upon someone from Atlanta so far north.  Yet, a sincere smile glows upon Leona's face as she crosses through the glass vestibule into the dining area toward Beth, who remains frozen in absolute disbelief.
In spite of the warm weather Leona wears a fashionable blazer with an unusually high collar and as always a floor length skirt, slit from ankle to hip along her left side, but discreetly overlapped.  A skirt that may be disposed of in a heart beat like a Hollywood prop.  And why, one might ask is a good looking unescorted healthy young woman not wearing her tight ass jeans?  Because it would make it difficult to hide the hardware strapped to the outboard side of her left calf, naturally.  Indeed, there are several unusual aspects to her accessories these days.  Where as in her former life decorative bobbles were shunned, she's now taken an interest in those of a practical nature.  The broad, heavy silver rings for example, with padded contoured backs that adorn both hands.  In street parlance, a ready and legal alternative commonly favored by the biker community in place of good old fashioned brass knuckles.  Thus, she could effectively drive either fist through a standard hollow core wooden door, or someone's face, and for her part suffer little personal discomfort.  Oh yes, and the armored bracelets beneath her sleeves crafted of titanium and tool steel laminate which extends from wrist to elbow.  So perfectly tailored to her arm as to have been forged there about.  A designer trinket only the most avant-garde of super models might possess and also great for those special moments were someone to lunge from the shadows with sword in hand and foul intent at heart.
For a brief moment Beth had slight doubt, a contradiction, could she be mistaken?.  After all this woman is carrying a large handbag, something her old friend detested.  An absolute necessity from Beth's point of view, in deed, the equivalent of an astronaut's life support system.  So too it has become for Leona on this side of the boundary.  However in lieu of the customary cosmetics and frivolities any modern young miss might have at her disposal Leona carries an assortment of pharmaceuticals including several poisons and antidotes any witch, junkie or assassin would be proud to posses and any DA likely to suggest five to ten for possession thereof.  Also we have ten thousand in cash, multiple passports, two I phones, lip gloss, pepper spray, a flask of gasoline, two led flash lights, a stout razor sharp spring operated knife, elastic bandages, several small magnesium flares, a credit card with a line akin to the GNP of Spain and a comb; all of which are in precisely fixed locations to assure quick accurate retrieval.
Beth rushes to greet her long-lost friend; they embrace. "I thought you were dead," Beth stutters.  "Everybody does." Beth is crying; she hugs Leona as hard as she can.  "Leo, your picture was in the wal-mart.  They even searched the woods around campus with dogs looking for bones and stuff.  It was panic city, totally; where've you been?" She shouts.
"I can tell ya for sure it wasn't Kansas."
"Huh? Leo," she whimpers inquisitively.  "Why would anyone go to Kansas?" Leona just smiles, her clichés have not improved and her dearest friend has not changed either; were that she could say the same.
That her manner has swayed toward the casually sarcastic is the least of it.  For better or worst, these past several years have tempered her character as the soothing molten brine of a forge quenches sparkling white hot tool steel.  She's become ever more precise of word and deed, unforgiving of disloyalty and quick to resolve any challenge permanently.  That supposedly virtuous quality known as patients long since lost; or better said forfeit as not to abide the foolishness of politicians or encourage the bickering of her advisors.  For now, in a fraction of a second, she can become a dynamic one is wise to avoid.
Nothing much interrupts Hale when food is within reach, but this is a special case.  "Tried to find our way back to that big fancy house," he consoles between French fries.  "Couldn't find it again to save our ass, no way!  We looked everywhere; followed every road on the map, even long driveways.  Every evening for weeks... Leo, it was gone."  Another ketchup covered fry meets its fate.  "Disappeared... just about like you did."
For the moment Beth's daughter is content to have saved her cookie from the cleanup crew, but Hale Jr. has a more curious nature.  "Mom, what's wrong?" he dares quietly, "Who's that lady?"
Beth's composure is melting like a popsicle on a hot sunny day.  "Hush! she implores, then recants,  "Oh... I'm sorry.  It's not you, Hon; I just can't think.  Hale, take the kids... please, anywhere, just go."  She points toward the children's maze.
Sensing something's amiss, Susana is beginning to whimper.  She and her cookie retreat to Daddy.  "Why's Mommy crying?" she inquires ever so softly with big teary eyes of concern.
Hale scoops her up.  "Sometimes people do that when they're happy, sweetheart.  Let's go to the slides."
There's a resounding agreement by all concerned on that motion as the slides and maze are not usually within their lunch time schedule.
"Mommy, can I take my treasure box?" her daughter pleads, tiny tears instantly replaced with smiles and thoughts of play.
"Yes," Beth is quick to concede, "you sure can."
"Let's go guys," Hale injects.  "Mom is busy."
Quite aside of this tender reunion, a rather nondescript fellow enters the restaurant and alights several tables adjacent the girls, facing Beth.  He soon has a cell phone in hand and pretends a conversation while attempting to covertly photograph Leona's friend, at least until he feels a slight prick to the side of his neck.  A somewhat disheveled young lady with long coal black hair and lots of freckles sits down in the chair blocking his view of the girls and smiles.  This is Philapee, Leona's confident, traveling companion, best friend, and some might say bodyguard, or perhaps even assassin.  She holds her hand out to the young man, momentarily revealing a small capsule.  "Wanna trade?" she inquires discreetly.  With some trepidation his finger tips lightly touch the area of his neck where he felt the sting while a very warm pulsing sensation begins to migrate therefrom.  "You only have a few more seconds," she reminds quietly.
His expression having turned now seriously fearful; and though he hesitates for a moment more, soon passes his phone to the stranger and accepts her merciful offer.  His life in fact, for the prick he felt was caused by a tiny poisoned blade which sprouted from the back of her ring when she ever so lightly brushed aside of his neck before taking a seat.  For all practical purposes, having just killed the lad then graciously granting a conditional stay of execution.  Of course she could have pried the suspect phone from his warm dead hand in a few moments had he rejected her kind offer and chosen instead to run.  Through, one might suspect that he would have tripped and hurt himself on some unforeseen sharp obstacle as another young lady of Philapee's calling happens to be loitering near each exit at the moment.  
Amazing, the critical little details missed in the blink of an eye by those of us, everyone in fact, self obsessed individuals who populate the landscape with not a hint of the blood letting that might transpire.  "Don't swallow, chew it up," she advises quietly.  "If ever we meet again," she warns, "and believe me you won't see me coming, there will be no second chance, do you understand?"  He nods affirmatively and departs with an unsure wobble to his step, hoping the capsule was truly the antidote.
As to Mommy, Beth as it were is dancing in frustrated little circles with tearful eyes and no idea where to begin her inquisition.
Leona attempts to lighten the air.  "Your children are darlings, and your daughter's--."
"Don't you darreee!" Beth warns, "try to squirm out from under this."  Her eyes narrow and her ever present smile has drawn to a pucker.  "Six years, Leo, not a word.  Six years! where the hell have you been?"
"I'm sorry, really!  One thing led to another; things got really complicated."
"What things?  I can't believe you didn't even call," Beth snivels.  "Not once! You missed the wedding and everything."  Having expended the family's entire quota of free napkins, Beth begins searching her combination purse/camping trailer for a hankie.  It does little good; she drops her bag to the floor with a thud and goes for her sleeve.  "Phones aren't that hard to find, you know."
"Trust me on this, please," Leona begs.  "There was no way I could get back to anyone once I left."
"That's bullshit!" Beth assures firmly under her breath.  "Where could you go on this planet that doesn't have a phone?  Bet you there's twenty of'em in this room right now."
To relieve some of her frustration, Beth starts to pound haphazardly upon Leona's chest.  The thought of her best friend since second grade running off without a word is embarrassing.  "Ouch!"  She stops the assault and begins rubbing her wrist.  "What is that?"  Not the least shy and given there has never been boundaries requiring permission between the girls.  She doesn't hesitate to unzip Leona's blazer to investigate.  "Holly shit!" she whispers.  Touch is Beth's way of verifying many of the things she sees; and this definitely needs to be touched.  "What is this stuff?  You wearing a chain link fence?  Is this some kind of new avant-garde fashion trend," Beth asks curiously, "Don't think I've noticed this in Vogue yet?"  She knocks at the close knit mail with her knuckles.  "It's metal," she declares in a mystified tone.  "Is it some kind'a jewelry?"  
"It's all the rage where I've been hanging out lately, like part of the local club scene.  Another passing trend, ya know, but I sort'a like it."
"Yea, I guess, be a lot cooler if somebody could see it though, right." 
"Nah! the whole idea is to be totally discrete, keeps it really personal."  Am I full of shit , or what?  But how the hell do I explain body armor?  Then I'd have to continue lying like some politician for the rest of the day.  "It's like each individual has to discover it on their own, 'cause it's a secret, like an inside joke, ya know."  Dear Beth, change the subject, please, so I can stop deceiving you.
"Yea... I guess," Beth mumbles half hesitantly.
"Trust me please.  It was something I had to do on my own." 
"Oh shit, you brat!"  Beth's voice rises and her eyes light up.  "You've joined one of those Steam Punk Goth cults.  I knew it," she gasps, "you went to California, didn't you?  We talked about that, 'member?  Why didn't you let me know?  I wanted to go too... probably."
"Come on... You know I'm not a west coast type.  I didn't really leave so much as I sort of got side tracked." Leona explains.  "Somehow, I didn't think anyone would really notice I was gone.  Time went so fast."  Leona takes hold of Beth with both arms and squeezes; she closes her eyes and rocks her friend softly from side to side.  "I'm sorry... the time just flew away.  It's like at the mall.   Your walking along, something catches your eye, and it just sort of draws you in a new direction."
"Yeah, I guess," Beth cautiously agrees.  "You should have stayed around.  Art's a millionaire now, I think.  He's got a condo, a BMW, and a Rolex."
"Pocket change!"
"Oh sure!  And he's still single and cute as a bunny, still got that nice little hind end too," Beth gleefully reminds. "Getting a little pudgy at the middle though."
"Yea, but did he ever grow up?"
Beth gives Leona one of her strange, over-the-shoulder looks. "Who cares?  Wait till he hears."
"Na!  Let's keep Arthur out of it, okay?  Remember the big fancy package that arrived last time I saw you?  The one I wouldn't open?"
"Yeah," Beth nods.  "You were still kinda freaked out about that roll playing game we beta tested, just before" she whimpers, "you... left."
"Well..." Leona confesses, "I opened it after all."
Though the best of friends surely they are, Beth can never be told the truth.  Just a few more tiny little lies and they will part.  For Hale has finally consented to a way over due dental appointment and Beth dare not give him an excuse to avoid it again.  So they agree to postpone catching up on all the exciting details of their separate lives till next evening beginning with wine and pizza at Beth's apartment, but it will never happen, much more so for Beth's sake than Leona's.
--
Their image fades as one to the past might reflect.  The smell of grease relinquished to the scent of sandalwood, the bright fluorescent lighting reduced now to candles' flames, and the hustle and background chatter exchanged for mocking challenges and threats of counterattack.
Hale and Beth are dating; the prospects of a match look good.  Her best friend, Leona, is accompanied by Art, her boyfriend of late.  He's a tall good-looking, but pretentious young man majoring in business and accounting.  They are hosted this evening by Perry, a sensible academic sort and a few years more mature and his wife, Christi, an articulate, grounded, English major.  Thus, have gathered six college friends who are now engaged in the final moments of a long evening at fantasy role game playing.
Art has graciously accepted the challenge of designing this evening's adventure, again.  As usual, his desire to conquer the realm has encouraged a slight tilting of things somewhat in his favor.  And as usual, he will act as both player and the game master.  His friends know he has stacked the deck, but they humor his antics in the interest of a challenge.  Leona always manages to sidestep his antics anyway.
Each player is obliged to create a prize--something they themselves have made to be awarded the last man standing.   Christi has baked a scrumptious devil's food cake with a masterfully crafted sugar castle atop to cover for her and Perry.  She also has five giant cupcakes hidden away; thus, each player will be a winner.  Beth will cover Hale and herself with a large pizza to have the champion's unlimited choice of toppings.  She feels strongly that Hale will likely not prevail; otherwise, she may have to top it with a quarter keg.  Actually, she will be making three pizzas for a video party the group has planned for the next weekend.  Art will surrender his sorcerer's amulet, an assembly of demonic attributes and crystals.  He doesn't see his masterful creation at risk, for he fully expects to breeze through this evening's tournament.  Leona has agreed to award the winner their choice of her wildlife sketches, matted and framed, including glass.  All the attendees will most likely receive another for Christmas.
Art and Hale are really into the macho one-on-one with classic weapons mindset--borderline fanatics of all things mystical.  Art even goes so far as to collect small statues of comic book super heroes and villainess types.  A great believer in the attributes of fate, He has brought his two pet plaster gargoyles along for good luck.  They presently occupy the living room's high ground.  Gazing down upon his adversaries as it were their task to vex his opponents defenses.
Mismatched furnishings, posters, and flea market bargains highlight the apartment.  Art has built a map rendered in three dimensions with papier-mâché, the realm of this evening's conflict.  It lays spread across a low table at the room's center.  Game pieces, dice and smoldering incense illuminated by a wide assortment of candles provide a sense of mystical authenticity to round out the decor.  Perry, Christi, and Hale have been flushed out; Beth is in jeopardy.  Thus, Art and Leona are left to duke it out.
A homemade cape inscribed with occult symbols is draped about Art's shoulders, this accompanied by his most fearsome magical amulet--an unbeatable combination.  His arms sternly folded, he foolishly suggests an unconditional surrender is appropriate.  "You're trapped; give it up now and I'll cut you some slack."
Christi snickers in unison to Leo's customary reply.  "In your dreams... dude."
Hale naturally agrees with Art.  "I think he's got you Leo."  Beth immediately expresses her disapproval of his partisan politicks with a jab to Hale's ribs.
Christi concurs with Beth.  "Psychological disinformation is not going to win the day."  Perry prefers the neutral, no-comment, wait-and-see position, particularly since Art's nemesis has never been fully taken yet.  Art stands confident he has stuffed enough tricks up his sleeve and set sufficient traps to topple this wily witch.  Leona rolls the dice, selects a card, and places two others she was holding on the board.  She smiles sarcastically with a pout.  Art begins to fidget.
--
Now I bid thee one and all venture to the land of fantasy, mostly Art's that is.  There, to stand for a time as prisoner of the group's collective imagination.
The unholy activities commence within the confines of a wide subterranean arcade, a dismal foreboding place deep within the bowels of some ancient citadel.  The damp rough stone walls are covered with the accumulated mildew of centuries.  Flickering oil lamps barely light the way between things abandoned long ago and accumulations of fallen debris.  Water dribbles through the low vaulted ceiling only to search aimlessly about the floor for an exit.  Along one side corroded iron cages hang several feet above the floor, many among them still occupied by the remnants of their long-forgotten tenants.  At the corridor's end, beyond partially open iron gates, a dimly lit dungeon awaits our players.
Two Ogres come into view, their heavy leather armor lashed together with lengths of rusted chain and straps of iron, helmets forged upon their heads, joined as one with masks of sordid mildewed leather to spare their master the sight of them.  These garments one could easily liken to portable torture chambers, for miserable surely are the sad souls restrained within.  A faint light glows from their eye sockets.  The first of them carries a torch and a massive sword so dulled by use as only now capable of breaking things.  A double-bladed ax broad as a man's chest rests upon his accomplice's shoulder.  They lumber along the slimy corridor toward the gates as shadows move slowly across the lighted area just beyond.
With sword and torch in hand, the first manages to squeeze between the seized gates into the dungeon.  His confederate, twelve stone heavier, tries but fails to fit.  As patience is not a virtue of his sort he rips the gate from its moorings with a roar.  The first Ogre spins about at the calamity ready to strike, then, lowers his guard uneasily.  "Fooolllll," he hisses in dismay.
The dungeon is an L-shaped room.  Oil lamps illuminate only the larger leg, thus, shrouding the shorter end in shadow.  Hidden there, just around the corner a sealed iron door awaits, being the only other exit.  Debris attest to the room's grizzly past.  The soot-blackened ceiling so far above its presence is known only by the rustling of the many bats now residing there.  Skeletons of machines, likely forerunners of those now employed in high-speed poultry processing plants litter the floor.  Rusted shackles and chains with brutal hooks dangle artistically from the walls.  Some of the heavy wooden doors securing the cells lining the perimeter have decomposed and fallen away or barely persist by a single hinge.
The first Ogre lumbers past his impatient associate, handing him the torch.  Picking up the recently detached gate, he wedges it firmly back into its former position and secures it with a length of loose chain to impede any who think to leave the party early.  Snatching his torch back with a grunt, Art's gruesome twosome approach the first of the cells.
 Cautiously the Ogre pulls a crumbling door open and enters while his oversized accomplice remains watchful.  Insects have all but turned the straw upon the floor to dust.  A well-dressed skeleton is heaped in the corner, the long since separated arms still chained to the wall.  Remains of fine threads and scraps of embellished cloth are a testament that this once well-to-do individual has run afoul of those powers that are said to be.  Otherwise, nothing of interest here, for history is the least of their concerns; they have a mission.
Turning to exit, he nudges a rotted wooden post which collapses without so much as an "excuse me."  They retreat as portions of the ceiling come crashing down finally providing some semblance of a burial for the occupant.  At this, the resident bats are becoming a bit uneasy with their guests.
Ogre the Impatient addresses the next cell by pulling the door from the frame and heaving it aside.  Snatching the torch from his counterpart, he readies his ax and courageously advances without hesitation.  A brave soul indeed, for he now finds himself teetering at the very edge of a pit which occupies much of where the floor should have been.  He relinquishes the torch in favor of regaining his balance; the light tumbles into the abyss with a roaring sound.  There it sizzles and flickers, half submerged in the muck sixty feet below.  The floor of the pit is set with a maze of sharpened iron stakes laced with the bones of less well balanced fools.  A stroke of genius soon follows from which an appropriate conclusion is drawn.  "Goonnneeee!"  He backs away, grumbling under his breath in languages unknown, but of unmistakable toxicity.
Ah! The "snap" of a twig instantly brightens their mood; both immediately fix their gaze upon a cell door at the adjacent side of the room.  There within a frail silhouette dodges about stricken of panic.  The hopelessly trapped fellow soon perceives a hideous leather mask appearing briefly at his window.  A mighty huff of dust and debris fly in all directions as the dry rotted door shatters, crashing into his chamber.  Massive and ominous, the Ogre's silhouette, sword at the ready, stands in the portal.  For lack of the torch his fellow dragoon sacrificed to the pit, he enters carrying a clay oil lamp scavenged from a niche in the wall.
A feeble old man, the image of a concentration camp survivor is cowering in the near corner of the cell shielding his eyes from even this minuscule light.  The Ogre advances, raising his weapon to strike.  The old man raises one arm across his face in defense, holding out his pet rat with the other as an offering.
"Master, please," he begs, "I am but milord's harmless lamp keeper."  But his fearful expression now changes to a coy smile.  "I mean you no harm."  A hand appears within the Ogre's shadow.  It sweeps aside as though parting a curtain.  "But I fear milady would have your head!"
"Huh?"
Leona's presence becomes apparent, although nearly concealed by a dark hooded cape.  A sword flashes through the air.  A lamp drops, shattering as it strikes the floor; burning oil now mingling with the straw and debris.  The lamp keeper lets out an ear-shattering scream as the Ogre's masked head drops into his lap.
Goliath the impatient charges into the fray.  Leona is quick to strike off the blade of his ax before it comes to play.  The reverse swing severs the handle, though still firmly gripped between the Ogre's palms.  Thus, is he left standing amidst the burning straw holding a short, stout staff in each fist and wishing his attack was better planned.
Back in the approach corridor, well beyond the bound-up iron barrier, a massive slime-encrusted drainage grate rises from the floor then to be heaved aside with ease and a loud "clank."  A squat hulk of a fellow emerges from the sewers below.  He lumbers toward the chained gates dragging two imposing machetes with cane hooks at their tips.  An agonizing death howl echoes through the corridor as he approaches the conflict.  His comrade, it seems, has come to no good end.
Behind him follows yet another conscript from Art's rogues' gallery, a burnished long sword at his command and gleaming shield for his defense; a shield so lustrous in fact as to be more of the ceremonial sort than something of practical purpose.  Smooth and polished as a mirror and accommodating a sharp barbed spike at the center, a prize likely forfeit by some unfortunate seeker of treasure in places better avoided.
--
From this dreadful maze wherein all manner of torment is so eloquently perceived, now again confront reality, where Art for all his clever designs is found sorrowful and deceived.
Leona, with the graceful restraint of a Vegas croupier, reaches across Art's stylized map of the realm.  There with the tip of her finger, she casually flips over two of his four toy soldier game pieces.  From our master sorcerer's perception they topple in slow motion like ten-story brick buildings from which the foundations have suddenly been dynamited.
Christi turns to her hubby with a smile and muses in a whisper.  "Surely he's learned by now a Mexican standoff is as close as you get to Leo."  Beth giggles and nudges Hale.
"You know," Perry confides, "she should consider ROTC next semester."  Christi glances back with a sarcastic smile.  "No, I'm serious," he continues.  "Why not?  I get the feeling this logistical maneuvering does more for her than mixing goop in test tubes ever would."
Art takes a turn with the dice, chooses a card, and places another from his hand on the table.  Leona places a card from her stash beside his; both are retired.  Outwardly, he seems confident, but within panic is stirring as Leona seems able to neutralize every obstacle he has crafted.
--
Reality quickly fades back to the realm of fantasy as the advancing Ogres crash like bulldozers through the flimsily chained gates.  Being Art's dutiful assassins of the moment, they are impatient and seeking merciless revenge.  Fire is spreading; rising smoke and heat have stirred the bats occupying the upper reaches into a frenzy.  They dart erratically through the thick, acrid haze and flickering light.  Visibility is becoming a premium.  Leona crouches near the floor, the better to see if not to breathe as well.
A sinister, darkly robed figure stands at the center of the corridor observing the conflict ahead.  Hundreds of panic-stricken bats stream from the dungeon; they instinctively avoid this menacing presence as they pass.  'Tis Art's alter ego.  His makeshift cape has morphed into quality garments adorned with mystic symbols of fine gold.  During the transformation he has acquired a magical power staff topped by the requisite glowing crystal orb.  His cheesy amulet, now beset with exotic jewels includes a winged demon; accessories worthy of any master sorcerer.  He's all decked out and prepared to firmly trounce this arrogant challenge to his absolute authority.  It's role playing swords and sorcery camp to the max, blended with the ultimate real-world threat--his girlfriend's reluctance to submit?  
Within the maze of smoldering cells, the backup team searches discreetly for their master's nemesis.  One motions to the other as if to say, "be still and silent."  He then points to the floor at the outside corner of the L-shaped dungeon.  A hint of Leona's cape appears there, a sure indication she is hiding in the darkness just around the corner.  With such keen insight these fellows would surely do well in the future's markets.  The Ogre with long sword and shield quietly crosses the room; then, moving along the wall to a position immediately adjacent his prize.  Readying his weapon, he braces himself, then takes a full swing as he steps blindly around the corner into the shadows.  The heavy sword cuts not the flesh it seeks, but solid stone, striking the wall with a tremendous jarring impact.
Severely off balance and now knowing he's stepped into a trap, he slices blindly into the pitch, but nothing of substance is there.  Leona's hand becomes apparent in the darkness just alongside him.  She flares her cape, tangling his weapon within its heavy folds.  The force of his counter swing causes her to spin full circle in the opposite direction adding considerable impact to her strike.  Mortally wounded, his weapon is cast adrift as he drops to his knees.
The last of Art's enslaved soldiers attacks the smoky shadows with gusto.  A battle rages nearly unseen in the faint flickering light; steel clashes, sparks fly.  The forth is slain, and now there is silence as men wait to die.
--
Once more I bid you retreat to the world of real problems: taxes, over-priced ladies' handbags, and strategically engineered shortages.  There, Leona's hand invades Art's side of the game board once more.  Again, much to his dismay, the remainder of his zombie army topples.
Perry can see Art is approaching a high simmer and thinks it a good time to help his wife out in the kitchen.  "Leo's copped the other two," he confides quietly to his fair lady. "There will be repercussions.  He takes this stuff too seriously.  I hope he never gets into politics."  They soon rejoin the others and serve up a fresh round of iced tea; perhaps it will help cool the atmosphere.
Everyone's attention is focused on the game.  How has the hand of fate stacked those cards?  What numbers will appear when the dice have stopped?  Destiny shall not be denied, neither for a ladybug wandering through the grass nor for the unknowing Lady of Durer as she wanders about this side of reality.  Hale is frantically consuming a slice of pizza as Art takes a turn with the dice and flips a card.  Leona counters, placing one of hers on top of his.
"A dead man's favor," Perry exclaims, "that works! She's going to make a traitor of your own fighter.  He'll be forced to assist in her escape."  These are not words a happy Art shall make, for indeed that locked iron door was to be her undoing.
--
Now, back into this swirling pool of collective fantasies.  Where, come what may, we shall have an end to this evening's handiwork.  To the victors their pizzas and cup cakes, but for the defeated, let them slink away to sulk as would those who dare to plot of requital and vengeance for another day.
Thus, we find the mortally wounded Ogre on his knees; his head back looking up toward the victor, yet not in despair.  He rips the mask from his head revealing the face of a tortured man.  Tossing it aside he inhales deeply as though it were the first time he's been able to get enough air to fill his lungs.  "I have so long waited to be free of that accursed thing; I do no less for thee, milady."  He pulls a key ring from his belt, fumbling a bit, holding it up with great effort to examine.  "By this you may pass."  He nods toward the iron door and offers her the keys.  "Finish your task," he begs, "that I am bound no more."
Leona grants his wish, then, turns to the door blocking her escape.  With a twist of the key the latch snaps and the rusted hulk slowly pivots, disappearing back into the pitch-black passage it once concealed.  Returning to the dungeon area she seeks a lamp to show her the way.
Art enters just then, in all his glory.  They stare at each other for a long moment, then, she's quick away into the shadows.  The lamp's reflection draws her attention to the slain ogre's polished shield.  It seems an omen, lying there beside the once formidable enemy who has set her free.  She retrieves it and sprints into the dark portal.
Art removes his cool amulet, holding it before him.  "Bring me her soul," he commands.  A wicked little bat-like demon emerges from the talisman amidst a hellish glow.  Long spindly arms with bony clawed fingers reach out, these preceded by an oversized mouth bristling with needlely sharp teeth and followed by a neck that quickly tapers off into a broad leathery tail.  Sweetheart of a thing, yet surely the sort only a mother could love.  It flutters away in Leona's direction, propelling itself through the air with it's tail as would a fish in the sea.  The iron door opens as the demon approaches allowing it to sail off down the dark passage, undeterred, mouth agape, and wicked talons extended.
Leona stands motionless in the passageway with little choice but to face the oncoming beast.  The anxious demon precludes a confrontation by slamming itself head-on into her image, reflected as it were from the confiscated shield she has hung from a torch bracket where the passage turned abruptly.  Standing just around the corner, facing the shield, she's held the lamp high to light herself providing a false target.  Now, impaled upon the barbed spike it wails and screams, struggling to free itself.  She pitches her clay lamp; it shatters against the wall engulfing Art's little pet in flaming oil.  The crackling flesh emits a foul stench suitable for the occasion.  Leona is quick away toward a fragment of light barely apparent in the distance.
Thus, now we find Art standing amidst the dungeon's smoldering debris gazing with disapproval at his amulet as it dissolves in a shower of fizzling sparks and thick black smoke.  "This just isn't fair," he sighs, casting the charred remnant aside.
Drawing a tiny dagger from his sleeve, he drives it into the side of his neck.  Thus, a grotesque transformation occurs; bulging scaly muscles, glowing eyes, claws, fangs, severe doggy breath--the complete accessory package.  Art's alter ego has gone full circle, transitioning now from one extreme to the other.
Meanwhile, Leona has found her way into the citadel's altar room where Beth, scheduled for sacrifice, is presumably waiting to be rescued.  A radical departure from the dungeons grim embellishments these walls are finished with finely dressed stone, the floor tiled in polished granite, and a cathedral ceiling of oiled cedar beams looms overhead.  Flaming silver sconces line the walls casting a warm glow on the room's interior.  An altar of pale green jade supported on the backs of gargoyles and flanked by smoldering urns occupies the room's center.  One wall includes several luxurious period-decorated cells secured by elegant polished bronze grill works.  The opposing wall is a series of arched stone portals opening onto a balcony facing the sea.  All the foregoing is complemented by matching accents of appropriate hue and arranged in a nicely coordinated demonic decor.  Sheer curtains across the arched openings roll and flutter in the ocean's breeze.
Knowing more of Art's handiwork is sure to follow Leona bolts the door, drags a heavy table up against it and wedges several chairs beneath the table's framework.
Beth is nowhere to be seen.  Leona calls out and sure enough her best buddy pops up amidst a heap of frilly comforters in the 1600s antique French salon.  "Hey... Leo," she replies with a silly grin.
"Nice!" 
"Spare me!" Beth responds, "No phone, no cable... it's a dunge'," she frowns.
"The keys?"  Beth shrugs that she doesn't know where they are.  Leona begins a frantic search rooting through the drawers of a cabinet next to the cell.  An adjacent door opens just then.  The Butler, a well-dressed ghoul, enters with a silver tray of covered dishes, lit candles and flowers.  He sees Leona and snarls his disapproval.  She up-ends the tray, dumping Beth's gourmet lunch into his face; swiftly producing a dagger from her belt and plunges it into his chest.
"He wasn't so bad," Beth pleads, "really."
That voice didn't come from the right place. Leona turns to find Beth standing outside the cell in her nightie, looking every bit a sailor's dream.  
Beth continues with the innocence of a child, "Why are you looking for keys?  I mean... he never locks it."
Glassware in the cabinet begins to tinkle as though to warn of an impending earthquake.  The approach of a great thumping becomes apparent and a monstrous wailing echoes through the walls.  Beth cringes somewhat.  "Sounds like you've pissed Art off again."
A clawed hand bursts through the bolted wooden door,  The impact scatters Leona's barricade like match sticks.
"Yep! You've really wound'im up this time," Beth concludes with a certain undeniable logic.
Leona pulls something from a string about her neck; between her fingers now a tiny hourglass.  "Let's have done with it; by these few grains of sand we live or die."
"Isn't that Art's weird little time-bomb thingee?"
The door bursts from its hinges; the Art monster squeezes his way into the chamber and stands.  He towers above the girls; his attitude less than cordial.  Fixing his eyes upon Leona, he crouches into an attack stance and challenges waving his head to and fro with a gaping toothy roar.  Leona rotates the miniature hourglass between her fingertips; the sands begin to flow.  An ominous glow arises from within the device as she carefully sets it upon the altar.  The girls look to each other as the monster lumbers toward them.  Both dash through the portals, across the balcony, and make parallel dives over the railing.  Leona's exit, a sleek swan, serious and to the point.  Beth, however, flips over feet first, back arched and arms outstretched, with an expression of pure glee as she descends toward the raging sea below.
The Monster approaches the altar with some concern.  Carefully picking up the hourglass between two talons he holds the curious apparatus up close to one eye for examination.  Knowing it must be stopped he rotates the device, but to no avail.  Just as fantasy defies the laws of reality.  Thus, shall the last few grains of sand defy the laws of gravity, continuing to flow upward until the flask has emptied.  Art lowers his head in dismay and expresses the current state of affairs in a low grumbling voice.  "Oh shit!"
As Leona and Beth sail through the air toward the sea below, a blinding light emanates from the exit portals cut into the rock face of the cliff.  An eerie fortress shrouded in mist looms above; it begins lighting up one level at a time.  The rock face bursts with a tremendous concussion.  Huge twirling boulders are propelled past the girls like shrapnel in slow motion.  The surface of the sea rages against their impacts.  The foundations now gone, Art's great stone fortress cracks and crumbles into the sea with a grinding roar.  Beth and Leona disappear into the froth, swimming straight down through an avalanche of slowly tumbling stone blocks and boulders.
Though the water is a boil with chaos the girls are not the least concerned, nor even find it necessary to seek the surface for breath.  For this is a fantasy after all and their fate has been favorably secured with a throw of the dice.  The turmoil around them subsides; they embrace as might mermaids at play among their favorite seashells.
--
The contest thus concluded, swords and spells are set aside, for now 'tis cupcakes by candle light and steaming Irish coffee for all.  Art appears heartbroken at the prospect he must surrender his amulet.  He passes it to Leona as Beth and Christi cheer her on.  "I don't have a thing in my closet that would go with this," she concedes, returning it with a smile.  "Why don't you hold on to it, we'll go double or nothing next time, okay?"  She leans over and kisses him lightly on the cheek and whispers.  "Cheer up... we all had a little fun at your expense.  Our turns will come round, I'm sure."
"Art, you know it wouldn't have worked anyway," Beth assures, teasing their vanquished sorcerer.  "You can only sacrifice virgins.  They would just send me back with 'rejected' stamped over my belly button."
Always eager to provoke a blush and Hale being such an easy mark, Leona teases.  "Hale!  Whatever is she saying?"  One might even suppose her a fraction envious of the quality relationship Beth and her beau enjoy.  Art's more the wham, bam, thank you ma'am sort rather than one inclined to cuddling.
Beth is grinning from ear to ear.  "Hey, don't start picking on my guy, too."  She curls up on Hale's lap, squirms around with a giggle and wraps her arms around his neck.  "He understands my needs," she relents coyly.  Hale blushes slightly and drapes his burly arms over her petite frame.  They look like a package of pull-apart breakfast rolls.
 Christi points to the three different-colored 16-sided dice, which show a 5, 6 and 7.  "Look at this!  I mean, what are the odds?  They had to be in ascending order, by the color, and no doubles; five seconds to escape, six seconds to detonate and seven seconds to disarm.  Perfect!"
Perry clarifies the mathematics.  "Any ascending combination would work, but I still wouldn't bet real money on rolling it.  Maybe we should round up some venture capital and send her to Vegas."
Hale adds fuel to the possibilities.  "You should put a buck on 567 tomorrow; fate has spoken."
Art seems to have detached himself from the rest of the group's merriment.  He toys with his fallen soldiers as one trying to understand how they could have failed him, especially with his gargoyles on hand for backup.
Beth queries Leona "So, what do you want on your royal pizza for the video party?"
"Oh! The usual... dragon's scales, frog's tails, and bat's ears... with a little gold dust around the edge if you please."
Christi chuckles.  "You people are worse than the Star Trek junkies.  Besides, I don't think frogs have tails."
"Actually, what I would like is a veggie," Leona clarifies, "with real slices of tomato, lots of mushrooms... and celery."
Beth wrinkles her nose.  "Celery on a pizza?"
"Why not?  I like celery!" Leona assures."  Dice it up thin like the onion so it will toast and maybe some celery seed too, and thyme on the tomatoes."
"I know celery," Beth assures, "What's thyme?"
Christi concedes.  "Does sound good.  Beth, come help with the cupcakes and I'll introduce you to Mr. Thyme.  It's sort of lemony; I like it."  While they organize the presentation in the kitchen for Leona, Christi remarks as to Art's soulful attitude.  "I don't know if Leo and Art are going to last.  She's awfully strong-willed; most guys don't care for that."
"She just likes to torment him over these games," Beth defends.  "I admit... she is a little odd though.  Loves those smelly used book stores across town.  She'd rather be scrounging around there than do the mall, comes up with the weirdest stuff too.  Last week she was totally ecstatic like she found an Armani purse at the flea barn for a buck.  Just a filthy tattered old book about some Arab guy, Genghis Kahn!"  Beth shrugs, "I mean... who cares?"  Christi snickers, easier to let Beth's historical misconceptions pass than try explaining.  "It's not even a class assignment," Beth continues, "and it's thicker than my French history book."
"Well anyway, I think it's starting to take its toll on Art," Christi concludes.  "I wonder if her mom's that way?"
"They're dead--her parents, I mean."
"Excuse me," Christi blushes shyly, "I had no idea."
"An avalanche! of all things" Beth exclaims quietly, "I mean, how weird is that?  They were skiing somewhere in Europe.  I forget where she said.  She doesn't remember them at all.  Her grandparents have raised her since she was like just a few months old."
"That's a shame; I'm glad you queued me in before I said something stupid."
Back at the realm Art starts packing up the model as Hale attempts to console.  "Chill out, man; it's only a game.  I mean, it's not like football or something."
Christi soon enters, all smiles, and ceremoniously presents her castle cake to Leona.  "For her majesty, Leo, conqueror of all she surveys and defender of the realm."
"And virtuous young girls like me, too," Beth adds with a smile.
"Very well then," Leona announces, "I command you all to join me."  She turns to Christi.  "Let's have a knife and divvy' up this treasure."
"Don't worry, I've got the rest of us covered.  That's all for you."  Christi produces the cupcakes and begins passing them around. 
"I can't eat all this!  Let's do the cake now and save those for tomorrow."
"Yea!" Hale agrees enthusiastically.  "Great idea."  Leona offers the first slab to Art.  Still brooding, he says nothing.  She continues cheerfully, allowing it pass quickly as possible.
Hale has nearly finished his portion by the time everyone is served.  "Looks like you need some backup," Leona observes, passing him another slice.
"No, no, no!" Beth chimes in.  "No more please!  He's going to be coming to Weight Watchers with me if he doesn't slack off soon."  Too late, the second slice is practically gone already.
"The poetic justice here is that Art invented that time-bomb card."  Christi reminds, trying to take some of the heat off Leona by splashing a little vinegar onto Art's scuffed-up ego.  "But, there were so many conditions it was suicide to invoke.  Then he convinced Hale he would need it and talked him into trading his bodyguards away."
"Yeah, great idea there," Beth assures sarcastically.
"It worked out fine for us," Hale defends.  "Remember?  I traded it to Leo for the 'Ferryman's Free Ride', got us out of the Zombie's swamp."
"Wasn't a trade, dear." Beth enlightens.  "She gave up the free pass to bail us out, dude."
Leona moves over behind Art, puts her arms around him with her head on his shoulder and rocks from side to side.  "Come on guys! It took three weeks to get this together for us.  There really is a lot of effort and coordination in something like this.  Too bad his Profs don't appreciate the management skills involved here."  She gives Art a squeeze.
"Hey! Why don't they?"  Perry suggests.  "You know, why don't you ask if they'll accept something like this as a business plan project?"
Leona picks it up and runs.  "Yeah!  There you go!  It's just as involved as any scheme to get bowling alleys back into the mainstream.  I would! I'd outline it and submit it."  She continues to nuzzle his neck with her chin and massage his shoulders, but Art isn't responding to either her physical attention or the praise.  She attempts a more complementary approach.  "Actually, I was planning on the Masada defense, you know, suicide as opposed to capture.  Besides it has been a long night, it's after five you know... we are about to see the sunrise."
Perry concurs.  "It is getting late.  When did we start? About seven right?  Wow! That's like almost eleven hours.  Great show, buddy, lots of challenges there."
The ladies round up the crumbs, Hale collects the soda and beer cans, Art gathers the game paraphernalia, and Perry goes to the bathroom.  With fond farewells to all, the players disperse into the early morning chill.  Art is the last to exit; Perry offers a hearty handshake.  "Really man, great game, thanks."
The door closes; Christi waits a few moments.  "I doubt there's a happy ending between the sheets for those two today; Art has got to lighten up.  He needs to learn from Hale--he and Beth... they're a riot."
"They understand the priorities," Perry concludes. "Art seems to be missing the point."
"Hale's a marshmallow." 
"Around Beth, yeah, but you've obviously never been in his company during a football game, especially if his team is losing.  But hey, I had a good time!  I'm not holding any grudges and I trust you aren't either."
"Was that a proposition?" Christi concludes with a smile.
"To da dungeon," Perry teases with a brutish look.
"No, no, not the dungeon," Christi pleads in a childish voice.
"To da dungeon, I say."  Perry insists in an artificially deep gruffy tone.
"Oh please, sir, not the dungeon," Christi insists.  But, despite her fervent pleas for mercy she's betrayed by a glowing devilish grin.
"Tooo...Daaa...Dungeon!
"All-white!" Christi concedes in a squeaky voice as Perry takes her hand and leads her to the bed room.  Likely a similar scenario will soon play out for Beth and Hale.  Two out of three isn't bad!
Dawn approaches as Art's old compact rolls to a stop in front of a stately old residence lately converted to mini apartments.  He and Leona sit quietly looking straight ahead; Leona finally breaks the deafening silence asserting the obvious.  "Are we not talking? I got lucky, so?"
"I didn't say nothing," he responds, keeping a close watch on the windshield wipers.
"Yeah... I've noticed.  I take it you're not staying for breakfast?"
"I've got a paper due Wednesday.  I need to get on it."
"This is Friday... well, Saturday... Okay, whatever!"  She exits, hesitates a moment, then turns back.  "Forgot my prize... the one I got for kicking your ass."  She reminds while reaching in to retrieve the foil-wrapped remnants of Christi's cake.  Art drives off without further ado.

Chapter-2

SEARCHING FOR LOST CITIZENS AT THE DAYDREAMER'S FAIR.

Are we victims of reality or fantasy,
And if so, which then shall it to be?
Is not one but the other, well disguised,
That each is the same, you see?

Depending upon one's point of view,
Are not either but just a game?
Curiosity being both cause and effect,
Well then... which is to blame?

A self fulfilling prophesy, perhaps,
Mere fact by any other name.
'Tis desire alone that counts the most,
For it matters not by which path you came.

Dare we venture there, you and I,
Though slight askew of time and place?
Atlanta, not so very far away,
But for the moment one need waste.

So incredibly near, In fact,
Hardly one breath must a traveler taste.
Could it be that more than one domain
Seeks to share that self same space?

A place where the rules of nature
Upon occasion slip askew.
Where time avoids the perils
A beam of light might pursue.

Preferring rather the longer route
As that around the blade of a screw.
Yet both to arrive at the self same point,
A place in common for me and you.

Such path taking more time of course
To get from here to there.
Hence, is progress held at bay
For want of memory or a displaced care.

Caution not to tell another
While there what you plan to do,
Or sure as death the hand of fate
Will have the fool made of you.

For here they dare propose
A sword is mightier than the pen.
Because 'tis not the course of history,
But your life you must defend.

Within a candle-lit chamber
Where secrets are said to reside.
A space of no apparent dimension
With not a corner where one might hide.

Within a pitch-black room
Where men in stately robes preside.
Some think of them purveyors of doom
Where those who error learn to abide.

That lawful order may be maintained,
This forum comprised of inquisitors three,
Judge of Sorrows, Lord of Consequence,
Yet not the least, the Nobleman of Equity.

Highest tribunal of the realm,
And this dark chasm is their lair.
The final word on disputes of game 
Being there's alone to declare.

Legislators more of boundaries,
The Games Regal their domain.
A field of play, by definition,
Where crimes may not be held to blame.

Rogues, villains, even murderers
Of no concern to them.
Interpreters of character are they,
Hence, more than forest or field to tend.

Rather questions of valor, honor,
Of loyalty pledged, where and when.
For the Henzec's jurisdiction begins
Where ends the concerns of lawful men.

Their task the fabric of the realm
And they the means this stuff to mend.
Though that it dare exist at all,
A space delicate and so slight to rend.

For neither sovereign nor rogue
These rules may violate.
Nor excused of buffoons or fools
It matters not how long they would debate.

When in there presence Lords recant,
That not but truth they may bear.
With beard and locks of pitch they come,
One lie, they stay till gray their hair.

Then there are the others
Never to be seen again;
But without exception
Those who are left as better men.
--
Before them now stands Marwyn, a rugged fellow of 25 years and considerably stronger than might he first appear.  One not unacquainted with certain arts some might consider strange in nature; and others pure and simple sorcery.  He himself once a player of the games Regal, but now an advocate of the realm qualified both to charge and defend players of the Games.  On this occasion however, he is called to inquiry and council of matters upon which no other of his standing may claim first-hand knowledge.
On his right a tall, slender, sober female, a solicitor of the realm.  She addresses the court's guest.  "Marwyn of Cereta, your vow of silence regarding matters of the game is hereby suspended so long as you stand before this forum.  As an officer of the courts do you affirm that nothing which transpires within this chamber may be revealed to anyone for any reason?"
"Yes!" He acknowledges.
"Were you once counted among those entitled to cross over as a participant of the Games Regal?"
"Yes!"
"Have you forfeited everything gained thereby and surrendered your warrant without duress?"
"Yes!"
The Lord of Consequence is first to inquire. "The fondest dream of every child in the realm is to qualify as a player of the games.  You stand apart, the only one once accepted to have cast this honor and its privileges aside.  Why?"
"I intend no disrespect... your honors.  In my eyes the game breeds distrust and conceit.  People whom I loved were slain or destroyed themselves and the best of their friends.  Gold is not a cause I choose to die for.  I was fortunate; fate has allowed me to return home to a simple and useful life.
"Do you then firmly believe and trust in the hand of fate?"  The Nobleman of Equity questions, probing Marwyn's philosophy.  
"Yes!"
The Judge of Sorrows turns first to one associate then to the other.  Both silently nod their approval whereupon he proceeds to enlighten Marwyn of the task for which he's been chosen.
"But for a few unfortunate sods chained up here and there all those with a license to cross remain safely away. 
They, enjoying their considerable good fortune with not a care, as you once did.  Your experience in that place and your honorable service to this tribunal qualify you in certain matters presently of interest to us.  Some twenty years past the treacherous and untimely fall of Durer has created an imbalance, an uneasy situation to this day.  A city administered by committees of favorites and appointees cannot but fall to ruin and Durer is well upon that path.  A simple notation has been discovered in the city's archives, slight, but ever so important.  Six words that imply the queen may have given birth to a princess just prior to the city's default.  We have reason to believe that if such infant ever existed it might have been smuggled across the portal to keep the child from harm's way.  In theory, that could not happen, but we must render a valid effort to dismiss every possibility."
"You see," The Nobleman of Equity adds with some pitch of concern, "why such a simple notation would exist in the absence of an official proclamation is troubling.   If the official record was destroyed we must know why.  Given the demise of Durer was such a rapid event the scribes may have been otherwise occupied and the notation ambiguous.  Either way we must be sure."
These disclosures are well above Marwyn's level of privilege.  He is beginning to see himself adrift in a small boat cast upon a troubled sea without sails, oars, provisions, or a rudder to stay his course.
"A grand scheme indeed that there may exist alive and well a lawful heir to the House of Durer," the Lord of Consequence adds.  "Such an individual could restore a measure of balance between certain of the kingdoms in a politically acceptable fashion.  For in due time, the alternative will surely cause a most painful undoing of a well-established city.  If Durer may be saved, then it must be done."
The Nobleman of Equity motions to an unseen officer who steps from the boundless shadows that ever surround the tribunal.  He presents Marwyn with a ring of the sort used to seal documents.  "This grants you access to any resource of the realm," the judge advises, "in whatever measure you deem necessary to sustain this court's inquiry.  The laws of the realm no longer stand before you; if it exists find and authenticate the child."
--
Humm!  Was that a dream, another of Art's games perhaps?  For no such place as you have just visited exists in this world, does it?  Ahhhh, but now we are awake again and back in familiar territory, downtown Atlanta, a lively place to be sure.  And so, come we now upon a roll-playing gamer's carnival.  Fun and frivolity for all, especially those with over-active imaginations.  Perchance, the perfect opportunity to seek out something the City of Durer, wherever that is, may have lost!
The parking lot is packed; Art's compact zips into the first available space.  He and Hale exit and sprint toward the exhibition hall.  They dodge around and between the parked cars like a quarterback and his best blocker in the final seconds of the Super Bowl.  The billboard above the entrance boldly proclaims "Gaming Exposition, Over 300 Dealers".  Leona and Beth are still in the back seat when the guys disappear through the gates of paradise.  Beth implies sarcastically.  "Think they'll be safe in there... on their own?"
"All I can say is thank God Art can't get a credit card.  He'll spend every nickel he's got and I'll have to lend him lunch money for the next two weeks."  Leona stretches forward between the seats to get a look at the dashboard.  "Looks like he's got almost a full tank of gas; I wonder how that happened?"
"I snatched a twenty from Hale's wallet for safe-keeping.  He'll rediscover it in the morning."  Leona chuckles at the thought that her 106 pound daisy of a friend has had to take something the size of Hale under her protective custody.
The ladies enter the main hall.  Isles of Booths and promotional displays of game-playing items: clothing, candles, new-age books, replica weapons, crystal balls, and lots of comics.  Every realm of fantasy from Atlantis to the Zodiac is represented.  Posters everywhere, most with busty, weapon-wielding, scantily clad females, typically accompanied by some Neanderthal or large winged carnivore.  The crowd is almost entirely young males with a few original hippies and Grateful Dead types for flavor.  The guys have disappeared without a trace, spirited away by some mystic force that was probably wearing hot-pants and carrying a sword.
Somehow? the girls end up at a clothing booth.  Beth pulls a provocative outfit from a rack and models it.  "Is this what the slave girls are wearing this year?"
"If it were up to these guys, I'm sure you'd be expected to wade through swamps, climb mountains of jagged rocks and ice, and fight demons with nothing more... and probably less.  Of course, they would be along to protect you decked out in fur lined leather and light armor."
"You and Art, ha!"  Beth exclaims with a wide grin.
"You know this is the first I've seen of him since he drove off and left me standing on the curb at sunrise last Saturday morning." 
 "You're going to have to throw the next one really bad.  I mean helpless as a snail, maybe even crying a little."
"Like hell!" Leona assures.
"Don't knock it!"  She turns up her nose and muses, "I can put my guy on his knees with a few tears."  Beth pulls another equally sparse outfit from the rack. "Ohhh... this is nice!  Yes, I could totally control Hale with weapons of this caliber,"  she quietly confides.  "I'm telling ya you need to get one of these teasers.  Think of it as one of your basketball outfits with some lace and a see-through tee shirt.  It's just another one on one sport," Beth chirps, "but both sides win, eek!"
"He can kiss my ass."
"He probably would," Beth assures with a devilish smirk, "more than once."
A young salesgirl dressed in Renaissance costume approaches.  "That's perfect for you.  Would you like to try it on?"
Perfect, what a coincidence, Leona muses to herself.
"Yes! Oh, and do you have anything bullet proof?"  Beth continues to harass.  "A nice drab green and brown Desert Storm kind of thing for my friend here with lots of pockets for ammo and hand grenades?"
Leona flashes a sour attitude.
"Yeah," Beth adds, "I'll sew a little red heart on it and you can wear it to your sword fighting class."
"Fencing!"
"What... ever!"
Leona sweeps the air with the back of her hand for them to go away.  Beth and the salesgirl move off out of sight to the changing booths while Leona fondles a jump suit. 
A young lady about the age of seven peaks out from between the clothes racks.  Shy as a hummingbird, she cautiously looks about.  Seeing no one else near she raises her line of sight, smiles and prances over to Leona with a curtsy.  A perfect little doll she is, dressed as a fairy ballerina replete with wings of sparkling gossamer fabric.  Very slowly they cycle back and forth as those of a butterfly whilst extracting nectar from a flower.
Leona crouches down to address her at fairy level.  "Well, hello, and how are you today?"
"Very fine, milady."
"Indeed you are!  And may I ask, what is your name?"
"I am called Toeluqule."  The little girl's wings flutter momentarily, yet so quickly as to become almost invisible.  The clothing on the rack shuffles in the breeze.
"And how may I please you, Miss Toeluqule?"
Her wings accelerate again, but for a moment, as she hands Leona a card.  "And what have we here?  'Your future for a penny with this card, Booth 108.'  Quite a bargain you're offering!"
"Costs a penny. Will you go?"
"Yes!"
"Promise?"
"For you, I promise."
At that, Toeluqule lights up with a gleeful smile.  Leona is distracted for a moment when she hears Beth and the salesgirl returning.  Looking back, she is disappointed to find her little friend has disappeared.  Given a moment to reflect, those play wings couldn't have cycled fast enough to caused a breeze, could they?
"You look pleased," Beth assures.  "What happened?"
"That was so clever."
"Huh?"
"The wings, from what I know of mechanics, I don't think it was possible."
"What?"
"Never mind, you had to be here."
"Spotted the guys at the food court.  I've got the munchies," Beth nods.  "Come on; let's see if we can embarrass them into treating us before they go broke."
"I'm surprised they'd stop long enough to eat.  Go ahead, I'll pass.  I've a little promise to keep; I'll catch up in a few minutes."  Beth scoots away to filch a freebie while Leona's off to search out the fortuneteller's booth.  It's hidden somewhat by stacks of portable partitions; well out of the mainstream traffic and definitely in the low-rent neighborhood.  Neither of the adjacent spaces are rented; both are piled with folding chairs.  The booth is little more than a cardboard archway which has been childishly painted with stars, planets, and signs of the Zodiac.  Faded mismatched curtains are hung to enclose the sides.  It's not impressive, but the price is right and a promise was made.  Truth be told, she's hoping the little girl will be there and might show her how those wings work.  The bad news is scribbled on a sign pinned to the curtain across the entrance declaring the facility "closed".  Leona turns away a little discouraged until a quaint voice beckons from within.
"Come in, come in please.  I've just been to the ladies room.  We are back in order now."  She parts the curtain and enters the small dimly-lit chamber.  As her eyes adjust to the light Leona finds herself before a massive stone archway rendered in a Celtic motif.  Unicorns hide among the designs and wistful maidens bid you enter.  A heavy dark green velour drape covers the portal.  There are marvelous contradictions here, for the stonework rises well above the level of the ceiling in the room she has just left, indeed from her present point of view there doesn't appear to be a ceiling  Yet, for some reason the conflict of logic raises no caution flags, even to someone as quick to question as Leona.
So gentle the voice that calls to her, "come in child, your future awaits."  Once the words are spoken Leona knows this is a request which she may not deny.  A calming hypnotic feeling assures her no harm lingers there within.  Beyond the curtain, two high-backed chairs face each other across a small black table; thereupon a silver tray and a candle.  The Cleric, a gracious lady with a truly disarming smile motions that Leona should come forward and sit.  Fine garments grace her person with sparse but quality accessories; no foolish trinkets here.  Art would have been disappointed as she is seemingly out of character by normal swords-and-sorcery standards.
"Have you come to me of your own free will?"
"Yes!"
"Very well, place first the card then your penny on the plate." Leona, somewhat transfixed, complies.  A tray of sliced fruits and a glass of wine moves into view at her side, it's held by two enormous hands.  Leona, ever curious as to how things like this happen, turns and looks upward.  An immense male with shoulder length blond hair wearing little more than something akin to jockey shorts is standing silently at her side. So large and muscular is he as to be of the sort found only on fantasy magazine covers or in the erotic dreams of Amazons.  She has a nearly uncontrollable urge to slide the palm of her hand across his abdomen, just to assure herself he is real.
Leona turns to the Cleric.  "Is his name Thor?" She asks with total sincerity.  Before the Cleric can answer she turns back, looks straight up into his eyes and asks, "do you have a big hammer?"  Then just a quick she is again facing the Cleric with a childish grin from ear to ear.  "Hung like a stallion isn't he?" she whispers quietly with a giggle.  Seems her current environment has flipped her like she's just finished off a couple joints. 
"He is called Rea." The Cleric advises with a smile and slight chuckle.  "Sample the wine my dear, it's very good."
"I've never known a penny to go this far."
"A penny by way of the Fay's invitation," the old woman advises affectionately.  "Considerably more otherwise."
"Yes, the little girl... she is so enchanting."
"More than you might suspect," assures the Cleric with a coy smile.
The chatter of the gaming fare has ceased, transposed to the distant sound of splashing water and the shuffling of leaves.
Leona senses her speech is becoming slurred.  "Please do tell her I've kept my promise."
"She knows you have.  Believe me; you wouldn't want to break a promise to that little vixen."
Leona begins to suspect booth 108 is no longer to be found by any attending the fair--nor for that matter, anywhere in Atlanta.  There is no desire to ask why or wonder how; and most uncharacteristically, she has not a care in the world as to what might happen next so long as it continues.
"Place your hands upon mine and close your eyes, dear," the Cleric suggests softly.  Their hands join.  Leona's eyelids grow ever so heavy, flutter, and close.

Leona's eyes flash open; she finds herself standing amidst the fair's activities.  The suddenness of it nearly causes her to lose balance.  Beth is fast approaching with an expression of relief.  "Where have you been?" she asks sternly.
"Ah... humm, good question.  Over there, yeah, by the clothes.  That's a really good question, you know."  Completely disoriented, she scans the room for a reference point.  "I think I was over there, but I'm... not sure."
"I was all over this place," Beth sputters, "and you were not here.  I was afraid you got pissed at Art and left."
"I met a little girl... I remember now, she had wings, dragonfly wings, and we ate warm sliced pears and raspberries with whipped cream.  I think they were pears.  Anyway, speaking of children, have you seen ours lately?"
"Yes, and we may have to catch a bus home."  Beth crackles rather sternly.
"Why?"
"'Cause they may not have time to drop us off."
"What?"  Leona questions with a puzzled expression.
"I think they're going straight to the Middle East to join the crusades."
"Oh crap."
"That's it exactly! The car is so totally filled with crap, if at all, we may have to ride on the roof."
"Where did they get the money?"
"Art must have had a stash," Beth advises.  "I saw Hale too, so at least I'm sure Art didn't sell him into slavery for cash."

Gold coins flow from a hefty leather pouch splashing onto the Cleric's silver plate with a chiming sound long since forgotten on this side of the gateway.  The patter of gold brings a smile to her face and a twinkle to her eye.  "Tell me, dear lady.  Is she the House of Durer? Is she the one I seek?"
"Yes, but much more of this world than yours; certainly not one of the vagabonds who come and go to play the games.  She knows nothing of the realm, nothing.  Set her upon the throne of Durer and the child would be assassinated within a fortnight.  So, if a funeral is your wish, she may grant it."  Marwyn displays a measure of regret as the Cleric continues.  "The eastern kingdoms have much to lose if Durer regains its sovereignty.  By hook or by crook, I fear they would surely slay the girl."  The Cleric's image dissolves and her voice fades into quiet echoes.  "See that she does not take lightly the consequences of regency."  Marwyn candidly steps back through the cardboard archway into the fair's proximity.  He regrets having found his mark, a lamb to be sacrificed upon the political altar of Durer.
Elsewhere among the fair's activities, Leona, her arms tightly folded, has set aside her befuddlement of the last hour to address the prospect that the guy she is hooked up with may never grow up.  "After finals, he's crashing to earth and sorting out his priorities or flying solo--that's it.  I enjoy the games too; it lets you out of your cage for awhile to just rant and rave.  Everybody needs a little of that.  There's got to be a balance though... limits; it has no value if it reaches the level of all consuming foolishness."
A harsh standard from someone who just a moment ago was mainlining pure, uncut, 200-proof fantasy and totally seduced by it.  But then, all things are relative and there was no foolishness about it.
"Leo, I think they're all that way," Beth concludes.  "If it's not this, it's sports, or beer, or cars, or wet tee shirts; just be happy it's not another girl."
"I don't want to end up his baby sitter," Leona asserts, "someone to bounce his moods off of, like that stunt Saturday morning."
All of a sudden Leona has completely lost her friend's attention.  Beth confines Hale by a thread so fragile a spider wouldn't dare to trust it and yet so strong the average male is hopelessly bound thereby.  Although she wouldn't dream of actually doing anything that might strain it to the breaking point, she dearly loves to flirt with the opportunity, especially if Leona is near to chastise her fantasies.  The approach of a sturdy, ruggedly-handsome young man offers just such an opportunity.  She jockeys for eye contact; her impish smile, little turned up nose, and wasp of a figure are like a three-pronged frog gig.  Aha! She's caught him, or so she delights to imagine.
But Marwyn's not drawn by Beth's enticements; rather his interest is of a much higher order.  Approaching the girls with printed handouts from outside Leona's line of sight, he and Beth exchange smiles.  As her presumed victim comes closer she lights up.  "Hi! I'm Beth."  Leona turns to see what new friend has come upon the scene.  "This is my friend, Leo."
"Hi, nice to meet you ladies.  My name is Mark; I write gaming strategies aimed at college-age players."  He hands each of the girls a paper as he continues the pitch.  "Thing is, I'm required to test-market my ideas on random couples from each campus.  Fifty bucks cash per couple, if you'll give it a try."
Beth being Beth she toys with his words.  "You want to pay us to play games with you? Hummmm!"  She glances to Leona and demurs.  "That might be fun," returning her attention to Mark.  "Do we have to bring the guys?  Leo and I, that's a couple."
Mark breaks eye contact.  "Hi!" He passes handouts to several others in close proximity to give the appearance Leona is nothing more than another random customer.  "A new game, check it out," Mark advises the other supposed potential test players.  Again addressing Beth.  "Without the guys who's going to save you from my dragons?"
Pointing toward Leona, Beth advises sternly.  "She can whip any dragon you've got."
"I'll leave it to you; hope to see you both."  Mark introduces himself to another couple as they pass and merges with the crowd.
"Wonder if he likes slave girls?"
"Slave girl my ass," Leona injects.  "You're such a little witch you should get a broom."
Beth raises the bag she's carrying and giggles a little, "Got it right here and my magic wand too.  You need to know brooms are out this year; translucent fabric is much more effective."
