The girls are approaching Art's parking space to find their counterparts struggling with a jumble of freshly acquired contraband.  The problem is finding just the right way to fit a battle ax and trident into the small car and still accommodate four passengers.  Art slides the long handle of the trident into the back seat between the front passenger door and the windshield post. "Art!" Hale interrupts.
"Yeah!"

"Like under the handle; I think we can push it up some.  Don't worry she'll fit.  Then you take the other side.  We can move the front passenger seat up a notch or two."

Hale dives in behind the seat again.  Art leans over the back of the front seat to help by blocking what little light there is.  The girls are being totally ignored.  Leona can see the jewel cleverly hiding alongside a crumpled coffee cup on the pavement.  She stoops, quickly retrieving the treasure before the guys come up for air. And there's a couple more in California hosted by publishers of game manuals and video producers.  It's research for my business economics class project.  I'm thinking of maybe setting up a promotional gig."

Six hundred years away, in a manner of speaking, Mark has again come to be Marwyn, the very same fellow but for his attire.  Now having verified Leona's identity as the child sought by the inquisitors he steps before the bar to present his findings.  The Nobleman of Equity thus asserts, "What of those who harbor her, these surrogate grandparents? Surely they knew of her origin."
"Both were players of honorable standing, Milords;" Marwyn advises.  "The archives list them as slain while defending her father's city.  Yet records at the gateway show they passed to sanctuary six days after the fall of Durer.  One small chest of coin was declared; it tallied six and one third kilos all of gold.  There was also included a jewel box; the contents are listed as one necklace, one dagger, one quarter kilo of emeralds, several rings, bracelets, and a few minor trinkets.  Taken as well, a case of alchemist's preparations including poisons, three trunks of clothing and several weapons, primarily long bows.  Everything was identified as Durerish in nature."
"Clothing?"  The Judge of Sorrows echoes,  "That should have raised suspicions that something was amiss."
"It did milord.  To expatriate clothing would be unusual; the affidavit indicates the trunks were duly searched and nothing was found to be out of order.
"Durer fell twenty years past," the Lord of Consequence reminds.  "They would have been in violation of the minimum play requirements and thus, retrieved by their own kind.  Would they not?"
"The log declares twelve days later notice was received of casualties from games in progress, internal warrants, and the affair at Durer.  The two who care for the child were listed as slain; their licenses were duly retired.  Hence, they avoided the time limits established for active players who are in sanctuary.  There was no reason to back-check the records of passage against the casualty notice.  They were lost, their obligations forthwith disposed of by their presumed deaths."
"Clever!" the Nobleman of Equity freely admits with a smile, "well accomplished, these folk are not fools.  They were thought dead, banished to the archives. Hence, out of sight and far from mind.  And they obviously had no intention of ever returning."
"Their complicity is a violation that should not be tolerated," advises the Lord of Consequence in a stern tone, then clearing his throat.
"The law of limits grants them stay, milord," Marwyn reminds.  "Only should they return of their own will may a charge be served upon either of them."
"Yes, an interesting loop hole that limits stuff," the Judge of Sorrows points out with slight disdain.  "I don't approve of those clever little devices that allow some to circumvent justice.  Was this by design or the hand of fate, Marwyn?"
"Were the hand of fate their guardian there would have been no need of such considerable haste.  Great dispatch is required to travel that distance in six days.  Four fresh teams and as many drivers properly located along the way would be needed to accomplish their transport in so short a time.  If word of their demise had reached the portal first, passage would have been denied pending inquiry.  When I inquired as to how they came to be listed among the lost defenders I learned the position they were charged to defend was consumed by fire.  Such complete destruction would conveniently excuse the absence of bodies.  By design Milords, well and carefully plotted."
"Durer needs a ruler not another marionette to replace the bountiful quantity already at hand and certainly not a maiden who has  never set foot within the realm.  There is no precedent for this quandary, not even remotely.  In these times anyone claiming the city by birthright would be challenged on every principal of law, and If she did prevail, she would rule at considerable risk.  So warns the Judge of Sorrows."
"We are not empowered to place a queen in jeopardy.  Were she to return it must be of her own will and with full understanding of the perils before her.  she would have to sit under the Minnon's hammer and be judged in public.  So say I, Lord of Consequence."
"I concur.  Though by the blood Durer may be her city only a stern lad wise in our politics and willful as iron is the least that may survive.  She belongs here and being not a player has no right to remain in sanctuary, but if we force her to return I fear we would be sending this child to her death.  This we must not do... ignore the rules, leave her be.  So sayith the Nobleman of Equity."
Marwyn steps forward and bows before the tribunal.  "May I be heard, Milords?"
"Come forth lad," acknowledges the Judge of Sorrows, "your council is welcome.  That is why you are here."
"I know the world of sanctuary, though she is in the care of players she resides among common folk.  As in ours, few commoners ever step beyond their daily chores.  As to her deeds, likely there are none to know.  This is not to suggest commoners are incapable, but rather... seldom are they properly challenged.  Courage, cunning, a will of the best iron, to this add warrior, charlatan, thief, and possibly sorcerer.  Milords, what have we then? If not but a player of the Games Regal, the gladiators of our world with all the realm as their coliseum.  Every single player I've known was a commoner who rose to the challenge.  Survival depends upon how quickly one learns.  This appears more a matter of qualifications and the will to endure than of blood lines.  Test her... severely, as would the blood sport."
"Within the games?  She could be torn apart.  We would have the blood of a lawful queen on our hands."
"No, Milords, safely... within her own mind."
The Judges look to each other for a moment, then, nod a tentative approval.  "Go on, lad."
"I have arranged a trial to inquire of this young women's character.  There is a binder with significant capabilities of this sort.  Her work is very precise; the girl could be cast into an event existing solely within the boundaries of her own mind.  Once there, allowed to mix freely with characters bound to steer her a course into turmoil.  That is the field upon which your Lady of Durer may display her valor or the lack of it.
"How authentic can a dream be?" questions the Judge of Sorrows.  "I myself have experienced many foolish things within the realms of the night."
"I speak not of a dream, Milords.  It does not occur while the subject sleeps.  During the event she will feel every pain dealt to her and suffer accordingly.  It would require the participation of the Minnon, however, and the trial must occur in sanctuary.  But thus, every response will be authentic for the Minnon forbids her react in any other way.  No untruth may pass into the stone.  Even so far as to experience death itself if it comes to such end.  When all is said and done her memories will be drawn away, consigned to the Minnon's domain.  Thus, each of you may bear witness to her every deed and displeasure."
--
While Marwyn plots a course for a ship not yet fitted with sail, Leona navigates the seas of her unbound imagination elsewhere.
She sits not at the furthest reaches, but well away from the crowd of the new semester's introductory lecture.  Daydreaming as it were for lack of night with no certain destination in mind.  The professor, a stout middle-aged fellow with a good sense of humor given the dry technical aspect of his profession, addresses the new crop of students.  Seedlings as it were, about to be exposed to the harsh realities of organic chemistry
"Last year you may have thought you were studying the exquisite science of chemistry," the professor advises his new crop.  "And though characterized as such, most was merely chatter about the elements and their salts.  At year's end you departed the academic environment with a joyous feeling that the next three are going to be a breeze; 'I've got it made.'  Well ladies and gentlemen, this year we call it organic; it will be very enlightening to some and quite mystifying to others.  In these next few months we shall undertake to separate the misty from those of you who would continue.  Our interests shall focus on just a few very common simple elements: carbon, nitrogen, hydrogen, and the one none of us may do without for very long, oxygen.  A simple combination of just two forms dihydrogen monoxide, the basis of all life as we know it and covering two thirds of the planets surface.  In their pure forms one is usually a black solid and the other three invisible gases.  Strangely enough, given the proper application of heat and pressure the black one, like the gases also becomes invisible and a highly prized symbol of everlasting commitment.  So, this should be simple as dirt, right?  But no, there's a glitch, dirt you see is a immensely complicated substance.  These four elements alone account for more compounds than all the others combined several times over.  Shall we begin?" The Prof pulls down a chalkboard with the equation: C12H22O11 + CH3COOH + NaCl + CH2OH(CHOH)16CH2OH = ?
"So, let's get to it.  What do we have here? Anyone? Silence!  Come on... Don't be shy.  Surely there remains some spec of insight that has survived summer vacation?"  A dozen hands rise, "I'm encouraged." the professor points enthusiastically.  "Let's have it."
"Common table salt!"
"Okay, that was the easy one, a little something to get you started.  What else?"  All are Silent.  "That's it... nothing more?  Oh my!  The beer and sun tan lotion has washed it all away?"  The professor picks up his seating chart, raises his glasses slightly, squints a bit, then fixes his attention on Leona's apparent total lack thereof.  A day sleeper, what more suitable victim to sacrifice?
"Miss Guthrie... hello, Miss Guthrieeee... anybody there?"  Leona remains inattentive, in another world.  He wonders how she managed the previous year.  "Earth to Guthrie, Guthrie... come in Guthrie."
Leona suddenly realizes she is being addressed.  It was easy to miss after all, I mean who calls her Guthrie?  "Yes. Yes sir! I'm sorry.  Ah, what was the question again, please?"
"Hum!"  The Prof points to the equation.  "The class was wondering if this compound will explode, or at least glow in the dark.  What do you think?"
She scrutinizes the equation.  "I don't think that's going to form a compound.  No! Pretty stable, no danger of an explosion... at least under normal temperatures."  The Prof begins to perk up with some anticipation; he may have caught a live one.  "Looks like... salad dressing to me, sir."  One of the students snickers quietly; the rest are wiser.  The Prof lowers his head slightly and snaps the thumbs of both hands toward Leona with his trigger fingers extended.
"Well... let us examine the lady's conclusions.  Her first observation is correct, under normal conditions no reaction.  It will not form compounds; it is a mixture, it yields nothing new.  The second observation is also correct.  Only under high temperatures would the sugar and oil combust and not so violently as to be considered an explosion.  Read it people; salt... sugar... vinegar... and your basic vegetable oil, dressing for the young lady's salad.  For the rest of you, however, a little something to occupy your time for the next few evenings."
In due time the lecture concludes, the students are dismissed, and thoughts of salad dressing are quickly replaced with discussions of more important social issues.
The Prof intercepts Leona on her way out.  "Miss Guthrie, a moment if you please?  For someone who seems to spend most of the class period in another world you have a fine understanding of the elements."
"It's my grandfather's influence; he fancies himself an alchemist.  I learned early on that he would be pleased if I took an interest.  Some of it must have rubbed off.  And there were certain subsidies factored into my weekly allowance if I cooperated."
"He's done you a good service."
"Took a while to make the transition though, only ancient names and symbols were respected in Pap's lab.  And... you had to know how to recognize the stuff in the wild and refine it.  Oops!" Leona rushes to the apparatus on the lecture table where a flask is foaming over under the influence of a Bunsen burner.  She turns the gas off.  The Professor follows, his curiosity intrigued by the curious prospect one of his students might actually be able to identify and distill metallic salts.  "It's a practical science."  Leona continues with a coy smile.  "When I was fourteen I decomposed a five-foot stump for one of our neighbors, a big old maple." 
The professor removes his glasses.  "Decomposed?" 
"Converted to kindling, well, splinters mostly, Maple's hard, shatters like glass.  What a bang!" she proclaims enthusiastically with a sneaky smile.  "Took two days to round up our cows again 'cept the one that died of a heart attack.  Oh-boy was grandma mad!  Poor old Pap had to sleep in his lab for almost two weeks."
With a cautious reframe, "five foot high... or wide?" the Prof inquires.
"About the same both ways as I remember.  There was quite a to-do.  We just acted dumb, kept our little secret till the cops stopped coming around.  When I was finally allowed back in the garage the nitric acid and all the oxidizers were under lock and key.  Pap had three liters of mercury less about half a pound or so, but after the big bang there was not a trace to be found.  Anyway, He's kind of pushing me in this direction and it's his dime, so here I am."
After Leona exits into the stream of gaggling students the professor considers for a moment where he might be now if he'd met this young lady back in his student days, when he was a fledgling of the SDS.  Probably, he surmises, some remote federal prison!

Chapter-3

BIND THE PLAYERS TO THEIR TASK, LET THE GAME BEGIN. 

It's Friday evening and Art's compact is jammed.  Beth decided to let the guys tag along after all, particularly since Art is the only one that has a car.  The crew's on their way to beta test this supposed exciting new game and sample the all-important continuous buffet.  Hale studies Mark's handout calling out the turns as Art drives.  "Should be it right there," he advises, pointing out an upcoming driveway.
The car eases onto the approach passing between two imposing stone gateposts.  Each is topped with a cluster of lamps, unique in this day and age in that they support live flames--a peculiar yellow one at that.  This stirs Leona's curiosity as to what type of fuel is being used.  Anyone else would merely be in awe, but her background in chemistry is constantly there to provoke such curiosity and said yellow flame is not common for any fuel she is aware of.  The heavy bronze gates attached to the posts are at least twelve feet high and wide open bidding them enter onto the cobbled stone driveway approaching the house.  Enormous trees populate the grounds and a thick hedge encompasses the estate rendering it a very private place.  Weathered stone sculptures of willowy maidens complement the setting.  A splendid old Victorian surrounded by porches and topped with spires and dormers patiently awaits a hundred yards ahead.  The grand dame's windows are aglow, highlighting the smooth crowns of the driveway's worn paving blocks.  Parked alongside, a cream-colored Jaguar sedan awaits.  "I'm sure I've been out through here before," Art mentions curiously, "never saw this place--just old barns and run-down trailers."
Beveled leaded glass doors, transoms and sidelights sparkle from within too entice as though they were a gateway to another world.  Which in fact they well may be for at least one of their number this night.  An old Firebird and a new Corvette are parked in front.  One young couple has just reached the stone staircase leading up to the porch.
The girls are glad the trip is over, being as they are packed in the rear seat beneath a heap of battle accessories.  "Did you happen to notice," Leona mentions casually, "that guy wasn't wearing his armor?"
Beth concurs.  "Maybe until we meet everybody, you know, this stuff could be a little intimidating at first.  If we decide to mount an invasion later, we're ready, right?"
A jacked-up pickup that sounds as though is has straight exhausts and what seems like four sets of high beam head lamps atop the cab zooms into view.  It comes to a break-neck stop alongside the Vet.  Both of the CB antennas are flying Confederate flags.  A tall slender gal wearing a full-length black dress and preceded by a pointed chin departs from the passenger side.  She nods to Art and inquires, "Is this the place for that new game?"
"I think so," he replies with a nod.
"Thanks," she responds, "see ya!"
A big guy exits from the driver's side, flips an empty beer can into the truck bed and hails Art with a high five. "Howdy neighbor!"
"Hey, how ya doing?" Art calls out, returning the gesture in kind.  The guy latches onto his sleek lady and they head toward the porch arm in arm.
As Art opens the rear door to free Leona, a helmet rolls out.  He's quick to retrieve the wayward accessory while she attempts to free herself from their mobile armory.  Beth is wearing the seductive little outfit acquired at the fair.  To say the least, she is quite pleased with herself.
An exotic beauty of about thirty cordially greets them at the sparkling double doors.  She's tall, tan, stacked, accented with long, billowing, coal-black hair and large piercing green eyes.  The guys are impressed.  And not just because of the shoulder less, low-cut, form-fitting, white satin dress slit on one side up to her hip.  So, it must be her smile.  Beth is heartbroken in her own little way.  Even so, within the ranks of the sexy, petite, slave-girl class she has no peer.
The reception foyer seems even larger than the house itself.  Styling is that of a medieval castle with exposed structural timbers and high vaulted ceilings assembled with bolted iron plates.  The level of illumination is surprisingly adequate though not but candles are there to light the way.  Double sliding doors on either side separate the reception area from the adjacent spaces.  Those on the right are wide open and grant access to the game room; those to the left are just slightly ajar.  Before them, an extraordinary stairway rises to an interior balcony.  A svelte maiden about the size of Beth clothed in morning glory vines and carved of alabaster stands as the newel post.  The stairway and balcony are cantilevered from the walls on the backs of gargoyles who keep a watchful eye on those below.  Beneath the landing is the arched entry to an unlit hallway which simply disappears into the darkness.
Leona is drinking in every detail of the architecture, her eyes dancing about as though following the path of a whimsical butterfly.  The guys on the other hand have failed to notice anything aside from the superb architecture ever so slightly concealed, but perfectly outlined by the receptionist's beguiling attire.
"Good evening," she says softly.  "My name is Sanaia.  May I see your invitation, please?"  Art surrenders the handout provided to the girls at the fair.  She examines it and returns a smile.  "This way ladies and gentlemen."  She guides them into the game room.  "There are refreshments; please... be at home.  The game master will join you directly." Sanaia then draws the doors nearly closed and disappears into the darkened passage below the stair.
Leona hears Beth quietly complimenting Sanaia's choice of fashions.  "Darn it!"
A rare opportunity for comment this, as it's not often Beth is upstaged.  "So much for you, slave girl!" Leona whispers softly.
"You know what?" Beth retaliates.  "I saw a vampire on TV looked just like her.  I swear!  And she's not fooling me with that coiffeur either, bet ya a nickel it a wig, hair extensions at least."
"I doubt it would make any difference to the guys;" Leona assures, "she owns them both, totally, and not a drop of blood was spilt.  Is this place something else or what?"
"Yeah! No matter which way you look, something's looking back at you."
"The word for this is Gothic.  I like it."
"It's freaky; looks like the covers on some of Hale's Heavy Metal CDs."
A massive fireplace of black granite flanked by stylized six feet tall dragons dominates the game room's decor.  Large flecks of an opalescent blue material accent the polished stone.  Flames of candles, though reflected, seem to burn from somewhere within the lustrous stone itself.  The raised hearth extends four feet into the room with enough space to sleep six comfortably.  Remnants of several five foot logs smolder lazily, but for the occasional wisp of flame.  Music pervades the area, the soft tones of a minstrel's flute and the plucking of strings.  The overall atmosphere is perfect for the task at hand, the seduction of fantasy game players.
Naturally Hale has been sidetracked by the buffet.  He was thinking chips and dip with some pizza and maybe with a little luck buffalo wings, but he never imagined anything like this.  Hundreds of shrimp on an ice covered pallet, salmon, cheeses, a dozen different wines, 6 dollar a shot cordials, chocolates, pastries, an expresso machine, Swedish meat balls and deviled eggs too.  Holly shit, it's like a film set from The Great Gatsby. 
Food on the other hand is the farthest thing from Art's mind as he stares in silent amazement at the three-dimensional model of an entire kingdom which occupies most of the room.  Villages sprout along the winding roadways and two major population centers are represented, one adjacent to a fortified castle complex.  Field, forest, and watercourses are easily discerned even down to bridges.  A mountainous area borders two sides replete with watchtowers and meadows.  The model is sunken into the floor so the players have a complete overview as would be presented to the gods were they looking down upon their subjects as from Mount Olympus.
Five round tables are positioned in a semicircular fashion around the model's perimeter, each accompanied by a pair of high-backed swivel chairs.
Two silver candle holders occupy the center of each table, one held at arm's length by a knight, the other by a maiden.  No candles await their calling as yet, for the choice of flames may not be made until all have taken their seats.  Two leather bound volumes await, one for each player.  These recount the rules of the game and the laws of the land.  Laws may be broken, with proper consequence rendered to those who are caught; but the rules of the game are the master's domain, and thus, they may not.
A stone podium with Celtic designs faces the arrangement of tables completing the circle of attendees around the model.  Upon the podium a single large stout candle.
Beth abandons Leona in favor of the social activities developing near the buffet.  Leona, for the moment, seems a lost child bewildered by the wonders of an amusement park.  Our resident slave girl warms the atmosphere by introducing herself and the guys around to the other three couples.  This evening's guests appear to have been selected for maximum diversity.  Their ages being in the range from 19 to 22 appears the only common element.  The decor is stimulating considerable speculation as to what adventures the evening may hold in store.
The first couple represents the higher-bred, slightly arrogant, yuppie aspect of society; no doubt they arrived in the new Vet.  Both are fashionably dressed and sprinkled with quality accessories--or as they are known in some circles, power symbols.  The young lady's gold Rolex for example.  Or the discrete pin attached to her lapel screaming out loud of significant political affiliations.  Subtle, discreetly-placed indicators to say her status is well beyond the norm.  Her escort is square-chinned, perfectly tanned, cologned, and monogrammed.  His airs complemented among other things by an emerald-cut diamond pinkie ring rivaling most of the engagement variety.  His authoritative attitude alleviates any doubt he expects to be at least a congressman.  Hopefully they've turned off their cell phones.
Next are the punk rockers: tattooed, pierced, wild hair in hues of pink and green, the young man possessing a near-tragic desire for attention.  His lady, shy and slight of build, keeps a watchful eye on anyone who approaches.  She's holding onto her escort's little finger with the desperation of a mouse being led through a cage of glaring hawks.  Two young rebels, not entirely sure of their cause, but not ashamed to show the world they aren't the least concerned with your opinion.
The walking rebel flag has already made the crew's acquaintance, his willowy black-magic woman close beside.  An assortment of patches attesting to his proficiency at various competitive turkey shoots are displayed like war medals.  Also notable is a captain's badge of the volunteer fire brigade.  He appears the sort if not by size alone that would command the respect of men.
Everyone's flying their colors.  And Beth fits in nicely with her Helen of Troy threads.  Strangely enough Hale and Art having opted-out of their gladiator duds are the only normal, unpretentious looking individuals of the lot.
--
Except for the four prime participants each of the other player's personalities shall be blended with the attributes of a candle fashioned within the realm--some from the depths, others from the commons--thus, for each adding a pinch of spice to the buffet of challenges that lie in wait over the next few hours.  Consider though, time is a strangely relative medium.  While the hands of a clock move from hour to hour for some, for others even a moment may linger endlessly.  Indeed, one could toil forever in the blink of an eye.  Quite a few of the realm's dictates have been set aside for this evening.  Just as this world's technology is forbidden passage into the realm, neither may magic depart of it, at least not without extraordinary precautions.  Thus, many guarantees have been secured by warrants under the tribunal's seal to bring Sanaia and her trinkets unto this cause.  But then, it has always been more expensive, though of practical necessity, that the plumber visit the leaking pipe rather than for one to carry the sink to the plumber's shop?  In fact the Minnon's stone is on temporary lend from the Henzics and a detachment of security personnel are very near at hand to assure its safety and immediate return when this charade has finished.  
--
Adjacent the room of games
Resides a chamber of spells.
A space where things most common
Oft times seek to rebel.

Displaced are they to hide and wait,
This once a lair where spiders dwelled.
Tread there now they dare not
Till this night's demons have all been felled.

Long shallow tables of hemlock,
Buttressed and braced against each wall.
Great mirrors of polished silver
Just above them one and all.

Each being precisely parallel
As one dares to face the other.
That all things placed there within
Reflect endlessly one to another.

A great irregular stone
To this space has found its way.
Where thoughts are kept, bereft,
Left to languish in dismay.

A sponge to soak up the wants of men,
A space where lies may be not;
A chasm filled with the deeds of them,
A place where right from wrong is taught.

A province of artistic encounter
Where conflicts of mind are fought.
Cloistered deep there within
The place where not but truth is sought.

Unimpressive to eye and sleek to touch;
A yard in every way its measure.
A thousand times its weight of gold
Slight fraction of this treasure.

Being of substance akin to coal,
Ebony, the true color of this rock;
Thus, compressed of many a soul,
Heaped up, abandoned, left for naught.

'Tis the window of the mind,
A place where things enchanted dwell.
Hundreds of faces forged upon its surface
As those consigned to wander hell.

Each contorted and bathed in grief;
Each set within a deep relief.
Each lost to friends, all lost to love,
Everything lost as to a thief.

Each forever a slave to the Minnon,
Eternally bound by their own lies.
No less a nightmare deep beneath
Than one who's buried before he's died.

Light seeps from each there within,
From the mouths, nostrils and eyes of them.
Their souls slowly consumed,
These wretched shadows who once were men.

With memories all but withered away,
But for misdeeds yet to atone.
Purgatory personified, come to light of day.
This is a Minnon's stone.

Quietly upon an obelisk of copper it sits,
Still as a demon hiding in wait.
Burnished hues of greens and blues,
Coarse and pitted this metal's state.

Keeper of melancholy infidels,
With all the days of forever to moan.
Beyond the reach of time and place,
As now of neither blood nor bone.

Unfulfilled intentions, ever adrift,
Not rudder, nor sail, just left alone.
Cast off upon the river Styx,
This is the Minnon's home.

As seeker of truth and justice
'Tis not unlike you or I.
Though never was it born,
Nor ever shall it die.

A lens of dire conscience
Focused upward toward the sky;
Caring not of right from wrong,
But quick to sort truth from lie.

Sanaia respectfully caresses
This most impressive rock,
Then to recite unpronounceable words
That may be written not.

A light within begins to brighten
Just the slightest pale of yellows.
Then to a frightening fiery orange,
That would alarm even drunken fellows.

Soon from black as pitch to crystal clear,
As no longer defined by shape.
But, dismay not of the Minnon's charges,
For never of it's chargers has one found escape.
--
Marwyn and Sanaia stand before their imposing servant which is on lend from the Henzics to watch their guests chatter and mingle as new friends do.  The game room's occupants may be viewed from any direction.  An observer simply moves around the stone to whatever point of reference is desired as though the stone had become the game salon and the players were now there within.  Sanaia holds the invitations she's collected from their guests out to Marwyn.  Unlike most of their surroundings these are shards of physical material that actually exist.  "Evidence of this evening's deeds, better lost, do you agree?" Marwyn nods.  "To ash then, be gone," whereupon the papers combust as they fall whimsically toward the floor.  He watches respectfully as the invitations graciously accept their fate, then glances toward Sanaia.  She smiles coyly as to say, just fire, nothing to it, really!  But Marwyn has studied the dark arts and thus, appreciates just how complex initiating actuarial combustion can be.  Most magic is slight of hand or simple hypnosis and as a player of the games he has learned to tell the difference.  Fire, on the other hand is rather difficult to fake because it actually affects the physical condition of its surroundings.
She places her hands lightly upon the stone's surface.  As one might expect, the cube is warm and hums with energy.
"They to remain our guests for this evening;
your Lady of Durer a prisoner of her own keeping.
They to eat, roll the bones, and make merry all the night.
She to kill or die before the dawn's first light."
Again Marwyn nods his approval.  He then points the yuppies out to Sanaia.  "These two are the wicked ones; they shall have sovereign authority."  He retrieves a slender wooden box containing five candles, each is marked with different symbols.  Handing two to the sorceress, "for our regents to be.  And this one, the rogue, is for the big fellow.  As to his companion, the slender young lady in black, unfortunately... we have this to deal with."  Marwyn passes a silver tube to his co-conspirator.  Cautionary markings are engraved upon the metal and the cap is bound by an interlocking collar.  "Whatever of this remains at the close of our inquiry must be resealed in this same canister and returned to Lavare."
Upon touching the metal containment, Sanaia shutters.  "yes! I know of this witch, her name is forbidden.  I trust she remains beneath the stone."
"Far as I know," Marwyn consoles, "Her participation was recommended such that it had to be."
"Recommended? how curious," Sanaia proposes, "that someone would have all of our guests maimed or murdered.  Though none would realize it but for your lady of Durer.  Such an experience could have profound effects long after this charade is finished.  I fear politicks has taken a seat at our table; not your original mandate, was it?"
"I'm no less a pawn in this than she," Marwyn reminds with a smile.  "My hope is that we both might survive.  Now, as for our carefree dissidents," identifying the punk rockers, "the rosemary scented tapers, those of commoners thrust into a unique situation will suit them well.  Allow them choose as they will for better or worse.  As for the object of our inquisition, her escort and this pair of merrymakers?"  Marwyn points out Hale and Beth.  "They shall go just as they are, candles of wax, untainted."
"Her two friends" Marwyn advises, "are the pawns, very important to our inquiry; we must guide them gently into harm's way.  Their plight shall challenge our lady's character; in this she will have a cause.  What is she willing to risk, coin, or life and limb? How far will she go to preserve them?  That is our question."
"And the lad she has chosen to bed?" Sanaia adds speculatively.
"Equally so," Marwyn continues, "he is her first bastion of defense and she his charge.  Would she place her safety entirely in his hands or assist in her own preservation?  We must learn whom she values more, her friends, her paramour, or herself, and how these relationships will fare under stress.  How quickly will new friends be found and allegiances formed?  More so, to what ends will these bonds prevail or crumble under the weight of a few coins or risk of injury?  Will debts be paid and commitments honored, or avoided, cast away when their usefulness is done?  I need to know every telling sign.  Is she a liar, a beggar, a thief... commoner or queen?"
--
Leona is hard pressed to imagine wealth of this extent the result of designing games.  Everything appears genuine, the workmanship flawless, quality akin to museum standards.  Such resources are not the domain of the working class.  Either the games are a serious passion and this fellow heir to some fortune, or his agenda must be considered of dubious nature.
While everyone jabbers and feeds Leona steps back into the foyer to conduct further reconnaissance, glancing upward to the balcony then back over her shoulder before approaching the partially open doors across the foyer.  Having been properly raised--that is to say, taught to respect the privacy of others--snooping about so is a strain upon her conscience.  Peeking beyond a partially open door, however, is not nearly such an offense as turning the latch on one fully secured.  One could argue as well that to offer such an enticement is in fact an invitation a guest would be impolite to ignore.  Amazing how the mind conceives of such justifications for improper behavior.  If this Durer thing doesn't work out perhaps she should consider politics.  And so the deed is done.  Parting the doors just a little more she cautiously slips through.
Are there to be no limits to this?  Tall slender windows with thick dark wooden frames grace the far wall, each with numerous small panes of glass leaded to their tasks.  Adjacent walls are lined with cases filled of large leather-bound volumes.  Tall slender bronze creatures stand between the cases; their feet bear sharp talons extending out onto the floor.  Any who dare approach should certainly take care not to step upon them lest the beast might wake and cry out, or worse.  Their heads, well over six feet above hers, gaze downward with stern expressions.  One could think them angry at this curious interloper.  At first she thought the use of candles a gimmick to add atmosphere, but this room as well is illuminated by tall bright open flames.  The volumes appear ancient in character, probably irreplaceable, yet all are left at risk to the loyalty of these tiny fires.  Were just one to break ranks or topple, these treasures, indeed the building as well could find themselves in serious peril.
In the spell room Sanaia advises Marwyn that his inquisitive guest of honor has separated from the herd.  "Wouldn't do to have her wandering about and step through a hole in the floor," Sanaia advises.  I've cast her in the illusion of my library.  Such a curious nature could prove a fatal flaw for one about to venture into unfamiliar lands.  Should we not have a lesson then," Sanaia declares with a sly smirk, "that she may profit by it?"
For Leona curiosity is second nature; the farm where she was raised offered numerous opportunities to explore.  At the library's center a great reading stand seems somehow out of place.  The design of it is simple compared to the exquisite gothic bookcases.  This construction is of chestnut with few embellishments aside of those articulated by a crew of wood bores from sometime past.  Well worn, water-stained, and charred by fire along one side, this appears more a keepsake from some long-gone monastery.  The top has four opposing sloped platforms each supporting some musty volume.  Rising from their midst is a stout iron candle holder tarnished nearly black, but with no rust.  Two rings of shallow dishes entwined thereabout, spikes at their centers with broad slight portions of candle impaled upon each.  Curiosity draws her attention to an open volume.  Are they symbols or words? Even the strangest of Grandpa's apothecaries has not the like to behold.  Uh-oh!  Something near at hand just moved; her attention flashes upward.
An owl is perched atop the candle holder just above her; it couldn't have been there a moment before.  The noble fowl nearly close enough to touch, turns its head to greet her.  They quietly stare into each other's eyes.  Wow! is that a beautiful thing.  Though the bird is bluish gray in color with flecks of orange and beige assigned to each feather, it appears almost golden and iridescent in the soft reflected light.  Every tiny feather knowing exactly where it belongs, precisely arranged, not a ruffle nor plume out of place.  No tailor could hope to make a coat so well fitted to his customer.  And those powerful talons which so firmly grasp the metal fixture, is this a friendly petting owl, or a guard owl?  "What an exquisite creature you are," she manages quietly.
"Who... Who-Whooo!" The owl acknowledges cleverly. 
To which she replies softly, "Leona, if you must know.  I hope you won't tell."  Being caught spying, even as it were by the family pet, she concedes, it's past time to get out of Dodge.  "It has been a pleasure to make your acquaintance.  I hope you'll forgive my intrusion."  She nods respectfully and turns back toward the sliding doors.  "Ohhh shit!"
The doorway is no longer there.  It seems things both animate and otherwise simply come and go as they wish around here.  Assuming her escapade discovered she cautiously scans the room for impending disaster.  All is just as it should be except there is no exit; the room is sealed.  This is... Hummm, I know... I came through a door, right there! Crap! I've been caught, but how does this work?  Confident in her sense of direction she carefully examines the wall panels and adjacent bookcases, but everything is solid and unforgiving.
Her attention returns to the owl.  "Come on now," she whispers, "I would not have thought a splendid creature such as you the sort to hold a grudge."  She turns back toward the missing doorway. "Okay, I'm sorry, I give up!  I didn't touch anything... honest."  What is going on here?  Her attention returns once again to her new feathered acquaintance.  "Could we possibly negotiate here?  I don't have a mouse or anything handy at the moment, but I could owe you... say, a burger," she shrugs her shoulders slightly, "okay, a mouse maybe."
In the spell room, Sanaia watches Leona; she's amused at the conversation.
Marwyn intercedes, "Don't scare her off."
"I assure you that is not her state of mind.  She has taken the position, and rightly so, that your pet is somehow involved, an accomplice.  It's a good sign, for in our world as you know, those who dismiss such possibilities are fools.  We are grooming a queen here, are we not?  Her first lesson is to be more cautious than curious.  If she learns only that it will serve her well.  Besides, she started it.  Do you really know her, sir," Sanaia questions, "have you looked at all beyond the Cleric's pronouncement?  I have inquired of her studies and visited her dwelling place; do you wish to know?"  Marwyn nods somewhat reluctantly, fully aware Sanaia would not have raised the issue but for caution.  "In our world a maiden hardly need know anything aside of keeping her skirt down.  On the other hand, this young woman has been educated continuously for over fourteen years.  I would judge her knowledge of alchemy the equal if not superior to anyone within our world.  She maintains an arduous schedule of physical activities, most dealing with balance and hand to eye coordination.  Among them, a style of precision sword play akin to dancing, using not blades but far reaching daggers, something the realm has never seen.  I have also examined her personal library.  How many of here age, male or female read anything aside of text messages let alone possess a personal library?  She is studying military logistics, command philosophy, historical attack and defense strategies.  Why?  These are the treatises of conquerors not queens nor alchemists.  And her favorite pet is her horse, she can ride.  Someone is planting seeds and 'tis not turnips they intend to harvest.  She surrounds herself with all manner of polished silica lead crystals, though they seem harmless enough, I have my doubts."
Back in the library, Leona continues to plead her case.  "You'll have to trust me on this; I just need a little credit, really.  I won't let you down."
The owl's head turns slightly.  "Who-Whooo!" Leona looks in the direction of the bird's gaze.  A dimly-lit corridor now exists where there was none before.  It's long, perhaps sixty feet with only the slightest hint of light at the end to guide the way.  She knows it's not the way she entered, but other than smashing her way through a window it appears the only viable exit.  "Thank you!"  She doesn't care to add destruction of property to her rap sheet just yet.  Thus, she concedes and enters the darkened corridor.
The passage takes her to a room, virtually a mirror image of the last, but for the contents. Here as well, the corridor from which she has just entered is the only exit.
A life-sized sculpture of once polished stone takes center stage here; like the reading stand it has seen better days, much better days in fact.  The color is amber with tones of dark brown and veins of pearlescent pink.  Two armed males and one armed female are depicted; they are back to back in a last stand defense posture.
The owl soon follows, gliding through the dark passage near the floor.  Throwing its wings out and its head back it rising nearly straight upward on pure momentum to perch atop the female's shoulder.  The underside of it's wings are the purest white she has ever seen.  To observe such a maneuver on a bright moon lit night one would surely imagine they had encountered a banshee.  
Leona has come upon an armory of ancient weapons; it seems she's stepped into the Smithsonian's basement.  Some are polished and obviously so sharp they need hardly be touched to draw blood.  Others are scarred, the blades nicked, the metal pitted; patina's acquired at great expense to both their owners and victims.  Some are rendered useless, broken; the leather and bone worn and cracked, but none are dirty or rusted.  Helmets so old as to predate biblical history and shields, exquisite works so mutilated they are no longer more than memories.  Full suits of armor, customarily the centerpiece of most such gatherings, are totally absent here.  On the opposite note however, are the unique longbows.  Fashioned of successively shorter iron leaves secured with bands of bronze or silver, they are not unlike a narrow carriage spring.  A hundred kilos at least required to bend such a weapon to one's will.
The collection is not arranged according to artistic merit.  Both the exotic and the practical, all clothed of equal status, none seem to be held higher by heroic deed or noble association.  And rightly so, as the deeds of men at war are seldom obligated to an orderly intent.
As was the library, this room is a keeper of history, an archive.  These are the tools of blood letting, but to what purpose?  Who were they, defenders, invaders, or the foulest assassin?  There is energy about too, so much so that it can be felt.  A plausible presence, ghosts one could suppose, but are they the perpetrators or an accumulation of his victims.  She has forgotten the owl entirely, the library with its stoic guardians and ancient words--even the reason she ventured down the dark corridor toward this light.  The thought farthest from her mind is to leave.  So then, of what use is a door anyway?  But now as always, as every dream must end, reality comes with a soft inquiring tone.  Though she half expects this adventure to end with the sound of her alarm clock because it has to be a dream, it does not.
"There you are!"  Leona flinches, startled by Beth's familiar voice.  She is peaking through the long misplaced sliding doors.
"The door!"
"Right, what about it?"
"Just be sure you don't close those doors... okay."
"Sure! What ya up to?"  Beth enters accompanied by her never-fading, ever-radiant, little smile of curiosity.  "Whoa!  He's as weird as Art."
"No... Beth, these are real.  If Art sees this we'll have to call 911.  And I doubt he would ever be able to face all that junk he's gathered again."  Leona carefully runs her finger along the flat side of a blade, hesitating for a moment at each of several nicks and indents.  "They have souls.  These dents are their memories, their nightmares.  They are slaves who were forced to do terrible things and they know it."  Beth winces; the heavy philosophy is not typical of Leona.
"This is a private place," Leona continues, "I shouldn't have come in here.  We need to leave.  That is... if I haven't lost my way back again."
"Hey! Is that a bird?"  Beth squeaks.  Leona spins around.  Her feathered antagonist is still perched upon the shoulder of the statue's female defender.  She expected it would have disappeared at the sound of Beth's voice, but apparently it is real.  The owl cocks its head as though Beth's inquiry was an insult.
"Yes!" Marwyn's voice replies.  "His name is Ulik."
That sort of sick feeling one gets at having been caught red-handed begins to rise in Leona's stomach.  She's thankful at least that being nosy is not considered a capital offense.  Now she must prepare to be thoroughly embarrassed and duly humbled.  Creditability is a terrible thing to lose, especially with her best friends present.  Whatever! Even if it means banishment, the trip was worth it, the game couldn't possibly be as enlightening as her recent adventure.
She takes the initiative, "I'm so sorry... I'm such a nosy person."
"My pleasure to tempt you," Marwyn assures.
"You're kind.  Would I be pushing my luck--could I ask a question?"
"My knowledge of these implements is at your disposal."  Beth, not being in Marwyn's line of sight looks to Leona with that special smile implying, "I think he likes you."  Appropriately, Leona shifts to basic maidenly vocabulary.
"Chivalry! I'm honored sir, and so I shall ask two.  I see not a suit of armor?"
"These were the weapons of commoners as they say, not nobles.  In fact, it was considered disrespectful to hide in such a way from your opponent.  Armor was considered the mark of a coward, an indication one could not defend himself; and it makes it difficult to run, too.  A very important part of defense strategy, besides a good crossbowman would make a porcupine of the fellow.  Far better to take your chances and allow a bolt go all the way through than stop at the half, anchored by the armor."
Beth's expression takes on a morbid frown at such gruesome thoughts.
"Sounds like you've been there," Leona implies jokingly.
"Most activity of this sort" Marwyn assures, "was concluded before my time.  That is, I'm sure we've all had relatives who've used devices akin to these in the past."
Thus enlightened, Leona lowers her eyes with an affirmative nod.  A silent moment passes while she considers whether there's enough room to put the other foot in her mouth, too.  What the hell, she's got to know.  "The iron longbows, I've never even seen a reference to weapons of this design.  Where are they from?"
"Cereta, a city which no longer exists, at least by that name.  Do you shoot?"
"My dear grandmother was a competition archer," Leona chirps with pride.  "You know how parents make their children practice piano.  Like, they know you would rather play with your friends, but someday you'll thank them.  Well... my piano had only one string.  The musical version would have proved a more useful talent these days."
"There may be other days; perhaps we shall put you to the test. The other players are waiting.  We should begin the game."  Marwyn and Beth cross the foyer back into the game room.  Leona hesitates for a moment to reassure herself of the room's relative position.  There is only one set of sliding doors--how could they lead to two different places?  Glancing back into the armory she notes the corridor from which she had entered is no longer there.  Her attention focuses toward the owl.  Ulik's head turns to face her.  "How clever you are."
"Who... Who-Whooo!" the bird replies.  She blows a kiss toward the owl with a smile then follows the others into the game room.
Leona catches up to Marwyn, conceding in a quiet humble tone.  "Your courtesy was more than I deserved.  Thank you."
"There is no room of my house" he assures, "where milady would be a trespasser."
Leona responds to his Chivalry with a gracious nod.
The couples take their seats around the model; Beth and Leona sit adjacent to one another, naturally.  Leona leans to Beth's ear and whispers.  "Hey!  Keep your eyes open, there's something not quite right about this set up."  Beth returns her customary anti-paranoia frown.  "I'm telling ya, this is the Twilight Zone."
Sanaia now visits the tables inserting seemingly identical candles into each of the empty holders.  The waves of light seamlessly reflected from her beguiling satin posterior have completely seduced the lads.  She walks slowly, but with long strides.  The slit design of her gown allows her thigh play a seductive game of hid and seek with the gentlemen, if indeed that be their state of mind.  Even Beth is impressed though never would she admit it.  And, lest we forget, is not the task of every sorceress to beguile her victims.
With all the preparations now in place Marwyn addresses his guests.  "Good evening warriors, sorcerers and fair maidens of Atlanta.  Shall we begin?  You have gathered here to participate in a game of fantasy for which you will be paid.  My assistant has provided each of you with a candle, some a blend of fragrances to suit your particular interests in life.  Those of you who agree to this proposition... please... light your candle now."
All but one, the well-healed female with the Rolex, accommodates his request.  Without hesitation or duress all but she have bound themselves--perhaps unknowingly, but nonetheless willingly--to this evening's adventure.
She alone quietly recants to her escort.  "A blend of fragrances?  Come on, this is getting corny.  Aren't we above this sort of crap?"
"Hey, it's Friday, right?" her escort consoles.  "The alternative is another all nighter making the rounds at Bo-Ho's.  That herd is getting old; you know... it's the same politics and whining bullshit every week, just deeper.  The best they seem capable of are a few new blonde jokes."
Sanaia has detected the girl's resistance to join the plot.  Each player must willingly light their own candle.  Though their participation is critical, a reluctant player may only be enticed, never coerced.  The Sorceress has the insight to know the girl is a closet chocolate freak; and so is on the scene immediately with a sample box of Godiva chocolates.  "I have a feeling you'll like these," Sanaia assures with a smile.
"Well... isn't this nice? Thank you," the reluctant yuppie mutters quietly.  Sanaia humbly departs.
"Babe you've just been schmoozed, may as well light it up cause she's got your number and you know it.  Come on, might be fun to conquer the shit out of these farmers.  Besides, this place is cool; I want to find out who's holding this guy's mortgage."  With a sarcastic frown and a quiet moan she strikes the match, touching it to the wick, and so relents, joining this evening's conspiracy.  In the case of four of those present a blending shall occur, the creation of a hybrid.  A dubious mixture of those who have come for the evening's entertainment entwined with qualities until now restrained within the candle's spices.  Personalities cautiously extracted from the dregs of the realm itself, concealed with exotic perfumes, tempered, and held captive within the wax.  All have lent themselves as pawns to be expended in this affair, the covert certification of an heir-apparent to the House of Durer.
Sanaia approaches the podium.  "Marwyn of Cereta, advocate of the realm, your subjects are bound.  Shall I set your devices in motion?"  Marwyn nods affirmatively.  Sanaia smiles as her finger ignites the candle sitting on Marwyn's podium.  More than paraffin is being consumed by this flame as the light therefrom is not the familiar orange glow one expects, but a very bright distinct yellow.  The same tone of flame that had topped the gate posts at the driveway.  By that same touch those ominous flames have now been extinguished.
Thus, Marwyn proclaims, "I am orator, advocate, and master of this game; henceforth 'tis my vision shall be clear.  Reality... be gone from this coven for there is no longer need of thee here.  Listen well and heed my words; this is not the endeavor of chance you may have suspected, but rather one of wit and courage.  I caution you now, always seek the way home or be forever lost in this apparition.  For some this shall be an aphrodisiac, an opiate of bliss.  For others, trials of torment, more of doubt, and thus, the sooner to dismiss.  The ascending order of six white dice shall determine the weapons, spells, potions and estates at your command.  The descending order of six black dice, the extent of obligations, injuries, torments, and misfortune yet upon your back to land.  The turn of a coin shall say you remain a pair or set each upon their separate way.  Those so cast adrift their own soul to search while this charade to play."
As Marwyn speaks the yuppie fellow slowly morphs into the Noble;  a richly-dressed individual replete with an air of arrogant appropriate for those thus empowered.  His champagne glass changed now to a silver chalice in the grip of a ring encrusted hand.  Sanaia offers him two ivory cups of dice that fate may entwine his future.  Viewing then with disdain he casts them aside with a careless flick of the wrist as it were hardly of concern to one so privileged.  Arrogance is like a deep, hidden cesspool, patiently awaiting those of such temperament to step in and drown in the stench.  He is lord and master now, whom none shall defy; for the power of life and death rests in his hands and those who resist will surely die.
A wooden tray worn by the ages is offered next, a further burden to His Lordship's schedule of entertainments.  Thereupon the sorceress's deck of cards.  With scythe in hand and pensive smile upon his fleshless face the grim reaper peers out from the back of her cards.  Sanaia arrays them in a semicircle with a wave of her hand. 
The Noble challenges, "You dare to annoy me once more?  Can you not see how valuable is my time, the power I wield?  You will be summoned if and when I'm ready.  Take them away."
"Fate calls but once, milord." the Sorceress decrees sternly.  "And he insists; you will choose now or not at all."  The Noble fixes an intense gaze upon the sorceress, as much to curse as warn.  Never for a moment do his eyes stray toward the tray as he selects a card, casting it aside without a glance.  Though the players remain steadfast with each other and the model, the room's decor begins to rotate slowly.  So subtle one could mistake the illusion for the play of a candle's flickering light.
 "Every player," Marwyn continues, "including those predisposed as the cards may dictate shall enter the realm at a random location and acquire the resources thereof to secure their fate.  This, plus one coin of gold to each for their safekeeping that none unduly starve, hence, a thief to bate.  Whatever secrets you hold dear go with you now in kind.  Each of you shall remember the truths you've learned that forever may they bind.  Though hidden there deep behind your brow, that never will you know the why... the when... the where... nor how."  
  At this the yuppie female morphs into a royal Consort, an overdressed hairdo with maximum ornamentation.  Her designer duds are now layer upon layer of intricate white lace decorated as a Christmas tree with tiny sparkling sequins.  Her attention lost to the tedious business at hand as she wields a fly swatter of silver and silk.  Thus, beating the goop out of some unfortunate insect that has crossed her path.  "How wonderful," Sanaia comments, "the work you do for the benefit of humanity.  But the time is nigh, thus, it must be done that you cast your fate unto the winds."  His Lordship's consort lines all the dice up in a row, flicking them one at a time with the tip of her finger.  As might a child at play she grins as they tumble away.
Sanaia now presents her tray of final destinies.  Thereupon alights an uninvited guest, some foolhardy fly, or perhaps one with a mission milady's good character to test.  Patiently the insect waits, prancing about, teasing His Lordship's mistress.  Her focus narrows, the deed is done, she takes the bait; smashing it and thus, allows an insect decide her fate.  She picks up the card to observe her workmanship with a smile.  "Got the little bastard," she muses.  "There are far too many bugs in this world."
The sorceress smiles too, "No doubt!"
Her royal personship looks at the card and frowns, it seems her victim sacrificed itself to secure a vengeful choice.  She turns to her benefactor for consolation.  "Sweetie, I want to try again; buy me another one," she pouts.
Sanaia is quick to advise, "But why?  This is such a good choice; no need to risk any worse.  I think you've both done well, though some might think of it a curse."  With that her tray is whisked away, for yet there are others awaiting their fate to tell.  The pace of the room's decor is accelerating, beginning to dissolve in fact.
Marwyn's oratory proceeds.  "What path destiny, what trick the hand of fate, what future be it lavish or deadly lies for thee in wait.  Expect to encounter local folk of every kind you may imagine.  Form any alliance that suits your cause.  You may enslave or subvert friend or foe alike.  In this game mayhem rules the day, demons and sorcery most surely plague the night."
As Marwyn defines the participant's world a Jester emerges from where the punk lad sat.  A silly buffoon gleefully attired in bright colors with tiny silver bells attached all about his person.  He juggles the dice, then flings his hands aside, allowing them drop as though too hot to hold.  Sanaia presents her tray with a curtsy.  Stirring the cards around a bit, he places his choice between the palms of his hands.  Then sliding them aside it seems the card has vanished.  With a flick of his wrist he retrieves it from under his hat.  The sorceress offers a delighted smile in response to the young man's flirtatious alter ego not to mention his apparent understanding of what is going on and who is pulling the strings.  As Jesters do, he sings her a poetic verse, or perchance a prayer.  For the coin has parted the ways of this couple.  And though appearance would not betray his deep concern, the thought his timid young lady must go alone into this strange world has moved him to despair.
"A tisket, a tasket... a telling card from your basket, I will sing and dance for thee... please treat my lady well.  She is a creature wounded, I cannot the truth to tell, but I will bleed and die for thee, if as I implore... you treat my lady well."
"You have more than pleased me, sir," replies Sanaia; "and so this I may tell.  Be not concerned, for indeed your sweet maiden will fare safe and well."
A slight fluttering has come to the sound of Marwyn's voice; overtones of an echo might be discerned by a cautious ear.  "Weigh carefully the words of others; false prophets abound and need not a reason to lie.  Respect the wisdom of children; for it is of an innocent nature as most have not yet learned to lie.  Barter or wager as you wish any resource at any time, but heed the laws of Karife, though some you may need to remind.  Fraud, deception, and the charlatan are honorable professions in this land.  Banker, lender, and thief the same vocation; as all go hand in hand."
The timid mousy little girl with spiked pink hair melts into a carefree, provocatively attired, but somewhat ruffled Harlot.  She cups the dice in her hands and takes a deep breath, then exhales ever so slowly into their hiding place.  Sanaia gives her a sly glance, and the dice are left to fall away.  Thus, her die is cast.  The Harlot kisses the tip of her finger and blows the kiss to Sanaia.  She selects a card, hiding it within her bosom with a playful smile.  And now, being she and her mate are of one mind, she sings her song as well.
"Come visit my loft and I'll make us a pudding of rum, apples, and plumb.  We can tell each other our secrets there, about the lads who when the sun comes nigh, off they always run.  Can you tell me why?  So bold they were the night before, but now so awfully shy.  Like bats they are, so frightened when the light once more fills the sky.  They like to play and I wish they'd stay, but no.  Please... can you tell me why?"
"Your new friend will not hide from thee," Sanaia consoles, "when the new light of day appears.  But rather bid you come into the sun that both of you may play."  The Jester's plea, the Harlot's song, two sincere young lovers; for a brief moment upon their separate ways they now have gone.
The background's rotation continues to accelerate and the room darkens as Marwyn proceeds, defining the game's restraints, or rather a lack thereof.  "In a world of fantasies mark you well; for pain and pleasure are the same sensation, love and hate the same emotion, gold and sand the same element, fire and water the same potion.  Virtue wins no treasure here, patience no accord, loyalty a sign of weakness and brutal strength yields no reward."  His words take on an echo as though spoken from within some deep cavern.  A breeze begins to ruffle the guests' hair.
The macho redneck is transforming into the Tax Man, an overbearing rogue unceremoniously devouring a roast chicken.  His aluminum drink can has become a large, empty, ceramic tankard.  Hesitant to return his snack to its roost--a scorched, greasy wooden plate--he fumbles to control all the dice within a single slippery hand.  Two escape, as crickets might spring free of a child's curious restraint.  Thus, overwhelmed by the complexity of his dilemma.  He commands those remaining tumble away carelessly with an annoyed grunt, seemingly more concerned of his fowl than his fate.
The dice dispensed, Sanaia offers her tray of endless choices with cards arrayed thereabout, a further distraction to his repast, but appropriate and necessary without a doubt.  My word, is there no end of this woman's tormenting me?  He wonders, taking hold of his empty tankard and raising it forth.  "Have you not a pitcher of ale, woman?  What use are cards if there be none about to wager?  I need drink."  
"Yes, milord, I shall fill you a cup full to the brim; but first choose your fate that our game of truth and dare may begin."
The Tax Man snatches a card from her offerings.  Reading it, he winces, frowns, and flings it back upon her tray again.  Then he attempts the unpardonable, impudently reaching for another.  The sorceress's response is quick, tapping lightly the back of his hand as to say "no" with but her fingertip.  Startled, our brazen Tax Man recoils from her touch, his mirth painfully sobered by a frightful sting.  A prick not unlike having a red hot spike driven through his palm.  The delightful relationship with his defeathered fowl is now willingly abandoned for a better cause, the urgent need to comfort his seething paw.  The smart of it abates within a few heartbeats, but the memory shall linger for some time to come.
Now with the selfsame compelling finger Sanaia slides his first selection to the edge of the tray.  "Only one per customer, milord," she reminds.  Her stern expression leaves no doubt he has made his choice and shall accept the consequences of it.  Her finger impatiently taps the back of the card he'd chosen.  Knowing this not to be a contest of strength he humbly reconsiders, being very careful to avoid that wicked digit.  
The turn of the coin has separated him from his mate and 'tis well in his favor it has.  No matter how foul this lout may come to be, he would fare poorly were it not so.
A frothing tankard of ale has come magically to view.  Thus, Sanaia graciously serves it up as promised to her rowdy patron.
The pitfalls of this evening's adventure continue to echo, each word from a different direction now.  The intensity of the breeze is picking up.  One might imagine the furniture soon on its way to other places, though not a single player sees any need to express concern.  Marwyn's voice rises above the howling storm whirling about the room. "Keep your sword sharp and ready, your wits about you even as you sleep, your purse strings tightly bound and your spirit close at hand.  Lose any one of these, and you've lost them all in this imaginary land."
The redneck's lady morphs slowly into a withered Witch, sly and contemptuous her smile.  The dice drop through long bony fingers in slow motion.  They stop dead upon the table's surface without recoil, each accompanied by the distant echoing sound of a heavy door firmly slamming shut.  A hand with many rings of skulls and other evil things comes forth to choose a card.  She raises it to view as her eyes begin to glow.  A tiny demon appears upon her shoulder, its head small and pointed like a snake weaves to and fro.  She speaks in a whisper; each word ends with a hissing crackle.
"Why do you torment an old hag so?  Have you no pity?"
"Rueshaba, you're lot in life is not my doing," Sanaia replies quietly.  "I am here to another task and you have come unfortunately into it.  Neither I nor our host has bid you come to this place and you know it.  Why pretend otherwise?"
"You know my name, my real name, don't you?  Why dishonor me with this Rueshaba farce?  Call me... invoke my proper name; summon me to your side.  I will come to you; I will serve you... only you."
"I may not.  The law has avowed none may address you by any name but Rueshaba.  Were I to call you forth indeed I would be served--served as others before me, served upon a steaming platter for your dinner."
"And were I more than a candle's flame just now," The Witch threatens, "I would rend you both to flavor my broth.  You would end not a slave, but a foul-smelling juice to keep company with the slime in my feeding trough."
"Vex me not," Sanaia warns, "or I shall melt your candle with honey and clove in a silver pot and set it into a hive of yellow jacks.
Those little demons would do you right; they would gnaw on that treat for many a long day.  You've only been allowed from under your rock to add a drop of venom and the stench of carrion to our gathering.  The chains that bind you here are not mine.  You know I have not the ways.  Thus, bound you must be by another who fears you not.  The rewards of blasphemy are known to thee; cast your threats to him who has placed the seals upon your tomb."
"The day will come, dear," Rueshaba threatens.  "I like what you've done, too bad these smitten lads can not see the real you.  Do I get to choose a card?"
"No need, your fate has long since been sealed and these cards can not change that."
While Sanaia's been dealing with the shadows of demons and morons, Beth has been trying to make sense of the rules manual.  When she has to read she wears glasses.  But, as not to miss anything, she places the bridge way out on the tip of her nose so she might peek over the top.  Handily, the end of her nose is turned up a bit and thus, well suited to that function.  Totally oblivious however to her hair, blowing this way and that most violently, at times completely blocking her view.  The fabric of her skimpy outfit flutters and ripples as though about to take flight, clinging in fact to her petite frame for dear life.  She rolls the dice one at a time, observing each with some little measure of glee or disdain as though she understood the consequence.  She glances toward Hale, in conference with Art at the moment, then shyly to Sanaia begging some hint of the evolving number's meaning.  Not but a smile Sanaia's reply; she's not telling what, or where, or why.  It's a tough haul for slave girls these days; no one seems to care.  The ancient tray of dreams is presented forthwith.  Beth eyes the cards, searching for some tell-tale sign of good fortune; none are to be found.  For Beth's personal amusement and to still her obvious concerns, The grim reaper originally present there upon is now a bunny.
"The moment of truth," she declares, turning again to Hale for support.  This time, he's deep in concentration as to which of several fancy hors d'oeuvres he should sample next.  She frowns and rewards his inattentiveness with a love tap.  "Will you stop already?  This is not a pie-eating contest.  My future's in the balance here; I need a winner."  Leona chuckles at Beth's vain attempt to embarrass him, but Hale's completely shameless when food is involved.  "There are important decisions to be made," Beth demands.  Then, as has become a favorite ploy, she delegates her future to his discretion.  That way, if something goes wrong, she can always say it was his fault and require him to fix it.  "Well!  Pick a winner for me," she demands.  Hale's fast, but Sanaia is lightning quick.  She gently but firmly intercepts his hand before he can touch a card.  His effort is honest enough.  Thus, is he spared the painful reward earned by the Tax Man's arrogance.
"I am sorry; milady," Sanaia reminds softly, "but only you may choose your card."
"Oh... Okay!" Beth ponders a moment more then dainty as any southern belle chooses her fate.  The cards are again shuffled and arrange for Hale.  Beth inquires, "Is it okay if I show him mine?"
   Of the elements available to chance, this one must be set according to plan.  "Yes," Sanaia replies.  "The coin's turn has cast you two together!"
A glowing smile appears on Beth's face at the mention of together.  "And... can I see his, too?"
"Yes, you may!"
Beth's open palm with her card held between two fingers is presented forthwith.  Hale takes it and for a moment pretends to avoid his obligation to do as well.  She cocks her head slightly, as a snake would coil before the attack, then swipes his stash of treats as a gentle reminder of his implied liability.
"Hey!"  Hale surrenders the goods immediately, handing Beth his card and retrieving the ransom.  They are forever at play in this way.  Isn't love wonderful?  Hale and Beth collectively take on the appearance of a merchant couple.  Not too fancy, not too plain, nor too rich, nor poor, but just right to play at this fun little game.
To be sure the toss has declared Art and Leona a pair, even as he must be forfeit if she were to claim the seals of Durer.  How their relationship weathers the trials to come will answer inquiries now before the court.  Whereas Leona has spent her time reading the leather-bound assemblage of rules, Art's been making notes about the model's design.  Something on this order would be perfect to promote his 'Gatherings' project.  He doesn't seem concerned that it would cost forty grand, take six months to construct and require a semi to transport, he's confident he'll figure it out.
Though he cares not to let it be known, intimidated is the least that could be said of Art's present state of mind.  No tournaments or anything else out there match this level of style or preparation.  Other events he, and at times Leona have attended were always well documented in advance.  Thus, players may count on certain levels of expertise and accepted standards of offensive and defensive procedures.  In time, the tricks and traps of each become known, and the fields of battle well defined.  Research is the key; who has done what, where, and how?  He likes to play, but not in the blind.  As the rules and structure of this challenge have never been published.  It could present an embarrassing dilemma.  The beguiling sorceress patiently attends Sir Art, awaiting his choice of tickets to oblivion.  His concentration has floundered, seemingly perplexed at the choice of a card.  Meanwhile, the room's background has dissolved into a dark whirlpool of contorted shapes and glimmering blurs.  Yet not a candle's flame flickers nor a card from Sanaia's tray dare be disturbed.
Leona can see he's stalled so she does a Beth to pop him out of the trance.  "Art!  You can't choose her!  You're stuck with me tonight, dude, so just take a card."  Embarrassed at her implication, he responds immediately, knowing the quicker the better to dismiss her comment.
Lastly, Marwyn's unsuspecting guest of honor must tempt the hand of fate.  "Milady, for your consideration," Sanaia coos respectfully.  Leona casts the two sets of dice and chooses with neither fanfare nor concern.  It's just a game after all and the most one may expect to do is deal with it as intelligently as possible.  The moment she has chosen all the remaining cards are whisked away into the turmoil which attends the room.
"Thank you!" Leona responds.
"A pleasure to serve, milady."  With that the sorceress bows cordially, then stepping backward fades into the blur of what was once the game room.
Art and Leona have morphed into gypsies--colorful but cautious vagabonds of the road, venders of whatever may be concocted of nothing and sold or bartered for value.  Wheelers, dealers and tellers of fortune, though none of it need be true so long as they keep moving.  Art now has a thin dark mustache and Leona is enjoying a new toy, too, playfully twirling her long, curly, coal black hair about her trigger finger.
All the guests now set about dressed as to be off for a masquerade ball, yet none have taken exception of anything the least bit strange.  Marwyn concludes his presentation.  "These truths now declared be upon your way; for of the realm a city you may rule some day.  I would know the temper and flex your mettle may endure.  Thus, into the forge's seething flames with you Milady of Durer.

Chapter-4

EXCUSE ME SIR! CAN YOU SAY, 
IS THIS PARADISE OR PURGATORY WHERE I PLAY?

Marwyn casually waves his arms outward and his hands aside as a master of ceremonies would welcome a guest.  The hilt of a fine long sword has come into his palm.  He brings the weapon around and downward in front of him, weaving an artistic graceful pattern into the air.  But now, the design is a bit more erratic, the grip not so firm or sure.  The blade no longer a steady menacing extension of a powerful arm.  This domineering weapon is no longer commanded by the hand of Marwyn of Cereta; his image has faded.
'Tis Sir Art of Atlanta that wields it now, dancing about in an aggressive mock combat.  The confines of the candle-lit game room have dissolved into a tranquil fog-shrouded meadow.  The surrounding countryside still hidden in the early morning mist.  A pale orange glow upon the horizon does its best to light a new day.  Were there a calendar to be found it would announce the arrival of August somewhere in the mid-thirteenth century.
Reality, fantasy, how fine the plane that separates.  One merely has to close his eyes and look over his shoulder to find the other.  Know it or not, each night everyone ventures to the realm of illusions when the conscious state willingly surrenders to play at dreams, or so most dare to think.  Have you never wondered why 'tis so oft you wake with not the slightest hint of where you've been or what you've done?  Were they dreams or could you have been a player in some fantasy's game?  Can't remember?  Pity!  Might your memories have been hidden away as those of Leona's adventure shall be?  Those memories so fierce and strange, forever lost, so as not to risk insanity.  And what of those consigned, as physicians oft' excuse, to an unexplained coma?  In truth they may be prisoners of a game, you see.  One from which they have failed to escape, or chosen yet there to be.  So at least, not as we, disturbed by the constant annoyance of reality.
Art jabs and parries at the air to his own accompaniment of subdued Kung-Fu orchestrations.  He twirls about to defend his back and in so doing loses his grip on the hilt.  "Oops!"  Away it goes, conquered by the evil Knight Sir Momentum and his trusty squire gravity.  Gliding off as it were to find more reliable support in the earth.  He's quick to the rescue as minor logistical errors of this nature are better kept to oneself.  Art, you understand is not the athletic type, his idea of pumping iron is carrying two bags of groceries at the same time.  In his estimation, cleverness of thought is the equal of any rogue's muscles.  And after all, this is a virtual environment.  But then, how is that weapon so easily slipped from his grasp?  
Leona, however, is more concerned with the practical aspects of their new adventure, like breakfast.  So as she sorts through their inheritance for something eatable, Art plays with her sword--her sword mind you.  "This is so fine," he purrs.  "I can't believe you got this."
