Oh man, this is what I need.  Calling out to Leona again, "you know this is going to be too heavy for you.  I mean, you're not going to be able to handle it, not effectively.  We should trade you know; it only makes sense."
Leona silently concedes to his logic.  If there were a head-on contest, the weight of it would be her greatest enemy.  But Art, having shown his hand, has provided her a handy bargaining chip.  So much for the cleverness of thought superiority theory.
Thinking he hears a reply to his proposition, Art turns around in her direction.  Leona, totally helpless, is being dragged out of the mist into view.   Huge greenish trolls, completely enshrouded with heavy armor have hold of her from either side.  They are accompanied by several more of their kind in various sizes, but mostly larger, on either flank.  And even more sinister silhouettes slowly advance from the distant haze, some mounted upon hellish beasts.  All are carrying monstrous weapons of every devious design and they are all coming his way.  Totally stunned, his eyes are as wide as his forehead will permit and a terrible foreboding crawls up the back of his neck.  He finds himself paralyzed; his arms fall limp, barely able to keep hold of his wondrous new toy.  The blade again seeks the firmer earth at his feet for support.
Leona calls out in desperation for his help.  "Bullshit! Go find the horses," she demands.  With the sound of her voice the menacing band of monsters dissipates.  All that remains are the rustling silhouettes of trees eerily projected through the mist by the rising sun.  In his entire existence he has never felt such a relief.  The breeze offers a chill to one suddenly saturated with perspiration, but a refreshing one nonetheless.  His attention remains absolutely focused on those harmless dark shapes off in the distance.  His hand is still shaking; it seemed so real.  A good stiff cappuccino would be great right now.
Their kingdom is a horseless gypsy-style covered wagon.  All manor of junk, that is--trade goods and priceless artifacts dangle precariously thereabout.  At the moment they are stranded in a meadow about two hundred feet from a future super-highway.  Two shallow parallel ruts with a sprinkling of broken stone are the only sign of civilization.  Beyond the road the landscape drops away quickly toward a wide stream, a dense forest rises at the far bank.  The meadow, awash with blue cornflowers and the Queen Ann's lace, rises slowly behind the wagon.  Several hundred feet further it fades into what may have been a hillside orchard as the trees appear to be in rows.  Leona emerges from the rear of their mobile home cradling a burlap bag and a large wooden spoon.  "Beans, I think," she conveys with a smile.
"That's it!  For breakfast?"  She retrieves a bundle of garlic bulbs and another of dried red peppers from the side of the wagon, holding them out to Art with a smirk.  "Fart seeds with flaming vampire repellent!  That will do wonders for our social life.  Is there a refrigerator?"  Leona responds with a negative shake of her head.  "Coffee?"
"Art! We're here to play this game, right?  So don't ask dumb questions.  Go find the horses."
"What horses?"
"You need to learn how to read the signs."  Pointing toward their humble abode, she informs, "That's a horse-drawn wagon, right?  We are in the middle of nowhere.  How did it get here?"
"Magic?"
Again pointing her finger, "What about that pile of lumpy brown stuff there with all the buzzing activity?"
"I noticed that.  By the way, is there a bathroom in there?"  Again Leona shakes her head no.  "Any toilet paper?"   "I'll check it out... while you find the horses."
"You know, first thing we need to work out is a defense strategy.  Holes with pungee stakes and trip wires with alarms.  Do we have any bells, do you think, or wire?" 
"Okay!  Why fortify a position we cannot defend, in a place where we are not going to stay?"
"Well... humm, you know I--"
"You want to sleep under this wagon tonight, right?  Like, you prefer the spiders and mice to me... is that correct?"
"Come to think of it, hey... you know what else?  Are we broke?  Is there any money?"
"I get the idea we are supposed to be gypsies.  So... the money is all that stuff hanging from the sides of the wagon; think traveling salesmen.  Which brings us back to the matter of, how do we travel without horses?   You see now, how it all sort of fits together?   No horses, no traveling, no traveling, no selling, no selling, no money, no money!  We eat beans and drink rainwater.  Understand?  So, if you don't like beans go find the horses."  
"You know, if there were bandits or something horses might be handy."
"Good idea!  Tell ya what, bring the horses back and I'll trade you swords, okay?"
"Yes, that works... good deal.  Okay, I'm going to need some rope... I guess.  Did you notice any rope?"
"What am I, your inventory clerk?  There are a lot of leather straps and stuff hanging right there."  Leona points back over her shoulder.  "Sort it out, dude.  Find the money yet?"
"No!  Where?"
"Don't you remember what he said about the gold?"
"No!... Where?
"Too bad we didn't get a piece of that magic gown.
"What magic gown?"
"The one that the gal passing out the cards and candles was wearing.  I'm sure you haven't forgotten.  With a swatch of that we could rule.  Apparently it has the power to make anyone who stares at it for more than two seconds deaf, dumb and blind.  Try the leather bag dangling from your belt; nickel says it's holding our stash."
He takes hold of it.  "Coins!"  Dumping the contents into his palm, two lovely, heavy golden sovereigns emerge.
"Okay then!  We don't have to be eating beans."
"Oh, really, did I miss the grocery store?"  Leona surmises sarcastically.
"What grocery store?"
"The one we need the horses to get to.  Art, this isn't going to be like one of the tournaments; it's going to fly on the run.  A lot of valuable advice was dispensed just before we started.  I get the feeling we need to review before there's a quiz."
Every plot has its plotters and thickeners both.  This one no different than any other.  Thus, why delay?  The plot is in motion, so now let the thickening of it begin.
Were this actually a Regal Game the administrator would not dare to intervene in such matters.  As the master of such noble undertakings must swear under pain of death at the onset to fairly judge one and all.  This enterprise is not so discriminating.  When all is said and done, none will lie in their grave, face the gallows or remain chained in a dungeon wishing for their end.
But this is a test and as one would run the gauntlet, the more severe the more accurate.  Neither is it an offer to free-lancers for their service to some dangerous well-paid task, for there is only one acceptable suitor.  To apply any restraint or show favor may falsely qualify the candidate.  In fact, such err may place her life at risk.  Plot-thickening is usually accomplished with the transfer of coin in the presence of alcohol.  What place better than the wine cellar beneath the game room, or thus it would appear?
Masterly-fitted vaults of dressed stone span two rows of stout pillars that march down the center of the room.  Shallow iron candelabra hang from the center of each.  Foundations of this magnitude are hardly necessary to support a three-story Victorian; but if not, then what manner of structure really stands above?  The chamber is cool and damp with a minimum of light to better suit the permanent tenants--the arachnids, that is, those web building engineers who keep all the other insects from becoming a nuisance.  They guard row upon row of musty barrels and cobweb-covered bottles, their contents patiently waiting to be summoned for dinner.  Caution though, for fantasy is the name of this game.  Conspirators have gathered amidst these aging libations this night.  Short, stout, well-muscled gentlemen these, dressed in the finest tailored suits.  Forty years to each at least, bearded one and all, and just plain ugly.  Commonly known as trolls, or at least the equivalent, and reputed to live beneath bridges.  Some, however, have come up in the world.  This has surely been the good fortune of these three profane, unruly brothers.  Nearly indistinguishable are they aside from one who wears an eye patch and another being just the slightest bit less tall than his brothers.  This because no one possessing of a sound mind, aside from his kin, would refer to him as Shorty.  They are gathered here in a pleasant but cautious mood, mulling the prospect of being over-compensated for a simple, perhaps even enjoyable task.  Lounging around a heavy oak table, or at least those of an untrained eye would think it so.  Each afforded a tankard of aged brew and a dozen gold pieces to toy with.
Marwyn enters; all three rise immediately to greet their host.  "Good day, gentlemen."  They each nod cordially and sit.  "Please be not offended of this charade, it was a package deal."  Marwyn spreads his hands indicating their current surroundings.  "'Tis not an attempt to deceive you lads, I assure."
"A fine cellar you've conjured here," Shorty remarks, as he looks about.
Marwyn points now toward Leona who can be seen sitting opposite Art through an area where the floor of the room above has collapsed into the building's basement.  The opening has been covered with a sagging translucent cloth.  Those above perceive it as the sunken model of the Kingdom where the game is to be played.  Placed as it were to keep any of them from stepping through the hole.  "She is the one I deceive and the one you would seek out."  
The group's designated negotiator, Patch, initiates the inquiry.  "Good looking wench and a handsome sum for a simple task."
"Only if you prevail unharmed," Marwyn warns.
"How could we not?"
"Fate has granted the lad with her what appears to be a unique weapon and the Minnon has accepted it as fact, so I can not tell you what that blade is capable of.  From what I've observed, I dare say he has not the courage to wield it effectively, but he may.  
There are two bindings upon this house.  One is the deception created by Sanaia, which is what you see here, an illusion of reality limited to this space alone.  The second binds only the girl herself within the Minnon's domain where her mind play, seasoned by the others' dispositions becomes as reality. 
Whereas to accomplish my means, you gentlemen being aware of your task shall act as outside contractors and must be bound in a work separate from the other two.  You, as they, will lend your temperament to the Minnon, hence to add the element I desire to her experience.  But, your memories are yours to keep for better or worst."  Marwyn places both hands on the table leaning forward to confront the three rogues.  "Spare not the maiden, she shall have no quarter.  Do as you will.  She must appreciate the gravity of her situation."  The hirelings glance briefly with slight of smile to one another.
"A dream it may be for some," Marwyn cautions, "a nightmare for others, but your task is by design.  Thus, for you three the pains of death would remain a very unpleasant recollection.  You are paid for that risk.  As fate shall have a hand in it I may not guarantee as to the consequence.  If things go awry, it shall be your privilege to act accordingly.  You have no mandate to spare her life if her actions warrant."
Patch looks to his comrades; they each nod approval.  "Agreed!" he declares.  Marwyn nods his acceptance and exits.  The coins are gathered into a leather pouch and the three offer a hearty toast to their now absent benefactor, then another toward the ceiling to their unsuspecting victim.
Marwyn returns to the spell room to monitor the game through Leona's eyes.  Sanaia casts a disapproving glance in his direction.  He knows she is aware of what has just transpired; this is not a lady from whom one may keep secrets.  "Better she is tormented in a dream," Marwyn offers in defense, "than granted a kingdom and lose her head."
"I understand," the sorceress assures.  "The task assigned you is not of a common nature.  Whatever the outcome, I sense the girl would not hold the means against you, though surely, were she ever to know, she may protest."
"I never imagined sponsoring activities of such lofty concern would be my lot.  I am but a player of the games that found concern of their meaning and took my leave.  This may not be her world, but she is safe here.  I cannot warrant to her future in ours and I prefer not to have her blood on my hands.  If she is to go, there shall be no doubt she has earned her passage."
Light of day has all but left the meadow where Sir Art and Lady Leona currently reside.  Most of the time has been spent taking stock of their newly acquired estate.  Clothing, blankets, rice to complement their hefty supply of beans, tea, a cabinet of potions, one finely tooled saddle and several crocks of wine and olive oil form the basics.  The cash-only department includes a few tools, some chain, a fair quantity of leather straps, nails, an assortment of harness-related fittings and a sizable stock of spices.  These likely meant for the blending of snake oils, invigorating potions and cure-alls suitable for the supposed curing of everything from the sniffles to full blown insanity.
Their primary stock of tradables--a great assortment of pots and pans--dangle from every available space about the wagon's exterior.  'Tis a wondrous assembly of odds and ends and every item as practical as a match, though not a single one of those is to be found.  Ah yes!  And a treasure, too; a small wooden box with fancy latches hidden beneath a collapsible bench.  Therein, two silver rings, a necklace fashioned of old coins, several copper hairpins, a collection of river pearls, some seashells and a dozen or so brass buttons.  Nothing to brag about you understand, but a treasure nonetheless.  For who among the country folk of this day and age would not care to possess it?
     This rolling five-and-dime was not meant to sneak up on anybody; in fact, it might be the original mass telemarketing device.  For such a clatter would rise from the wagon's movement along a country lane so as to announce their arrival well an hour in advance.
Art has managed to track down and retrieve one of their horses.  In fact, it found him wondering in the woods and knew better the way home than did he.  Many hugs and kisses his reward, at least thus far, and though based primarily upon his firm declaration to search far and wide for the other come first light.  The consensus being that even on level ground, surely at least two are required to drag this strip mall-on-wheels around.  By stating his willingness to search for the other he's avoided any discussion as to whether Leona had used the singular or plural when the weapon's bargain was proposed.  And she being as clever as any barrister when it comes to saying exactly what she meant.  But once said, though just as sure to stand absolutely behind her word and thereafter impossible to dissuade.  Besides, half a sword would be of little use so she has advanced him credit on the unsecured portion.
Thus, ends a relatively uneventful day without dragons to slay nor a fortress to scale, and much to Art's dismay no real treasure to plunder.  Sanaia's spell has been flawlessly executed thus far for neither subject has detected the obvious, that the other players and the game room are gone.  From Leona's point of view it has been near perfect.  And now, with the sun resting somewhere beyond the horizon, even better.  The night sky is sublime, more intense than any she has ever seen in northern Georgia.  Neither muddled with the restless haze which accompanies civilization nor diminished by reflections of extraneous light.
Crickets, tree toads, whippoorwills play to a choir of katydids as a great symphony without a conductor, seemingly random and still perfectly orchestrated.  An exquisite rendition of silence come to life; each tiny living instrument singing its heart out for no cause less noble than finding a mate.
And so the game's greatest temptation begins to play upon her thoughts.  Why have so many consigned themselves to Purgatory? she reflects quietly.  Crammed into the population hives where the buzzing is enough to drive a bee crazy--transitional zones between here and Hades where happiness is owning things solely for the purpose of telling others you have one, or better yet the latest one.  Tormenting oneself in a place where automobiles are reincarnated as self-propelled boom boxes, their owners akin to religious fanatics?  Sad souls, who feel it is their right, duty and holy mission to spread the word.  Never mind how offensive or distasteful those they have perceived to be uninformed may find it.  A world where there exists no shelter from the constant bombardment that declares "you need one of these."  And the greatest concerns are whether one's cell phone battery will last the day, how many calories are in that $4.00 cup of designer coffee or where can I cop a pill to make it all go away.  She's thankful, that when the need arises in the real world she can at least retreat to her grandparents' farm to find ever so lovely quiet.  And thankful now, to lie contentedly snuggled up in Art's embrace.  Why has all this been hidden until now?
Art concedes, "This isn't exactly what I expected."
"It will do.  But, the first order of business is to find another horse; otherwise we're stuck."  Leona reminds, "First thing in the morning, right?"
"Find another horse, right," Art echoes.  "Somewhere in the back of his mind he knows this wayward steed is going to ride his ass into the ground before all is done.  "Anything else?"
"Yeah, I wish I knew how that owl changed the library and made it seem as though it never really happened."
"What library?"
"Never mind," she concedes with a grandiose yawn.  "I wonder what Beth and Hale are up to?"
--
Enjoying the serenity of the local countryside does not seem to have been their lot as well.  A disheveled Beth struggles admirably to support Hale.  They are being prodded along a narrow filthy stone passageway by several dungeon associates, each equipped of a torch and mace.  This, not to be confused with the spraying variety, but rather the standard issue cast-iron head of four dull opposing spikes situated upon a stout oak baton.  Our thrill-seekers have had their ankles shackled and shoes confiscated.  Thus, they may fully appreciate the mixture of bugs, sharp little stones and slurpy stuff covering the floor.  The air is hardly breathable, abiding somewhere between the poorly tuned exhaust of an old diesel pickup and a septic tank vent.  Hale's leg is braced with splints lashed with strips of cloth above and below the knee.  The young man is in serious discomfort, thus, he's moving very cautiously.  One of their escorts shoves the pair aside as they arrive at a heavy wooden door.  As not to be thought less than a gentleman, he removes the restraining pin and flings the door open for the new arrivals.  Alas, the charade is up when he breaks wind foul enough to clear the passage by force alone.
"Hang on, I think we're home."  Beth implies, in an attempt to raise Hale's spirits.  
The other security affiliate thrusts his torch into the black void; he waves it back and forth violently as though to impede any who might attempt to rush forward.  Several rats make a hasty exit between his legs.  Startled expressions appear upon the tormented faces that emerge in the dim light, then retreat sorrowfully back whence they came.  The first guard starts prodding Hale in the back with his mace.
"Okay, no problem!" Beth intercedes," We're going."  They advance meekly into the pitch black as the door slams shut behind.  Both turn to watch the flickering light from beyond the barred window fade to black as the guards retreat to more pleasant surroundings.
Shufflings and breathings are becoming evident from different directions within the space.  Then a phlegm-expelling cough confirms absolutely that they did not get a private suite.  Beth begins the negotiations, her tone just above a whisper.  "Hi!"
To which the duly elected neighborhood welcoming committee chairman replies, "Thems that dies is put aside da door ta be took aways quick.  Best ta get'im out soon as ya can no matter how good a friend day was.  There's a hole behind da door for your business and don't be thinking ya kun get out through there.  Last one tried got stuck fur a week fur they hooked him out... what da rats didn't finish.  Gets real bad when some'ums wedged in dare.
Water bucket comes round twice a day, drink all ya kun case there's times when day furget ta come 'round fur a while."
Beth probably didn't need to know all the details just yet, and it seems no one remembered to bring the freshly baked chocolate chip cookies either.  "Wow... welcome to the tomb of gloom, hon," she mutters quietly, before getting back to business.  "How many are in here, please?"  
"With yun's, three hands and two... eer three now.  Cog, did Ep die?"
"Yep!" a gruffy voice replies.
"Two den, wit' yun's."
"Hale?" Beth advises sarcastically.  "I thought only Catholics ended up in places like this."
"Waud ya do?" comes another voice from the darkness.
"Some guys were beating on my guy," Beth responds.  "I found I had the need to express my objections, so I hit one... with a shovel... on the head."
Aside from the shuffling and mumbling, some pretty serious coughing and wheezing is coming from one area in particular.
"Could someone help that person?  I think he needs some water."
"Ain't none!  'Sides, shoulda died by now, but 'ee just won't."
"Hon," Hale ventures.  "I don't mean to be rude, but I have got to sit down."
"Ya still standing lad?"
"Dis ain't the king's court.  Sit ya down."
"I can't see anything; I don't want to get in someone else's spot."
"Takes a time ta get uset ta it.  Walk ta my voice, come on... little furder... good, ya kun sit dar, nutten ta stumble on."
Hale and Beth cling to each other as they settle into the straw.  "Thank you, appreciate it."
"So dearie, this goon ya whacked, was'e wearing a bright color round is arm, was'e?
"White, no, maybe yellow; I'm not sure now."
"Yellow," Hale clarifies, "two on each sleeve."
"Ohhh! Ya clubbed a good un.  If I had a pitcher I'd pour ya a pint, I would, fur wacken natten."
"Must'ave well-ta-do friends ta get ya here safe after dat," a new voice proclaims.
"Safe!" Beth echoes.
"Be asking a heavy purse fur yuns, I'd wager."
"We don't know anyone around here."
"If that be true, I'd keep it hid."
"Unless you count Art and Leo," Beth continues.  "And who knows where they are?"
--
Thus, while Beth and Hale acquaint themselves with the hip local underground scene, out in the meadow, the first rays of sun slip through the wagon's curtains to tease those sleeping within.  Bird songs arise adding their consent to a new day's beginning and advising those not soon to join in that they are wasting their lives away.
Art and Leona lay sleeping amidst a heap of disorderly blankets and clothing.  From without, the whimsical melody of a flute comes to invade their nest.  In a fantasy, as this must be thought, one could easily excuse it as harmless background diversion.  However, accompanied by the crunching sounds of foot traffic upon a path strewn with twigs it becomes a matter of considerably higher priority.  Let the game begin!
Leona's eyes flash wide open.  She sits up and begins whacking Art on the shoulder repeatedly--this while trying to stabilize her position among the disarray and get a look through one of the tiny windows.
"Holy shit!  Art... Art... somebody's coming!"
"Huh, what?"
"We've got company!  Get it in gear."
Art pops up wide awake.  "What?  Crap!  Where's my sword?"
"I didn't say we were under attack," Leona reminds, "just get your pants on."
An entourage is approaching their camp site.  Two guards with lances flying gray banners with blue stripes are followed by an ornate cab.  The vehicle is fitted with a large window across the front and smaller ones within the doors on either side.  This medieval ATV glides along on a gilded wooden framework and the ultimate suspension system of its day: eight husky servants all of whom carry swords.  Several chests, baskets and a couple of fine-looking hams accompany on a shaded open platform just behind the cab.
Prancing alongside, a musician plays the panpipes; he is armed as well and to no minor degree.  Light of foot, too, for one so muscular.  The cab is followed by two rear guards and an Old Woman in shackles.  She is chained to the belts of both guards.  Though not appearing as much of a threat, the arrangement would allow them to hold her at bay between them.  Bringing up the rear are several loaded pack mules escorted by more unarmed males.  All the armed attendants wear matching clothing and doodads.  Certainly there is no interest in keeping a low profile.  One could imagine the cab's occupants to be local movie producers on their way to a gala premier.  Their manually transported cab in lieu of a horse drawn coach some manner of status symbol, the local equivalent of a stretch limo.
Given the approximate time frame of the game, Leona knows this is a man's world.  She chooses to stay out of the picture while introductions and inquiries are made by her trusty head of security.  Art's task is to learn how far off and in which direction one might travel to reach the area's nearest population center.  Thus, she sets herself upon a stump near the wagon.  So as to appear disinterested and taking the opportunity to examine her newly acquired weapons system.  The sword is short and double-edged, akin to those associated with the legions of Roman.  Thus, easily handled especially in close quarters.  Though not rusted, it is discolored, severely pitted and nicked on both edges.  The leather thong bound about the hilt is unraveling.  Best of all, it's as dull as a stick, more of a pry bar than a weapon.  At best something one might employ to clear brush or split kindling.  She drives one edge into an adjacent stump and begins stroking the blade with a flat stone in an effort to create some semblance of a cutting edge. 
Art approaches the oncoming procession with a friendly wave and matching attitude.  He attempts to engage the forward guard.  "Hi!  Nice day, don't you agree?"  Neither the guards or servants so much as glance in his direction.  He can see there are two occupants in the cab, both male, and neither one seems to have any interest in making his acquaintance.  One is a pudgy Snob in his 50's, fancily attired with gold threads and plenty of Rolex quality trinkets.  The other, a Pious looking bearded fellow wearing a monocle and fine robes of dark hues.  Art can't help but to think Laurel and Hardy have finally made it really big.
Art does a half-hearted bow as the cab passes.  He then turns his efforts toward the Musician who is trotting along at the same pace providing music.  "Nice tune, may I say.  By the way, how far would it be to the nearest village?"  It's as though no one can even see him.  Yet, when he tries to bypass the entertainment and approach the cab, the Musician is quick to block his advance.  A discreet FBI sort of character with the responsibility of keeping local riffraff and autograph hounds from annoying the VIPs.
Pious gives Art the evil monocle and then glances toward the wagon.  Something interesting catches his eye; as Leona strokes the tarnished blade he can see bright white sparks dance into the air then accelerate skyward.  Removing his lens piece, he again observes the peasant girl's toiling.  The fire is only apparent when observed through the monocle and thus concludes these ignorant dotes may possess something of legendary qualities.
Confiding quietly to Snob as he passes the monocle, "Watch the maiden, sire, through the wizard's eye."  Snob holds it up to his line of sight and views Leona's activities.  "See the fire that seeks the sky?  I think it Clovin, milord.  She toys with a king's ransom."
Snob pulls a lever inside the cab; a gong on the exterior chimes.  All but the old woman comes to an immediate halt.  A second chime and the servants carefully lower the cab onto its feet.
When Leona realizes they are going to stop, a thought flashes by; she needs something to offer as refreshment.  'Tis after all, however minuscule, the thought that counts and such a courtesy would tend to create a tiny, yet perhaps valuable obligation.  She lays the sharpening stone aside and slips around the back of the wagon to search out there meager supply of wine and as many cups as may be found.  Hopefully it is still wine and not vinegar.
Art approaches the cab, but the Musician dances about as before blocking his path.  The two forward guards move to flanking positions at the door of the cab; one then opens it with a respectful bow.
Snob and Pious exit; Snob waves his hand and the servants break formation.  Several turn away and relieve themselves, the remainder gathering at a barrel strapped to one of the pack mules to drink.  A nicely padded bench is brought forward from the platform and positioned to accommodate the VIPs' all important posteriors.  As Pious motions for this anxious peasant to come forward the Musician conveniently steps aside.  Art advances and begins to extend a handshake, but catches himself, sweeping his arm aside such that the movement is incorporated into a gracious bow.
Pious inquires.  "Are you of this city, sir?"
"Ah... no, we're from out of town, Atlanta."
"Atlantis... yes... the prophets of Lecia have spoken of that wondrous place.  A perilous voyage, I imagine; your mission is surely of great importance."
"Nothing special," Art concludes.  "Just a short vacation."  The small talk soon turns to schmoozing, and while Leona searches for cups a deal is cut.
She returns with a tray, a large gray crock of wine and an assortment of cups and wooden goblets.  Her mission, to indenture their guests to a favor, quickly sours.  Her sword has gone missing from the stump where it was just moments ago.  She looks toward the activities.  Snob is holding the weapon; he passes it to Pious who examines the blade with his magical monocle.  Pious nods; Snob hands Art a dagger.  Leona can imagine what has just occurred; fuming nitric acid would be as iced cherry Kool-Aid compared to her current disposition.  With odds in excess of ten to one, neither rage nor indignation is the proper approach for this situation.  Hence, a ladies most effective attack strategy, a glowing smile to breach their defenses.
Snob notices that Leona is heading their way and protests to Art.  "Your woman is coming.  She has no business with us; send her away."
Art turns with some concern, rushing to intercept Leona.  He knows he has pushed his luck.  "Check this out," he entreats in hushed tones, showing her the dagger.  The sheath is beautifully worked silver including several gems set into the designs; the pummel and quillons of solid gold, or so it appears, and set with three large topaz.  "Do you believe this?  Feel the weight.  He collects old knives; we're going to trade."
"You already have... more than you know."
"Oh shit! Leo, listen Leo we--"
Leona saunters past Art on a beeline line toward Snob and Pious.  A disarming smile and a light bounce to her step, who would imagine she has larceny in her heart and retribution on her mind?  The game has begun, her sovereignty has been challenged.  This pair of scoundrels has set the pace; and this Georgia peach shall not be made the fool.
"Good sirs, we so appreciate your patronage.  There is a charming secret, too, something very special of which my man is unaware."  Her tone is sweet as honey; fortunately they consider not the cost of gathering honey from bees that do not wish to part with it nor take note of the fire her eyes.  "The hilt, let me show you how it works."  Leona takes hold of the blade's very tip at arm's length with her left hand, giving it a delicate innocent twist.  The hilt is filthy and Snob does not relish the touch of it.  He relaxes his grip; a light tug and it is free of his hand.  It happens quickly; cautious Pious is too late to warn.  Everyone's attention is fixed on the sword.  She steps quickly backward, flips the blade and grasps the hilt.  All are taken aback by the aggressive action; priorities have suddenly shifted.  "The special thing is that it's mine, you ass, thus now I swear it shall never leave my side again."
Snob is astounded by Leona's uncommonly aggressive behavior.  He rises to his feet and asserts his claim.  "The bargain is sealed, the weapon is mine.  Return it now or spend the rest of your days tending latrines, if you're lucky."
"Sit or I'll have your head as well." she commands loudly.
Pious is quick to take hold of his master's tunic and tug downward.  "Please Milord," he implores quietly. 
Art is in a silent panic; he has no idea which way to go or how to negotiate such a volatile situation on the run.  Leona has effectively committed them against four guards and a dozen armed servants, any one twice his size.  All he has to his defense is the fancy dagger.  He dare not so much as remove the blade from its sheath for fear of instigating an all out attack.  The Servants and Guards are moving toward the confrontation, some reaching for their hardware.
Leona, now with both hands firmly upon the hilt, advances toward Snob.  "Bid them stay," she advises.   "A ragged blade makes for a foul cut and I'll have both your throats before all's done."  Both are helplessly seated, easily within her reach and retreat is blocked by the bench just behind them.  The flanking guards carry long lances, effective against charging horsemen but useless in such close quarters.  Pious fears before any could step back far enough to lower their blades and address her threat noble blood would be flowing in abundance.
At such close range, armed and cocked as she is, the use of magic could prove a devastating error of judgment to his master's good health.  Hence, he accepts they are lost to her discretion.  "Hold!" he exclaims, extending both arms with the palms outward, essentially relieving Snob of command and orders their security force to stand down.  
Art attempts to come to their assistance.  "Leona, honey... please!  Everybody here would like to be friends."  He turns to Snob.  "She just wants attention; you know how they are sometimes."  Very poor choice of words; Leona shoots him a glance which could be loosely interpreted as eat shit and die.
Snob has never been within reach of an armed adversary; he pursues a fool's defense, talking past Leona as though Art still had some measure of control.  "Return to me that which is rightfully mine," he demands.  "Then beat her, or I shall have you both slain."  Pious cringes.  Adding insult to injury is not going to stay this maiden's hand; for were it so, they would not be facing her wrath in the first place.
She counters his arrogance with diplomacy.  "A lawful trade there shall not be when the items exchanged belong not to thee.  So sayith Karife's book.  The weapon was not his to barter.  It was mine and it remains so until I discharge it.  Do you abide?"
Pious intercedes as council for Snob.  "A wife owns nothing; all her possessions are at her husband's convenience, therefore, the weapon is his lawful property.  His acceptance of the dagger binds the exchange."
"That ass, my husband... no way!" she assures with contempt.  "That which is mine, is mine.  That which is his, is his.  Do you abide of Karife's laws?  Deny me and seal your fate or concede and have done with this foolishness."
Pious is becoming concerned of Leona's references, not to mention her unyielding defiance against such odds.  Something is not as it should be; logic would forbid such disdain and country maidens certainly do not quote the laws of the land.  Also, he fears his master may be arrogant enough to order an engagement that cannot but lay them both to waste.  "Dear girl, milord and I must confer in private.  Surely you would not object if we step back to the coach for a moment?"
"You shall stay where you are or I will make two of you only each half as tall.  You may turn away from my sight.  That's as private as it's going to get."
An unhappy Snob and thankful Pious turn toward each other.  Pious adds a measure of privacy by raising a hand to the side of his mouth as he whispers into his master's ear.  "You must recant, milord.  I fear this a test we dare not fail.  No common wench recites Karife's laws.  She is steadfast, milord; there is no fear nor doubt in her eyes.  She means to have you with the first strike at any cost."
 A seemingly endless silence passes before Snob turns to face his antagonist.
She again demands he concede.  "Do you abide, sir?"
Snob offers a reluctant nod.
"With that, I presume you acknowledge my right to settlement."
Snob turns to Pious in total amazement.  "Settlement... settlement!"  Snob is beginning to change color.  "This arrogant wench would have service of me?"
Pious motions again, indicating another brief conference is required.  As they turn away from Leona, Pious places a comforting arm around Snob and again quietly guides his thoughts.  "Milord, at times it is the most bitter tonic which cures one's ill.  If this be a test of your obedience to the laws, if she is an agent of the court, a legion of troops may await her signal.  I beseech you, do not falter now."
Again they turn to face this unrelenting demon cast into their path.  Pious acknowledges her rights, presenting himself, though still seated, with a gracious bow.  "Milord and master would hear your demands."
"Three flasks of wine, a basket of bread, one of your finest hams, half of any cheese you may possess, my foolish friend's pardon and the old woman's freedom."
Snob is noticeably annoyed, but Pious carries on the negotiations.  "As you will, milady!"  Pious nudges his disgruntled patron and Snob grunts in agreement.
His oath thus proclaimed for all to witness, she backs away from the confrontation.  Art is summoned with a few wiggles of her "come here now" finger.  He promptly steps forth, whereupon she quietly confides.  "Return the gentleman's knife.  Then walk, don't run!  Walk to the wagon and get your sword.  Come back here and stand beside me so we look like a team."  Art graciously returns the knife to Pious with neither a word nor eye contact.
The forfeit provisions are carried to the gypsy wagon by Snob's servants.  They grumble quietly of what choices they would have made were they in Snob's position.  Leona has backed off several yards, discouraging any attempt to outflank and blind-side her.  The iron collar about the old woman's neck is unlocked and her chains fall away.  She strolls toward her champion with somewhat of a limp, but her head is held high and she's smiling.  The old gal sits herself down contentedly in the grass with a huff.  Art has returned to Leona's position.  He's sort of slouched over, leaning on the hilt of his sword, the point of which is sinking into the ground under his weight.
"Get with it," Leona advises quietly.  "We're at ten-to-one here!  Are you trying to invite retaliation?   Stand up, take hold of the weapon with both hands, lay the blade on your shoulder and spread your feet, you know, like for balance.  Try to look menacing, will ya?" she adds with a growl.
The bested shysters hop back into their limo.  The entourage reforms and we have liftoff.  Snob floors the accelerator, perhaps hoping a quick exit may leave the memory of his foolishness behind.
Nothing like an adrenaline rush to supplement the appetite.  Although the quality of the wine would be better appreciated by a true connoisseur, the fact they have it at all cries aloud, round one is theirs.  Some ice would have been a nice touch, though.  The old woman grins from ear to ear as she cuddles a thick blanket and looks with anticipation at a full plate of steaming rice, spicy peppers and ham.  And of all things, a cup of wine, too.  "Tings can sure change quick," she suggests in the quaint tiny voice reserved only for grandmothers.  "U'm sure my head could spin right off."
"Around here I'm sure it could, literally," Leona agrees, directing her sarcasm toward Art with a solemn glance.  "We may have gotten very close to that exact possibility this morning."  The old girl has a wonderful sense of free spirit.  Several sprigs of a plant with tiny blue flowers are entwined within her long matted gray hair.  Slight of build is she, a hundred pounds at best including her heavy woolen smock.  Weathered and rosy her face, with eyes exceedingly bright for one of such years.  Leona introduces Art and herself, then asks, "by what name are you called?"
She looks up to Leona with a bit of embarrassment.  "Most calls me brier patch 'cause dats where I live.  Never had need of a name 'cause I was mom's only one, always knew when she called had ta be me she was needing."  Her limp draws attention to what appears a nasty bite just above her ankle.  "Day set da dogs on me or da'ed never got me."  Leona tends the abrasion; the skin's been broken in several places, but it has healed over nicely.
Leona fetches a small cabinet of what might be medications from the wagon.  "These may help, but I'm not sure.  Can you tell what any of them are for?"  Their new consultant identifies most from their scent and appearance, including one poison.  "Where were they taking you?"
"Some deep hole wit a heavy stone on top; U'm not sure where.  I was accused, folk 'cross da valley was having dare chickens carried off.  Dare's foxes in da wood, un some don't keep a watch on'um, letum loose ta run 'round pecking at things.  Ya gotta have a pen if ya gonna have dem birds, or da foxes ull sure have'um.  Butt da foxes are too smart fur'em.  Can't catch'um, butt ya cun catch me.  Dare's a lady fox with a litter, she's under da stump at da edge of my garden patch.  So ya see, ain't no wabbits coming round ta botter my beans and squash.  Her pups are so pretty, but they got ta eat un they don't care fur grass much.  Well doz folks dat couldn't keep dare chickens, day come 'round cusing un found some fetters.  I don't keep dem kinda birds, too messy, un I don't fancy eggs.  So day said musta been me was doing it.  Put me in da village cage fur tree days long till da magistrate came ta gatter me up."
"They must have thought you a great risk for all the care they took to keep you."
"Day's afraid I'd bit'em un I wooda too!  With two ta pull on ya like dat day cun keep ya from get'en at'em.
Leona could not keep from chuckling a bit at her matter-of-fact fearless attitude.  "Can you tell us where we are?  I mean more like where are other things from here--which way to go?"
"Yep!  I bin all over da place."
With quill and ink upon scraps of leather, Art sets about drafting a map of the roadways and watercourses crossing the area.  Under their guest's tutelage, villages and way stops are added with notations as to which are friendly and those to avoid. 
"One more thing Art," Leona advises, "the sun.  It rose there," she points, "and it's here now.  Tonight we add the setting position and a line to show direction of movement and we're in business."
"Um so tired," the old gal says with a yawn.  "Kun I take a nap, if ya please?" 
"Sure," Leona points.  "The wagon is a bit untidy, but--"
"Dis a good spot!  Iddle do fine, un da suns nice un warm."  She curls into a ball with the blanket; snuggling down in between several large thick tufts of grass and dozes off almost instantly.
"You believe that?  Thinks she's a rabbit."  Art takes Leona aside for a high-level strategy conference.  "Not to change the subject here, but you could have got us wiped out with that move this morning.  And that 'abide by the book' stuff, what was that about?"
"I was referring to the laws of this realm.  What laws you may wonder?" Leona reminds somewhat sarcastically.  "The ones printed in those fancy leather binders we were given.  Oh, those, remember?"
"So, they couldn't touch us?"  Art responds with a questioning glance.
"I didn't notice the game master loitering in the area nor do I have my cell, do you?  So 911 wasn't an option was it?"
"What do you mean?"
"There's no one out here that I know of to enforce the rules; I was bluffing.  He knew he had to follow rules.  Otherwise he would have sent his crew to take what he wanted in the first place, not trade.  Apparently the powers that be around here are familiar with the theory of entrapment.  Their doubt was our edge.  But what if they had called me on it?  Your defense strategy--was that it propped up against the wagon?  I won't remind you where your head must have been."
"Yea, but you jumped right in his face," Art reminds grimly.  "Like you wanted to play chicken with a semi and your head lights turned off."
"No! I was playing a serious game of chess.  You know how that works, right?  Put a knife to the kings throat and your in charge regardless of his resources.  When someone says check, the only option is to stay the attack, a counter attack means nothing even if you can check the other king because next move it's over.  The king in pearl must defend at all costs just like in real life.  Trouble is, sometimes in real life you run into a psycho or religious nut, then you gotta go off book.  If I had stepped back rather than forward the next move would have gone to puggie and we would have been finished on the spot, game over!  Fortunately the skinny guy was rational enough to control the other whom I suspect was a border line fool.  If he had ordered an attack I would have whacked him and bet the farm the skinny guy had enough authority to control the troops.  I really wasn't sure who was in charge of what; but it's a good bet the most arrogant one is top dog."
"I was trying to supplement our net value.  That knife was worth a fortune.  We could have rented a small army."
"Right, what are you starting, an IRA?  And in the meantime I should strap a skillet on my belt and carry a brick?  Are we here to win this or just as fodder for the machines?  'Cause that's where we're headed if you trade the weapons for trinkets."
Art starts to fidget like he's developing a case of hives.  "This just isn't stirring me up.  There should be more magic and powerful forces, ya know?"
"Art!  We just stood down fourteen armed men under the command of a frustrated dictator and his legal goon.  Not one drop of blood was spent... and we won a ham.  There's got to be some magic in there somewhere.  Give it a chance will you?  Even Genghis Kahn started out in a hut.  I'm going to stay with her.  What she knows about this area is the most valuable resource we have--except maybe the horse.  You do remember the agenda we established last evening, do you not?"
"She's liable to sleep all day," Art proposes.
"So! No telling how long they were dragging her around out there.  When she comes around I'll learn whatever else I can.  Meantime, there are things to sort out, like why was that turd trying to scam my knife.
"I still think that guy was on the level," Art rebuffs, "we threw away a real opportunity."
"Gimmy a break, Art!  You're a business major, a college-trained scam artist!  And you never heard about the original con... new lamps for old?  Whatever!  It's done now.  So understand please!  Our greatest need is to find that missing horse before someone else does.  Domestic animals have a tendency to stay together.  It should be near the same area as the other was.  And if you smell a carcass... check it out and watch for wolves; if it's dead I need to know.  Can you ride?"
"Yeah, sort of, but it's been a while."
"Well, it's time to brush up." Leona insists.  "We have that old saddle; get one of the blankets and make this work.  If you're on horseback the other would be less likely to shy away.  In fact, they will know each other and may seek each other out.  It's a piece of cake, so make it work, okay?"
"It's going to take some trial and error to get the saddle attached, but--"
"I'm a country girl, remember?  You hoist the saddle on her back.  I can strap it down" Leona assures, "and get all the gadgets attached." 
Sir Art of Atlanta is soon upon his way.  Not in search of the Grail nor to save the down trodden, but to seek out a misplaced docile beast of burden.
Leona spends most of the morning planning for the possibility a second steed may not materialize, all the while keeping a serious eye on the perimeter.  Given time to reconsider, the victim of this morning's escapade might take a notion for revenge; he certainly seemed the type and he had the manpower.  It's about noon when their guest pops up from her nap, bright-eyed and if the truth be known, bushy-tailed too.
The ladies settle down for a chat.  Leona's new friend being a fountain of practical wisdom and local information including fairy tales, rumors, prophecies and comedies of error.  As the conversation rolls into early evening Leona had hoped to see Art trot back into view leading their tardy equine by now.  Her concern begins to mingle with the topics at hand.
"Well, me tinks one's close by," her new friend suggests, "u'm sure."  The old girl rises to her feet and sniffs the air.  She snatches up a few strands of dry grass, casting them loose to see what direction they choose.  Turning to face the breeze and rising high as she can on her tiptoes, "Yep! right dare," she points.  "Just on da slope, dis side dem tall pointy trees." 
Leona zeros in on the distant landscape.  Sure enough, there's a horse grazing on the hillside just beyond the area earlier confirmed as an abandoned orchard.  "You've got it!  Wow, that was easy!  Please excuse my rush; I've got to get up there before it wanders off."  Leona breaks for the wagon to gather anything with which to fashion some sort of restraint.
As she emerges with a makeshift lariat the old girl adds afew drops of wisdom for her quest.  "Don't be ta quick now; day can get ta running off if day tink ya sneaking up on'em."  She hands Leona a bunch of thick roots she's pried from the meadow.  "Dis what ya need, horse nip, ittle get'em.  Let um see ya, be slow about it; hold dees up to'em, he'll come ya way.  Dares once a big house up dat hill."
Leona graciously accepts her guest's advice and the bundle of horseradishes.
"Thank you, I'm so glad we met."  Leona gives her new best friend a quick hug.  "I'll be back soon as I can."  Fixing her position and that of her objective with the sun, she dashes off across the meadow.  "Make yourself at home," she calls back, "whatever you like."
The tree line is clogged with blackberry briers spiraling well above her head, some so tall as to have entwined themselves with the trees.  Each year many of the old stalks die leaving thorn laden skeletons to defend the new shoots, everything then tightly bound together by a fierce alliance of honeysuckle and grape vines.  This coalition has all but secured the meadow from trespassers.  It doesn't take long to realize she is ill equipped for the task.  But, if she turns back now to change clothes the light will wane stealing her prize.  There's little choice, she wades into the thicket.  It's akin to a WW-I battlefield strewn with prickly unforgiving barbed wire.  By the time she has emerged her smock has been sacrificed and to little avail as her arms and legs have also been superficially shredded.
She soon comes to realizes her torturous trek may have been for not.  Her quarry is but fifty yards away and upon its back a familiar saddle.  So then, where is Art?  She is about to call out when sounds of activity catch her ear.  There could be trouble; better her arrival remain unannounced.  Remnants of a stone structure may be seen beyond the thicket.  Drawing her weapon, she advances cautiously.  Windowless walls come to view, likely a defensive perimeter of some sort now fallen to ruin.  The sounds are clearer now, not of conflict nor torment, but more the unconcerned byproduct of someone fumbling about.
From a sizable breach in the wall she can see Sir Art is in no immediate danger; he's rooting around in the debris of what appears to be a small collapsed lean-to.  The wall encloses a large courtyard; remains of a much larger structure occupy most of the opposite side.  She quietly perches herself in the opening to watch while he meticulously searches the rubble like an archeologist hot on the trail of some ancient relic.  Were a cup of water in her hand likely it would soon come to a boil.  She is scratched and scrapped from head to toe, the light weave of her clothes snagged and torn by every thorn they brushed against because of his foolishness.
"Ah!" he shouts out, nearly toppling backwards.  "Why didn't you say something?"
"I assume you've found our missing horse since you have time for this.  I didn't see it; did I miss it?"
"I was all over back through here."  He does a select-all movement with outstretched arms.  "No sign of it yet.  What happened to you?"
"We'll talk about that later, but right now I want to know about the horse," she Insists.  "If you haven't find it yet what are you doing here?"
"It looked interesting.  I mean, there's no telling what you might find in a place like this."  Art takes note her voice is on the rise.
"Yeah!  But you're looking for a horse and you know damn well you're not going to find it under one of those rocks."
"Yeah, but you--"
"You stinking shit!" she howls.  "I just tore myself to shreds to get up here 'cause I thought I had spotted the other horse," she exclaims furiously.  "First things first and the first thing we need is mobility.  Till then we are stuck, helpless, you understand?"  Leona drops back to the far side of the wall out of sight; Art is quick but cautious to follow.  His credibility has been called into question.  Some logic, however lame, must be presented to justify his actions.
"Once we roll out of here you know we'll never see this place again," Art defends.  "I didn't think the opportunity should be lost and I don't think I should have to kiss your ass every time I want to do something."
"At the rate you're going you may never get that close to it again.  You're in a rut.  This game is about retreat.  It's like looking in a mirror, it's backwards.  We're not here to round up venture capital or save the world.  The object of the game was clearly stated.  If we find our way back, intact, we win.  Our net worth when we leave here has no value, we can't take it with us.  We are going to get our asses scorched if you don't come up to speed."
"You seem awfully wound up on this, even more than usual."
"Am I missing something?  You were the one who'd memorize the rules before a tournament--every angle figured, every defense ready to go.  Total commitment with strategies up the yin-yang.  A certifiable game-aholic!  Now all you want to do is play bingo.  What's the problem?"  She points toward the wagon.  "You see the road, the stream, right?  Well, the wagon is down there on the left, just the other side of this grove.  No need to rush on my account."  She mounts up.
"Hey, wait a minute!"
"That's two strikes dude.  One more, me and this mare are going our way and you and that wagon can sit here till doomsday."
"Just cool it, okay." Art demands, "I get a vote on this too."
"Right! and we agreed did we not?  The horse was top priority, there was no mention of this treasure hunting bullshit."  She turns away.
"Hey wait!  No reason we can't ride double, and--"
"Like hell!  I'm not going to take a chance on hurting this animal for your convenience.  I paid my dues coming up here; I'm riding back.  If I were you, I wouldn't tarry too long.  The sun's crashing and I can tell you for sure," pointing back the way she came, "you don't want to wait until you have to cut through that field.  See ya!"  She trots off toward the far end of the ruins, soon coming upon two parallel ruts likely cut into the hillside long ago by wagon wheels.  The tracks meander downward through the forest.  She surmised correctly that they would merge with the road following the creek.  A left turn at the bottom of the hill brings her effortlessly back to the campsite.
Back in reality, so to speak, Sinaia and Marwyn observe her departure in the glowing Minnon.  "This fellow she is with is a dung heap.  Do her the good service of having one of your goons cut his throat."
"He was her choice of an ally," Marwyn replies with some regret, "things must be allowed to run their course."
Returning again to the meadow, Leona's friend has brightened the fire some and sits patiently watching as the sparks dance away.  "Ya caught'um; good fur ya."
"Not exactly;" She admits glumly, "this is the same one we had before."
"Where's ya man? 'E 'ain't been lost?"
"No... it's his turn to walk."
"Ya been in da nettles I see.  Lemme get ya fixed.  If'in dem points is stuck in ya day kun turn bad."
The sky's nearly dark by the time Art's silhouette can be seen coming down the road.  Choosing the long way around was probably the only good decision he's made since they arrived.  Conversation is scarce and cautious throughout dinner.  Art doesn't care to pour gasoline on a smoldering situation.
"Ittle be dark soon," advises their guest.  "Best if'in um home 'fore da morning."
"You can't go off in the dark," Leona begs with serious concern.  "You'll be tripping or stepping into a hole and twist an ankle or worse.  Please, it's no trouble for you to stay; there could be wolves."
"Som'a my best pals is wolves.  Dares so few left.  Folks don't lik'em."
"I fear you'll be lost.  Stay the night.  There will be plenty of room in the wagon since Art prefers to sleep under it."
"Huh!"  Art exclaims quietly, followed by several cautiously whispered adjectives which do not bear repeating.
"Oh dear!  I could ne'r be lost in dis wood," the old girl confides softly.  "I know my way well as da breeze."
"I wish I could say the same." Leona admits somewhat sadly, "Can you tell me anything of the way home?"
"If ever ya lost," the old woman teases, a gleam in her eye, "Always look ta yourself fur the right way ta go... then ya takes one step more if fur certain ya want ta know."
"Thank you, ma'am."
Clouds have all but taken the moon, its light subdued to a soup of haze and mist.  Their guest turns toward the forest and walks away.  A few steps and her image begins blending with the trees and shadows, then it fades upon the breeze as she were vapor.
Art strains to follow the old gal's movement.  "Cool!  She's gone.  I mean totally, like pouf... gone." 
Soon thereafter, Leona retreats from the fire's glow.  There isn't much sense in rehashing what's been said.  Perchance the morning will reveal some grounds for blending their points of view.  One thing is certain, right after the maid throws open the curtains and carries off the fine silver and what remains of her gourmet breakfast, she is going horsehunting.  Art isn't sure if he's sleeping indoors this evening or not, thinking it best to wait awhile and try his luck after she's fallen asleep.  His quandary is soon resolved beyond the customary shadow of doubt.  Leona returns, hands him a blanket, then turns away without further debate.  Only the glowing embers of the fire are left to warm him tonight; they brighten in the breeze, sparkle and then subside with a faint crackle.
Tranquillity is not always the virtue one might suspect.  These three stout figures who cautiously slink across the dimming horizon, what could their purpose be?  The dawn soon enough to herald their coming, for in the dark of night their quarry could slip away and be lost.
Looking like a teepee with a head, Art finds himself sitting beneath the wagon wrapped in a bedspread with only his defense strategy for company.  Never having been much for traditional Cub Scout outings nor one to enjoy the company of bugs, he sits, unable to sleep.  He reflects upon the days events seeking some means to curry favor with his disenchanted lady.  The coals of the fire taunt, hissing a warning at him, as a light scattering of large raindrops has begun.  He wonders, perhaps could they provide an excuse to claim his rightful place in the castle?  Surely she wouldn't demand he spend the night in the rain.  Then again, given the queen's present disposition and the fact she's armed, some fresh country air may be the wiser choice this evening.  Intense quiet has a sound all its own.  Things that pass unheard during times of light are amplified beyond belief when the silence that is night approaches.  How could a beetle or centipede possibly raise such a ruckus when they pass by?  Even the wildflowers have withdrawn their support, most having closed till dawn comes again to tease them open.  Little doubt they will enjoy the morning's dew more than he.
--
Deep in another part of the forest, a light drizzle bathes the trees; even in the pale light of a clouded moon the leaves shine.  Water trickles from the steep sodden roof of a small bungalow.  All matter of insects and little springy things that like to jump have begun to croak and sing welcoming the shower's arrival.  Behind the cottage a garden patch is just as happy as they for a pleasant dousing.  A rabbit there, not the least deterred by a bath while he dines, munching contentedly upon the greens.  It stops, perks up and looks around, cautiously sniffing at the damp cool air.  Something's coming near and it doesn't smell good; the hare, being no fool, decides perhaps 'tis better to continue his repast elsewhere.  Thus, he sprints off into the night before his scent too might be noticed and he becomes something else's dinner.  A huge stump stands guard at one corner.  Three red fox pups cautiously exit from the lair there beneath its gnarled roots.  They dash off to greet mom, a welcome sight indeed who is approaching with a fresh hen in her mouth.  She drops the fowl.  The pups crowd around and little yipping sounds abound; they are so happy to see her.  Everyone gets a good nuzzling, of course, and then the meal begins.  Mom's been gone for three very long, long days and they are as hungry as ever they've been in their short lives.
"Yup, I know ya dears are famished, but dease tings happen," Mom reminds.  "I would'a been sooner, but dare was a debt needed tending.  Um just glad ta see nunes run off un got lost; dat would never do.  Ya wouldn't believe who I just sat down with; was da daughter.  Yup, a fine sweet girl she's come ta be un we owe'er a great debt we do, 'cause we all got terrible close ta being dunfur.  Poor pick of a mate dough; wouldn't swap ya a chewed chicken bone fur 'em."
--
Adjourn again we shall, back to the outskirts of Atlanta and a ramshackle farmhouse where nothing is what it seems.  There, Marwyn and Sanaia continue to monitor Leona's trials as they are revealed within the transparent domain of the Minnon.  All is as it should be within the game room.  The players have picked up on the momentum and proceed to establish their individual niches within the real game's events.  This side of the coin played with the personalities they've developed for themselves.  Neither entirely true, as people seldom display their real disposition, nor altered by the game master's candles.
All traces of the extraordinary transitions that occurred during the onset have faded.  Their physical appearances and attitudes are as they were prior to the binding.  They socialize and joke at their dilemmas and impending disasters with little concern, it's a game after all.  Leona resides among them willful as ever, calmly studying her opponents and cautiously seeking her way.
On the dark side of the coin their playing field is boundless, confined not to a single room as that of their counterparts.  Events unfolding within the Minnon's domain are by extension the same as those defined by the players actions within the game room.  When a card is turned or the dice are rolled whatever wonder or hazard they may create acts as a touchstone to the Minnon.  Thereby, its consequences must be addressed within Leona's real-time fantasy of seemingly solid objects.  She has been divided into cause and effect, subject simultaneously to the rules of fact and fantasy alike.
Activity within the game room has been in play less than half an hour.  Whereas Leona has experienced nearly forty hours of events and conflict upon the platform where she alone resides.  If her activities were transposed to the time line within the game room she would be humming like a computer's processor on uppers.  Certainly there are cautions to be weighed for her situation is not unlike the insanity those with multiple personalities encounter.
Of special interest to Marwyn is that Leona now possess the blade originally acquired by Art.  "Though fate served him well, I find no fault in exchanging that coarse thing for the treasure they were offered."  
"He was offered," Sanaia points out somewhat objectionably.
"Yes... of course.  Still, I dare to think he has her best interests at heart."
"I doubt that, sir.  As I said, a pile of dung of more value to flies than the maiden we torment.  And the device is not lost," Sanaia reminds.  "You allow the child no worth of her own.  Consider her lineage, it was a matter of honor.  The lad gave his prize in exchange for what he desired and he was glad to be rid of it, then tried to steal it back to gain more for himself, what then is he but a cad?  She chose not to be put at risk by his foolishness.  So now this piece of iron you've dredged up from one of our player's memories is milady's to bargain with." 
"But fate granted the blade to the lad.  What has attracted her to that weapon?"  Marwyn asks.
"Do not confuse fate and destiny.  One is more of chance and circumstance," Sanaia advises, "the other is meant to be."
 Sanaia points into the crystal.  "It appears your presence is desired and mine soon as well; shall we return to the service of our guests?  Your turn first, I think, while I shall keep the watch."
--
Back now to the far side of the coin, there to observe Sir Art as he patiently awaits a call from the lady upstairs.  Alas!  There comes no tapping on his ceiling neither to apologizes nor invite.  Within the hour his teepee has slumped over, forming now the shape of a large baked potato.  There he lies, wide awake, another hour trudging past with not even a yawn for encouragement.  All manor of subtle shufflings may be heard from the adjacent meadow.  A fan club of lady mosquitoes has assembled, swirling around like a flock of buzzards just above the side of his face.  Unseen but not forgotten, for when one comes near as to lit upon his ear it's as though a flying freight train was approaching.  They can hardly wait for him to fall asleep that all may become better acquainted and finally dine.  Will sleep ever come to end this low-level torment?  The breaking dawn assures it has indeed, though not for long.
Something long and strangely segmented approaches Art's feet.  It continues right up over top of him without a care.  He explodes from beneath the blanket in a panic, crashing his head on the underside of the wagon.  Turns out he's been run over by a family of skunks, each following the other nose to tail, all in a row.  They are taken as much by surprise as he.  Mom and her brood of little stinkers scatter in all directions as Art scrambles for his mighty defense strategy.
At the commotion, Leona drops from the rear of the wagon sword in hand.  She sees the villains scampering off.  "Keep it down; you'll scare the horse."  She sniffs the air.  "So far this is your lucky day.  Either that or you scared the stink right out of them," she muses.
"Hey, those are my pants." Art protests.
"You can only wear one pair at a time, so we're going to be sharing them.  These are more practical, especially for emergencies."  The sun hasn't even cut the horizon yet and already he's worn out.  He lies down again, pulling the blanket over his head in an effort to recapture some of the zzzzzz's that got away last night.  A few minutes and he dozes off without a care.  Without a care is hardly an appropriate frame of mind when snoozing in the realm.  Such folly seldom lasts for long and can be quite a risky business.

Chapter-5

FIRST BLOOD UPON A MAIDEN'S BLADE
MAY NEVER BE ENTIRELY CLEANSED AWAY.

In the realm, as does the sun, so do all things about you.  Thus, none should tarry or laze about, but early to rise lest they miss an opportunity to greet friend or foe alike.  A most important time of day indeed, the best time to begin a siege as it allows all the day to die.  It should be of no surprise then when Art's cozy blanket suddenly disappears exposing a disoriented business major, one who should be more truthful to himself and stay away from fantasies.  Either that, or earlier to rise, for now he must face three corporate raiders of a type not commonly encountered in the Wall Street environment.
These fellows carry sharp ragged oversized weapons instead of briefcases and the Fed. probably does not regulate their activities too closely.  Their finely tailored suits have been replaced with thick well-worn leather armor including all manner of functional straps, buckles and pointed iron rivets.  All three stare at Art as though he were a platter of prim rib roast hot from the spit.
Art is hoping Leona will again call out and dispel this menace as she did the last time proving it yet another bad dream.  Patch nudges Shorty, nodding toward the rear of the wagon, turning then to Sagen with a nod toward the front to assure their quarry is contained.  They disperse, climbing up and entering the cabin from both ends.  The suspension squeaks as the frame jostles about.
Squeaks are a bad sign, Art suspects, as they tend to reinforce the notion something really is going down.  Art scrambles backward from under the wagon picking up his sword by the blade as he retreats.  He finds it to be as sharp as it looks.
Patch squats down ducking his head slightly and walks under the wagon, advancing directly toward Art who has sprinted about thirty feet away.  Art turns to face his antagonist and reassess the situation from a safer distance, still not entirely sure these guys are genuine.  Blood flowing with some enthusiasm from the palm of his hand cautions that this is not a drill.
"First blood is yours," Patch grumbles sneeringly.  "Now, 'tis my turn, boy.
"Shit!  Who are you?"
"Your replacement!"
"What!  Why?"
"Why not?  That wench of yours obviously needs a firmer hand.  My brothers and I shall console her grief and teach her manners."
"What grief?"
"That of your loss," Patch assures, "after she has buried you."
Art and Patch engage, Art ever backing away, his adversary toying as he advances.  The event heats up; Art's leg is slightly cut, though again by his own clumsy actions.
"If you keep swinging that thing, lad" Patch advises with what could be perceived a smile, "you'll perish by your own hand and I'll have no fun today."
Leona, it turns out, did not return to the comfort of her blankets.  She went instead to gather wood in the adjacent thicket for the morning's tea.  Hearing the clash of steel she bolts toward the wagon thinking those she vanquished yesterday have wised up and returned for vengeance.
Hardly of notice at such trying times is a family of furry little stripped rascals.  They scamper about with great anticipation.  A few whispers and a precise wave of the hand, their banquet is served.  Long wiggly worms and fat juicy grubs topped off with the biggest hive of ground hornets they've ever seen!  And for dessert ripe apples, pears and bright red plums covered over with every wild berry nature has to offer.  Umm, yum, yum!  The careful observer may also catch a subtle reflection and the faint image of a satin gown dissolving into the forest mist.  The element of surprise is a wicked device, and such a foul deed it is to be set upon as one sleeps. "If she must be inquired of so severely," Sanaia relents, "let it be done on a field level to all."
Entering the clearing behind the troll, Leona advances toward the skirmish.
Patch and Art are jockeying for position; already the long sword has become an almost unbearable weight.  The troll wields his broad ax one-handed as though it were a badminton racquet.  Art can hardly maintain a defensive posture and the bloody handle does not improve his grip.  Suddenly Patch lunges with a powerful strike sending Art staggering backward and his sword spinning away, whereupon Leona makes her presence known.
"Hey!  Short shit!"
Patch's distraction allows Art to regain his footing.  Rather than seek out his lost weapon, he dashes across the road toward the creek.
Pleasantly startled, Patch turns to greet Leona.  "There ya are.  I been looking forward to the dessert!"
He does not advance, being careful not to encourage her flight.  Sleek and agile as any doe she could easily outrun the lot of them.  Better to wait until that option is forfeit; thus, idle conversation to distract and delay.  "Your man's fled.  Perhaps we should be friends.  Can be a hostile land, this, strength in numbers ya know?"  He watches for signs she may break and run as his two brothers advance from behind her.  She hates to abandon all they own to a thug, but with Art out of sight it would be foolish to engage this rogue.  He does not appear the sort to be easily dissuaded.
"Where the hell is Art?" she questions while searching for some sign of her presumed ally and protector.
One of those creeping up from behind motions the other to flank her position as they close the gap.  They move swiftly for their stature and soon a three-pronged trap is set.
"Might be ugly as a bog toad," Shorty advises from behind, "but my brother ain't short."
Leona turns to find herself surrounded.  The other two have silently crept to within five yards.  Her heart begins to race; she can't recall any rules appropriate to counter the impending confrontation.  Her escape option has been forfeit, it's fight or concede.  Neither offers a bright prospect.  She desperately needs Art to attack one of her flankers; a false charge, anything to create a diversion.  Even a loud holler would offer her some opportunity to make a run for it.  Anxiously she scans the perimeter hoping he will pop up amid the tall grass and do something, but it doesn't happen.
With her adversaries closing from three sides, she resorts to consoling herself in very subdued undertones.  "Calm down, be cool... just a game, play to win, but most important... have fun, Ha!"  There is little else to do but cautiously stand her ground and wait for Art as the trap closes.  "Arrttt!" she calls out loudly, but alas, it seems the presumed captain of her fate has abandoned ship.
Patch comes right to the point.  "No need to die this day."
His brothers offer options and consequences, their hope, to avoid damaging the property.  "A damsel in distress ya are missy.  Surely ya can see... ain't no knight coming to take ya away from us."
"He's gone, girly," Patch offers impatiently.  "Run off, left his iron in the grass there.  Better forget him now... afore you get yourself in trouble."
"With proper training the likes ah you could be a favorite," Sagen adds smugly.  "Many a gentleman be pleased to provide ya a life of luxury."
Leona refuses to waver.  She maintains a death-tight grip on the dull hulk of a weapon, turning to face one then another, attempting to keep an eye on all three as they advance to within striking distance.
Shorty, the troll she is facing, suddenly changes his congenial expression.  With an intense stare he strikes his weapon against the tip of her sword.  She holds steady; he strikes again, harder.  "Try not my patience, wench; drop that useless stick or ya gonna get hurt.  Ya have nice teeth, be a pity to lose'em."
"Cuts and bruises," Sagen consoles, "invite a sad future of harsh treatment girly."  Standing at arm's reach behind her, he runs the tip of a spiked mace across her shoulder and down the center of her back.  She ignores the provocation.  "Be careful now, missy!  A nasty scare or mangled limb and the courtesan ends up a scullery maid... or worse."
"And so easy to avoid," Shorty entreats.  "Let the weapon fall or I'm going to cut that hand off."  He glances toward Patch for an instant.  "Brother, make haste!  We shall have need of a red hot iron to seal her stump lest she bleed to death afore we've finished."
Leona's head bows slightly, her blade drops from the ready to a horizontal position.  Releasing the hilt from the grip of her right hand the blade, now held only by the left, droops further toward the ground.  Her right arm slowly descends to her side.
All three of Marwyn's antagonists advance closer in around her.  Sagen, the one behind, places a heavy hand upon her shoulder.  "Let the iron go, missy."
--
A still and somber Leona sits quietly next to Art at the small table in the game room.  Everyone else seems frozen in time, absolutely motionless, not so much as a blink or the sound of breath.  A deafening silence pervades the space.  The scene could be a photograph were it not for the flickering candles--they the single indication time still exists in this place.
Only Sanaia is able to move.  She glides toward Leona with her tray of possibilities.  "Troubled times oft bestow opportunities, milady; never doubt the choice is yours."  She hands Leona a cup with four dice.  Rolled upon the tray they show, 1, 2, 32, and a picture of a bloodied sword.  Lastly, a deck of cards is offered; Sanaia arrays them with a casual swipe of her hand.  Leona chooses, but does not look upon its face for she doesn't want to know.
"Will there be anything else, milady?"  Leona places one of the cards she now holds upon the tray; it displays a broken sword.  She picks up the dice showing the bloody weapon and places it upon the card.
"I would draw lots with this demon for my future."
Sanaia bows as she withdraws.  A moment later the tray with the dice as they were cast is presented before Marwyn.  "She will fight," Sanaia advises, "rather than be taken.  And the card she drew and held I have never seen before.  Someone toys with us, sir, and I beg you recall we are not in the realm.
--
As the blade of Leona's weapon droops further she allows the hilt to rotate between her fingertips.  Now, tightening her grip again, the blade swings slightly backward such that she has hold of it as a dagger.  Looking straight into Shorty's eyes, she whispers discreetly. "So be it!"  Sensing this a challenge, he cocks his arm to strike and in so doing leaves himself exposed to a rising blade.  Leona snaps her sword upward in an awkward but effective fashion.  The tip catches Shorty below the right arm, slashing upward across his leather breastplate and cutting his wind pipe and a major artery diagonally.
His weapon drops, he grasps his throat; precious thick red fluid spurts from between his fingers and dribbles through the severed armor.  Leona's left hand is now at arm's length before her right shoulder.  Grabbing the hilt with her right hand then abruptly bending both arms, she snaps it swiftly downward.  The blade driven backward along her right side into Sagen, who's standing directly behind her.  He doubles over, pushing her forward as he backs off the stinging cold iron.
Bending one knee as she steps forward allows her to duck and yet maintain her balance, this to avoid a killing strike from Patch, immediately to her left--the last standing of her tormentors.
