His blade flashes by less than an inch above the side of her face.  The broad flat side severely grazing her left shoulder.  Having missed its mark, the momentum of the heavy ax leaves him in a precarious off-balance position, facing Leona somewhat sideways without an immediate defense.
The ax's impact knocks Leona to her right.  Quickly releasing her left hand from the hilt allows her to throw the injured arm outward, maintaining her posture for a brief moment more.  The sword, now held as a dagger in her right hand, comes left toward Patch as she spins about with all she can muster in a final desperate lunge before tumbling backward to the ground.  In such close quarters, she's able to slash her exposed attacker across the middle before his precarious stance brings him crashing down as well.
They are undone, one and all, with three precise moves; hardly a second has transpired.  Had she deviated in any way more than an inch her reward would have proven fatal.  She rolls left on her injured shoulder aided by the momentum of her last swing.  Thus, quickly recovering a firm defensive stance.  The nerve endings in her hands, forearms and fingertips are sizzling at though she were being pricked by thousands of tiny pins.
The wounded troll attempts to regain his footing using his ax as a crutch.  Leona, not nearly so seriously injured, drops to one knee and with a full swing strikes the handle of his ax in two.  He plummets back to earth face first.  Patch rolls over slowly, all the while expecting to have his head struck a killing blow; but it doesn't come.  In fact, her effort could just as easily have severed his arm or head, but she chooses to disarm him instead.
She stands in the midst of the wounded trolls, bewildered as to how such a dull blade could have possibly done so much damage.  Their heavily metal clad leather armor slit with the ease a honed blade would split an apple.  The most she had hoped for was to knock the first off balance allowing her to break and run like hell.  But everything meshed perfectly as the workings of a fine Swiss watch.  Thus, the hour of doom has chimed and the ground is now covered with blood, shattered weapons and dying men.  Sagen is doubled up lying on his side.  Shorty's on his knees, steadied by the one hand and holding his throat with the other; he's choking, desperately gasping for breath.  Patch, on his back holding his gut, the least wounded of the three, but defenseless.  Leona is apprehensive and confused, taking quick deep breaths.  "This can't be right!  This isn't a horror movie," she cries out, "it's a game."
--
Leona closes her eyes for a moment to clear the image.  When again they open she finds herself standing alongside the great fireplace in the game room.  Several charred logs among the heap of glowing charcoal continue to flicker.  Details of the room are muddled; only that occasional wisp of flame comes into focus.  Solemn, indistinguishable figures move about at the room's edges.  There are voices--deep, slow voices, like a recording being played at the wrong speed.  She really doesn't care what is being said anyway.  Her head is bowed, her left arm braced against the mantle.  In the one hand she still holds the card drawn from Sanaia's tray; in the other, limp at her side, she's crushed a helpless soft drink can.
What have I done?  What's this about?  She looks to the card for an explanation, some hint of reason.  Printed thereupon in coarse Gothic script are words most profound: "BY THY HAND, NOTHING SHALL STAND BEFORE ME."
--
Within the blink of an eye she is returned to the meadow's carnage.  Her left hand rests against a stout old locust.  She raises the blade held in the other to view.  The inscription printed upon the card is faintly evident now, exposed by traces of blood seeking solace among the pits and irregularities of the blade's surface.
Sagen calls to his brother.  His painful voice stirs Leona back to the battle's aftermath.  She shouts at Patch.  "This is only a game; are you all right?"
"As well as any... recently disemboweled."  Patch rights himself cautiously, bracing himself with one arm.  "Will you grant I may tend my brothers milady?"
"Yes, please do!" she motions erratically.  "You've got to stop all this bleeding."
Patch gropes off toward one of the fallen.  He reaches his brother, Shorty, leaning close to his ear.  "Are you still with me?  Say something."  He listens, but the breath has left his sibling.  Patch rolls him over and closes his eyes.
Leona places her hand over her mouth and whispers in dismay.  "Oh shit!  Why couldn't they have just left me be?"
He moves on with care toward Sagen.  "What of you?"
Sagen chokes, cautiously forming his words that things within do not unravel more by his own efforts.  "Not well... something burns inside... and the heat of it grows.  I fear the wench has poked a hole in parts that are not to mend.  And you?" 
"I'm soon dead," Patch advises, "Shorty's gone."
"The she-devil?" Sagen inquires.
"Untouched!"
Leona is sobbing quietly.
"But for the grief of our sad ending," Patch adds.
"How do we come to this?" Sagen asks.  "Have we been deceived?" 
"I think not.  The fair are beguiling creatures; it's their nature.  But none ever more than this wench; and so quick of hand and precise her efforts.  There is not the time to consider our folly now," Patch reminds, "'tis done and we as well.  A great task yet remains; I hope I may bear it."
Sagen expires.  Patch closes his brother's eyes and staggers to his feet, glancing toward the remorseful young maiden who has just wiped out his clan.  She doesn't seem to be wary of his activities nor concerned he may harbor ill intent.  Were it for himself alone, he might consider attempting some ploy to exact a vengeful deed.  But obligations to his fallen brothers come first.  Sheer will alone cannot prevail; he knows the bleeding must be reduced.  Stripping down to the waist, he binds the wound with all at his disposal.  The sheath of his brother's sword laid over the dressing, and finally his own broad leather belt cinched tight to the last notch.  It will have to do.
Things are needed.  He takes note of the area then crosses the road to investigate the watercourse.  Fate has not abandoned him.  A large dead tree undercut by the water's flow has uprooted itself.  Considerable floating debris has accumulated among the branches, a windfall for which he is thankful.
 There stands a grove of evergreens between the bank and the creek bed adjacent to the meadow.  Patch disappears into the thicket.  He soon reemerges with several straight, thin, fallen trees wedged under each arm.  Dragging them over the edge of the embankment, he returns again to the thicket for load after load of slender cedars, saplings fallen in their youth for lack of light among the faster growing pines.
Leona, somewhat composed and now resigned to the fact she may have actually killed two men, investigates his curious activities.  The gap between the bank and the fallen tree has been filled in with a dense accumulation of cedars and heavy pine bows stacking in crisscrossed layers.  Using the bank as a ramp, he struggles to lift the end of a substantial log onto this heap alongside several others.
"What are you doing?  You're going to kill yourself," she warns.
"There's no need; that task is surely done.  I must build a pyre for my kinsmen.  Crows and boars will devourer our flesh and scatter our spirits to the borders of the world.  My brothers and I must be consumed by fire or we shall never be joined again.  I swear not to offend thee, milady, and beg that I may continue."
"Do as you wish, whatever."
Patch resumes his final labors.  Being unaware of what other vows he may be bound to, Leona dares not but to watch from a safe distance.  She should be concerned of Art's circumstance, but he is lost to her thoughts entirely and no great loss at that.  As the morning wears on, climbing the bank becomes increasing difficult for Patch.  By noon Patch is soaked to his boots with blood.  There cannot be much left, but never does he falter nor speak a word.
Unfocused and glassy-eyed, he allows his burden to drop.  Too dizzy now to continue, his limbs so numbed they are nearly lost to his control.  He staggers to a nearby willow and props himself against the trunk, the task is too great, death soon at hand.
Off in the far reaches of Patch's mind, at first a distant echo, the quaint voice of an elderly woman comes to be.  "In a bit of a tangle are we?  Family obligations can be such a strain upon one's spirit.  No one would deny you've made a noble effort; pity the task shall not be complete."  Her ethereal voice whispers pleasantly into his ear as though she were sitting right beside him.  "Can you face them, if ever again by chance you meet?"
He sits calmly, motionless, dying, listening to the spirit obliged to chronicle his deeds.  There she sits on her pillow, just on the other side of the self-same tree.  A spry, slender peasant women, so close indeed their hands could touch.  She appears no more than 70 perhaps, but given her occupation one could imagine she is ageless.  Her long gray hair neatly braided and laced with tiny flowers of white and lavender coils about her upon the ground.  A sewing frame rests upon her lap; she hums as she pulls the stitches.
"For such a vagabond this really doesn't look so bad."
A squeaky voice objects adamantly to any kind word included in his eulogy.  "They were pricks! each and every one; you know it as well as I."  Another maiden has come upon the scene; mounds of untamed red hair flurry about as she jostles to and fro trying to get Patch's attention.  No more than 30 years to her credit, brightly colored and elegant every stitch of her attire.  She scolds and berates the dying troll with every foul word she can muster.  But he doesn't acknowledge her presence in the slightest.
"Leaving you and those vile brothers of yours to the worms," she proclaims sternly, "I'd say is more than any of you deserve."  At times ranting incoherently and then carefully pronouncing every syllable of endless discredits and curses, she continues, then reverting again to hysterical jabbering.  "Wish I was a buzzard, I'd have your eyes out of that ugly face while you can still feel it."  No doubt they have met before and she wishes to inform all the world of their deep and obviously lasting friendship.
Before long, half dozen large ominous carrion eaters have gathered on branches high in the willow.  They call out inviting their friends.  Black and ugly as sin, waiting as demons might to drag the spirits of men from a blood bathed battlefield.  "You see, already they've come for you.  I shall applaud all the day long while they peck you apart.  There is justice; I'm even more anxious than they just to watch then feast.  I hope they leave something for the fly puppies.  If the weather cools there might be enough left of you to last for several of their generations."   
Leona has harnessed the horse and is binding ropes to the log Patch had abandoned.
Squeaky takes notice, "Foolish wench!  Surely you would not pardon these villainous bastards?"
"Oh, and you were not just as she?" the Weaver reprimands calmly.  "As was I, and aren't we all?  Is every maiden not at least once beguiled, seduced... misled.  Most keep their balance, though some, as were you, are betrayed and do fall victim.  But I implore you now, let it go.  You must," she cautions, "lest it consume every grain of your spirit.  Nothing will remain of you--nothing."
Squeaky bitterly pleads her case to an inattentive Leona.  "Their ill intent was obvious," she rages.  "The lot of them would have bent you over that stump," screams the frantic red-haired wench while flailing the air with her arms.  "Even were you half dead."
"Leave her be," the Weaver retorts.  "Naught of your pains shall sway her and you know it.  The effort to even attempt it reflects badly upon you."
Leona tightens the ropes and hauls the log away as though the women didn't exist.  In fact, only the Weaver assembling a tapestry of the dying troll's life is aware of the interloper.
The troll pulls a heavy coin from a thong around his neck.
The talisman has a distinctive hexagonal design with strange symbols both cast and cut thereupon; it vanishes as he flips it into the air.
The Weaver smiles and compliments his action.  "Well done!  For a moment I thought we might have a loose stitch here."  She twists the thread about her finger and snaps it.  The troll's eyes close; his head nods slightly as the last of his breath escapes to mingle with the breeze.
Leona toils late into the evening, stacking layer upon layer.  At the furthest from the embankment now seven feet its depth.  An arduous task considering the damage inflicted to her shoulder this morning and a good day's work by any standard.  Perhaps 'tis fuel in excess of what might be required, but more is better than less given the task desired of it.  Raising the platform near the level of the bank was the only way she could hope to place the three brothers, each in excess of 200 pounds, onto the pyre.  People simply do not roll as well as logs.  She has had to remove the flat tailgate panel from the back of the wagon to serve as a pallet allowing the mare to haul them to the edge of the embankment.  From there she has set two long straight cedars trimmed of their branches and laid to act as a skid track upon which she may now push the pallet out to the platform's end.  The loading and unloading is bloody business.
All must be complete before dark lest she intend to guard the corpses through the night.  For if a bear or wolves were to catch the scent of all this blood the deed could be lost in turmoil.
Dusk finds Marwyn's three confident pawns, each with his weapon in hand, lying side-by-side atop the funeral pyre.  Smoke is curling up around the perimeter, rising skyward toward the vultures that have been circling all day.  None shall have a taste of these morsels unless their craving is for charcoal.
Squeaky's frail but lingering image is finally silent after 12 hours of continuous denunciation, fading away now, content she has done her best to condemn the spirits of her tormentors.
"Ashes to ash and dust to dust," Leona consoles softly, "as I've heard it said.  Let it be so for thee."  I hope this is what you wanted.  I trust you would have done the same for me.  She stands watchful as the flames rise until the platform is no place for any living thing.  Dry spindly cedars stacked between the heavier pieces ignite with the roaring temperament of a jet engine.  She has never been near a fire so hot.  Still sad for the morning's events, but thankful this ceremony was not in her honor.  Her eyes close for a moment that tears may rinse the smoke away, but not the memories, they are condemned forever to stay.
--
Marwyn and Sanaia gaze into the crystalline stone keeping watch upon their ward.  The sorceress begins to snicker quietly as the pyre rises into an inferno.  She turns to Marwyn; her tone changes to mild laughter.  "What your mercenaries have done is temper the mettle of a genuine hellion."  Sanaia continues to laugh aloud while Mark watches the pyre illuminate the surrounding forest.  Leona stands before the blaze; the light casts her shadow a hundred yards off into the meadow.
The brilliant flames and fragrant aroma of well cooked meat attract many of the forest's nocturnal predators.  A pack of wolves watch cautiously from the tree line, but none dare approach the glaring conflagration.  When they look to each other, the blaze reflected in their own eyes is startling to their comrades.  "For want of a lost horse she has become master of a singularity," Sanaia relates quietly.
"If such a weapon exists, where might it be found, I wonder?"  
"Do you really know her, sir.  Have you looked beyond the Cleric's pronouncement?" Sanaia questions.
"It would have made no difference," Marwyn relents.  "Once I informed the Henzecs there became a great urgency to repatriate the maiden.  At first yes, there were concerns for her safety and so I developed this gauntlet that her return might be justifiably avoided.  It soon became evident that even were she deaf, dumb and blind it would make no difference on her behalf.  The matter is political, they desperately need a figure head even if she only survives for a short time.  If her position can be preserved, fine, if not, if she were murdered, none could fault their noble effort and it would justify continuation of the current status-quo.  Either way there problem is solved.  The fellow in the coach," Marwyn reminds, "he spoke the word Clovin.  Inquire to your circle of its meaning."
"I shall. But look here, the inscription on the card she held after, also not part of the deck. It's not a weapon she's acquired, it's something else."
"Like what?"
"Recall you when she snatched it back from the fellow trying to trade it away from her man," Sanaia reminds.  "She swore an oath to the weapon.  What ever it is it just pledged it's fealty to her in return.  Where did that thing come from?"
"One of an assortment randomly dispersed at the game's onset.  Like everything else used to construct the game, something of a memory from one of the borrowed personalities.  As I remember you had misgivings at the time.  I even cautioned Patch before he accepted that the lad's weapon might carry some attributes."
Rueshaba! Only Rueshaba would have ever had contact with something of this nature.  Could be some sort of spell awakened by her pledge.  Oh shit!... could be a demon in the true sense of the word.  Mixing that witch with our players was a mistake, I fear. Hope your charge doesn't do anything that would dishonor her pact."
"We have nothing one might consider a demon here about," Sanaia assures. "However, I'm not knowledgeable of Rueshaba's origins other than  she's come from outside our known world and I don't mean this side of the gateway.  There must be another path, a back door, now there's a thought.  It's going to be a long and engaging night, sir." 
The inferno's intense warmth is suddenly withdrawn.  Leona opens her eyes to inquire why or where it's gone.  The blaze is absent, replaced by the smoldering logs within the game room's hearth.  There she stands once more focused upon the subtle prancing wisps of flame.  Beth has come to inquire why she's not rejoined the others around the model; it's soon her turn to play again.  Leona has a death grip on Beth's arm and speaks to herself in whispers.  "It was so real."
"Leo, you all right?" Beth asks.  "You're breaking my arm."
"Sorry!"  She turns Beth loose.  "I'm scared; I don't know what's happening here.  I mean, I was there!  I really did it, cut them to the bone."  Her voice shudders.  "I could feel the knife being drawn through them.  I swear I killed them all."
Within the spell room Sanaia has concern; memories of Leona's trials are mingling with those of her activities among the group socializing in the game room.
"The spell is not binding her as it should," pointing into the stone.  "Those memories should not invade her presence here, and I don't know how they've come to be here.  Right now she is aware in part of both places at the same time.  For the best of us this would be confounding; for her, it could be dangerously so.  I doubt she can overwhelm the Minnon, but at times she is able to challenge my binding and by so doing frees herself from the Minnon's influence.  Right now she is literally standing on the blade of a knife."  
"Can she see this space as it actually appears."
"Apparently not,"  Sanaia gestures toward the Minnon, "or you would see it that way here.  She is paying very close attention to something however."
"We must get this back under our control." Marwyn demands.  "There is not the means to steal a memory from this world. They must be parted; memories of her trials are to be known only to the Minnon."
"Do you want me to stop it?"
"No... not yet!  How would we explain that?  Everything would be reduced to hysteria.  Whatever resources are necessary, summon them here.  Find the means to separate and contain any of her thoughts not of this place.  I'm going to stay at the podium so I can calm things if the bindings unravel.  Keep me advised."
"One does not place a phone call across the boundary," Sanaia reminds.  "You of all people know the transport restrictions implied by the portal.  The only tools available are those we now possess."  
"Well!" Marwyn inhales, then exhales. " we shall have to do the best we can." He concedes as he exits.
"This is extreme," Beth admits with a weary glance, "I've never seen you stressed out."
"Are you okay?"  Leona asks.  "'Cause I'm... I don't know... I think I'm hallucinating or something.  I don't think I'm here with the rest of you.  It's been... like three days."
"Leooo! You came with us, remember?"  Glancing at her watch, Beth assures, "We've only been here about an hour and a half."
"You feel okay though," Leona repeats.  "Right?"
"Yeah! I'm super.  Hale has surrendered unconditionally to the buffet, but he'll survive."
Speaking of Hale, he's just taken a turn with the dice.  Better yet, now he gets to choose a card.  Only Sanaia delivers the cards, definitely one of the evening's high points.  He throws his head back, gazing toward the ceiling and calls to Beth.  "Hon, it's your turn.  We're about to get our heads chopped off.  You've got to come up with a scheme or some heavy coin here."
"Me!  Your the one in charge of finances," she fires back with a smirk.  "Gimmy a second; I'll come and save you." Returning her attention to Leona, she proposes, "You wanna call it a night?  I mean like Hale and I are so far down on the food chain the roaches get first dibs."
Leona shakes her head no.  "I can't leave.  That's about the only thing I'm sure of right now."
"Can't?  There's a new word for us," Beth teases with a shrug as the girls return to their seats.
Leona calls Art out on his untimely exit.  "You ran off and left me to those creeps.  Why?"
"I didn't run.  I choose to retreat."
"Retreat my ass!  You knew I was surrounded and you took off.  They were behind me; you didn't say a damn word.  I came to your aid; you cut and ran.  I saw you!"
"You saw me?  Hey, come on... the dice offered an option.
We were outnumbered by experienced fighters.  The best chance was to get out of there, fast.  You could've done the same.  There was no reason to defend that old wagon."
"I couldn't," Leona whispers in no uncertain tone, "and you knew it."
"It worked out."
"Yeah, and three people died," she hisses.
Art looks to Leona with a confused expression.  "You mean those three goons?  Yeah, right!  That was a great play; you wiped them out."
Leona places both hands to her forehead to reflect for a moment.  "Right," she whispers to herself. "Just a game, great play... shit!"
Beth consoles Hale.  "Have another cookie, I'll take care of this.  I mean really.  It can't get much worse, so things have to improve."  Beth rolls the dice.  "Ah!" she squeaks with glee.  "See, told ya!  We're going to be moved from the torture chamber to the inspection cells."
"To await execution," Hale reminds, clenching his hands.
"Hon, it's still an improvement, don't knock it."
--
Thus, the coin rolls over again, the line crossed, and we are to the realm once more.  There, as Beth had predicted, fate's come forth and spoken kindly on their behalf.  Beth and Hale stand before a table in chains flanked by their personal dungeon assistants, the extra large grim brothers.  On the opposite side sit three men, a Monk, a Scribe and a Supervisor.  All appear totally disinterested in the pair.  The Monk reads the local edition of Playboy and the supervisor sleeps while the Scribe scribbles and picks his nose.  The room is totally irregular; it looks to have been part of a mine at one time.  Rather foul water flows along the wall to one side.   Remnants of previous installations appear to be growing out of all the surfaces.  Heavily corroded iron rods, shackles and the like, no doubt it was once a hostel for migrant workers on their way to the grave.
The center of attraction is three tables connected end to end by iron latches so as to act as a single unit and still afford portability.  The first is fitted with a head stock and a series of restraining clamps.  The next supports a cradle arranged to guide a sharpened wooden stake.  And the last, the machine's engine, anchors a rack-and-pinion driven plunger articulated on either side by heavy spoked hand wheels.  The assembly conveniently straddles a drainage trench cut into the floor from which a conduit leads off toward the stream.  Sharpened stakes about eight feet long have been piled against the adjacent wall, apparently they are consumable items dispensed on a one-per-customer basis.
An attendant notices the device has caught Hale's attention.  Prick that he is, he approaches with a big grin, placing a massive hairy but consoling arm around Hale's shoulders.  "Ya might ah heard 'bout dis while yau's in the pit; we call it ah shishkebaber.  Wanna try er out, laddie?"  He leers at Beth for a moment, then closes his act with an eerie slow-motion chuckle.
The designate administrator furls his brow, glancing from there beneath and with but a wiggle of his finger issues a firm instruction that the fool should get lost.  The old Monk, wild hair, green teeth, dark robes, and deathly somber personality finally acknowledges the couple's existence.  "His most esteemed and benevolent Lord Mishoff has decreed you both shall be impaled when next the moon fails to rise lest 100 coins of gold are paid on your behalf to compensate for the injuries you've imposed upon His Lordship's faithful servant.
Beth has to ask, just for the record.  "What about our trial?"
The Monk's lack of expression says it all.  "Now then, who will come forth to discharge your debt?"  Silence ensues, the Monk clears his throat slinging a hefty green slimer on the floor.  "Name those who are to be petitioned."
Beth replies with some hesitation.  "Well, Ahmm, you see, we just moved into town, and... Ah.  I left all my credit cards at the shop; do you take plastic, by the way?  Everyone does these days, you know it's the trend."  The monk narrows his gaze.  "No!"  She turns to Hale.  "Do we have a plan, any kind of plan?"  Hale shakes his head negatively.
"Enough!  His most generous Lord Mishoff has provided a scribe to plead for your life to friends and kinsman; be wise in your choice of words."  He waves them on to his associate.  "Bring the next."
The Scribe, starved, wilder hair, no teeth, loincloth, smiles and readies his charcoal stick.
"Hale," Beth says somewhat grimly, "I think this is our lawyer."
--
Leona presence has come again to the meadow and Sanaia is quick to relieve some of Marwyn's anxiety.  Informing him that his subject has returned to the Minnon's domain of her own accord.  There, Leona views the residue of a long hard day's work put to the torch.  The pyre, now reduced to a bed of seething coals blanketed by eight inches of light gray ash will guard the secrets of yesterday.  For not the slightest token remains of those for whom it was set.  Even the iron of their weapons appears to have been consumed.
Until now, death and the ceremonies associated with it have never been a topic of concern.  Everyone just sort of goes along with the program: dig a hole, drop them in, pile the flowers on top, and try to forget.  With this, however, she has developed an appreciation of her opponent's philosophy.  "If any deed could free a person's spirit, surely this is it."  Reduced to basics and consigned to the breeze is certainly a more refreshing thought than laying in a water-logged pit and slowly being consumed by bacteria and worms."
A corpse, first refrigerated, then thawed, drained, prodded, pickled, polished, and arrange for display, seems a grossly misplaced gesture.  And to what end?  Why perpetuate grief?  Why would anyone want to forever imprison those they love within a concrete shrouded cavity.  Surely, to remember one who is truly missed requires not that their carcass be sealed up beneath a granite signpost.  Which raises a very interesting question: why has she never been to a funeral before?  All of her friends have lost family.  Where are my relatives anyway?  Certainly there must be someone aside from Pap and Granny.  Within moments the bundle of wild flowers she has cast upon the hot ash have joined with her vanquished adversaries.
If she intends to leave the meadow--and she does--there is little doubt the wagon and most of its contents must be abandoned.  There's been no sign of Art since his untimely exit yesterday morning.  Apparently he never looked back or he would have known the conflict was resolved.  Their relationship has been on the skids anyway and his lack of commitment could hardly be more obvious.  "So be it," she proclaims quietly.
In spite of its appearance, the curious blade she's come away with has proven more than capable, almost frighteningly so in fact.  That transaction was the best deal she's ever made.  For had she attempted a defense with the burdensome long sword last evening would have been her funeral, not her attackers'.  Though recent experience has shown some logistical modifications may be in order to streamline the efficient handling of it.  Reflecting now, she remembers how distracting it was to have the scabbard waggling about and painfully banging against the side of her knee as she ran to Art's assistance.  And it was awkward to withdraw, the loose scabbard actually resisted the blade's removal until she restrained it with her left hand.  Tenth of a second here, quarter second there, these could exceed any margin of safety and result in a fatal error.  Lashing the scabbard's end to her thigh like a gun fighter's holster doesn't help either as it positions the hilt in a clumsy relationship with her hand and even further restricts her ability to sprint.  The key is to have it totally out of my way, she muses, yet instantly accessible.  An analytical approach soon finds the scabbard's end laced through a hole she's punched in the outward side of her left shoe and the business end strapped to her calf just below the knee.  In this way the weapon is totally secured, not flopping about as before when she jogs back and forth or sprints at full speed.  And the hilt is closer to hand allowing that the blade be withdrawn from such a low profile that the rising motion is an effective close quarters death blow from the moment it clears the sheath, upward, left to right. 
The balance of the day is devoted to sorting and assessing the value of every item at her service.  By dusk she has reduced her estate to about 150 pounds of necessities and high quality tradables--most notable among these the long sword Art abandoned.  What remains is Art's share, she concludes; and besides, he did get away with all the cash.  Morning is soon enough to hit the road; it's too late now and it may be her last opportunity to sleep under a roof.  For the evening's remainder, she sips tea, reassesses relationships, and further contemplates her perplexing lack of relatives till she's fallen asleep.
Much chirping and pain presently heralds dawn's first glimmers.  Her shoulder has become unforgiving, her left arm rendered nearly useless.  Dropping cautiously to the ground she half expects to find Art under the wagon rehearsing excuses, but he remains AWOL.  Frankly, it's somewhat of a relief, for never again could she trust him.
Here left arm is nearly useless and her shoulder is throbbing.  After considerable experimentation she manages to ready the mare by hoisting the saddle from a tree limb, then backing her mount under it.  Securing a makeshift litter proves no less a task.  By early afternoon she's abandoned the campsite, choosing the same direction taken by Snob and company; may they never meet.  Her maps show only scattered farms for the next two days' trot.  It's not going to be a pleasant journey, for even the mare's gentle joggling motion is unkind to her tenderized shoulder.  Concerns that it may be dislodged or fractured plague her thoughts.
Rigging the litter required much longer than expected and she's not progressed as far as she had hoped by day's end.  A grove of broad low trees catches her attention, or rather that of her nose.  Covered with fuzzy white and pinkish blooms of remarkably pleasant aroma, the flowers appear as tufts of cotton candy--a country carnival favorite of hers.   Hundreds of small, spotted, grayish-blue flutterbys swirl about the trees seemingly unable to have enough of it.
While painfully striking flint to iron in hopes of conjuring up a hot cup of tea, a huntsman's horn comes to ear.  The trumpeting is soon accompanied by a great, fast approaching rumbling of hooves.  She rises from the fire making to steady her mount lest it rail against the commotion and scatter her worldly possessions.  Well she has, for the forest lane soon expels a thundering assembly of knights in armor of the practical rather than ceremonious variety.  Shortly thereafter a contingent of squires follows guiding a herd of packhorses.  They pass by with neither a nod nor fare-thee-well.  What might incite such great haste? she speculates.  Were they retreating or rushing to someone's defense?  Anything failing or unable to heed that ominous horn would have surely been trampled and she is thankful to have been off the road.  But such is not her primary concerns, what is are the aching muscles, her nearly disabled shoulder and the scent of rain presently upon the breeze.  Dragging all that fuel and those three goblins to their final reward has taken more out of her than first suspected.  Much remains to do, and painfully so, unless she chooses to wager against the weather.  A poor bet given dark clouds are on the horizon up wind of her position.
Several pieces of thin but tightly woven linen stitched together into a tarp are the mainstay of her housing system.  Not waterproof, but no matter, for geometry is the key.  Choosing a low nearly horizontal branch, she places the two poles from her litter directly beneath about a yard apart.  Each is set upon flat stones to keep them above the ground.  One side of the sheet is rolled around the first pole to secure it then pulled taut over the branch.  What remains is then wound around the second pole.  By this the tarp is securely anchored along its entire length on both sides without the need of stakes, tie-downs or tent poles.  The construction project is a painful, cautious and awkward proposition.  If the clouds should melt, any water seeping through will cling to the underside until gravity bids it drip free of the pole's lower edge keeping her relative dry.  Or at least that is the plan.
Upon the two horizontal poles, our Girl Scout places a layer of locally supplied short sticks to cross between them as a platform.  Next, a mat of fresh pine boughs are installed over the flooring.  By this her sleeping platform remains six inches above the dampness and most of the little things that scurry about the ground in search of something to bite.  Food, clothing, and such are bundled up and stashed at the end against the tree's trunk for safekeeping.  Finally her blanket upon the boughs of pine is laid and a lace work of leather cords strung hither and yon across the tent's open end.  Several metal utensils are discreetly attached to dangle therefrom and chime an alarm if her castle is invaded.  Lastly, her sword withdrawn, tethered to her wrist, and placed conveniently at hand.  Though this may have seemed more enterprise than value received; better the effort than sitting all the night, cold, miserable and soaked like a sponge.  For in this day and age the idiom, to catch your death, meaning pneumonia, is no joke.  Sleep is not fast in coming, her aching shoulder sees to that.  The waning moon arrives casting shadows upon her bed chamber's ceiling allowing her watch a lizard's silhouette cautiously surveying this strange new terrain.
And the rain did come more by the pail than in drops of dew.  And the wind did blow mightily as well, so much so that it became necessary to disarm her alarms if ever she were to get some sleep.  And speaking of sponges here they are now.  Two brothers of the Sandal-Wood order on a pilgrimage to the mountains have come upon Leona's cocoon.  They however had allowed their rain storm insurance to expire and thoroughly disproved the theory, shelter, if needed, could be found along the way.  Completely drenched, they look to the bright side.  Making fun of their soggy state and sport of one more fortunate.  "Look at this if ya please!" one confides to the other.  "Here are we soaked through and suffering a dreadful night."
"By our own foolishness, if I may add," his associate concludes.
"Thank you... for that clarification brother; may I continue?"
"Yes, please do."
"As I was saying; and yet, in spite of our sad state this lad still lazes about two hours after the dawn... snug as a bug in a fine wool rug.  There seems no justice, do you think?"
"Perhaps the fates thought it time we had a bath?  I'm sure we shall dry soon enough, within the next few days at least.  This fellow's preparations are very sensible.  I'm thinking, might we learn something here?"
The small donkey accompanying the good brothers blurts out his dissatisfaction with both being ignored and restrained from joining Leona's mare for breakfast conversation.  "HHEeee-HAAaawwww!"
Leona bolts to a sitting position, blade at the ready and quite prepared to repel borders.  A large frumpy toad having joined her late in the evening sits at her feet, warily keeping one eye on each and wondering what sort of stew he's hopped into.  She fixes her gaze on the two inquisitive, pot-bellied old coots peeking into her tent.  They appear to have been standing, until recently, fully dressed under a waterfall.
"Has it been raining?" Leona inquires.
The sound of her voice verifies what their eyes have just realized.  "Oh dear, 'Tis a maiden."  They back away so as not to give her alarm.  "Please excuse our blundering, milady.  We mean you no distress, I assure."
"No disrespect intended, my friend and I thought you a vagabond as we.  Wondering if perhaps a spot of tea might be shared, or rumors of things hereabout."
Leona moves to the gateway of her repose, "Yes, I would consider trading a pot of tea and even a measure of toast for some local news."
One fellow shrugs his shoulders and smiles.  "Alas milady, there is not a dry twig to be found for at least half a day yet."
In no time her sleeping platform is disassembled and a blazing fire warms body, spirit, tea, and toast alike.  One of her guests produces a crock of olive oil, adding a wonderful accent to their daily bread.  With a meager but satisfying meal under their robes, both now stand totally unencumbered of modesty facing the wonderfully warm fire, their garments unraveled and held out at arms length to dry.  Politely facing away from their host, one might add; even though it was by her invitation they dry themselves thus before catching a chill.
The morning is alive with the chatter of birds.  All are wishing each other well at the storm's conclusion and glad to have had a bath.  Every newly formed puddle has acquired at least one little green frog, each extolling with great exuberance to any lady frog who will listen the benefits of his company and the opportunity presently at hand.
The brothers have dried and warmed to their satisfaction.  "May we take note of your shelter?" one asks.  Leona bids them proceed with a nod and courteous wave of her hand.
"I cannot wonder enough at the perfect way in which this  structure of nearly nothing has functioned."
"What manner of cloth staves off such a down pouring?"
"Feel it," she implores.  "It's soaked; there's nothing special about it.  Nearly any type of material would do, though being of a smooth surface is necessary.  'Tis the steepness of it, sir.  Water is so anxious to follow its course it avoids the opportunity to drip."
"I have seen a drop of water act as you say, but never concluded the usefulness of this theory."  Another matter plays upon my mind.  "I hope I shall not risk your displeasure."
"Go for it!"
"You favor your left arm so, have you been hurt?"
Choosing not to recount the unpleasant details of her christening, she lies.  "Lost an argument with a tree limb; I was dismounted and found myself upon the rocks."
"Brother Jahnis has a skillful knowledge of these things.  If you would allow him, with all due respect, to examine the damage?  Perchance we may assist."
Leona unlatches several of the loops that act as buttons on her shirt.  Thus, exposing the sorrowful state of her shoulder.  Painful-looking bruises extend from her neck to her elbow.  The skin has not been broken, but seriously abraded with some slight bleeding.  Taking great care not to antagonize, Jahnis employs a firm but gentle prodding of the structure.  He concludes the damage is superficial.
"It has not slipped from the joint, nor do I think it broken.  But some mending is due.  Time is needed most of all," he advises.  Nodding to his traveling companion, "Brother, would you bring my preparations?"  A narrow wooden chest soon arrives upon the scene.  Several small clay crocks and pouches of aromatic powders are arranged for his craft.  With mortar and pestle he grinds and blends a balm of thistle, camphor, oil of clove, and other things better left unknown; else, the DEA might take offense at their origins.  Cautiously now, he applies a dab of it in small swirling motions over the bruise.
The aroma is pleasant and natural, not like any fragrance she is familiar with.  Closings her eyes she slowly inhales the vapors; her nose tingles with the scent, then becomes totally numb.  In fact, her shoulder has ceased to exist, too.  This stuff is definitely not an over-the-counter product.  With a thin wooden spatula Jahnis scoops the remainder of the paste from the mortar into a tiny clay cup, folds a patch of soft leather over the top and secures it with a thong.  "Apply just a tiny bit when you retire each night; 'twill soothe the hurting and soften the skin that the touch of your garments do not offend."
"I have things there to trade," Leona entreats, pointing toward the bundles at the back of the tent.  "Choose what you will."
"Even my dear mother would not burn her bed to warm the likes of we two," Jahnis assures.  "My brother and I are pleased we could offer some assistance in consideration of your kindness.  Now, hasten we must to be where we are expected by mid-day the morrow."
"Could you by chance tell me anything of the way home?" Leona inquires softly.
"Home is where you began; thus, one could return by going back the way they came, I suppose."
Unless you are as we," his brother adds, "then home is wherever you find yourself at the moment.  Does that help?"
"I'm sure it will; I'll add your thoughts to what I've learned."  Each offers good wishes and farewells, then the brothers are again upon their merry way.  Though her shoulder seems absent from the facilities at her command, the sense of feeling below the elbow seems in reasonable working order.  The tarp has dried and reconstructing the litter is not near as demanding as the day before.
Though heavy cloud cover remains and those to the south are dark and foreboding, she really must move on.  Such risks are most common in reality, but easily dismissed in the context of a game, at least until last evening.  If I'm caught in a thundershower, I'm going to get wet, and mosquito bites are accumulating.  These are not the sort of hazards one comes upon at the roll of the dice.  Revelations of this sort have thrown her priorities into a state of flux.  The simplest of daily problems are now of consequence.  Why is there no option to simply quit and go home?  If things had gone badly back at the wagon... would I be dead?   Why did Art flee; is he aware of something I am not?  But, wasn't I just talking to him a few minutes ago... or was that... days ago?  This couldn't be going on for days; that's not possible.  How does this play engage all the senses?  The breeze ruffles my hair, the birds and crickets serenade, the fire felt warm, the oil had an appealing taste, and the road is there, right before my eyes.  But where have the other players gone?

Chapter-6

THE CHILDREN CHASE THE DRAGONS AWAY 
WHILE THEIR PARENTS PLAY IN THE FIELDS ALL DAY.

Another day has passed into early afternoon before further signs of the citizenry come to view.  An occasional cottage or garden plot in the distance, a field with a cow or two, but all seem unattended.  The road winds its way along the edge of a rocky embankment.  Several piles of flat stones have been extracted from the shale, but the carts and even tools have been abandoned.  What could be so urgent?
An hour more along the lane and lest she be deceived, voices are near at hand.  Just around the stand of pines she now approaches; children giggle and call to one another as if at play.  Indeed, she discovers there are four, running about the meadow adjacent to a small cottage just ahead.  The three youngest, two girls about six years of age and a wobbly lad not more than two, are cautiously threshing the knee-high grass with sticks.  They advance in a line adjacent to one another as though herding crickets along for the family's chickens.  The fourth, a lad of perhaps ten acts as the trail boss.  He follows behind the others carrying a wooden rake in a defensive posture as though about to attack something; a snake perhaps.
They are distracted but for a moment by Leona's arrival, aside from the older lad who knows a pretty girl when he sees one.  Now, leaning on the rake's handle as if it's been a real tough day, he smiles and waves.  Leona dismounts and approaches.  "Good day to you, sir.  Are your parents home?  I wish to ask for directions."
"Naa, they're all down to the crossing till dark."
"And which way might that be, if you please?"
The lad points in the direction she was headed.  Their brother having broken the ice, the others abandon their games and come to meet the stranger.  They seem amused that she is not wearing a skirt.
"What name do you answer to?" Leona inquires.
"Orion, who are you?"
"My name is Leona, pleased to meet you, Orion."  Her respectful tone raises a smile.
"Are these your brother and sisters?"  He nods a yes.  "What are you looking for?"
One of the young ladies is quick to exclaim with giddy enthusiasm, "dragons!"
"You mean they're so small they can hide in the grass?  I always thought they were much larger."
"Naa!"  The young man clarifies, "they're really little, they can hide anywhere.  That's how come none ever sees um."
"Hum... very good logic, actually.  Like a rabbit?"
"Lot smaller I think.  Ain't never seen one."
A trumpet calls out from the distance.  One of the young girls immediately takes the little boy's hand and pulls him back from the roadside.  They run toward the cottage; the other young lady wisely follows.  Leona leads her mare well off the roadway.  Whereas the man in charge takes a defiant stance in the middle of the lane, leaning a bit for a preview of what will soon come thundering past.  The sound of approaching horsemen is alarmingly apparent.  Not until the teams turn the corner bearing down on his position does the young lad dash back toward the road's edge.  The other children, now safely on the porch of the cottage, watch fearfully as their brother defies the most powerful machines of the day.
A flatbed wagon supported by double axles at both ends and drawn with four teams rumbles past.  A whirlwind of debris and gravel rises in its wake.  The lad turns his back to the onslaught but stands his ground.  The wagon's bed is thick and reinforced with iron straps.  Springs as long as a man is tall support the axles.  Thereupon sits a large strongbox of riveted iron plates securely chained down to rings along the wagon's length.  Two more heavy wagons soon follow; both appear to carry flat iron plates.
The lad shakes the dust from his head and berates their foolish efforts.  "They'll never catch it in that dumb thing."
Leona inquires.  "Catch it?"
"The dragon," he explains in a tone as much to say, you're not paying attention, dummy.
"Right!"  Leona concedes with an affirmative shake of her head.
"It'll burn that thing up like tinder.  Ain't no way ya can catch one."
The danger having passed, the three youngest have resumed their quest.  Leona takes her leave and is preparing to mount up when one of the girls screams.  "I found it."  The little darling has both hands firmly about her dragon swatter and proceeds to thrash a clump of tall grass for all she's worth.  Her sister joins the fray.
Leona and the lad with his rake rush to the conflict.  Upon arriving the girls are off toward the side of the cottage, giggling.
One exclaims to the other, "Let's find another," and they rush off toward the rear yard.
Examining the dragon's lair, the lad frowns then follows his sisters away, shaking his head with notable disappointment.  Leona stoops to find the remains of a bird's nest.  Several scrambled eggs are mingled with the moss and straw.  The youngest boy now appears on the scene.  Not to be left out, he swats the nest with his stick.  Glancing to Leona, he then dashes off to join the rural dragon-disposal unit.  At times it can be difficult to appreciate the ignorance of youth.
She eases the remains aside to reveal a single unbroken egg well beneath the debris.  Hello!  A survivor!  From its location, it must have bounced out or slipped through the twigs during the attack.  Fragile and helpless, it begs to be rescued; she accepts the challenge.  I can't leave you to those little gremlins.
Cradling the egg in her palm, she tears a bit of cloth from an item on the litter and folds it loosely over the egg several times.  For lack of a pocket tucking the little bundle into her bosom for safekeeping.  She then mounts up and continues upon her way. 
The troubling inconsistencies of the game have been momentarily offset by a greater duty--that of finding a bird's nest, where for better or worse she might deposit her newly adopted charge.  By evening the tree-lined road fades to open pastures dotted with small barns and haystacks.  Quite a to-do appears in the works ahead.  Horses, wagons, carts, and small groups of people line the roadway.  Approaching the activities, she notices nearly everyone is carrying some long-handled tool or weapon; this is not a typical social gathering.  Conversations are hushed and the air is tense; serious business is afoot here.
Rows of peasants, 40 abreast, cautiously advance through the fields on both sides of the lane thrashing at the brush with hoes and rakes as they sweep across the landscape.  Many wear leather aprons and some have donned helmets.  Without exception everyone carries some type of shield.  Obviously the children were mimicking these maneuvers, but it's doubtful these folks are looking for bird's nests.  
A rear guard of a dozen or so follows several yards behind each rank; each of them carrying a crock or pail.  Mounted soldiers, they and their steeds extensively protected, prance about in what appears a supervisory capacity.  The activity seems geared toward herding or attempting to provoke an attack by something thought to be hiding in the brush.
Leona is greeted with friendly smiles and gestures as her mount trots by the gatherings; she acknowledges in kind.  Additional groups similar to those patrolling the fields are forming up in the adjacent meadow.  By ones and fives, on foot and horseback, by the cart full and wagon load, all have come to fight the mouse.
Not being an especially hot nor humid day, why then is she beginning to sweat?  This confrontation is not nearly the sort of battle one has come to anticipate in a roll playing game.  Writers of fantasy and daydreamers alike would be embarrassed to present such a minuscule challenge compared to the dragons of lore.  If it's a game, she ponders, why aren't the dragons bigger, slinging fire-balls and tearing everything apart?  It stands to reason they would be more like what she has come to expect--huge bright red things, soaring through the air upon leathery wings with mouth and talons agape--as in the movies.  Not some mouse hiding in a field.  Everything is out of context here.  It's reality and that is not a good sign.  I've never been so unsure of what's happening!
Hints of passing conversations attest to the population's collective concern.
"I've heard an entire troop of Whyian's guard was burned up in a flash," one excited fellow relates.  "They was camping outside a cave in Howeria valley.  Next thing, they was gone."  The storyteller's audience lingers on every terrible detail and he loves it.  Hasn't had so much attention since he dragged himself from a pond with a big old snapping turtle clamped down on his toe.
"Was right there it happened, night 'fore last," another exclaims, pointing toward a thatched cottage a quarter mile off the road. "Burned Hebb's dog to a crisp.  They's lucky it didn't come in the house ferum."
"Did ya hear 'bout the witch got one tied to a stick?"
"What good'll that be?" a curious lad inquires with a wide-eyed grin.
"Can't turn around ta get at'er." He rebutts.  "Points that stick at folks, woosssh!  End of um!"
Rusted armor and shields of every kind, most severely dented and poorly maintained, are being dispensed from carts along the roadside.  Stacks of heavy leather aprons are piled near at hand for those who prefer more mobility over the security of iron.
The fleet's battleship, the self-same wagon that earlier tested young master Orion's courage, waits ominously for its terrifying prisoner.  The lad was right.  The device is so incredibly cumbersome as to be on a par with the Maginot line, its only practical intent, to assure the population that their lords and masters are willing to expend vast sums on their behalf.
A wooden ramp floored with plates of iron has been attached to the side of the bed extending outward perhaps fifty feet into the field.  Metal barriers have been erected on either side to restrain and direct anything herded onto the ramp toward the waiting iron chest.  Additional interlocking plates are being set up in the field creating a flared funnel-like barricade narrowing as it approaches the ramp.  No less than eight men toil to set each iron segment in place.  All in all it appears a contrivance for gathering randomly fired cannon shot.  The commander of this weapons system is a stout fellow of morbid self-sacrificing disposition.  Tightly clenched in his fist is the chain.  What chain you may wonder? the one holding the trigger in check which releases a massive spring-loaded drop door.
A platform erected above the strong box supports two ceramic vessels with pour spouts.  Likely they should bear a skull and crossbones.  These are set upon cradles, likewise spring-actuated, causing them to pivot automatically when the drop door strikes a releasing mechanism as it seals.  Apparently the plan is to drown this menacing demon.  A masterpiece of Rub Goldberg Defense Contracting the likes of which only the higher echelons of the Pentagon would dare attempt to justify.  Any creature requiring this level of containment is not going to back down from those fools in the fields, she assures herself, however many there may be.
Every device of such extremes requires an active ingredient; this charade is no different.  Well off to itself on a patch of rocky ground, noticeably unattended by the curious, sits a stout wagon.  Thereupon a huge ceramic crock, taller than a man in fact, with iron reinforcing bands drawn tight around its perimeter.  A lid with the appearance of a sorcerer's tall hat, tapers upward to a narrow vent which sputters and chokes as it expels a yellowish vapor.  Two brave fellows draped in heavy leather robes and wearing long pointed shrouds over their heads with tiny mica windows are in attendance.  They dispense the tanker's payload into ceramic buckets and ferry them to the roadside.  The dousers, as she has heard them referred too, gather the crocks and form up as the second rank of each contingent sweeping the fields.  "Hhooollllyyyyy Sshhhiiiitttt!"
One such douser, obviously uncomfortable with his assigned task, sets a bucket on the ground as Leona's mount trots near.  He's wearing rigid boots with metal shields, mitts, and a leather apron laced up the back like a hospital gown.  The hem extends well below the tops of his boots and the collar is cinched tightly around his neck.  The fellow appears as a two-legged cow turned inside out and wearing a tin hat.
"What have ya got there that warrants such anxiety?"  Leona inquires.
The man picks up a rusted forearm guard from the roadside.  He turns away, shielding his face as he cautiously slips it over the edge of the pail.  The liquid boils up around the armor as it dissolves amidst a dense cloud of yellowish fog-like vapor, an apparition the fearful fellow is careful to avoid.
"Aquaregia!"  She cautions, looking toward the ranks of people combing the fields.  "What are those fools doing?"
A robust old fellow with thick silver hair and the manner of a tradesman offers up his opinion.  "Ah dragon's come 'mong us, er so they say.  That poison is thought ta be the only remedy.  I'd venture all this is more an excuse ta avoid several days' chores, but call it what ya will."
"This seems not the best approach.  Your dragon could be no worse company than an acid of that strength, and in open buckets!  I can't believe it."
Elsewhere, but not to far away, a strapping young man with a short beard speculates as oft they do regarding unfamiliar females who venture into their domain.  "Don't see many that choice wearing pants and riding ah horse full saddle.  All ta herself I'd say, toting her things along behind like that.  That sort be ah fine time spent up in Billy's loft, then on her way again without another thought 'bout it, I'd say."
His friend nods in agreement, pointing out Art's weapon; "There, tucked in 'longside 'er saddle, not the kinda thing ye find lying around, is it?  Probably belonged to ah fella thinking 'long the same lines as you.  Got another strapped on her leg, too.  Funny that, but she's got more iron than the constable's a carrying."
"Ya worry too much," the lad responds as to justify his amorous fantasies.
"I'd 'spect she'd hand your brass right back to ya on ah tinker's tray," his friend muses with a cautious smirk.
"'Member that lad up on the hillside over to Correy," another pleasantly reminds, "couple years back?  'E run afoul one of'em gypsy wenches.  'E just sorta squeaks and whizzes when 'e tries ta talk 'ese days.  Had ah little blade fixed to'er ring; nearly cut 'is throat.  Got clean away with 'is goats, took 'is still, and 'is boots too and near about all 'is clothes."
"They always got 'least one more hid in their boot, too," adds another cautious lad.  "That dragon out there... be ah pleasure ta do business with compared ta ah gypsy wench if'in ye get'er spitten mad."
Fact is, none have the nerve to approach and they care not to have their friends try and succeed where they themselves dare not tread.  Of course there is always one who considers this sort of rhetoric a challenge.  Taking up the gauntlet, a tall, slim fellow approaches Leona with a assured smile.  He bows in a very gentlemanly manner and makes his pitch.  "Conall Esail at ya service milady.  
We've nearly got us a full regiment; four more and Lord Hem 'ill sponsor us.  Join our ranks, ya could share ah purse of ah thousand in silver.  I'd stand with ya, keep ye from harm at my peril, I would."
"A gracious offer, sir," Leona concedes.  "But I'm traveling and quite anxious to get to where I should be."
"Tiring pursuit that; you'll be wanting ah good night's rest then.  I know ah fine loft would be put at ya disposal," he assures confidently, "'long with a fair measure ah ale ta keep ye warm.  And good sweet hay enough ta suit your mare, too."
Leona affords him a smile for such gallant effort.  The fellow's pick-up lines are far more eloquent than the roguish BS she's heard at the campus sports bar.
Her self-appointed silver-haired knight laughs, coming to her rescue in a jestful manner.  "I know this scalawag," he muses colorfully, "and 'tis not ah dragon's tail 'ee has on is mind either."  She cannot but blush with a chuckle in appreciation of her new advisor's discreet implications.
Much to her young suitor's delight, she leads her mare off the road and dismounts.  "I've had no better offer, sir, be assured, but still I must decline.  Even for one night I dare not tarry or the way could be lost."  The lad is disappointed, but his broken heart will probably mend within the hour, unless he spies another pretty maid sooner.  Nodding respectfully, he rejoins his friends.  A gentleman he was indeed, as few she knows of his age are willing to accept a lady's first 'no' for an answer.  Nor the second or third in fact and she will probably not be privately vilified, cursed, or slandered for declining.
More curious than she's willing to admit, Leona returns her attention to the old gent who playfully scuttled the lad's advance.  "I know little of dragons and even less of slaying them.  I'm told they're very small," she waves her arms aside. "How is it possible then to find one hiding out there?"
"Same way as needles are found if ya lost one in a haystack--when ya sit on it."  He assures with ah cherry grin.  "These fools think their quarry's going ta burn off the end ah some fellow's hoe and give its self away.  From what I've heard of'em it'll hardly be that.  I expect you'd see ah whole rank of'em turn ta cinder and half ah acre set to burning.  And the rest, they'll be a running in all directions like the sorcerer's demons was up their arses."
The old fellow approaches and casually alludes to the exposed hilt of Art's weapon with a glance.  "Don't know where ya might av found that, don't care either, none ah my business.  Might save ya some grief if'en it were more out of sight, though."  She acknowledges his counsel with a discreet nod, glances about to see if anyone is paying her any mind.  Thus assured, she retrieves a small blanket from the litter and flips it over her mare's back and the saddle.  "That'll do," he advises with a smile. 
"Somehow, I don't imagine there's really a dragon to be found," Leona quietly speculates.  "But the open pails of acid, I can't believe the risk they assume carrying that around in the fields.  What's the purpose?"
"If the advance rank is attacked," he concludes somewhat sorrowfully, "they're the bait, ya see.  The second row is ta douse the area with that vile poison."
"They throw it at each other!"  Leona's face turns pale.  "You can't be serious," she insists.
"Doubt it would make ah difference to'em that've stirred the little devil up.  Never heard of any that's throwed ah pail yet," he consoles, "but ah fews been spilt.  Misfortune always attends when that stuff's around."
"What about the iron box?"  Leona asks, nodding toward the heavy wagon.
"A beauty ain't it?  Some fool, likely ah wizard, has convinced another fool, likely His Lordship, that if one could be caught it could be tamed and used as ah weapon like the packs of dogs that attend His Lordship's soldiers."  With that the fellow breaks into a jolly good laugh.  "Or they had nothing better ta do with half the iron in all the land."
"Has it ever happened?  Have they ever actually found one?"
"Not yet in my lifetime," he assures, "but some has claimed ta see'em and there are whispers ah their comings and goings in the past.
"What do they look like?" she continues to prod.
He clasps his hands together and shrugs.  "That's the problem, no one really knows; and those who do ain't telling.  If one was sitting plain as day upon ah rock, long as it didn't burn something up they would pass it by.  This foolishness usually begins when there comes ah fire none can account of.  The first accounts ah such are over four hundred years in the retelling and the tale they tell far more distant than that.  Been ah lot of bull heaped on top ah the pile over all them years.  But the walls ah both cities and the bridge tween'um still stand in a place near the winter's setting sun."
"Cities?" Leona repeats.
"Not just cities--great cities, least so I hear told.  One on either side of a river as deep as any sea; ah river so swift no boat might cross.  Ruled by brothers, they say, with eight kingdoms bound ta each and each wanting what the other had, acourse.  Neither side could sire an heir 'cause they was poisoning each other's children quick as they was born.  Hatred got so intense, heard it said even the birds refused ta sing.  Both cities was sealed up with powerful curses when the dragon came and none have dared ta enter either since."
"Then no one knows if the dragons ever got in?"
"No my dear, way it was told ta me, gates were bound ta keep it from getting out.  What order there was twixt the Kingdoms, and even within, soon come ta feuds among the elders.  Everyone desired ta be the new master, 'twas just as well none could reach the bridge.  Fur ya see, it begins and ends within the walls; ya must first enter one ah the cities to cross over.  Legend would have it was their own father locked them in and created the demon ta end it."
"Locked them in!"
"Yes!  They say travelers from that region claim the seals are still bound ta the outside ah the gates.
"Hordes of gold guarded by dragons," Leona smiles, "the classic scenario."
"The greatest kingdoms are not destroyed by pestilence nor invaders."  The old fellow assures, "When there's much ta be had 'tis the greed 'mongst'em that pulls the foundations from under their mighty walls and brings 'em ta their end.  Now ya know as much of dragons as I," he assures.
"That's a teaser for sure."
"If the creature these buffoons pursue is anything like that of fable, ya can see their efforts are fur naught."
"As you are such a wealth of information, may--"
"The way home is the way ya going, though 'tis round about the place ya seek.  Stay with the valley; by day's end ya come upon an inn.  Now I must take up my hay fork and rejoin the folly lest I be excused from the great feasting come day's end.  Fare-thee-well, milady."
"Thank you kind sir," she declares with a gracious nod, then mounts up.  From upon her mare she looks straight to Master Esail, whom she suspects has been keeping an eye in her direction since she declined his generous proposition, she waves.  His continued interest is confirmed, for he bows immediately as one of his buddies wraps him on the shoulder in just.  Who knows, perhaps she will have occasion to pass this way again and so be inclined to look him up.
Most amazing is how close the structure of this entire dragon affair resembles the present-day situation of her own post 911 world.  She wonders if there must not be a text which has been passed from one king, pope, dictator, prim minister, or president to another over the centuries.  For all this farce lacks are colored pennants proclaiming the current dragon terror alert level to keep the peasants ignorant, happily taxed and ever dependent and upon their leaders for guidance and protection.
The Brobose Inn is conveniently located, and not so by chance, midway between Mosheum, the principal city, and the two major villages along the primary route to the border with Sorin.  A rest stop for travelers from the eastern provinces and social gathering place for all who wish to gather socially.  It's preceded only by its reputation for the finest bitter ales, the sweetest blackberry wine, and by all accounts the best venison stews to be had anywhere in the land.
'Tis a grand structure crafted of hand-hewed beams and dressed fieldstone with generous helpings of stucco plaster to smooth things over.  The roof of split cedar shingles has acquired an accommodating, thick plush layer of dark green moss, the better to keep the heat in come winter and most of the rain out.  Steeply pitched, the roof supports a concoction of dormers with tightly shuttered windows, glass being a luxury even for the wealthiest of merchants.  Two massive stone chimneys stand as sentries, one to either side, their portals blackened by the constant need to replenish the stew pots.  A stout thatched barn lies directly behind, more or less attached by a wide covered breezeway--respite for drunkards and beast alike and a source of great adventure and endless delight for the handsome young lad who tends the stock.  For indeed, the country maidens who bring cream and eggs for the cooks always find some excuse, however lean, to visit there.
The Inn sits amidst a stand of magnificent oaks,  fortunate are they to have survived the construction, as such fine logs are always in demand.  This foresight well worth the sacrifice when one considers the value of their shade come the summer's heat.  The cock of the walk, a bouquet of flaming colors, prances proudly about assuring all his plump feathered ladies they are secure in their endless search for bugs.  Doorman, a great floppy old hound, lay near the entry keeping a sharp nose on the comings and goings.  Hardly to ever open his eyes, otherwise, lest the scent of Cele, his arch nemesis treads upon the air.  She, a sly half wild house cat, who raids his food dish when he's been distracted and regulates the Inn's mouse population.
Upon entering, one may choose to the right for a restful sit-down meal or to the left for those more interested in spirits and the news of the day.  The owner, one Mr. Jagat Bose, who acts also as the barkeep, being the most reliable source.  For everyone has a tale to tell and he has all the day but to listen.  And thus, well abreast of every rumor, romance, real-estate transaction, farce, fable and funeral within thirty miles, which is to say near all the world.  His post, the standup bar, occupies one side with a wide entrance into the kitchen just behind.  A grand stone fireplace commands the opposite side of the room.  There within, the spit supports a sizzling rack of venison.  The meat's inviting aroma permeates the room while a low fire sputters and flashes, fueled by the drippings.  Adjacent the bar, an open stairway rises to a narrow cantilevered balcony accessing the guest rooms--four above the kitchen on the south and two larger in the loft above the private dining area.  Vaulted wood trusses keep the roof, which for the most part is also the ceiling, safely in place above the goings on.  Chains dangle from the juncture of each truss to support stout iron rings for lamp lights, candles and the occasional fool who fancies himself an acrobat.
Several fellows, old and worn as the stones paving the floor, sit on either side of a long bench just inside the door.  They pass the day at a game involving dice and colored sticks.  The wager at the moment has two shiny red apples bet against a double handful of shelled black walnuts.  One of the old fellows jokingly plies the Harlot's favor with a basket of tart green plums, she being the selfsame shy young lady with pink hair who, as did Leona, started her adventure from the game room.  Sashaying around as though to tease them all, indeed her pleasant distraction and revealing décolletage are the only reasons they are not sitting in a cool breeze under one of the oaks.  Three well-to-do gents smoke their pipes as they dine at the great round table in the corner while a couple of weary travelers break bread into their stew near the fire.
Leona enters carrying a polished copper skillet, dull by comparison to her smile.  Jagat immediately realizes this is not a cash customer.  He also knows he is going to lose this contest because pots are the domain of the fair maiden who warms his bed and she would likely kill for such a treasure.
Our vagabond of the moment chimes in with her sales pitch.  "This fine utensil could be yours for a pittance, sir, and no hard coin need be in the bargain.  A clean room for the night, a hot bath, and my dinner... what say ye?"  She flashes her eyes like a silent film star.
Jagat calls out toward the kitchen.  "Wife!"
She replies from the kitchen, unseen.  "I despise pots."
He confides quietly to Leona.  "Stand your ground, for sure it is she will recant."
He repeats his request with a deep serious tone.  "Come hither, woman."
She emerges from the kitchen, tall and willowy, a gem-in the rough of 30 plus years.  She answers to Klena and her sour attitude changes instantly to that of a child on Christmas morn.  "Finest copper it is!" she purrs, taking hold with both hands as one would cradle a dove with broken wing.  "I'd wager 'Is Lordship's hearth has no better."
A startled Sir Art of Atlanta peeks around the corner of the kitchen entryway, then quickly makes his presence absent from view.
Leona's gleeful salesmanship turns to retribution.  "You miserable bastard," she shouts with the contempt of a mother abandoned with four starving children.
The Owner winces as Leona sweeps up the skillet from Klena's gentle embrace and heads straight into the kitchen without so much as a may I?  The girl unable to find enough pleasant adjectives to celebrate their reunion, advancing as she hurls indignities of every caliber.  Ev and Edie, two short stout kitchen maids in their mid-fifties are taken aback at these revelations of their handsome new helper's character.
"You sleazy, despicable, nauseating, cowardly, miserable milksop!  You ran and left me to those thugs."
"Oh my!  Sounds worse than he looks," Ev confides to Edie with bright eyes and a curious grin to match.
Art's concern fades for a moment as he ponders the meaning of Milksop.  He looks toward Edia for some indication of how terrible of an insult this may be.  She just shakes her head slowly and lowers her eyes.  When Art refocuses on Leona's attack, Edie turns to Ev and snickers.  Leona is holding her skillet up to Art's face so he can see his reflection in the polished metal.  "You see this sorry excuse of a man looking back at you?  When I'm done every feature of that face is going to be permanently impressed into this pan, like a monument to jackasses."  Art cringes, realizing finally this is not a drill; his lady fair is really going to cream him.
Klena comes to his rescue--or better said, to the rescue of the fine copper skillet she's fallen in love with.  "No!  You'll dent it," Klena exclaims as Leona draws back to whack him upside the head.  Art still in total disbelief that she would actually do it.
"Here, this will do ya."  Klena expeditiously exchanges an iron version for the copper one.  "owes me nine months' wage; take care not to damage'em beyond 'is usefulness.
Caught just as he was on his way to deliver two overflowing pails of slop to the hogs, and restrained by leg irons, he has few options.  Attempting a limited retreat he's foiled by his ankle restraints, crashes clumsily backward dousing himself with scraps, scum, and grease.  The kitchen help scatters, chickens flurry about in a feathery panic, and Cele, the resident mouse dispatcher dashes for cover, crouching beneath the butcher's block.  Always in her feline mind, the near miss of a wooden bowl full of steaming bean soup dispatched when one of the customers expressed a less than flattering remark about Klena's end of the day leftover specials.
Ev and Edie are excited to no end at the confrontation; it appears their new recruit is about to get his comeuppance by this flaming wench, a rare sight in these times.
"From Sir Galahad to kitchen knave in three days," Leona continues.  "Well done scoundrel!"  Klena's well-timed interruption has allowed Leona to calm just below the boiling point, enough at least to save Art's ass for the moment.  She halfheartedly flips the pot in Art's direction taking comfort in his present garbage strewn state of affairs.  He dodges as it recoils from the stone floor with a hollow "Clang".  Leona exits in a huff, confident that whatever predicament he's gotten into is no worse than he deserves.
In defense, the best Art dare offer is a worn clich'e.  "It's only a game, hon!"
"Dork!" she fires back in reply.
Edie's smile lights up.  "That's a new'un!  Hey Ev, what's a dork?"
"Ah... don't know.  But ee's a pretty one," she smiles with her round rosey face.
Klena ducks back into the kitchen to take stock of Art's situation.  She finds him sprawled on the floor covered with the sow's dinner, but still intact.  Turning first to Ev, "Find'em some clean clothes."  Then to Art, "Clean this slop up and be quick, then fire the kettles and draw a good hot bath to the corner room for my new guest."
Leona has invited the innkeeper's wife to join her.  Hence, the two most important ladies in Art's life, his ex lover and his turnkey fill each other in on his misadventures.  Half an hour passes before Art's seen again, backing into the dining area through a door beneath the stair at the room's far end dragging a stout oak tub.  The corners are sealed with pitch and joined via a series of iron shoes into which tapered wooden wedges have been driven to form a watertight seam.  Archaic and heavy, but for Art it's all in a day's work for some time to come.  He props the tub on end and walks it across the room on the corners.  From there it rises with great effort one step at a time toward the balcony until it has disappeared from view near the far end.  Only the thumping of its travels remains to indicate the awkward vessel has yet to reach its destination.
Relating Art's heroic tale of woe, Klena informs, "when he turned up he was covered in dirt and blood.  Looked as if he'd been hiding from the constables in the barnyard.  You've gotta be careful; desperate men can be dangerous.  Worse yet, if 'Is Lordship is after 'im, it can bring a lot a trouble to ya door.  Sounded like a merchant from the way he talked, had a pleasant manner too, so we took a chance, cleaned'em up."
"Yeah... he's a bull shitter," Leona advises.  "But I wouldn't have believed he'd pull the stunt he did."
"He boasted of slaying no less than four bandits that had set upon some hapless old gypsies.  After they were safe away he was forced to flee when a great many more came upon'em."
"There was but one," Leona assures, "and at that he was disarmed and helpless.  As I came to his aid, two more appeared.  He ran!  Left me... with not a word the others were approaching from behind.  I'll never trust him again, never!"
"You was fortunate to get loose of'em.  Sadly it doesn't do any good to report such things--none at all in fact."
"Just as well.  I prefer to forget it ever happened."
Klena places her hand softly upon Leona's arm and inquires discreetly.  "You didn't get free of'em, did ya?  If they hurt ya, Ev can be very comforting in such matters.  If ya wish, I could have'er visit with ya later."
Leona smiles shyly.  "Thank you, I appreciate your concern.  But really... I was too quick for them; got a bruised shoulder, that's all."
Such a sad state to behold is all one might say of the roasted rabbit Edie has just served up.  There isn't nearly as much left as might be expected after the fluffy fur coat and head had been removed.  Leona consoles herself that little may be done for it now but to appreciate the sacrifice it's made on her behalf.  Having fast food on every corner has made life a lot safer for the bunnies in her world.  Art jingles along, ferrying steaming pails of bath water up the stairs while the ladies dine.
