"That's a good way to keep track of him," Leona commends; "kind of like keeping a bell on your cow so it doesn't wander off."  Klena agrees with a nod and casual smirk.  Giddy at the thought, Leona can hardly wait to sink into her bath; the experience alone shall make the two days ride worthwhile.  And it's going to be twice as pleasurable having known Art himself drew the water two buckets at a time.  If nothing else her appreciation of many things is being sharpened.  'Tis doubtful she will ever take hot and cold running water for granted again.
One of the old men approaches the bar with an empty tankard and a lead coin in hand.  Anticipating his request, Jagat produces a hefty pitcher of ale and antes up six iron strikes for change.  "You'll soon not be able to tell the dragons from the cows."
The elder fellow replies with a wary glance, "Mystical creatures, sir, I've seen their handiwork."
Again Jagat anticipates, "Hebb's dog?"
"Aye, you've heard then.  Burned up to a cinder it was."  Pointing an unsure finger toward the hearth, "Not the kinda fire we know," he assures.  Now relating, according to reliable sources, the events of two evenings previous.
Seems it was well after dark when a peasant couple, peacefully retired, were awakened.  Their dog had begun to bark; the commotion intensified and soon became frantic.  The man rose; he could see his dog in the moonlit landscape, but no intruder.  Better he investigate than risk a fox finding its way into his hen house.  As he began lacing his boots an intense light beamed into the room through the open window.  An eerie silence pervaded thereafter; not but the crackle of burning pine boughs remained, as portions of the landscape were now afire.
The terrified couple dashed away seeking the assistance of neighbors.  They found sections of fence alongside the cottage afire along with some of the lower branches of an adjacent tree.  Straw littering the ground was aglow and a wheelbarrow, and a full watering trough near the fence were also burning.  Most strange however, these things were burning only on one side--the same side.
At first light all the neighbors came round to investigate and speculate.  Soldiers arrived later.  They were immediately directed by the onlookers to a gathering near the smoldering fence.  A dog was lying dead at their feet.  It appeared normal till one of the peasants flipped it over with a pitchfork.  The opposite side was completely burned out, the ribs charred, nearly gone.
The old storyteller takes a sip of his brew and continues.  "Um old, but I wants to get older.  Them that seek out such a demon have pebbles in their heads where good sense ott'a be.  Was only a dog.  More a those 'round here than we need anyway, so why not just let the creature be?  But no, they dream of a purse of silver.  Not me, I dream only of that sweet maiden."  He motions toward the Harlot with his brimming tankard and a sly smile.  His wisdom now spent, he and his brew shuffle back to rejoin his friends at their game.
Klena, meantime, explores Art's expeditious transition from wealthy gambler to scullery boy.  "I've not known any to be so strangely curious.  How much did this cost, how much for that?  Where could one thing or another be found?  What wage was expected for all manner a labors?  On and on he went.  Couldn't be sure if he was want'en to buy something or selling it.  Used words nobody ever heard of.  A few acted like they knew what he meant, but I think not."
"Let me guess," Leona imbues with a smile.  "Capitalization, amortization, depreciation, stuff like that?"
"Yeah!  What's he talking about?"
"Nothing important, he's having flashbacks to a previous and for the moment an uneventful life."
She looks to Leona inquisitively, then continues.  "Ice, was a big worry; the lad wanted to save it till end of summer.  Ya only get ice in wintertime, even a fool knows it'll milt.  Ya can't keep it like dried corn or kindling.  Couldn't believe iron and lead strikes was money; seemed to think metal should be easy to come by as gathering horse shit.  Had more plans than a new groom for 'is bride on their wedding night.  And he was frantic to find something to scribble on; thought parchment should be common as dirt.  Next thing ya know he was figuring to make it... out of trees, would ya believe?"
"I don't understand why he's gotten so far off track," Leona confesses.  "We're lost so to speak, trying to find our way back home.  Or at least I am."
"Where do ya call home?"
"In truth, I'm not sure right now.  You wouldn't happen to know where that might be?"
"I've always said home is where ya find it.  Wandered in here about nine years back hoping to save up a copper or two, cleaning and such.  Married Jag, the owner's son, found a home.  Been cleaning up ever since," she scratches the back of her head, "but with no pay."  Leona smiles, thinking comically of how some things have never changed.  "So ya could say your friend's found 'imself a home, 'least till 'is debt's paid."
"What is a lead strike?"  Leona asks.
"A coin with 'Is Lordship's mark pounded into it."  She extracts one from her pocket and drops it on the table with a dull thud.  "Ten of 'ems a copper, but takes ten iron strikes to earn one and ten coppers to earn a silver.  We don't never see gold around here, least till your friend showed up."  Klena displays her wily got-a-bargain smile.  "Being as it's copper, that pot ya was going to bop'em with, it's paid your room, board, and a bath every day for a month, and I still got the better of it.  A wonder he's not ended up in the mines afore now.  Just to hear'em talk ya could tell he's a bit of a shyster, wanting to buy things without coin and get paid now for things he didn't have to sell till later.  For some'um smart enough to read and write he's dumb as a chicken."
"His major is business.  Up-and-coming wheeler and dealer, shyster as you say, but I don't understand how it has become such a factor in our circumstance?  It's as if he was planning to stay."
"Has'e a craft then?"
"It's complicated.  Let's say at times his thoughts get so far ahead of him, he becomes an idiot."
"As when he took to jiggling gold coins in 'is hand for all to see, which no man smart enough to lace 'is boots would do."
"That's Art!  Yes... perfect example."
"Ya could buy twenty acres of fine bottom with a nice cottage, a well, and a good team, maybe two, for what he squandered.  Soon became the best friend of everyone, he did.  Folks was going home and bringing their kin back to get in on it.  Then sure as 'is Lordship will hang ya for not paying your tax, the gambling started.  Cleaned'em out in no time; lost more then 'is worth, too.  Hard labor or worse till the end of 'is days if I hadn't convinced Jag to put up 'is debt.  Not like I got eyes on'em, but he's a nice-looking lad.  If he ever got free of the mines alive, just end up another rogue."
"That explains the chains."
"An assurance he'll remain till 'is debt's paid."
"I don't have a problem with that!" Leona muses auspiciously.
"Why does that always happen?" Klena wonders aloud.  "Only one I know doesn't gamble is Jag; 'course if he did I'd skin'em and hoist 'em on that spit," pointing to the fireplace, "and he knows it.  He's a good man, the best... and I know it, too."
"You understand how most guys like to fight?  I imagine gambling a form of combat favored by those who prefer anguish or ruin over pain of death."
"Sounds about right."  Klena agrees with a nod.
"Trouble is, a little hindsight ain't gonna get it; at issue is how to deal with Art.  We were intended to be a team, back each other up; but he's proven a danger to me and a hazard to himself.  Under the circumstances he's about worthless."
"He'll be earning seven lead strikes a month against his due.  Bound himself willingly to Jag for nine months more, at least.  Hardly worth it till his hand heals; my hope is he'll improve.  Ya may pay what he owes, six coppers less his wages and collect'em back anytime."
"You know that works... yeah," Leona smiles coyly, "like a safety deposit box.  Works great in fact.  So you don't intend to cash him out, I mean like trade him off or something, your going to keep him, right?"
"Oh yeah," Klena assures, "he's a rascal, but not a trouble maker like some, and Ev and Edie have just about adopted 'em."
  Art is still in fire brigade mode, ferrying pails of hot water from the caldron behind the Inn up to fill Leona's bath.  His ankle bracelets do little to improve the efficiency of his labors, but no matter as work days are not limited to eight hours.  On this leg of his journey a special sort of obstacle presents herself.  He hesitates about half way up the stair.  The Guest, a luminous, Rubenesk, scantily clad female of about 40 years emerges from her room.  The balcony is narrow and she is a big girl.  Art knows he isn't going to get past without a pat on the bum--his, that is.  Known to be a heavy tipper on both sides of the scale and horny as a toad, her room is the first at the top of the stair.  A permanent guest of late, since her 'ex' burned their house down.  Some have rumored he fled to escape her endless cuddling.
Those jingling chains going back and forth past her den have proved too much of a temptation.  Emerging to avail her chamber pot for cleaning, she flashes a provocative smile toward Art as he approaches.  "Come forth, lad.  I won't bite ya... very much," she adds with a sly smile and subdued snicker.  As Art eases past she turns her attention in his direction.  Still waiting patiently when he returns, his pails now empty, she hands him her pot.  Another of his collateral duties is to collect, clean, and expeditiously return these, as overnight guests are not expected to use the outdoor facilities.  Lingering at the top of the stair she watches as Art descends.  Calling out to Klena in a May West sort of drawl, she bids politely, "send the lad up when his chores are done; my window is squeaking."  Art hesitates, cringing slightly, then continues on his mission.  Another smile to Art and the voluptuous spider retreats into her lair.
Much to Leona's delight, Klena advises on the finer points of his obligations.  "While he works off 'is debt he may learn a few useful crafts--at least to serve and please a lady... in every way."
Leona smiles at the prospect.  "Excellent!" she concludes.
Art reappears, preceded by the jingle of his shackles, pot and pails in hand.  He glances toward Leona with a sorrowful expression, sets his cargo by the staircase and jingles over.
"Come on... did you hear that?  You've got to bail me out of here!"  He points toward his unfashionable ankle bracelets.  "Look at these, Leo; this is getting out of hand."
"You... can kiss my ass.  On second thought, no ya can't," she adds sarcastically.  "At least not until you had some practice and I think that's in the works.  Besides, you had all our cash.  Come to think of it, you owe me a gold coin, too.  I may just cash you out, sell your paper as they say.
"You can't be serious."
"When you get a few minutes run the numbers.  I figure at your current wage you owe me about fourteen years of humble servitude, dude."
"We're partners, Leo.  You gotta cosign for me on this."
"With what? all I've got left is the mare.  Besides, as you were so kind to point out earlier, it's only a game, right?  So, fetch me some fries and have fun."
"I don't think they know what a potato is."
"Sounds like a personal problem," she fires back.  "Find some!"
"You don't understand," Art pleads.  "It was a calculated retreat.  They were all over the place"
"There were three and two were coming up behind me, and you knew it and didn't say a word.  It was a knife in the back, you shit!" 
"I was bleeding to death," he implores, holding out his bandaged hand.
Flashing a stern look in Art's direction, his principal creditor advises, "Hardly!  Now stop annoying my customers lest my generous offer to save ya hide from the master of the tin mines shall be withdrawn.  I'll collect my due from them and you can toil for the next eight or ten years digging holes and crunching rocks to repay their kindness.  You think it's tough here, try hard labor eighteen hours a day.  Is that what ya prefer?"
"Not really."
"Then ya better get back to filling the lady's tub."
Art retreats humbly; his bath-water boy and chamber-pot duties may not include a 401K, but he needs time to think.  The prospect of becoming a gopher is a step in the wrong direction.  So as not to incite further interest, he very quietly places his pending paramour's pot at the balcony's edge rather than at her door.  At least quietly as one may who is obligated to drag several feet of chain everywhere he goes.
The girls have resumed their chatter when an obnoxious, but legally sanctioned local rogue enters the mix.  The Inn's door swings wide aside and who but the Tax Man swaggers in.  Four of the game's original players are now in attendance.  He's followed by his trainee, the Wannabee, a seedy sort with a narrow face and slight of stature compared to the mass of his mentor.  An arrogant pair these two, with matching duds, hats and amulets.  
Cloe, the resident harlot or barmaid depending on her mood, becomes noticeably uncomfortable.  She quietly slips out of sight.
Klena displays immediate concern of this unexpected intrusion.  "Oh no!  Not now," she quietly confides to Leona, "he'll be upon you like a leach.  Quickly, follow the barmaid away."  She nods toward Cleo who's just about to disappear through the rear pantry door.
Lacking a contingent of trumpeters to proclaim his arrival, he slams his fist onto the counter as though his presence wasn't already obvious to everyone.  That is, except one of the oldsters who had his back to the door and now appears to be considering a heart attack.  "Ale and meat for His Lordship's auditors," he bellows, making a grand gesture to all within the room as everyone is surely honored by his very presence, or so he imagines.  The patrons acknowledge his royal personage with nods or by hoisting their cup.
Leona's casual attempt to exit catches The Wannabee's attention.  In spite of her boyish clothes he recognizes this eager-to-be-absent person as female.  An excellent chance to score a point, he alerts his superior with a nudge and The nods in Leona's direction.  Not being one to miss an opportunity, the Tax Man is quick to exercises his authority to challenge unfamiliar faces.  The security of the entire kingdom could be at stake--spies, terrorists, and such after all.
"You there... with the blue shirt... come here."  He turns and quietly advises his Wannabee.  "Pay attention now!  Learn there's not the need to enter a contest to claim a prize."
Klena rises, keeping her gaze toward the floor as she moves on to resume the duties awaiting her in the kitchen.  The encounter is out of her hands now.  Unfortunately her new friend will have to deal with this arrogant lout as best she can.  Klena manages a reluctant nod as she passes the scoundrel.  Once past, the Tax Man makes a lingering assessment of her posterior, totally ignoring her husband who is apparently obligated to consider the buffoon's prolonged attention some form of compliment.  The privilege of rank one must conclude.  Snatching up his cup, he pushes his chest out and struts toward Leona.  They come face to face across the very table where she was having her dinner.  She smiles shyly; he gestures, she sits.  Preferring to loom largely over his quarry, he remains standing.  "And whose charge might you be?"
"Excuse me," she squints a bit... "charge?"
"Who is your escort?  Do you come here unaccompanied?"
"My traveling companion has found other interests to concern himself for the moment."
"I see."  He toys with his amulet for a moment then holds it forth.  "Do you know what this is?"
"No sir, I do not."
"'Tis the seal of the realm.  Those few who are authorized to wear it are loyal knights in service to His Lordship.  I am empowered by this to act as auditor upon the full authority of the royal senate of nobles.  Now then... who are you?"
"No one really, just a traveler passing through these fine lands."
"Do you have your traveler's tax receipt?"
"Oh... that, yes," Leona plays along to see how far he intends to push it.  "I had one, but I didn't realize I had to keep it.  I'm sorry, I thought as long as I was within these borders there would be no further need of it."
He leans imposingly across the table knowing full well there is no such receipt and that she is throwing his own bullshit right back in his face.  He presents his proposition in an aggressive whisper.  "Have you any idea how serious this could become?  Indeed it is your good fortune that I may be inclined to shelter you from this most serious matter.  Anyone but I, you would be off to the mines.  Not a pleasant place for a delicate young maiden... such as you most certainly are."
A compliment and a threat in the same breath; how clever this ass must think himself.
Art ventures out from the kitchen.  Klena grabs his arm and tows him back out of site.  "You don't want to get into this, lad.  She need pay 'er dues, then 'ill go away."
Leona accepts the provocation.  If games we are here to play, then let the play begin.  "It seems there are many kind gentlemen in this land concerned of my future well-being."
"Where will you stay this night?" he inquires bluntly.
"I have bartered for a room here, sir."
"Bartered!  Have you not the means to pay the traveler's tariff?"
"I have means, sir," she replies coyly, "but no coins."
"Then until the cock crows," he commands sternly, "my service shall be your duty."
Leona looks straight into his eyes with the gaze of a demon possessed, for she is becoming increasingly aware of her capabilities.  Why, after all, should the obstacles of this game be treated differently than those of any other?  "So be it, milord," she concedes with a timid, disarming smile.
One of the well-to-dos at the corner table snickers and shakes his head with approval.
Back in the kitchen, the maids are sadly concerned for Leona's well being.  Klena is pacing anxiously trying to think of some device to change the course of events--even so far as to consider offering Cleo double her usual fee to accept the Tax Man's abuse.
Art looks to the ceiling with concern.  "Uh-oh!"  He turns his glance toward Ev, "Hope that guy's not a friend of Jag's cause he just stepped in some deep shit."
Ev consoles, "Um sorry, lad, it's just a way things are round here some times."
"You don't understand; 'so be it' is an ultimatum, Leo's equivalent of back off or pull your pants down and kiss your ass good-bye."
Ev squints and wrinkles her brow, befuddled of Art's comment.
Leona rises and leads the way up the stairs.  She arches her back somewhat, an enticement to highlight her apparently prized hind end.  In fact a distraction, and the more so the better.  Some would call it Novocain; perchance it will ease the pain.
The Tax Man seems unconcerned that his conquest carries a haggard leather sheath with a short sword, though most likely he hasn't noticed.  One end strapped to her left boot and the other tied off just below her knee.  Where most carry such weapons awkwardly swaying from their belts this one rests contentedly at the owner's fingertips.  She ascends with a slow rhythmic sway, each step taking her paramour a bit closer to his cleverly won and much-anticipated reward.  Feeling confident she is bested by his mere authority, he smiles contemptuously; after all, wise females know their place and duty to His Lordship's representatives.  But then, Leona is from out of town; her mating rituals may be slightly askew of his expectations.
As she strides past the chamber pot opposite the Guest's door, she snatches the handle.  In a natural forward motion, pivoting on the toe of her left foot, she swings it overhead at arm's length.  A tremendous momentum develops as it sweeps around full circle.  However, since she has turned halfway about, it now travels toward her attempted seducer on the upswing.  Thus, the lustfully infatuated again faces the lady infuriated.  On this occasion, however, Leona holds the high ground, her suitor yet three steps short of the landing.  The iron bucket rising now in an ever-accelerating arc.  Their eyes meet for but one final passionate fleeting glimpse.  She smiles good-bye, as only a moment remains before these fated lovers shall part forevermore.  One would think a hollow metal object of this type would chime as a bell when struck.  This union, however, produces a sound rather like a good solid pumpkin being stomped upon by a large Clydesdale.
A flying Tax Man is a strange and awkward bird at best.  His attempt no doubt thwarted by gravity and want of feathers, but not the lack of flapping his arms.  Careening along the wall, then off over the edge, he crashes headlong into the tables and chairs below.  A remnant of his lower lip clings to the adjacent wall, poignant reminder of the collision's severity.  The iron lid separates upon impact, flies over her shoulder across the room, ricocheting off the far wall and slams into the dinner setting of the well dressed louts who quietly commended the Tax Man on his clever acquisition of a date for the evening.  One jumps to his feet and reels over backwards covered with venison stew.  Karma's a bitch!
Still carrying her three legged battle pot, Leona descends slowly, focused entirely and much to his distress upon the Wannabee.  She doesn't even look to her handiwork sprawled unceremoniously across the floor, but heads straight for his obnoxious associate.  "Hey..." she coos, "you want a piece of my ass, too?"
Stunned as one struck by lightning, his back to the wall, he can't recall weather the door is to his right or left.  Glancing quickly, he tries to see the opening but the thick posts in the wall construction prevent him from detecting the frame.  He could find himself cornered if he dashes the wrong way.  Instinctively, he begins to draw his weapon.  Leona swings the pot upward catching it between her palms then snaps it forward as one would pass a basketball.  The spinning iron pot with its three sharp stubby feet projecting from the bottom becomes a formidable missile.  He blocks the impact much to the distress of his elbow, losing his weapon, a portion of his chin and several teeth in the bargain.  Knocked backward against the wall, disarmed, his face bleeding profusely and one arm having been rendered useless; he searches desperately.  Where is that confounded door?  
As Leona raises her left foot to take the next step, her right hand catches the hilt of the sword strapped to her leg.  When her foot next strikes the floor with a loud clap, the weapon is in hand.  So smoothly accomplished as to seem it has simply appeared there.  She knows this weasel has set these events in motion.  Nothing would please her more than some offensive move to justify his demise.  For his effort has surely deprived her of that long sought and much-desired bath. 
With a venomous pitch to her voice, she screams, "I'll have your liver on toast for breakfast you little bastard."
In light of her rage and the damages so effortlessly inflicted on his heretofore immortal mentor, the prospect of such a surgery seems quite possible.  Certainly there's no need to dare her prove that proclamation.  The old men have abandoned their high-stakes gaming and push each other through the rear exit.  The Wannabee takes note: A door!  It's on the other end of the room, but he has a potent engine at his command--intense fear.  Dashing between the tables, he skirts the room's perimeter nearly impaling himself upon the kettle's swing bracket as he crosses the hearth.  Spinning out, he crashes to the floor, but never stops peddling and finally scoots head-long through the open rear door.  If Leona were as mean-spirited as she sounded, she could quickly exit through the front and wait for the bastard where the horses are lashed; but she lets it slide, this time.
Cleo peeks around a corner; then steps into view, fully delighted at her tormentor's current state of deconstruction.  Both the well-to-dos, who had thought the Tax Man's technique so charming, now stand quite motionless and concerned for their futures.  Klena braces herself against the kitchen doorway, astonished at the wreckage that just moments ago was the scourge of the entire vicinity.  Art's new girlfriend looks on quietly from the top of the stair, likely concerned for the waste of so much perfectly good manpower.  Ev and Edie jockey about for a view of the carnage from the safety of their kitchen.  One nudges the other and points toward Art.  "an't 'e the lucky one?  She must 'ave a soft spot in'er heart for dorks."
Jagat, his head in his hands, knows there are sure to be complications and conflicts of interest.  Though not uncommon for someone to get his head bashed, nor the first time it had happened at the Brobose, but it's His Lordship's auditors that are usually the bashers.  Though he would prefer to do otherwise, he instructs the stable lad to ride to the soldiers' compound and report what has happened.  The Wannabee is surely on his way to do the same.  And so Jagat must at least appear to have His Lordship's interest at heart.
 Leona glances to the unconscious object of her affection as she saunters by. "Moron!"
The stew splattered well-to-dos take her relaxed demeanor as an opportunity to exit quickly and quietly, before she recalls their insulting consent, the remainder of their evening sacrificed upon the altar of good sense.

"U'm not sure, but I know it's a lot worse than a dork, yep!"

"I know."
"Might be good you don't mention that to her.  We don't want to give the impression she's been betrayed.  Never seen a sheathed weapon come to hand so quick, I didn't even realize she had it."
"She'll need money," Klena reminds as much to ask permission.
"Yeah."  Jagat agrees, "five or six coppers to see her along and a good helping of the dried meat I've set aside for hunters.  About four hours I'd say before trouble gets here.  See she understands the consequences of this business."
Klena remains somewhat befuddled.  "I still can't believe it, a chamber pot of all things."
"Just be thankful your kitchen knave still has his head 'cause I'm sure if she really wanted it, i'd be on a pike by now.  Quickly," Jagat reminds, "getter on her way.  I need tend this jackass and see if he's alive."
The Tax Man is out cold and likely to stay that way for some time.  One of the flattened table's legs has splintered and driven itself deep into the fellow's thigh.  The wound is bleeding profusely, the sliver may have severed an artery.
"Ev!"  Jagat calls out, "round up some bandages and a pale a water to get this morbid business cleaned up.  Edie, I'll need my horse shoe pliers too if I'm to have this stake out of his leg.  Hurry up now, if we're to salvage this valuable asset to our community, we best get started."
The harlot inquires with a tone of hopeful anticipation,  "is he dead yet?"
"No!"
She kneels next to Jagat and counters in a quiet, pleading voice.  "But it could be so."
"Hush!  There'll be enough trouble as it is.  Few weeks he'll starve anyway; his jaw's halfway down his throat, what's left of it."
"That's nice," she contends sweetly.
She stands, casually placing the heel of her shoe on his pinkie finger.  Discreetly raising her weight from the other foot now, she rocks back and forth slightly.  Tiny bones and joints splinter to the crackling sound of sugary revenge--one of those rare little treats that has made rising early this morning worth the effort.  Jagat swats her on the leg and motions her away.  She complies reluctantly, but with a satisfying smirk knowing she has contributed to the misery he shall endure when his senses return.  "Never mind," she purrs, "I think I'm in love."
Klena rejoins Leona to consider the options.  "Ya about murdered 'im, I think."
"He was fortunate we didn't get behind closed doors."
"To stay is folly; you must be away at once, girl."
"I'm going to miss my bath," she relates disappointingly
"Some things are not to be; I know ya understand.  Quickly now, let's have ya on your way."  Klena escorts her through the kitchen and into the stables.
"Listen careful now, or you'll be hanging from a tree before sunset the morrow.  Ya got to leave the litter; the tracks would take'em right to ya.  I'll keep your things safe.  They will expect ya to flee away from'em into the open country.  Unless ya can grow leaves, people hide much better among more people, so make for the city.  Your clothes suit ya now for traveling, but that ass who run out the back, he'll tell 'im how ya was dressed.  Before you're seen change into a country maiden and keep a smile about ya."
"Been there, done this, haven't ya?"
"Not I!  'Twas one of my brothers was not exactly a good citizen.  So then, how to get ya there."  Klena looks to the sky for her bearings.  "Stay with the moon straight into the forest.  When ya reach the creek turn left into the water.  Don't try to rush.  The creek bed is washed to rock; let your mare find her own footing.  It'll be slow, but no track will remain to tell of the way you've gone.  Go far as you can by that path before the sun rises.  Leave the water at first light.  They know these ways too and might station sentries to keep watch further along the water way."
"Yes, good thought."
"'Tis the rising moon ya seek.  Mark your way at night and follow the course when there is light enough to guide ya.  If ya find yourself in the wood without good light, wait; otherwise you risk tripping your mare.  A broken leg for either of you would serve poorly.  Most traffic is upon the roads early; it will slack as does the day.  If you choose to risk the roads, dusk is the best time.  Two, three nights at most to reach the city's outskirts, it'll depend on the clouds.  Stay out of sight to all till you can mix with other people.  The constables will inquire and offer a purse; every man 'ill want it so they'll be anxious to point out any lone maiden they've not seen before.  If someone does catch sight of ya, change direction for half a day at least.  Venture not through the fields.  Anyone doing so is highly suspect and make no fire this night or the next."  Klena snatches some old dust-laden saddlebags from a peg on the wall.  "Here, choose wisely from your things.  Wrap any object of metal in cloth lest it call them to ya."
"Ummm! yes, I understand."
"If ya wish I'll free the lad.  The auditor's horse is probably still out front to carry him." 
"No!  He would be the death of us both; keep him just as you intended.  There will come a time when he and I must take leave of this land.  It's better if I know exactly where to find him."
Klena dashes back to the kitchen while Leona gathers necessities and a change of clothes better suited to a country maiden.  She soon returns with takeout: mostly dried meat, a water jug, and a few coppers to see her fugitive friend safe away.
"You save my life with these treasures and your wisdom; Thank you, I hope I can repay you some day."  
"Don't worry, just be careful and safe."  They embrace as new friends oft do who may not meet again.  "Truth be known, you've avenged many.  I despised that conniving, foul-smelling son of a rat."
"Foul-smelling, sounds like somebody I know, too; I'm really going to miss that nice hot soaking."
"Not so much as your head.  Now go!  Find your way quickly, and remember no fires."
Leona trots off into the diminishing light.  Early afternoon of the next day finds her sitting, sword in hand, her back to a stout hemlock and sleeping.  To assure her blade's not lost in any frantic scramble which may ensue, the hilt is bound to her wrist with a leather thong.  In case riders are scanning the wood she's settled into a small washout at the forest's edge for cover.  A brook trickles along the midst of it, gurgling a respectful good morning on its way into the adjacent meadow.  From here, approaching riders or anyone following the creek bed now in open view half mile distant could be seen.  Mosquitoes dance in the air before her face while their bolder relatives chance to alight on the back of her hand for a sip of breakfast.

Chapter-7

EVERYONE NEEDS A FRIEND,
EVEN A TINY FOUR LEGGED BIRD WILL DO. 

Claiming her seniority to this cool dribble of water in bold ear-piercing tones, a crow initiates our fugitive's new day.  And just as well, for something's amiss.  Leona's eyes flash open with a startled expression.  Bugs!   Her free hand rises to her bosom and she smiles.  Hahhh!  The bird's egg, it's hatching.  I'm so sorry, I totally forgot about you.  What am I going to feed it?  She quickly scans the surrounding ground scratching some leaves aside like a hen, but nothing comes to sight.  Gently reaching into her blouse to retrieve the hatchling, her smile becomes a confused expression.   Something is not quite right here; she quickly withdraws.
A tiny gray lizard, scant more than an inch long, has firmly clasp itself to the end of her little finger.  And it's holding on for dear life.  She attempts to shake it free with a few quick flicks of the wrist, but it will not let go.  "You're not a bird; who do you think you're trying to fool?  Let go of my finger you little creep!"  The lizard's tiny black eyes blink and then close as it begins rubbing its chin back and forth on the tip of Leona's finger.  "Go catch a bug, will ya?"  Leona's attention is captured by the appearance of a beetle running through the debris of the forest floor.  "Look!  There's a tasty one."  She stoops near to the ground; repositioning herself so as to bring the scampering insect closer into the lizard's view.  The beetle dashes past totally unaware of it's being used as bait.  Her newborn remains resolutely attached to her fingertip.  "Come on... go for it.  Not your flavor huh?  Hey, now this looks good."  A small orange centipede dodging and twisting its way around the fallen leaves is next to be offered for sacrifice.
Leona wiggles her finger to motivate an exit.  The tiny lizard jumps free, nosing its way under some damp leaves.  She watches as the small mound shuffles about, all the while thankful she hadn't picked up a snake's egg or she probably would have had to strip to catch it.  The movement culminates in a flurry of activity beneath the leaves; for a moment she's concerned something a little higher on the food chain may have just ate the little critter.  Several damp bugs and a cricket beat a hasty exit from the commotion.  The ruckus settles down and the reptile's little pointed head appears with a tiny blue snail in its mouth.  Gobble, gobble, gone!  "There!  You see how easy that was?  You certainly don't need me."  Leona has long since withdrawn her hand.  The lizard glances back and forth, panic-stricken, searching for that all-important finger.  The first finger it ever saw, and the only one that really counts in all the world, but it's gone.  The tiny critter raises its face to Leona as much as to say "you're not going to leave me are you?"  It begins scampering back and forth like a puppy anxious to be picked up, begging to be cuddled, never taking its eyes off Leona for a second.
"Gimmy a break," Leona sighs, placing her hand back to the lizard's vicinity.  The little creature jumps back onto the tip of her finger.  She raises the tiny beast to conversation level.  "Are you sure? 'Cause I just don't think this relationship can work.  I watch the Discovery channel too, you know.  So I'm pretty sure what's going through that wee mind of yours, but I am not your mother, understand!"  The lizard leaps from her finger to her vest and disappears back from whence it came.  "Ah, you little pervert!"  She flexes and twists her shoulders a bit and giggles just the slightest.  Cheap thrills!  Get over it.  She muses with a playful smirk.
The snap of a twig from the thicket beyond places the matter of misplaced pets on hold.  "We'll talk about this later," she confides quietly under her breath.  Surveying the perimeter, she strains to identify any movement; nothing comes to view.  Her mare has taken a notion to munch the greens in a shaded area between the forest's edge and the suspect thicket.  She cautiously leads the animal from the clearing into the heavy cover adjacent to the tree line.  The distinct rhythm of at least two people randomly walking through the brush becomes apparent.
--
A flip of the coin and we find Mark monitoring the play from the game master's podium, his attention focused upon Leona's expressions and body language for any further sign of distress.  Ever calm, she ignores the idle chatter among the other players and remains focused entirely upon the event at hand.  Her designated partner has fallen to disfavor, their relationship for the time being at least completely dissolved.
Sanaia approaches Mark and quietly informs, "Other interested parties have joined your game."
His eyes narrow as he turns to address her concern.  "Who?"
"Not who," Sanaia assures discreetly, "so much as what."
"How are we compromised?"
"All that transpires there, occurs here.  It follows then the trespasser is among your guests.  Were there any other candles that were not lit?"
"None!"
"Could one of those we used have had more than a single presence attached?"
"If so, it was not the intent."  Concern is flooding into Marwyn's thoughts again.  How he wishes now he had avoided this entire affair at the onset.  "An intruder, why?  I don't understand what they would have to gain."
"One of the Minnon's security escorts could be a trader or spy.  I fear we have too many fingers in the making of this stew.  Remember when I thought it unusual to have Rueshaba's presents at our table.  Someone, I dare not imagine who, but someone, seems intent on interfering with your inquisition.  I can't tell if we are under attack, or inquiry, but someone is stirring our puddle and the mud is blocking my view."
Mark is unsettled at the prospect.  "I may not put her at actual risk.  If there is a need can the spell be terminated safely?"
"If the binding were unraveled now her memories would surface immediately and of course there is the dramatic change in the surroundings also.  Such revelations may prove a hazard to her future well being in this world.  Whereas, the interloper is but another element of her dream.  It seems benevolent if that's possible."
"From our world or hers?"
"Not from hers', I assure you."
"Are we at odds with the Minnon?"
"No!  On that account all is in order; but that was the good news."
"And the bad?" he dares as one perplexed, slowly running his fingers through an abundant crop of hair.
"Her safety net is lost; I've tested my access to her thoughts, I was denied.  Aside of the skunks, I have not, nor do I intend, but were the need to arise... I could not influence her actions nor the surrounding events.  Your game will conclude upon its own terms."
  "Find a way back, you must.  Lest I find myself accountable to the Henzecs for all I have set in motion here, not to mention the security of a future queen, I suppose."  Sanaia nods her agreement and retreats.
Thus, back we are again, back within the bounds of Leona's imagination.  There to play catch-as-catch-can while she attempts to identify intruders of her own.  Although generally cooperative, this morning her mare has taken the notion breakfast shall not be interrupted.  Apparently from her mount's point of view the consequences be dammed!  After all, they're not going to hang a horse as an accomplice.  It continues munching leaves from the tips of branches encompassing their collective hiding place.   There is little she may do aside from remaining very still and wary of the slightest misplaced sound.  Countless tiny carnivores are pleased of the opportunity her caution affords.  The elements of nature seemingly forever hungry, they dine upon her person at their leisure.
An hour has passed quietly; if there were a search party surely they would not lie in wait.  Finally choosing to break cover, she quietly approaches the clearing's edge for a look-see.  This time it's she who snaps the twig.  Suddenly two does spring up from the tall grass no more than ten feet away.  Thinking herself caught for half a moment she jolts into combat mode.  The adrenaline spike lingers for a few seconds, then subsides leaving her covered in perspiration, a gentle reminder of her outlaw status.  The does both fix their large lovely eyes on Leona, soon all that remains are their fluffy white tails pointed skyward and bounding across the meadow. 
Strangely enough, the birds still chirp and the breeze still shuffles the leaves just as they did the day before.  Could it be they don't care?  Did they ever?  A harmless sparrow sits upon a low branch very near; it watches as she passes.  No reason to be particularly concerned, but then, are they not shy cautious creatures, more likely to be on their way at the first provocation?  What master might entice, and by what means to keep this timid creature from taking flight?
--
In a most ungracious place, foul, damp, gray, and bleak, there stands an architecture of despair.  Random heaps of stone blocks assembled not of mortar, but rather the will of their master.  Vaulted ceiling so high reason would deny they could exist.  Tall slender windows draped of fabrics thick enough that a crossbow's bolt would find them difficult to breach.  Passages sodden and narrow, more the appearance of sewers, perhaps their burden to drain away the misery manifest there within.  Shadowy figures lurk about the perimeter, cling to the buttresses, and perch upon the stone gargoyles that jut randomly from the pilasters and walls.
The portal into the hearth is large enough to accommodate a wagon drawn by four abreast.  Two great stone trolls support the lintel upon their backs; a thousand years of soot cling to their grim faces.  Chains and hooks dangle haphazardly from places above and large caldrons are stacked in the corners.  More a heap of charred bones than remnants of logs, the ash piles silently scream "Run for your life."   Long dark foreboding wooden tables, their tops thick and irregular, stand at attention against the adjacent wall.  One might suspect of them a fine facility for butcher's work.   
Great baskets woven of iron straps sit atop two rows of stone columns that flank the room.  Mounds of ash have amassed around the base of each, heaped up higher than a man is tall.  Seething charcoal fills the baskets.  As the glowing chunks are of themselves consumed, the remnants trickle from between the lattice, tumbling to join the smoldering accumulations upon the floor.  Hardly do they offer enough light that a moth may find its way.
The Witch, Rueshaba, who's real name may not be written or spoken sits upon a massive polished obsidian bench, the edges cut sharply true and square.  It has neither a back nor sides nor the comfort of a cushion.  Why would someone possessing of such authority hesitate to lavish comforts upon herself?  Could it be she feels not?   A thick heavy cape of coarse fur the color of dust is draped over her shoulders, wrapped about in a manner concealing all but her deathly pale face.  So grim the expression thereupon, a corpse would appear refreshing in her presence.  A great oval mirror stands near, the glass, if that it be, red as blood fresh from a dying man's wounds.  Leona's image moves across the crimson pane as it might be seen from a certain sparrow's point of view.
On either side of milady's throne stands a tapered round pedestal of polished gold, these twice the height of a man at least.  The baskets of glowing charcoal present reflections most unique to complement their presence.  Atop each of these a narrow round cage, thick rods of hexagonal quartz crystal thereabout to keep her prizes at once safe and at bay.  Within each stands a solemn old man, his head bowed, his eyes sewn shut, and his wrists secured to his ankles with bindings of iridescent white iridium lace; the restraint of choice when magical powers are involved.  Their garments luxurious and soft, of the finest white linen, hems and cuffs trimmed with belts of burgundy colored silk profusely set of gray moon stones and diamonds.  Prisoners yes!  But still respected well above any of her other reluctant guests.
Snob was most upset at being made the fool by some arrogant smart-ass little wench.  Thus, he and his trusty sidekick Pious have come to strike a bargain with the devil-designate of these lands.  Unusually confident and at ease given his present company, one may hardly avoid calling to mind the paraphrase "ignorance is bliss."  Pious, being of the order of sorcerers is much more in tune to their pitiful situation.  Even the wrong thought could be their ending, and Snob does have a way with words some might think offensive.  They stand before a table upon which sits a small open chest, a generous heap of gold coin therein and one black pearl--her dark majesty's standard fee for terminations, providing the body need not be returned.  Rueshaba adores black pearls; she has them ground to fine dust and mixed with her wine.
Addressing her guests while looking toward her all seeing mirror, she asks, "is this the unfortunate one to whom I shall deliver your vengeance?"  They both nod affirmatively.  "Speak the word!  Let there be no doubt of our bargain."
"Yes!" say both, Snob eager to have done with the wench, and Pious eager to have done with this entire and most stressful business.
"For her an agonizing death, for you the sword strapped to her leg... correct?" 
"Yes!"
"Granted," she hisses contemptuously.  "Now be gone, vipers."
Pious encourages a hasty silent exit, being careful not to notice too much of the decor, his most sincere wish to avoid anything that may give rise to offense.  An abundance of life forms sheltered from view among the shadows follows their departure with some disappointment.  There have been times when the master announced an unscheduled banquet for her guests.  Each of her pets has favorite parts, but it's always a first-bite first-served affair.  Thus, one must be very quick or end up with something not as good--just a smelly gnarled old toe instead of a nice tender tongue, for example.
Once they've left, several things more or less alive crowd around the throne, each vying for a friendly reassuring pat on the head as any puppy might when the coast has cleared of strangers.  "Everyone thinks me the wicked one, why is that my pets?  I am but a hireling."  All quickly agree with subtle whines and whimpers to curry favor.  "These things I do are the deeds of others--those who care not to soil their hands with blood or marrow.  Every one to the last of them by far worse than I, their spirits blacker than mine shall ever be.  How unfair!  I am but a slave to their foul corrupted thoughts, yet all see me as the ruthless master of my deeds."  Could this be? a smile has come upon her face.  "I do fairly well enjoy it though, as one delights in scratching a most intense, but lovely itch."
She rises, drifting effortlessly across the room, safely bundled within the confines of her cape.  Movement of her royal personage causes quite a stir within the household; from every corner comes more of her pets.  Dark and shadowy, coarse and foul, two legged and four, with claw and talon, and hook and fang, both large and small, and fat and tall, gather one now, then gather them all, at their master's beck and call.  They know it's to be a night out, an adventure in the wood; a depraved good business with blood to spill, flesh to rend and bones to crack.  They hiss and growl, some have even begun to scrap, begging for their master's attention.  Heavy deep-throated bells toll from towers somewhere above; thunder begins to crackle and lightning sputters and flashes across the late evening sky.  For wicked is as wicked does and a wicked night surely this shall be.
Two well-dressed senior gentlemen confined atop pedestals of gold, each to the other turns ever so slightly, coy smiles strained upon their sealed lips.
--
Safely absent from this frantic home-team pep rally, an unsuspecting Leona lies contentedly sleeping.  Snuggled up for the evening beneath an aged maple.  Woodpeckers have converted the thick dead branches above into a community of condos, yet it remained well shaded.  Good for keeping the dew away, for it dampens one's spirit to rise a soggy sort come light of day.  Best about this spot is an abundance of large stone outcroppings and boulders that offer a measure of concealment from any passing near.  Ever inquisitive, the sparrow that has been sprinting from tree to tree along her way all the day now sits calmly in the self-same tree.  A silent vigil its duty to keep, lest the object of interest be lost and that would never do.
Oh, but surely something wicked this way comes!  For a mist thick as honey begins to seep through the surrounding brush.  Dense and milky, it rolls across the forest floor enveloping all within its path.  Several large rocks that stand as sentries might, they to guard a lady's bed chamber through the night, yet so discreetly bypassed as to be the lady's undoing and none the less a witch's delight.  The mist boils up over Leona's form; she struggles with her breathing, but does not awaken.
Animals have a keener perception of impending danger.  Bird, her inappropriately named pet lizard and barely 14 hours old as yet, is extremely concerned of mom's present circumstance.  Tiny nostrils flare as his head turns to and fro, trying to keep watch in all directions.  The little critter runs anxiously across Leona's vest, neither his movement nor voice capable of alerting her to the crumbling state of security.
Shadowy four-legged forms begin to permeate the mist; they grope about the area cautiously, their heads hung low to the ground.  A large narrow hand of long bony fingers with talons at their ends moves toward Leona from above.  The knuckles are encrusted with jagged spines; were it not for the arm there attached one might think it a spider.  The fingers begin to spread as the wicked appendage approaches her face.  Salivating in anticipation, the crouching beasts watch; they know after the master's first strike the struggling victim is theirs to rend limb from limb, each morsel to be savored as children might their holiday treats.
Bursting into spontaneous combustion, the hand ignites as if reaching into the unseen exhaust stream of a fighter jet straining at full throttle.  The perishing limb quickly withdraws from Leona's vicinity.  Its astonished owner retreats, her robes and hair smoldering from the intense heat.  She stands motionless facing the sky; eyes and mouth wide open attempting to relieve the intense anguish with a desperate silent scream so shrill the bats soaring above fall to earth dead.  Her hand held high above her head, the fingertips aglow like remains of dry twigs just withdrawn from a raging furnace.  The breeze encourages them turn to ash.  Flesh, if that's what it was, reduced to glowing charcoal, the bones within crumbling like spent kindling as one smoldering joint then another falls away.
Two wolf-like demons anxiously await the master's command.  The contempt in her eyes alone is enough to order them forth; both charge off in Leona's direction.  The first leaps high over the brush toward the clearing.  The demon combusts violently in mid-flight, disintegrating like a kite of flaming tissue paper.  Burning remnants twirl awkwardly through the air as they are thrown back toward the witch.  The smoldering hindquarters lay twitching at her feet.  The second lands astride Leona's legs.  Teeth glaring, it rears up to no avail, the rapidly incinerating carcass hurled back against the rocks.  There it dissolves helplessly into little more than scorch marks and glowing bones.  Rueshaba's pets continue the attack, charging blindly to their doom.  Nothing may approach the seemingly unconcerned maiden, lest it be completely incinerated, yet no flame has yet to be seen even in the pitch of night.  Smoldering remnants of leaves are falling like glowing snowflakes; the branches above Rueshaba's head smolder.  Her image gropes away wailing curses into the night; so vile are they as to make ill every spider within reach of her voice.  Even the bats cannot fly with such disturbing thoughts in the air; they take to dangling from the nearest branch till the chaos has subsided.
Returned now to the great reception hall of her citadel, Rueshaba sits before her blood stained mirror to sort things out.  She soothes her damaged parts in a vat of simmering tallow and mouse urine while munching crispy little fried reptiles.  "Where is she?" the crone commands.  "Come hither little witch.  I would know the place you hide."  Leona's sleeping image comes into focus.  The air is heavy with smoke; several fallen trees in the vicinity still burn.  Not yet even troubled enough to wake.  How can it be? the incensed hag wonders.  Nothing in all the realm has ever resisted me; who is this viper?"
She shouts to her underlings.  "Bring to me my books."  There begins a rumbling of something heavy ever so slowly moving near.  So it is they come into view, two massive wooden cabinets over twenty feet tall being tugged about on wheels worn flat centuries ago.  A dozen nasty muscular little fellows toil mightily to move each into position, one on either side of her voyeuristic window.  With a wave of her hand the doors are unlatched, swinging away to let loose their secrets.  An ancient library of musty bound manuscripts and loose parchments presents itself.  A great reading stand is placed before her and ladders arranged to facilitate the hasty retrieval of volumes she might require from the upper shelves.  Her bookkeepers stand ready to serve; each of them has donned a pair of fine soft gloves.  For none may touch these writings lest some spec of knowledge be learned or rubbed away.  Such misfortune would require the fellow rendered to wax, the ultimate service of any who displease.  Thus, have some become not but the light of a candle, their final task showing the way to another.  Unraveling the identity of this Jezebel who has singed more than pride is now number one on Rueshaba's to-do list.  She motions for one of her dearest to come nigh.  "That annoying little man whose errand we've just been on, send word he should come soon as he may to claim his prize."
--
Back in the forest, late morning finds Leona waking with a significant headache.  As her eyes open she flinches, rolling over to escape the sun's merciless intensity.  What happened? I'm late, gotta get my lazy ass in gear!  She places a hand tightly over her eyes in the hope it will relieve some of the vicious throbbing pain there behind.
"Ooooh crap!" she manages in a slow miserable tone, "my kingdom for an aspirin.  Smoke!  I've no fire, what's burning?"  She tilts her hand as it were a visor, peeking out from beneath.  The air is still thick with smoke and odors of an uncommon disgusting nature.  Instinctively she takes hold of the weapon lashed to her wrist and attempts to stand.  Ready to fight perhaps, but in no condition to deal with gravity just yet, thus, embarrassingly soon upon all fours.  A more cautious second attempt earns an honorable mention.  Upright, more or less at least upon her knees.  A maintainable position so long as she braces herself against the tree, yet still exhausted and so nauseatingly dizzy as to be totally defenseless.  It's not a warm and cozy feeling when one discovers they've spent the night in the midst of a battlefield, apparently during the battle.  The light continues to assault her eyes and her head throbs, but she's on her feet.  Well... maybe not!  Her legs buckle again and she slowly slides down along the trunk to the ground.  Feeling much as a tub of seasick pudding might, she concedes the best place to be for awhile at least is squarely upon her backside.  Fortunately, nothing out there seems to be moving.  Aside from her meager bedroll and the leaves stuffed beneath it for the sake of padding, everything within fifty feet has been scorched to cinder.  Heavy stumps of brush smolder and crackle; the forest floor has turned to a sparse frail blanket of ash.  Charred remains of unholy creatures lie about, their limbs painfully contorted, but for one furry sort seemingly cut in two by a white hot knife.  A great need to be on her way wells up among the thoughts bouncing around within her aching head.  All this smoke is bound to attract attention, but her mare is nowhere to be seen and she can hardly move.
Gotta get out of here, she tells herself.  Let's go... come on, do it, do it!  Another attempt to stand, but this time as she rises something heavy brushes her shoulder and moves across her back.  She juts away and turns; a large leathery hand tightly drawn into a fist reaches from above.  An instinctive swipe of her ever-present blade and the threat is gone.  Quick movements however, are not appropriate for one still lacking the fine art of balance.  The view from flat on her back just goes to prove that what you don't know really won't hurt you.  A huge presence looms directly overhead.  Something akin to a large baboon is tangled about the charred branches of the maple whose protection she had sought the night before.  Only the thicker limbs and trunk remain; all else has been burned away, and apparently so with no ash to show for it.  As any brave knight come to a maiden's defense the maple has served her well.  The arm to which the hand had been attached extends upward nearly ten feet to its source.  Fangs thrice those of any wolf extend from gaping jaws; a valid testament to the distress of this creature's most timely demise.
Truth be known, nothing would please her more than an opportunity to investigate.  Being nauseous however, and not having anything to throw up is such a confounding contradiction.  It would sour whatever might be gained from her inquest.  Though the idea of dragons roaming about is fascinating, being absent before the curious come near is of a higher priority.  They shall certainly have ample fuel for speculation and no doubt the great iron box will soon be dragged to this very spot. 
Gathering up her things she wobbles off toward the forest's edge.  Thankfully her mare has fared better than she; it comes to view grazing peacefully in the open meadow a hundred yards distant.  Alas, no amount of enticement seems adequate to bring it near; wiser than she, the animal wants no part of that charred clearing.  She relents, dragging herself and the heavy saddle to the mare.  Even then it takes her last apple and some earnest coaxing to calm the horse's anxieties of whatever occurred last evening.
--
Within the shadows of her safe haven, Rueshaba considers Leona's activities a trite attempt at disinformation.  "Yes, you know I watch, and I know you know.  You think to mislead with your foolish playing at innocence?  When I have learned your secrets, a special place I shall make for you among my most tormented.  Stay watchful my pets.  I would see every step she takes till the time is right."  Rueshaba looks again with great disdain at her damaged limb.  The air becomes so charged with her anger that the drapes upon the great windows of her citadel are drawn tight to the glass.
Hours pass, but her research yields nothing of this brazen invader's origin.  None dare to make a sound at times like these.  The poor creature tending the fire beneath her soothing caldron of acidic tallow all but holds his breath in fear when he approaches.  Frustrated and thus antagonized, Rueshaba abandons her research.  Now seeking the cool comfort of the imperial slab and the reluctant council of her imprisoned wizards.  Pointing to her crimson window, she demands in a deathly tone, "Who is that?"  Alas, neither has a single useful thought to add.  Outwardly they offer sympathies, all the while high fiveing each other and tumbling about joyfully within their graves.
Bird too has assumed the watch, now perched upon Leona's shoulder riding shotgun as it were.  He had a jolly good time last evening and now a thought, there may be more.  Looking back the way they've come he eyes a great old tree, dead for half a century, the branches nearly all fallen away.  The lair of an owl could that be near the top?  No owl of late therein resides, but rather just a smelly little creature hides.  There to watch and wonder what may pass, patiently it waits in service to a witch's task.
A bright sparkle is the last it will see, when comes the end of this old tree.  A spike of light unknown to any but a witch's watching window now about to die.  The demise of it akin to the final moment of a claymore mine--a very directional outward sort of decomposition.  Rueshaba flinches at the occurrence and turns to view the end of it with considerable sadness.  Smoke and flame billow from the framework where once her precious blood red window did resided.  White hot droplets of molten glass are scattered before the vacant opening.  Unfamiliar sunlight streaks the smoke-laden air.  It seeps from numerous tiny holes burned through the draperies hung upon windows in the opposite wall.  An unpleasant acrid aroma, even by the standards of this house, rises from the smoldering mildewed fabric.  Elements of the metal frame, in their haste to exit, have toppled one of the baskets of glowing charcoal with a great calamity.  Much anxiety follows while the lady of the house watches her bookkeepers dump pails of water upon the smoldering scrolls of her precious irreplaceable library.  Her lair has never been breached; the event gives rise to thoughts of things better left alone.  Crystal clear is the warning it betrays: "I know where you live, too."
With not but a devious thought she musters a horde of tiny goblins to her aid.  From every corner dark and damp, the rafters above and basements below, spiders and beetles of every sort are shaken from their solitude at Rueshaba's silent command.  Not the tiniest resource is immune or to be wasted, for if the composition lacks the faintest speck of the original the new window's quest will falter.  "Gather every scrap of it," she asserts quietly.  "Every... last... scrap... do you hear?  It must be mended.  Find every last scrap," she wails in a voice that causes the structure to shutter."  Now in a subdued tone once more as much as possible to console their fears.  "Be mindful my darlings, for every scrap you lack you shall lack a scrap as well.  Now get thee fast" she screams, "to work lest I toll the bell."  They scamper off in a frenzy to the tedious task at hand, for even now they morn the loss of any part they now possess.  Rueshaba feels a great need to torment something, but what?
--
The forest has thinned to meadows and fields of grain bordered by hedgerows and meandering stone walls.  Remaining out of sight and still maintaining her course is becoming increasingly difficult.  Soon thereafter suburbia appears on the horizon.  She slips into a private space and transforms herself back into a frail innocent maiden.  Although her sword is still securely strapped to her left calf it now remains out of sight, hidden beneath a long simple skirt of coarse sun-bleached linen.  Letting her hair down and replacing her vest with a more provocative blouse, the transition is complete.  She can only hope Bird will have the good manners not to embarrass her in public.  Walking her mare rather than riding, she decides, will draw less attention.  There will be enough of that when an unescorted female begins inquiring of a room.
Aside from the stockyards, most of the area outside the city walls is comprised of a seductive mixture.  Small cottages and garden patches abound, these artistically blended with the occasional smithy, barrel-maker or produce vendor's shed and many grand trees.
It's like never-never land and she wonders briefly what would happen if she just stopped looking for the exit and settled in, for indeed it is an enticing palatable drug.  But then, considering her rap sheet, within a month she would probably be public enemy number one.
Current priorities are: quarter the horse, find a cheap motel and convert the only item of real value she possesses into cash.  By sunset she has convinced the proprietor of a quaint little inn--the Brier Keg by name--that her sole desire is to reunite with a country lad working somewhere thereabout.  Seems he has promised to take her as his wife upon the passing of her sickly mother, an obligation which recently concluded.  Didn't bring a tear to his eye, but any unescorted maiden with the nerve to inquire of a room surely deserves the benefit of the doubt.
With the dawn, Leona has hitched a ride in the back of a produce wagon and is on her way to the big city.  The gates are manned, but the guards seem more of a statutory requirement.  Neither do they attempt to identify, inspect, tax, or hassle those passing through.  The city wall is not imposing; mud bricks six feet high and half as thick with a cap of sloped flat fieldstone to minimize the weathering effect of rain.   Certainly not a deterrent to invaders, but rather more as a division of the classes.  A notable exception is the Keep: an apprehensive pile of gray stone occupying the high ground west of the city complete with defensive battlements and watchtowers.  If there is a restricted neighborhood, likely that's it.  Not exactly a tourist attraction, as rumor would have it most who visit are escorted and once within unlikely to be seen again.    Neither trees nor structures of any kind exist within a quarter mile of the foundations so as to provide a clear unobstructed view of anything approaching from any direction.
The business hub resides at the city's center: a large stone-paved plaza including manned wells, watering troughs and shallow cisterns at each of its six corners.  The plaza hosts an open market primarily of perishables, which vanishes by the heat of midday.  Much to the administrator's credit, livestock is confined to pens outside the city walls.  A well thought-out system of public latrines is hosted by supervised former drunken brawlers paying their debt to society.  All in all, the city is surprisingly free of objectionable odors.  Around the plaza's perimeter lies a broad roadway encompassed by rows of long narrow wooden-framed shops with shuttered windows.  Few of the structures reach three stories in height, but each and every one is separated entirely from the others by a wall of stone which would effectively restrict the spread of a fire.  Beyond these the streets are set out in orderly blocks of the better shops and fine residences.  All in all expertly arranged, indeed there appears to be building codes in effect.
For a game so perfectly based upon the most minute of details only one flaw is readily detectable.  The dominant structures of any medieval city, aside from the royal residence, are the churches, yet none are to be seen here.  From a game player's point of view all this serenity and order alludes to a setup like the meadow where she and Art entered the game--too perfect, too quiet, a prelude to disaster.  Every place she's ever visited no matter how polished on the surface has a dark side, but in the light of day it does look good.  Okay, enough site seeing, back to the task: I need working capital otherwise I'm soon going to end up sleeping under a bridge and eating grass.  When in Rome do as the Romans, or so 'tis said.  Question is, how do the Romans around here do things?
Mindful of maintaining a low-profile she's wrapped Art's sword in a blanket along with a wooden plank to disguise the shape.  Trying to find a shop handling such items so as to get an idea of the weapon's street value is no simple task.  After several hours the cumbersome blade has become very heavy.  Neither is a single weapon of such caliber to be found at the market.  In fact the only swords in sight are those swaying from the belts of soldiers.  Apparently weapons of serious conflict are not readily available at this level of commerce, at least not over the counter.
The closest she has come is a cutlery shop handling hunting equipment, primarily longbows, hunting knives, sickles, scythe blades and a lot of leather goods.  Thinking back, it probably would have been wise to hack it around the crowd attempting to flush dragons from their wheat fields, but too late for that now.  Wishing a private consultation, she has loitered about until the only other customer has left.
The Merchant is a sizable roundish sly sort, but with an honest manner, about the age of 50.  No doubt he's noticed the large heavy bundle in Leona's arms and imagines some sort of proposition is in the works.  She lays the armload upon his table with great relief and the care a mother might afford her child.  Unraveling only the end, she slides the hilt out into view, inquiring cautiously.  "Would something of this nature be of interest, sir?"
"Depends upon what it is attached to.  I shall have to see it all milady."
Leona flips the folds of cloth aside and steps back to allow him space to handle it comfortably.  He examines the workmanship, paying special attention to the maker's mark.  "I don't know this mark.  Where was it made?"
"I have no idea of its origin, sir."
The Merchant is used to having purveyors of contraband extol all manner of frivolous claims as to the royal lineage or magical powers of their wares.  He is grateful for her silence.  "May I test the metal's temper?"
"I would not expect otherwise, sir.  Do as you will."
Retrieving a small chisel and hammer from his work area, he places the point on the flat of the blade just above the hilt.  Holding the tool very loosely, he strikes the very edge of the head that his hammer glances free allowing the chisel to recoil.  The chisel pops up out of his hand.  The bite can hardly be seen and examination of the chisel reveals the point somewhat dulled by the impact.  "A fine iron, milady, but only the nobles have need of such extravagance.  My customers are mostly peasants; all they ever hope to own could not pay for this blade.  I doubt as well His Lordship would care to have them in possession of such weapons."
"Are you acquainted with any who might be interested?  I would pay you a fee so long as I receive fair value."
"I could not accept a commission, milady, lest I create doubt as to my interests.  Most whom I know would challenge your right to posses such a blade and confiscate it.  I fear you could be arrested.  Wise to keep this matter hidden, as you have.  I don't believe I can help."  Leona's expression silently registers her disappointment.  "You could seek out an area they call the Cat's Walk."  He continues, "A man there called Badger deals in these sort of things.  If you go there take some hardy friends along and be prepared for the worst.  They offer you fair value though, but they may try to steal it from you."
"Thank you, sir.  May I impose further with a question, somewhat strange perhaps?"
"You do not impose at all, milady."
"What blade without an edge... would cut almost effortlessly?
"Humm, sounds a matter to be taken up with sorcerers."
"I'm sorry... I intend no offense, sir."  She flashes her eyes and pouts a bit to ease any tension the mention of magic might have provoked.  Raising the possibility of a sale to soothe things over and change the subject might be wise.  "Have you a small knife, single edged, but of quality metal?"
The Merchant produces a short stout hunting blade for her consideration.  The back edge is serrated like a saw; it could prove handy and deserves a place upon her wish list.  For the time being, a sincere interest is the most she can afford.
"Don't allow the simplicity of this blade to fool you," he adds.  'Tis of the best metal to be had in this land.  A stout blow with a hammer and this will cold-cut a chain; the edge will die in the effort, but so will the chain."
A Customer enters, a tall healthy fellow of perhaps 30, well trimmed, and one who appears to spend a lot of his time in the sun.  If clothes are any indicator, one would also suspect him to be of high station.  He's accompanied by a fancily attired lad of 12, likely his squire.  This is the first person aside from uniformed solders she has noticed availed of a side arm.
"Milord," exclaims the Merchant, nodding respectfully.  "Your boots are ready."  The shopkeeper then disappears into an adjacent room.
Leona quickly attempts to cover the sword thinking the shop keepers advice wise till there is time to consider all of her options.  Unfortunately the cloth drapes itself over the hilt in an unconvincing fashion.  The customer exchanges smiles and nods to Leona, then glances rather curiously toward the familiar shaped object hidden by the folds of material.  This could be a problem.  He moves his hand in a slow questioning fashion that his finger points toward the hidden hilt.  "May I?  Leona thinks it better to remain courteous and agreeable, for the moment at least.  She flips the edge of the material back revealing the hilt then the blade. 
Turning to Leona he inquires quietly.  "How does one so fair come to possess such a tool as this?"
She's a bit edgy at the Merchant's earlier cautions, but relents to a possible sale.  After all it's not the only weapon at her disposal.  "It was forfeit, sir... in combat.
"In combat?  It must have been quite a battle to involve weapons of this weight."
"A small skirmish actually... of a personal nature."
The Merchant quietly confides to his customer.  "Milord, I know not the maker's mark, but I would judge the metal superior to that of His Lordship's armory."
Returning his attention to Leona, the customer inquires.  "What would milady ask for it?"
Holding up the dagger, Leona addresses the Merchant.  "This blade, sir, what cost?"
"Three coins of silver," the proprietor responds.
"Then thirty and three is my price sir."
"That's all you require?"
"I've made my bargain," Leona insists. "Do you accept?"
The Squire's eyes follow the negotiations, though they tend to hesitate somewhat when they fall upon Leona.  The customer nods his acceptance and places three gold and three silver coins in Leona's palm.  "Thirty and three, as you wish, milady."
She smiles, then passes the silver coins to the Merchant, slips the sheath of the knife into her boot and graciously nods to the gentlemen.  "A fine day to you all."  She exits without further ado.
The customer's at once impressed and disappointed, his eyes follow her away into the crowded market.  Most young ladies who chance upon his company are all too eager to jabber excessively and can hardly be politely dismissed.  But, in fact, he may have preferred this curious arms dealer dwell a moment or two more.  "An appealing sort, seldom do you meet one with a mind of her own... or any at all as to such matters as this."  Turning toward the Merchant, "Did you believe her, that forfeit yarn?"
"She does not chatter idly as do most.  But also consider, is there any creature more deceptive than a fair young maiden can be... when she wishes it so?  None sir, there is none."
The customer addresses his young Squire for the fun of teasing.  "Well lad!  I know she's turned your head, for she's turned mine.  And if you've paid attention then you've learned of things that may serve you well.  A merchant is a good judge of character, lest he soon be a beggar.  Even so, she has confounded him... and lad, that is a maiden of great craft."  The Merchant clears his throat and nods in approval of the customer's observations.  "What do you think then, lad?" he further asserts.  "Is she off to seek scents to announce her presence and fine cloth to catch the eye, or find drink and potions to make this world seem a better place?"
"Neither, Sir," the lad proposes.  "If that were her desire, why would she purchase such a costly knife?"
"Well done then!"  The Customer steps back a little surprised at the young man's grasp of the situation.  "A keen eye for what goes on will save your hide and a valuable squire make."
Leona's pleased to have unloaded Art's weapon, if for no other reason than the inconvenience of lugging it around.  Now off with not a care, having a fine new blade in her boot and a secure jingle in her pocket.  She sets a course to re-explore the city's highlights more now at her leisure; confident in the thought her disguise has concealed the unfortunate incident of tax-collector abuse.  Now if I could just find a soda vending machine.
--
Snob and Pious have returned to their hired assassin's stronghold.  Snob is eager to claim the prize of their devious venture and poor Pious, a nervous wreak.  A tense uneasy air lingers as they traverse the length of the foreboding court chamber.  Rueshaba smiles as they approach.  Pious does not take this as a good sign.  Try as he may to detect some sort of thought, the witch's mind appears a complete blank.  Looking over his shoulder he notes, rather uncomfortably, dozens of things lurking in the shadows and crowding in just behind.  They bow respectfully in consideration of her unique station, presenting the customary well-wishing and formal salutations.  She stands, or rather rises; this is definitely not a positive move in their favor.  Pious' heart has taken to pounding; he is considering options.
Quietly the witch laments.  "You concealed the fact she was a demon."  Her demeanor quickly turns to rage, "A demon with the fires of Hades at her beck and call."  She flips the cape back exposing the charred remains of her hand.  "You beg me to spill blood for you so you may sleep at night.  And for this... I am forever deformed in your service.  You would play me," she howls, "as a pawn in your wicked games?"
Snob and Pious look at each other with great concern of their immediate futures.
"I assure you, majesty, we were unaware of--"
"Silence!" she screams, holding her mangled paw forth for their closer examination.
"A lot of discomfort is involved in the making of something like this.  Although I was, at least for the moment, unable to complete my part of our bargain your payment is forfeit due to avoidable pain and suffering."
"Yes, yes by all means!  The payment is yours without question, yes indeed... entirely yours, majesty."
"I did say quiet, did I not?"
Snob lowers his head and nods a yes.
If there is any hope of escape Pious knows it is now; he must create some diversion and spirit his way out of this place immediately.  He begins to raise his right arm in a suspect motion, but finds his effort instantly restrained.  Looking to his limb, he notices something has unfortunately swallowed it near halfway to his elbow.  Their eyes meet for an instant; indeed, the creature almost seems to smile.  Ivious, as it is called, is a knuckle-muncher; fingers are his absolute delight as opposed to toes.  A big brown furry thing with small round dark eyes.  His teeth are not the sharp jagged sort preferred by his comrades, but rather flat and broad, all the more for crunching, you see.  Now there comes a most unnerving sound.  Forthwith, Pious's arm is now easily withdrawn.  But alas, all that was once beyond his wrist is gone.  Munching slowly on his sublime little treat, Ivious backs away.  He shrugs shyly as one begging your pardon as to say he just couldn't help himself.  Indeed he is smiling, secretly hoping with all his heart this foolish fellow will raise the other arm too.  Oh please!
