His eyes seem to beg, for with that his master would allow he may munch another.  Pious chooses to preserve what remains of his limbs, taking hold of the bleeding stump with his free hand.  He returns his undivided attention to their host, sad of eye, but silent.  For 'tis not the time for words and really, what could one say anyway?
"Foolish boy," Rueshaba coos.  "Have you not noticed?  I collect sorcerers."  She waves her incinerated hand toward one of the elevated cages flanking her throne.  "These are some of my better specimens; you shall be among grand company."  She turns to one of her guest's escorts.  "Como, he is bleeding all over my floor, it will draw bugs.  Fix it."  A short muscular sort of man, more or less, appears from the shadows carrying a small iron box and a pair of tongs.  Setting the box upon the table, he smacks the back of Pious's remaining hand with the tongs driving it away from the bleeding stump.  Pious, in a totally submissive form of shock, says nothing nor attempts to move away.  The servant opens the box releasing a whiff of steam, then reaching in with the tongs he extracts a metal cup.  The interior is fitted with rows of tiny fishhook like barbs; in the dim light one may detect a telling dull orange glow.  Como grasps Pious's stump firmly with a stout powerful hand and drives the cap over the end; whacking it several times with the tongs to assure a nice snug fit.  Sparks flash from the metal as bits of loose hot oxide flake away.  Flesh sizzles and poor passive Pious collapses in a dead faint with his mouth wide open as one to scream without a sound.  The servant slurps some greasy ointment around the blistering edge and drags him away rather unceremoniously.
Wide-eyed and soaked with sweat, cock-sure Snob now trembles with regret.  The Witch places a finger under his chin and lifts his face to her hollow terrifying eyes.  "As for you dear boy, I hope it will not be an inconvenience to join me for dinner this evening."  One of the escorts, who has found his way to Snob's side unnoticed, drives a powerful fist deep into his gut.  The blow thoroughly knocks the wind from Snob's sails; he drops like a rock to his knees.  Another of his guardians grabs the top of Snob's head by the hair, places a foot to the back of his neck and pulls his head back.  A third fellow drives a large shiny apple into the disorientated fellow's gaping mouth.  Four more of her retinue have come forward carrying a great covered silver serving dish.  They remove the domed lid, grab Snob by the arms and legs and flip him onto the platter.  Clamping his limbs firmly now into restraints that have been riveted to the platter's surface.  They heave the cover back in place and cart him off to the ovens.  One rodent of a fellow runs alongside banging on the huge bell-shaped dome with a mallet.  Rueshaba shakes her head slowly as though to excuse the disturbance with a thought, children must be allowed their fun.
"I shall dine late.  Baste him often; those plump ones can become leathery at the edges.  Blend the tallow with sweet vinegar and dill for a broth of hoof and ear."  The attendant bows and backs away.  Feeling much better now, having vented her rage upon those truly at the cause of this entire inconvenience.  Thoughts of further retribution are set aside for the time being, but not forgotten.
--
Whereas, Snob is on his way to the kitchen, Leona mingles happily with the population.  Peddlers hack their wares; purveyors of tools, fresh fruit, and potions to secure one's good health or favorite maiden are the most popular.  Imagine a flea market comprised entirely of well-used necessities with not a collectable item or flimsy plastic foreign import in the lot.  Had the trolls not come into the mix, she and Art would probably be among this same crowd extolling the virtues their fine cookware to passers-by for pittance to secure their daily bread.
Leona's presence draws the attention of an elderly couple, members of the merchant class by their appearance.  The woman exhibits surprise and stares at first, her expression changing to a warm tearful smile.  Before her husband realizes what's come to mind and failing to catch her arm, she slips away through the crowd in Leona's direction.  Glancing back, still aglow when he calls to her, but being persistent in her quest that little choice has he but to follow.
The woman steps into Leona's view and makes her presence known with a discreet curtsy.  "Milady, you're safe."
Her husband catches up, taking her by the arm.  "Come away woman; can you not see she is too young to be whom you imagine?"  Turning to Leona the gentlemen begs.  "Please excuse my wife; she thinks you a long-lost friend."
As her husband leads her away, the woman glances back.  "I will keep your secret."
Startled at the thought of being recognized but quick to recompose before the opportunity is lost, Leona shouts, "Do you know the way home?"
"The path lies with the stars, milady," comes her reply as the woman disappears into the crowd. 
The sincerity and quickness of it has caught Leona off guard.  Possibilities flash through her mind, but nothing of rational content.  So easy to become entangled in the fantasy; so uneasy, the lingering desire to make it real.  She chalks the event up to being another clue cleverly delivered under the pretext they had once known each other.  When you sort it out, all that really matters is that she did answer when asked of the route to the game's conclusion.  The only genuine nagging question is what nightmarish event took place in the wood before she awoke amid the ashes of her campsite?  Such does not fit a game's profile; every event should either ask or answer a question and at the very least involve the principal players.
Wandering about the plaza Leona comes upon the local version of the Internet, the public bulletin boards.  Two panels under roof crossing each other such that they create four distinctly separate quadrants, each addressing a specific segment of the population based upon class and literacy level.  This is information central, an opportunity to discover what makes this world tick--a very important asset to anyone in Leona's line of business.
All the notices are original works, alluding to the fact not even the simplest ink block printing technology yet avails itself.  The first quadrant is for the simple folk, messages scripted in hieroglyphics.  A picture of a cow or duck with an indication of its cost and either a hand holding a coin or empty, as to say I'm buying or I'm selling.  At the bottom of each was a symbol matching one of the identifiable zones laid out on a map posted with the advertisements--a basic outline of the city wall showing the main streets, the square, and an indication of the Keep's position relative to the city as a reference point.  Basic and simple, but once understood, a suitable means for the totally illiterate to transmit information in a public forum.  Without exception, these notices were marked on thin wooden slats.
Within the second quadrant obviously catering to the more educated, pictures are accompanied by written descriptions and directions.  These posted on a coarse paper of sorts.  Notices of births, deaths, and weddings along with the customary want-to-buy or sell offers.  Of note were offers for lands and buildings, a fair hint the system was not a feudal society based entirely on labor bound to the land.  There were also offers to indenture and to buy and sell the indentured.  Most were associated with apprenticeships, though some involved the satisfaction of debts.
The third was an upper class version of the second, appealing more to those with greater resources.  Posted on a finer quality of paper and even a little color here, the text embellished with some calligraphy.  This would assure interested parties they were dealing with the educated segment of the population, and thus to caution, for who is the more likely to scheme?
The final quadrant was the rogues' gallery.  One panel had only a single well-done portrait of fearless leader at center stage accompanied by a long list of his accomplishments.  Aside each were edicts, laws, and proclamations, all crafted with the best interests of the people at heart, think taxes and things you can't do.  The consequences of violations fell into two categories: work in the public service, think slave labor until you qualified for social security; or more typically, termination of your contract.  On the adjacent panel were lists of executions, both public and private, and the FBIs most-wanted list.
Fortunately Leona's likeness didn't include much detail: an obvious female dressed as a man with a short sword strapped to her left calf.  Looks as if long peasant skirts are in this year, like it or not.
On a bright note, however, Beth's portrait is lovely; they have both made the official shit list.  Leona begins reading quietly under her breath.  "Prayer of absolution for Beth of Atlanta and her man slave."  She drifts into silence for a short time; then the volume comes up again quickly.  "To be executed six days hence, lest 100 gold coins be duly paid and receipt thereof presented.  Shit!  That girl is a problem... I swear.  I can afford to bail Art, but a 100, no way!  Several gentlemen of means in the vicinity have interrupted their conversation, seemingly quite surprised this young peasant wench can read at all, legal notices no less!   A privilege heretofore considered exclusively within their domain.  What is the world coming to?
Leona disarms them with a maiden's first line of defense--a smile.  "Excuse me, good sirs.  Can you tell me if I understand this correctly?  All would be forgiven and my friends set free if this amount were paid on their behalf.  Is that right?"
 One of the gentlemen steps up to the task and renders his expert opinion.  "Quite so; that is what it says."
"Are there bail bondsmen in the city?"
"Do you speak of bonded men, indentured laborers, those who work for their debts?"
"Ah, not exactly, more of those who would pay this fee now, and be repaid later with interest.  What I mean is, to be repaid in a greater amount than the original debt to compensate for their risk, or rather services in such matters."
"'Tis Moneylenders you seek then."
"Yes, where could they be found?"
"A hundred in gold to secure the freedom of two knaves!"  He turns to his friend with amazement, then begins to chuckle.  "You jest?"
"I assure you, sir, this is a serious inquiry."
"If it be serious, how then would you intend to repay them?"  Tapping the notice with a finely gloved hand, he exclaims with a devious grin.  "If you spent the rest of your life on your back you couldn't earn this amount."  Only the witnesses thereabout spare his life at this moment.
"The details are my concern, sir." She rebuffs calmly.  "But first, if you please, where may they be found?"
"The brothels and sties along the cat's walk, north of the city next to the yards.  My carriage is just there."  He points to a fine coach and four, patiently awaiting the pleasure of his company.  "If you would like to earn a copper... or two, then along with you," he nods in the direction of his coach.  "I've fine rooms at the Brovin's Inn," he continues in a snobbish tone.
Well then, there's a possibility!  Fine rooms could offer a private opportunity to cut him loose of his purse... among other things.  Playing the shy and innocent, she teases.  "I appreciate your concern, sir, but you're far too much the gentlemen to be seen with one of my kind.  I should not want to soil your reputation.  'Tis more appropriate I entertain those who reside in the gutter with the likes of myself.  I'm sure you understand; it's for your own good, sir."  His anticipation quickly turns sour and he walks off in a huff, grumbling obscenities to his friend.  Well dressed and pretentious these louts, foul of mind and breath alike.  Strange, how it is that wealth and arrogance nearly always dance arm in arm and upon the backs of those less fortunate.  Were this not such a public encounter, well she might have lifted her skirt to offer no less of her favor than a tax collector would earn.
From the corner of her eye she spots another fellow who's taken note of the encounter.  A scruffy sort with his arms folded, leaning on a hickory staff and having a bit of a chuckle.  She judges him a wild card, one who watches and knows how things get done.  Leona turns her attention on him.  "Since you are having such a fine afternoon, somewhat at my expense, sir, perhaps you wouldn't mind assisting.  I need an understanding of how this public ransom system works."
The interloper lowers his head slightly, squints, and smiles.  A little embarrassed at being called to task by this young wench of questionable intent.  He nods, accepting her implied obligation and steps forth to answer her challenge.  "I wasn't laughing at ya; no offense intended.  I was just tickled at how swift ya stuck ah feather up 'is ass.  And ya know, he ain't ever going ta figure ya was fooling with 'im."
It's been said and wisely so, the best defense is an offence.  Thus, she challenges again. "What are you implying, sir?"
He looks about to be sure they are alone, keeping his voice in a quiet tone.  "Look here now!  You're the calm little kitty, but I'm thinking ya ain't no alley cat.  Next thing ya need ta know is ya have some really pretty ankles.  Must be ya dress ain't long as ya like ta think.  Ya need ta let ya hem down till it's in the dust."  He glances around, then casually pulls her wanted notice from the board, rolls it up and slides it into his sleeve.  "I don't much like tax collectors neither.  Now listen careful.  Cat's Walk ain't no place fur ya 'cause that's ah mean bunch over there; no way err ya gonna find their gold.  Un if they catch on to ya, you'd never get loose 'cause there's too many of'em and they stick mighty tight together.  Ya gotta figure another way.  First ideas ya see is generally not the best."
Leona's a bit embarrassed at being read like a book on a bright sunny day.  "What are you called?"
"Round here, U'm Stick."
She extends a hand.  "Leo."  Their hands clasp; for better or worse she's accepted him as her confidant.
"Now, which of'um is your people?"  She points out Beth's image.  "Shoulda no'd it."  Pointing toward the ground, several feet have gathered on the opposite side of the panel.  He indicates with a nod they should move on to a more private area.  "Just ah thought now, don't ya get mad 'bout it.  If she's curvy ya might sweet talk one ah these well-ta-do bastards ta pay 'er way out.  Hundred in gold's pretty steep.  Hafta stay with'em fur ah good while, wouldn't be easy.   Hafta treat him real nice, too.  Just till she got ta be trusted; couple years I'd say, then maybe get a chance ta run off.  Better 'um getten 'er pretty little head lopped off; that'd be ah shame.  Looks like she comes with ah man slave, too; it'll help the bargain."
"That's Hale... her boyfriend.  How long have I got to work this out?"
A serious concern dawns upon her consultant's weathered brow.
"What's wrong?"
"Ya better hope 'Is Lordship don't catch wind ah that.  I'd say somehow they got the idea... see they'd be thinking she has that lad as one's been bought outright, paid fer in full.  'Cause, that's how they writ it here; means she has money, means she has friends with money, means she might get paid fer.  They'd be in the lime pit by now if Roux didn't think there was somebody ta pay up for'em."
Leona becomes pale and quiet.  "They call each other slave and master sometimes, just for fun."
"When folks use'em words 'round here it ain't fer fun.  Ya gotta go see'em and be sure they keep the tale told right.  Be six days from this morning.  It'll happen at sunrise.  They like ta get an early start up there 'cause if they burn'em they'd want the smell ta be gone 'fore lunch.  She'll be okay till dark the night before; that's when the guards 'ill be allowed ta have 'er."
"How can I get in to see them?"
"Ya go up ta the Keep, the prison side, mind ya.  Tell'em ya want to inspect the folks ta be sure they ain't dead er dying 'fore ya pay the fee ta get'em out.  You'll be allowed ta talk private with'em, but not fer long.  So don't be crying and all, be quick ta get things said that need saying.  If ya bail'em free, soon as ya get loose ah those walls go back to wherever ya come from.  Don't waste time thinking it's done 'cause his royal mind has ah way ah changing, ya see.  Be ready ta travel afore ya collect'em.  Don't even think you can get'em out any other way 'cept paying, 'cause ya can't."
"Have any ever escaped?"
"Not a one!  Got near a 180 men quartered up there, least so I hear.  Only two ways, ya pay, or ya end in the lime pit.  Nobody gets out no other way.  Ya know, sometimes it's better ta lose ah friend than get stuck in there with'em."
"Is there any place around here where that amount could be found?"
"On the best day, saying they was just paid fer ah pair ah fine coaches, the wagon smiths south of the city might have 30 coin.  Happens maybe once ah year and there's least ah dozen men on hand ta see it doesn't get lost.  Find yaself in ah hailstorm ah hammers and horseshoes ya would.  I'd say that's about the most ya going ta find in one place 'round here.  Less ya go out into the countryside and storm one of the manors.  But them folk don't throw hammers, they have swords and crossbows fer such problems. "
"Interesting thought!"
"Be sure ya find ya ah good pair ah boots 'fore ya get started after this foolishness."
She glances downward.  "Thanks, I'll add those to my wish list."
"What is it makes ya think I won't be waiting up there ta point ya out and collect that gold piece on ya head.  Once ya got in the midst ah it, be no way out fer ya if they knew who ya was."
Leona stares into his eyes for a short silent eternity; he doesn't try to look away.  "Because, you don't like tax collectors either."  Stick nods his approval.  "Do you happen to know the way home?" she adds.
"Wherever I am, that's home fer me."  Leona nods her understanding.  He turns and soon blends into the browns and grays as a leaf would be lost among all the others in a sudden gust of wind.  Leona goes upon her way.  There is much to think about and plans of deadly consequence to assemble.  To be sure, no game worth its salt is complete without a risky save, right?
--
Several cocky lads of little more than 20 years are passing a crock of brew and horsing around adjacent to the inn where Leona is boarding.  The objects of their frat mentality showmanship are a pair of giggly round-faced maidens each of whom has at least 10 kilos on any one of the fellows.  Coming down the lane with nothing less than armed robbery on her mind, Leona scarcely notices their courting rituals as she marches straight toward the inn.
Of these fools one envisions her as the prize of the day.  "I'll leave these plum puddings to you lads," he confides to his buddy.  "I prefer something with less of a bounce and the form of a wasp.  He rises and starts in Leona's direction with more conviction than suits a gentlemen's first encounter with any maiden so fair and capable.  Even more so, one whom of late has laid three unwelcome suitors in their graves and consigned another twice his size to permanent rehabilitation.  Indeed, who but a country fool with a pint of moon shine sloshing around between his ears would grab an unsuspecting, five foot six, well-armed 120-pound wasp?
With a confidence only alcohol may impart the impetuous lad steps directly into Leona's path.  She side steps, thinking their encounter some unintentional logistical error.  He immediately checkmates her new position confident he and his high spirits can sustain without consequence any blow she may offer in response.  Declaring his intentions without remorse, he sings out gleefully, "What a grand night we are going to have!"  Which is about half right; for he has failed to appreciate she is on a mission and not in a wenchable mood.  He steps forward and stoops slightly wrapping his arms around her thighs.  Then, lifting her upward buries his face into her bosom with the enthusiasm a bumblebee might employ when addressing a helpless clover blossom.  She spreads her arms as far apart as they will reach, which from the lad's point of view is a heavenly invitation.  Literally blinded by his boundless affection, he fails to notice she has clenched both into tight fists.  Retribution is swift, their romance abruptly terminated when she snaps her elbows slamming her knuckles against both ears.  So much for his response theory.  He immediately abandons his interest in cleavage, dropping Leona back to her feet--this because he can't hold the girl and his ears at the same time.  They are being pummeled with loud stinging echoes as though clasp between the halves of a recently divided hornets nest.
Within his inner ears, the balancing mechanism's gone into shock.  He reels, attempting to maintain an upright stance and with both hands preoccupied presents a perfect and defenseless target.  Unfortunately for the lad Leona has fully recovered from his initial surprise engagement.  She next delivers a knuckle encrusted roundhouse to his throat.  Thus, does Adam's apple begin wonder if Eve was really such a good idea after all?  Now faced with more serious issues--that of inhaling, and though he dare not try just yet, exhaling as well.  The discomfort to his ears has taken second place to the more critical function, breathing.
Any play of less than three acts would be deemed shoddy; and this shall not be so construed.  A sharp snap of her fine new boot to his crotch, intended more you understand to cool the passion than inflict pain.  Thus, her honor is vindicated, her virtue preserved, and she wins by a field goal.  He folds, totally disoriented, not knowing what to grab next, wishing only that he had more hands to comfort all the things that have come lately unto distress.
With a sway of her arm she's withdrawn her newly acquired hunting knife and now stands ready and willing to answer any further indignations with the letting of blood.  Wisdom has demanded she hold the heavy artillery hidden in reserve.  The lad has folded himself over on the ground rocking, reeling, and choking as one having a seizure.  Yet not the least bit aware of how truly fortunate he is that Bird can discern a fool's affection from a serious threat.  For surely, in all the realm he is the only individual that has or ever will rubbed noses with a demon.
His buddies are not sure what's happened.  Hardly three seconds have transpired and they can see the experience has been painfully incapacitating.  One secures a wooden rake and rushes to defend his fallen friend from Leona's wrath.  The gigglers are suddenly silent.  Neither can imagine why any gal in her right mind would kick a handsome horny young stud in the balls on a Friday night.
"What happened?  Did she cut 'im?" exclaims one of the victim's amigos.
Another has rushed to his downed pal while Leona is held at bay by their rake wielding comrade.  "Don't think so, don't see no blood!"  The smitten lad, curled tightly into a ball with both hands firmly locked between his loins cannot but wheeze in his defense.
"She's cursed him," berates another.  "She's a witch."
The Innkeeper, a significant presence with whom few would argue with or without a rake, rushes out to cool the situation.  He steps between the lad and his reluctant muse.  Backup soon arrives in the form of his wife, she remains near the door, a glowing iron from the hearth at her disposal.
Leona relaxes her stance.  "I should like to go about my business if you don't mind, sir;" she asserts with the snooty air of an offended debutante.  "You should take measures to see that these ruffians do not impose their ill manners upon your guests."
The lad has regained some composure though the sound of his efforts to breath are truly pitiful.  Swallowing, however, shall be put aside for some time yet lest there be considerable sacrifice to accomplish it.  Though his voice is frail and discolored, he attempts to undermine his assailant's character as best he may.  "A smuggler I say hiding things under her skirt."  The Innkeeper's attention shifts to Leona.
"Contraband... my brace!  You lout... I've a sprained ankle.  'Tis a splint... bound to my leg so I may walk with less pain and no further business of yours.  Your foolishness," she is quick to point out, "could have broken it.  I might have ended on crutches or unable to walk at all for weeks."
A pretty young wench, as Leona surely is, somehow acquires a certain edge in such matters; particularly if the mediator is of the opposite gender.  The given explanation is plausible and the circumstance, four drunks opposing an injured maiden favors her position.  In such a one sided situation even a rogue would not suggest she lift her skirt to disprove the lad's accusation.
Chivalry demands the Innkeeper come to her rescue.  "Enough!" he bellows.  "Take this jackass from my premises and come not again to annoy my guests or I'll see the constables 'ave the lot of ya cleaning latrines."
With that, Leona presents a respectable nod to her knight-errant.  "Thank you, good sir."  Without further ado she prances off to her room--with just the slightest limp, of course.
The ruffians gather up their injured comrade, and not forgetting their crook, make haste away with only the sympathies of the puddings to console.  The Innkeeper returns to his customers, stopping briefly to admonish his mate.
"And ya was concerned this wench would 'ave every cock within shouting distance at er door fur favors?  I doubt any a these lads ill be leaving a coin on er pillow in the morning."
"We can't have this sort under our roof," his wife insists.  "It was her wound him up.  You've got to put her out."
"As long as she be a paying guest she may stay," he advises sternly.  "Ya boarders ill be wanting their meal soon, and I'll hear no more of it."
--
Late in the day it was when a fine carriage drawn by a courtly pair of prancers and afforded a very proper coachman comes to a gentle halt before the Keep's prison gate.  A brutish guard watches from the safety afforded of his ever-locked assemblage of iron bars.  He's supposing one of His Lordship's guests has mistakenly come around to the wrong side.  The footman pays him no mind, stepping gracefully from his perch to arrange the exit platform, then opening the coach's beautifully lacquered door with a gracious bow.  No doubt someone of considerable means has come to call.  Is it to be Cinderella or her fairy godmother?  Neither it seems, for 'tis Leona who exits completely enshrouded in a plush-velvet hooded cape of elegant peach and lavender brocade.  The footman accompanies as she approaches the gates where two more wardens have now gathered for this rare spectacle.
Upon reaching the portal she passes Beth's execution notice to the footman, snobbishly motioning that he should forward it through the filthy bars to the guards.  Snatching the notice, the key holder declares his senior status and sends the other gate goons on their way.
"Milord and master bid me attend this wretched place," she pleads quietly, "that I may attest to the good health of this wench and her servant."  All the while she takes careful notice of every detail; the fortification's architectural features, estimated dimensions and defense mechanisms.  Even the shape and location of shadows upon the walls could be useful things to know, for if push came to shove, most likely it would be approximately this same time of day.
An imposing mass of stone, the Keep, thick, heavy and cold.  A sense of hopelessness pervades the structure and surely extends to all those confined therein.  Though the portal she stands before is at least twenty feet high the hinged iron gates baring the exit are but twelve.  Even so, were anyone able to scale it still they are doomed to fail for the upper ledge is topped with cantilevered decks of thin sharpened spikes like the quills on the back of a hedge hog.  Far to flimsy too support the weight of someone attempting to pull themselves over it would be like climbing headlong into a loose stack of fencing foils.
A siege door hangs just out of sight above and behind the opening.  Constructed of ironclad timbers over two feet thick and guided to the ground by deep channels cut into the stone walls.  A spiked bar running along the lower edge is arranged to engage a series of indentations cut into the pavement stones.  The design alleviates the inherent weakness of opposing doors with their weight supported upon hinges.  Gravity is an undeniable mechanism and when a door of this design falls to earth the opening is sealed, bound and braced about its entire perimeter. 
Yet another guard, this one wearing a helmet now joins the conference; he grunts to his subordinate, evidently thereby granting permission for Leona to enter.  The key bearer unlocks the sliding bar tethering the gates, slamming it back with a sharp clank.  At least the gates swing open smoothly absent the signature squeaking most have come to anticipate from viewing too many horror videos.  She waves the footman back to her coach and enters with a confident stride.  The helmeted guard leads the way to the cells with a certain resentment as though he has so many other more important things to do at the moment.
Once within the walls, again that foreboding clank as the gate is immediately locked behind her.  While one warden maintains the watch, the keeper of the keys returns to the guard's room about 20 feet to the left in the ground level of the adjacent watchtower.  A wide stone stairway wraps its way around the tower as it rises to the battlements.  The siege door is raised and held by two chains coiled about the drum of a great winch mounted to both the wall and pavement by iron lugs.  This in turn powered by a gear train and turnstile large enough to accommodate four teams of draft horses.  A hand lever maintains the latch that restrains an escapement mechanism used to regulate the rate of decent. That single lever is the key to sealing off the prison yard.  Leona is escorted cross the vast deathly quiet space.  Along the walls all manner of clutter.  Carts and wagons of every sort, piles of cut stone and timbers, storage lean-tos stacked with firewood, barrels, and crocks--every available space around the perimeter is utilized.  It appears His Lordship is plagued with the same inescapable dilemma as every household on the planet, just too damn much junk to fit in the basement.  On the right is a high wall with no windows and only a single ironclad door at the yard level.  Joints in the masonry have been trowelled flush and smooth to eliminate handholds or ledges which might facilitate climbers.  Interior walls jog about randomly such that the area narrows to a roadway about thirty feet wide; this extends straight away for at least another two hundred feet.  Riders come and go at the far end, horses are being led about and a significant amount of manpower is present.  Billets for His Lordship's troops and stables for their mounts would be a reasonable guess.  A call to arms could bring mounted soldiers into the courtyard almost immediately.  Prospects for extracting Beth and Hale by any means aside from paying the bounty are dimming quickly.
Collateral facilities within the yard's activities area include an elevated platform of open ironwork with a burning stake at its center, a gallows to suit a party of six, and stocks, some of which are occupied.  One of the residents confined thereto has either expired or doesn't mind the crow standing on his head pecking at the back of his neck.
The guard leads her to a series of constricted blind alleys on the left side of the yard.  Stopping at the second of these, he points into the gloom while motioning toward the left.  "There!"  His job more than well done he's off to rejoin the gang at happy hour.  Leona is left completely unattended to seek out her friends.  Their cocksure, lackadaisical, no-one-would-dare attitude offers some consolation.  The alleyway is lined on either side with deep narrow cells secured of iron bars.  Unusually high ceilings combined with the cramped access have cast everything into grave shadows, though the sun is still slight above the horizon.
She ventures into this sordid realm of iniquity curtailed.  The air is rancid, a blend of decaying straw and human waste.  The first two compartments appear vacant; the occupant of the third has managed to hang himself from the cell's door lintel--no simple task given the effort required every shred of his clothing and there was nothing to stand upon.  Desperation of this sort is not encouraging.
Beth lights up with the enthusiasm of a child discovering the Easter bunny has just popped in with a basket of chocolate-covered marshmallows.  "Leo!" she exclaims, whacking Hale a couple of times in her special joyful manner.  "Did you hear? get up come on." her voice singing with glee as she hops about like an escaped jack-in-the-box, frizzy, frazzled, and filthy from head to toe, but smiling nonetheless.  Rising carefully, Hale makes his way to the front with a serious limp.  On occasion, his injured leg has lapsed into the realm of numb, which tends to bring the floor quickly within arm's reach.  Beth and Leona clasp hands through the bars and lightly touch foreheads.  What a relief to know her best pal is in the neighborhood.  "Look at her will ya," Beth teases.  "No matter where you end up these days there's always some diva strutting around."  Spoken with true grit and a tiny tear in each of her otherwise big bright green eyes.
"This is pretty rank.  You guys okay?"
"Compared to where we started out these are luxurious accommodations.  We only got out of the pit 'cause they consider us paying customers now.  Even have a cover for our potty, keeps the smell down but not the flies.  But around here that's like hanging with the high rollers in Vegas."
"That was blind luck," Leona advises cautiously.
"I don't care.  In this dump it's the little things that really count, trouble is most of them bite.  They even gave our back shoes.  This isn't exactly a beach, you know; shoes are really important."  Beth concedes, "I wouldn't even care if they were different colors or someone else's."
Leona glances back toward the courtyard to be sure one of the guards hasn't come round to keep tabs on her.  Suspicious of the way her escort just walked off she places a finger to her lips to quiet Beth.  His absence could be a ploy to catch her at something foolish like passing a weapon.  Thus, they might discover the secret of Beth's supposed slave.  She then checks to see if anyone's occupying either of the adjoining suites.  Satisfied both are vacant, she entreats quietly.  "You called Hale a slave... they believed it.  They think you're connected to money or at least wealthy friends."
"That'll be the day!"
"You're not listening; they think Hale really is your personal slave."
"Well... sometimes, but not lately."
"Seriously now, this getup is rented, a charade so they'll think you have rich friends.  We've gotta keep that picture in their face or it's the end of the game for you guys.  Really, Hale are you getting this?  When someone's around it's important you play the part.  'Cause If they catch-on... I'm... I'm not sure what will happen."
"Yea'sa masta, mint julep anyone?"  Hale follows the sarcasm with a profound thumbs up and an affirmative nod.
"Leo... I don't want go back inside," Beth pleads.  "You can't even imagine what's going on down in the basement; it's like the class play at some psycho ward, but it never stops."
"I think Beth and I are on the short list," Hale advises grimly.  "Do we have a plan?"
"Yeah... sorta'.  I'm working on it, but it's complicated.  I mean I know every game has it's own rule book.  There should be basic elements though, you know, like standards you can depend on, but not here.  One minute two and two make four, next thing you know, so far as being a game, nothing, and I mean absolutely nothing adds up.  Sometimes it's just too real, next thing you know it gets so extreme it couldn't be anything else but a game.  Doing the best I can to make sense of it and figure out the limits, but it's confusing.  The major difference is the sense of touch, fire is hot, water is wet, things have weight, shit stinks, how do you do that?   And things hurt too, I mean like real pain, that's not normal... is it?   And time, oh man, time is all screwed up, the time line is stretched out beyond all limits, it doesn't make sense.  Like how long have you guys been here?"
"Forever," Beth replies with a frown.
Hale clarifies Beth's understanding of time.  "I make it six days, maybe a week."
"Right, nearly a week now," Leona reminds cautiously.  "We didn't sign on for Marine basic, games play for hours not weeks.  So what the hell is this?  You didn't just lose points--you get your knee tore up or a smack to the head!  It just can't be this way, Something's wrong, I can't figure it.  Doesn't any of this seem strange to you guys, or is it just me?  
"Yeah, now that you mention it, my leg does hurt.  Funny, it never crossed my mind anything was out of place though."  Hale shrugs his shoulders.  "You're right I guess, but I don't see any way of getting around it, do you?"
No!  That's the problem--there's no option here, no time out.  I don't see the door.  Come on, help me out... I need a hint.  How did you guys end up in here anyway?"
"Started out really nice."  Beth responds, reviewing their brief history as law abiding citizens.  "We woke up in this perfectly quaint little room, everything was so cozy.  I guess we were supposed to be married.  Ha!  Anyway, next thing we hear this whining, you know, like instant children."  She gives Hale a little nudge and smile.  "Wish I had my cell to catch his expression.  Turns out to be this giant, I mean really big orange stripped cat, the Alice in wonderland kind."  Her expression turns sullen, "I hope somebody's feeding her.  Anyway, so while I played with our new kitty, Hale went down stairs to check things out.  Turned out, like we inherited a pottery outlet; is that cool?  Okay, so, whatever.  We opened for business, right?  Next thing you know, I mean it wasn't even two hours and some jerk drops a flowerpot or something.  So, what can you do?  Like Hale goes out to collect, and they get into it.  But this creep had a crew, you know, bodyguards... and they all jumped on Hale; just started kicking the shit outta him."  Beth points affectionately to her new slave.  "While the turd that caused the whole problem, he steps back to enjoy the show.  Well, nobody was paying any attention to me and I was standing right behind him.  There was this big heavy old shovel propped against the wall."  She fidgets and cocks her head a little with a devious grin.  "I'm sure it had his name on it.  So I whacked the SOB, wasn't a love tap either.  Leo, it made a sound you wouldn't believe; just like in the horror movies.  Next thing you know we're in the paddy wagon, cart actually.  I looked back, his crew musta set the place on fire 'cause it was going up in flames.  Along the way people were throwing garbage at us.  A pair with a bite out of it hit my shoulder and landed in my lap.  I threw it back, didn't realize they were just trying to be helpful.  Wish I'd a kept it.  Then they dropped us in the slammer, and I do mean dropped."
"Wait, something's wrong;" Leona suggests, "everybody was supposed to get weapons and--"
"Oh, was that for me?" Beth supposes.
"Was what for you?"
"A hatchet, I guess."  Beth surmises with a shrug.  "When Hale went to check on our investments, I opened the closet.  Wasn't a built-in, you know, one of those big furniture like things."
"An armoire?" Leona advises.
"Yeah!  Anyway, I wanted to see what kind of outfits I had, almost got clobbered when this big hatchet rolled out.  I mean like an extra large pizza pan on the end of a fence post."  She shrugs, "I couldn't even lift it."
"That figures.  Hale probably got a slingshot."
"It was a knife, big one;" Hale recollects.  I remember now, lying there on the table when I went downstairs.  Never dawned on me that I should have stuck it in my belt or something."
"Yeah, I know what you mean," Leona agrees.  "You have to get in tune pretty fast around here or it's over."
"So where's Art?"  Hale asks.  "What's he up to?"
"Branched out, you could say... he's kind of in the catering business right now.  How's your leg?  Can you get around okay?"   
"Could be better," he informs discouragingly.  "My knee's messed up, throbs sometimes.  My foot goes numb if I walk on it for more than a few minutes."
"Could you run if you had to?"
"Trot along for a while maybe, a short while."
"Don't worry," Beth assures.  "I'll hold him up."
"Do you think you could ride a horse?"
"I'd give it a serious try," Hale advises, "long as it was moving away from here.  Problem would be getting on one; ribs are bruised pretty bad too."
"Shit!  Stay off of it much as you can.  When the time comes we may need to move out fast.  Beth, how about you; ever ridden a horse?"
"You mean on the merry-go-round, right?"
Bird's pointed little head pops up; he looks around, notices Beth staring back and disappears back from whence he came.  Beth's eyes light up.  "Hey!  What was that?  Are you aware of something living in your bra?"
"That's Bird!"
"Leo, that was a little snake... with feet, not feathers."
"It's a long story."
"I'm sure... Is it housebroken?"
Hale's not surprised at anything anymore and can't resist.  "I think we have a few of those in here, Hon.  I'm sure I can find you one if you like... might have fur and a long tail though."
Beth is not in the mood for sarcasm.  "If you can't offer some constructive element, just go away, okay?  This is a time for positive thinking."
Hale limps back to the straw heap and eases himself into the pile.
"Leo, this is no fun anymore." Beth confides in a serious tone. "I'm tired, this place smells bad and I'm getting itchy.  Hale and I have been penned up together, I mean like totally inseparable... for five days now at least.  He hasn't even touched me, not even a nudge," she whispers.  "It's like being married.  If we don't get out of here soon, it's going to ruin a good relationship."
"It's just as well," Leona says with a sense of caution.
"What!  I can see it's time you and Art took separate vacations.  I recommend Acapulco."
"Probably right, but that's not what I'm getting at.  This is serious, very serious.  You've seen the guys that run this place; they aren't too sharp and... well, they're kind of unregulated.  Stay out of sight, in the shadows, in the back there.  Let Hale collect the grub or whatever.  Don't do anything to attract attention to yourself, especially making out.  Last thing you want to do is give one of these goons any ideas, understand?  The rules didn't cover a time-out because something's not fair.  What I mean is, there may not be any way to turn them off once something got started."
Beth nods her understanding. "Got it," she sighs in a whisper.
Sounds of someone approaching stir the sober atmosphere to caution.  An old woman in tatters comes nigh--the cleaning lady one might suspect.  Round shoulders and nearly bent in half for the years of toil she has traded likely against some minor infraction.  She's taken a motherly fancy to Beth, perhaps seen as the daughter she never had or one lost along the way.  First casting a shy, but suspicious glance toward Leona in all her finery, she then turns her warmer attentions to Beth, producing a bruised apple from a fold in her apron.  A real treasure under the circumstance and probably a significant sacrifice on the old woman's part as well.
"See what I found ya!"  She says in a whisper, "Sweet I'm sure it is, too."  She passes the apple through the bars to Beth, cautioning softly, "you need this for ya baby."
Beth flinches, then responds just as discreetly.  "I told you, I'm not... that way... really."  She insists, then turning her eyes to Leona with the innocence of a child caught in the cookie jar.  "It's just not possible."  Leona responds with only a sly smile.  Beth rebukes her insinuation.  "I'm not!" she repeats sternly, but still so quietly that Hale remains unaware of the topic under discussion and so most surely, she is and knows it. 
"Yes you are dear." the old woman counters politely.  "I know it from the scent of you."
"Now there's a compliment," Beth relents with a sour look.
"And a fine stout lad like your man there it'll be, too," the old dear adds with an assuring smile.
Leona takes the old woman's hand. "Your concern for my friend is appreciated and I thank you."  Take these, you know how the system here works.  Get them and yourself whatever you can." Leona has placed several coppers and a dozen lead strikes in the old woman's palm.  "Can you tell us anything of the way home?"
"To the garden of Iris ya need go, can't see the way fur ya though."
"Thank you."
"Go now or pay," comes a gruff edict from a brawny silhouette standing amid the alley's entrance way.
"Hang in there, and keep Hale off that leg.  I'll be back soon as I can."  The group disperses, Leona rejoining her grim escort for the fifty-yard stroll toward the gates.  The keeper of the keys emerges to grant her exit from his dismal domain.
She inquires of him, "Are you the master of this gate?"
"There is none but I." he declares smugly while toying with his beard.
Leona snaps her thumb, propelling a silver coin in his direction.  The ring is sweet to his ear.  He snatches it from the air like a dragonfly would secure some unsuspecting morsel on the wing.
"See that the girl and her man servant are well fed and not bothered;" Leona announces boldly, "it will be greatly to your future benefit."  Anyone hopping to ply the jail keepers' natural sense of compassion and secure a bit of comfort for a friend's final days dare not offer up less than a copper, but silver, well, now your talking loud and clear.  He opens his palm to see what he's caught then acknowledges her generosity with a slow courteous bow.  No doubt their will be considerable debate this evening as to how such spoils shall be divided for 'tis likely none of these rogues have ever touched a silver coin before.  Leona tries to appear as aloof as possible, strolling casually to her coach as though no care would dare to trouble her.  Her rented footman again humbles himself as she approaches; the door is opened with grand fanfare.  Expensive this charade, but necessary and not unlike any Hollywood production where image is in fact everything.  Dangling the prospect these two unfortunate guests have wealthy benefactors may buy some time, slight measure of comfort and hopefully restraint from their captor's desire to torment.  Jolted back into the soft leather seat as the team pulls away, the need of a bold plan plays upon her thoughts.  Lingering there also, the morbid reality that from history's point of view bold ventures are attributed only to those who have succeeded.  Whereas, those who have failed were obviously misguided fools with any recollection of their deeds soon forgotten once the bodies were buried.
Her thoughts are spiraling with possibilities and the probable consequences are not a pleasant place for the mind to dwell.  I've got to get them out of there.  These trials are mine, I'm not sure why, but they're mine not Beth's.  It's not fair.  and now she's pregnant, give me a break!  Come Oonnnnn! This is right out of the Hollywood play book  Somebody has been watching a lot of old films and making notes.  Chill... So where are we?  I don't think I'm dealing with complete psychos so logic should be the best course.  Problem's two fold, but basic enough.  First the time line and second, there are very few places in this historic framework or realm or whatever where a girl might snatch a hundred in gold all in one spot.  So, what are my options?
No such thing as banks, everything's cash and carry.  All the liquid assets are in the hands of top dog and his underling lords, or the crew that runs the Cat Walk.  Which, as it is apparently tolerated, brings us back to underling lords.  All the available weapons systems are seriously dependent on blunt force manpower.  So, all I need is a large, well coordinated special forces unit that can function without coms, RPGs or helicopters... not likely!
Short term cash hoards, two options.  A tax collector, and from what I hear they stay in secure fixed facilities and you go to them.  Which brings us back to a full frontal siege.  I wonder if that thousand in silver for the dragon's head is really out there?  I suspect it's all show and no go.  Four days out and back, no time for planning, finding it, swiping it, and if it's not there at all or I can't get at it, no time to execute a backup.  Beth would be finished.
Stick's suggestion, and a wise one at that, the sugar daddy option.  But, given her condition neither daddy nor Beth would go for that and not likely to fly well with Hale either.  Be a lot easier to pull her out of some villa than Roux's dungeon though.  My charms certainly aren't worth that kind of cash in this town or any where else for that matter.  Maybe I could interest someone at a serious discount, fake it till I find his stash.  Get real! bastard be dead soon as the light went out.  Running out of options here, Leo."
"What's left? investor scams.  Well, I didn't have to cross the Brooklyn Bridge to get here, nor did I notice the Eiffel Tower on the horizon so monument sales aren't going to work.  Besides, way too much time required to set up a mark.  But hey! there is my stock and trade?  With the right stuff I can make some pretty weird things happen, 'least as far as these people are concerned.  There is bound to be an Alchemist somewhere in the town and this is a fantasy roll playing game right?  Every game has three primary elements; The evil sorcerer, Roux is onboard for that part.  Dragon lore, though the local version is not much to brag about there are fools enough around to count that in too.  And last but not least, some fuzzy faced old turd that claims he can turn lead into gold!  Good old smoke and mirrors, the stuff of fantasies... Might work.  After expenses I do have at least two genuine gold coins left to salt the ruse.  I think I'm in business.  If I rig up some batteries I might be able to avoid the investor gimmick and go with counterfeits.  Stuff has to look good.  Besides Beth, someone is going to have their head on the line too if it goes south.  Could be less risk trying to fool a tax collector anxious for his commission than one of the local millionaires who have likely been approached by scammers before.
Laying her head back into the thick plush cushions she closes her eyes for a moment's deep reflection, but it shall be denied.

Chapter-8

GAMES WITHIN GAMES AND DREAMS AMONG DREAMS,
WHICH ARE REAL AND WHICH ARE NOT, BUT THOUGHT TO BE?

Sounds of the horses' hooves clopping along are covertly transposed to that of vague but familiar voices.  The joggling of the coach diminishes more and more till finally all is still.  The background conversation is clear now, the clipity-clop of her rented team has ceased.  Leona opens her eyes to find herself sitting across the small candle-lit table from Art.  He suspended in deep concentration over his predicament as kitchen knave and as much removed from her presence as she from his until just a moment ago.  Okay... Nobody's like 'Oh, you're back.'  So where've I been if not here?  Over her shoulder, Beth and Hale are jabbering to one another, each arguing the fine points of unrelated topics.  The game master's absent from his podium, but everything else is exactly as it should be.  Everyone is present, calm, cordial, and accounted for; no one appears even slightly perplexed nor uncomfortable.  She now recognizes the yuppie male from his portrait on the bulletin board as the fellow Stick referred to as Roux, Lord of the lands and apparently the scoundrel holding Beth and Hale prisoner.
Within the crystal, which is Leona's mind, the image of the coach's interior has faded to a view of the game room.  Sanaia alerts Mark of what this change to his guest's perception means.  "She's returned again, her presence is entirely removed from the Minnon's domain.  See how she inquires of her surroundings?"
"Is the spell broken?" Mark asks with concern.
"No, as you see in the stone her perception of the room's interior is as we would have it, not as it is.  Rather, her participation has been suspended, a defense of sorts.  Somehow she's accomplished this, an effort to stabilize her thoughts, regain her footing.  Great doubt still lingers as to which is real and which is not.  That's why she's done it... to test this environment against the other."
Mark rises, feeling a need to make his presence known within the game room.  Sanaia catches his sleeve.  "Mind you, sir.  She has a very forward and aggressive sort of disposition at the moment.  If you go out there just now she may challenge you to explain what's happening.  And as you've accepted the burden of game master for this endeavor; you may not decline, in fact you are compelled to answer truthfully."  Mark exhales deeply as one beginning to realize he's becoming more and more entangled in a web of his own making. 
Leona waves her hand slowly through the candle's flame; it's hot.  Now caressing the soft drink can on the table, it's cool, the shroud of condensation is refreshingly damp.  Recently acquired no doubt or it would have warmed to the room's temperature, though she has no recollection of how she's come to possess it.  Everything seems solid and real, yet a moment ago hadn't she flipped a silver coin to some roguish fellow seemingly in charge of hell?  That coin was cold, too, and hard enough to sting her thumbnail when she snapped it into the air.  The sound of it rang as clear as the soft background jazz she is listening to right now.
Upon returning to the podium, Mark avoids eye contact with his guest of honor.  There's no need to give the impression her activities are being monitored, nor to instigate a challenge.
Lord Roux, better identified as the male of the yuppie team, as we stand now on reality's side of the playing field; rolls the dice and flips a card.  He pouts playfully, an expression of concern arising as he shares it with his partner, now the Consort.  "Treachery in the ranks, my dear; the seeds of revolution are brewing a bitter tea for us.  I shall hang them all," he declares with an assuring nod.
"The spies dear," she advises insistently.  "Use the spies."
Placing another card from his reserve of defenses over the first, he raises his sight expectantly.  Sanaia's tray has become more welcome since first they met; he's practically come to flirting, but then that personality developed during the binding has slipped into the Minnon's realm where Leona should be also.
"And how many choices am I permitted on this occasion?"
"Only one, sir."
"Will it be a good one?" he teases.
"I have not the means to say, for that which is good to one may be tragic for another."  With that she smiles while he selects the fate of his conspirators.  He appears to have found a welcome conclusion to his dilemma, slamming the card down with great delight.
He turns to his partner with an aloof expression, awaiting the recognition and praise deserved of one possessing as he does of so much natural talent.  "Treachery begets treachery, they are found out.  How shall we reward their misdirected intentions my dear?  To the gallows do you think, or one of the machines?"
"Much too quick, no fun there.  Consign them to the stake; I'd prefer they squirm for a while when the fire's are lit."  Thus, fate's hand has snatched up some poor fellow to suffering, or has it brought a pail of oil to the wrong pile of kindling?
A somewhat disgruntled Art casually addresses fair Leona without even the courtesy of looking in her direction.  "I can't believe you just left me there."
"You left me... remember?" she replies with the same curtness.  "And you haven't the resources to support my quest.  Beth and Hale are in deeper shit, you can afford to wait.  I expect our exit will be under hot pursuit.  Given a choice, I'd advise you stay where you are so I know where to find you in a rush.  You get froggie and run for it, you better plan on finding your own way 'cause once I've got Beth and Hale I'm not going to risk any delay searching for you, got it?"
That said, she continues to scan the room for some hint of what is transpiring.  If any of the other players are experiencing the game as she is, they hide the fact well.
Beth is sipping up the last viable drops of her root beer when Leona decides to test the legitimacy of her alternate universe.  She reaches over pulling Beth near and whispers softly into an unsuspecting ear.  "Why haven't you told me you're pregnant?"
Beth ceases her slurping and drops into suspended animation for a moment while the gravity of Leona's inquiry sinks in.  She stands, cocking her head slightly as she tends to do when something has gone off que.  "Excuse us," she pleads with a sweet smile, taking her friend by the arm and leading her off to the privacy of the powder room.
In the spell room the ever-observant sorceress smiles.  She's going to test the validity of the other game against this one.  Marwyn come to me, we must talk.
Beth drags Leona into the ladies' sanctuary, her expression uncharacteristically stern.  Leona is grinning from ear to ear at the thought there may soon be more than one Beth in the world. "You are!" Leona whispers.  "Wow!"
"Where did you hear that?"  Beth demands in hushed desperate tones.
"Amazing!"
"Amazing, my ass!" Beth demands again, "who told you that?  I took a bus all the way to Chattanooga to get those kits and paid cash, and I wore that stupid old wig and my glasses, put on six sweaters and dressed like a nerd and everything.  And you know they're not a 100% accurate anyway.  Who told you?"
"How many kits?"
"Three."
"And?"
Beth begins to shuffle around and looks toward the floor.
"Three for three!" She mutters.
"You haven't told Hale yet, have you?"
"Nope!" Beth admits, "timing has to be perfect."
"Sorry for the jolt, may not have been the best idea I've had lately.  I had to check something out and that was the only way to confirm it.  Something weird's going and it could be a big problem." 
"About seven months mine's going to be a big one too."
Leona takes hold of Beth with a comforting squeeze and soft reassuring tone.  "Trust me; in this world, you and I are the only ones who know."
"In this world!" Beth's eyes lighting up inquisitively, "Is there another... I mean like reality TV two?"
"It's starting to lean that way."
"That would be freaky."
"I have this distressing uncertainty, weird as it sounds, that I'm not altogether really here.  I just hope the rest of you are."
"Huh? Come on! You've been in outer space ever since I found you in that room full of knives.  What happened?"
"I don't know," Leona concedes, "but all of a sudden it's like I can touch smoke and feel the shape of it even though I know I can't.
"Great!  Leo, anyone else, no problem, but when you're not making sense I get a little worried."
"Yeah, me too."
"Like I said before, let's just get ouuuttttt---." 
Beth's voice fades mid-comment to a whisper as reality yields to the previous joggling about and clipity-clop of fantasy land.  Little difference which is which, for under the circumstances what's to be done?  She must hold a steady course and walk the fine line set before her till she's certain of which way to jump.
Before sunrise the morning next Leona has covertly returned to the Keep's vicinity, cautiously slinking about the forest's edge on a logistics and reconnaissance mission.  The structure is a nearly rectangular heap of stone with battlements no less than thirty feet above the ground and five watch towers thereabout.  All in all the facility is one hundred percent functional, as to say less than an architectural delight to the eyes.
The eastern bulwark parallels the city's wall approximately three quarter mile east.  As the wide roadway approaches the corner watch tower it divides, one branch turning sharply west then north along the western wall, but also continuing down into the adjacent hay fields and ultimately sweeping in a long arc southward into a dense forest there beyond.  The other continues straight ahead parallel to the Keep's foundations on the city side.  The roadway's held in place with several heavy retaining walls in a tiered fashion.  Adjacent thereto the landscape drops steeply over a rock strewn hillside for another hundred feet, then leveling somewhat to a gentle treeless fields planted to hay extending eastward all the way to the city.
Locals would consider this the voluntary entrance.  Those who visit by this rout do so without escorts to assure they don't change their mind and run for their lives.  The portal is wide open till dusk, flanked on either side by twenty foot square watch towers and ultimately protected, as at the prison, by a massive drop door supported between the adjacent tower's foundations.  A dozen guards are on hand to verify invitations introducing travelers or dignitaries from other city-states who have pre-arranged an audience with Roux, Lord of Mosheum.  The road terminates abruptly at the entrance, thereafter the ground drops off into a steep inaccessible decline which continues to the corner then west.  A few small heavily barred portals at a level well below the road's surface can be seen in that portion of the wall.  These are likely to assure the residents of the basements do not suffocate before Roux has an opportunity to send a welcoming basket and inquire of their good health.
The Keep's southern rampart is straight and uneventful, adjacent thereto more open fields also planted to hay.  About sixty feet from the corner along the western bulwark is the involuntary gate, the always locked prison's entrance with which she is already familiar.  Escorts are nearly always necessary for those approaching this portal and most who depart travel due west to the lime pits just out of sight beyond the forest's edge.
Just east of the north west tower is the service entrance and security headquarters; a hive of activity if only for the amount of hay coming in to feed and bed the horses, and near as much stable residue constantly on it's way out.  Roux's troops and their steeds are apparently garrisoned full time within the walls; hence available 24/7 at the drop of a pin, or more likely a head.
Were someone intent on taking the fortification this would be the weak point.  For if the guards could be overpowered in the middle of night without raising an alarm and the drop door release secured, the sleeping garrison could be taken at a minimum of risk leaving the facility nearly defenseless.  Even so, the task would require a hundred regulars and perfect coordination.  
There are neither outposts nor sentries beyond the walls and no secondary containment, not even a ditch.  Leona diagrams the topography, ground cover and roadways.  For every wager of life and limb requires facts and however well conceived dare not exclude contingencies.
--
Though Alchemy is considered akin to witchcraft and sorcery it is tolerated for all those holding sway over the population employ such practitioners and specialists.  Yet never do these same folk fail to condemn any who so much as mention the existence of these so-called black arts.  Alchemy at least, being a science of the elements, dares embrace a foundation in reality.  Though shunned by most, a precious few carry on in self-imposed exile as prisoners of their hopelessly inquisitive nature.  Alchemists, not the worst of criminals then, remain cautiously out of sight and yet highly prized by those having faith or shackled of dire need.
'Tis thus, Leona wanders this most secluded lane.  Nearly lost among honeysuckle vines so thick even the poison ivy may not find its way.  Hidden there, a large cottage covered in thatch comes to view; several outbuildings also thereabout, each of these the same in hue.  Above the door a wooden sign, by threads of iron there it hangs.  Letters in Greek and words known only to a few, "Alchemist" it dares declare the resident to be.  Cloistered peacefully among great weeping willows, this a quiet marshy place well away from the common folk.  A domain ruled by many snakes and giant toads who dearly love to croak.  Where great flies of dragon's namesake hum about, slender bodies of iridescent blue upon gossamer wings they float.  Willfully defying every concept gravity might imply, and ever so cautious of any passers-by.  Has this maiden come upon their quiet bog to reside, or as some, seeking not but a tranquil place to hide?  Narrow windows obscured by vines, baskets of flowers and drying herbs dare the curious to peak inside.  Purveyor of remedies, concoctions and mixtures to soothe, a proclamation to assure no evil sorcerer there within abides.
Entering, she finds the interior an artist's still life of ancient apparatus, magical devices and mechanical contraptions.  Seeming a particular emphasis upon exotic containers and models of flying insects, the proprietor perhaps aspires to be the Icarus of his time.
A quaint little lady, at least a century on her calendar and looking favorably toward the next, eyes her guest.  She displays the sort of curiosity a child might, having found a new sort of brightly colored bug.  Quietly she sits, but very much attuned in what appears to be the world's first and only rocking wheelchair.  A bay window close at hand, enclosed by a lattice of reeds and threads, several small birds thus confined to keep her company.  They twitter and chirp with excitement heralding Leona's unfamiliar presence.
The dear old girl maneuvers a counterbalanced, gimbal-mounted device with the appearance of a window.  The contraption includes four small round panes of glass--another first, quadrafocals?  Without a word she proceeds to carefully check Leona out, bottom to top.  Of special interest is the tiny face staring back from the edge of Leona's blouse, in particular the red trident-shaped iridescent marking under the creature's chin.  In just the right light, they appear to shimmer and glow as that of a ruby-throated hummingbird.  A tiny detail none would notice from any other point of view and come to think of it, neither would they want to.  One could assume this a very important indication of the maiden's rank within the world of sorcerers and witches.  For none before are known to harbor such a pet, 'least with such intimate adore.  Leona patiently waits while the inspection proceeds and then exercises her undeniable authority.
"Good morning milady, and how are you this fine day?"
"Oh my... a fine day it is, yes."  Thus, acting as official receptionist the dear gives a little tug on one of several cords dangling from the ceiling.  Within a few moments, the Alchemist, a short, stout gentlemen appears at an adjacent doorway.  Upon his shoulders at the moment the upper portion of what appears a leather prototype for the first hard-hat deep-diving helmet including a crude air hose, made it appears of gut, dangling from the top.  Unlatching the protective faceplate, he swings the tiny window aside, all the better to see his new customer.  Mom winces at the pungent aroma that follows after him, but relents and motions anxiously for his immediate attendance.  Removing the apparatus with a great exhalation of relief, he bids Leona wait a moment and hastens to mom's side, bending down to listen with a hearing funnel.  Mom's words never fail to impart great wisdom especially when the funnel is requested, for thereby she can speak so softly that even when company is present they may not overhear.  And even were they less a revelation, is it not after all the place of every good son to be mindful of his dear mother's wishes?
"The dragon" she whispers, "which half the realm searches for, know ye why it shall not be found?"
"No Mom, not the slightest."
"They are very wise in both thought and deed," she continues ever so quietly.  "They can walk in plain view yet unseen.  Even now, one stands before us, yet as it were not there at all.  See you keep a civil tongue, deny this sorceress nothing... or we are toast!"
"Yes, mom," he rises from the conference, turning to Leona with a cheery but cautious disposition.
"My name is Hemmil.  How may I serve thee, milady?"
Leona has been tuning up her sales pitch, for the fate of her friends depends desperately upon this fellow's assistance.  If he declines, she may be forced to take granny hostage, which would be very uncool by any standard.  "I intend no disrespect to a wise and learned man such as yourself."  A little buttering up never hurts.  "As a student of your craft I have knowledge you may find useful, knowledge I would gladly share.  That is, in exchange for certain materials and services you alone might provide."
Leona's respectful attitude is disarming given Mom's misunderstanding of her preeminence.  That she would ask rather than demand or threaten is a great relief.  Mom at first feared that by some odd quark her inquisitive lad had offended some unknown entity and this witch was the agent sent to resolve the dispute.
"I can show you the way of a flame ten times as bright as a candle, and properly employed, hot enough to cut cold iron as a knife would slice bread.  And another, sharp as the breath of any dragon to bind it together again."  The mention of dragons causes the Alchemist to flinch, but he maintains his composure.  "Indeed if all goes well I shall make lead appear as gold, though in truth, lead it shall remain.  These secrets are yours if you will help me play my enduring game."
With such enticements, Hemmil hardly needs his mother's warning to encourage cooperation.  But claims are to be taken with a grain of salt, for deeds are quite another matter and charlatans abound.  He remains distraught of the notion this young maiden will be rummaging through his cherished possessions however.  Neither does the prospect she may expend ingredients nearly impossible to replace tickle his fancy.  Alas, however, he is not the sort to disobey his mother.  And truth be known, both concerns are preferable to becoming toast.  "Mother grants you license to do as you will; my apothecary is at your disposal."  Those last few words are truly difficult, but looking to mom for reassurance, he is pleased to see her beaming smile of agreement.
A great feeling of ease comes over Leona; she responds with a respectful and most sincere hug.  "Thank you, sir.  Your kindness may save my friends from the gallows."  The touch of a sorceress--Wow!  For a moment, Hemmil's not sure if he is still to be counted among the living; surely his heart has skipped a beat.  General consensus foretells of those so embraced as having lost their will, if not life itself.
Thus, Leona has set herself no less a task than that attempted by every wizard, witch, fool and sorcerer of lore, both real and imagined; the humble transformation of lead, the most base and manageable of metals, into the stuff upon and for which empires and fledgling corporations are built and destroyed.
Every con requires working capital and this venture is no exception.  Thus, her next order of business is to convert as many possessions, meager as they are, to currency.  The necklace of ancient coins, a few rings and river pearls discovered in the gypsy's wagon are the only items left to sacrifice.  Though it is of well-worn bronze pieces, she comes away from the trading with four coins of silver.  A revelation, the old coins must have been more valuable than she suspected.  The rings and other tiny treasures net seven coppers more in total.
With the silver she purchases a light, well-crafted two-wheel cart and a second horse to help pull it.  Then promising to add her fine leather saddle to the bargain for the inclusion of certain modifications.  The tongue is to be replaced to suit a team, with a bit of extra space for a small narrow bench there between.  The axle remounted to a set of fine limber carriage springs, and the ends set with brass sleeves so as not to wear upon the support pins.  Iron rings are to be heat-shrunk and bolted about the wooden wheels like barrel hoops, and the wheel bearings enlarged and bored to accommodate thick lead inserts with brass sleeves.  For this time and place, such modifications are the equivalent of installing a roller cam, three deuces and a nitrous oxide tank on the family's old Chevy.  The tailgate is to be extended by two feet of good oak and hinged on both sides as well as the bottom with removable pins.
"Yes, and I shall have a stout plank of oak two feet wide and three feet high securely attached to the back of the driver's seat and another to that with hinges along the left side.  A heavy leather strap wide as my hand with buckles must be installed at the center to fit half again the girth of your apprentice there."  She points out the lad riveting the iron ring of a carriage wheel at the anvil.  "And two others, half as wide sturdily fixed from top to bottom on either side.  I've asked of your standing; all pronounce you a man of your word.  I must have your pledge this be complete with the rising sun three days hence."
"My word is my bond," the smith proclaims with pride.  "You shall have your cart just as you desire, milady."
Leona extends her hand.  The smith hesitates, turning his soiled palm to view; she takes a firm grip of it, sealing the bargain with a firm snap.  "Done then."
Once off and out of sight, "Never seen the likes of that," the smithy remarks to his apprentice.  A wench with such exact demands, 'tis not a good sign, lad.  She need tend to her pots and children; 'least till the hay needs stacking."
"Are ya going ta do all that stuff, sir?" the apprentice inquires with some reserve.
"Yes, I've said I would; the bargain's been struck and she has paid in full.  Man can't go back on his word or we would soon be earning our bread at less profitable chores."
"But she's taken the saddle she's promised off with her."
"Would ya expect her to stand here for three days while we fix her cart, lad?"
"No, guess not."
"Have ya ever ridden a horse without a saddle?  You got to think, boy, it is to be a two-horse cart.  I'm thinking she only had the one she's riding 'cause she just bought another from me, that makes the two.  When she's back to claim her cart, she'll be bringing the horse 'cause it's a two-horse cart she wants.  So the saddle ya see, it'll come back with her.  Do ya see how that is, lad?  Besides, I have the cart and the horse, and nearly all she's paid for them.  So ya see, she's the one to be trusting us to keep the bargain."  The apprentice reviews the sequence of give-and-take in his thoughts for a moment.  He nods rather an "I suppose so" than a complete understanding and returns to his forge and cherry-hot iron.
While the wagon smith soups up her sporty new APC, Leona is off to gather the materials to deceive and confound her antagonist.  First to the potter's shed for a sack of moist clay, therein her metals of deception to cast.  "And I shall have six square crocks in each dimension the size of a man's foot.  And a basin too, twice a foot wide and three times as long, but only half as deep.  Glazed and fired watertight, inside and out, one and all."  Lastly, a basket of finely powdered quicklime from the potter's kiln for a very special cake.
Then to the barrel maker for several uncommon kegs, one only a foot and a half tall and another very peculiar in every way; of its purpose one might think surely to catch dragons.  "I shall need the staves on one end to extend beyond the closure by the length of your middle finger.  There is need of a bunghole the size of an egg at the center of the recessed end with six more around in a circle no larger than a nail.  Each of them to be tightly fitted with a tapered brass plug."
"The smaller cask is to be half the size of the others in each way, but of hard locust, sir.  No less than four times the normal thickness with hoops covering its entire length, one upon the other... three times over!  Both ends must include a plate of iron over the wood and likewise securely embedded within the staves.  There is to be but one hole in the side, half the size of a copper and midway between the ends.  Two heavy iron bars shall be forged round about it with a sturdy handle riveted between them.  Finally, I shall require a standard ale keg set in a cradle so as not to be rolling about."
"Most unique, this small cask," the cooper implies.  "May I ask of what use you intend for it?"
"The purpose is my master's business, sir; I only know what he requires, not why.  It should be of no matter so long as I pay for the service and receive it well-done."
"I assure you everything made within my shop is well-done, milady," he asserts with pride.  "This curiosity shall be no exception."
Next to the foundry for metals, His Lordship's own as a matter of fact.  'Tis a foul-smelling, filthy and miserable place where the heavy work is done by men in irons.  Prisoners of His Lordship's dungeons, granted dubious favor for their strong backs.  Art was fortunate Klena had taken on his debt; it would have greatly complicated matters had he ended up here or in the mines.  Spinning a tale of her father's need for things of which she has no understanding is the simplest way to avoid questions.  To power her mechanisms of illusion she bargains for several small lead ingots, lead sheets, a basket of coarse unrefined ore and some very expensive thinly hammered copper foil.  With flirty smile and playful manner, wondrous promises are made of which there is no intention to keep, but they do invariably earn the blushing maiden's discount.  
Now to a vender of dry goods for the makings of a spider's lair, a coil of strong hemp twine for weaving webs of treachery to confound any who dare pursue.  Paint bound of linseed oil to keep it secure in the rain in tints of brown, yellow and green to color her cart all the less likely then to be seen.  Beans, rice, salt, simple utensils, and a shallow cast iron pot, the likes of which she once had many, is added to her lot.
Her war chest is nearly depleted, not but a single silver coin and six coppers remain where 14 coins of silver once hid.  Yet to be found the deterrent of choice: a reliable longbow and at least two dozen good shafts.  The two gold coins remaining from the sale of Art's sword must be conserved, lest her deception fail for the lack of a proper hue.
A tinker's the final source of elements critical to her devices; but the sun has yet to proclaim the hour of noon and proper selection of certain components requires light even less than the moon.
Returning to the Apothecary to begin her great deception, she finds Hemmil nervously waiting to see what disarray she will impose upon his helpless domain.  Attempting to ease his tension and assure her presence is not a threat Leona displays her gatherings for the day.  This, to dispel concerns she may conscript major resources from his stash.  "Whatever tools I may borrow," she assures, "I promise I will return to wherever they were found.  None shall be taken nor lost.  I have no desire to disrupt your experiments, sir, and shall make every effort to keep your things in good order."
