A substantial portion of his workshop has been set aside for her conjuring and witchcraft.  Apparatuses safely relocated and the hiding of everything he hopes to preserve stealthily accomplished with great haste this morning during her absence.
Not the least aware Bird's presence has secured their relationship, her foremost desire is to prove her worth to this bargain.  Magic of this magnitude demands she bake a cake, one requiring temperatures very near those of a foundry.  Blocks of hardwood must be roasted without access to air, thus forming the necessary dense charcoal fuel.  A lean-to at the rear of the workshop houses the primary tools of every alchemist: a furnace, a kiln and a great leather bellows to force an air stream into the appropriate vessel.  A stout young lad has been commissioned for the next morning to labor at the bellows and fuel for his task must be ready.  Leona loads a large iron tub into the furnace chamber, fills it with blocks of oak, and slides an iron plate over the top.  Though coal would be preferred none is to be found, nor is it even known to exist.  When the vessel is heated to normal wood-burning temperatures the air will expand and expel itself along with any residual moisture still within the oak.  She fuels the furnace with kindling and small logs and sets it afire.  By morning the oak will have been converted to a low-grade coke, hopefully capable of baking a stone cake.

Chapter-9

TURNING LEAD INTO GOLD IS EASIER THAN MAKING DIRT.

The most critical element of her deception hinges upon how faithfully she can cast lead reproductions of the gold coins still in her possession.  The Alchemist's tools are crude, but still the most accurate to be found.  Aside from the miller's water-driven grinding stones or the mechanism for lifting the Keep's siege gate, machinery does not exit here.  Alignment and uniformity are the keys to success in the high art of counterfeiting.  Leona retreats to lessons first learned in second-grade art class, impressing objects in moist clay to make pretty designs, with appropriate refinements of course.
A small mallet activated by a length of hemp thrice strikes a chime hanging upon the wall.  Hemmil immediately interrupts his task.  "Pardon, milady, my dear mother calls.  I shall be just a moment, if you please."  Looking toward Leona, he hesitates as one waiting for permission.
"I'm fine with that, sir.  There is no great discovery to be missed this morning."
He nods shyly and shuffles off to see what dilemma mom has envisioned now; for three chimes is the equivalent of a fire alarm.  As he enters the sitting room Mom motions him come near.  She seems calm--much too calm for a three chimer.  She always speaks very softly when something has agitated her; thus, he must first retrieve his listening funnel.  Cocking her shoulder in a quaint little-old-lady sort of way and smiling ever so slightly, she drops the bomb.
"My boy, have you prepared His Lordship's elixir?"  She tweets softly as a bird talking to itself.  "The coach I think has just arrived."
"Oh dear!" he croaks nasally, a panic attack well upon its way.
"I thought not.  You must also suggest to our guest, in a very polite way, mind you, best it would be were she to remain unnoticed.  For you know how inquisitive old Botch can be and we have not a good answer for her presence, do we?"
Hemmil scampers off, wondering exactly how one might graciously suggest to a sorceress that she should at once make herself scarce.  He approaches Leona, who is quite involved with her counterfeiting preliminaries, clearing his throat to get her attention without actually interrupting.
"You look vexed, my friend," Leona responds cordially.  What problem must be solved?"  The shop's door chime rings out followed promptly by a brief proclamation announcing the arrival of His Lordship's messenger can be overheard.
"Best I am not to be seen, do you think?" she whispers.  Hemmil nods agreeingly.  "Where then shall I be?"
He points timidly toward a half-open door at the far end of the workshop.  It leads into a dark cobweb-laden storage lean-to.  Quickly scanning the work area for any incriminating items, she retrieves her two gold coins and departs.  In less than a flash she's quietly disappeared into the shadowy lair of things long since lost and forgotten.
A sigh of relief pleasantly descends upon Hemmil, though short-lived, for he must hasten to the sitting room, receive his guest and make excuses.  Thus, he stiffens up and exits with a confident bounce.  His salutation is preceded with a gracious bow, no simple task for one his age.  "Master Botch," Hemmil acknowledges.  "Please convey my humble blessings to His Lordship and all his trustees of Mosheum our fine city.  I hope this day finds you well and in good spirits."
"Yes, yes, as well and good spirited as any.  There are many tasks to occupy one in my position and I must get along with them, you understand.  So, may we proceed?"  Sir Botch nods to an accompanying servant who passes an exquisite wooden cabinet to Hemmil.
"Yes milord, immediately, the last of it is seeping through the filters just now.  If I may be excused then?  I shall have His Lordship's balm straight away into the flask."  Botch waves a hand excusingly.  Thus, Hemmil shuffles off to his laboratory, where once out of sight frenzy ensues.  A web-enshrouded jug is exhumed from a shelf beneath one of the tables.  He pries out the stopper, carefully taking the slightest whiff.  Whoa!  He recoils at the odor which produces a ghastly expression; that jug is resealed and exiled to a top shelf.  He continues, cautiously sampling the aroma of several others till the bouquet of a squat green crock brings a welcome nod of approval.  Hemmil extracts a fine glass vessel from the messenger's cabinet and places a funnel therein.  A second glance reveals a caterpillar has wedged its way into the tapered spout and turned into a hairy crust, likely a causality of the residues.  The obstruction is ejected with a thin stick and an exuberant puff from the small end.  He tops His Lordship's decanter up with an oily, honey-colored concoction some might define as laudanum with a spirit, and others, absinthe with a thud.  It matters not whether the green fairy now wears garlands of apricot or opium has taken on thundering overtones.  Either way, the consumption of this stuff cannot but initiate mind-altering experiences and an inescapable desire for more.
Returning to the sitting room Hemmil returns the cabinet to His Lordship's agents with a courtly bow.  The servant removes the decanter and pours a half shot for the Alchemist.  Poor Hemmil graciously accepts, throwing it back in a single gulp.
His head shudders briefly.  "I believe it more palatable blended with a hot cup of plentifully honeyed tea; but I shall concede the details to His Lordship's desires.  Though I would not presume to instruct, as always I must caution, sir, this is a potent restorative; one must respect its authority."  Hemmil's voice is beginning to squeak, he struggles to continue.  "Restraint is the key to its effectiveness; a certain measure of danger does exist in using too much... too often."
"Yes, yes, I understand.  'Tis indeed reassuring to see you stand behind your potions.  I fear there are some who might be tempted to conceal treachery amongst their services to Lord Roux."
"A terrible thought Sir Botch, terrible, terrible indeed."  They bid each other formal farewells and Botch is off to annoy other good citizens of the city.  Hemmil returns to his workroom and flops with some unsureness into a chair.  "You may come out, milady," he advises in a sickly tone.  "The wretched fellow's departed."
She is quick to emerge from the spider webs.  "I think something has died back there."
"'Tis where the cat drags its victims.  The beast is well fed, I see to that, it has no need of them.  But it continues to kill... like some in our midst.  For the joy of it I suppose."
"You look ill, sir.  Is there anything you require?"  She begins to approach, but Hemmil stays her advance with a sleepish wave of his hand.
 "Nothing may help.  It's that confounded potion; I have no antidote for its stupefying effect, befuddlement is my reward.  I'm obligated just as His Lordship's cooks to consume a sample as reassurance no poisons have found their way into the mix."  He inhales a great lingering yawn and rubs his eyes, knowing that in short order he shall become as mindless as a peach pit.  "It will be noon of the morrow before my thoughts are clear or my feet capable of finding the floor.  Please see to Mom if she calls."  He rises and staggers off toward his room, dismayed and confounded of his own devices.
The remainder of the afternoon is spent measuring and mingling elements of foul intent.  These better kept from her host's curious eyes, so it's just as well her patron has retired.  By and by the sky has turned to shades of rust, lemon and plum, and mom has dozed off contentedly.  But there'll be no rest for the wicked for time has come that Leona be on her way to keep an appointment with the Tinker.  
Traveling at night is a slow perplexing concern undertaken by very few, and nearly impossible if the sky lacks at least a quarter moon.  The phases of this mysterious orb are well-known to all; for both thieves and honest men alike must abide of its scheduled flight.  Not entirely dependable though, for who shall say when clouds might flood the sky and steal away that invaluable bit of light?  Nature shall not be denied; in fact 'tis the only real tyrant of any land.  So it happens, as the chosen hour of her plotting comes nigh; some four days hence, the sky will turn to pitch.  And all the better so, for 'tis much in Leona's favor this wandering sphere of light is destined to keep appointments on the other side of night.  Even more so if it becomes necessary to invoke her brand of magic.  The intended route away being a narrow road which soon dissolves into a deep forest.  A path dark as dusk even in the light of day.  None but fools or the very desperate would attempt such folly after dusk.  But that which hinders one may serve another well, and that which hides the way may preserve them all from hell.  For one who commands the light holds sway over even the darkest of nights.  
Approaching the metal smith's shop, Leona notices the watchful gaze of his own fair lady from a tiny window in the loft above.  The citizens of this world retire early with the best intention to rise at dawn.  For the light of day is a valuable commodity of which not one moment may be wasted by the working classes.  Few in this place have more than meager resources to deny the night.  Candles and oil lamps are expensive and so reserved for the early hours that one may begin their day's work with the cock's crow.  Uncommon 'tis sure that anyone would be doing lawful transactions after darkness has fallen.  The Tinker, however, is pleased to have a customer at any hour who offers so great a reward.
Earlier, when first she visited to inspect his wares, curious requests where made of his talents.  Among other things, 120 fine slivers of copper were ordered to be carefully cut from the thin hammered sheet she provided.  "They must be no wider than they are thick" she has specified, "and each the length of my index finger at least.  And a 120 more, these only half as long, but five times as wide."  Indeed, this maiden's requirements are among the most curious he has ever been asked to execute.  Earlier, searching through his inventory of expensive brass bowls and plates she had selected several, each having a slightly different shape and curvature.  "Of these good sir, I shall require each be polished on their inside only to as bright a finish as you are able."  A lucrative bargain to accommodate her needs has been negotiated.  On his part, the necessary labor and materials.  For hers', the secrets of a lamp that can bring a flame upon the tip of an iron candle so bright that it may clearly show the way thirty feet hence even in the pitch of night.
Now has she come to judge his polishing skills to determine which of his pots has the most effective focal length.  The winner to be incorporated into the head lamps of her getaway cart.  Each of the bowls is propped up such that they face an uncluttered whitewashed wall.  Then, with all other flames extinguished, she slowly moves a single candle to and fro at their center.  Each curvature concentrates the beam upon the wall in a different way.  The Tinker is astonished at the phenomenon, a fair indicator this wily maiden does possess the secrets he's bargained for and the best of it is that no witchcraft is needed to duplicate the effect.  Having determined the most suitable for her needs, careful measurements are made to document the flame's position relative to the bowl.  The Tinker's been contracted to produce iron conduits with a series of pinholes at their tip, along with a suitable means of securing them between the polished bowls and the small kegs she will deliver for his modifications day after next.  Just out of sight, the Tinker's suspicious wife lingers while he and Leona draft plans and debate the best means of constructing her devices.  As the assemblies need be absolutely stable dimensionally if subjected to severe joggling about were it necessary to get her transport into overdrive.  If a conduit were to separate from the keg or the reflectors became misaligned, the lamps would become useless, thus, appropriate reinforcements must be carefully contemplated.
For her return trip she's brought several torches and a crutch of sorts.  One end is trimmed to engage her saddle's stirrup, the other to support her wrist.  By this she may hold a torch at arm's length for an extended period that her mare feels confident of its way.  Crickets and katydids chatter to a chorus of rustling leaves, and there seems always a dog somewhere just beyond the torchlight's reach concerned of their passing.
--
Word of some wild female's scrap with one of the indigenous ruffians has spread as quickly as rumors of dragons.  A goodly number of otherwise unfamiliar faces have come around to the Brier Keg throughout the day.  All it seems are anxious to speculate as to what calling this high-strung wench pursues, and in so doing find ample excuse to consume a pint or three of booze.  In theory alone she has grown to well over six feet tall and near 200 pounds without her club.  All are curious to catch a glimpse of the Amazon who has kicked Matthew Pounds' arrogant ass--in public no less!  The Innkeeper's somewhat wary of the crowd.  Yet not having cause to send them on their way, though somewhat boisterous, all have remained on reasonably good behavior.  Though for sure, he has enticed a pair of roving constables with free sausage and ale to tarry thereabouts should order need restoring.  All who linger are within walking distance of their abodes; yet still 'tis rare to have a dozen patrons more than usual this late into the evening.
Leona's arrival, well after dark, raises eyebrows even higher and initiates another round of drinks and hushed conversation.  Offering not a glance of provocation, she ignores the stirring.
With so many coming and going throughout the day, nothing but bones and crumbs remain of the dinner served up two hours earlier, a portion of which she was entitled too.  The Innkeeper's been smitten by her fierce independence and motions her come nigh.  Thus, as her trustee of the moment and much to his wife's chagrin, he has set aside a plate of ham, potatoes and a baked apple.
"Thank you, kind sir.  I shall go to my room straight away and not cause any trouble for you this night."
"No trouble at tall!" the Innkeeper assures,  "I've sold more ale today than any fortnight past.  Lads 'ave come from near and far, some lingering the entire day.  I'm inclined ta think," he muses with appropriate beam, "'tis fur no better reason than a glimpse of thee."  And though several have boasted they'd buy her a pint, the time is nigh and none have dared.
She lowers her head as much in dismay as to hide the smile refusing to remain at bay.  "I have no inclination to dally with these fellows.  Let them think as they will.  Please see that no one comes to my door until first light and then only to wake me."  She carries her plate off for a private meal away from the attentions of her fan club.  Considering her objectives, there is a great desire to be as a fly unnoticed upon the wall.  This sort of attention can only create problems if she's forced to run.
Though her mind is awash in details; the drone of the insects and amphibians of the night are an undeniable sleeping potion.  She is soon fast to slumber and thus, perchance to dream.  Which is to entertain a fantasy within an illusion--at least so it would seem.  But know yea this, a dream is quite the private place, held in great esteem.  A lie is something with intent to deceive.  A dream is but the mind's attempt to please.  Hence, such flight of fact the Minion shall forgive of thee.  For self-delusion while one sleeps is thought no lie to be; and naught is lost nor gained by that which only dreamers see.  As to the Minnon's eye, such lacks truth or false of any quality, and thus remains unseen as that to be held privately.
--
Finding herself now within a great hall, though soon to realize she appears a child about the age of three.  She looks about as only a child may possess such innocent curiosity, yet moreover with the perception of an adult.  The ceiling is high, very high as though it reached into the clouds well above the sky and the walls are sheathed in light warm walnut and burled elm with grandiose moldings of damson plum and pecan.
I've never been to the other rooms, yet still I know what each is like, why?  There are narrow panels of bluish crystal with enchanting designs, but I can't see through 'cause their so high.  I know they're windows, and I know what view lies beyond, but I can't see anything except for sky.  I'm not very tall at this time you see.  Stately bronze borders skirt round about each.  But, how ever should I know that, is someone tutoring me?
A young maiden wearing a near translucent snow white smock glides by carrying a tray of candies and flowers, but pays me no mind what-so-ever as though I didn't exist.
 What is that, I wonder?  Smells like lemon sweets to me.  Love this floor, it's covered with fuzzy stuff, soft and warm to touch.  Lamb's wool, I think.  It tickles my toes and makes them curl as such.  I know because I've not any shoes and just the tiniest feet.  Daddy's face is fuzzy, too.  Mom giggles when he comes too near.  Talking to me like expectant father's do, as though I really could hear.  A breeze with the scent of sandalwood flows through the room.  I feel my hair float upon its embrace; lighter than gossamer it was then.  That lemon candy, please, can I have a taste?
I see a grand table at the far end of the room, lavishly set with candles, flowers and all sort of elegant dishes filled with the tastiest of treats.  The guests are waiting for me, I think.  I know mom is, 'cause I'm late.  It's not my fault! I'm walking toward them fast as I can, but they keep moving farther away.  I don't understand why; I know it shouldn't be, if only where they are they would stay.
Seems I've caught up at last, now sitting there like the rest.  No one seems upset at my tardiness; I was trying hard as I could, and one must always do their best.  Even though I really haven't arrived yet, I've always been misunderstood.  Pleased they are now in fact that dinner may at last be served, I'd love a taste if only I could.  A quiche, mom's favorite, so you know it's mine, too: four layers of cheeses, each with a different kind of mushroom and olives all mixed through.  Best part is the third layer with chunky blue and white cheese, red olives, and for all I know toadstools, too.  I love this stuff, I know I do, wish I could remember how it tastes.  Everyone looks so big, like they were giants; I'm so small compared to them, really, it's a disgrace.  They wear robes of rich bright fabric, spun by little worms I've heard, and spun upon little looms too I'm sure.
The man at the head of the table has a beard and mustache; oh my, he's big.  There are six beautiful ladies on his right.  The nearest to him, my mother, his new bride I think tonight.  She has two rings, one of gold for all to view, the other of light that none but her and I may see.  Beside each a slender young maiden stands in waiting for anything they desire to be.  The others are never very happy when daddy presents them a new bride, but he is master of this house--hence all things here must abide.  Thus, they may not but endure, yield to his desires and set his amorous adventures aside.  On the master's left sit five young men, tall and strong every one of them, each three years older than the next.  They are my brothers.  I know they are even without a clue, because they are his sons and he is my father, too.  I know he is 'cause he smiles at me, though my mother dare never tell her husband so.  My mom, though Queen of Durer she may be, carried off to paradise, pampered, plied, and seduced as these things go you see.  I love him still, though little choice had she, but neither mom nor I ever may confirm such to be.  For I happened to know she thought it all quite grand and thus, more than willingly offered her hand.  Strange, I can't see their faces, though they sit right there before me.  Some way obscured no matter how I strain to make them out, but I know who they are, or at least who they are supposed to be.  What am I doing here?  Are there not games to play?  How does all this come to be?  Are there not dragons to slay?  Is such not my destiny? though yet I am so far away.
Umm!  The aroma of a grand pudding fills my head: plums, white raisins, figs, dates, sour currents and sweet raspberries all very bright red.  Spirits of rum and brandy with the fruits abound.  Soon enough it will have my head spinning round, for I'm much too young for this rum stuff I've found.  Though indeed 'tis the best part of any banquet, be it large or small, or just a pudding and that's all.  A young maiden with long hair and flowing robes easily seen through, sets it upon the table for all to view.  A delicious dark brown, still steaming from the oven, beside it a bowl of cream whipped with honey through and through.
The others are talking, to me I think, or maybe just about me.  Doesn't seem polite does it?  I can't hear the words, but I know what they are saying.  Everyone's dismayed I'm not another boy to be.  All but my mother that is, 'cause she's just pleased as she could be, and she's the only one who really counts you see.  But why another anyway, there are five already, isn't that more than enough?  I know it is for me.  Though he truly loves his sons, but with five to carry on, why should any worry that I shall not another be?  I think father needs a daughter more than they an extra brother.  Anyway, what's done is done and what shall be, shall be.
My father outwardly agrees, but I think it mischief just to tease, 'cause I know he really likes me, too.  And mom's good as he.  Raising her glass, she proclaims to all, "It's too late now, for a princess my child shall be.  And every good king should have at least one, if you ask me."  All the while both are smiling, and sincerely so, as when lovers tease, but won't let go.  I know these things; for the realm is entirely in and of itself, you see.  And all that is there my father has wrought, including me!
My brothers care least of the lot; though they would just as soon I were not.  My being at all some might say tends to confuse the plot.  Why can't I have my pudding and cream before I wake from this frivolous dream?  For it's so grand and tasty, and I care to miss it not.
A tall narrow man with funny clothes and bells on his toes comes nigh.  A flat velvety blue box he brings; I cannot but wonder why.  A gift, how can this be?  For I am yet to draw my first breath; my mother must do that for me.  He opens it teasingly to show what's hidden deep inside; his eyes light up with wonder, and his little bells jingle his surprise.  And all the while, a silly smile, from ear to ear with great and noble pride.  There within a silver chain so fine it may hardly even be seen--a spider's work I think.  A tiny creature has hold of it, how totally discreet, with pointed head, and pointed tail, and four short little pointed feet.  Looks like those who chase bugs in the garden, at least so it seems to me.  My father gently picks it up; I just knew it was mine to be.  Feared he might break it though, 'cause his hands are really big you see.  But no, not so, he slips it carefully over my head; can't tell you how pleased I feel.  A gift he's made just for me, though as yet I am not even real.  "This is our secrete that none but we shall know, now then my little princess... off again you go.  For there are games to play and villains to slay until again you return someday."  And that was the last he ever said.  But I know he's pleased now that I'm finally back, sleeping here in this very bed.
With that her eyes open to the morning's first light.  She lies very still, trying to recapture particles of a beautiful dream flopping randomly about within her head.  Bits and pieces of a wondrous puzzle, dare she try to put it back together again?
Framed within the open window of her room a nimble spider watches from her dew-laden web.  Tiny beads of moisture caught therein, glowing orange and very bright; strings of delicate jewels gloriously displayed in the dawn's first subtle light.  Fragments of moisture, perfect in every way, surrendered of the night's cool air as it came to say, "those sweet dreams I've brought last night have now all gone away."  A rapping comes upon her door, and with that a voice.  "The cook bids you rise; there are hot biscuits, broth and tea in the kitchen."
--
Leona has shortened a pair of Art's pants, which she wears beneath her skirt to ride.  They alone are much preferred whenever possible.  Once back to the Apothecary, her first task is to retrieve the fuel prepared last evening and bake a cake.  The blocks of coke are removed from the iron tub and stacked back into the furnace around a ceramic vessel along with a small pot of lead.  On this occasion, however, they shall have all the air they desire.  One block is held back, ground to a very fine powder, accurately weighed, and blended with quicklime, then transferred into the coke-enshrouded crucible.  The fire box has been charged with kindling and fuel by the lad who's come to work the bellows.  Now one coin of copper is placed with a smile in the palm of her hired man's hand, and at that he's very well paid for his task.  She has alluded, though falsely so, that there could be further opportunity on the horizon so long as he stays absolutely silent as to his labors this day.  And so in fact half his reward is a bribe.  Like dropping a quarter into a vending machine he goes to work pumping the great bellows, forcing a generous supply of air into the furnace where the coke shall welcome its coming with a rage.  First a dull red, then orange, and finally a bright, shimmering, iridescent ball of intense heat surrounds the pot.  If the temperature rises high enough, oxygen will be driven away from the calcium and replaced with carbon.  A simple recipe of common enough materials, rocks and charred wood, but properly contained and formulated they can yield a compound of considerable potential.
The Apothecary's roof is piled high with thatch except that portion securing Hemmil's prized above all things accumulation of experimental data and formulations; the area there above staunchly  safeguarded by fired clay tiles.  Expensive, but this corner of Hemmil's tiny kingdom must be absolutely secure from that most basic and destructive of elements, water.  And better so, for Leona's ally has learned the value of the soft verity, give or take a few bird droppings and soggy insects.  Several stout barrels stand ready at the down spouts dedicated to the task of collecting it.  His foresight will serve well, freeing her from the effort of distilling well or bog water for the battery's cells and plating tank.  The quality of these solutions must be carefully controlled, being as they are the only means of regulating the circuit's resistance.  A power surge or short circuit could dissolve the apparatus in a few fiery seconds, bringing a quick and decisive end to her entire scheme of things.
Having served up Mom's carefully processed lunch, which is to say mush, and enduring yet another cautious scolding as to the hazards of having a sorceress under their roof, Hemmil enters his work space to find Mom's demon in disguise placing a pale or water on a simple marking at the center of the floor.
Leona smiles, "Good sir, there could be some danger to my next procedure, might I be left alone for a while?"
"Yes milady," Hemmil assures quietly, turning about and shuffling off.  He returns to Mom's sitting room and settles upon a small padded stool.  All was going well, or so he thought and he strains to wonder what he may have done to displease.
Mom thinks this a bad omen, for she knows he dislikes that wobbly old stool, and responds to his sober attitude with a cautious, I told you so glance.  "Is something amiss my boy," she questions.  Looking for every opportunity, as mothers oft do, to reinforce her foregone conclusions.
"She ask to be left alone," he replies in a dismal tone.
"She may be conjuring a demon," Mom dares suppose, "and doesn't want you to hear the words of the spell or his name.  We must be forewarned.  Go 'round to the garden and peek through that tiny window behind the grape vines to see what she's up to."
This sort of devious behavior is not in his character and he's uneasy of Mom's request, but usually she knows best.  Though, what's to become of the opportunity at hand if the sorceress catches sight of him spying on her.  Though against his better judgment, he discreetly approaches the cob-web laden portal.
Hemmil's soon back to Mom and in quite a tizzy.  "She's set a bucket of water to boiling Mom... a wooden bucked Mom, as though it were upon a blazing hearth.  It's just sitting there on the floor, frothing and steaming, but there's no fire!  Oh dear," Her son stammers, wringing his hands remorsefully.  "We may yet have demons joining us for dinner."     
Having calmed somewhat, Hemmil has returned to the garden, yet not sure if he wants to peek in again and glimpse some devilish creature dancing about with the sorceress.  He's nearly to it when the back door opens.  Thinking himself caught at this foolishness, he freezes, wide eyed, and tries to concoct some explanation for his presence.  Leona exits carrying the enchanted water pail.  She pours the contents out slowly on a large flat stone amidst a great huff of steam.  Many relatively uniform quarter inch tear-shaped beads roll out with the flow of boiling water.  Hemmil advances shyly with sincere hope the stone is not covered in vile little squirming monsters.  And though they appear not, from some points of view when properly persuaded they surely can be.
Leona detects some anxiety and feels an apology may be in order.  "They are lead not silver as you might suppose from how bright they appear at the moment.  Their luster soon will fade and turn again to gray.  Pellets were required for my purpose so the metal had to be poured from high in the loft that it would cool as it fell and not spatter.  Some droplets might have missed the pale and burst when they hit the floor.  I didn't mean to banish you, sir," She smiles, "but I didn't wish to risk injury to my gracious host, either.  I've as many as I need, so all is safe again."  Hemmil nods his understanding, smiles, and excuses himself.
"There are no devils coming to pick at our bones, Mom.  A total misunderstanding, All is well.  The truth of it so simple," Hemmil confesses, "I'm ashamed of how foolish I must have sounded."  He takes Mom's hands and confers a reassuring squeeze.  "We are safe, after dinner I will explain."
Pottery projects are next.  Leona mixes the lead teardrops with moist clay, sculpting the mass into thick-walled bottles with narrow short necks.  In modern terms, the lead pellets would be classified as shrapnel, a principal ingredient in the assembly of anti-personnel devices more commonly known as hand grenades.
Much to Mom's annoyance, one of her dear boy's tasks this morning is the burning of brimstone in a small beehive oven.  For there shall also be need of sulfuric acid, and just as in the modern world, offensive by-products are the price to be paid.  Particularly due to the archaic equipment cobbled together for the task.  The foul smoke must be collected and compelled to bubble up through a vessel containing heated rainwater.  Unfortunately, the crude valves embodied within Hemmil's leather bellows have not a good enough seal to create the pressure required to force the gas to any depth.  Thus, the greater portion escapes from the fluid's surface rather than dissolve.  And the interconnecting hose, a matter of stitched catgut, leaks badly as well, filling the house with the foul stench of decomposing eggs.
How tedious and demanding the efforts someone of this calling must have endured to prevail in ancient times.  Not a scrap of wire, hose or pipe is to be found.  No power aside of muscle avails itself for even the simplest task and every standard is unique to its creator.  One obstacle atop another and everything so slowly accomplished as to never be done.  Only genuine dedication could have prevailed under such burdening circumstance.  Every student of the art should be required to do a lab like this, she consoles, just to appreciate the efforts of their predecessors.
To make electrical conductors of an uncommon sort, she forms some of the soft clay into thick flat sheets.  Then she cuts narrow troughs and designs into the surface, these to be filled with molten lead.  At strategic points, wooden dials are pressed into the designs; thus, will holes be formed in the solidified castings when the charred wooden pins are driven out.  Lead cast in these troughs will form busbars to carry electrical power between the battery cells and plating tank.  Copper wire does not yet exist, and if it did the cost would be prohibitive, but lead is abundant, easy to work and relatively cheep.  The molds and grenade canisters are placed into the sun to pre-dry as much as possible.  At day's end, she will low-fire the kiln, baking them ever so slowly as care must be taken not to melt the encapsulated lead shot or fracture the containments.  If they are to burst explosively under the influence of her pyrotechnics there must be no structural deficiencies.
Her involuntary sponsor takes careful note of these activities.  Interestingly enough, there is not wailing nor incantations, no flailing of the hands, nor even exotic organic ingredients.  Indeed, no sigh whatsoever of witch's craft.  Each procedure is carefully orchestrated, neither time nor material wasted, and every goings-on is as basic and common as weeds.
Now, a metal smith she must be.  Taking hammer and chisel to anvil, she cuts the lead sheets into sizes suitable for her cause--that of constructing plates for the most simple and basic of consumable batteries.  For it is electricity she absolutely must have.
A long and tiring day is near concluded and Leona has not eaten since the sun first shown.  Therefore, it is with considerable eagerness she welcomes a bowl of Hemmil's spicy stew.  Barley, lintels, and onions with fowl and many peppers.  As it turns out, while the furnace was baking her magical fuel cake, a clever little chamber built into the side has granted them two loaves of freshly baked bread as well.
The final order of the day is a test to assure her recipe has properly composed itself.  Good Hemmil, ever inquisitive but indeed courteous, has graciously limited his inquiries to very few.  Always mindful to avoid any issue of a personal nature, but seemingly concerned of her plight.   blacksmith's tongs are employed to extract the glowing vessel from Hemmil's furnace.  The contents have fused into a single clump and declines to exit the crucible gracefully.  Laying the crock over upside down and applying a few light taps with a wooden block for motivation, an encouraging "thunk" her reward.  A hard bluish gray biscuit has emerged.  With hammer and chisel she breaks the clump of calcium carbide into pieces about the size of acorns.  The prize is stored in wide mouth clay jars, each sealed with a wooden plug wrapped with a thin soft strip of waxed leather as a gasket.  Even the humidity could cause the compound to deteriorate, and any outright contact with water would initiate a untimely and destructive reaction.
The sun having consigned its duties to the moon, shroud of night sets now upon the land.  An excellent time to show off, hopefully!  Leona sweeps up the remaining crumbs of the biscuit, placing the debris into a small crock.  Now all the candles save one are extinguished.  Pouring just a trickle of water into the crock initiates a great foaming and bubbling event.  A crude, long-stemmed tin funnel is placed upside down over the top to contain and direct the escaping gas.  With considerable pride, she announces, "For your assistance good sir, the first of the fires I've promised."  Bringing the flame of the last lit candle near the top of the funnel, the acetylene ignites with a "pop".  A brilliant white flame the length of one's finger juts from the opening.  The interior of the room is at once as though the roof had been torn away on a bright sunny day.  Things thought lost are suddenly evident in the nooks and crannies where they've been hiding beneath thickets of cobwebs and dust these many years.
Hardly containing himself, Hemmil calls out. "Mom, come quickly!"
Mom has wheeled herself to the doorway, cautiously peeking around the corner to see what's happened.  After all, there is a dragon in their midst, and this intense light may have been the end of her own dear boy.  Even Bird has emerged briefly, taking note of the event, thinking perhaps a cousin has come to visit.  "Properly contained and mixed with a pointed stream of air," Leona advises, "this flame is hot enough to cut cold iron well as a saw can divide a wooden plank.  And if need be, mend it back together again."
Placing a small polished tin bowl in her palm, she is able to direct a concentrated beam, as though the light were under her command.  A magic eye as it were, clearly showing the finest detail of anything upon which it alights.  Setting the lamp on the floor, she scans below the benches as a beam may venture to places the open flame could not seek.  Treasures banished by his father, condemned to be lost forever in the dust, come to view at last.
Spiders and such shriek away in terror.  For a hundred generations to come they shall relate to their young the legend of the day of light, at the time of its coming, thought by the scholars of their community to be the beginning of the end of the world.
Leona is relieved to have her creditability validated; had something gone amiss that trust could have never been rebuilt.  With this, she feels Hemmil will keep her confidence and contribute his best efforts willingly to her cause.
"The furnace has driven power into the rock; now the water sets it free.  Everything has power locked within; we need only find the proper key.  This flame will soon draw short and expire as any other would.  Only the lime ash will remain; just as it began so shall it end."
Under her breath mother cautiously adds a sprig of wisdom.  "All things return to their beginnings no matter how grand they may have become."
"Well said!"  Leona compliments, nodding her agreement.  "I must be on my way now or I shall fall asleep before I've found my pillow.  Till morning then, a pleasant night to you both."
The comforts of pillows are set aside for a while as her schedule demands the day's preparations yet incomplete.  Owls question her presence and bats flutter haphazardly overhead as she wades through the high grass at the edge of the road south of the Keep for contingencies need be addressed before the appointed hour.  It was a cautious trek as she dare not use a torch and risk her presence be noticed from the watch towers.  There are no roving patrols, nor dogs.  His Lordship's confidence in stone walls and his iron hand are a fool's paradise.  Several hours later, her late evening chores now complete, she welcomes sight of the inn.  Yet again arriving well beyond the hours kept by any maiden of a respectable character, more rumors forthcoming no doubt.  All well deserved as not, for what but devious are this femme fatale's every waking thought.  She dismounts, slips her skirt over her cutoffs, and walks the last fifty yards to belie her arrival.  Wishing to avoid the curious congregating therein, she slips into the kitchen through a back door.  A silent disconcerting glance from the innkeeper's wife welcomes her.  Still Leona nods respectfully, rounds up some toast, a portion of cheese, and a cup of tea to carry her through till morning.  Slipping into the hallway sly and quiet as a cat and without a glance toward the drinking area, she glides quickly away to her chamber.
The moon is getting sparse, thin as a field hand's worn-out sickle.  Her window faces the waning light, no need then of a candle to enjoy a meager meal nor find her pillow.
This night, the spider's silhouette and her beautifully engineered web completely envelop the window's opening.  Leona considers for a moment wiping it away to save the moths that will surely perish there before morning.  But why, isn't the spider entitled, as the hawk who's caught an unfortunate sparrow, the fox with its hare, or indeed, Hale with a helpless burger in his grasp.  Were a mud dauber to happen by 'tis the spider would perish, and not well of it either.  It's the natural order of things, as a capitalist or warlord might say, where the strong and clever prevail and the foolish shall ever die young in their service.  The trick then, to know where you stand in the line and when to step aside.  To her own ends she rightfully concedes.  After all, with an eight-legged watchdog my well-being to keep, no mosquito may come to dine on me tonight.  How can this possibly be a game?  I've crossed some kind of line here, but I didn't see it.  I need to find it, I need to know where that line is.
She crashes slowly into her bed and rolls into the quilt.  No sooner do her eyes close and she perceives a call to arms.  Or was that a call to biscuits; yes... biscuits, not battlements, I think?  Her eyes open.  Wow, that was a quickie!  A glance toward the window reveals her tiny sentry remains on guard, the light of dawn willfully displaying the creature's handiwork.  Remains of a banquet dangle helplessly in her guardian's web: delicate wings, ever so painfully lost, and tightly bundled leftovers, snacks reserved for the afternoon tea.
Oh! that her enthusiasm were equal to that which break of day imparts to the birds; who would not bound into the air and fly away?  So many different voices and each no doubt with something important to say.  Certainly would be nice to tarry a while, just snuggle up and listen to their songs.  But for Beth, confined to that filthy cage, no, even a moment's delay is too long.  At least she's got Hale to console her.  Yet here I lie, a spider to protect me and a lizard to keep company with, but we're a team... and Art's a real shit head.
Bird has been on guard, too; demons never sleep you know, the bedpost his watch tower from lights out till dawn.  Safer there; his charge you see is a restless sort when she dreams.  Not that her frolic and tussling about would cause him harm, but more his effort to get free might cause her alarm.  Her shoulder's still uncomfortable in the mornings, least till she's had time to twist and wobble around for a while.   The massive black and blue bruise thinning now to a lovely mixture of greenish and purple accents dwindles more with each passing day.
--
At the Apothecary, Mom's breakfast is the challenge at hand.  Though Hemmil does his best to make it interesting, adding honey and nutmeg this morning for instance, it always literally boils down to mush.  Everything for mom is cooked to mush; no matter of its beginning, mush is how it seems to end.  Lovingly, she places a frail hand upon his arm.  "My boy, when I saw that light I thought you lost, fearing surely you had crossed that witch and she had burned you to an ash."
"I think you more concerned than need be," he consoles with a gentle touch.  "In one day I learned so much; I can barely contain my wish she return.  She has made a list of mixing numbers and weighing numbers; everything fits together according to these.  Never the need to be waving a hand or reciting strange words as others do.  Not at all like Baroa, always casting her torment upon some poor creature who has crossed her path, or looking for an excuse to put the itch on your back.  Yesterday, in my haste I was about to touch something and she stayed my hand, cautioning it was hot.  Baroa would have allowed it, thinking a blister serve me right, then taunt me all the day for my error and wish me further ill 'cause of it."
"They can be soft-spoken and still mean as skunk-berry briers in the dark."
"This sorceress does not threaten to have her bidding done.  Even as the lad did something common sense would forbid, she came not with contempt, but a smile to explain his error.  There was no retribution nor ill mumblings, and she paid the lad with good coin not some worthless charm and a fools promise that his wife would be pleased of it."
"She may be all that and even kinder," Mom reminds, "but we don't know if she possesses the dragon, or the dragon her.  Who is to say which stands before us or which is the master?"
"I saw it... when she set the flame, perched upon her shoulder it was, then it was gone.  There seemed nothing special about it, mom, not even half as long as my little finger."
"Always be mindful of that creature."
"Are you sure 'tis not just some curiosity she has taken a fancy to?  Like the young fellow with the firewood cart; he always has a salamander or frog to keep him company."  Hemmil defends, "I've seen more ferocious bugs hiding beneath the worktables."
"You of all should know, things are seldom in every way what they seem.  Never touch her things either; wherever she places something, leave it.  Everything she touches will have her stain upon it; thus will it never be out of her sight even though it were hidden.  Never, never try to deceive, these things they know." Mom assures.  "I've seen it, and you know it too."
"I promise... I shall be very careful not to offend.  Still I think if she intended us harm, we would be a couple of onions by now."
"I should rather be a pepper," Mom suggests, "a sweet red one if you don't mind.  I've never much liked onions."
"Yes, Mom, I know you don't.  Your breakfast is getting cold; shall I warm it?"
"That would be nice, and some butter, too."  Mom does not find much consolation in her boy's wistful attitude, nor for that matter her comparison to an onion.  Shortly there comes a knocking at the door; the dragon has returned.  She concedes, there is little to do but voice caution in the matter and hope they shall not end up as onions, or anything else so distasteful.
Her son rushes to welcome Mom's favorite villain of late, but alas, only a purveyor of watermelons greets his enthusiasm.  Knowing she's at odds with Roux, Hemmil has actually become concerned of Leona's whereabouts by the time she's arrived.  Delayed somewhat, as the critical path of her enterprise first demanded two kegs for her lamps be delivered to the Tinker.
Upon her return, of what use he's quick to wonder, this mysterious small keg sheathed in rings of iron?  But the purpose and composition must remain unknown, for knowledge of the mercuric based explosives soon to be confined therein could bring a foul end to this simple world.  She is quickly back to her undertaking, for not a moment may be spent without good cause.  The molds encouraged to cure in the warm furnace are now fired in the kiln, several pots of lead included therewith.  Having the lead ready when the molds are first removed will allow the busbars be cast immediately.  This is desirable as the molds would still be quite hot and thus less inclined to fracture due to thermal shock when the molten metal is poured.  Care of every guise must be exercised for there is not the time to reconstruct a single element of her equation.
The tedious business of making molds for casting lead coins the likeness of His Lordship's prized gold sovereigns is next  They must be fired no later than tomorrow as the finished product need be delivered and duly certified by the day thereafter.  A clock is the most wicked and heartless of masters.  No matter what the task nothing may stop the passing of time, nor beg its pardon, not bribe, nor threat, nor smashing it to pieces, for a clock is but the messenger.  And 'tis well known, killing the messenger will not change the message.
"Uuuu-whooo!"  On that unlikely note Hemmil perks up with significant anticipation.  This is the mating call of a Millerie Minifoph.  Not a rare bird as one might expect, but a charming little gal of sixty-plus years who would never admit she was a minute over fifty.  Recently widowed, rumor having it her loving husband burst from consuming so much of her highly prized cooking.  She's not one to be left alone in the world at such a tender young age, nor patient enough to wait till some lucky fellow discovers she is available.  Millerie has taken it upon herself to find a new husband at the earliest convenience.  Much to Mom's delight, Hemmil has become Millerie's number one prospect.  True, the lad is forever busy with something, but there is after all a limit to the amount of mush and over-cooked vegetables a mom can take.  Millerie would be pleasant company--indeed a blissful turning point for all concerned.
She glides through the front door and proceeds straight away toward the workshop, a freshly baked rhubarb pie in hand and Hemmil's best interests in her sights.  The sound of a strange female's voice glares like an air raid siren.  She stops in her tracks and inquires of Mom, "Who... is that?  Never mind," she concedes softly, throwing her head back with the airs of a duchess momentarily concerned of the gardener's new assistant.
Mom's caught entirely off guard.  'Tis a tricky question, and a proper diplomatic response requires some thought.  No matter, Millerie is anxiously on her way toward the workshop to see for herself what mischief may be afoot.  She certainly will have none of this; a confrontation is imminent.  She stiffens up for the challenge and charges into battle.  Hemmil meets her with a warm shy smile at the entrance to his domain, whereupon she cuts straight to the point.
"Who is that?" Miss Millerie insists.
"My student," he's quick to respond.
"A female apothecary... how novel."  She wedges past Hemmil a bit to investigate; better safe than sorry after all.  Leona offers a smile.  Plainly, this child dressed as a tomboy is far too young to offer any serious competition.  She probably hasn't the slightest notion of how to stuff and bake a quail or whip up a proper apple strudel.  "Come alone now, the both of you, while this pie is still good and hot."  Her eyes flutter as she offers an enticing smile to Himmel.  The aroma of Millerie's pastry has permeated the entire room.  The taste of it sweet, tangy, and sublime in every way.
For the moment Leona has lost sight of her objectives.  "That was a treat," she confides delightfully.  "Thank you for inviting me.  I've never had a taste of rhubarb before.  There are so many kindnesses to repay and little time before I must be off."
"Where are you going dear?"  Millerie inquires auspiciously.
"I seek the house of Iris; do you know the way?"
"Iris!  From what I remember of me mother's tales, those Iris gals were a strange lot." Millerie asserts.  "Didn't care much for the men folk, you know.  Took up their customs and moved off they did."
"Do you remember where, or how far, anything?"
"I'm thinking they've gone quite a long way."
"I was told they might point the way home... for my friends and I.  Do you remember where they were before they moved?"
"From here, south I suppose.  It's been a long while, you understand."
"Well," glancing toward Hemmil with a smile, "time I returned to my lessons.  Thank you so much for your help and that wonderful pie.  Next chance I get I'm going to round up some rhubarb for my Granny's garden patch."  She leaves Hemmil and his lady friend to their twittering; even Mom has made herself conveniently scarce.
--
A circular hole, the slightest bit smaller and half the thickness of a sovereign has been cut into a carefully shaved wooden slat.  Backing it up with an oak block that doubles as a handle, Leona has constructed an impressing tool.  The face of her original gold coin must be wiped with a damp cloth after each impression.  That subtle trace of moisture acting as a parting agent to see none of the clay comes away with the original to mar the next impression.  Available technology precludes casting both faces of the coins simultaneously.  Thus, each counterfeit must be assembled from two separate castings.  Early afternoon finds 22 molds each with ten impressions of half a coin.
Storm clouds have begun to invade the sky.  To assure a ready supply of dry fuel she's begun carrying firewood from a shed at the far corner of the yard to the porch.  If this farce is to succeed there must be no screw-ups, for time to unscrew things there is not.  The unforeseen must be solved in advance, shortfalls adequately overstocked and calculations checked until there is no doubt.  These are the premiums on Beth's life insurance policy and each must be paid in full.
The shorter broad copper straps, each with the end slightly bent, are laid out side by side on wooden slats like a comb, 35 upon each of three.  A second slat is clamped over the first and tightly bound to hold these copper fingers in position.
The first of the cured molds is removed from the kiln; it will yield three lead bars a yard long.  Each is mated with one of the copper comb assemblies.  When the lead is cast, the resulting element will have captured the rows of aligned copper strips.  These are the hooks from which her dubious lead copies will dangle in the electrified broth.  As each mold is filled, the pot is restocked and set again within the fire.  For there must be sufficient metal to assure a continuous pour that no less than a full length solid bar shall be had.  The remaining elements are likewise cast, each differently shaped lead component to its specific purpose within the machine.
Shorter bars are clamped together and marked to identify them as a matched set, twelve pair in all.  The pairs are clamped together and a series of saw cuts are then made across the flats of each set.  In this way, when separated the cuts will align perfectly.  Sheets of lead are next set into these cuts and crimped tight with a broad-bladed chisel.  The perimeters of sheets from six of the assemblies are folded up to form shallow trays for the finely ground lead dioxide ore.  By this she has built up stacks of flat parallel plates with enough space between to insert two fingers at least, six of flats, and six of trays bound to each pair of the saw cut bars.  Fuses, a very important component of any power source, are entirely absent here.  Indeed, there is no way to estimate what amperage might rise from the cells.  The switch is but a sheet of lead tacked to a wooden block.  Turning the device on is accomplished by placing the block across the gap between two of the busbars.
Well after dark now, thunder still teasing in the distance, but alas the rain has yet to fall.  Hemmil is weary beyond words.  It's far beyond his bedtime, but he would gladly stay up all the night to observe more of her unique constructions.
"There are things I must gather in the morning."  Leona advises, "so I shall be late in coming.  It would be a great help if you would move the molds from the furnace to the kiln and fire it when you rise.  They've not dried sufficiently and I fear they would crack if I kindle it now."
Hemmil nods his understanding with a yawn.  "It shall be done, milady."
--
By the time Leona has reached the inn it's begun to drizzle, the air has cooled significantly, and the wind is gusting.  With the moon's light all but gone and the shower having extinguished her torch, it has been a slow precarious journey.  Waves of leaves swirl over the ground and all indications are that a good downpour is soon forthcoming.  The Inn's lamps are out and the windows shuttered; she may very well be spending the night in the barn.  Fortunately, the barn door has a terrible squeaking to its credit.  Intentional perhaps, for it can hardly be missed and serves well as any burglar alarm might.
Barely does she have the saddle from her mare before the adjacent window's shutter swings back.  "Who are you to be there in my barn?"  A voice from within calls out to challenge sternly, "Answer up or I'll come bash in your head."  Leona is quick to identify herself, apologizing for yet another inconvenience to her landlord.  "I thought as much," he grumbles.
"The loft will be fine, sir.  Don't trouble yourself."
"Well then, send the old vagrant sleeping up there down 'ear and I'll open your room for 'em.  For sure I am you'll think 'em some hooligan hiding in the hay.  Ee's an old friend and I'll not care to 'ave you pounce upon the poor fellow."
"Ah!"  The sky is beginning to open; this is not the time for indecision.
"Get ya around to the door," the innkeeper assures.  "I'll be there in a moment."
"Yes sir," she humbly replies with a thankful tone, then dashing through the downpour and huddling against the side of the building.  The door latch snaps and it swings aside.  She is quick into the darkness, the door then closed against the down pour and bolted behind her.  Flint to iron, and tinder to wick, thus, his candle now is lit.  "Take this ta see your way.  There's broth and potatoes been put in your room ta keep ya.  Better hurry 'fore the mice carry them off."
Only now does she realize that in the rush of things, she has neglected to reinstall her skirt.  The Innkeeper steps back, cocks his head a bit, and looks her over.  She's quick to turn a bit sideways, that her ankle brace be not mistaken for a weapon.  How embarrassing that could be, after all.  "Well then, what's this 'ear?  What's become of your clothes, 'ave ya lost them?"  He inquires, cautious as not, being well aware of her destructive potential.
Careful to hold the candle so her left side remains in the shadows, she weaves a little tale of half-truths.  "Oh, no sir, not lost, for they are left with the mare... in my haste to come in from the storm, sir.  I'm sure you can imagine how it would be uncomfortable for me to ride, as I must to earn my keep... dressed as a maiden, that is."
"Ya 'aven't mentioned how it is ya make yourself useful."
"I carry small things.  Apothecaries and such... from merchants to those needing them, those who have not the time nor means to gather such for themselves.  A small fee is earned for my trouble.  Tomorrow in fact, along with my savings I shall have earned enough for a fine cart.  Then I may transport the likes of dry goods... and earn a greater fee.  Then I will buy a small cottage with a field and build a little barn for my horses.  You shall see," She implies with pride, "I may end up delivering your barrels of ale some fine day.  I have it all figured out."
Though probably pre-occupied with his duties at the Brobose Inn, Art would likely be encouraged to find that fair Leona has just developed the concept of UPS.  Maybe there is hope she will see the light and begin to appreciate the fantastic opportunities that abound here at hand after all.
"Indeed ya do."  He smiles, but cautions, "Grand plans are easy ta come by, but the wind hereabout blows most of'em away.  What ever come a that lad ya was searching out?"
"I found the smithy he was apprentice to, but he was gone," she whimpers.  "Took up with another," sniff, "couldn't wait for me."  She lowers her head, "can't trust them, not a one."  She sniffs, raising her gaze to the Innkeeper.  "Least not the young ones anyways," she assures with a final sniff.
"That's too bad," he sympathies. "They'll be another, just don't kick the shit outta a 'em next time."
Leona chuckles lightly.
"Suppose you've planned on a fire ta dry out fur ya retire?"
"I hadn't, I'm not one made of such the rain would cause me to melt, sir.  I shall dry in due time, but thank you for your concern.  Good night."
He chuckles; her wit and the lack of good lighting have prevailed.  Now both may seek the comfort of their pillows without further imposition, and indeed yet upon good terms.  The inn keeper's wife meets him at their bed chamber's door.  She is less than pleased of all the attention this disreputable maiden garners.  "Not a word," he reminds sternly as he passes, "not one."
Leona slips away to her room, relieved the con went smoothly, but feeling just a little guilty for camping it up so much.  Had she opted for the fire, she speculates, he might have offered her the headwaiter's job.
In the morning, Leona forfeits her breakfast and quietly slips straight away to the barn, not wishing anyone else take notice of her curious flair for fashion.
--
Her high-performance rig is sitting in front of the wagon smith's barn when she arrives.  She inspects the springs, their connections, and the modified wheel bearings, checking off each alteration and verifying the security of the attachments.  All is well done, perhaps even sturdier than expected.  The smith doesn't come forward until she's finished, but he does take notice of her satisfaction with his work.
"You've inspected it top to bottom; does it meet your expectation?"
"In every way sir, fine work you've done for me.  I'll loose the straps so you may claim your saddle."
"The lad can take care of that fer ya."
"Thank you!  May I impose to have your assistant hitch the team--I need to watch and learn, you understand."  Before his labors have concluded, he's also called upon to drill additional holes to facilitate attachment of the lamps and water keg.  While loitering about, Leona appropriates a double handful of worn-out bearings to supplement her supply of lead, which has run lower than expected.  Several generous forks of hay are also added to soften the bed for her passengers.  All in all a bargain for the tidy sum of a single copper, to which she adds another for the apprentice's unwavering assistance.
"For the lad, when you feel it appropriate.  He's done well by me."
"As you say, milady."
Things are coming together; she is soon but a cloud of dust upon her way.
"Don't think ya charged her enough, sir," the apprentice is quick to lament once she's out of sight.  "The metal in them old bearings was worth more than a copper, I'd say.  Then there was the hay, too."
Forever in need of educating his apprentice, the wagon smith advises.  "Look there in the field, what do ya see lad?"
"Nothing... but the grass sir."
"Yes, green hay it is, and since the sky don't charge me for the rain, what does it cost me ta have it growing there?"
"Well... nothing I suppose if ya put it that way, sir."
"Right, now then; are we hay merchants or wagon smiths?"
"Wagon smiths ta be sure, sir," the apprentice is quick to agree. 
"Right again lad, wagon smiths, not hay merchants.  Wagons are heavy, as I'm sure you know and they wouldn't go far were there not a horse attached.  So then, naturally there are horses about--our customer's horses I mean.  In the order of things, if we treat their horses well, it comes round that we treats them well too.  And 'tis wagon smiths we shall remain so long as we have customers, you see."
The young man's wheels are turning again.  Fortunate it is that his master understands the need of lessons in public relations as well as how to mend a wheel and continues to elaborate.  "Annoying our customers for pittance of hay, which as ya remember costs us nothing, would shoo them away like flies.  If word got round, we might end up hay merchants after all.  Working dawn till dusk for a few lead strikes, that is, instead of being wagon smiths and paid in fine silver.  Do ya see how that is, lad?" 
The young man ponders the concept for a few moments, nods a yes and is about to return to his labors.
"By and by Her Ladyship ask me ta give ya this."  He places the copper in the lad's hand.
"My word, sir, a copper!"  He looks to his master with some astonishment, it being the first coin he has ever received for his labors and a fine one at that.  Forty full pints of ale dance whimsically about his thoughts, maybe fifty, or even sixty.
"She didn't have ta pay ya cause it's me ya work for, not her."
"Should I return it?" the lad wafts sorrowfully.
"No, that would be foolish and an insult ta the lady's good intentions.  Neither would serve us well."
"But, no one ever pays an apprentice sir.  Why would she do that?"
"There are those as grateful for our help as for our labors.  And ya just seen an iron strike's worth a hay ta come round near a hundred-fold in just an hour.  Now that's a fine profit," the wagon master assures.  "Do ya see how that is, lad?"
"Yes sir, think I do."  Though in truth, it will likely require considerable reflection when time permits.
From the Tinker, Leona recovers the two small customized barrels, now fitted with iron candles and polished reflectors.  He too has followed her instructions faithfully, and proudly shows off a smaller version assembled entirely of brass--a likely forerunner of the carbide miner's lamps later adapted to carriages and the first tin lizzies.  Leona points out a few shortcomings of his design, and so, now upon his way to being the Thomas Edison of his day.  When the voltaic cells for her electroplating operation are set in motion she will have pushed the technology of the game through nearly five centuries of development.  She hesitates to reflect upon what might come of this world were it to continue beyond the game's conclusion.  The formulation of her high explosive mine, were it disclosed, would likely consign much of it to ruin.
Final elements of her sorcery are gathered now from the potter's shop.  Six square crocks for the battery containments and the large plating tank are loaded into her new cart, each carefully isolated from the others by mounds of hay to assure they survive the jarring trip back to the Apothecary.
A day of following Beth through the malls has never been as hectic as this.  More provisions are needed and she is tragically light of coin.  From the open market she purchases a bushel of apples, a flank of dried salted beef, several blankets, and two hefty sacks of oats to fuel the two horsepower engine of her new get-away cart.  Last of the necessities is a sturdy longbow.  For this she returns to the cutlery shop where Art's sword was disposed of.  Only nine coppers remain in her war chest.  A tidy sum for the common man, but not much to support four fugitives on the lamb, particularly if there is need of a bribe to secure someone's cooperation.
The Merchant recognizes her as the willful lass who so impressed his wealthy customer the week before.  Thus, she's earned a bit more respect than might be accorded the average maiden curiously wandering about his premises.  Most important, he presumes she can afford most anything her heart desires.  She's taken an interest in his selection of hunting bows and he's quick to accommodate.  "A good day to you, milady.  Fine sport archery.  I've some excellent target bows that would suit a lady."
"I was thinking more on the order of one that could take down a boar, say at about 40 paces."
He waves his hand toward the far end of the rack. "Any of these would be up to such task.  May I inquire, is this for milady?"
"Yes!"
He selects a weapon for her inspection.  "Highly crafted this one, a bit more costly, but the maker takes great pains.  Assembled of thinner elements in larger number, the additional layers afford more strength to a lighter weapon.  And I assure you, he concocts the finest glues in the realm, he does.  I've never had one of his bows come undone."
Leona sets one end to the floor alongside her left foot, steps into the arc, and snaps the bow string taut with the expertise of a seasoned archer.  The Merchant muses to himself as to why he is not surprised she can string a 60-pound bow in a heartbeat.  If nothing else, her visit shall make for interesting speculation when next the noble who purchased Art's weapon visits.  She pulls the bow slowly to its full reflex several times, thinking it stiff, but manageable and smoothly drawn.  "What cost have we here?"
"One and eight, milady," the merchant coos.
"Could that price include an extra string sir?"
"Indeed it could."
"Thank you, sir.  And what choice of points do you offer?"
"For something with such a tough hide, the weighted single-bladed broad-heads would serve best."  He hands a shaft to Leona for her approval.  "The maker of these is a craftsman who abhors imperfection.  Each has been shaved to an identical weight and balance," the merchant assures with pride.
"Have you any shafts with narrower but heavier heads," she asks, looking straight into his eyes, "something that would set deeper?
The merchant hesitates for a moment, then from a leather folder below the counter he produces a shaft with a barbed head about a third the width and half again the weight of a standard hunting point.  "perhaps these, just as well made by the same craftsman.  I've heard that properly delivered, they can penetrate chain mail.  Not to infer that to be your purpose of course, but I've heard it said."
Leona examines the tip and indeed it appears up to such task.  She withdraws the fine blade previously purchased from this very same gentlemen the week before, placing it upon the counter.  "Pray tell, sir.  What credit might you consider for this fine blade, used only twice to slice an apple, but never yet to cut a chain?"  With that, she shamelessly displays her best and most humble expression.  This was unexpected, as he knows she left his shop with a small fortune just a few days ago.  Yet here again she stands, not even with new clothes to show for it.  He examines the blade to assure himself that no misdeed has crossed its edge.
"I would grant you two and five against purchases in my shop or two and two if you prefer coin."
"A fair arrangement, sir, and I humbly accept."  She adds seven coppers to the bargain, coming away with the bow and 40 matched shafts, which may in fact be spent against vests of mail.  In her haste to be off, she has forgotten a very important accessory.  The Merchant, accustomed to such oversights, calls to her before she can slip away.
"Would milady require a glove?  Plucking that string could have the hide off your fingers on short notice."
"Oh yes!"  She twirls about and in so doing tells her secret.  She returns to the counter fumbling for her purse.  The Merchant, having seen it all but empty, offers her a fine glove of tough pigskin.
"With my compliments," he nods, adding so as not to embarrass, "for a valued customer... good hunting, milady."
Leona smiles and returns the gesture, prancing out to the square with the step and air of any young lady, having just received a grand present and pleased of it.
The Merchant has overheard some of the hooligans who frequent his favorite watering hole whispering of a certain wench whose confrontation with an unfortunate tax collector has become legendary.  Though most dismiss it a foolish rumor, hearsay would have a short sword strapped to her left calf, a blade that flies to her hand of its own accord within the blink of an eye.  He has seen plenty of swords and many another strange weapon, but never one concealed as this, though certainly there it was.  For in truth, any female spinning quickly around as a dancing gypsy might, will surely have upon her the gaze of every fellow in sight.  And the faster she turns the more she teases, "Hunting boars... right!"  He concedes with a sly smirk.  Seems there's bullshit all over his floor that none but he may smell and only since just now.
Having gathered the last ingredients for her venture, she returns to the Alchemist's to assemble her deception.  The worn bearings she obtained from the wagon smith are cleaned and boiled to remove any residue of grease, then added to the melting pot.  The voltaic cells are the next challenge.  One assembly each of lead plates and pulverized ore trays are placed in opposing positions within the square crocks, this to form a single stack of alternating elements.  Wood blocks are inserted between tray and plate to assure they do not sag.  Flat stones are added to the bottom, filling the spaces between the busbars supporting the plates and the sides of the crocks to prevent them from shifting.  Any contact between the elements would short circuit the cell with a furious arc.  The posts of each bus are connected together in series with lead bars which act as jumper cables.  Attachments are made by driving out the charred wooden dials that had been inserted into the molds prior to casting, then replacing them with lead pins.  A pointed iron punch is driven into the assembly pin causing it to expand like a soft rivet.  The positive pole of the system is affixed to a bar spanning the plating tank into which two pieces of folded copper sheet have been embedded.  The negative side connected in parallel with the three long bars having the appearance of copper combs.  Thus, the framework of her electrical generating system is assembled.  When the space between the opposing sets of plates is filled with sulfuric acid, an electrical potential shall arise, or so she hopes.
The new slug of lead has liquefied; it's time to make money.  Molds of the coin impressions are removed one at a time and the lead carefully cast therein.  Molten lead has a very high surface tension.  As the impressions are filled the metal mounds up in a convex-shaped puddle.  Not nearly as high were the molds cold, but still more than desirable.  Once solidified, the tedious chore of finishing the backs of the half coins begins.  Each blank must be filed flush with the face of the mold before being removed.  This is necessary to maintain an identical thickness to each finished replica, a task requiring half the day at least.  For to maintain its cutting ability, the fine-edged file will demand removal of the soft metal clogging the serrations five or six times for each half coin blank thus finished.  Once smooth, a keen straight groove is carefully cut into half the blanks with an awl and the ridges formed thereof carefully scrapped away with a sharp chisel.  These to accept the fine copper filaments so the lead blanks may be supported from the negatively charged busbars.  Each filament yet requires a small loop be tied into its end so as to be hung from the three rows of hooks.  They complete the electrical connection between the counterfeits and the plating bath, hopefully drawing a golden sheath of creditability over her play money.
A dozen candles sit across the rear of her workbench, each with a thin pointed iron rod which has been driven into a wooden handle and placed just above the tip of its flame.  A copper filament is placed into the groove on the backside of a casting, then clamped with the mating half into the cloth-covered jaws of a small wooden wedge style vice.  The tip of a heated iron is then carefully drawn over the joint, melting the seam together.  Release the wedge clamp, rotate the coin a quarter way round, and repeat the operation with a new iron as by now the first would have cooled beyond its usefulness.  Thus each single coin is formed with a fine copper tail, and each must be perfect.  Tedious maximous as the Greeks might say, for all in all over two thousand different operations are required.  The work finished, a very tired sorceress allows her weary head to rest, just for a moment though, upon an aching arm, there soon fast asleep.
Mom's breakfast arrives with some sense of urgency.  "She's stayed all the night, Mom," Hemmil exclaims in a hushed tone.  "Sleeping at the worktable," he points.  "I don't know what to do.  Should I wake her?"
"No!  She could be conjuring a spell," Mom implores cautiously, "or under one, for all we know.  To wake her may insight a terrible rage.  Who can say what might be undone... or unleashed?  Let sleeping dogs lie, my boy.  There is good reason to heed such wisdom."
"No spell has she used to do her bidding; she toils just as the rest of us.  Come and see."
Mom throws an uncomfortable glance, then nods a reserved approval, her curiosity overwhelming the fear of being transformed into a toad, or even worse, an onion.  Hemmil quietly wheels his dear mother into the workshop, a preview of upcoming marvels to behold.  First they examine the apparatus of metal bars and plates.  "How simple it is, Mom," Hemmil points out.  Taking particular exception to the lack of magical writings, strange talisman, or the inclusion of bloody parts from ill-fated little creatures as seems the custom.  "Wait till ya see," Hemmil teases.  Hemmil wheels Mom toward Leona's worktable, being as light of step as Cele when she stocks Doorman's food dish to filch chicken scraps, her favorite.
Coins the image of His Lordship's best are neatly laid out upon a cloth atop the bench.  The newly cast lead, yet to tarnish, appears nearly as fine as silver.  Mom's eyes light up bright as Leona's magic candle; she begins to jingle, hardly able to contain her expectations.  Hemmil quickly wheels her back to the sitting room before she's overwhelmed by the prospects.
"Oh, my word!"  Mom exclaims, seemingly unable to catch her breath.  "Do you think she can really do it?  I've heard it can be done.  I've heard it time and time again.  Your father tried, and his brother, and all the others, too.  Every person with a brain between their ears, and many more without have tried.  You would not believe the effort... and the coin they wasted.  Nearly every copper that came into their hands spent for one absurd notion after another."
"Calm down, Mom," Hemmil cautions.  "You're getting far too excited."
"I swear he was about to drive me crazy with it, your father was."  Mom's good arm is flailing about as though she might try to fly at any moment.  "They built contraptions, unbelievable things; you can't imagine the foolishness."  She protests, pointing an unsteady finger toward an attached storage shed.  "Some of them still lurk back there in that pile of junk."
"No good will come of this excitement, Mom; you must calm your thoughts."
"You see, my boy, the metals are so like each other."  She sputters, undaunted, yet knowing the wisdom of his concern.  "Both are soft and heavy," Mom continues gleefully.  "And you would think... Just a little change in the color would be so simple.  They mixed the lead with everything from bat piss to mother's milk, but nothing would work.  Nothing!"  She stamps her foot resentfully, "Made me so mad."
