Mom's got a hold of Hemmil's arm and just won't let go.  He's trying to remember where her calming tonic has gotten off to.  "Please mom, let me loose now, I must find your syrup or your going to pee." 
"Just you hush and listen to what I'm telling you.  That witch has clouded your reason; just look at her, so young and perky.  No one of her years but a sorceress could know these things," Mom assures with unbridled passion.  "If His Lordship catches hint of these doings, he'll hang us all."
Hemmil spots the ominous dull green bottle, a preparation concocted by his last remaining uncle.  Re-formulated several times over the years, softened he supposes to accommodate mom's increasing age.  It must work though, for none remain of her childhood playmates, nor hardly even any of their children.  "Very well, I shall not wake her."  He sets the bottle on mom's tray.  She looks at it quietly.  "You know 'tis for the best," Hemmil assures.  "It has always been so."
"You'll see," she quakes, pointed a frail finger.  "If we don't come to toast or onions, we're gonna end up dangling from the hangman's pole."  She takes a swig of her tonic, wrinkles her nose in disgust and chases it with a heaping spoon full of her over cooked mush for relief of the foul taste.  Soon, she's folded her arms up around herself with a very "you'll see, I'm right" expression, and awaits the calming.  In no time Mom's recollections of her late husband's foolishness have abated and she's wistfully gazing out the window trying to count the golden yellow butterflies who frequent her white lilacs.
Though unaware of the consequences awaiting Beth at sunset this very evening, there seems a great urgency to his tutor's efforts.  Several times squirrels or a raccoon have gotten into his workroom and created quite a ruckus.  Hemmil sees no reason why such a harmless event might not reoccur at any moment.

Chapter-10

WAKE UP, WAKE UP, YOU SLEEPYHEAD; 
OR YOUR FRIENDS SHALL SOON BE DEAD!

CRASH!  Leona's eyes flash wide open.  "What? Oh shit! it's daylight!"  She jumps to her feet, calling to any who would answer.  "What time is it?"
The Alchemist steps into the shop from the rear yard.  "Are you all right, milady?  I heard something break... I thought."
"What is the time?" she insists.  "How much of the day is lost?"
"'Tis morning yet, the day's hardly begun."
Leona bolts to the outdoors where the sun will tell the tale; she makes it to be between 7 and 8:00AM.  Beth will become the guard's plaything in less than twelve hours.  "Shit!"  Dismayed of her laziness, she returns to the workshop.  How could she allow those precious hours slip away?  "Will you help me?" she implores Hemmil.  "There is much yet to be done.  "The lives of good people hang in the balance."
"Oh my, we can't be losing those; good people are hard to come by.  Set me a task."
"Bring three pails of water from the rain barrels," she declares.  In one pail she mixes a pickling solution, this to remove her oily fingerprints and the slight oxidation that has formed on the bright, newly cast coins.  Any trace of either upon the metal's surface would act as an insulator deflecting the molecules of gold attempting to attach themselves to the electrically charged surface.  In another she concocts a solution to neutralize the effect of the first.  The third remains plain water to rinse away any residual trace of the neutralizer within the second pale.  The three most important requirements are that the lead facsimiles be absolutely clean, clean, clean!  "You must not touch the coins with your fingers," she cautions.  "They may only be handled by the copper tails.  Dip them into one bucket after another, start always from the left, hold them to each for a count of five.  Place one upon each hook," pointing out the hooks cast into the underside of the three bars spanning one end of the plating tank.  "They must not touch each other.  If at any time there is doubt to your purpose, please sir, do not hesitate to inquire.  The time of correcting has passed.  I am bound by any error between now and the setting sun."
The Alchemist nods his understanding and sets to work preparing the counterfeit replicas for their final transition.
Leona has gathered most of the makings for her pyrotechnics: brimstone, saltpeter and charcoal for black powder, phosphor and resin for matches, nitric acid, alcohol, and the playfully elusive quicksilver to concoct a powerful fulminate.  If push comes to shove, she fully intends to shove back.  The munitions are equipped with self-contained matches and strikers.  These elements are sealed against moisture with hide glue and the wax of bees.  Clever the treasures these little workaholics have learned to fashion from a flower.
The 110 best of the counterfeits are chosen for the mission.  The hour of eleven arrives as Hemmil hangs the last of the coins upon the copper combs in the plating tank.  Leona has fetched several more pails of rainwater, filling the tank to a level just above the lead counterfeits.
She crimps the very edge of a genuine gold coin into each of the two copper clips supported from the bar opposite the fakes.  Rude and crude to be sure, but it will have to do, for she has not the facilities to reduce the gold coins to water-soluble salts.  An experiment this costly is difficult for Hemmil to imagine.  Those two sovereigns probably exceed his entire net worth.  To risk such wealth is a measure of confidence few of the Alchemist's profession would dare.  From Leona's point of view, a bid for the life of her friends at any cost does not require a second thought.
The countdown approaches zero as the six crocks of metal plates are filled with the juice of smoldering brimstone so unpleasantly concocted earlier.  Every recipe has its magical ingredient though, that special something that makes it work.  For bread the yeast, for a cake the soda, for pickles the brine, and for coin of the realm brine will also do just fine.  Coarse salt ground ever so finely and stirred into hot water, pour it into a pot with chicken you have soup; poured into soft rainwater and you have free ions.  Not so tasty as the soup, but it will encourage the flow of an electrical current.  Ions are tiny things, rowdy at times if left to their own devices, but securely bound to the laws of physics when an electrical current is in the neighborhood.  Thus, in a matter of speaking, many will attempt to carry baggage on their trip across the plating tank--a single molecule of purest gold pried from the seed coins and transported to the opposite pole of her batteries.  In this case, the lead counterfeits dangling at the plating tank's opposite end.  This, the age old equivalent of a lad presenting a band of gold to his mate in the hope he might gain a little spark.  Gold molecules are much larger, and thus not so nimble as their energetic transporters, the electrons.  Little choice have they but to impale themselves upon the surface, thus, in fact electroplating it.  While the conscripts pass directly into the lead, eager to rush back home to the opposite pole of the batteries which spawned them.  The question most grave: will Leona's soup of brine yield discolored pickles or coin of the realm?
To gold then, let the lead become, at least superficially.  Leona pours a small cup of the brine into the plating tank, stirring slowly with a wooden paddle.  Dead shorting a fully charged battery this large could be a scorching business; she shields her eyes and cautiously sets the lead key in place, closing the circuit.  The aspiring sorceress watches patiently, but no bubbles are forming on the plates of her batteries.  Dismayed at the prospects, a heavy finger taps impatiently upon the table.  More brine is added, again slowly stirred into the plating tank's solution; still the circuit refuses to close.  At most the six batteries can only generate about ten volts.  For such a crude construction, there is sadly little potential to overcome the plating solution's resistance.  Amperage, however, is another question entirely.  Once started, it could surge, frying the delicate copper filaments supporting the lead blanks.  Electricity is not exactly one of her specialties; she has traced the circuit point to point several times and the only possible shortcoming is the low voltage.  A fine balance must be struck and no instrument yet exists to measure it.  Calm is paramount, in spite of the perspiration dampening her brow; a rash decision at this stage could set her back several hours.  Her schedule would crumble, throwing the project and the fate of her friends into chaos.  There's no option but to continue adding salt water in small measures until this puppy barks.
BBZzzaaap!  Sparks flash abruptly from the battery connections and busbar junctions with a scary enthusiasm.  Leona jumps back, pulling her hands away as the batteries awaken with an intense crackle.  Minute gaps between the joints are fused together when the current rushes homeward.  The surface of the fluid in the battery crocks begins to fizz like soda water as hydrogen is expelled from the reaction.   Wayward sparks ignite the escaping gas.  Ghostly blue flames begin to dance about the tops of the cells.
"Yes! We have lift off!" she announces with glee.  Leona embraces her entranced assistant.  The apparatus has come alive with forces he has never known existed.  Mesmerized by the spectacle, the consequences of a witch's embrace come not even to mind.
Her attention is drawn back to the plating operation.  One of the filaments supporting a coin has begun to glow, brighter and brighter until it melts, separating with a sharp spark.  This is not a good sign.  Another filament turns bright orange, burning out as she watches helplessly, then another.  Each filament, by virtue of the crude method of its construction is slightly different than its siblings.  The thinner ones, hence those with the greater resistance, are not able to carry the current.  There's no way she can adjust the current back; it is what it is.  One by one various of the filaments glow red hot and melt, allowing their precious cargo to drop free, disconnected from the circuit.  Each one that fails increases the current across those remaining.  Others are heating up, beginning to sizzle at the waterline.  Shit! got to stop this meltdown.  They've got to be cooled.  She takes up a pail of water, carefully pouring it into the plating tank until the level has risen to just above the thicker support hooks.  By this, the entire filament is submerged, thus, cooled by the plating solution.  The system stabilizes itself, but not before there are fourteen casualties, four more than the absolute minimum necessary to meet Beth's financial obligation.  She may be able to fake the coins, but there is no way to fake the number.  There must be a hundred or it's no sale.
The dropouts are moved to the central area of the tank, then cautiously extracted with a technique better suited to a China man.  Nine of the salvaged coins still have a portion of the delicate wires attached.  She is able to bind these short tails with the spare filaments held in reserve, thus, allowing her re-insert them into the bath.
Over the next four nerve-racking hours, twelve more burn-outs deplete her supply of replacement copper threads.  To maintain the minimum payment, eleven of the re-established coins required makeshift supporting cradles, however, these will establish unreliable electrical contact with the support hooks.  Obvious imperfections will result, but at the moment, quantity has become more important than quality.  By early afternoon the two genuine gold seed coins and their copper cradles have totally dissolved, thus terminating the circuit.  For better or worse, it's payday.
Leona holds one of her counterfeits up to inspection.  They look fair as anything a child might filch from a plastic prize vending machine at the grocery mart.
The copper threads are cut from the coins with the utmost of care, any remaining snag burnished away.  No projection must linger to prick the finger of its suitor.  The minuscule threads are saved.  As they were submerged in the bath to keep them cool, they are also gold plated and may fair as capital in a pinch.  If perfectly distributed the delicate film of gold is about one fourteen hundredth of an inch thick.  But, a fingerprint or some wayward oxidation may have created a blister as thin and fragile as a soap bubble on the lead.  No doubt, the less they need be handled the better.  She has had an impressively finished wooden presentation case made for transfer of the payment in a royal fashion, a ploy designed to facilitate ease of counting and inspection with the minimum of fondling.  Thus, heightening the possibility and her sincere desire they be accepted as a lot.  Only a fool would accept them without careful scrutiny were they delivered in a leather purse.  Of this brand, such scrutiny would doubtless prove embarrassing.  Less likely also that they would be dumped into a cash box with other coins.  The dull thud of lead most unwelcome when the exquisite chime of precious metal was anticipated.  Soft linen spacers are to be placed between the coins, lest the delicately plated finish be worn away from the high points as they rub one against the other during transit.  The roads are not smooth, nor has Leona's wagon been equipped with the premium Mercedes suspension package.
She inquires coyly of Hemmil.  "Is there a purveyor of scrap near, that this apparatus may be broken apart and sold?"
Hemmil can hardly believe the words.  For what he heard cannot be the words she spoke.  "Why?" he pleads desperately, but with reserve.  "When this urgent business is done, would it not befit to make as much more as you need?"
"This device makes false gold; it's not worthy of an honest man's labor.  My deception is intended only to pay an unjust debt.  Those receiving it shall reap as they have sown."
"Yes, I see;" Hemmil is quick to agree, "a righteous... and yes, a worthy cause, but what--"
"I feel none the worse for having cheated them, but I harbor no wish to deceive others.  That aside, I pay my debts with good money, sir."
"Oh my," Hemmil is quick to beg.  "I never meant you should not."
"Of good money I have very little left.  There is desperate need for the value of these metals in my purse."
The Alchemist is in a tizzy.  The thought of destroying such an apparatus to recover base metals is scientifically unacceptable.  Attempting to reconstruct it from his notes and memory when a fully operational model now sits before him, is folly.  It must be preserved.  Besides, he may have forgotten something and the smallest detail could defeat a replica, whereas this one has proven it works.  Hemmil inquires, as she had hoped, of what bargain might be struck to put this salvage nonsense aside.  Not a con, for she owes him much and would not dishonor their friendship and trust.  Though in fact, there was not a moment to spare for demolition of the apparatus and transport to a metals' vendor.  So, had he not offered, she would have had to abandon it anyway.  He receives more than good value for his investment, and she, 2 silver coins and 6 coppers to cover travel expenses.  During construction, emphasis was keen upon the batteries as a power source, alluding to the plating mechanism as one of many potential accessories.
"Keep well the secrets of this deception," she warns.  "Remember always, the heart of these coins is still lead.  When they congregate, they will betray one another by their own voices."  Shuffling several of the failed coins to illustrate, she allows them drop to the stone floor.  The "thud" produced of their impact is an unnerving contradiction.  "They will not ring true."  Hemmil acknowledges with a sober nod.  "You need ally yourself with the tinker, he has knowledge of the devises that can use the fuel I've disclosed to you.  As partners it could be a very profitable arrangement.  I may have asked this before," Leona continues, "but everything's been in such a rush.  Do you know the way home?"
An unusual inquiry for one seemingly in charge of her own destiny.  His head cycles slowly as one perplexed, his thoughts still confounded by the revelation she could have scrapped this wonderful apparatus without a care.  "Milady, it appears this land suits you well.  When your quest is resolved," he whispers softly that Mom not overhear and think him hexed, "do come back.  You are always welcome here."
"I will hold dear your invitation, sir.  You've been faithful to your word and very understanding these past short days.  And I hope the things I've revealed prove the equal of my inconvenience."  Leona's parting embrace is not the ominous gesture it was perceived when first they touched.  Indeed, the Alchemist gives her a firm grandfatherly squeeze in return.
Mom is still in calm world, totally distracted by the dancing flutterbys.  Even so, Leona feels a parting word is due and must be said.  "A fine gentlemen you've raised, ma'am.  He does you tribute with honest words and deeds."  With that they part, Hemmil left to ponder the apparatus he has just acquired and Leona off to secure her friends' future good health.  The secrets of acetylene, electricity, and at least how to make lead look like gold, for better or worse imparted to this world.
--
As one might suppose, the prison's guards are not authorized to accept cash on their employer's behalf.  And in fact, who but a complete fool would hand one of those rogues a purse and imagine that coins would not be lost at their very touch?  All such deposits are made to His Lordship's chief money counter.  Likely an otherwise unemployable relative, who upon receiving payment grants a letter of pardon.  This document then presented, under seal no less, to the keeper of the gate in a timely fashion.  Bureaucracy is surely the hilt of that ragged blade called time; deadliest of weapons, capable of slaying any army afoot or afloat, friend or foe, and with not the loss of a single second of it's own.
So begins the first field test of her getaway cart, for in a rush she must be.  Even for children, the bone rattling one must endure aboard such coarse transport would soon enough loose its novelty.  And her's better equipped than all but the best of coaches.
The royal counter's humble abode is an unimpressive stone bunker sixty feet square and three stories high.  Soon as the tower comes to view she dawns her hooded cape and slows to a normal pace.  There is one well-guarded entry at ground level and no windows whatsoever.  Adjacent to the structure are rows of wooden warehouses and open sheds.  Within appear all manner of Kegs, crates, sacks, stacks and piles.  On the opposite side, a melee of stock pens and grain bins.  It would seem His Lordship is willing to take payment in any currency not the least of which is cow dung.  Two parallel fieldstone walls about six feet high surround the royal Wal-Mart; minimal watch towers rise at the four corners and flank the gateway.  Although not to be seen until one realizes the error of his ways, the presence of many angry dogs is more than obvious.  They occupy the space between the low walls--A mote of sorts occupied by four-legged piranha.
Upon inquiry, Leona is informed that hard currency transactions are limited to the counting room on the tower's uppermost floor.  Thus, she is promptly escorted to an enclosed stairway at the building's center with a manned iron entry gate.  Aside from the stair, as there should of necessity be no place to hide, the first floor is completely devoid of walls.  One side of the approach aisle is defined by bars of iron from floor to ceiling.  The area beyond is piled high with textiles, leather and cases of spirits; the spoils of dictatorship, all securely locked within.  On the other, a disorderly mess hall occupied by curious eyes and hushed mumblings.
Reaching the top of the stairwell, she finds a half dozen more guards flank the path to this glorified collector of bribes--a well-dressed and likewise well-rounded 400-pound turnip--a fellow so obese one could hardly imagine him capable of rising from his seat without a hoist.  On his left resides a pale gentlemen of sensible attire, a monocle in each eye and two more about his neck.  Such scrutiny suggests there could be more than one counterfeiter afoot in this land.  Leona begins formulating an emergency exit plan, but no matter how you cut it, pardon the pun, there are few options.  Whoever inscribed those ominous words upon her weapon's blade had better be right.
Eight others, unfortunate as she, stand in line before her with cash in hand awaiting the privilege to bail out friends or relatives.  The first of them now having the wages of his sins counted no less than four times by Mr. Monocles.  This is not the place to employ someone afflicted of obsessive compulsive disorder.  The coins she has made are good, but if he doesn't buy into the gift-box ploy, he's bound to detect the ruse.  For by his caution, it certainly appears his ass dangles as much in the balance as any confined within the Keep.  Mr. Turnip is probably the only one important enough to get her out; but how do you take a hostage that requires a fork truck to be moved even on level ground.  How could one such as he possibly descend the thirty foot exit stair?  He must be akin of Repunzle, forever consigned to the upper floor of this tower.
Finally satisfied there are twelve genuine coins of the realm present, Monocle's slides them off the edge of the table into one of several strong boxes.  They ring true.  A foreboding reminder that even if her coins slip by as genuine, they will fail the final challenge victims of their own inflection.  Mr. Monocle marks a meticulous memorandum in his ledger, then transcribes the names of the parties involved upon the coveted pardon.  Lastly, the document is passed to the ever smiling Turnip for the final benediction, a swirling signature attesting that indeed some infraction, though it may have been murder in the first with three witnesses, has been officially forgiven in exchange for hard cash.  Turnip takes his responsibilities a bit more lightly, no doubt being well connected and blameless by virtue of his plausible deniability; after all, 'twas the other guy counted the cash.  Turnip folds the document, seals the edge with a wax impression and passes it to the grateful recipient.
The procedure seems to take forever.  She is just about to burst with anxiety regarding what those few unauthorized moments of sleep this morning may have cost when a tiny bell sounds.  Mr. Monocles closes his ledger, rises, nods respectfully to the great Turnip, and disappears through a curtain at the back of the room.  One of the guards steps forward announcing, "This day's business is done.  No fine shall be levied against those now present," he assures.  "Good day to all."  He returns to his post and stiffens up.  Those remaining in front of Leona turn about with solemn faces and proceed toward the exit stair.
"No way!"  She advances toward the Turnip;  Several servants have already begun setting out a massive dinner, his anticipation such that Leona's presence has totally escaped his attention.  One servant removes the cover from a large platter exposing not one, but four baked fish with all the trimmings; another conscript pours the wine.
"Kind sir, I beg your pardon," She pleads softly.  "But this matter is of the utmost urgency."
Caught quite by surprise, his head snaps to attention, his mouth still agape with anticipation  "Are you blind as well as deaf?  Go away, I am about to begin my dinner?"
"The morrow is too late sir.  Those whose freedom I have been sent to secure are to be executed at dawn.  Their bones are worth nothing, but so long as they have breath, they have value."  Leona sets the box upon the table and removes the lid.  "Good sir, there is much to be gained for all with but a few moments effort."
"The counter has left, his ledger gone with him.  Next time perhaps you will have better planned your day.  Neither their fate nor the folly that will see them hanged is concern of mine.  Now be gone I say."
This guy is going to get hurt.  His size is exceeded only by his opinion of self-worth.  Leona leans forward to confide at a lower tone of voice, presumably to spare the Turnip any embarrassment.  "Sir, surely you don't mean to say you cannot count to a hundred on your own behalf?"
Mr. Turnip flushes into a beet.  What's to lose, she turns up the heat?  "Having lost one of his favorites to your gluttony will surely cause my employer to bring the matter directly to His Lordship's attention with particular emphasis I'm sure upon the sum you have chosen to forfeit on his behalf.  A hundred in gold, for a moment of your inconvenience?"
Unable it seems to reply, the food so close and cooling quickly;  he's totally confounded by anticipation.  He motions to the remaining guards.
"My master loses, your master loses, sir, I beg you consider, what might you lose?" she continues with pure contempt.  "I fear that very soon your stomach may find itself without a mouth to feed it, being attached to your head... as it is... for the moment."
"You little bitch."  He waves the guards off.  Tracing a row of her coins with his fingertip, then, running his thumbnail along the series of stacks, he slides the box aside with a sharp glance to his tormentor.  Likely he had hoped there was a shortfall, but alas, failed to notice the forest for the trees.
"One hundred in fine gold," she whispers.  "Do you agree?"
Much to his future dismay, he has not removed a single coin for inspection.  Her charade has passed muster.  Reaching with a great strain, as his arms hardly exist at all, he attempts to secure a blank pardon from Mr. Monocle's work station.  Leona is quick to assist his effort for fear she would die laughing were his chair to flip over.  He glances over the warrant she has presented, hastily transferring the particulars to the official parchment.
Leona's careful to watch that he faithfully records the information; this is no time for typos.  Where the names of those to be pardoned are declared he writes only 'Beth of Atlanta,' whereupon Leona is duly obligated to point out the error of his ways.
"This warrant includes her man slave, also, sir... and I have paid for both."  Turnip's desire to wring her neck is more than obvious by the showing of teeth as he hisses.  Likely he would order she be put into irons, were it not so apparent by her shear arrogance alone that she represents a wealthy and therefore powerful entity.  The greatest resource of poker players and generals alike is their ability to convince one's opponent their position is indomitable, though yet they stand upon sand.  Thus far, she has mastered the deed.  He adds the necessary connotation and slides the document to her side of the table.  "Now, but for your seal, I would gladly be upon my way, sir."  Again he retrieves the parchment.  Placing wax to flame and his ring to the same, hence, the deed is done with great disdain.  "Thank you, sir... enjoy your dinner."
"I will remember you," he assures.
Leona casts a sly smile back over her shoulder along with a parting thought.  For she knows if the lead coins are discovered, 'tis likely he has just signed his own death warrant.  "As you wish, milord; for well you may."  And with that she is fast upon her way.  Risky business that, and glad she is to have done with it.  
By the time Leona has reached the Keep, light of day floats just above the horizon.  Her error in dosing off may have been the most fortunate of accidents.  For the closing of the counter's ledger actually played well to her favor.  The pleasure exacted of such profound last words was foolish, though.  Her comment could have drawn suspicion to the coins, creating waves in a sea thus far calm.  When the Turnip discovers his folly, he could send a messenger to disavow the pardon.  But it would arrive too late.  Besides, since Mr. Monocles has beat the rap by his mere absence, most likely and with considerable indigestion, Mr. Turnip would be the wiser to correct his foolishness from his own pocket.  Then again, since there was no entry upon the official ledger and the strong boxes already locked, he may decide to stash it under his pillow saving this delightful discovery for another day.  Until Beth and Hale are in her possession and the Keep long out of sight, Murphy's first law must ever be upon her thoughts.  That which may... invariably will.
--
Though  the sun has set the sky is still well lit, but not for much longer.  Leona quick steps to the prison gates with a confidence one may only gain from experience, not to mention the explosives concealed within her carry-on.  The prison yard is bathed in shadow; not a soul is to be seen.  All seems calm; not so much as a breeze dares to trespass upon her intrigue.  Only the conversations of crows in the adjacent wood disturbs the deathly silence.  The moon will turn its back to the coming night, thus, an excellent evening for the devious doings at hand.  Glancing upward, the parapets appear unmanned; but there also, the massive siege door just a few yards above.  Once released, precious few seconds would remain before sealing the Keep and the fate of any trapped within.
So realistic are the settings upon this stage, she cannot imagine it a game, but if not then what transpires here?  Games are contrived to challenge the efforts of those who would play; to place obstacles in their path, to confound their strategies, to test their will to win.  So be it!
Pulling the bell cord to announcing her presence at such a late hour elicits curses from the guards' room in the tower's ground level to her right.  
She is wearing a long dark cape to conceal her more utilitarian attire.  The short sword strapped to her left calf is in a ready proximity.  She carries a large leather shoulder bag from which the pardon is now extracted.
Upon the guard's arrival, she announces boldly.  "I bear a letter, sealed and now properly delivered to thee.  This to secure the release of a maiden, Beth of Atlanta, and her man slave."  He yawns in her face with not the slightest thought of an "excuse me."  Though not accompanied by a servant to handle the paperwork this time, she maintains her snotty charade.  The unsavory fellow snatches the document from her grip with a flare of annoyance and walks away without a word.  His disappearance back into the guard's room stirs more foul comments regarding anyone discourteous enough to be delivering official documents at such late hour.  Disturbing everyone's dinner seems to have become her manor for the day.
--
For a moment shall we slip away to the gala activities taking place in His Lordship's private arena.  There within, dear Beth finds herself in a bit of a panic.  She has been invited to a banquet, she herself chosen as the main course in fact.  The impatient dinner guests are not of the sort to quibble over whether their meal has been properly cooked; in fact, such preparation would preclude most of their fun and the sweet taste of fresh blood.  Entertainment for the evening includes graphic displays of many sharp teeth accompanied by generous amounts of growling, creative howling, and the occasional, but very dramatic slobbering snarl.
Wide-eyed and more scared than she has ever been, Beth's attention shifts back and forth desperately as the enthusiastic dinner patrons circle her pen.  The sight and smell of blood trickling from her knees, the result of her reluctance to join the party, tantalizes the pack carnivores.  Around her neck is a stiff heavy leather collar, a fun little modification Her Ladyship of the moment has devised to prolong the victim's agony.  The beasts are just too efficient once they've gotten in; the leather guard prevents too quick a termination of their primary objective, the windpipe.  Beth stands at the center of a bottomless cage, this supported several inches above the loose dirt floor by a retractable chain.  A small bucket is hung from above rigged that it may be tilted by pulling a rope to discharge the contents upon uninspiring victims, thus raising the dog's level of interest.  The cage's bars are all that restrain the pack of ferocious canine's surrounding it, keeping them as it were from the agile little morsel they consider to be their dinner.  One bright young rascal is digging frantically, attempting to undermine the enclosure.
The cage itself dangles at the center of a small arena.  Along one side of the central dirt-floored area is a spectator level.  This is elevated three feet above the activity area to provide a better view.  Extending an additional foot and a half above the spectator's floor is a solid stone curb which runs the full length.  Rows of barbed iron pickets are set into the top edge of the curb to discourage the entertainers from joining the ranks of those being entertained.  A large cozy hearth dominates one end of the viewer's area, roasting there within a scrumptious piglet.  This adds to the rich configuration of scents encouraging the dogs' appetites.
A similarly raised but narrower utility level runs the length of the opposite side, though without benefit of the picket-topped curb.  Two sentries are stationed there with lances to assure the main course does not somehow scurry away and ruin the evenings fun.  Within these walls, there is no means of crossing from one side to the other without entering the pit created there between.  The playing field as it were, being 10 by 15 yards, has no roof.  Thus, the entertainers may watch the stars fade with their consciousness as they perish, each allowed but one performance upon this bloody stage.  Several hoist beams span the abyss.  An iron maiden, hooks, shackles and nooses dangle solemnly therefrom.  The dog handler is a totally unconcerned brute; a spiked mace sways from his belt should any of his pups require reprimand.  He leans against their pen which sits near one end of the playing field.
Polished copper reflectors run the entire length of the low wall on the spectator's side.  Long narrow troughs of burning oil are set before them.  These provide a flickering lighting effect worthy of any Hollywood Gothic horror film.
The yuppie team, for those who may have misplaced their casting list, reside at either end of a lavishly attired dinning table.  Several servants await their beck and call.  The lady of the house is an impatient sort.  She stands, raising her glass to encourage the dogs with a toast.  "Dig... come on damn you, dig," she encourages.  "That's the way... get to it!"  With that she casts a joyous smile to His Lordship and again raising her wine cup, toasts the snarling hell hounds.
With a casual motion to one of her servants she instructs him tug on the cord attached to the bucket above the cage.  Tilting slightly, blood dribbles from the rim.  Some of it catches Beth's shoulder, the tacky red fluid running down the length of her arm.  Not sure at first what's happened, she steps aside as the majority splashes to the dirt floor rather than upon her face.  Scent of blood an aphrodisiac to any carnivore, the dogs thus enticed go crazy.  Beth looks up, then, turns an unholy gaze upon her antagonist.  Her Ladyship nods sarcastically in return and takes another sip of her wine.  Beth would return all the treats left under her pillow by the Tooth Fairy for a one on one moment to fully express her gratitude.  But alas, other things press upon her good nature at the moment.
"Yes, that will do, very good."  Her Ladyship motions a pause to her servant.  "Save the rest, it will serve better when they've gotten to her."  In keeping with the spirit of her toils, she now turns her affections to His Lordship.  "Why not raise the cage a little, sweetie?"
"Patience love," he consoles.  "No need to rush.  The sun is gone, the air will cool soon and we have all the night.  It's like sex, better if you make it last, dear."
All the while, unaware of Beth's impending conversion to burger bits, Leona nervously awaits the guard's return.  He reappears with a devious smirk; another follows wearing a helmet.  His words instill her worst nightmare.  "The wench was took."  He advises in an arrogant tone, apparently dismayed that he and his friends will be deprived of their pre-execution party favors.  Leona's mind reels.  "Stupid wench sassed His Lordship's favorite, she did."  He further consoles, "Ya can have what's left come morning." pointing to an area adjacent the gate.  "Be put there.  No need to trouble us 'bout it, just haul it away.  Be sure to come early 'cause the foxes and possums keep an eye out for these kinda treats."
"Where?  No!  You've got to get her back here... right now," Leona challenges.  "This is illegal; the ransom's been paid, she must be returned now.  It's the law."
"I say it to ya again, she's been took, gone, ya understand, gone?  Still got the slave if ya want'em."  
The helmeted guard opens the gate and stands aside.  Leona enters, the guard steps back as she approaches, seemingly drawing her in further.  Once clear of the gate the other locks it behind her.
Her voice calm, but rising.  "This is illegal, I'll have you both on the gallows if she is not returned at once."
The first guard starts toward Leona; the other stays his advance and nods him away.  He seems uncommonly anxious.  
"Ya want the slave boy er not?"
Her thoughts are in a panic.  Need to calm down.  This is a set up, a trap,  they are going to try and take me too. Get Hale out first then it's scorched earth.
"Yes!"  Leona double times toward Hale's cell followed by the helmeted guard.   She advances as if unconcerned, further and further into the Keep.  Light of day is waning fast.  The alley along the row of cells is entirely shrouded in deep shadows.  "Hale!" she calls out.  There is no reply.  Again much louder, "Hale, where the hell are you?"  
"Hey," tone of his voice tapers off, "back here." She moves further into the shadows as he steps to the bars of his cell, not exactly in high spirit.  In the failing light she can see his face has been pummeled, his lip split and bleeding.  "Where's Beth?"
"Gone!"
"I don't need anymore of this 'gone' shit," she raves; "I said where?"
"They dragged her in there."  Hale, a bit despondent and hardly able to speak, points out a door in the wall across the yard. 
"How long ago?"
"Half hour maybe, kind of hard to tell.  I couldn't spot them."
Leona addresses the guard authoritatively.  "Where does that door lead?" as she points, also taking in a full sweeping view of the area.  No one is in sight; this arrogant fool is totally alone and intended it should be so.
"Nothing for you," he advises calmly, thinking his wish granted.  "Speak of it again and I'll have you in the stocks."
He's cleverly arranged our encounter with intent to get me in a corner.  Ahhh, he's in love, how sweet, for all hell is a boil just beneath his feet and begs him proceed.  She changes her stance now with one foot in front of the other assuming the need to retreat from his reach.  "My benefactor would have your head."
"Your benefactor be damned.  My Master is Lord of this land," he entreats venomously.  They stare at each other while the impending challenge solidifies.
"So be it," Leona advises softly, that none may say each was not fairly warned.
His gaze narrows; so anxious this fellow to execute his clumsy plan.  The thumb and fingers of his powerful hand spread as it reaches for her throat, but alas, it falls off.  Next thing ya know his wind pipe and all there about save his spine mysteriously separates from the rest of him.  The Guard staggers forward against the bars of Hale's cell, eyes wide with surprise.  They search for an explanation of what has happened.  Inhaling has become a chore, blood gushing down his throat where air should rightfully be; the art of speech eludes his every effort.  The female viper's image blending now and forevermore with the night as the last bits of consciousness fade due to lack of blood pressure.  Demons in the abyss applaud her fine workmanship, for they've a new toy to torment this night.  
"Nothing more to say?"  He begins to slide downward.  "Hale, catch him."  Hale reaches through the bars to support the deceased fellow.  "Better he stands for now."
A voice commends her workmanship with a painful tone.  "Well done!"
Leona quickly spins about, but finds no one there.  A fellow moves into view from the shadow behind the bars of the adjacent cell.  He too has been severely beaten.
"Be at ease, milady, For sure I am no threat to thee.  We two are the only witnesses to your handiwork.  Certainly I shall never tell."
"I remember you... fellow in the cutlery shop.  You bought Art's sword."
"Yes, a better day that than of late.  Fine weapon too, worth every coin twice over.  Wish it had been near at hand when I was summoned for His Lordship's pleasure."
"How do you come to this?"
"Thinking myself among friends I spoke too freely, turns out at least one was not."
Leona attempts to pry the keys from the vanquished guard's hand, but death's grip intends to keep them.  Not a problem, she pulls his arm taut and takes the other hand off at the wrist.  Her fine garments have suffered as much as he, spattered, laid to waste by all this bloody give and take.
Hale winces at the thought of Leona turning that key while still attached to a severed hand.  He never suspected his girl's best friend could be the real live star of a B horror flick, his favorite thing aside of football.
"I have need of an ally.  Will you stand with me?"
"Aye... to the last of us."  Leona unlocks his cell.  Bruised and lacerated, but capable, the battered fellow emerges.  "Karn of Orchard at your service, milady."
"Leona, if you please."  Karn nods his understanding.  "Get this creep out of sight, drag him into the back and strap on his weapons... and the hat, and the vest too."  Hale relaxes his grip as Karn takes hold of the guard and drags him into the cell.
Hale's arms and hands are soaked with the guard's blood, it's warm and glistens even in the dim light of dusk.  There's so much he can even smell it and he desperately wants to wipe it away, but there is nothing to avail of such task, he just stairs.
"Hale!"  Leona's voice jolts him back to reality.  "Don't get sick on me, you gotta keep it together... for Beth, okay?"
"Yeah, right!  I'm good."
Karn rejoins Leona, he's in good spirits.  "Shall we search for your friend's lady then?"
"I wanna get Hale out first," she confides.  "Now that that fool's dead the gate has to remain under our control till I can find Beth.  Escort us out.  Keep your head down.  I'll do the talking."
"Leo," Hale pleads, "what about Beth?"
"One thing at a time, buddy, I'll find her."
Karn supports Hale as they walk toward the gate, Leona ten feet in advance.  As the remaining soldier exits the guard's shack, she flips a coin high in front of him.
"Gold for your trouble this night."  Gold!  What wondrous thoughts must have passed before his eyes, reaching up with both hands as not to miss such a rare treasure.  Fondness of coin has cast any hope of defending himself to the winds.  She produces her blade from beneath the blood-spattered cape and rushes forward, driving the iron deep into his chest with both hands.  He's not one of the 200-pound goons that seem to be typical hereabout.  Thus, her momentum pushes him backward into the guard's room where both crash to the floor.
To her left, she immediately notices a huge pair of boots, unfortunately with great hairy 200-pound goon type legs therein.  They rest upon the floor just the other side of a table next to where she and her gasping pillow have landed.  "Shit!"  Why she had never considered there could be more than two is a question better reviewed later.  Both are taken entirely by surprise; fortunately her adversary has only a wooden spoon and bowl of warm dinner slush at his command.  Big fellow though, and like a big tree, requiring much chopping to dissuade his advance.  What transpires, unpleasant at best, the gruesome details of which need not leave the room.  For to elaborate may well cast doubt upon the quality of our heroin's character.  Suffice it to say their acquaintance has slipped into a 'no more Mr. Nice Guy' sort of affair, the furniture suffering even more than he.  She exits, more than a bit disheveled, having forfeit her fine cape during the melee.  It was time to change anyway, the garments beneath being black as ink and better suited to the current situation.  Her leather satchel is still slung from her shoulder and she's confiscated a crossbow, a pouch of darts, and an unimpressive sword to outfit her battered conscripts.
During the fracas, Karn's unlocked the gates and dragged Hale up into the back of the cart.  Leona rejoins them in good spirits considering what she's just got away with, though smarting from a serious whack to the side of her face derived of flying-furniture syndrome and a throbbing knot upon her noggin.  "You're driving," she advises Karn, "Wait as long as you dare... but don't be retaken.  There are belts on the seat, strap yourself down."  She passes the watchman's sword to Hale and flips the bow into the cart.
"Leo," Hale pleads.  "I've got to do something."
"You wait... understand?  You wait because with that leg you'd have us both dead.  You can't defend yourself and I can't protect you and Beth both.  You have to stay."
"But Leo--"
"No!  I mean it Hale, please don't go back in okay.  You've got to trust I know better.  When I come out I'm going to be in a hurry and I need you two right here ready to go."  She takes hold of Karn's arm.  "Don't let him go back.  Close the gate behind me so there appears no breach."
"Would I not be more useful if I came with thee?"
"No, if there's no driver we're all dead.  The keys!"  He concedes with a nod, passing her the key ring and steps back without further argument.  Leona snatches up the heavy little keg and dashes back into the prison.  The device was earmarked to open the gate.  That having been accomplished it shall facilitate the closing.  She wedges it tightly under the drop door's winch platform, then sprints toward the door Hale identified.
Karn slowly nods disapproval of her foolishness.  He takes hold of Hale's shoulder with a firm grip.  "Well lad, the general's given us our orders; sometimes it's the waiting that's tougher than the fight."   His word given, he must abide her request, least so long as his conscience allows.  If she fails to return, having bound himself to the last of them, he will go back to seek her out, the cost be damned!  Besides, in the pitch of a moonless night he knows the team would little more than wade slowly into the darkness.  They are lost anyway.

Chapter-11

ROUX BEWARE, FOR THE LADY OF DURER
COMES NOW TO THY LAIR.

Venture now into a corridor but six feet wide fashioned of large dressed stone blocks, the ceiling pitched sharply upward to an apex twenty feet above.  A shaft so sparsely illuminated by oil lamps as to say, light is not welcome here.  At the far end a heavy ironclad door where someone tinkers with the lock.  It gives way cautiously to a motionless silhouette hardly to be seen against the nearly absent light of day.  Thus, Leona enters the intersanctum of Lord Roux from his own prison's courtyard.  Come she now to seek the master of this pit, sword in hand, a game to play.  Just inside adjacent to the door, a rack of crossbows upon the wall, six in all.  She removes one of the weapons.  Placing her foot in the stirrup and pulling the lever back, cocking the bow.  A dart then placed securely into the track--each weapon thus loaded and once again to its place upon the rack.  There to lie in wait, for when next she opens that very door, who's to say what may be there to greet her.
Sheathing her blade, she slings a bow over her shoulder, deposits a pouch of darts into her carryall and takes a second, keeping it at the ready.  Hence, she's off to the first intersection of this maze, just around each corner the passage is equipped with an open iron gate.  The configuration poses an interesting defense mechanism.  Were both locked, any intruder would be trapped, finding himself subject to a crossfire from the adjacent corridors.  The facility was designed with conflict in mind, but her presence attests to the tragic state of which its security has deteriorated.  She chalks the wall of the corridor just traveled with an arrow toward the exit and continues to her right.
The passage brings her to a large room, a hub of sorts, with exits in every wall.  Four possibilities and no hint as to where each might lead her.  It's going to be a maze, lacking only the fabled Minotaur, for the moment at least.  There is a little more light, but still just enough to keep one from tripping over the cat, or detecting an ominous shadow on the floor.  That of an inconspicuous open cistern occupying one entire corner of the room.  The water level being eight feet below the floor would preclude her exit as the walls are covered with slime and smoothly finished to minimize leakage.  Columns four foot square support the vaulted stone ceiling, and well it is they are so wide, for company's afoot and there's no other place to hide.  The sound of boots and voices approach, but from where?  Masked by echoes rebounding from the smooth ashlars, their source direction is unclear.  Shadows flicker upon the walls of one entrance to the room.  She ducks behind a column opposite the intruders; the shuffling of feet hint as to their path.  Keeping a tight profile, she shifts her position as they pass her by.  Unarmed servants carrying bolts of cloth, one an old woman, the other little more than a child.  Thankfully both have chosen the same route.  Leona has never been a religious person, but she thanks whatever powers are at play that they did not discover her.  She had neither the means to bind nor silence them, and even were it possible, the time to do so could be critical to Beth.  Slaughtering helpless civilians to gain their silence is not a pleasant prospect.  Truth be known, she may have failed such a trial.
The slightest chime of a single bell comes next to challenge; however, it does not come from afar.  Still fast against the column she has but to turn her head.  The Jester who so impressed Sanaia with his song at the game's start leans against an adjacent pier just below an oil lamp.  He holds a toy stick figure with a carved wooden head, dressed as he.  The limbs are loose, secured at the joints by twine so they may flail about when he operates the lever on the handle.  The head has a toothy smile with the corners turned sharply upward, bright round eyes, and a long pointed bent nose.  The man himself, a disarming, but sad smile his only real defense.
"No danger here, milady.  No reason to fear, just the fool, you see."
"A fool would have raised the alarm and died," Leona advises, "thus your wisdom is foretold."
"'Tis not oft maidens so equipped slink about these dark places."
"I'm searching for --"
"A svelte young maiden with flaxen hair?"  He injects.
"Where is she?  This is deadly work, sir.  Deny me not."
"A terrible harm comes her way and I am not one to enjoy such events.  I will show you where, but then I can no more than wish you well."
"I am as your shadow; betray me and those bells of yours ring nevermore."  Leona remains concealed as much as possible, hugging the walls, keeping an eye to her back as she follows placing chalk marks to record her route.
The Jester prances along, bells jingling.  Reaching the end of a  blind intersection, corridors continue both right and left.  He looks in one direction, then the other.  Freezing in mock surprise, he hops into the air kicking his feet as if riding a bicycle.  He bends forward in an exaggerated bow as though greeting someone still unseen from Leona's point of view.  She takes the hint, slipping out of sight behind a pilaster.  Two Guards walk by the Jester; neither pay him any mind.  Unfortunately they choose to turn in Leona's direction.  Still in the bowing position, the Jester cocks his head sideways in their direction and frowns.  Springing back to the vertical, he quicksteps up behind the Guards and taps one on the shoulder with his jingling stick figure.
The guard turns.  "What?" he barks.  
The Jester stomps his foot, shakes a knotty finger in the Guard's face, snaps to attention and points in the opposite direction with his stick figure.  Both Guards wave his foolishness aside.  Intent upon the path to their graves, they proceed toward Leona's hiding place.  Confrontation is imminent as she has no way of avoiding discovery if they continue.  Before the guard's stride may take him out of reach, the Jester whacks one of them aside his neck with the sturdy handle of his stick figure.  Turning about with fire in his eyes, the guard slowly comforts the sting.  Much as he would like to ring this fool's neck, he knows such nonsense must be tolerated for this harlequin has His Lordship's favor.
"To the kitchen knaves," the clown demands.  "And be quick about it, the cooks want for wood."
The Guards change course, grumbling and cursing as they go.  The Jester watches, being sure they have exited the area and then checks the other direction once more.  Tapping his stick figure against the wall several times, he calls very quietly.  "Milady!"  Leona peeks around the corner.  The threat having dispersed, she advances to a new concealment.
In the arena, Beth's situation is deteriorating quickly.  Fangs and blazing eyes preview the dogs' intentions to their defenseless prey.  They have all but undermined the cage from several directions now.  Beth is confined to the central area, attempting to fend them off with her shoe.  A solid whack to the nose of one sends it into a squealing retreat, pawing at its nose for relief as it whines.
Her Ladyship is highly irritated at the pain inflicted upon one of her pets.  "The vile little urchin's injured one of my dogs sweetie.  That brat... look what she's done.  The poor beast is in pain.  Lift the cage a little," she entices.  "This atrocity must be avenged."  Raising another toast to Beth's demise, her glass held high; a bit off center herself though, nearly tipping over at the effort.  "To a wounded friend so noble, may vengeance be just, swift and... I mean slow."  Plopping back into her chair, she turns her attention to a servant close at hand.  A stoic sort this fellow, displaying a higher level of attitude--Her royal Ladyship's personal secretary no doubt.  "From now on, their shoes are to be confiscated, do you hear?"  He nods, duly noting the new restriction upon the rights of prisoners being consigned to doggie fodder.  Her voice is becoming a bit slurred; likely she's been nipping at the elixir Hemmil prepared to incite Lord Roux's more visionary moments.
"She should pay for that.  Sweetie, have one of the archers put an arrow into her leg; that will cool her down.  Sweetie... are you listening?"
"That will not be necessary," he assures.  "The dogs can handle it, really they can."
Her Ladyship sincerely feels she has been wronged and penance is due.  She stews, not at all satisfied with her perceived mate's laissez-faire attitude.  There is but one guard permitted to carry a crossbow in the immediate presence of the gruesome royal twosome, one no doubt who is trusted well above any other.  Such a weapon in the hands of a traitor, considering its far-reaching capabilities, would be a serious error.  Swords and lances may be defended against or retreated from, but the speed with which a dart is propelled from such device allows precious little opportunity to be avoided.  She motions the master guard come near, rises, confiscates his bow, swings about and fires the dart toward the cage with a laugh.  The iron rod passes just under Beth's elbow.  Ricocheting off one of  bars with a frightful clang, it strikes one of the dogs in the hind quarter.  "Drat!" she concedes annoyingly.  The wounded animal lets out a murderous squeal, dragging itself yelping and whining toward its master, the dog handler.
His Lordship is intensely unhappy with his muse's insolence.  His gaze slowly redirected to the opposite end of the table, many unspoken words of disdain and regret therewith.  "I said... it would not be necessary.  Now see what you've done?"
She drops back into her seat with a sullen frown and not another word, quite confident she can find a way to make up for his displeasure later.  The spent weapon quietly laid upon the floor, then kicked under the table so as not to further offend.  It disappears somewhere beyond the confines of an elegant cloth draped thereabout.  The imperial bodyguard becomes extremely uneasy, his function totally neutralized by the arrogant consort's foolishness.  An awkward situation in that he must now further disturb His Lordship, who is already highly displeased, for permission to reclaim something he was ill-advised to relinquish in the first place.  Adding insult to injury, as to do so will require he get down on hands and knees for all to see and crawl under the immense table to retrieve the spent weapon.  It helps not knowing that had he resisted her demand, certainly she would trump up some excuse to have him hanged.  Such are the insults of royal servitude.  He hesitates to be the fool for a few moments and thus, the fate of every player changes irrevocably. 
His Lordship rises, pointing a finger of stern consequence at the squealing dog; the handler immediately bashes the dog's head in with his mace.
One of Beth's tormentors lunges forward between the bars far enough to catch the toe of her shoe, pulling it from her hand.  Almost losing her balance requires she steady herself against the cage.  A nearly fatal error, another of her suitors seizes his opportunity for a snack, but misses.  Had she been caught and pulled to the bars, she would never have come away till it was done.  Her Ladyship never misses an opportunity to cheer the home team.  "That's it sweetie, catch her!"  Beth is beginning to break down; she wipes her eyes, steadies herself, and prepares for the last stand with a whimper and her remaining shoe.
Within the seemingly endless maze of corridors, the Jester checks another intersection to see if it's clear, then back steps to a wide heavy wooden door.  Opening it, he enters the room momentarily, then, motions for Leona to join him.  They disappear into the anteroom which adjoins the arena, dark and empty except for a small table and another door at the far end.  The portal's perimeter is faintly defined by the light beyond; a great commotion of barking dogs is evident.  This is a door begging to tell its secrets.  
"This path is the least guarded," informs her ally.  "Two with lance and sword await beyond that door.  There is a pit on the left, the maiden is there.  Don't attempt to cross, or you will be trapped.  Roux and his Lady will be over on the far side.  They wear only white.  Beware the archer at his side."  Placing a hand upon the wall to the door's right, he further declares.  "This wall continues straight away to the end with no exits but the door standing before you here.  Wisdom and speed be yours, milady.  I am gone now."  He nods respectfully and backs out into the passage, closing the door behind him.
Leona addresses the situation forthwith, the finer details to be worked out on the fly.  Pulling the door open, she steps into view and has a bead on his royal person before anyone realizes she is there.  Roux, still standing, is a clear target.  If the guard nearby is the archer of which she was warned, he appears terribly distressed and unarmed.  At this range the bolt would reach its mark nearly as quick as a shotgun slug.  The two sentries on Leona's side of the pit instinctively hesitate.  The situation has progressed beyond their control within the blink of an eye.  Each knows to advance places His Lordship at deadly risk, and by that, no matter what follows, surely they to a grizzly end.  Roux confirms the wisdom of their discretion by raising his hand to halt any further movement.  The bones have rolled in her favor; for the moment Leona has complete command of the situation.
But for the dogs, everything is silent and motionless until the Royal Consort realizes her sweetie is under the gun.  She snaps to her feet.  "Assassins, Assassins!" she screams.  Turning to the bodyguard, whom she had just disarmed, she anxiously points his attention toward the invader.  The guard looks to his empty hands, turns his palms upward as he spreads his arms slightly and looks to the foolish woman with disdain.  His Lordship's attention turns to his frightened Lady with a brief but affectionate assurance that all is firmly under his control.  "Shut up and sit."
The person he faces is calm, focused and has placed herself in a desperate situation.  Desperate people are dangerous, but calm people are extremely so.  If she were an assassin he would already be dead and she upon her way.  Thus, to strike a bargain would seem to be her intent.
Leona states her case and the authority by which she intends to press it.  "To move is to die.  Call the beasts to heel."
No less than four to five seconds are required to redirect the dogs or have the sentries engage her position, a hundred times more than that required to take his life or at least render the remainder of it a miserable undertaking.  Thanks to his idiot of a companion, his only defense has been neutralized by the turn of a card in another world.
Leona restates her ultimatum in a much agitated tone.  In fact she screams, "Now, or be damned."
The Noble motions to his dog handler, who blows a whistle.  The dogs break off the attack immediately, retreating to their master's side.  They sniff curiously around their bloody, motionless comrade.
Beth is sobbing lightly.  This isn't nearly as much fun as one of Art's corny games.
Highly pissed off at his embarrassingly sorry circumstances, and arrogant by nature, Roux knows he must maintain a position of authority.  A bluff, however, is the only defense he can muster.  Taking a heavy self-assuring tone, he informs, "Your life hangs by the next word I speak."
"And yours is at the tip of my finger... so say your word... and I'll have done with you.  Lock up the dogs."
The handler again looks to His Lordship for direction.  The master of all he surveys, but for a single errant finger has been called to task.  He motions to the handler who coaxes the pack into their cage, then slides the bolt to retain the door.
"Now your knife, drive the blade in behind the bolt to bind it."
The handler complies, tapping the hilt lightly with the palm of his hand.
Leona takes exception to his token.  "Would you toy with your master's life?"  She inquires loudly, "drive the damn thing home!"
"Do as she says, you ass," Roux is quick to chastise, "The wench is not to be antagonized."
The fellow takes a firm swing with his mace, then another; his dogs retreat to the far corners of the cage and cower down in a huddle.
"Strike it," she commands, "snap the blade off then drop the club into the center of the cage."
Compliance is immediate; he seems to be learning.
"Free the girl."
A casual upward motion of the royal hand and Beth's cage begins to rise.  She impatiently squirms under the edge while keeping a watchful eye upon the caged dogs.  She dries her eyes, dusts herself off, recovers her chewed-up shoe and marches to the edge of the arena where the two guards stand.  Confronted by the raised platform, she extends her arm toward one of the guards.
"Well, are you a gentleman or not?"  Beth questions.  The guard looks again to his master for guidance.
"Get her up out of there!"  Leona exclaims, reminding all in attendance they need not inquire of His Lordship for direction.  The two guards jointly hoist Beth to the platform, whereupon she shuffles over to Leona's side.  Leona's attention never strays from her target, and His Lordship knows it, for had she flinched he would be gone.  "Except for Roux, everyone to the heath, facing the wall and without a word."  The two guards from Leona's side cross the arena and with some assistance to overcome the pickets, join the others.  Silence prevails.
"You okay?" she inquires of Beth.
"Yeah, I guess.  Feel like a used badminton birdie though.  Have ya seen Hale?"
"He's waiting for us at the gate."
"Great, I owe ya.  Uhmmm... would it be a lot of trouble," Beth pointing ominously toward her Ladyship; "to just sort of... like kill her?  That bitch in the white dress right there."
"Maybe later, this thing is getting heavy, and we need to get the flock out of here."
"Right!"
"I need that bastard as a hostage, but we can't get across the pit past those spikes and if I allow him to move I know he'll go for that curb.  We have to run for it, really fast."
"My knees are kinda torn up, options?"
"Dog food!"
"Been there, done that, let's go!"
"Through there," Leona points with a nod "that door leads into a hall.  See if it's clear, and be careful."
Beth sneaks up on the door at the opposite end of the anteroom, cautiously opening it a little which allows her to see only in one direction.  All appears clear.  She moves forward somewhat to look around the edge in the opposite direction, all the while with a death grip on the handle.
A hefty guard happens to be passing at the time; curious of the door's strange activity, he has stepped up behind it.  When Beth peeks around from within, she immediately displays her best shy smile.  It does little good to act the innocent considering all the dirt and scratches on her face.
"What mischief is this?" he inquires suspiciously.
"Ahhh Hi... where's the ladies' room?"
The burly fellow grabs the edge of the door, pulling it open.  Beth, being somewhat attached to the handle, comes trotting right around with it.  Thus, she has inconveniently positioned herself squarely between the guard and Leona.  With the door now wide open, Leona is disclosed pointing a crossbow in the direction of the arena's VIP gallery.  Her priorities abruptly changed, she acquires the more pressing target and looses the bolt.  The dart passes clear through the fellow, shattering as it impacts the stone wall beyond.  He drops like a rock.
Beth stands frozen, staring back at Leona in disbelief that she really did that.  A fin from the dart has imparted a neat red line across her forehead, and it stings.  Apparently nothing is off the table including occasional William Tell fantasies.
The moment Leona is distracted, Roux dives to the floor, taking cover behind the raised curb along the edge of the spectator's platform.  The jig is up.
Leona drops the spent crossbow, retreats into the anteroom and slams the door's bolt.  Expecting company within seconds, she withdraws a wooden wedge and one of the ceramic grenades from her bag.  The wedge is driven firmly under the door with the stock of her crossbow.
Beth jumps as guards crash up against the door attempting to overcome the latch.  "Let's get out of here," she spurts.  "What's that?"
"Better dying through chemistry."  Leona twists the cap breaking the wax seal on the grenade's fuse and withdraws it abruptly, striking it against the detonator as one would ignite a railroad flare.  The grenade begins to hiss, expelling a few sparks at first, then, only a slight telltale stream of acrid smoke.  She places the device upon the table, detonation at waist level being the most effective option.   Her trap set, the girls exit into the corridor.  Another wedge is now driven under the second door tight as possible and yet another into the doorjamb at the hinges.  Leona snatches up the fallen guard's weapon handing it to Beth.  Beth looks at it for a moment though it were a snake smiling back at her.  They dash off down the corridor.
Of late, His Lordship has become exceedingly fond of the floor, pressed flat thereupon as close as one might possibly be--seemingly glued to it in fact.   Hyperventilating somewhat, he refuses to rise even after his trusty servants have rushed to his aid.
"Bring them back," he howls, "a purse of gold for each of them alive.  I want them back... alive mind you... alive."  Several more guards have come on the scene.  They vault over the pickets and sprint across the arena toward the anteroom; this could be a retirement opportunity.  His Lordship continues to rant.  "Raise the alarm," he screams, grabbing a servant who scurries by.  "See the gates are secured at once," he instructs in a shrill panicked tone, now having risen to his knees.  Pushing the servant away, he turns his wrath upon the dog handler.  "Loose the dogs you buffoon.  Why do you delay?"  Frantically attempting to extract his twisted blade from the hasp, the handler dare not but agree.
	"Yes, milord."  Alas, when good steel is meshed with softer iron, the bond created thereof is not to be easily dissuaded.  The servants scatter; turmoil abounds.  People are scampering about as though a basket of frisky frogs had been tossed upon a hot griddle.  	"Summon the lord of the watch," their reinstated dictator wails, now secure upon two feet and seemingly back to full command status.  "I would know how this invasion has came to be."
The guards have overcome the first door and are now within the anteroom, hung up by the wedges driven under the second.  Leona's firecracker clears the space with an ear-shattering concussion.  Sorcery of a nature heretofore unknown is afoot.  Two fellows exit immediately in a random airborne configuration; another staggers into view, cloaked in blood.  He stumbles from the edge of the platform headlong into the arena.  Things unseen were perceived to buzz about the room snapping at the walls.  A soup tureen upon His Lordship's fine table has abruptly shattered.  One of the servants is doubled over in pain thinking himself stung by a great hornet.   Thick plums of smoke pour into the arena from the upper portion of the open portal.  The light reflected from the flaming troughs cast the scene into a ghostly pale.  Once again relinquishing command and glued to the floor, His Lordship pounds his fist with little regard for the roaches who had gathered for the banquet of crumbs.  It's the first time they've ever seem him from quite this close.  The reluctant anteroom door is now open, dangling precariously from twisted hinges, the face of it splintered and perforated by shrapnel.  One fellow, lucky by comparison to those inside, was in the passageway bent down trying to extract the wedge from beneath the door.  His nose will never be quite the same, but the onslaught of lead pellets passed safely over his head. 

Chapter-12

OF BEING CHASED BY THE HOUNDS OF HELL 
AND THINGS THAT GO BOOM IN THE NIGHT.

The low level of lighting imparts an eerie morbid character to their surroundings and renders Leona's exit markings difficult to trace.  From the sound of it, the dogs are loose again and coming their way--at least four as she remembers at about sixty pounds each and likely trained to be absolutely fearless.  They would attack as a group at full speed regardless of any peril she may impose.  A man bends to reason, by that he may be threatened.  A dog so trained does not think nor have reservations of its future well being.  One shot to sway their advance and one swing of her blade is unlikely to prevail against 240 pounds of airborne hounds.  A vicious bloody melee would ensue and the girls would likely be overwhelmed.
Rounding a corner, they find a guard is about to lock a gate across their path.  If he succeeds they're trapped, caught between the iron bars and hounds' porcelain-adorned jaws.  Leona takes the shot; with nowhere to hide he's squarely hit.  Beth runs ahead as Leona recocks her bow.  They dare not be without a ready dart, for the wailing of dogs' echoes through the corridor.  Beth finds the slain guard has fallen with his weight opposing the gate's direction of swing.  Even in death the portly fellow may have defeated them.  Try as she may, even with the prospect of being reunited with her puppy pals to encourage, the gate refuses to budge more than a few inches.  "It's stuck," she cries out, poking at the fellow with her confiscated sword in the vain hope of encouraging his retreat.  But, he's feeling no pain.  
The dogs round the far corner, bearing down on the girls' position.  Leona desperately charges into the gate, hitting it on the fly like a football tackle.  Her left shoulder seems always in the way of things lately, but she dare not risk injury to the right.  The gate gives way barely far enough for Beth's slight frame to squeeze by.  Leona turns and fires the last armed bow into the oncoming dog pack; there shall not be time to reload.  The charging canines are neither impressed nor dissuaded by the screeching hound that took the dart.  Her grenade fuses require nine seconds for detonation, she has three at best, and in such restricted quarters it would be suicide.  If she tries to wedge herself through the narrow opening and gets hung up, she would render herself near helpless and be ripped apart.  Time has come to stand fast; she draws her weapon, grabs a dart from the ammo pouch as a dagger and prepares to repel borders.  Beth has taken hold of the gate with both hands.  Placing a foot against the jamb for leverage, she's able to pull it open slightly more.  
"Come on," Beth screams.  "I've got it!"
A second wave of hounds rounds the corner; three were doable, perhaps, but eight are just too many.  Maybe she'll fit--she must!  Leona exhales far as she can and goes for it, successfully jamming herself through with a great amount of self-imposed scuffing.  Beth pushes the gate closed as the first wave of dogs crash against the bars in a murderous frenzy.  Their impact nearly forces the gate; indeed the corpse at her feet now helps as much as it had hindered.  There are no alternatives.  Beth's holding, but loosing ground; the bars are alive with gaping jaws.  One has gotten its head between the gate's edge and the frame, which will not allow the gate to fully close.  Leona rebounds, throwing her weight against the onslaught of teeth; crushing the intruder's snout.  The creature pulls itself back with intense muffled yelps.  Beth loses her shoe yet again and near as well her foot, kicking at the beasts.  Her hand is bitten badly for which she recites a little prayer in the higher octave ranges wishing the hounds soon upon their way to doggy hell.
Leona's bitten firmly on the back of her left calf, but there is little to be gained of complaining as Beth is still covering the subject adequately.  She feels the hot foul breath of another as it nearly has her ear.  She jams a crossbow dart into the hasp to secure the door a moment before the second wave collides with the first.  Her shirtsleeve is forfeit and her wrist nipped before she can jump away.  One creature wails, pulling frantically to extract a paw trapped beneath the door and the stone floor.  Beth stomps on it, retrieves her fallen weapon and bashes the trapped hound's head hard as she can with one arm and no regret.  The bars are alive with teeth and vicious barking, indeed it seems these curs are so wound up they would kill each other for the first opportunity to taste of their quarries' blood.  Beth drops the blade and backs away, she is in tears, doubled over in pain clutching her bitten hand for some slight measure of relief.  An open padlock can be seen lying on the carnivore's side of the gate with no hope of being retrieved.  The dart jammed into the hasp will hold, but only till the guards catch up, then they'll be set loose again.  Were there time enough, and had she not abandoned the crossbow to accomplish her exit, she would slay them all one by one and take great pleasure in so doing.
A dart skids along the wall beside Beth and continues down the passage.  Another strikes one of the dogs in the side; throwing it into a screeching tantrum.  Mingled with the barking, the girls can hardly hear each other speak.  The manpower has arrived, fortunately, now more careful of their quarry than the dogs, considering past events in the anteroom.  They advance cautiously behind shields and volleys of darts.  To avoid hitting the animals bunched up at the gate, they are firing the darts so as to ricochet off the ceiling and skim along the walls and floor.  One has found its mark, striking Leona through the toe of her boot.  She pulls Beth from the line of fire into the adjoining passage.
The wall bears one of her escape-route markings allowing her to recognize the corridor, this was one of the iron gates, she remembers, that would have had an invader caught within a cross fire.  At the far end there appears a door; yes! the rack of crossbows.  That has to be the door to the courtyard.  Both are exhausted and painfully abraded, but the girls dare not tarry to catch a breath.  With cover fire the guards will soon breach the unlocked gate, and with that again will come the dogs.  Beth's beginning to stammer; the relentless barking is about to have her completely undone.  "We're not going to sit down here and wait to die, okay!" Leona reminds.  "So get your ass to that door at the end."  Leona points.  "Crouch down in the corner, face the wall and hold your ears.  Get going!"  Beth halfheartedly sprints to the door and huddles in the corner.  Though the girls are out of sight, darts continue zinging through the adjacent corridor.  Their pursuers are laying cover fire, an effort to hold Leona's magic at bay while they advance.  Even so, the relentless hounds are her major concern.  Striking off another grenade, she sets it just around the corner, mid corridor, near the gate, the dog's commotion should distract from its presence.
With the first step away, she's painfully reminded there's still a dart in her left foot.  Precious few moments remain before she becomes a victim of her own devices.  Already the guards are attempting to quell the dogs so they can reach the latch.  They've only a few feet around the corner from where she now sits trying to extract the projectile.  Back to her feet again, she is in full forward motion.  She can see Beth is looking back at her, "turn around," Leona screams.
Lead hornets fill the air with a deafening vengeance as the grenade bursts.  Docile stone walls come alive; deflectors, suddenly riddled with hundreds of deadly impacts.  Some ricochet from the smooth ashlars again and again finding their way into the adjacent corridor.  Leona's left forearm is grazed straight through.  Another has struck her in the side and it stings like hell.  Had the impact not been taken by her leather carryall the lead tear would now be lodged somewhere well beyond her ribs.  Only twelve feet from the detonation, the concussion has sent her toward Beth head-first.  A forward-flying Leona is somewhat more graceful than a backward flying Tax Collector, yet nonetheless precarious--the key being one's ability to land well.  Oil lamps are swept from their perches.  Though constructed that their flames be slight, the reservoirs were substantial to minimize the need of constant refilling.  Fuel from the lamp at the corridor's intersection is instantly vaporized by the shock wave.  A billowing sea of orange flames cloaked by ominous dense smoke rolls out along the high pitched corridor ceilings as the waves at sunset upon an upside-down ocean of ink.  Other lamps shatter in place or fall and break contributing to the fuel supply.  Only one of the dogs may be heard now, its voice painfully retreating.
