Through the thickening haze an injured fellow can be seen to stagger by; feeling his way as he continues blindly down the adjacent corridor.  Fortunately none more capable come into the mix, for Leona is temporarily out of order.
They must get out; the thick oily smoke will soon render the corridors uninhabitable.  Indeed none shall follow by this route any time soon.  Leona rises unsteadily, a bit more scuffed from her conference with the unforgiving stone floor.  Maintaining her sense of balance is more of a challenge though; for her ears insist the head there between thinks itself a bell.  And she has left a calling card, blood for the hounds surely to follow.
Beth is becoming a smidgen distressed.  "This is getting out of hand, Leo," she informs impatiently.  "From now on Hale and I are playing bingo.  You and Art can deal with this sword fighting shit."
Knowing something was said, but unable to make out the words, Leona agrees with a nod.  Hastily unloading the rack of crossbows, she slings one over each shoulder, hands one to Beth, and carries the last.  "Can you hear me?" she asks, not yet able to confirm her own words.  Beth affirms with a nod.  "Hale's waiting outside the gate.  Once we go... you don't stop, no matter what.  If we get separated, stay near the walls.  Something gets in your way, you point and squeeze this lever on the bottom.  Be calm, don't waste it, you've only got one shot."  Leona pulls a thin black swatch of material from her bag.  She drapes it over Beth's head, securing it around her neck and waist with laces.  "Take hold of this," offering the edge of her leather carryall.  "Hang on, stay with me if you can, it's really dark out there."
Indeed it is, pitch black.  There are less than a dozen torch lights stationed about the entire yard.  Of these, two flank either side of the gate and none are so bright as to be more than a blind reference for those who already know their way.  Certainly they cast no light upon the ground, which may be more to their advantage than not.  The girls scoot off into the darkness fast as they dare.  Leona limps upon her way, the dart wound and dog's bite having taken a toll of her stride.  "The gate's over there, right between those four lights," she advises Beth in a whisper.
If ever she has played blind man's bluff, this is it.  A hundred adversaries could stand before them and neither they nor them be any the wiser of the other.  She strains to detect any sound or glimmer of light that sword or shield might carelessly reflect.  Most encouraging though, there is no sound of panting nor the slightest growl.  All her effort would be misspent within a few terrible moments if another pack of attack hounds come into play.  They've been quick about the business of getting out and the explosions were contained deep within the sealed structure.  Though curious some may be of such rumblings, who would dare to question His Lordship's private activities?  Fifty yards hence the unmanned gate promises them freedom; could one hope the alarm has not yet spread?  But now as though it were her wish, a bell begins to toll.  Considering the distance they must travel, she has estimated the first of the garrison's troops could mount up and reach the prison side gate within 60 to 90 seconds.  If the gate has not been sealed before the horsemen arrive, they would be easily overpowered.
Just outside the gate Hale and Karn wait anxiously.  "They're alive, lad!" Karn exclaims.  "The bell, do you hear it!  No need of that were they not loose somewhere within those walls."  Karn jumps from the cart, sword in hand, and heads toward the portal.  "Will you die for your lady?  It's time to fight lad; we must hold this gate or they'll be trapped."
Hale can see nothing but a faint outline of the gateway, and then only because of the flickering torches on the other side of the wall.  As for the ground, for all he knows it's not even there; a tricky proposition for a fellow hobbling along on one leg.
Security is coming on line fast.  Leona has see several torches moving about on the parapets overlooking the yard, and more are evident descending the stair adjacent the watch tower at the gate.  They are going to be cut off and Beth will be nearly defenseless.
"There!" someone above is heard to shout as he heaves a torch in the girls' direction.  Darts and arrows descend haphazardly toward the escapee's perceived location.  Those ricocheting from the paving become like scatter shot moving horizontally just above the ground.  Others impale themselves upon penetrable surfaces, their journeys safely ended.  The ladies run the gauntlet.  Piles of firewood, feed sacks, hay bails, wagons and hand carts, each offering it's own special quality of shelter, but none more valuable than the moonless sky.  Leona heaves a heavy piece of wood back in the direction from whence they came.  The audible disturbance draws considerable attention, archers on the parapet sending a hail of projectiles only to be swallowed up by the void.
Karn wades into the sentries descending the watch tower's stair.  Each carries a torch to see his way and thus are excellently well marked quarry.  The first few are taken by surprise and quickly rendered useless.  In their haste, and for lack of railings, one slips from the edge not to be seen again.  Confusion and dark of night his shield and the confiscated guard's helmet to disguise his loyalties, Karn would seem to be at least three different attackers.  Two of Roux's men engage one another, with one being wounded before realizing they are of the same banner.  Picking up a fallen torch, Karn points it toward a guard who has lost his own and exclaims, "There he is, after him."  The hapless fellow runs off into the dark, two of his own comrades in hot pursuit.  Torches and silhouettes dance about, the archers above now hard pressed to define a viable target.
Hale fairs less well, losing ground to a swordsman who is working him into a corner.  The fellow's in no rush to end their affair; for none may find fault so long as he appears to be doing his job.  And thus occupied, not obligated to engage another who might best his challenge.  When the time's right he'll have this cripple's head, the glory of victory and maybe a promotion.  With all the confusion and dark of night who could argue it was not a gallant contest to the last.
Burning torches strewn about the ground due to Karn's scathing attack bring the onset of a dastardly deed to Leona's attention.  They vaguely illuminate a fellow who labors to release the siege door.  Assuming sitting-duck status, she takes aim at the fellow who dares to seal their fate and looses the dart.  He pulls the lever free of its catch.  The winch drum starts to unwind.  Clanking chains precariously announces their impending doom.  Karn knows it's the executioner's lament he hears and could dash away, but that was not the bargain he struck.
--
Dark of night fades to candle's light and the sounds of battle abate to a restless flute's lament.  Once again, Leona sits in the game room with her friends; all are safe and close at hand, though like before, frozen as in a photograph.  Before her a silver tray, four cards thereupon await.  The sorceress explains the implications of each. "One of these will save the day; another, your friends alone, all well upon their way, but with that choice you must quit the play.  The third of them would have the lot of you into chains, to what avail only time may say; the last will slay you one and all and not the least bit kindly so."
With odds hardly better than Russian roulette, the time to pay the piper is at hand.  She's exhausted all her trump cards and tricks to survive and reach this point.  Leona's dilemma presents a grand opportunity for Sanaia to regain control of Leona's memories.  For indeed there is a law nearly as profound as gravity, that one must give to get.  The interloper which has stolen away the sorceress's control of Leona's memories may only be foiled by its master.  Though not so in reality, by default within the game's context, that would be the player.  Rules have given to each participant authority to bargain at the expense of any resource which they command.  Unauthorized though he may be, Bird is certainly that, and as such, may be bartered.  "Forfeit a treasure of my choosing," Sanaia offers, "and thus, may you select two and retain that which you favor most."
Leona's surprised by Sanaia's offer.  Aside from her sword's apparent ability to cut whatever she strikes, there is nothing to trade, least of all treasure.  "I have no such wealth of which I'm aware."
"There is no talisman on the board for it, but if you say, it will be so.  The prize must abide your decision... thus away it will go."  Leona agrees, choosing to reduce the odds to an even money bet.
"So be it, and I shall have two of those cards to choose."
Her first choice is the card that would have had all of them into the dungeons and likely tortured to death.  She looks to Beth, unconcerned as always of her plight.  Are they truly in this room as she perceives it now?  Or is this the charade and in fact all have been discreetly spirited away to some witches' brew of a nightmare?  The interloper has ceded to the rules of the game, allowing itself to be removed, quietly, without duress.  Leona flips the second card, the sorceress is summoned away, and once again the game begins to play.
Mark congratulates Sanaia on her resourceful thinking. "Clever!"
"Thank you," she says calmly with a devilish smirk.  Clever is included with my fees."
"Did it work?"
"The intruder is playing by the rules; it has withdrawn.  You know it served us as well as she; the Witch was too potent an adversary.  Much would have been lost to your inquiry had the girl been taken so early on."
"Yes, and shrewdly plotted as to have none the wiser.  There is much to wonder about this intruder, you know.  I mean, is someone looking over our shoulder?"  Sanaia nods with an inquisitive smile.
Steel clashes, shattering the calm of the game room.  Again there is much scuffling and clatter all about her.  The candle's flame which had stolen her away is suddenly scattered haphazardly, taking the form of a dozen fallen torchlight's and four more all in a row aside the prison gate.
She immediately refocuses upon the sentry who holds their future.  He's been struck by her bolt, tumbling forward, pulled into the churning mechanism.  Gears are bound up with arms and legs as the door literally grinds to a halt painfully upon his unfortunate bones.  So much depends on the correlation of events, that precise point where time and place cross.  Fate requires but one simple tool to engineer the most intricate of designs, a fraction of a second this way or that.
With the winch's silence, now may be heard the sound of hooves pounding the ground.  An abundance of torches bob about in the dark a hundred yards distant; His Lordship's troops have mobilized.
Dropping the spent bow and bringing one of those slung from her shoulder to the ready, she dashes toward the winch.  Hardly a moment shall pass before it must be made to fall and not availed to rise again.  Ten yards to her right, three capable swordsmen are closing on Karn.  So many torches are now strewn upon the ground that he's lost the cover of darkness.  The pressing horsemen disallow her direct intervention.  Launching a dart squarely into the back of one oppressor, then heaving the spent weapon toward another to distract his assault is the best effort she can spare.  By this Karn takes the offensive, nicking one attacker who quits the engagement.  The remaining sentry takes up the challenge on his own, abruptly losing most of an arm.  Both foe back away, one the wiser, one the fool.
"Find the girl," Leona screams at Karn.  "And get out now."  The mine beneath the winch must be detonated with the hope gravity will reassume its duties.
Beth is on one knee, struggling desperately with her chewed-up hand to steady a shot at Hale's assailant.  She releases the bolt, the dart penetrating deep into his thigh.  Wounded thus, he drops like a lead balloon.  Seeing Beth, Hale instantly loses interest in his antagonist, allowing him slink away defensibly hissing and reciting verse generally reserved to Shanghaied sailors.  His plan to avoid engaging a better man has earned not gold, but the need of a crutch for the rest of his days.
Karn knew of Hale's dilemma, but could not assist.  Thankful the lad had distracted one of the sentries, for he could not have held for long against four.  Now he and Beth assist Hale, as the beleaguered escapees make their way to the cart.  Great relief settles over Leona knowing they are all at last beyond the walls.
Movement is the key to survival, but to fire the mine she must risk being a fixed target.  The spline of a broad-head grazes her knee as she stoops, another abruptly taking root in a heavy timber only inches in front of her face.  She strikes the fuse, it fails to ignite; again, and again, still no spark.  The scent of urine!  Some fool has unknowingly pissed on it!  Contact with the striker has caused the moist ignition compound to crumble and fall away.  From her pouch she retrieves a tight bundle of thin wooden sticks, the end covered with a leather sheath.  The cover seal's broken, the cap twisted and withdrawn sharply igniting the tip in a flurry of sparks.  She jams the flaring end to the mine's malfunctioning fuse port.  Unlike the firecracker used to dissuade the dogs, this is a formidable device, one meant to destroy things.  Her approach is desperate, an extremely dangerous alternative, but it must be detonated at all costs.  The dampened fuse begins to sputter.
Before she can rise, someone grabs her from behind.  With no time to draw her weapon, she reaches for anything solid as they tumble backward.  Grasping for support she catches an arrow embedded in one of the timbers, coming away with only the broken shaft.  Driving the splintered stick around behind the side of her head as violently as possible she strikes her assailant in the side of his face.  His grip relaxes, allowing her to pull free and scramble backward to her feet.  Turning about, sword in hand, she advances only to find the fellow has no weapon.  His good sense set aside by thoughts of reward; thinking to capture her alive and kicking along with a generous purse of fine gold.  But he neither retreats nor advances, instead careening past as if he were blind and crashing face-first to the ground.  An arrow calling her by name has found its way to the back of his head.  Friendly fire is surely the unkindest cut of all.
It was a costly delay, the first of the mounted soldiers are upon her.  She slings the last armed bow to her service and lets the bolt free, losing her carryall in the effort.  His attack painfully neutralized, his lance nearly finding its mark even without the horseman to guide it.  Heaving the spent bow toward the next, she nearly dismounts him as well.  Time has defeated her; any second everything near at hand will be ripped apart.  Horsemen are all around her, the exit portal no longer an option.  Diving to the ground face down, she snuggles in tight alongside the friendly fire casualty only a few yards adjacent the wench.  Clasping her hands over her ears, she patiently waits out the longest and perhaps last moments of her life.
A powerful hand grips Leona's right forearm and attempts to lift her upward.  Then it's gone, though the glove of iron mail that embraced it remains.  Physically, her surroundings are instantly transformed.  Her sense of touch has departed and all is silent, only pressure remains, slight assurance she may still be.  Or not!  For now she stands at water's edge while her mare, Carmel Girl sips the cool water.  It's a lovely day and all is perfect.
From her antagonist's many points of view, however, a splendid vengeance is unleashed, rearing up out of the ground like a horde of howling demons that none are prepared to confront.  Shattering the winch and most of the foundation, allowing the chain to uncoil wildly as the drum jerks and wrangles through the air, set to spinning by the massive weight of the falling door.  Fifty-pound limestone blocks bounce across the yard's cobbled floor like marshmallows on a windy day.  The kegs iron bands have shred into razors and rivets have become white hot projectiles.  Pity those standing near, for they are now spread upon the surroundings like strawberry jam or blended with the evening breeze.  The concussion clears the first rank of men and animals to the last.  Splintered timbers from the platform spin off into the darkness like chain shot.  The steeds of the second rank rear up in an attempt to turn away from the oncoming debris.  Nearly all the riders are thrown into the midst of the startled mounts who roll and stumble about in pain and confusion.  Those of the next rank, still advancing, collide with remnants of second.  Many of the horses fall precariously one upon the other.  A tangled heap of half-ton animals frantically attempting to right themselves and taking precious little care as to the means of accomplishing it is not a place where mere mortal man should be.  Leona and her bodyguard stay very close when they travel at warp speeds.  His corpse takes the initial impact, flash burns and flying debris at full cost.  Thus, for the most part being rendered to mush, but generally still intact.  Though tumbling preciously across a stone floor can be somewhat abrasive, slight compensation may found in that it extinguished her clothing, which was afire.  Still, transport by impact is seldom the best means for it rarely has a specific destination in mind.  Her hearing is totally dysfunctional; a loud high pitched echo is all that remains, bouncing back and forth as though it were trapped somewhere between her ears, but trying to escape.  All that can be seen are hazy flickering lights, each of them in triplicate arranged in triangular patterns and flashing specks of bright white light strewn among warbling dark bluish gray geometric designs.  Her entire surface is terribly numb, yet buzzing intensely as though she were in the midst of a giant bee hive.  Bruised, abused, dazed and confused, with several fractured ribs as a bonus, but still glad to be alive, more or less--at least she thinks so.  Though not so for many others, the massive limestone foundation blocks between her and the mine had much to do with preserving her life, deflecting the lessor stones and much of the blast's shock wave toward the oncoming troops  
Torches and burning embers ejected from the wall sconces litter the area.  This random light alludes to the fact the siege door does not yet rest firmly upon the ground.  A hefty timber from the winch platform has found its way thereunder creating a gap; thus, someone light of frame and very determined might slip away.  But, it matters not, for she has lost control of all motor functions and in fact has no idea what her current position relative to the ground might be.  All has been neutralized by the tremendous vibration permeating her entire being.  Even so, it's been a good day's work, considering she got a late start.
Just outside the walls, her getaway cart rocks and jogs about as Karn attempts to calm the team after the detonation.  Fortunately he was at the reigns at the time or the cart would be well upon its way to no where in particular.  He cannot remember being so bewildered as to what has occurred.  Things of this sort are only spoken of by the thoroughly inebriated, they just don't really happen.
Thinking her friend lost, Beth has begun to whimper.  She flops out of the cart with only the slightest flickers of light from beneath the fallen door to guide and ventures back toward the narrow breach.  Crouching down, she takes a cautious peek into the mayhem of the prison yard.  Activity is apparent, though more evident from the sounds than what may actually be seen.  Bits of images come and go in the light of torches.  Several fires are being tended to; one has gotten quite intense.  Dozens of silhouettes ramble about, mostly those of horses.  All seem thoroughly bewildered as to what just occurred and none possess of any interest to continue searching for His Lordship's lost toys.  The focus is on untangling the damaged personnel and gathering the mounts so as to keep them from stepping upon the injured.
Beth tries to raise a response while Hale stands a nervous guard.  "Hon, there's nothing we can do" Hale consoles.  "Not after something like that."
"Think of something," Beth stammers.  "We can't leave her."
"I don't know what she did, but... you know it must have been pretty bad."
"She blew the place up dummy; Beth informs sternly, "you know how she gets sometimes... when she's mad.  We've got to get back in there," Beth insists.  "Do something!"
"How?  I mean, what!  Sometimes things just don't work out, and you know these guys are bound to start coming out somewhere else."
She pretty much ignores him and continues in a subdued tone at first, then, for lack of a reply a bit louder.  "Leo!  Leo, come on... please, Leeooo!" she sings out.
Before Hale realizes it Beth is halfway under the door, another instant, she's gone!  He stoops to see what's become of her, but there is not enough light to be sure.
"Hon... Hon, come back please!  Crap!"
Karn soon joins Hale.  "Sorry 'bout your friend in there, we did our best, lad.  What was that happened in there?   Where's ya lady?  Oh Shit!  That wily little maiden of yours hasn't gone back in... under the door... has she?"
"'Fraid so!"
Karn drops to the ground to see what he can.  Neither he nor Hale could possibly fit through.  There's no sign of Beth.  He turns back to Hale.  "You must entice her to return.  They've not finished with us.  Soon as they can regroup they'll be coming to search us out."
Beth is crawling around on all fours.  She spies Leona, more or less curled up into a ball and not moving at all.  The wind's completely out of Leona's sails, and she's still not exactly sure where she may have landed.  Beth skitters over to her best friend and gives her a nudge.  "Hey!"  Leona does not respond.  Beth takes her hand; "Hey, wake up!"  Leona shudders as though suddenly aroused from a dream.
"Hellooo! are you there?" Beth teases desperately.  "Let's get out of here 'fore these dudes wise up, come on."
Leona tries to focus, could be Beth.  What's she doing here?  Leona is hard pressed to reply.  "Can't hear," she mumbles, "just buzzing, so dizzy, am I dead yet?"  Beth shakes her head negatively.  "No?  Not yet, didn't think so, wasn't sure though.  Thought all of you made it out." she slurs very slowly, "You okay?"  Beth nods a yes, delighted as ever.  Leona can't hear herself talk, but she can feel the words--at least it seems so.
"Come on," Beth advises inspiringly, let's go!"  
"What?  Get out of here, will ya.  I can't move."
"Sure ya can... come onnnn."  Beth tugs precariously at her friend's arm; Beth's touch quells some the debilitating vibration that has taken control of her senses, but still she is unable to move.  Beth straightens Leona's legs out and unfolds her arms, her friend is limp as a boiled noodle.  She tries to roll Leona toward the door, but one hand isn't enough and the other is too painful.  Beth manages to bend down far enough to get her shoulder against Leona's back and with her good hand pulling upward then pushing at Leona's hip, nudges her hero along half a turn at a time.  It's tough going for a lightweight with lacerated knees.  After a few flops, a semblance of touch is becoming apparent at Leona's extremities as Beth pulls, flips, drags, flops and pushes her along. 
Groaning a tentative, "Okay, I'll try," Leona raises a palm to quell Beth's selfless struggle.  She slowly rolls over face down on her own initiative, arches her back and draws one knee after the other up beneath her hips to the accompaniment of much moaning and grunting.  With a little more complaining, she rolls one shoulder up, braces her posture with an elbow, then rolls to the opposite, doubling down on her bet.  Braced as such upon her knees and elbows, she manages to push a hand forward, more by way of tilting her shoulder and flinging it sideways as not.  It's a beginning!  Beth, though unarmed, keeps watch and sweeps any glowing coals aside with her indispensable Swiss army shoe while Leona trudges forward on her elbows, not yet even as capable as an infant learning to crawl.  Though considerably more are now on their way to the disaster scene, those few on site still in operable condition are concerned more of their comrades who have been thoroughly crushed, stomped, burned and shredded during the affair.
Peeking under the door, Beth informs, "hey you guys, over here! come on, I've got her!"
Hale and Karn are flat to the ground, both delighted at the prospect they may soon actually depart.  It's no trick at all for Beth, but there is a bit more to Leona.  She must slither and wiggle to get started; her head and one arm are all that will fit under her own steam.  Something to get a hold of was really all the fellows needed.  With Beth pushing and the guys tugging, they manage to drag her under the door.  Good thing she's still numb as a marshmallow and buzzing like bee or her ribs would have had serious objections to the aggressive handling.
Hale attempts to lift Leona to her feet, but she is like a soggy towel.
Beth's quick as a mouse to follow, and not a moment too soon.  The razor-sharp tip of a lance soon follows.  Pushed under the door from the other side, it strikes the stone pavers between her feet.  She jumps away.  "Look out!" Hale shouts.  The blade is quickly withdrawn, then, comes again; reaching further on the second attempt.
She proceeds to scold the attempted unseen assassin like a grunge band's groupie.  "Your mother bleep, bleeds, and you can bleep, bleep's bleeping, etc. etc."
Hale grabs her arm, pulling her back.  "Where'd you hear that stuff?"
"Rappers!"
"Get thee to the parapets," a voice from within cries out.  "They are here, just beyond the door, fast to the parapets I say."
Karn is quick to gather Leona up out of harm's way.  He carries her to the cart, heaving her into the back with the finesse one might employ were he trying to steal a sack of potatoes.  Frump!
Before he can depart, she grabs his arm.  "Thanks for waiting.  Go the road southward around to the left into the forest.  You must not cross the field; stay on the road."  Not quite up to speed yet, she slumps into the straw about half unconscious.
Karn confides to Hale in an uneasy tone.  "I shall do my best, but I fear the horses will no more than walk.  I doubt they can see the way better than I, and I cannot at all."  Karn takes the reins, tugging at the horses, leading them along as fast as they will follow him.  Dumb animals they may be, but certainly not foolish; they refuse to run blindly in the darkness.  With great effort he encourages the team up to a slow trot.  Arrows may be heard as they buzz past, also the twang of crossbows being let loose from the wall above the failed door.  A moonless night may hide them from view, but it fails to conceal the sounds of their movement.  Hopefully, they will be out of range before one of their number or a horse is struck.  With a half a mile at least until reaching the forest's edge, prospects are dim they will not be overtaken as soon as the troops regroup.
Hale knows Leona's not a dummy.  He implores Beth, "Hon, you've got to bring her around.  There's something important missing here."
Beth is first to notice the stream of torches winding around the far corner of the Keep's foreboding silhouette.  "Leo, I see lights!"  She jostles Leona to no avail.  "They're coming again! Leooo wake up, please."  Hale is trying to figure out how to arm Beth's spent crossbow in the dark.  At the moment they only have the one Leona confiscated--a single shot for their entire defense system.  Then the water barrel comes to mind.  Yes! and there was a bucket, too, he remembers.  With some feeling around he manages to get it about a third full and heave it into Leona's face.
A stern wake-up call, true, but what are their choices?  This brings the urgency of their situation back into focus, mostly because she's now beginning to hurt as the false security of total numbness begins to evaporate.  "Oh shhiiit!  She reels slowly to one side and twists slightly.  "Is everybody out?"  She grabs Beth, then strains to identify the other passenger.  "Is that you, Hale?  Good!"
"Leo they're after us again," Beth informs fearfully.
"We're not moving," Leona correctly reasons, "why... why are we not... the lamp?"  She crawls up over the seat back.  "Hey, you out there, stop the team!  Get up here and drive this thing."
"They will not hasten into the darkness milady, nor can I see well enough to guide them.  What would you have me do?  Our only hope is to get into the forest and scatter.  Hide till dawn, then try to make our way."
She can hardly hear her own words and strains to understand those of her primary, only in fact, ally.  The sounds rise as though spoken from the depths of a well.  "Come up here now, horsemen are on their way."
"Then we must abandon this folly" Karn advises, "and take to foot."
"No! You swore to stand with me, get your ass up here now."  She turns to Hale for assistance.  "Help me out.  I need to get around to the front of the team."
Beth volunteers knowing Hale's leg has pretty much had it.  "I can do it," she insists in spite of how chewed up and battered she is. Leona feels around for a stash of items gathered in advance so as to be quickly retrieved.
"Hey look!  They're going the wrong way."  Beth informs excitedly, the row of torch lights moving off toward the city.  Another group, perhaps a dozen, has turned north toward the adjacent woodland.  Several men with torches precede each contingent sprinting along on foot to keep the horsemen on track and search for any sign the cart has left the roadway.
"They not sure which way we've gone yet; won't be long though," Leona replies, souring Beth's positive moment.  Sure enough, a third column breaks out of the main body now advancing in their direction.  Karn realigns the reins, reluctantly climbs to the driver's seat and patiently waits while His Lordship's cavalry advances upon their position, a trying task for one of his nature.
When Leona slides off the cart's tail end, her knees fold and she is once more in a heap.  "Damn it! where are my feet," she bemoans.  Nearly a deadweight and more than Beth can handle, Hale joins the effort.  In no time the fearsome threesome's hobbling right along.  As her systems begin coming back on line Leona's taking note of every quirk.  The concussion may have damaged her back for there are lapses of sensation.  Twisting and then snapping the cap from one of her homemade matches, it begins to fizzle and glow, then sparks up catching fire--this before reaching the team.  There is need to approach slowly with the light as not to alarm them.  Much concern is in Karn's eyes as she hands an apple up to him.  "Get those leather straps buckled around you tight.  If you're to be lost, sir, it should be for better cause than a bump in the road."  He knows with that fire to guide Roux's horsemen will spot their position, but what is he to do?  Expressing a groan reminiscent of pap's when he lowers a heavy box of fire wood to the hearth back home, Leona swings the oak panel hinged to the seat back around and latches it to the cart's foot board.  "To keep you from harm's way," she advises.  Hence, Kare's left side is now protected well as his back by inch thick oak planking. 
"Why are we passing out apples?"  Beth asks. 
"Something sweet to steady the horses; you need to do that while I start the lamp.  Keep your injured hand down at your side, the sent of blood might set then off.  Use the other, Spread your hand out flat, palm up with the apple on top.  Don't try to hold them between your fingers or you risk being bitten, understand?"
"Oh great!"
While Beth cautiously bribes the horses with treats and Hale props her up, Leona pulls the wild cards from her sleeve.  Removing the lamp keg's lid, she fills the upper chamber with water, then latches the cover back in place.  The tapered edge thereof has been spread with a generous gob sticky bee's wax to create a gas tight seal.  No simple task, her hands still numb, it's like working with bananas instead of fingers.  Dripping through the pinholes, water begins to excite the calcium carbide in the lower chamber, whereupon the sweet pungent odor of acetylene soon permeates the air.  Bringing her match to the iron tube at the reflector's center, there's a mellow pop! a flash, and now a brilliant white flame rises before the polished reflector to show the way.  Leona had attached a blinder on the lamp side of each horses bridle so as to prevent the bright flame from blinding them.  Karn's view of the flare is blocked by the reflector, he sees only the roadway and is so exceeding glad of it as not to wonder for a moment how this could be.  He steadies the uneasy team as Beth offers each yet another sweet delicious apple.
As she moves back toward Karn, Leona looses a strap restraining a heavy carpet rolled up on the left side of the horse.  A venetian blind of overlapping horizontal oak planks unfurls down along the steeds left flank.  The escapees are quick as they can back into the cart.  Leona calls out, "Go, take us away and be quick.
Karn snaps the reins with enthusiasm setting her machine in motion. "Haw, Haw!"  The team is hesitant at first till they become accustomed to the limited field of view, but soon rise to a brisk pace.  Leona pulls herself up alongside Karn, "do not cross the field," she cautions.
"Yes, milady."  He's surprised to find the cart rides smooth as any carriage his former station allowed.  As with taxes and wealth, neither does darkness come in equal measure to all who venture into the night.  Though each of His Lordship's cavalry carries a torch, they fare poorly in finding their way.  Indeed such noble effort does little more than foretell their exact location, tire their free arm and limit their ability to use a far-reaching weapon effectively.  Best of all, as they are second in line, their torch flames shall make excellent targets of them.
Lighting of the cart's lamp has vividly defined the troop column's prey.  For the escapees, however, there is not a more necessary evil.  A hunter's trumpet calls out to the dispersing squads of troops, announcing to all, "Come nigh to us, our quarry is found."  Their pace picks up considerably.  Knowing the road to curve left around the field ahead, a path from which the cart may not deviate effectively.  The unit's commander orders a squad of his men to break away into the field to outflank their objective as much effort could be conserved were they cut off from the sanctuary of the forest.  The cavalry steeds are much more disciplined than Leona's team.  With the light from her cart now sufficient as a reference their trusty steeds charge into the darkness unconcerned of the consequences.
The cavalry's closing in from behind, their lances and banners apparent even in the failing light of torches.  A dart is heard to strike the tailgate and the stinging sound of another passes by.  Leona explains the workings of crossbowmanship to Hale.  "Now you can feel the cable, and the latch right?"
"Yeah!"
"Okay, here's the problem.  It's dark, you can't see what you're doing, this wagon is all over the road, but you can't load the dart until the cable is set, got it?"
"Right!"
"If you bump the trigger while you're loading the dart, your nickname is Three Fingers... understand?"
"Right... Got it!"
"Okay, it's set.  Don't even touch the lever, point it away, brace yourself, stay down, and hold on.  Let me deal with it for now.  If I need help I'll let you know."  She takes up her longbow.  The glove to protect her fingertips is not to be found, however.  Lost in the shuffle, it hides somewhere in the straw.  There is pain on the horizon, for one does not pull a longbow with fractured ribs, with or without a glove, lest they shed a tear.  Each time she tenses the string, it's like being struck across the chest with a whip.  With the fifth shot her fingertips begin to sting, her ribcage aching with a vengeance.
Karn takes note of those crossing the field in advance of their position.  His faith is to be tested again, and so soon.  It's a task more demanding for him than any physical effort shall ever be.  He calls out to his general with some anxiety.  "Milady, we are being outflanked, there to the left."  Alas, she is seriously engaged at the moment and even were she not, her hearing is still seriously deficient.  Reaching around behind the seat, Karn manages to attract Hale's attention to relay his concern.  He forges ahead, himself defenseless, hoping that he and the team may breach the forthcoming roadblock without acquiring a lance through his chest.
Leona leans to his ear, verifying the demands of his mission.  "Do not waiver from the road; the forest is your mark, sir, at all costs."
The flankers are fast approaching, now scarcely thirty yards from the road.  Suddenly a great turmoil prevails in the darkness; torches twirl through the air aimlessly.  A web of strong hemp has been woven through the saplings obligating all who venture there to caution or despair.  Only one lancer has evaded the trap and reaches the road.  Leona takes the shot.  The fellow's steed is so alarmed at the intense on-rushing beam of light that it bolts, carrying the lancer off on a wave of panic.  Neither of them have hit their mark, thus, both shall see the sun rise again.
Soon after entering the confines of the forest the road narrows such that the cart may neither be bypassed nor outflanked.  Those who would pursue have little choice but to form a single row behind the rolling blockade.  A logistical catastrophe, for the lead horseman lit by his own torch becomes a helpless target.  One likely to suffer more beneath the hooves of those who follow than from the broad-heads coming his way.  Many of the riders have abandoned their useless torches, rather choosing the cart's silhouette as their objective and ignoring the pitch black that hides all else.  Thus, low slung branches consent to join Leona's arsenal.  The only weapon they may now bring to bear is a crossbow.  Each rider has but one shot and that unsteady at best.  For anyone galloping on horseback, reloading a standard crossbow on the run would be near impossible, much more so in the black of night.  Disaster then their fate, but 'tis a game after all and they its pawns, condemned to await their end.
By the ninth shot, Leona's fingertips are sore, her ribs in extreme distress.  By the twelfth her fingers burn as if held to a flame.  But, so long as these fools refuse to disengage suitable restraint must be imposed.  fourteen shafts pass into their ranks before their advance is stemmed.  The cost, fingertips nearly pealed away and a rib cage in pain akin to those on the road behind who have rolled beneath the hooves of their countrymen's steeds.  The chain of events to which they were so fiercely bound is finally severed.  At least until dawn when His Lordship's smiths will surely try to forge the links together again.  "They've backed away," She informs Karn, "lessen the stride.  Are you well?"
"No injury here milady, and the horses feel right.  Is there any water to be had?"
"Yes!  Hale, there are cups under the barrel.  Draw some water for this gentleman?"
"On the way dude."
"Do you know the bridge ahead where there are great piles of stone?"
"Yes!"
"It will take half the night, pace the horses to expire there.  I expect a friend with a fresh team.  Your password is 'if any stand nigh.'  His reply shall be 'to show the way home.'"  There's freshwater back here for the steeds if it's needed; you be the judge.
"Are you leaving us?" Karn inquires, more in jest than of true concern.
"I hope not, but if I don't lie down soon I'm going to drop dead.  If the light wanes, unlatch the top of the keg and pour a little water in.  These will keep you," she advises, handing him a couple of apples and a cocked crossbow.  Then taking a firm hold of his shoulder, she concedes, "Thank you for your patience."
"I am your man;" he concedes quietly.  Never doubt of it, milady."
She retreats into the straw to conference at executive level with Beth.  "You know all the clues.  You need to collect Art and figure this out."
"What!  Are you resigning?"
"I'm just trying to cover our ass; what if something happens?  There's no guarantee certain things don't happen.  You can't win the game every time--it wouldn't be fair.  Karn knows where Art is, and he knows his way around this town."
"I don't like the tone of this conversation, Leo."

Beth whimpers a bit.  "I've already done that... thank you."
"Hey, one more, this sword I've got, it's special.  Don't let it get lost.  Give it to Karn not Art; he's the best qualified to make use of it."  Finally, time to rest, perchance to sleep in spite of the aches and pains which have risen from every quadrant of her being.  Which of the three remaining cards did she draw?  For one at least, though her friends escape demands she does not wake.  The adrenaline subsides, the breathing softens, her eyes close, and she is soon away without a care.
Beth looks to her battered defender, then to Hale and begins to cry while pulling at the heavy leather collar lashed about her neck.  Hale hadn't even noticed it till now.  "Take it easy," Hale consoles, "you know Leo, she'll be all right.  What is that?  Hey, hey, be calm, Hon.  I'll get it off.  Turn around some, feels like there's buckles on the back."  Soon as Hale has loosened the straps she pulls it free and heaves it into the darkness.
"Don't ask," she anticipates.
Half the night passes before Hale and Beth have joined the slumber party--three babes cast adrift in a fantasy's dream.  Fortunately, Karn stays the course, pressing ahead into the endless darkness.  All the world has disappeared, gone, but for a cart and the 20 yards of road directly ahead.   Very cool the late night air, 50 degrees perhaps.  The chill keeps the team comfortable and the driver alert, now with time to wonder why this sorceress has pulled him from the grave.  Hunched-over old hags with raspy stinging words is all that's ever came to mind.  Never one so young, but certainly a force to be reckoned with.  The river surely nigh, for a heavy fog now shrouds the way.  A deception spawned of the cool evening air mingling with moisture trapped below the forest's canopy along the waterway.  Two great stone pillars with a broad hefty beam spanning across their tops rises in the mist ahead.  They appear as sentries to announce one's arrival at the bridge crossing from the lands of Mosheum into those allocated as the domain of Sorin.  He pulls the team to a halt midway upon the rickety old structure and unbuckles his seat belt.  By this none may spring upon them from the dark roadside while the cart stands at ease.  Lifted so above the roadway, the lamp's beam is an eerie sight to behold, cutting through the haze as some otherworldly force at his command.  Waters here are narrow, but swift and deep.  Stones piled thereabout have been gathered to construct new foundations--a public works project floundering in bureaucracy over how the costs should be shared among the cities.  Indeed, the foundation blocks have set for so long the intersection has come to be known as the stone piles.  Just beyond, the road divides, a branches branch running east and west as is the customary boundary for defining the border between any two cities.  A twenty yard wide swath of land which no man may own and no invader may cross that the Henzec's not come down upon their heads in a great furor.  The main road continuing northerly into the heart of Sorin.
Not knowing what or who to expect, Karn stands upon the seat with crossbow in hand and inquires to the darkness.  "If any stand nigh... come forth and be seen."  His confidence recently betrayed, his nature has taken a cautious turn of late.  With the extended seat back and side gate he would be a difficult target to define.
From the darkness, an answer, "Aye sir, ah traveler here."  Stick walks into view at the far end of the bridge shading his eyes from the beam of light. "Just taking ah nap till the dawn... ta show the way home."
Karn drops to the ground, the passwords having been properly exchanged.  Stick approaches from the far end of the bridge, his trusty hickory staff in hand.  Not the sort that cares to be noticed, he's appropriately attired in the darkest of browns and grays.  "Ya look familiar, sir.  May I inquire au ya name?"
"Karn Suirvol I'm called."

"I've seen you about the city.  Pleased to make your acquaintance, sir."

"There are many in our wake who would likely agree.  One in every six of His Lordship's garrison suffers from her wrath.  Unfortunately she also, as much of her own magic as those upon whom the spells are cast."
Stick confides in a very low tone of voice.  "Do ya make her out ta be ah witch, milord?"
"Don't know what she is, but if she sets her mind to something don't get in her way."
Stick withdraws a small torch from his belt and approaches the lamp.  Placing it in the flame's proximity, it alights.  "A flame it is, never seen ah fire so white."  He turns his attention back toward Karn and is somewhat startled to find that all has disappeared but the faintest image of his own torch's flame.  "I'm blinded... bewitched?"  He drops the torch and begins rubbing his eyes and blinking.

Stick strains to see the road as images of the city's blind beggars plague his thoughts.  Stooping to recover his torch, he admits, "I thought myself vexed.  In the back ya say, asleep ya say?"
 "I think she's been hurt inside.  There was a great uproar when the gate was brought down."

The original team has been most patient and deserving.  The heavy venetian blind protecting the exposed flank of one is cut loose. Good portions of oats and several apples are served up to each as reward for services faithfully rendered in the line of fire. Rolls of linen bandages, bulk cotton and soft pieces of leather make up the vast majority of her medical supplies.  The apothecary includes the potion given by the good brothers to soothe her shoulder, a red clay bottle of freshly distilled 190-proof fuel-grade moonshine--disinfectant that is, a pouch of powdered alum, a vile with several swigs of Mom's soothing elixir, a vial of iodine tincture, a small pot of salve Hemmil concocted from what she was able to tell him of Hale's knee injury and the assortment of remedies filched from the abandoned wagon.  The Alchemist's preparation exhibits the same nasal deadening aroma as the topical anesthetic which so kindly aided her battered shoulder.  Her operating theater is comprised of a small razor-sharp blade, a low quality dagger, several of the finest sewing needles she could find, cotton thread, and a pair of tweezers courtesy of the tinker who made her lamp.
She unties the lashing about Karn's arm and removes what remains of his shirt.  There's a mighty solid fellow under there along with an abundance of bruises and several impressive old scars.  None of the newer work appears more than superficially annoying.
The arm is another matter; someone has nearly cut a half inch thick slab of it free.  Fortunately the flesh is still attached by a healthy stump.  It has served as its own bandage, but severed to this extent it will be some time in the healing. But I can offer better odds you won't lose the arm or worse to blood poisoning if you'll let me disinfect and close it.  We have more trouble than we need, sir; it's foolish to risk more which may be avoided."
Thoughts of a friend taken with infection cross Karn's mind.  A simple nail puncture laid him to his grave, but not without his leg being sawed and sawed again three times.  It was a foul and lingering business.  Anguish throttles his voice, but he concedes.  "Do as you will, milady."
 Stick has returned from the riverbank with another pail of water.  "I'll start us ah fire and hold'em fer ya when ya ready.

Then, kneels behind Karn, reaching up from below to gain a firm grip of his shoulders.  Leona glances toward the thick blade, but says nothing.
Given the status of her fingertips, the repair will probably torment her no less than her principal ally.  A steaming damp cloth is first used to wipe the area clean. The damage appears clean and the cut smooth.  Fortunately the weapon had a well maintained edge. Fresh blood has emerged across the surface of Karn's wound, priming the surface.  she gently smoothes it closed again. Once dry she traces the cut's edge again with a smidgen of the narcotic save to deaden the edge.  Stitching flesh is different from sewing a colorful patch on the back pocket of your jeans.  The fabric of humans offers less resistance to the needle, and somehow, even were it not her own, she feels the pain.  The act itself creates a special obligation and first timers often feel a little queasy regardless of which side of the needle they're on.  Both men watch quietly as the wound it repaired.

"I'm afraid these fingers of mine are not going to allow me to bind it tightly.  Two laps of cloth, then once around with the leather and bind it tight. Blood flow begins anew with the removal of her boot, the dart slit a minor artery in the top of her foot near her toes.  Though the damage was minimal, once removed however, the projectile provided an open channel through her boot.  Any obstacle her sock may have offered was overwhelmed by her own system's desire to provide oxygen for muscles to facilitate her rapid activities at the time.  Had she not lain down and fallen asleep, reducing her metabolism, she might have ended quietly; no one the wiser till she failed to awake.  The second card she chose then touched kindly by the hand of fate.  Thus, even in parting Bird has served well; twice she's been unknowingly preserved by a scrap of compassion shown an orphaned egg.
Stick has set to work, placing Leona's finger over the wound to stay the flow while he cleans up the sticky mess she calls her foot.

She flushes the area with cool alcohol seemingly causing the wound to sizzle, dabs the bright red tincture thereabout and bids Stick bind it.  A thin piece of leather is added over the first lap to provide more of a fluid-tight seal that walking doesn't encourage flow.
Privately, she is concerned.  A puncture wound of this nature cannot be adequately disinfected superficially.  So, there is the chance of developing an abscess or gangrene, but they've done the best they could.
"Lots round here thinks blood is just ah nuisance," Doctor Stick advises, "like wasn't ah good reason fer it.  I know some cuts themselves when they get fevers, just lets it dribble away.  Not seen one of'em come ta ah good end yet."
"Your thinking's correct, I assure you."
"All ya need do is look around ah battlefield to see all the dead men's run outa it.  Ya'd think that would tell'em someum."
Working their way up, she rolls slightly on her hip to access the bite on the back of her leg.  She presumes the dog got a mouth full of iron bar along with leg or the wound would be much deeper than it is.  After it's cleaned, moon shine and iodine with a bit of salve to lessen the pain.
Catching a whiff of her disinfectant, Stick teases. "That potion of yours might serve ah man better ta drink than bathe.  What's it fer?"
"Helps keep things from spoiling.  Your patient will always fare better if you rinse a wound with the strongest spirit you can find.  I suspect even ale's better than nothing.  Consumed, it may dull the pain, but it thins the blood, causes it to run out faster.  I recommend chicken stew... with lots of onion and garlic."
"Good stuff, that!  But there's times when ah fellow's mind needs soothing, too.  Strange about ah dog's bite though, wicked as they be, more likely not to turn bad like cuts from a blade.  Lest the beast has the curse of foaming, none gets by that's bit by one ah them kind."
Fine cart ya have, had it made special I see.  Serving you well, too.  Thing about it, though... it has to follow a road and roads are easily followed, if ya get what I'm saying.  I 'spect we need ta tend that arm next."
"Yeah, good thing I'm right-handed, seems my left side's been the preferred target since day one.  Now I've whacked it again."  She pulls the soggy red sleeve back with great care.  The lead shot seems to have gone all the way through.  If there are any stragglers though, it's going to present a big problem down the road.  The wound has pretty much swollen closed and it hurts a lot more than her ribs.  Chances are the detonation heated the pellet well beyond the point where bacteria could survive.  It's cleaned, dowsed, dabbed, wrapped and bound.  Bless the brothers and their wonderful ointment.  Is this stuff great or what?
"Course ya know... the dawn is only 'bout three hours off," stick offers in the way of idle conversation.  "I fear ya gonna end up easy pickings once the sun rises.  Ya do realize... there's four horses at your disposal now?"
"I do, but there's no saddles and my friends have never ridden.  Even if we had the gear, at more than a trot they wouldn't make it.  I doubt I could myself against a good cavalry mount.  Craft and trickery is our ally not speed, sir.  We don't have the resources for head on conflict.  Besides, two of these animals are borrowed, are they not?  You did borrow them, right?"
"Yep, from ah friend," Stick assures.
"And I promised two good steeds in return."
"Yep, but things can get lost," He reminds.
"I would never ask you to deceive your friend."
"Thing about my friend is, he knows me, so he knows things can get lost."
"I appreciate your concern," she assures with a warm smile.
"I see, well then, off with ya shirt.  Let's hear if your insides sound right."
"Say what! just a minute there!"
"Wise as ya are in lots of ways, young lady, Um much older and wiser in others.  'Sides, ya just stomped all over Lord Karn on the same account.  What's good fer the gander is just fine fer the goose, too.  I need to listen close at ya breathing.  You're friends, if they loose ya, they're dead, and ya know it; so be still."
"Well... shit!" she concedes, knowing certainly there is considerable discomfort and propriety should be her least concern.  "How do you know my ribs are hurt, anyway?"
"Lord Karn told on ya.  He's just as concerned for you as you're fer em.  I've seen men was torn apart; I know what the bones under there look like.  Bad if one gets turned in on ya.  Do ya know the taste of blood?"  Leona nods affirmatively.  "Been any of that coming up?"  She nods again, but in the negative.  "Good sign."  Another nod in the affirmative.
"If a lung was punctured I'm sure I would know by now and there's nothing anyone could do about it anyway."
"Still ya should be listened ta," Stick insists, "'sides If there's a problem, knowing 'bout it is ah fair part of the cure, don't ya think."
"As Karn said, do as you will... but be aware, there are limits."  She pulls the shirt off.
Drat!  What's this?   Stick has never seen the likes of a bra before and being forewarned as he was, thinks it wise he neither inquire nor push his luck.  The purpose more than obvious, and this is after all a purely medical inquiry, right?  "Lie back now and relax if ya can."  He prods about, his fingertips searching where his eyes need not follow.  Indeed they're closed as not to cloud the issue.  "Breath in, fer as ya can without hurting."  He presses his ear against her side, one place then another while she draws in the refreshingly cool night air deeply but with caution.  "Ya sound right I'd say.  No bubbling or hissing, just banged up some and growling fer ya dinner.  Everything feels connected right, too.  Ya need bound up good an' firm so the rattling of your cart won't keep ya hurting.  Give things a chance ta settle in where they know they should be."
Selecting again the small leather-covered crock which provides the stuff of pure comfort, she massages a small portion of the salve over her ribs.  It feels exceeding pleasant upon her scorched fingertips too.
"What have ya there that ya seem ta like so much?"
"From the effect, I imagine it some form of narcotic.  Do you know the opium poppy in this land?"
"I do know of it," Stick admits, "but not personally."
"Yes, an unwise choice of recreations, but in small measure some preparations are a blessing, I think this is one."
"Ya should let me apply it for ya, for sure I'd be gentle as your own mother."
She cocks her head and returns a disapproving nod.  "I shall do fine, thank you."  His reply but a coy smile, as any old fellow caught at such folly.
She must yield before all is done, however, for he is the better of them to bind her up.  "Breathe in 'bout half way... hold it there while I wrap ya up.  Needs ta be firm, but not so much ta deny ya breath."  She soon finds herself swaddled round about with lengths of linen ribbon from the navel to her underarms.  Done carefully as a gentleman could and such as not to offend a lady's modesty.  "Be good if ya just lay still fer ah couple ah days."
"Yeah!  Be good if all hell wasn't coming down that road behind us in the morning, too.  I've gotta take care of Beth now, then we're out of here."
"Shouldn't we clean up some ah these scratches."  Stick asks wringing out a warm damp cloth, but Leona resists.
"They've clotted, better to just let them be.  I want to take care of the others and get moving."  With that pronouncement she begins to rise till Stick catches her ankle.
"Hold on, let's be sure if ya need ta run, ya can.  Lots a briers out there in the woods," he reminds.  "And your boot ain't ah fit place for that foot, 'least fer a while."  He slips one of the leather pouches he had used for provisions over Leona's bandaged foot, tying off the drawstring above her ankle.  Folding the excess from the sides underneath for support, he secures the bundle by crisscrossing several loops of a leather thong roundabout to fashion a forgiving but firm moccasin.  "This 'ill keep ya till the swelling down un it'll fit in ya boot again.  
"Nice! I like that."  She acknowledges her appreciation with a firm one-armed hug, at least as much as her ribs will permit.  "Thanks, I owe ya.  Someday you're going to get a nice check in the mail.  Beth... come around here," she calls out.  "Let's play doctor."
Beth bops into the light.  She's in very good spirits for a former can of dog food.  "Ummm, I like the top!  Can I get a pink one with sequins?"  Leona looks like she's headed to an audition for a part in the Invasion of the Teenage Mummies.  "I'd even settle for strips," Beth continues with a smirk.
"Just behave!"  Beth's hand is not a pleasant sight, she really got a wicked chomp.  If the animal hadn't clamped down on the iron bar it probably would have pulled her arm through.  There would have been no way to get her free aside from sharing her with the beast--which is to say, cutting her free by severing the arm.  Leona just stares at her dear friend's mangled hand for awhile.  It's such a small delicate thing.  "How's it feel?"
"Aches, especially my fingers," Beth confides quietly.
"I didn't know it was this bad.  Why didn't you say something?"
"Everybody's hurting!  You look like an advertisement for 'wife beaters anonymous'."
Leona flexes her jaw a little, "yeah, I know.  We'll deal with the cosmetic stuff later."
"I'm just glad we got out," Beth assures.  "Things are really looking up from a few hours ago."
The bite is cleaned and wrapped with the greatest of care along with a generous helping of Doctor Feel-Good's magic ointment.
"Send Hale back.  Keep an eye on that torch he's been watching for me."
Beth leans over the back of the wagon's seat and informs, "He says he's okay, Leo."
Leona is around back in a flash, but Hale cuts her off before she can start.  "I'm okay I tell ya.  My knee's not an emergency like you guys.  Rest of these dents don't even count.  Come on Leo, I've been getting along with this for two weeks now; couple more hours ain't going to make or break us.  You know that creep's not going to let it slide and it's not going to stay dark forever.  So let's get the hell out of here."
Leona emits a frustrating exhale.  "It's a good call," she affirms with a nod.  "Let's go."  She rejoins Karn and Stick.  "We've got to be off the road before the birds start to sing or we're going to end up sitting ducks."  Both her allies are quick to agree.  Leona gathers her medical supplies and recovers her soggy boot from the pail.  Water spouts from the hole in the toe, a gentle reminder people could get hurt around here.  "If nothing else," she muses to Stick, "I am learning a lot about the fugitive business."
"There's plenty more ta know if ya gonna make ah trade of it.  I think ya off ta ah bad start, though, having the whole of His Lordship's garrison coming fer ya on the first go." He chuckles.  
"You'll avoid the road I trust?  A fellow leading two horses along may be suspect of complicity."
"With all this commotion, last place I'd wanna be is anywhere 'tween you and Roux.  At dawn I'll cross the shallows and follow the deer, be home by night." 
"Thank you.  You've saved my friends and I."
"Any that's set their mind ta confounding that ass Roux is a friend of mine.  You be careful now."  He bows respectfully and leads the horses down the narrow forest road to scatter misleading implications along the way.  Soon he's just another moth cautiously finding its way in the night.
Karn's brought the cart around, the most direct rout to the Brobose Inn being the main road directly into Sorin.  Leona joins him on the driver's bench; his task the road, hers searching for a suitable exit.  They need to find an inconspicuous place to depart the road and be out of sight before the dawn.  Purses of silver will be dangled inspiring all to search out and inquire of strangers recently in the area.  And who would blame any that would point out these presumed villains to claim five year's wage or a stout team of plow horses?
At the first crack of dawn the cart's lamp is extinguished.  Were any to witness such a ghostly thing moving about the foggy countryside a great concern and speculation of its meaning would arise.  Authorities would surely be inquired upon to explain so strange a phenomenon, thus, attracting unwelcome attention to Leona's band of rebels.
They cross a shallow creek which appears as a black tunnel into the brush along the roadside, an excellent avenue to depart from the roadway that would leave not a sign to tell the tale.  Karn scouts the possibility only to discover the creek bed drops abruptly four feet into a narrow pond with no way to skirt it on either side, a course one could not hope to navigate with the cart.  The upstream fairs no better, that path blocked by a fence with open fields beyond and no place to withdraw.  Just as well perhaps, for an experienced search party would likely think the same and be drawn just as they were to such opportunity.  Young children also frequent such places in their endless search for tadpoles, crayfish and the ultimate prize, a brightly colored salamander.  Cooling their feet, the horses would like to stay longer, but time does not allow.
The forest thins to meadows and planted fields, at least so far as can be seen in the available light.  High with undisturbed grass or crops, their cart would leave tracks a blind man could follow if they depart the lane now.  First cock is heard to announce the day, and the faintest lamp lights may now be seen in the distance.  Time runs short against their favor.  The farm hands are at their morning due, bread and gruel served with milk for the lucky, perhaps even an egg for the headman.  Birds are beginning to accompany the courses rising from the hen houses as yet unseen, but surely near.
Pointing ahead to where several haystacks faintly rise against the horizon, Karn declares, "there! that field looks as if it's been cut.  Let's have a look.  Our tracks would be hidden in the stubble."  Sickle men have laid low a field of grain and wagon tracks crisscross in every way.  "This is good for us, none can tell who has gone where or when.  We need take leave of the road here and make haste for those hedgerows dividing the fields."  Leona agrees with a nod.  Their horses needing a bit more encouragement however as they are intent upon gleaning a snack from the debris.
In due time all are safely tucked away, lost within a thicket of stout young pines densely entangled of multiflora rose.  Any movements along the road are still clearly visible from their vantage point.  Concerned of nothing but greens to munch, the horses present their greatest risk.  They must be tethered and served a hearty breakfast lest they wonder into the open field and give up the thicket's secret.
Karn takes Leona aside.  "I'd be sizzling on the stake like a piglet about now had you not come to seek your friends.  I owe you more than I can repay."
"Sir... none would be here, if each hadn't played their part.  I was undone, my friends helpless.  Had you not led us away, we'd be there, swinging in the breeze to keep you company.  I dare say there's no debt between us that hasn't been faithfully paid.  In any event, I wouldn't have left you in that cage."  Each nods graciously to the other.  The current order of business: sleep and rest for the weary and wounded.

Chapter-13

OF WAYWARD RABBITS AND WICKED SQUILLETS;
 ALL BETH REALLY WANTS IS A BATH.

Midmorning finds Roux himself leading an expedition of a hundred and twenty brave souls followed by a coach and four.  Bringing up the rear is a caravan of supply wagons and another equipped with two shallow decks.  Pens in fact, filled with dogs: large dogs of bad temperament.  Last of the entourage is a flatbed wagon specially arranged to transport water barrels.  Several are lacking, in their place a small empty iron cage suitable at best for a single prisoner, two if properly packed.  The coach's passengers are a special lot: the court magician and his two apprentices, advisors in the black arts.  And one other, a consultant presupposed to have experience with a specific item His Lordship has recently misplaced.  Pious his attitude, most gruesome his expression, and so deathly pale of appearance his associates may not but wonder of his health if not his mission.  One of his hands has been replaced by a metal cap, a special socket fitted to its end for the attachment of certain useful tools.  Representing not so much the interests of politicians, as are the others, but rather having to do with the pecking order of forces divine.  His presence is in the nature of a replacement until a blind red lens shattered of late, which could see through the eyes of others, is refashioned and polished till once again it is sublime.
Assembled they are under the pretense of allies to counter devices a most wicked of perpetrators has cast in their various master's paths.  Two are charlatans, clever of words and quick of hand, no threat to any but themselves.  One however, is master of his trade, quite capable at the art of dispelling curses and like silent Pious, holding demons and illusions at his beck and call.  His ways are not of trickery, Escheloson his name, of his calling very proud, sorcery his game.
Their prized possession on this fine day is a leather pouch found at the Keep, curiosities both common and unusual there within.  It sits quietly but ominous in their midst upon the carriage floor.  One of those less talented would so love to tamper with its contents, thinking to discover some new trick to impress the ignorant, but he's been cautioned to hold his ambitions in check.
They are hardly upon their way before the call to halt is trumpeted.  The column approaches a clearing alongside the narrow forest road.  There, the results of last evening's farce are set out for display.  The wounded commander of the attempt to subdue the escapees approaches.  Four of his men lie quietly side by side.  Each has given up the most one could expect, their widows due a pension now.  While a host of others, various degrees of damage their lot, are tended by those lucky to have been near the rear of the column.  Horses wander around, some limping, others lying in the grass unlikely to rise again, dog food and glue presumably their future.
Quick to berate their failure, His Lordship growls, "A unit of my cavalry could not seize two wenches fleeing in a horse cart, how is that so?"
"They hath laid waste to our ranks, sire, four to their graves and eight to ruin.  Traps set in the field brought low those I sent to outflank their route."
"A trap?"  Turning to his commanders, he bellows with contempt, "You see, as I suspected, she has accomplices."
"Trip lines were hidden in the grass, milord."
Roux squints and tilts his head curiously.  "She anticipated your move?  No!  Impossible!  Her plans are too perfectly executed; no matter what flaw is cast into her path, still she succeeds."  The commanders all nod their agreement.  None but a fool would dare otherwise when accusations of this nature are in the wind.  "Again I say nay.  Only with spies to guide could she have prevailed.  There is conspiracy afoot.  I'll see every one of them to the gallows.  None have escaped my justice and this brazen witch shall not be the first."   Most of the able-bodied survivors are conscripted to fall in behind the others.  For none but those to be buried have earned a day's rest and leaving only the wounded to tend those soon to be dead.  At the call to advance they prance off at a fast trot into the forest.
"Someone should have asked how it was the Keep failed to restrain them in the first place," suggests one disgruntled fellow.
"Didn't you hear?  Spies were the culprits," comes a reply.  "When he gets back somes gonna get picked and condemned.  Upon their misfortune shall rest all the blame."
"Be doing just what ya was told, all'a sudden everything's wrong 'cause ya should'a knowed better.  Um if ya did it some other ways, is still your fault 'cause ya didn't listen to'em. "
"Well put, sir," his comrade commends.  "When it comes to pointing at others 'round here, justice is swift.  lot quicker than for folks getten caught red-handed."
"Right 'cause when it comes to blaming could be mistakes made, so they gotta chopem an burry'em quick."
And speaking of blame, whether earned or not, as such gruesome device may attest, were they privileged so, or as some condemned there also to go.  Finding their way to His Lordship's arena where a gown once lavish and white might be found.  Now shredded and stained of tears and thick syrup of reddish dark brown.  Locked away, out of sight, within a cage of iron, accompanied by the grizzly debris of an arrogant deplorable lass.  Dare you imagine the surprise when the royal consort was remanded, with not a servant for her needs to come round?  All her shoes lined up neatly in pairs within the cage where she was destined to be found.  Left in the dark, forlorn and alone, but for the uncaring ravenous hounds.  They to extract payment in blood for last evening's drunken clowning around.  
--
Quiet prevails around the brier thicket where early afternoon arrives before Karn begins to stir.  He ventures along the hedgerows for cover until he might slip into the wood, a crossbow for company.  With the cautious reserve of a fat wise old gobbler, he follows the downward slopes until finding a trickle of water.  Scooping out a hollow, he uses a cup to fill the pail for the horses.  By the time Leona has come round, the animals have been fed, watered and hitched, should need of a quick exit arise.  Sleep is a wonderful mechanism, but risky business for someone whose head is so much in demand.  She looks over the crew; light of day reveals them to be a battered bloody lot.  For her part, the shrapnel wound is sore as hell, but not seething as the night before.  Inhaling is a hurtful yet bearable business and shifting her weight to the heel of the injured foot relieves most of the discomfort rendered by the dart.  Combined with the dog's workmanship, however, suffice it to say she and Hale would not be much of a threat in a three-legged race.  There is still considerable resentment in her back as well.  She twitches and torque's her shoulders and hips several times, but no tingling or numbness arises.  As any concerned feline, she takes account of her litter.  "Beth, your hand, how is it?"
"Okay, really great compared to before."
"Can you feel it?" Leona inquires further.
Beth nods, "Oh yeah, but it's not pulsating like it was."
Leona motions Karn to come near.  Little doubt of her purpose, he volunteers his arm for examination, the bandage is still clean.  "And you, sir?"
"Much better; and you, milady?"
"Sore as hell, still a little dizzy.  But I think I'll survive if my boot will just dry out.  Hale!"
"Present and accounted for, chief, hanging in there."
Leona lowers her gaze, a sigh of relief accompanying her voice.  "Boy! What a day that was."
"Yes!"  Karn adds with a measure of local insight.  "I am truly bewildered of how we have come away so much intact.  And we must take care not to be seen or heard if we wish to remain so.  Stay low as you go about.  The crops been harvested so there is no need fro anyone to come back in this area, but if any of the field hands notice movement here, they may take a notion there is game to be had.  We would soon have the company of bowmen.  And there is sure to be a fine purse offered for our hides."
"Not to be discouraging," Leona intercedes quietly, "but can anyone say for certain we're not surrounded?"
Beth answers up proudly, "Hale and me have been taking turns on look-out ever since you guys crashed this morning."
"They have indeed, milady," Karn attests, "until just now when you woke."
"Sorry... I didn't mean to bark."
Beth cringes, "don't say bark, any other word but that.  Listen, you guys definitely need a little more clean up work.  You all look like you've been in a gang fight, you know.  So I'll be the look-out, okay?"  She takes Leona aside, quietly confiding.  "His leg is really getting bad.  He won't admit it, but I can tell when he's hurting."
"I've got some stuff should help."
"Thanks, I really do need him."  Beth slinks off into the brush toward the edge of the field to keep watch.
Leona motions that Hale should join her, he replies with a salute and hobbles forth.  "Karn, can you bring another pail of water?  And I need you to find some saplings, something strong and flexible, about a dozen the thickness of your little finger.  There's a small saw in the chest.  It'll be quieter if you use that to cut them."
The clumsy splints that had been tied about Hale's leg for support were lost during the battle of the Keep.  Over the course of events their edges had thoroughly abraded his ankle and thigh.  The superficial damage is cleaned and bound with a trace of the brother's topical painkiller.  "Holly cats! is that stuff quick."
"Isn't that the truth!" Leona agrees.  Wish I knew where to find more."
"My old coach would kill for a case of that," he assures.  "Oh man that's nice, what is it?"
"No idea, but I don't wanna try it on your knee yet, might make it too numb.  I've got something else a friend mixed up specially for you.  Combining them could bring on a reaction.  So let's go with the other stuff for now and see how you feel."  His leg is swollen and contorted around the joint; it doesn't look good.  She applies a generous helping of Hemmil's concoction and loosely wraps the area to keep it clean.  She binds the covering above and below the joint to keep it in place.  Slips of leather are applied over the bandages about his ankle and thigh, then a trellis constructed of the saplings lashed around his leg.  The arrangement is such that the saplings will bind against the leather slips when he stands, bypassing the knee.  This, taking more of the weight directly to his more qualified ankle.  All in all, quite an intricate construction including several crossbow darts for ready access if there is a fire fight.
 Hale's face is not nearly as battered as Karn's.  A pair of black eyes aside, most of the damage is to his left ear and cheekbone area.  During the clean up, some of the alcohol finds its way to his lips.  "Um, where'd you get the moonshine?"
"Made it, took almost two gallons of local Thunderbird."
"Leo, that's pure sweet white lightning!  Is it hard to make?"
"Be quiet, I'm trying to concentrate.  Don't you dare even think about drinking it either," Leona warns.  "It's strictly for medical use, understand?  I need your brain between your ears not somewhere off in the breeze?"
"Beth won't let me have anything but beer these days anyway, we made a deal."
"Then she knows what's good for you.  I hope you're paying attention."
"Yeah, I guess.  I came around to pick her up one night, me and some buddies, we were wasted, man."  He snicker's under his breath at the recollection.  "She beat the feathers out of me with a broom.  I mean really hard, too, broke the handle.  The guys never let me forget it either."
"I'd like to have a picture of that," Leona chuckles.  "There you go, dude.  You job is to lay still and let that goop do whatever it does.  We're outnumbered, and outgunned and we don't have home court, so we need everything we can get working for us, including your leg."
"Leo Nightingale and Mary Elizabeth the Terrible:" Hale muses, "the rock and the hard place."
"Behave!  This is serious deep shit.  Every time you try to stand you're going to strain that joint."  Her attention shifts, she motions for Karn to join her.  "I know you guys aren't going to care for this, but it's for the best.  Hale, anytime you need to get on your feet, I want you to call on Karn to help you up.  We've got to keep the pressure off your knee so it will heal.  Mobility is our only defense and right now you're not very mobile.  I don't want you doing anything someone else can do if it involves that knee.  Any questions?"  The lads look to each other, then silently to Leona.  "Good!  You and Beth will sleep in the cart.  The level of the tailgate will allow you to sit on the edge and swing around to get in and out, understand?"  Leona retrieves his crossbow and sword from the cart.  "You know what they tell soldiers in the army about their rifle?"  Hale's presents only a blank expression.  "these are your new best friends.  Where you go, they go, always."
Attention shifts to her principal ally and second in command.  "You sir, are next.  Settle down right here.  One of our number need be able to mingle with the local folks.  For supplies, to find out what's going on, someone who knows how to talk the language.  We do not; that leaves you."
Karn looks to Hale for some insight, Hale just smiles back.  "Pay attention," she continues, "if duty calls you must be ready, nice and neat, at least so much as possible."  Now with the loving care of his own sweet mother she cleans up the abrasions his face accumulated while vacationing at the Keep.  Those flowing anew are stemmed with a dab of alum.  He squints a bit with the sting of it, a sure sign of life.  "Take off your shirt and coil it around the top of your head."
"Why?"
"When are you going to stop arguing with me?  Your hair is a bloody mess; it's got to be soaked.
