Unless you want to stand on your head in the bucket for an hour, it's the only way I can see to get it cleaned up."  His expression betrays the image crossing his mind.  "Haven't you noticed all the flies whirling about?  If you get any staler they may consider raising families on your head, and we don't want that, do we?"
"No, milady."  He complies; attended by some embarrassment at her suggestion he's attracting insects.  The Lord of Orchard is a strong solid fellow, about the same weight as Hale, but with 20 pounds of it across his chest and arms instead of under his belt; he probably doesn't watch as much TV.
Karn notices Hale flip an expended apple core aside.  He catches his attention and motions he should join him.  "Lad, have you been casting them apple parts out of the wagon as we was coming along last night?"
The implication suddenly dawns on him, "Probably, two or three."
"We must leave no clue of our coming and going, lad.  It's very important."
"Just wasn't thinking.  Sorry.  That was the first one today, here I mean."
Karn retrieves the spent core.  "Every trace must be buried or carried away with us."
"Got it... every trace."
"You've got to think of this as a murder mystery," Leona adds.  "Everybody's looking for clues, okay?  Now get into the cart and take a nap.  You'll catch the late watch."
"It's daylight!"
"I know, but you can't stay up all day and half the night too.  Get in the shadow of the sideboard and cover your head, whatever!  Just go to sleep."
Karn perceives he has stepped out of place, turning to Leona apologetically.  "I'm sorry, milady.  He was your charge.  I should have informed you of my concern and allowed you address it."
"I think we can dispense with the milady, it's a bit formal given our circumstances.  I answer better to Leona, or Leo, if you like.   We're in this as equals, you and I at least.  There's no chain of command."  She pours water enough over his head to soak his shirt then hands him the cup.  "Another cup every few minutes and work it around some.  When it's empty, draw us a full pail."
"Yes mi... Leona."
When all is said and done, Karn's cover girl make-over has failed.  He still looks a battered mess.  Considerable swelling and subsurface discoloration remain; only several weeks time will bring his face up to par.  Leona shakes her head.  "That's the best I can do; it's an improvement, but you still look scary.  I imagine anyone you approach would suspect you're a fugitive or run, thinking you professional brawler."
She wobbles her jaw from side to side and feels about with care.  "The side of my head doesn't feel too swift, how's it look?"
His expression pretty much confirms her suspicions.  "Fair as you are, milady... Leona, at the moment it seems you've been in quite an altercation."
"Yeah, I thought so.  I earned a loose tooth back in the guard shack; Hale's all beat to shit, too.  Beth is the only one who's halfway presentable and her clothes have survived the best.  Okay, you're going to have to tutor her.  She will be our spy while the rest of us hide behind her smile."
"I'm sure Lady Beth could extract whatever she desires from any country lad crossing her path."
"Oh yeah, she could do that all right.  Trick is to see it's done without seeming out of place, as a foreigner might."
"I understand."
She leaves Karn to his soaking, moving off toward the edge of the thicket in alongside Beth.  "What's up, anything moving around out there?"
Beth points.  "There was a couple people way up on the edge of that second hill for a while.  And I saw some bunnies over there, but mostly just blackbirds pecking around."  She strains a bit to look around Leona; Karn's physique has caught her ever-wondering attention to the male of the species.  "Hummm, lots of muscle.  Nice and furry, too--a teddy bear."
"Don't you start!  Hale's got enough grief, and we--"
"Cool it.  I was thinking of you--this is a double date, isn't it?  Wonder what he'll look like when all the scratches and bumps heal up?"
"Damn good actually!" Leona admits, not cute like Art, but never mind.
"Ohhhh, you've met before.  I'm glad to see you're still paying attention.  How old do you think he is?"
"Bethhh... get real will ya?  We have other priorities.  He's part of a game, remember?  At least I hope so."
"Well then, what have ya got to lose?"
"What?  I said it's a game.  Do you know something you're not telling me?"
"Not really, but didn't you ever have a dream about something you knew you shouldn't do?  But you knew it was a dream," she glints, "so you did it anyway?"
"Stop it!  Gimmy a break, will ya?"  Everybody's together on this, like some kind of conspiracy.  That's what happened to Art.  It's seductive this place, and he wants to stay.  Like you can do whatever you want without consequence.  I love to blow things up--I've wanted to do that so bad.  I'm getting pulled in, I want more, but it hurts too, and it's so dangerous if you're in the wrong place at the wrong time.  What if I could find the right place at the right time?  If I didn't hurt so bad would this be fun?  It's got to be a game, fantasy fulfillment in spades.  Is that good or bad?
"Leo... you still here?"
"Huh?  Yeah!  Forget it!  Right now, I just want to finish this game, or whatever.  Soon as I've got Karn cleaned up, he'll relieve you.  I'll be sending him back without his shirt; don't you dare say anything about teddy bears."  
Beth snickers with an impish smile.  "Ah come on.  Bet ya a dollar I can make him blush."  
"Behave!  We need to get some antiseptic on your knees and clean up the scratches and that cut on your forehead."
"I still don't believe you did that," Beth confides gravely.  "Next time you're going to have a William Tell moment let me know first."
"Wasn't much choice, I'm just glad you didn't flinch; it would have been hard to explain to Hale."  Beth returns a very profound expression.  "Karn's going to start teaching you the local accent; we need you to drop out of Atlanta and join the Middle Ages.  You're going to be our secret agent."
"Mata Hari!" she squeaks with delight, "sounds fun."
"Right! but when she got caught they put her in front of a firing squad and shot her, remember?"  With that sobering thought Leona returns to the salon, rinses out Karn's hair, dabs iodine on his assorted lacerations and orders up another pail of water to soak his shirt.  A general's work is never done.
Once Karn's returned to duty, Beth's remaining scrapes are doctored.  Knees and elbows not withstanding, Beth attempts the more severe scuffs Leona has earned for her efforts.  The abrasions to the side of her nose and the area around her cheekbone will require weeks to heal.  "Ya got some great colors here," Beth informs sarcastically, referring to the bluish green and reddish purple side of Leona's face, acquired in memory of the guard shack incident.  "Leo, that's the best I can do with what we've got," Beth implies sadly.  "Sorry, but all kidding aside, you look like you've been in a demolition derby without your seat belt."  Beth glances at Hale then back to Leona.  "This is crazy" she relents, "if I had a cam-corder we could make zombie movies."
Leona takes hold of Beth with a gentle hug.  "Okay, I know things look bad, worse than they really are I think, but we're hanging in their.  Everybody's fixed up and it will be dark soon so we can move on and collect Art.  I hope he's staying out of trouble."
"Why didn't he come with you?" Beth wonders aloud.
"It started out that way, but he got tangled up in some other obligations.  Hope I can afford to bail him out."
"What'd he do?"
"Just being Art, you know.  He's not in jail exactly, not like you guys were.  Friend of mine's looking after him.  Believe me, it's for the best.  I'm going to try and get back to sleep now.  Take over the watch again and send Karn back here; he needs to get some zzz's too.  I expect it'll be another all nighter on the road."
So as not to disturb the crew's positive momentum, Hale has silently harbored several pressing questions, but they're beginning to bubble to the surface.  "Has anybody eaten in the last couple of days?  Can we catch a fish or something?"  Beth immediately gives him a swat.  "Does anybody know anything about roots or mushrooms?"  He pleads.  "How about this stuff the horses are eating, what is it, can it be cooked or something?"
Leona comes to his rescue.  "I'm sorry, buddy, I completely forgot.  I did bring some basic stuff."
"You mean food?  Real food, not just apples... and you forgot!"  He turns to Beth with a quiet desperate tone.  "She forgot!  What is it about women and food, you just don't care... do you?"
Beth whacks him on the arm again.  "I knew it, I did.  Here we are, number one on the FBI's most wanted list, hiding in the weeds for our lives and still, all you can think about is food."  She appeals her position to Leona.  "I swear," she points, "he's put half that bushel of apples away already."  Focused once more upon Hale.  "You know, it wouldn't hurt a bit if you lost a few pounds."  Hale frowns!  Swinging her attention to Leona again, "look at him... he was just starting to slim down some."  She pats his tummy with the back of her hand.  "But now he's full of applesauce."
Hale dares to beg for some slack, though he knows Beth will grant none.  Their ongoing verbal food fight is the equivalent of whispering sweet-nothings to each other.  "Hon, those apples are the only eatable thing I've seen since we got busted."
"Don't Hon me, if it came down to a bologna sandwich or yours truly, you'd be full of bologna."
Leona snickers.  Come hell or high water Beth shall never relent.  It's a long story going back to a certain infamous wager made when they first met.  "Okay guys!  I'll fix something, but keep it hush, we don't want to screw up now."
The conversation has caught Karn's attention.  Glancing back toward his charges, he notices Leona has retrieved the pot from the cart.  He abandons his post for a moment to caution, "Would you have a fire?"
"I need to boil water."
"Scrap out a pit, be sure it is well concealed.  The light of day will not hide the smallest flame among these shadows.  Start it small and tend it carefully.  Only grass enough for tinder, leaves and small twigs will crackle too much.  Country folk have very keen noses; smoke from places where it should not be is always their concern.  And no meat into the pot, country dogs have even keener noses.  They know where there is the scent of cooking there are usually table scraps to be begged."  Though they mean us no harm directly we dare not be seen by the local folk, strangers are always remembered and Roux is counting on that to find us."
Boiled rice, beans and bread solid enough to be used as building blocks are welcomed by all, along with an apple of course.  Though the fare is nearly tasteless but for a hint of salt, 'tis a banquet fit for deposed nobles, wounded rogues and slave girls alike.
Mid-afternoon finds Hale scraping up the last bean of his best ever Thanksgiving banquet while His Lordship's troop column arrives at the stone piles.  The trackers dismount, several taking to foot on each branch of the intersection for signs of the escapee's route.  Though the drops of blood from Leona's foot were a hundred yards apart, Roux's hounds have had no difficulty following the trail which began when more liberal quantities were discovered within the prison yard.  This is not to suggest however that Hale's enticement of freshly abandoned apple cores was insufficient.  The remainder of the troops are permitted to dismount providing a welcome opportunity to stretch and relieve oneself.  Those investigating the branch east along the water route soon come upon scraps of bloody cloth, oats and piles of dung so fresh they are still slight warm within.  By this, identifying the position of their quarry's temporary field hospital.  Dogs howl as they frantically sniff the area where Stick disposed of the bloody rinse water.  Their enthusiasm so intense as to suggest a fresh shallow grave may be near.  Such clues are most welcome as much of the area adjacent the watercourse has been stripped of soil over the years by floods exposing near solid rock, a less than ideal surface for the detection of tracks.  His Lordship's pleased with their presumed escape route.  Taking his troops along the border's edge unannounced is less likely to stir attention than marching straight way into Sorin's open countryside which might be misconstrued as an invasion.  Perhaps by this the diplomatic formalities and anticipated bribes may be avoided.  A hundred yards further along the hounds discover additional fragments of Karn's blood-stained shirt.  One animal suddenly lets loose a frantic tirade when its nose is slashed by a razor-sharp broad-head, dried blood thereupon so fresh the ants still labor to carry it away.  Extracting a broad-head often renders the injured party a serious liability to his comrades.  Relishing the thought one of those he seeks has been seriously wounded, Roux assembles his squad commanders and orders the troops, as the escapees had hoped, to advance eastward along the watercourse.
Unfortunately one of the scouts following the route directly ahead of the stone piles has returned with conflicting data, one of Hale's fresh infamous apple cores.  Thus, a sour note rises from the orchestra pit as the senior tracker attempts to point out, cordially as possible, the deficiency's of Roux's judgment.  "Milord," another  suggests graciously, "imprints in the soil at the prison would say the cart's wheels had iron bands like those of a carriage."  Stooping down, he points to faint though fresh grooves in the exposed shale.  "Now see here these marks on the stone, these say a cart with iron rims recently turned about on this very spot."  Roux dismounts and joins his commanders who have gathered to view the evidence.  	"Milord, we know this wench is no fool," the senior tracker reminds.  "Why then all of a sudden would she be so careless?" he asserts cautiously.  "I feel there are too many vivid indications pointing us to the east, that they were contrived to lead you astray.  With the discovery of this, in plane sight on the road well into Sorin"  holding up the apple core, "I feel she intended you consider the evidence she knew the hounds would detect leading eastward a falsehood.  The core a clever ploy to draw you forward into Sorin with confidence.  But, I beg you recall, she sets traps.  And this," again raising the apple core to view, "has also the scent of a trap, milord.  I think she actually went east, that the apple is a trick."  The commanders cautiously glance to one another, yet remain silent on the topic.  Privately, Roux is stunned at the prospect that even with 120 lancers at his beck and call anyone might dare to plot a strategy of this depth.  And so with the careless abandonment of an apple core, Hale has covertly confounded Roux's confidence yet another notch.  
Pious the Pale's patients with the military's time consuming and pretentious investigation has been exhausted.  He exits the coach calm as death itself and presents himself forthwith to this twittering assembly of self-absorbed administrators.  "Why do we delay?"  Pious questions in a slow deep authoritative voice.  "The witch is no longer here, she has gone straight way into Sorin."  With that he turns about and walks slowly back to the coach.
Roux watches Pious's exit but says not a word.  Nor do any of his commanders dare a comment.  He does not appreciate having his command supremacy bypassed so to speak, as has just been the case, but this ghoul comes very highly recommended.  "It appears our preeminent advisor agrees with the scouts assessment." Roux concedes, "we proceed directly into Sorin immediately."
The men mount up and align themselves four abreast.  Those having witnessed firsthand the carnage their quarry had wrought at the Keep begin to speculate of their future rather than rejoice of this supposed good fortune.
--
After brunch Leona reminds solemnly.  "The worst is over, I hope, but we need to be very careful.  This Roux character has a lot of resources and I blew his creditability all to hell.  No one in his position can afford that, so he's going to be looking for us in a big way.  From now on, anytime we're stationary, like now, if you're not sleeping you need to be watching.  I think it's best Karn and I take the night shift, so you guys have got it till dark.  Beth, you relieve Karn; keep an eye on the road and the woods to your left.  Hale, you've got the right flank; watch the field in front and the hollow along this side."
Karn joins the cook for his turn at the buffet.  "This place you call Sorin?" Leona inquires.  "Will he follow us across the border?  Are there any rules or restrictions, I mean are we any safer here?"
"No!  Crossing borders affords us no sanctuary.  In such matters the Lords offer mutual courtesies to each other.  Gold will pass from one hand to another and notice of his intentions forwarded to the first principal city.  An envoy will join his ranks to assure he does not hang any citizens of Sorin without good reason."
"Good reason... how kind."
"As long as appropriate fees are paid, mind you, without good reason is not out of the question.  Roux will think this route is chosen to secure the support of friends or family, someone duty-bound to shelter you.  Any here even suspected of your acquaintance are at great risk."
"There are a few at the Inn.  They've taken care to remain in good standing and I hold it not against them.  Roux?  I've heard that name mentioned before.  Would that be the same as His Lordship?
"Yes, Roux of Arigon he was, now Lord of Mosheum he is.  When he crosses into this land he will send an envoy to the House of Sorin.  In turn word will be sent back to all of authority that his presence is welcome here and under what circumstance each of us may be redeemed for value."
"Circumstance?"
"Dead or alive; I suspect you at least are worth much more alive.  Surely the pains of your dying are a pleasure he reserves to himself."
"I'll keep that in mind."
"None have even attempted to invade the Keep; to even speak of such an event would have a fellow to the gallows.  Breaching his stronghold, then, taking his prisoners as you did, such trespass is unpardonable, beyond redemption.  Pity those he suspects would not have kept that secret.  They probably stood in my place this morning.  The rest of us matter little, but you, milady, you do not want to be taken alive.  Do you have poisons?"
"Those I had were lost at the Keep."
"When we return for your man, I know people there; I'll secure a measure for you."
"No need to go out of your way on that.  I'm not planning to end by my own hand."
"Why then did--"
"If things went awry I wanted at least an alternative to offer my friends.  What of you?" she inquires softly.  "When we first met you seemed well in charge of your future."
"A rebel concealed in plain sight I was; now a rebel in hiding I am.  My lands confiscated, given over to the fellow who told the tale.  Now with this, there will be troops posted to assure I do not exact vengeance upon that scoundrel, though yet I may."
"Try and get back to sleep.  I'd like to put as much space as I can between us and Mr. Roux again tonight."  It seems her eyes have no sooner extinguished the light than she's being prodded.  It's Beth, her expression a work of urgency, a finger across her mouth pleading for silence and caution.
"They're here," she confides in a panic, "coming right down the road!  A whole army!  All this 'cause I whacked some bastard with a shovel?  It's too extreme, Leo... and they started it."  There seems no rest for the wicked nor weary, at least not so in the games they now play.
"Calm down; wake Karn."  Leona slinks off toward the thicket's edge.  The convoy slithers along as a giant brightly colored snake, preceded however by a pack of enthusiastic hounds in place of the serpent's flickering tongue.  Diligently they search, sniffing at every bird dropping and beetle for any hint of what they've come to know as the scent of her blood.  Soldiers and officers alike, all very prim, proper and polished with lances held high and banners trailing nicely in the late evening breeze.  Appearing as more of a spectacle meant to impress than a posse searching for rogues of the state.  Several riders break away at an accelerated pace toward a group of cottages and barns nestled in a shallow valley half a mile ahead.  Appropriate advance notice must be rendered to set at ease any concerns the citizens of Sorin might otherwise conjure.  No cause for alarm good friends, their banners could as well proclaim.  Be at ease, an invasion 'tis not.  The others perps. ease in alongside Leona to enjoy the spectacle for what it's worth.  "Impressive," she admits, "Lots of PR." 
Karn does little to console their fears.  "I had hoped if they were coming at all they would arrive sooner.  This could be an unfortunate turn of events."
"Dare I ask why?" Leona inquires with some reservation.
"Light of day is nearly gone.  I suspect they will need all that remains to set up camp for the night.  That field would be ideal."
Sure as it were his wish, the command to halt may be heard as it's passed back along the column.  The ranks break up and turn into the newly cut field.  By the time they've settled in hardly 200 paces separate the hunters from their game.
"Oh no!"  Beth laments.  "Tell me they're not moving in."
"Their first order of business will be to start the cook's fires.  Wood is needed," Karn explains regretfully, "and there is none to be had in that field.  Our concern is which direction will they choose to seek it out.  If we try to separate the team and hide them in the wood, I fear the commotion would betray us.  It might be wise to get Hale into the cart.  If they come this way we must run for it."
"It's too early," Leona laments.  "Last evening's ruse cannot be repeated.  I haven't enough arrows to hold them off till dark, nor are there fresh horses waiting, they would run us to ground."  Beth looks to Leona for some assurance of their future.  She is silent for the moment; the options are few.  "Shit!  You're right," she concedes with a heavy sigh.  "We would run.  Hale, work your way back to the cart, keep low; Beth you too.  Gather up anything that's been left lying around."  She waits until they are off near the cart, then, addresses Karn.  "Listen well, for I have a situation.  On the one hand, nothing really matters, but on the other, so to speak, I have not the right to drag you down with us.  If you wish to take your chances separate from ours, I have no problem with that, but I cannot spare you a horse."
Pointing over her shoulder, he conveniently avoids the subject without comment on her proposal.  "There, the wagon with several men crossing the road.  They have chosen in our favor."
"I can't believe we just sat here till they caught up and now they're moving in next door."
"Your team could have gone farther than this, but not for the entire day.  A man upon a good mount is not nearly the burden we are; you cannot win a race with your cart.  Remember, one dart strikes either of those good steeds, the chase is over and you lost.  Had we continued, everyone would have known of our passing.  The only thing raising more speculation than who has been seen with whom to hide in the loft is the presence of strangers.  'Tis more of value I think that none may point saying we have gone a certain way than to delay and hide here as we did.  What you've done was the wiser choice, I assure you."
"If only we weren't bound to this cart; the roads are as much my enemy as that bastard Roux... But those two can't ride; I've no other course."
"Dismay not, I've never seen anything better suited to its task than this cart of yours," Karn compliments.  "Listen now... dogs always take note of foxes or coons in the night.  On that account, the sentries will expect some commotion from them.  Thus, we might slip away... very slowly.  Once down the lane beyond their sight, you may light the way and we are off undetected.  We backtrack to the bridge and take the longer route to your friend.  Had they passed earlier, this nuisance would have been spared to us, but then they would have been in our path.  With no way for us to know exactly where until we came upon their camp in the dark and your lamp would have forewarned of our arrival, we would have been trapped.  Either way, the only safe route is back, and better now for we know where they are."
"There really wasn't much choice then?"
"I think not."
"I've one more killing device.  If I could sneak into their camp and finish with him, would the others give it up, go home?"
"You would never get past the dogs; they would pick you out, of this I'm sure."
"I saw only 6 or 8 leading the way, if all are all kept--"
"See the farthest wagon there behind the coach?" Karn cautiously points.  Those are cages full of dogs.  There are always dogs, lots of dogs; fast, expendable, obedient, and fearless--the perfect soldier."
"You just ruined my day," Leona dismays quietly.
"Every dog will know each and every man in the camp.  They take turns feeding them to that end.  See the stakes they're driving now?  Those I suspect are to post the hounds around the perimeter, a first line of defense.  Precautions of this sort are more common to a military encampment; you should be honored.  Whatever it was you did it weighs heavily upon his thoughts."
"I've never considered myself the sort to give someone nightmares, but I can think of no one more worthy.  Why the rope between the wagons? 
"It appears they dare to render us a further service.  Normally mounts would be kept in the midst of the compound so as not to be harmed or stolen.  Apparently, they've determined we don't present threat of an outright attack.  Looks to me he's chosen to exclude them.  There are no trees in the field, so I suppose it a leash line to steady the mounts.  That will place them between us and the camp.  Our greatest enemy is those hounds."
"Yeah I know, I've had some problems with his pets."
"The horses would not sleep well with the dogs too near; hence they will be kept back further from this side of the camp.  The mounts will shuffle about all night, their tramping will conceal our movements and the dung will confound our scent.  There will be sentries, but they are not near so keen as the dogs would have been."
"How long will it take, the other route?"  Leona asks.  "I've only enough feed for one more day."
"I know of several out-of-sight meadows along the way for grazing.  It can be worked out.  And there's a hunting lodge, if no one's there we might spend a night or two in fair comfort."
One of the dog handlers has approached the encampment's edge with several of his charges in tow.  He's kneeling, apparently leashing one of the hounds to a stake; the others left to sniff about unattended.  One of his crew lets loose a loud whining howl and bolts into the field, three others are quick to follow.  The handler immediately calls out, two turn back instantly upon his command.  He resorts to a whistle for further encouragement.  The third breaks off the chase and returns as well.  All are greeted with enthusiastic affection.  Undeterred by his master's wishes, however, the first one away continues to charge forward.
"Why is that son of a bitch coming straight for us?" contempt and anxiety both flavoring her inquiry.  The dog continues howling as it advances in their direction.  Several others at the camp are prancing back and forth, straining upon their conscience as though they might join the renegade at any moment.  Suddenly a hare perks up from the stubble and sprints away.  Naturally it makes for the thicket, its only hope of eluding the hound.
"Damn it, I knew that bunny would come back to haunt me."
"Get your bow!" Karn entreats.  "If that bastard comes through here, it's got to be cut down fast."
The rabbit leaps into the thicket, the hound's glaring jaws just moments behind.  Caring of nothing but an exit route, the hare scoots under the cart and off into the forest beyond.  The hound is taken totally by surprise, stopping dead in its tracks at the sudden revelation the brushwood is occupied.  Karn cannot take a shot without seriously endangering the horses.  Leona has dropped to one knee, she makes a deep gruffy sound.  Only four yards away the animal accepts her challenge.  Turning from Karn to fix its eyes upon her and lowering it's stance to attack, it begins to growl.  Her arrow goes straight down the mongrel's throat, slashing through vitals literally from head to tail.  Reflex causes the dog to leap forward about a yard.  The animal wheezes violently, but unable to produce any sound of consequence, it silently expires.  Another arrow's at the ready.  "Are any more coming?"
Karn's attention shifts back toward the field, he motions her to calm.  The other dogs have remained obedient.  No one seems to have taken further notice of the event.  Soldiers are leading groups of mounts and securing them to the ropes strung between the wagons as Karn had suspected.  Others are feeding and watering the animals, tents begin to appear, and the cook's fires are beginning to smoke.  Their antagonists are settling in for the night.
"Will they come looking for it?" Leona asks.
"No!  They wouldn't waste time searching for a disobedient dog.  If it did come back they'd probably poison it.  Just one like that could lead the entire pack astray."
Beth has tears in her eyes.  She's holding onto Hale and sobbing quietly.  "If we ever have a pet it's a goldfish, you hear me?  That's it," she snaps, "nothing with teeth."
"Okay," Hale consoles.  "It's okay!"
"No it isn't" she reminds with a sniff, pointing toward the encampment.  "There's a hundred more of those damned things right there."
"I've never wished ill upon any helpless creature till just then," Leona admits sorrowfully.  "I'm glad the bunny got away though and I hope this sets my obligation to rest."
By the time the sun has met the horizon, three large tents have risen in the midst of Roux's encampment.  The grandest, including a private bath, is assembled of orange and yellow strips and surrounded by many banners of black and golden brocade, no doubt His Lordship's humble abode.  Five yards adjacent sits another suited to the officers, a large table at the center displaying maps of Sorin.  The last, but a few yards further to accommodate the advisors, or sorcerers if you please.
They've found no indication of their quarry's passing since the contrived debris discovered at the Sorin border.  Pious presents himself yet again at the command tent.  New revelations raise the tension a bit as Rueshaba's morbid drone advises ever so slowly.  "I feel the one you seek is but a stone's throw from where we stand, milord.  Only darkness veils their presence.  But, if you seek them out now, as before, they may slip into the night.  But once the new day has come they we be helpless against so many.  Prepare now, at crack of dawn be ready!"
Turning to the captain of the watch, Roux inquires.  "How many stand the guard?"  
"Eight pairs man the perimeter, four the watch on your quarters, sire, and four to guard the mounts, including myself 25 total, milord."
"We came away with a 120 at arms and gathered, was it nine from the cavalry?"
"There were eight came on to join our column, sire.  We have 127 men and we seven not including 12 wagon masters and cooks, the court wizards, and of course our honorable guest."
"Aside from the last watch, 103 at arms then.  Every man shall be in the saddle ready at the crack of dawn.  Eighty men to go forth then; Twenty and a commander to each quadrant of the camp... teams of two.  Each spreading outward in a different direction around the entire perimeter.  How many dogs have I?"
"Thirty nine, milord," comes the answer from his senior tracker.
"Perfect, one then for each team.  The 23 who remain and one of you shall stand here as a ready reinforcement to aid immediately in any encounter.  The searchers are to seek and sound the alarm, not engage.  Not until all have been summoned and this witch surrounded.  Go, make the arrangements, I want no confusion.  See that every man knows his task."
The officers bow and disperse, allowing the Keep's master to consult privately with his wizards.  "To those of you whom I employ at my court, a most serious inquiry.  My honorable guest," nodding respectfully to Pious, "seems able to sense the location of this wicked wench whom I seek.  When she came into the Keep to do her evil work, why was her presence not detected?"
Escheloson, the court's master wizard offers his opinion; wisely, his two slight-of-hand apprentices listen and learn.  Indeed, neither would dare address His Lordship directly for fear of revealing their lack of expertise.  "Milord, either she may conceal her powers from those who might see them, which is a rare quality, or far more likely, she has none.  Ill intent, in and of itself may not be identified unless it is escorted by some level of magic from within.  She may have potions and instruments, but lack any power of her own."
"When we met," Pious admits, "I thought her only clever, but ever so willful."
"You know this wench firsthand?"  Escheloson inquires.  His Lordship is likewise intrigued, not being previously aware of this fact.
"Yes, not her name nor home... but we have spoken.  Thus, she is known to me.  Certainly not by bonds of magic, for there is none of that within her."
Escheloson turns to His Lordship with a silent gesture alluding to, "You see, it was as I said" and receives a pardoning nod in exchange.  Pious has avoided mention of enchanted blades and the vengeful desires of his partially incinerated master, Rueshaba.  But then of course, his service has not been lent to this foray to caution or discourage these fools.
His Lordship's relieved of much anxiety to hear the wench is but a common rebel with a bit more luck than most.  One who may be wounded, tortured, or executed as any other of his subjects.  A most  refreshing thought at the least.  Pious's assurance, not unlike a treat offered a child before bed, sweet things to conjure sweet dreams.  "Have you learned anything from the items she left behind?  Roux inquires, "any hint of where she came from, why her interest in the maiden and her man slave or the Lord of Orchard?"  His voice rises.  "Who are her allies?  What conspiracy is afoot here?"
"All has been in such a rush, milord," Escheloson advises calmly, "and the coach far too jarring.  With that our quarters have been prepared we may now render a proper and detailed inquisition."
Roux throws both arms aside and bows his head slightly as to amplify his frustration.  "Get on with it then," he commands.  Roux exits the command tent and returns to his own to sup, thoughts of his tormentors bound in chains by breakfast have made him hungry and eager as a child the day before his birthday to pass the night.
The contents of Leona's abandoned tool kit have been spread out upon a table in the midst of the sorcerer's tent.  There, tentatively divided into the common and the as-yet unidentified.  Lighting here is far superior to the officer's facility.  Each of the tent's four support poles is equipped with large, multiple, fan-flame oil lamps.  Pious, Escheloson and his two apprentices ponder the items silently.  The common include: white chalky stones, blocks of charcoal, 10 yards of hemp cord, flint, a wad of tinder, several wooden wedges, a thin iron slat, a coarse file, half dozen pointed metal hooks, each a different shape, assorted keys and two small torches, their ends sealed in lead foil.
One of Escheloson's apprentices, Hezhspi by name, is quick to add his penny's worth of foolishness to the game.  "Provisions of a common thief, I think, nothing more.  For a copper one could assemble the lot," he snickers smugly.
  "Obviously, you think very poorly," Pious counters abruptly, thus setting the bar well above useless rhetoric.  "Common thieves do not come and go at will from Keeps let alone your master's apartments.  Those hooks are the means to undo locks not raid chicken coops."  Pious picks up the surviving grenade from Leona's arsenal, holding it forth for Hezhspi's examination.  "What do you think of this?"  There is silence; Pious answers his own challenge.  "Brimstone, ash of wood, lead, clay, a bit of phosphor, and most interestingly the residue of hen coops, but no magic.  Do you agree?"  Still the fellow remains silent; a lovely red complexion has risen to betray his ignorance.  Pale Pious is not one to hesitate when idiots and their misconceptions grace his presence.  His is stern business, not the playful jabber of the court nor one of its misplaced jesters.
"Nothing of a wizard's art sets before us here.  I tire of this folly."  Time has come for him to recount the day's events to she of whom he is bound.  In truth, he desires guidance, for things seem not as they should be.
Once their honorable guest has departed, Escheloson is quick to pick up where Pious had left off.  "We are not here to entertain, least of all each other.  Mind your tongue if you have nothing useful to say.  There is more to be learned by listening than speaking when such as he is about.  Though simple things these may be, each aspires to a lofty purpose.  The tools of one, though uninvited, who would make their way in dark places of which they had little or no knowledge.  Such is the art of assassin's not simpletons."
Every alchemist is a wizard of sorts and every wizard is first an alchemist, who in due time inquires beyond the physical.  Aside from what the senses might plainly detect, the primary analytical test of anything in this day and age is little more than how it feels, smells, tastes, or reacts to fire and water.
Aside from the grenade, which Pious was kind enough to analyze by his very touch, there remains three other unknown items.  First, a stoppered crock containing half a liter of oily, pale-yellow aromatic liquid, which when brought near a flame is confirmed to be of a highly combustible nature.  Next, a small vial of thick pale liquid immediately suspect of being a poison, largely due to the small quantity and the care rendered it's packaging.  It fails to ignite, but upon heating, expels a pungent odor.  This is set aside until a few field mice might be captured as test subjects.  If they survive, a more detailed analytical procedure will be applied.  Last to be inquired of are six bundles of very thin wooden sticks about eight inches long, their ends protected with ceramic caps and sealed with beeswax.  The seal of one is broken and carefully removed to disclose a crusty brown material firmly adhering to the sticks.  Escheloson states the obvious in the context of a lesson for his apprentices.  "Wax is more often to secure something from the damage of moisture than add to its purpose."
"Why the clay cap?  Could it not have been dipped entirely in wax to protect it?" asks Lozene, his more inquisitive apprentice.
"The maker apparently feels wax would foul the purpose of it."  A sample brought near a flame bursts into combustion intensely.  Another portion, first moistened, fizzles and smokes, but fails to sustain a flame.
"Is it a torch then?" Lozene ventures."
"I would doubt it." Escheloson suggests.  "There are others already included here, why then another sort of the same device?  No, these are to some other end, but fire would seem their purpose."  Picking up the convenient flint, he strikes it against the brown compound to no avail.  When struck with Leona's iron file, however, flame violently erupts from the tip.
"You have it! a torch capable of lighting itself."  Lozene beams with curiosity.  "The flint and tinder are bound together.  It ignites so quickly."
"Many worthy uses here," Escheloson teases with mild enthusiasm, "if the making of this stuff can be found out."
"This interloper seems intent upon setting fires, but what is to burn?"  Lozene asks.  "Fire would not harm the Keep, but for the furniture and linens it is entirely of stone."
"These may have been to operate the devices used against the sentries.  Lead," Escheloson recalls, "The pale one made mention of lead being in the flask.  Fragments of lead were all about the passages... driven into everything and all who were near with great intensity."
Hezhspi is paying little attention to his mentor's inquiry, choosing instead to fondle the heavy ceramic container.  Lead beads can be seen smoothly embedded in the crock's surface, but the comment on that peculiarity fails to raise alarm.  The cap is wax-sealed, just as those of the sticks his master presently tampers with.  There seemed no hesitation in opening one of those.  Besides, their learned arrogant guest has certified the container free of spells or demons.  What can be the harm?  He gives the cap a sharp twist to break the seal, but something strange begins to transpire.  There was a crackling sound at first and now a fizzling noise bodes ill of his deed.  Smoke has begun to stream out from around the broken seal and the cap itself has become unbearably hot.  His curiosity suddenly replaced by anxiety, he cautiously returns the container to the table as one not wishing to disturb it further.  Oh, but woe is he it may be said of any child who plays with fire, yet understands it not.  Indeed, but for curiosity, the world would be much safer for cats and fellows like Hezhspi.
The Master gazes with intense disdain toward his foolish student.  Turning back to the more prudent Lozene, he instructs, "Be gone from here fifty yards and be quick."  Turning again to Hezhspi, "This riddle you have set in motion, you shall stay and solve, for I have just tried and cannot."  Realizing he has screwed up big time and thinking retreat the wiser choice, he attempts to follow the other apprentice away.  Much to his dismay he finds himself now frozen to the spot.  He assaults the object with futile spells of every kind; still it fizzles and sparks, unimpressed of his pleas.
Normally Escheloson could extinguish a small fire by spiriting the air away from around it for a moment.  Of necessity, however, the chemical compounds of a fuse are self-oxidizing and thus, needs not a single breath to proceed.  The master takes hold of his thick cloak and furls it about himself as a cocoon.  A magical shield against the evil very soon to come.  The grenade explodes.
Quietly meditating well off to himself, Pious rises to his feet with a great laughter, a feeling until now he had thought forever lost.  'Tis autumn, and though a frost has yet to settle in the fields, much of the grass is already dry and would be quick to embrace the caress of any flame.  Thus, the stage is set and thereupon turmoil shall soon preside, come to dance wildly through His Lordship's temporary domain.  'Tis that timeless fable of mice and men once again come near.  For the best laid plans of neither of them seems very wisely spent around here!
She to whom he is bound has heard his plea for reassurance of this foreboding task, and now comes to counsel with her spy.  "I am with you," Rueshaba whispers within his mind.  "What secrets are learned?"
"My queen... as you instructed, I have offered my service and they are accepted.  The one you seek inflicted a remarkable destruction at the Keep, but I found not a trace of magic nor any evidence of the melting fires.  She prevails only by common alchemy put to good use or simple force of arms."
"Alchemy did not rend my hand nor abolish my window."
"I detected only the sword of which you spoke.  She was very near.  They had planned to set upon her with the dawn, but that work has dissolved.  She has breached the camp just now; I fear this expedition is at an end.  All has reduced to folly."
"How does one wench attack an army?"
"By allowing one of her tricks to be found, they took it into their midst as one might welcome a lost child."
"The Horse of Troy," Rueshaba whispers.
"Exactly, their curiosity has set it in motion.  Turmoil and fire rage through the camp even now, but I assure 'tis not the fire of your concern.  Only common things burning there.  What is your wish, my queen?  How shall I serve thee?"
"Stay, seek her out.  I am gone from you now."
Much turmoil indeed!  The resulting concussion rips the tent from its moorings converting it to a ragged, shallow, dome-shaped hot-air balloon of sorts.  Instantly vaporized, the gasoline-like contents of the crock nearby has created a billowing fireball upon which the remnants of the canopy rise.  An ominous blazing shroud, it glides through the air as some great glowing jellyfish, a blazing demon in search of prey.  When the intense initial fire-ball dissipates, burning vestiges settle back to earth.  They whip and curl about, born upon the evening breeze as though alive.  Drifting across the ground dispensing fire through the grass in their wake.  Two of the oil lamps formally within the tent are propelled intact as fiery missiles; they roll through the encampment spreading good cheer and flaming oil among the tents.  The less volatile fuel from a dozen others has converted the immediate area, including the officer's tent, into an inferno.  Thus, Roux's cavalry are privileged to witness the first practical test of a vaporized fuel air mix explosive.  That being very much akin to what transpires within an internal combustion engine, though on a considerably grander scale.
Had the officers not been off to advise their second's in command to organize the search parties for the coming dawn they would have had a splendid taste of their quarry's wrath firsthand.  
Much speculation on that account shall be forthcoming.  For what difference, whether by the hand of fate or the Lady of Durer's subtle long reaching embrace, for either way dead men are dead.  Dozens of pellets have pierced His Lordship's domain.  Fortunate he was they slowed considerably as having to penetrate four layers of heavy fabric first.  Lord over all he surveys, once again he finds his nose where the bottom of his boot should be, this time bleeding and thinking himself half assassinated.  Who is the cat here and who is the mouse? and how does such ill favor so oft find its way to His Lordship's fine house?  Is there justice even in dreams?  One could hardly imagine, yet thus, so it seems.  What use then, a fantasy, if at any moment reason may come to call, or at times, scream, waking one and all.
The lucky pellet hasn't gone very deep, penetrating the flab just below his armpit, there finding a nice cushy rib to bind against.  Shaped as a teardrop though, the pointed end shall be the envy of every stinging insect Roux has ever known.
Neither man nor beast is sure of what has happened.  Small fires seem to be everywhere and spreading, taking many of the two-man tents to task.  Darkness is a formidable ally, it breeds confusion, and confusion is an enemy like no other.  For it suffers no casualty of it's own regardless of its deeds.  Are they under attack, which way are they coming, how many, where are the officers, where is my leader, what shall we do?  The great majority rising from their sleep are of course out of uniform.  Thus, unable to discern friend from foe in the pitch of night and surrounded by the thick smoke of smoldering grass fires.  They become their own worst enemy.  Sentries engage their comrades thinking them invaders.  Before order comes to the encampment, three will lie dead and seven wounded beyond repair at the hands of their own men.
The sharp crack of the detonation and accompanying fireball have stirred the mounts into total panic.  Many are veterans from the demolition of the Keep's siege gate the night before.  Ropes strung to tether them between the wagons are no match for their number or mass, being on the order of 70 tons.  Scattering in all directions they trip over tent lashings and stumble upon the men.  Three of the four sentries are run over like twigs and many of the pup tents are destroyed.  Given their relatively light weight, the dogs are more securely restrained, but none the less unnerved at the pyrotechnics and chaos.  They attack anything within reach.  Several find the hooves of the mounts their reward for such indiscretions.
At zero plus two minutes the major threat is the unconstrained grass fires.  If they are not extinguished soon all the tents will be forfeit, and many of the saddles damaged or destroyed.  Crop losses aside, public relations would suffer greatly if an uncontrolled field fire were left to its own devices.  The men are ill-prepared for such activities; lacking the basic fire fighters necessities of their trousers and boots.  And there's no ready supply of water nor suitable tools much aside of sleeping blankets.  A dozen men are burned, five seriously enough to decommission them.
In addition to Hezhspi, who was instantly perforated and subdivided way beyond repair, four others have also been seriously wounded as a result of shrapnel.  Escheloson's cape served well to his defense, but the device's effect wasn't quite what he'd expected.  Though his shield withstood the concussion it could not subdue the drastic pressure fluctuation.  The walls of the tent, flimsy as they were and sent almost instantly away, still provided enough containment to nearly destroy his eardrums.  Some time shall pass before the master wizard may again appreciate the song of birds, the melody of a flute, or His Lordship's ravings.
Such opportunity is not to be wasted on spectator sport.  Thus, Leona and company are quick to take advantage of their enemy's misfortune.  Though the dogs raise an adequate alarm of their exit, none can separate the hound's concern of the escapees from the mayhem rampant about the camp.  Nor in fact do they care.  This vixen from hell is to be avoided.  Leona and Karn lead the cart as a blind man dares to feel his way.  Well back along the forest road the second lamp is lit, His Lordship's prize again allowed to slip away into a moonless night.  They backtrack to the Sorin border.  This time turning west at the bridge, a longer but safer route back to the Brobose Inn where Art hopefully remains.
'Tis a night long in passing; the team proceeds at a fair trot, there being no need to push them.  Pleasantly uneventful but for the occasional raccoon or skunk crossing in the lamp's beam, or the curious gaze of glowing eyes reflected as the lamplight sweeps the forest at a turn in the road.  Karn's destination, a brook crossing the roadway, should avail itself an hour or so before dawn.  The cool air is beyond invigorating and after several hours the wooden bench becomes a trial to Leona's hind end.  Karn seems to pay it no mind, and Beth and Hale are snuggled up in the straw asleep.  Leona, her arms wrapped about herself, has only a thin shirt and the bandages beneath to keep the chill away.  Not at all encouraging are the few drops of rain felt from time to time; a shower would be a discomforting event, for alas she's made no provisions for such.
Leona has an armed crossbow tucked between her knees and another within reach, they the quickest remedy to a challenge.  Karn can see the chill is uncomfortable for her.  "It would not bring us to ruin," he reminds, "if you joined your friends to warm up."
"Suppose our passing raised a patrol sleeping along the roadside?  Your hands are occupied.  You drive, I shall keep the watch."
"Did you cause what happened back there?"
"Indirectly, I had some things with me when I entered the Keep.  They were lost when the mine exploded and I got trapped.  There was one grenade remaining.  They must have brought it with them.  And a quantity of highly flammable oil, too.  I'll bet that's what got things going so well."
"At first I thought you had gone ahead with your plan to slip into the camp.  With all due respect, milady... are you a witch?"
"Depends on your point of view, but really, by your definition... No!  The bombs can be set off by anyone, there's nothing magic about it.  But they are very dangerous to those who don't understand how they work.  Someone must have tried to open it thinking it was a bottle.  One remains in the cart.  Next chance we get I'll explain how it works in case you need to use it."
At best the Lord of Orchard is curious, at worst smitten of this female for whom he can recollect of no equal.  He plies politely in every way, direct and roundabout, seeking to learn from where she has come and to what end.  Leona's hard pressed to provide reasonable answers, but neither does she wish to lie.  Were she caught it would undermine the creditability of a relationship critical to her needs.  With the guise of a politician she politely avoids his direct inquiries and dances with the words.  Each time turning the conversation back upon his adventures and expanding the topic away from herself.  So it goes for the next four hours, the history of Karn and the mystery of Leona.
A chorus of frogs is rising in the near distance; a sure indication water is at hand.  Soon reflections of the lamp's beam are seen to bobble about upon the foliage ahead.  The pace is slowed; a broad shallow brook crosses the roadway just ahead.  Karn pulls the cart off into the watercourse, urging the team to follow the stream bed into the forest.  Cool water about their feet, a pleasant reframe from a journey requiring nearly all the night.  Several hundred yards along their progress is halted by a fallen tree.  Time has disposed of the branches, but the trunk is a good two feet in diameter, still fairly solid and firmly rooted to the bank.  "I'm thinking the meadow's not far off.  Even if we could hack through that thing I fear 'tis not deep enough here to float so great a log aside."
Some backtracking is required to locate a suitable exit point and soon their conveyance is resting upon dry land.  A small torch is lit from the lamp's flame and then a wooden plug extracted from the side of the lamp's reservoir allowing the water chamber to empty.  The brilliant flame soon withers and dies and all about them reverts to pitch.  Leona handles the torch while Karn looses the team, each rewarded with a couple of apples to tide them over till breakfast.  What a relief to be off that hard wooden bench.  After several hours it becomes a torment not unlike sitting on a thousand tiny tacks.  Leona's posterior burns to such an extent she considers dropping her trousers and sitting in the brook.
It seems only a moment more, though by the slightest glimmers of morning's light, that someone is again in her face.  Local magpies object profoundly to the presence of intruders within their domain.  Jays and woodpeckers soon add their concerns; there shall be no sleeping in this morning, however much deserved or desired.
"Good morning, milady," Karn announces, presenting her a hot cup of tea.  Does he never sleep?  "I'm going to lead the team off to the meadow for grazing."
"Sounds good," Leona agrees.  "Beth!"
She rises immediately like a Pop Tart from within the cart.  "Hey!  What's up?"
"Go with Karn.  Once things get settled take the watch, He's been up all night and he needs to get some sleep.  Hale and I will keep an eye on this end."  Beth slings a crossbow over her shoulder and gathers up a pouch of darts.  Adding a couple of apples, she ambles off behind Karn without a word.  It's encouraging to think she and Hale are picking up on this, that  they might survive on their own in a pinch.  She assigns the watch to Hale along with stoning of the birds as need be for quiet, then curls up in the back of the cart to nap if possible.
--
His Lordship's orderly encampment has been reduced to a scorched, smoke-enshrouded field, frayed nerves, and much subdued speculation.  Everyone's very much confused, not exactly sure if they've actually been attacked, and if so, by what.  A humiliating conclusion at best to the pomp and prancing about of the previous evening.  Few have even caught a glimpse of their enemy, yet this is the third confrontation within 24 hours rendering over a quarter of the garrison dead or disabled.  The country folk are curious, but dare not come too near.  There is obviously great tension in the air and perhaps demons as well, no one wishes to stir either up.
Dawn greets a weary and tormented lot.  Shrieks and moans rise from a hastily improvised field hospital.  Few have had any sleep at all and many are wrapped in blankets for lack of clothes.  The great fox-hunt scheduled for first light has given way to a task infinitely more pressing--that of recovering the mounts which are scattered far and wide.  During the course of the search remains of a fresh camp sight are discovered.  Earth beneath spent ashes is still warm from just hours before.  Indeed, the escapees were so close His Lordship's archers could have made the shot without advancing from their sleeping quarters.
By mid-afternoon it appears half the population of Sorin, the country folk at least, has assembled about the nearest farmstead.  Chores and such set aside, all have come to enjoy the VIP's misfortune and mumble of its meaning--the rubber-neckers of the middle ages one might say.
Several grandiose horsemen and a fine carriage approach the encampment, official envoys who have been invited to join the hunt.  But alas, the lady fox and her cubs have slipped away and the expedition's back is broken.
Calm and quandary are the decorum of the moment, casualties are counted, resources salvaged, and the wounded treated.  A fair number will be sleeping under the wagons again this evening as two in five of the tents have been lost.  Including Hezhspi the inquisitive, six have perished.  Two dozen more are injured, of which more than half no longer have worth to this mission.  His Lordship's been severely stung by a frozen lead tear requiring a painful surgery, and his master wizard is deaf as a doorknob.  Things have come well undone to which a heavy thundershower now adds insult to injury.  Last evening it would have been more than welcome, now just another torment.  Those fortunate enough to have saved their tents play host to soaked comrades.  As does His Lordship, for his perforated and scorched domicile has hardly a space to stand.  Not that he would hesitate for a moment to evict the lot, but of necessity, as the emissaries of Sorin are now present, he must at least appear a reasonable man.  
Pious the Pale has chosen to poise himself silently in the downpour; for what is discomfort to one such as he, now bound in Rueshaba's service for the rest of his life and thereafter most of eternity?
--
As weather goes, that being shamelessly nondiscriminatory, saints and sinners alike get wet when it rains.  Thus, 'tis not without some apprehension that the first few large cold drops splash upon Leona's face.  "Rain!"
"Yep," Hale concurs, with the hindsight of a true sports fan. 
"I've got nothing to cover this," she grumbles incoherently.  She hops from the cart.  "If things open up we're going to get wet.  It's too damn cold for this kind of crap."
"I'm really disappointed Leo," he continues to tease.
"Gimmy a break, will ya?  You can't have a sports car with the conveniences of a minibus."
Hale places a consoling hand on her shoulder and breaks into a smile.  "Lighten up chief!  Anybody's got a complaint about your work, I'll kick their ass, and that includes Art."
Hale carefully stoops to consider the possibilities, no simple trick with one leg rigidly braced.  "What do you think, under the wagon maybe?"
"Lying in the mud?" she frowns."
Wind is beginning to whip the treetops as the drizzle picks up.  Thunder echoes mournfully in the distance.
"Maybe we'll luck out," Hale encourages.
"I think we used all that up last night.  What we need is the stuff of a good fire stashed in the dry before it's too late."  With that, she's off to gather as much dry wood as can be found before the shelter of the trees gives way and all is soaked beyond use.  Hale attempts to lend a hand and is soon reprimanded.  "No, you've got to stay off that knee.  Get down by the cart.  I'll bring it to you; you heave it underneath.  set a couple thick ones crosswise first to keep the rest up off the ground."
"Hey, this new brace is okay, knee's feeling good.
"No!  You're going to need that knee for more important things, save it."
"Okay, I got it, you gather, I stack."
A fair supply of relatively dry firewood has found its way beneath the cart by the time the sky fully opens.  They take cover best as they can, their backs tight to the trunk of a big old maple.
"Sorry, I know I'm turning into a real bitch lately, but I've got issues here I can't explain."
"No problem," Hale consoles.  "You sounded just like my mom first time she caught me smoking.  "You're going to need those lungs someday," he mimics in a quaint voice.  Leona smiles, Beth's fortunate to have his undivided attention.  "It's just standard motherly banter," he continues.  "I hope Beth found a place to keep dry; she just about can't stand wet clothes.  Turned a garden hose on her once, you know, just for fun.  Holly shit! I thought she was going to excommunicate my ass."
Leona takes hold of his hand and squeezes.  "Whatever happens, you've gotta take care of her first."
"Yeah... I will."
Their tree shelter serves to little avail.  The ground turning to muck as the torrent continue unabated into late afternoon.  "Wish I had a bar of soap," he injects.  Leona agrees with a nod.  Aside from the frogs, who turn near ecstatic on wonderful days like this, both are thoroughly saturated and chilled to the bone by the time the deluge has subsided.  Soon thereafter Karn and Beth emerge from the forest leading the team; they've fared no better.  Beth's hair has become a work of fiction, it appears as a battlefield between the frizzy and the forlorn.  Miserable at best, her arms wrapped about herself and shivering, she attempts to find some comfort in Hale's waiting embrace.
"I'm freezing here, guys." She pleads softly with a shuttering voice.  She was looking pretty frazzled before, but now, wet as a fish.  If there's ever been a case of coyote ugly cute, there she is.
Leona recovers the crock of homemade gasoline from her stash.  A splash of fuel for encouragement and the damp kindling, though hesitant at first, comes to life.  Even Karn, who seems unaffected by any measure of discomfort, welcomes the blaze.  They twirl slowly about like hot dogs on the backyard rotisserie, trying to cook both sides evenly without scorching anything important.  The breeze persists and with it residual drops of water continue to fall from the canopy of leaves above, a bearable inconvenience given the state of things just half an hour past.  Aside from their shoes, everyone has soon dried out, more or less, and the heat feels more wonderful than anything else that has come their way in some time.  Thunder is still very much in attendance, the air cool and breezy.  Another shower literally hangs above their heads like the sword of Damocles, ready to drop any moment.
Karn attempts to raise their spirits.  "We are four, maybe five hours from the hunting camp I mentioned.  With this weather, travelers would be scarce if at all.  Could be there by nightfall or shortly after if we travel by day, but... there may be sentries."
"We'll go for it," Leona concedes hesitantly.  "We've got to find some cover... even if it means invading some little farm and taking hostages.  At this rate everyone's going to end up with pneumonia.  Besides, I doubt there's enough fuel in the lamps to last for more than a few hours so we're going to have to risk exposing ourselves anyway.  She refocuses on Karn.  "Lead the way, sir."  Completely soaked, the straw that had acted as padding must be abandoned.  Hence, they shall not be traveling in the grand style to which they've become accustomed.
Less than an hour passes before a subtle drizzle begins anew to assure a miserable night if they fail to locate shelter.  Rumbling as they may, the clouds continue to tease for the next several hours with only occasional sprinkles.  Though yet it should be as day, light has all but fled the sky, everything thereabout cast in shades of darkening gray.  Leona's handling the team while Karn strains to identify the overgrown path off the main road.  He's waded into the roadside thickets several times thinking it found, only to return.  The way he seeks had been abandoned some time ago and nature eagerly demands it return to the forest proper.
"Hold!  Let me take a closer look back in there."
"I can try to restart the lamp," Leona suggests.
"Were it in the sky, that would help, but as it is, I fear the moving shadows would cause distortion to the way things normally look."
"Right, I see your point."
"I will find it, milady," he insists confidently.  Though not this particular spot, true to his word the next attempt bears fruit.  Only saplings bar their way and they stand aside or bend willingly as the cart slowly forges ahead, Karn now leading the team.  "Wait here and quietly.  I need go ahead to see if anyone occupies the camp."  With that he fades into the forest while the others huddle to evade the chilling mist.
No small composition, Karn's hunting lodge; the silhouette looms against the night sky betraying it to be twice the structure of the Brobose Inn.  Something strange about the fields beyond though.  "I see something," Leona points out, "lights out there in the forest, and they're moving, look!"
"A sliver of your friend the moon has returned, milady.  It's a reflection upon the water where the breeze has stirred the surface."
"Water... okay, I get it, you've got a lake out there?"
"Yes, quite large, usually shrouded in a great mist by now, but clear this night."
I suspect the rain's cooled the air to the same temperature or less than the water's surface," Leona deduces.  "That would hold the fog down."
"There are cabins all along the far shore," he warns.  "Even a candle could give us away.  No one is supposed to be here and none must think it otherwise.  There are plenty of blankets, we must cover the windows before the hearth is lit."
Sopping wet, freezing cold, tired as hell and hungry as wolves in midst of winter, but all things in due time.  First there is considerable groping about in the dark, the stubbing of toes, falling over chairs and breaking of fingernails, just another ordinary fun day of playing at fantasy games.  Before the torment has concluded two large tall cabinets have been pushed, pulled and dragged halfway across the building.  They are set side by each adjacent to the hearth to obstruct the fire's glow from reaching large windows facing out toward the lake, their heavy draperies drawn tight.
Flint and iron now mate to conjure a spark, the glowing tinder then betrothed with slender brides of wax to father a flame.  Even in a single candle's dim light, the appointments speak well to the Lord of Orchard's standing, luxuries now graciously shared with weary vagabonds and scoundrels alike.  They stand in a great central room, the ceiling so high above the candle's beam has not the will to reach it.
Logs as tall as Karn himself are easily accommodated by the hearth and a stout supply of dry wood humbly awaits to warm body and soul.  But only kindling is to make the sacrifice this night.  Iron knee braces anchored to pivots set in either side support caldrons.  One large enough for Beth to bathe in and from the attention she is paying it, that possibility may be on her mind.  While kindling the fire, he establishes the ground rules necessary to maintain their security.  "Fires must be kept low and not stirred that sparks might rise beyond the chimney's top.  They need be doused cold as the grave at least an hour before dawn," he cautions.  "At times smoke tends to linger above the roof so we must allow ample opportunity for it to move away.  Some of the workers are known to fish at off times.  They won't come near this end of the lake, but if anyone would go out you must be cautious.  Keep the lodge or the forest between yourself and the lake.  The horses are not to be left out of the barn; water then must be brought to them."
Hale, ever inquisitive, "Nice pad, they friends of yours, or are we home invading?"
"'Tis mine... was mine, if that is what you've ask?  I've been undone by the charge of sedition; thus am I now as you.  An outcast... my loyalties misunderstood, a trespasser in my own house."
Heaps of inviting dry blankets are gathered from the guest rooms and piled before the glowing hearth.  The simple pleasures of drying out and warming up, comforting beyond words.  Hale is so content he doesn't even realize he hasn't eaten for over 24 hours.  Beth is curled into a ball, gently purring.  Leona, as usual has lashed the hilt of her blade to her wrist and found a spot she fancies.  Karn has gone off, probably to secure the doors or something.  Who cares? all is warm, quiet, and safe.
By the time the peasants have begun to stir the Lord of Orchard has shaved, bathed and changed from his tattered bloody clothing into a country gentleman's attire.  In fact, he's also backtracked to where they had left the road to disguise as well as possible any signs of their trespass.
When the draperies secured across the great windows are pulled aside, though a drizzle persists and the sky remains overcast, the rising sun is for a time so low it skirts beneath the clouds.  Splashing from the lake's surface, light floods the room with an intense golden luminescence.  Warmth from last evening's fire lingers pleasantly, dispelling the clammy atmosphere that had permeated the lodge when first they arrived.  More of wood framing than glass; the windows are assembled from hundreds of tiny panes.
"I'm going to tend the horses," Karn declares.  "We shall need one of you at least half awake to man the watch."
Hale bobs up from the pile of blankets he and Beth currently occupy.  "I've got it," he assures, rolling out to the call of duty.  A rumpled Beth appears; she strains for a better look at the silhouette asking for volunteers.  "Is that Karn?" she mumbles.  "Doesn't sleep much, does he?"  That profound observation now duly recorded she withers back into the heap for some extended dream time.
"Horseman may only approach from one direction," Karn advises, pointing out the road paralleling the lake's shoreline.  "Once they've come into view we've only a minute, so be quick to warn."  Hale nods with a yawn that nearly draws the curtains into his face.  "Wake up lad, time to be at your best."
Another affirmative nod, his eyes brighten against the glowing rays of dawn.
No shanty their hideout, a small castle in fact with floors and walls of finished limestone.  The room they occupy is at least thirty by fifty feet.  Trophies glare down from high upon the walls; great pairs of antlers and the heads of boars, pelts and furs are in abundance.  Upon finally rising, Beth comes to realize she's been using the head of a giant grizzly for her pillow.  Sitting quietly for a moment she contemplates the gaping jaws.  So large was this creature she may not have qualified as a complete meal.  Intent upon sharing her discovery she nudges Leona.
"If this ain't an emergency I don't want to hear it.  My ass is whipped."
"You, tired?  Come on," Beth persists.  "I know you love this stuff.  Wake up... get a load of this place.  We're strutting in some high cotton here."
"Get lost," bubbles caustically to the surface from Leona's vicinity, "Leave me be."
Returning from the barn, Karn lovingly cradles something akin to an oversized deflated basketball.  It's covered with a terribly offensive, sticky, reddish brown, black and greenish sludge to which many insects have become hopelessly stuck and hence expired.  Placing it upon the table with a bright smile, he then produces eight eggs from his pockets.  These little treasures are seemingly fresh as residue of chicken shit still clings to several.  Without a word he is off again.
Beth gives the strange object a visual once-over; she dare not touch it.  "What is that?  Looks like an alien egg pod," she speculates.
Hale concludes, without a doubt and an affirmative nod, "dinosaur turd."
Cobweb-laden flasks of wine accompany when next the Lord of Orchard returns.  Picking up one of the eggs, he advises, "Check each of these separately before they're dropped in the skillet, some may be on their way to becoming chickens.  There's charcoal in the kitchen, makes a nice even heat and no smoke.  Found a sack of cornmeal, too.  It's been stored in a tight cedar chest," he assures, "to keep it from the mice and insects."  Withdrawing a knife, he slices away the brine encrusted about Hale's supposed prehistoric dropping.  A succulent, deep red, salt-cured country ham is hidden there within.  The aroma immediately sparks Hale's appetite.  It suddenly dawns on him as some long-lost memory; he hasn't eaten for hours, maybe days!  Strangely conflicting is the feeling he wasn't really hungry till just now and he can't imagine why not.  Hot corn-bread biscuits with honey nicely complement the scrambled eggs and fried ham.  Roasted pecans and peach brandy are served up as desert.  Hardy stuff by any account, indeed a repast suitable for the gods.  The ham is enticing, but Leona's jaw hasn't quite come up to that level of chewing power yet.  She gets by slicing it very thinly, as such something one may taste and swallow with very little actual work.
All these culinary delights now safely stored where they will do the most good, Hale inquires, "Is there a bathroom, or outhouse, I guess you would call it?"
"This way, lad," Karn ushers him to a spacious adjoining room.  A fine throne of equal value to every class sits against the wall, a duplex in fact with two smooth contoured seats of oak, one about a third smaller than the other.  "When you've finished, draw a pail of water from the cistern."  He points to a curbed 10-foot square opening in the floor, topped up to the overflow as recently as last evening.  "Pour it in the drain there," designating an adjacent floor grating.  "That'll wash everything out to the pit."
"Indoor plumbing," he muses respectfully.  "What's that thing?"  Hale motions toward an oblong polished brass kettle sitting several feet above a shallow pit full of ash.  The vessel, fitted with a generous smoothly rolled edge for ease and comfort, sets like a cradle between two iron pivots.  A sprocket of sorts attached to one side allows by the cranking of a handle, that the entire kettle tilt discharging its contents into a floor grating.
"We have cooked in it, and on occasion boiled the bed linens when I've had a guest bring lice along as pets, but most of the time it's for bathing.  You fill it up and set a fire beneath to warm it."
"But we can't have a fire during the day," Hale observes disappointingly, "'cause of the smoke, right?"
"Not exactly, there was no proper way of arranging a chimney.  Hence we must use charcoal so as not to fill the house with smoke.   You leave the windows open, then a little kindling to get it started is all," he explains, pointing to a large bin at the rear wall.  "Then add some charcoal; you don't really want flames licking the sides, just heat enough for simmering."
"Right, I get it.  Man this is cool... can we use it?"
"Be a shame not to."  Hale is quick to nod in total agreement, "Well, let's get it filled up then."  They form an impromptu bucket brigade; the kindling is lit and stacked with charcoal.  Karn takes hold of a brass framework with smooth wooden slats attached along the flat side.  When lowered into the tub, it creates a shelf to support the bather above the kettle's bottom.
"What's that for?" Hale asks inquisitively.
"Keep's ya from singeing your hindquarter."
"What if it gets too hot?"
"Splash a bit over the sides, it will run down and cool some of the coals."
"Right," Hale purrs, like a Buddhist monastery student finally  enlightened after much dedicated meditation.
Back in the central room, Leona has taken over the watch when Beth momentarily catches sight of something.  "Hey, did ya see that?"
Beth's comment sparks an adrenaline rush.  "Where?"  Leona's posed for confrontation in a heartbeat.
"Up there," Beth points into the exposed roof beams, "a poor little bird!  It's trapped in the house."
A sigh of relief allows Leona to defuse and focus on Beth's concern. "I think there's... hummm... a little cluster of bats maybe.  See," she points.  "There in the corner, those little gray bundles dangling from the ceiling?"
"In the house," Beth stammers indignity, "with us?"
Leona shrugs, "Hey, remember, you had a mouse in your apartment once."
"Yeah... so?"
"You liked it."
"Did not!" she rebuts indignantly.
"Sure did!  We cornered it, got it in the wastebasket and you started feeling sorry for it."
Beth starts to squirm a little.  She knows Leona's memory is nearly flawless and this is going to be a looser, but she persists.  "Did not!"
"Yep!  I was going to throw it outside," Leona reminds, "and you were afraid the cats would find it.
"That was different."
"Nope!  They're just mice, but with wings, hang from the ceiling instead of running around on the floor.  It's better, they're out of the way up there.  Besides, anything that eats bugs is all right by me."
"Leeoooo!"  With furled brow, Beth glances up toward the flying mice again, a woeful disconcerting frown presented in defense.  Intent on appealing her case to Hale for a more favorable ruling, she calls out to request his immediate attendance.
Peeking in from the adjoining room, he responds enthusiastically.  "Hey, come check out this neat bathtub."  Which is akin to saying, I just won the lottery, so now we can get married.
Far as Beth's concerned the world's just stopped spinning, insignificant thoughts of bats, even vampires, even zombie vampires, even zombie vampire bats, who cares! have taken second place among her long list of concerns.  Addressing Leona in a church service whisper, she confides softly.  "There's a bathtub?"  Her eyes grow wide.  "Is that what he said?"  As one entranced she follows Hale's voice though Svengali himself was calling to her form the shadows of some pulp novel.  Having found her way to the ladies' room, she approaches the copper caldron in awe, staring quietly at the answer to her prayers.  "It's beautiful," she murmurs with an angelic softness to her voice.  "Where's the faucet?"
"Don't need one," pointing out the cistern.  "We just filled it up from the well there."
"An indoor pool, too?"
"Ah, not exactly."
"Can I be first, please?  I need this really bad."
"I was thinking we should give Leo first shot, I mean, with all she's done and everything, you know."
Beth's eyes sadden; she nods in agreement.  "You're right.  By the way, not to change the subject, but keep an eye on Leo.  Like, if you can help her move or lift something, give her a hand.  She'd never admit it, but I can tell and she's hurting."  Beth saunters back into the main room approaching Leona with the smile of a used care salesman.  "Flip ya for it."
Leona squints inquisitively, "For what?
"The first bath."
"I can't now, I'm on watch."
"If I lose," Beth counters soberly, "I'll do that."
"No, go ahead, I had one... last week sometime."  Beth begins smiling and starts to hum like a bumblebee.  One could imagine her about to lift off, but certainly not to such an altitude as to trouble the bats.  "I really kind of need to do my laundry, too," she adds. "Okay?"
