"Yeah, I know exactly what you mean.  Go, I'll catch it later!"  Beth dashes off; this is going to be better than after the prom!
Karn struts into the main room showing a bit of the former pride which attends those of privilege.  He's quite pleased to have such clever resources available for his guests.  Volunteering to relieve Leona of the watch, he cordially invites her to join Beth for a look at his high-tech bathing facilities, or soup kettle, depending upon the occasion.  When she peeks in, Beth is stirring the water with a large wooden paddle.  With only one paw available, she's found it best to brace the end of the handle between her neck and shoulder.  The sight is that of a wild frayed creature to be sure, a witch perhaps, toiling over her caldron.  Hardly a frightful one though, for a glowing smile presently envelops her entire being.  "What are you doing?"  Leona inquires.
"It's kind of like making fudge.  You have to heat it slow and keep stirring, you know, or you get your bottom scorched.  Karn said one guy didn't stir it; hopped right back out.  Cracked his head open on the floor, fried his ass, too."
"Just what we need, someone requiring the facilities of an ICU.  Don't you dare get in there till you sure it's okay all the way to the bottom."  Leona looks into the water and taking note of the submerged cradle.  "There's a good idea; somebody's using their head."
"That wooden basket thing, yeah.  Once you get in, Karn says ya have to keep wiggling like a tadpole, stirs things around so the bottom doesn't get too hot.
"Let me do that."
"I got it," Beth insists. "I'm okay."
"Why isn't Hale on this?"
"He said he would, but I got it figured out."
"Yeah, I see.  How's your hand?"
"Sore, but not throbbing like before.  Karn said it would take an hour for it to warm up.  Lot of trouble, but it's still a bargain in this town."  Always anxious to play the devil's advocate, Beth slips into a low mischievous tone.  "You know, if he's half as good as he looks," she teases, "you're missing an opportunity.  Can't be Art holding you back; you haven't said ten words about him yet."
"Art's in the trash... and when this is over, Karn will vanish."
"So, you thinking about this guy?"
"No!"
"Why not?  You know you should try to keep your face turned a little to the left, by the way."
"Why?"
"Well... still looks... a little off-color you know.  But I don't think he's the kind of guy would have a problem... with that."  Beth nibbles on the tip of her finger a little, keeping an eye on Leona for some reaction.  "Ah, anyway, never mind."
"I'm not trying to make it with this guy," Leona insists.
"I can see this is going to be like a soap.  A teaser, rambling on for weeks; are they gonna do it... or not?"
"Trust me, they're not." Damn it, she's teasing it again.  It's like nobody really wants to finish this.  Am I the only one playing to win?  Maybe that's it?  Maybe I am the only one.  They were all just sitting there in the game room like nothing was out of place.  Except me, I was the one out of place.
"Your attitude is a crime against nature," Beth informs calmly.
Leona chuckles quietly, "Give it up!  Speaking of soap, is there any?"
"Certainly, this is a full service spa, peasant!"  She alludes to a platform just below the rim, an extension of the entry stair behind the tub.  Thereupon rests a pitcher, several washcloths, a stack of fine towels, and a glazed plate with freeform chunks of a yellowish coarse brown substance--probably the soap.
Leona examines the suspect material.  "Be careful, this is not the hypoallergenic beauty bars you're familiar with.  They actually put lye in this stuff, so don't get any in your eyes.  I brought some with me, but it's like rust remover; you could use it to dislodge barnacles."
"I never considered a bath a life-threatening experience," Beth concludes.  "But I swear, next time that smart ass Marnie Cuahger starts wining about 'the good old days,' I'm gonna be on her like a city cat on a country mouse."
An uneventful half hour slips by.  Hale and Karn are sorting through a great chest selecting the dudes' new threads.  Their interest suddenly held at bay when sounds of ecstasy begin to rise.  Apparently, Beth's finally easing herself into the hot water and simply can not contain her bliss.
"I think she's making out with the tub, Hale."  Leona implies with an impish smile.  "I'm sure it's just a passing fancy.  Bet you a nickel they break up within an hour after the fire goes out."  Even Karn chuckles a bit.  The rapture falls silent for some time except for the occasional splash, until she calls out for Hale's attendance.
"Aha!  Maybe she's aspiring to a m'enage a'trois," Leona teases.
Hale looks a little puzzled.  "A what?"
"A threesome," Leona clarifies.
He shrugs at the implication and presents himself forthwith only to return a few minutes later.  "Needed more charcoal; the water was cooling down."
Leona snickers. "Hum, could be a long-term relationship after all."
--
While Beth pampers and polishes her posterior, within the confines of Rueshaba's citadel, all toil frantically to repatriate the elements of her mystical window.  Invaluable as an eye upon the world as seen through countless others, but for the moment disarrayed and scattered far and wide, a victim of Bird's instinctive temperament.  For some hours yet, little demons of every sort will scamper about searching out the tiniest of fragments, even so far as climbing the draperies and inspecting the walls inch by inch.
Alas, by evening, now reassembled, but not quite up to specification yet.  Be it a loose screw, a splintered bone, or a pinch of salt more than is called for, something has foiled the recipe.  Furious, she stalks back and forth cursing in languages even demons care not to speak, while pondering thoughts all the better none should know.  The furniture trembles and dust upon the floor moves aside at her approaching step.  The substance of her magic window, however, is not to be intimidated by such an agitated state.  For it must be whole or not at all and nothing less will do.  Things inanimate care not of threats; they seek peace in ways the mind dare not imagine.  Thus, neither pleasure nor pain are of concern, balance being their only true desire.  And no force however vile may deny it's so.  Most of Rueshaba's attendants and parts of things still able to move have slinked away into the shadows or climbed high into the roof trusses hoping to elude her impending wrath.  For all her effort, spatterings of blurred images accompanied by bright flecks of light, subdued ripples of gloomy hues, and the coming and goings of tiny fish or bugs, or something of that sort, mingle incoherently within the glass.  It appears as a TV set from the 1950's, needing its antenna adjusted or a weak vacuum tube replaced.  "I promised you all a treat," she wails.  Reemmmeeeeember?  For every piece you've lost I shall have from each of you a piece."  Her arm rises and with it a great tension as her vassals prepare for their punishment.  "Now pay me my due," she demands with hideous delight as she snaps her wrist.  A multitude of stifled screams and painful yelps echo about the citadel.  Then a bit of whimpering like a clutch of puppies having been scolded for chewing their master's slipper.  "Be still," she instructs sternly.  "Or I shall have another, perhaps an eye this time for losing the sight of mine.  Come before me now," she decrees, pointing a finger more ominous than the grim reaper's scythe.  That which I seek cannot leave this room; as sure as I am here... it must also be.  Now find it."
They crawl, scamper, limp, and slither away to their task.  Limp! There were no toes forfeit.  "You there," she points, "why... do you limp? You were not infirm when this misfortune came to be.  Nor was the bit you lost a bit of foot, come here," she demands sharply, "and let me comfort thee."  Considerable trepidation rises in its eyes, for in this place there is not the option of fight or flight, but only to obey.  "Poor dear, have you injured yourself in my service?"  She snatches the creature's ankle, upending it with a firm yank.  "You darling little bastard, what have we here?"  Rueshaba plucks a sharp shard of glass from its foot, then drops it on its head with not the least concern of damaging the floor.  "If I were not so happy... I might consider if I should grant you a kiss or rip your dear little head off.  Later perhaps, an appropriate reward will come to mind.  Does anyone else tread upon painful feet?" she wails.  "If my window fails to obey when next I call, I shall view very harshly any found to conceal a portion of it."  She hands the shard to her master technician.  "Recast my window maestro and add this note to the melody."
--
Back at the hideout, Leona calls out teasingly to Beth.  "You're going to be known as Beth the Prune if you don't get out of the water before long."  Beth doesn't feel such harassment is deserving of comment.  Another hour and several charcoal refuelings are required before their resident mermaid finally reappears, shuffling into the room bound up in a frumpy gray blanket.  Not but a frazzled hairdo and her toes to be seen.  "Anybody have a comb?" she inquires casually.  
"Beth the Prune," Leona continues colorfully. 
Beth makes a face as she starts on her way up the stairway.  "It was worth it," she injects smugly, "and I'll straighten out in a while, you'll see.  Reaching the landing, she turns her attention to Hale.  "Hon!" She purrs enticingly, "when you get scrubbed come up and see me, I need you to do something."  She turns up her nose and prances off trying to conceal a mischievous grin.  The edge of her blanket flows along the balcony like the train of a Hollywood diva's gown.  Karn alludes to her attitude with a slow gracious bow.  Everyone's mood is relaxed; Beth's grand entrance and playful exit are a perfect catalyst for the moment.
Leona turns to Hale.  "You've got five minutes, dude, then she's going to be wondering what's taking you so long.  Better get moving."
Hale flushes a bit.  "Wasn't she in there for like, what... two hours?"
Karn clarifies the deficiency in Hale's theory.  "Lad you must never allow the bath water nor a maiden with such thoughts to cool.  Get thee to the tub!  I'll bring you a fine suit of clothes that you may disrobe in the style demanded of such an enterprise."
Even Hale must grant Karn's poetics a smile, though he's just been politely compared to a go-go boy toy.  
"I assure you, lad," Karn continues, "the ladies enjoy removing a gentleman's belts and buckles, just as much as we unraveling their frills and bows."  Hale nods and turns toward the bath.
"Hey, we're still at war!" Leona reminds.  "You weren't thinking of taking a bath without your best friend were you, soldier?"
He throws up his arms in a surrendering motion and retrieves his crossbow.  And so, now officially authorized to soak and simmer in service to Her Ladyship, Beth the Prune.  Karn soon follows, heaped upon his shoulder the great chest previously acquired from one of the bedrooms.  The improved morale and comforts of the moment offer a welcome respite to ponder the clues supposedly leading to their escape portal.  So much has transpired, yet they seem not a single step closer to even defining their objective.  Leona repeats them to herself several times over, yet nothing of worth comes to mind.  "Forever seek the way home;" the game master implored, "or be forever lost."  A chilling thought at best.  Certainly it would be better to retrieve Art knowing their destination in advance.  Then again, he is a player and could be part of the solution.  If he would only try!
Hale emerges soon enough, bathed, trimmed and finely tailored, lacking only a splash of lavender and hardly that.  His splints, for the moment set aside, indeed it was a necessary evil as otherwise he could never have gotten into the tub.  Karn steps aside, proudly announcing with glorious fanfare; "Milady, may I present Sir Hale, a noble Lord of Mosheum, at once both slave and master of the Lady Beth."
"Looking good dude," Leona flatters.
Hale duly nods his appreciation, though ascending the stairs with his crutch somewhat dampens the moment.  This a tricky maneuver accomplished with articulate sidesteps and complicated by the crossbow swaying from his shoulder.  But having reached the landing, his flourish restored, he is soon rewarded by Beth's enthusiastic reception.  "Oh woowww!" rebounds from the corridor above initiating a round of smiles and silent applause. 
Karn has volunteered to draw fresh bath water for Leona while she maintains the watch.  She can't help but wonder if he may harbor amorous intentions of his own. Beth's recent antics doubtless an effort to stir the pot in that direction.  Could there be conspiracy afloat?  She wouldn't put it past Beth for a moment to prod their host directly with subtle words of encouragement.
Sunlight suddenly brightens the room.  Though the drizzle persists, a mighty wind has entered the fray, coming at last to sweep the low dreary clouds away.  Karn motions toward the mist-shrouded lake; a faint rainbow has come to celebrate the transition from overcast of gray to late-morning's light.  Leona smiles and relates, "where I'm from, lore would have a pot of gold waiting to be found where the light touches the ground.  Of course, none have ever retrieved the elusive treasure because the end really doesn't exist.  The closer you approach the more the image diffuses, fainter and fainter until it's gone, though others still see it clearly from where they stand.  It remains, yet can no longer be perceived from the seeker's point of view.  Thus, the treasure's forever protected with only illusion to guard it."
"Indeed!" Karn replies curiously.  "Hereabouts they would say a beautiful golden-haired maiden awaits there, willing to offer herself to the first lad with good fortunate enough to find the way.  And as you say, none have ever succeeded.  Thus, a fair maiden she will always be."
"A maiden! 'To the house of Iris you must go.'  I knew there was a bell ringing somewhere when I heard that.  It's mythology; Iris is the rainbow!  Intangible, a deception of refracted light!  Each point of view perceives it in a different place.  This could be a problem," she concludes in hushed tones.  "You can't touch it, you can't even really see it; the end of a rainbow... cannot be found.  Shit!  This whole deal might be a setup.
"Have I offended thee?"
"No!  Not you, that bastard Mark," she hisses.  "The house of Iris... a place, something solid," she mumbles, "not a symbol.  Okay, that's better... maybe... I think.  You've helped greatly by bringing this connection to mind.  Is there any place you know, a building, or a group of people, anything called by the name Iris?"  A puzzled expression and negative nod do little to ease Leona's anxiety.  The possibility of being trapped in a paradox is not a comforting notion.
"Well... that's later anyway.  I need to stay with what's immediate.  I need arrows, and tightly woven linen, enough that I might fashion a tent."
"Shafts and bolts there," he points. "That cabinet in the hallway.  Take the bed linens for your tent; they are of the finest cloth.  There is a sleeping room off the kitchen for the squires.  You and Lady Beth may find garments there.  Though not meant for a lady, they are clean, of good cloth, and perchance may be a better suit to your size.  Search through the lodge, anything of mine is yours.  Were times better, milady, I would make you no less an offer."
An interesting choice of words, she reflects.  By the time Hale and Beth have descended from their tower of ecstasy, Leona has laid out the cloth from which to assemble the crew's new home.
Karn graciously interrupts.  "Milady's bath is ready."
Alas, her turn to soak.  Though not unappreciated, she is relieved to be free of the wrappings that have secured her rib cage of late.  As if being black and blue from head to toe weren't enough, her torso is now further complemented by several antagonizingly sensitive concentric red rings.  Brush burns from the binding's edge, a toll exacted over the last two nights by the joggling afforded of their escape conveyance.  Overall, her natural skin tone has take on more the appearance of an exotic caterpillar than that of a young woman.  Slipping into the hot water briefly recounts the thrill a French fry might experience when first dropped into boiling oil.
The stinging subsides, and she's soon squeaky clean and thoroughly aglow for it.  She exits the spa in her fine clean squire's appointments.  Sure enough, however, soon as the drill sergeant takes a brake, discipline falters.  Resident temptress and part-time match-maker, Lady Beth is still shamelessly cloistered within her blanket.  Hardly suitable attire were there need of a hasty exit or call to arms.
Hum, but what's this?  Leona muses, knowing it's not like Beth to stay still for more than a few seconds, especially when she's on her feet.  Something's captured her attention, for she's acquired a twig from the kindling pile and got a cautious eye on the bookcase.  "What are you up to over there?"  Leona plies inquisitively.
"Look at this!  It does look like a mouse."  Leona investigates.  One of the little bats has found a comfortable niche for a snooze between several musty old volumes.  Beth is torn between keeping a safe distance and her curiosity, thus her need of a defense twig.
"What ya going to do with the stick?"  Leona inquires soberly.
"Umm, I don't know."
"Leave it be.  You wouldn't want some giant hairy creature poking you with a stick in the middle of the night."
"I'm not a giant hairy creature," she responds indignantly with a tilt of her head and furled brow.
"If you wake it up, far as that little bugger's concerned, you are."
"I'm not going to hurt it."
"Have you explained that to the bat?"
"Gimmy a break, will ya?" she snaps in a whisper.
"If you promise to be calm, okay?"
"I'll be calm," she fires back quietly; so as not to alarm her exotic discovery.  With that assurance, Leona slowly presents the back of her hand to intercept another little interloper that's begun climbing Beth's blanket.  Beth glances down to see what's going on; her eyes light up.  "Eeeeekk!" she murmurs.
"Just be still... there's no problem unless you make it one."  The tiny invader's wings shutter as it searches for balance, crawling sluggishly onto the back of Leona's hand.  She raises her palm slowly, positioning it to allow the critter continue and take hold of a loose leaf binding adjacent to its sleeping cousin.  The one Beth discovered was just a quaint tiny ball of fur, but this little bug muncher has its wings half spread and is looking back with an endearing face only a mother could love.  As the more adventurous one snuggles in, its tiny cousin emits a reassuring squeak that the traveler's found a groovy place to hang out.
"Is that ugly or what?"
"Probably thinks the same about us.  Haven't you found a comb yet?  Your going to scare them."
"Huh!  They can't see can they?"
"It has eyes doesn't it?"
"Where'd it come from?" she chirps.
"Probably from under the lower shelf, when you woke it."
"What?"  Beth back steps and warily stoops to discover a dozen more tufts of fur dangling from the underside of the shelf she was cozied up against.  "Ugh, it's a nest!" she warns.  "What are they doing under there?  I thought they lived up in the roof."  Realizing now she's outnumbered, Beth retreats several steps to gain some fighting space in case there's an assault.  She doesn't even trust woolly caterpillars any more since her shocking personal discovery that even cute little orange lady bugs actually do bite.
"You know how it is in the dorms," Leona replies smugly.  "When the guys come wandering back in the middle of the night, they can usually find the building, but it's more of a challenge to find their rooms.  Leave them be, they won't bother anything.  You need to get dressed," Leona emphasizes, "and find your crossbow.  Don't forget we're still in deep shit here."
"Yeah, I know," her friend admits timidly.  "I just needed some goof-off time."  Thus, the flying mice are left in peace while Beth shuffles off toward the squire's boutique to select her new fall wardrobe and find a comb.  Her furry new friends not entirely forgotten though, she glances back with a wary eye to make sure she's not being followed.
In need of thread and cart measurements, Leona ventures off to the barn.  Karn observes her approach is painfully hindered by the injuries to her foot and leg.  He has refitted the bed with clean straw, refilled the team's feed sack, and is presently rinsing the water keg.  "I thought it wise to refill with fresh that all is ready to depart.  You should sit, milady, keep the weight off your foot."
"I'll make it."
Karn replies with a weary expression and slight twist of his head, as much to say, 'who do you think your bull shitting?'
Leona nods her agreement and settles upon a nearby stack of wooden planks with a sigh of relief.  Looking back to Karn with a battered face while delicately caresses her left forearm to ease the aching, she offers a minimum smile.
"Is there any way I may assist, milady?"
"Be great If you know where I could score a dime bag or half a pound of Tylenol."  Taking note of Karn's puzzled expression, she adds, "pay me no mind, Sir.  I jest with you.  Though there is much discomfort, the good news is none of my aches are throbbing.  That would be a bad indication.  And you, how is your arm."
Very well, thank you, milady."  Karn assures, "Aches some, but much better than ever I expected."
"Good.  I take it you don't think we should stay much longer?"
Comfort and security are not equals here," Karn reminds.  "We should not delay too long.  I suspect Roux has posted solders at the manor about three hours off by the road coming round the lake.
"The one we're watching?"
"Yes.  Any force at arms would likely approach by that route.  From the time they come to view, we have two minutes, maybe three.  Few know of the way we came in and the barn would hide our departure, but not for long.  I'm encouraged that none were here last night to greet us.  Eventually someone will be reminded of this place and they'll come."
"We really need one more night to recoup, if we can.  We'll bail out first thing in the morning.  Have you a drill, an auger, something to bore holes?  Can you make wooden pegs, do you think?"
"I'm not a peg-maker by trade, but I've had some whittling experience.  I shall get it done."
"We've all ventured in new directions of late, this is but another."  With a piece of charcoal from the forge she marks the desired locations, eight along either side of the cart and several on the seat back and tailgate.  "We'll need a couple of poles that can be lashed vertically to the seat back and tailgate and another to cross over top and support the cover, strong but light."  
Once the grand design is approved and construction details worked out, Karn produces a hand brace and three crude wood-boring bits.  Holding them up for her examination, he inquires, "And what size pegs would milady desire?"
 Karn's task assigned, she concentrates on the more technical problems--that of lamp maintenance.  Cleaning the spent chalky residue from the crude devices and salvaging what remains of the precious fuel.  There is only enough for emergencies, an hour, two at most.  Unless the moon is bright and the sky clear, hereafter they must risk being identified.
"Oh, I nearly forgot.  Thread, is there any thread, needles, too?"
"For sewing?" Karn inquires.
"Yes!"
"I think not, that craft is done at the manor, not here.  If any is to be found it would reside in the squire's quarters.  Could leather laces serve?"
"I could make do, and it would be stronger."
"There are cobbler's tools and leather in the kitchen storeroom."
So goes the day: Karn drilling holes and whittling pegs, Leona stitching, Hale standing the watch and Beth trying to find just the right combination of leather, suede and lace to embody a fashion statement.
Before retiring, chairs are precariously balanced at each entrance and strung with snares, then stacked with pots to trigger a calamity if the door they guard is disturbed.  Night passes quickly and quietly.
Final assembly of the tent is the first order of the new day.  A series of loops are incorporated into each of the long edges to catch the pegs Karn's installed in the sides of the cart.  Along one side the loops are fixed so as to securely anchor the edge.  Along the other, slacked loose that once in place they may be cinched up tight pulling the cloth taut over the crossbar.  The end closures are strung with tethers so either flap may be tied off to the vertical posts.  All in all, theoretically capable of keeping them dry.
A strange brew simmers in one of the hearth's caldrons--a mixture of ash, topsoil, red clay, and ground charcoal.  Fine bleached linens, once adorning the beds of noble guests are soon converted to a more practical drab muddy gray.  Chunks of clay and ash are then artistically smeared over the material to render the fabric indiscernible within the forest's shadows.  Indeed, thoughts of a similar technique being applied to the team have come to mind.
The camouflaged material is dried and taken to the barn for a trial installation.  Beth and her crossbow tag along.  She is quite pleased with her new outfit, having found the perfect complement, a wide-brimmed leather hat.  Which for reasons known only to her, now requires that she speak with a corny German accent.  Of no practical help, and soon bored of the tent rigging, she wanders off nosing around the barn.  Perhaps a pair of long gloves might be found or better yet something akin to a purse.  "Take care," Karn advises.  "There may be snakes about looking for mice."
It's not long before she discovers several baby chicks huddled in the straw.  "Hey guys... there's pe-pes back here."
Karn looks to Leona with a puzzled expression.  She clarifies, "baby chickens."
Of course, as soon as she advances to capture one, the little birds scurries away in total panic.  Beth soon finds herself confronted by a protective old hen flapping her wings and reading her the riot act.  Having stated her case, the hen struts off followed by a herd of tiny yellow fuzz balls.  All of whom are now quite assured that whatever that was, it won't bother them again.  Beth retreats to the tent raising, first with a smile and southern bellish manner, "they're sooo cute."  Then, logic of a sort.  "But now, I'll think of them every time I see eggs in the grocery."  And finally, stark realization, "darrnnnn!" she winces.  Leona casts a sympathetic glance, knowing hot wings and omelets are out of the question for at least a few weeks.  Karn watches quietly as Beth wanders back toward the lodge, all those concerns so profound and heavy just beneath her fine new leather hat.
Leona consoles with a quiet chuckle.  "She'll get over it, don't worry.  Sometimes she has a... priorities conflict."
Within the hour other concerns well beyond the fate of an egg arise.  Two horseman approach, attired neither for sport nor combat, but very well dressed to be sure.  Not commoners these.  One a young man of his early twenties, Doran called he.  The other a sprout, hardly sixteen and brother of Doran, Adair is he.  Fortunately another lad faithfully mans his post and thus, is keen upon their presence.  The rest afforded Hale's knee of late, earned of that bothersome crutch, now repaid.  He moves with ease, quickly and quietly to warn his comrades.  "Heads up!  We've got company."
"How many?" Leona asks.
"I saw two."
"Where's Beth?"  Hale hesitates.  "I thought she was out here with you guys."
"She went back in... I think."
In fact Beth has refilled the vat, set the charcoal aglow and settled in for another pleasant soak.  'Tis after all a new day and bathing is such a delight.  Besides, there is much to contemplate what with the pe-pes and thoughts of scrambled eggs.
Karn is fast to the loft and up into the rafters for an overview of their circumstance from the high ground.  Choosing to return more at the convenience of gravity than ladders, time being of the essence.  "Two we can handle," he assures.  "I saw no others, but others may follow.  The mounts do not appear as military and they are left unattended.  I suspect these fellows visitors."  He takes Leona's arm.  "I'll go in by the front first, drawing their attention, you then from the lake side.  We shall have them between us."  Catching Hale's sleeve, he advises, "You with her lad, but stay outside.  Keep watch that no others come unannounced till our present business is complete."
The two young men enter the great hall a bit wary that their keys were not required to loose the door.  "'Tis a fine house," concludes the younger lad.  "Father's come into a grand arrangement."
"Yes, and as this is so far from the manor, while dear father tends his politics, we shall engage of great mirth and levity here I think."
Doran's attention is caught by a faint breath of smoke lingering in the air.  "The fireplace is still fresh.  Someone's been here."  He points out the blankets and such haphazardly strewn before the hearth.  With nothing of worth to lose the wise would be quickly away, off to gather reinforcements.  But wisdom seldom travels in companionship with the young and is particularly lacking among the young and arrogant.  They choose to play the fools, drawing weapons rather than considering a gracious retreat to their steeds.
"Kerplumk!"
The brothers look to each other; an uninvited guest has given themselves away.  "Take heed!"  Adair whispers, Doran's reply but a nod.  They advance toward the door separating Beth the Prune from their curious eyes.  Cautiously they enter to seek the source of that foreboding displacement.  Their quest soon finds them before a resplendent young creature confined to a tub by chains of modesty and not but a large plumed hat to offer her refuge.  Wisely Beth freezes, this a turn of events requiring careful diplomacy.
"Brother, I think we've found us a water nymph here," Adair suggests smugly.  The younger lad smiles, surely wishing it were so as lore would have genuine nymphs of any persuasion notoriously easy to get along with.  Their sole purpose to entice, seduce and mate with any who come near.
"More likely a gypsy, I'd say." Doran suggests, "so there's bound to be more.  How many friends have ya brought along with ya?" he inquires of his younger brother's new-found fantasy. 
Confronted thus, Beth restrains her urge to launch into a southern tantrum or threats of retribution.  Better these two are kept unaware that her allies dally about in the vicinity.  "Gimmy a break, do I look like someone who travels with a gang?  I was on my way to Mr. Orchard's house.  It started raining so I ducked in here to get cleaned up some."
"How did you get in?"
"Karn's a very good friend of mine.  I have a key.
"He's been dragged off to the Keep, probably hung by now.  Hence, if you desire to stay, you must make new friends.  Now get thee out of my bath."
"I will not," she exclaims sternly.  Doran is not the sort to be put off, least of all by some helpless featherweight wench.  His approach is met with splashes and a barrage of soggy soap bars.  Beth's voice is still rising, "Leave me be!  I'm warning you.  I'm a witch... I'll turn you both into frogs."
"Well now, if ya do, being as frogs are so fond of water," Adair muses, "can I get in the tub with ya?"
"Not even in your dreams, creep!"
Doran's temper flares.  "Enough!" he shouts, about to reach for Beth until a new and strangely familiar voice entreats from behind.  "Enough is right, lad.  Come away now and let her be."  Karn greets them with a friendly nod and sword in hand, though not in a particularly menacing way as the point rests upon the tip of his boot.
"Milord," Adair acknowledges.  "Father said you was taken off to the Keep, and these lands had now passed to our name."
"Perchance, there has been a misunderstanding, lad."
Adair has been spared the treacherous details of how this discord was set in motion.  Doran, the eldest, on the other hand, knows it was his father who betrayed Karn's trust.  Thus, securing for the Lord of Orchard an appointment upon the gallows.  Karn's estates thus forfeit, rewarded to his father, Lord Bredon.  Such craft is not without debt and such debts are seldom discharged with mere coin.  Vendetta's a topic that can weigh heavily upon the mind.  Thus, Doran appreciates that he and his brother may end up as a down payment for his father's deceit.  Knowing also that to cross blades with Karn would surely have them both carved up like a festive roast.  A bargaining chip is needed and none but the frivolous maiden in the soup kettle is at hand.
He back steps quickly toward Beth's water park, attempting to lay his blade aside her throat.  The keen-edged metal employed to grant him reprieve abruptly shatters though it were a piece of roofing slate.  One sharp shard wickedly slashes Doran's cheek; a disfiguring gift to remind treachery is oft it's own reward.  The hilt's swept from his grasp.  It whirls away to ring upon the wall.  Before the fractured remnants settle to the floor, Karn has poked his blade at Adair's backside to assure he does not unwisely join his older brother's folly.  Wide-eyed and bleeding, Doran faces a different maiden now, this one with coal black hair and eyes of steely gray.  Not quite so fair nor defenseless, her intense gaze warning that further misdeed may render an abrupt end to his reckless affairs.  The breeze made by her sword's passing and the sound of good iron dying will long reside among Master Doran's most troubling memories.
Even Beth was unaware Leona had slipped in from the adjoining pantry at the rear.  She nearly sprang from her tub as might one of the little green creatures she purports to conjure.  "You little prick! Beth hisses.  "You're going to wish you were a frog."  Thus redeemed, she plops back down into her kettle.  Young Master Adair of his own accord has laid both sword and dagger quietly to rest upon the floor.  A piercing stare from Leona silently instructs Doran to follow suit.  He concedes, but not without some disdain, casting his weapons alongside his brother's hardware.
"Haven't you forgotten something?" Leona advises, noticing geometry most likely that of a boot knife beneath one leg of Doran's trousers.  "Since you choose to deceive, I shall have your boots off, too."
"Milord," Doran protests to Karn.  "My brother and I are gentlemen of an honorable family.  Hence, father will answer your ransom demands.  He probably searches for us even now.  If we are harmed, you know His Lordship himself will muster twenty good men and hunt you down."
Karn frowns.  "Only twenty?" he objects sarcastically.  "How do you suppose they might succeed where a 150 have already failed?"  He grabs a handful of aristocratic ruffles, pulling Doran nigh.  "If you survive this adventure, a day may come when you learn of how fortunate you were, having crossed this maiden and lived to tell the tale."  Beth is still fuming, and to prove it she pelts her antagonist hard as she can with her last soggy gob of soap.  "See how you've riled up my guests?" Karn continues.  "A gentleman, even those born of a brackish lot, takes not a helpless maiden as his shield."  Giving a firm yank to the arrogant lad's trouser leg, Karn exposes the concealed dagger.  "Now do as milady commands... or I shall have those boots off along with your feet, and carve up what remains of your insolent hide to feed my catfish."
Meanwhile, Master Adair is in complete agreement with Leona's request, perfectly reasonable he thinks as one aspiring to a future well above that of mere fish food.  Siting himself down alongside his brother, he frantically looses straps and laces eager to free his limbs of any offending contraband.  The site of blood dripping from his brother's chin does little to instill confidence in their future well being.
Being as pasta about to spill over the rim of a boiling kettle, Beth peers down from her shinny copper tureen to watch as the villains are taken to task.  "Turn them into frogs, Leo," she teases.  "We'll dip'em in corn meal and fry us up a skillet of greasy frog fritters."  Continuing now in a significantly heightened tone of voice, she pleads, "Is this party over yet?  Can I finish my bath... pleasseeee?"  She slams the water's surface with her good hand, splashing everyone.  The injured paw reserved of necessity to keep hold of her ever-durable hat.
For lack of better, their guests' wrists are bound with their own boot laces.  The lads face each other, sitting on either end of a flat wooden board dredged up from the barn.  Leather straps salvaged from old harnesses are buckled about their ankles and knees lashing them to the plank.  None of this work is nearly secure as it should be, but the plank at once keeps them together and yet apart such that no skullduggery may ensue.  Doran's wound is cleaned and bound with several loops of linen lapped around under his chin and over the top of his head.  Beth has topped it off with a large silly bow.  He appears as a character from a film of the silent era, some slapstick comedy involving a toothache.
Karn and Leona have adjourned to the porch opposite the lake front to consider the fate of their guests.  The watch must be maintained, even more so now and these two present a pressing security issue.  Simply stated, they have not the manpower to maintain two separate vigils.
Karn thus presents the facts, assumptions, and his argument for their demise.  "They've provisions only for one day.  I know these lads and they are not the sort to be hunting for their dinner.  Either they intended to stay only this night, Bredon having sent them to take account of his loot, or servants will follow within a day's time."
"Assuming they've come only to inspect the place, how soon do you think before they're missed?"
"three hours, half a day at most to return.  Concerns will arise well before nightfall on the morrow.  We may expect a search party two hours past sunrise day after next, six to eight men.  Then again, they may have rushed ahead of a larger group who could turn up at any moment.  'Tis enlightening these lads have arrived at all.  Bredon would never have let his sons come out here if he knew I were free.  I'm sure he would not risk these two if we had to take them hostage, but Roux would not hesitation."
"If Bredon doesn't know, then the general population hasn't been alerted either," Leona suggests.  "Such good fortune could free us up to move about."
"I'm thinking we are not yet exposed.  To do so demands Roux acknowledge there are those afoot who have forcibly declined his hospitality.  If one has prevailed, so may others--hardly the sort of event to inspire confidence among his subjects.
"With a crew the size of what came after us?"
"Likely very few if any know 'twas a lone maiden wrought such chaos and stole away three of his prisoners.  If word of such a breach found ears, it would be dispelled, blamed upon rebels in concert with demons and the black arts.  Any successful infraction must fall beyond the deeds of men.  Some of the tale will be dismissed with laughter and wine and some will end covered with dirt and quickly sown to grass."
"I think it's a universal constant reliable as mathematics.  You can always depend on politicians and generals to blame anyone but themselves.  Where I come from, we also have what are called corporations and religions, three layers of feudal lords.  Though different restraints are applied, each is just as bent on intimidating their vassals.  When their interests run in parallel there is much wealth to be shared among them.  But when they oppose, a weapon called technology comes upon the fields of battle and the common men are ground to dust with tragic efficiency."
Karn's disposition freezes abruptly.  He raises a hand to caution then a finger to his lips suggesting silence.  Something's provoking the brush and twigs crackle underfoot.  He motions her toward the far corner, a precaution to assure none are approaching from the opposite direction as well.  Quickly now, he advances toward the disturbance to find out what incites this restless foliage.  Leona finds no threat from her vantage point and shifts attention back toward Karn.  Calmly he motions her at ease, the tension transformed to curiosity.  A grand stag cautiously eyes them from the thicket's edge hardly twenty yards away.  The deer she has seen at home are drafts by comparison; till now one of such stature could only be perceived from the pages of National Geographic.  Karn teases, "Would milady care for venison this evening?"
"Don't you dare, we have more than enough to keep us.  Beautiful!  Let it be."  A nod signifies her wish is his command.
The buck snorts, alerting his harem.  Four doe sprint away into the forest while he maintains a defiant stance between the lodge and thicket.  Once his consorts are safe away the stag turns and bolts.  Three vigorous bounds and he's gone.
"You feel no one knows we're fugitives yet?"
Karn nods affirmatively.  "And none shall be the wiser, least till Bredon finds his sons.  Perhaps 'tis best they have nothing to tell.
Thoughts of silencing the young men add a distinct chill to the air.  What if this is somehow real and not just a clever game I play?  "I'd rather not."
"There is no need of your involvement, milady."
"No!  All we gain is another enemy in their father; we've more than we need of those.  Could they not serve better if we apply the wisdom of Mr. Stick--the principles of disinformation?"
"Of what?"
"They may offer the means to confound Roux, perchance a wild-goose chase.  Suppose we allow them to overhear our plans and mislead as to our intended destination?  If we scare them enough... their tale of woe becomes convincing, which in turn adds creditability to whatever they might overhear."
"Their restraints concern me.  With no shackles or locks to our service, a few hours left alone and they will be free and on their way.  The moon is coming bright again and with the lake shore to guide they could find their way at night.  An entire day of travel with no cares of being set upon would be lost to us."
"I'm sure there's a way, but... you know what?  It may not make any difference.  I'm already on the shit list around here.  You could say this is my second offense, or maybe third."
"How do you mean?"
"I got into a ruckus with some lout at the Brobose Inn about a week ago.  Few days later when I discovered Beth was at the Keep, I found my own likeness posted alongside hers.  So I'm known to have a gold piece on my head.  Almost happened again at the Brier Keg.  I doubt anyone could tell it was me, but you--"
"Was it you took the day pot to one of Roux's auditors then and whooped that rascal Pounds, too?"  He rolls his head back, motioning toward the sky as one suddenly enlightened.  His attention returns to the battered face of his favorite she-devil.  "'Tis a relief to know all three are one and the same.  I feared the land was being invaded by Amazons and none but myself yet to realize it."
"Don't be a smart-ass," she bids in a hushed embarrassed tone.  "He was looking for an easy mark and I wasn't in the mood for any more bullshit."
"Arguments sparked by that event set me on the road to the gallows."
If he hadn't been there none of us would have survived the Keep.  This is being manipulated--has to be!  Reality's not this well coordinated.  So it is a game, right?  But haven't you had this argument before? 
"Milady!"
"Yes!  I'm here... how's that again?"
"When I heard the tale I remarked, and not in jest, some bashing of auditors was past due.  Tempers rose, sides were chosen, and quite an upheaval commenced.  Roux's goons were upon me at first light the next morn."
"Sorry you got dragged in on my account."
"Some wisdom was to be gained from it.  I learned friends and enemies oft appear the same.  Pardon my forwardness, but also it appears I was meant to be there."
"Yes... I was just wondering about that.  Okay then.  As to the fate of our guests, I want to leave them alive."
"As you wish.  Shall I beat them to a pulp then, get them in the proper mood for scaring?"  Leona casts an unhappy frown in Karn's direction. "I thought not."
"Fear and pain are not necessarily related.  Fear is crafted within the mind; 'tis there we must go to frighten," Leona reminds.  "They would harbor a belief of things magical--dragons, witches and whatever--would they not?"
Karn ponders her inquiry with care, not wishing to offend.  "Everyone does."
"Then we shall bind them with their own doubts and superstitions; no chain of iron restrains more firmly.  We must play a little mind game I know, it's called, 'good cop, bad cop.'"
The captives are temporarily relieved of their cumbersome wooden plank and stashed in the pantry, a windowless corridor lined of empty shelves and the preferred abode of many insects and mice.  "Since you lads and your back stabbing father are living in my fine manor house now," Karn implies, "and since I'm a little short of coin at the moment, I must insist you provide a slight advance against the rents.  I know you understand."  Karn draws his dagger and snips their purse strings with a smile.  Before departing he further warns, "Ya know... I've had a hard time keeping ya two alive.  That little vixen you was tormenting wants your balls.  I've got things smoothed over some, 'least for a while.  You would do well not to stir this pot; wouldn't take much and the both of ya will end up in the stew."  The young aristocrats are now left to themselves.  Thus, providing opportunity to consider Karn's supposed intervention on their behalf, meditate upon their recent sins and torment one another with tragic scenarios of deeds yet undone upon their person.  Several quiet hours are allowed to pass for the sake of credibility until they are allowed to overhear bits of a presumably private conversation.  The exchange includes hints of their captor's future destination and discussion of fictitious demons known as Squillets.  Hale purports to argue in their defense, implying their actions did not warrant such vile consequence.  Beth of course wishes them a most agonizing and devious end, which confirms a measure of Karn's trustworthiness.  The good cop has succeeded in gaining at least slight of their confidence.
During the next few hours the cart's readied and provisioned.  A generous supply of clean bandages is added to the depleted first aid kit.  To shed evening's chill and morning's dew, several fleece-lined leather vests are conscripted along with more of the wide-brimmed hats that have become fashionable in some circles of late.  Personal umbrellas of a sort not unlike Beth's, but for the pheasant feathers artfully tucked under a belt she's trimmed and added as a hat band.  A change of clothes for each, many socks, and anything that could be construed or adapted as an under garment is spirited off to their cause.  All that remains of the oil from the manor's lamps is gathered along with an ax, a piece of flat iron from the forge, another pot, utensils, arrows, a hammer, and crossbow bolts--the practical everyday things.  Beth for her part has confiscated several goose-down pillows, building herself a nest between the water keg and storage chests.  In all fairness she's not the only one seeking a softer touch.  Two have been deflated somewhat, wrapped in linen and reserved to comfort the cart driver and his shotgun's hind ends.  Hale receives a crash course in cart handling, his only concern, 'Where's the brakes?'  Karn and Leona will ride the mounts graciously provided by their guests.  All is set and ready to go.  All that is, but for the frightening.
A stout heavy clay crock is filled to a fourth with essence of demon.  This infusion, a blend of her own highly flammable liquid fuel, peanut-sized chunks of porous leather, candle's wax, lamp oil, coarse saw-dust, ground charcoal, and several creatively configured slabs of brine-laden husk from Karn's fine country ham.
Neither evil signs nor discord of magic are needed to restrain the supposed, ravenous, blood Thirsty Squellets contained therein.  Rather a good hard cork stopper pressed firmly into the spout will do fine.  Now, a silver clasp scavenged from Karn's fine apparel is crimped over the rim of the crock's mouth.  This is to see that the vessel bursts violently and not just pop its cork.  For all in all, the single purpose of this witch's brew is to be set free in the most frightful and glowing way possible.
"What is this?" Karn inquires.
"One of my favorite things, a little bomb!"
"Is this another spell as that which cursed Roux's encampment?"
"Not exactly, since I've no explosives to spare, for this apparatus containment is the key and then a very rapid pressure drop the means."
"Yes, milady," he agrees completely, but shrugs his shoulders as one without the slightest idea what she's babbling about.
"If they follow your instructions the boiling oil will have the crock burst violently.  Decompression will cause the liquid to vaporize creating a nice fireball.  The sawdust will add a fluffy cloud of sparks and the bits of leather will soak up oil, catch fire, and be thrown in all directions.  To a superstitious observer they will appear to jump out trying to catch those near at hand.   You know, like Ahhh! Run!  The Squillets are loose, panic is what we seek to inspire.  If they investigate when the fire has burned out they'll find the pieces of ham which will appear as tiny charred carcasses."
"Dead Squillets," Karn supposes.
"Yes!  You're getting it!  By such deception the trick is not so easily found a fraud.  They will think they've destroyed a demon and they'll have proof in the flesh for all to behold that it actually existed.  And for future reference a valuable clue, too.  Dead Squillets have the smell of charred ham.  Word of it will spread, and the mention of Squillets may be useful another day.  That is, if they don't drop it themselves, crack it open, and discover the ruse.  If not, the illusion remains intact, adding creditably to what they think they know of our plans.  And you saw for yourself, everything I put in there was real.  No hocus-pocus, no magic.  You could have made this as easily as I."
"There's more oil.  Should we not have filled it to the brim?"
"Well no, it's all about pressure dynamics, the oil's not compressible.  If you fill the crock full, after a few moments in the fire it simply cracks.  All you get is a flare-up, we need a boom."  She flings her arms aside in an expanding fashion to illustrate.  "You see, by leaving it three-fourths empty you provide room for the vapor, which is... compressible and--"  Though Karn is listening, his expression betrays the lack of understanding.  "Never mind!  We'll go over this again later," she assures, "when there's more time."
"Sorcery without magic," he resolves quietly.
"Think of it as politics... on a different level."
The captives are returned to the central room.  This time they are strapped into chairs, their wrists bound separately, one down along each side to the rear legs.  The lads again face each other about eight feet apart.  Aloof and silent, Leona enters, her bag of tricks slung over one shoulder.  She casts an evil eye to each then sets about her mischief.  This time the plank that had been used to separate them is placed upon their knees.  She scrawls allegedly magic writing from one end to the other with a charcoal stick.  Taking special note of the foreboding arrow signs pointing at each of them, The lads watch in dread.  Local lore of such devilish doings has rendered them both frightened stiff.  Next a spindly three-legged stool is set upon the plank midway between the lads.  "Karn," she calls out authoritatively.  "Bring my Squillets!"  He appears carrying the crock at arm's length accompanied by much concern apparent upon his sweating brow.  Placing it ever so gently upon the floor, he sighs of relief, then exits with noticeable haste.  'Tis said all the world's a stage and each a player thereupon.  Should fantasy's game be different then?  For surely none could protest of such fine and wicked jest.
The trick now is to inform without threatening words, as such are the weapons of fools.  Tapping several times upon the crock as to disturb something restrained therein and then placing her ear against the surface as to confirm of its presence, finally a devilish smile upon her face and the deed is done, with not a word.  Now, one could truly say imagined demons are here to play, thus, are bound these fools to stay or else with their lives condemned to pay.  Much to the dread of her prisoners she suddenly shakes the crock violently and places it upon the stool, then tiptoes away backward.  Any excessive rustling of the precariously balanced plank will likely cause the top-heavy assembly to falter sending the crock of antagonized imaginary demons crashing to their freedom.  All this, not unlike watching the construction of one's own gallows.
Liquid fuel is next trickled on the floor in a circle around the fearful lads.  The dire tool of complete silence aptly employed throughout their torment.  When the ends of the fuel circle have met, a wooden stick withdrawn from her pouch seemingly bursts into flame at her touch.  The liquid is ignited and a fire swoops over the floor, racing in both directions at once.  The lads watch, horrified as it momentarily surrounds them in a ring of bright smokeless flame.  Though the display leaves not a mark upon the floor, a lasting impression shall endure upon those it has come seemingly to curse.
"I didn't do nothing, didn't touch her," Adair declares in desperation.  Doran, the older lad, though steeped in perspiration, holds his tongue silent.
Leona shoots a stern expression toward Adair.  "Nor will you ever think it again," an imposing finger pointing toward the crock, "if you break my seal."  Her deeds are proof enough for any intelligent fellow.  This is a witch and their lives hang in the balance of the caution she's just proclaimed.  Leona exits joining Karn who's been discretely watching her charade through a window.  He's dressed down into peasant trimmings for their trip.  If Bredon knew he was hauled off to the Keep, others may as well.  "Think they believed all that poo?" she asks, a tone of delight at her performance.
"I'd say they've both shit their britches."
"Hummm," she smiles.  "Your turn now, they need something to hold on to.  Go in and be the good cop, give them hope."  A few agonizing moments pass, allowing a sense of desperation to set in before Karn enters.  He steps in the open door, motioning to the condemned that they need stay clam.  Then turns, looking around as though he prefers none see him enter their chamber of horrors.  By this, a casual indication he is at odds with their tormentor, the prescribed sign of hope to draw then further into his confidence.
"Can ya help?" Doran pleads.  "What are we to do?
"I can't cross that mark she's made round you two.  They'll catch my scent, wouldn't want them coming for me.  Be thankful she's chosen to play with you, else she'd have your heads in a sack by now.  Most important... don't jiggle about," he cautions.  "If you let that crock fall and break they'll be at you.  You've been marked.  Once they get loose nobody can help ya!"
"What's she put in there?"  Doran inquires in an anguished tone.
"It's a little monster it is and she's had a litter of pups, too."
"A litter!" Doran gasps. 
"Yes, and you know how hungry newborns can be.  I've seen them, like tiny ferrets they are and ferocious as a pack of wolverines."
"What about that fire went around us?"
"Well you see, when her playing is finished, be poor sport to have them loose upon the peasants.  She's fixed them onto you.  If they get loose they're bound to stay within the ring till they starve."  Doran and Adair look to each other with great dismay.  Seems their father's good fortune has snared them a gruesome fate.
"Get us free of this, sir."  Doran pleads, "I swear I'll take your side with father.  I know he'll see you safe away, I swear it."
"And bring a terrible end to all of us?  Have you learned nothing from your foolishness?  This wench is not one I dare to deceive.  Set her a course she has, counting on you fools to topple that crock.  All ya have to do is be still.  Your father knows you're here, does he not?"
"Yes," Doran answers.  "We're expected back for dinner the morrow."
Well then, a day or so they'll come looking for you.  So long as you stay put you'll get by.  If not, 'twill be no fault of mine.  You've been fair warned."
A panic attack looms over young Master Adair.  He appreciates his was to be a life of careless luxury.  This, his first occasion to think such fond prospects may slip away as but a wisp of smoke.  "What about them things?" he cringes, perspiration cascading form the lad's face.  "They got our scent now, we'll never be rid of them."
"Calm yourself, I'm trying to tell you.  A child could do away with them so long as they are not let out.  Only way is to bake them, but don't throw the crock into a fire.  If it breaks, some might get loose and you don't want that.  They'll come right for you.  A good thick bed of red-hot ash is what's needed.  Set the crock in the coal's midst and bank the embers around it.  Be real gentle; don't stir them around.  Then get away 'cause when they die they'll come out in a fury.  I'll take my leave now.  The task is in your hands, fare thee well."
"Wait," Doran pleads.  "My bowels are about to pop."
"Sorry lad, far too late now.  There are times when we all must make sacrifices."  Karn strides away, but stops just short of the door to add, "When next you see your father, be sure to remind him we've unfinished business, he and I."  A gentle clank of the latch and they are left as captives, delicately bound of their own misgivings.
Karn rejoins the others who silently applaud his fine performance.  He bows, graciously accepting their praise.  "I truly enjoyed that," he admits.  "A farce of this sort has never occurred to me as such grand sport."
"A litter indeed," Leona chuckles.  "And sacrifices... that was curl.  I think you a natural born thespian, milord, perhaps we should open a traveling theater company."
Hale encourages the horses onward, Beth's hidden in her nest of down, Karn takes the fore, and Leona the aft.  It's late afternoon and though it would have been nice, there are just too many complications to stay another night.  Four hours at most till dark, and barring catastrophes, the Brobose Inn two days ahead.

Chapter-14

ONE FRIEND NEW, ONE FRIEND OLD,
WHICH THE BETTER IF THE TRUTH BE TOLD?

Two days of bouncing and swaying, in its fondest dreams a milkshake could hardly wish for better.  The countryside's at peace, lovely in every countryside sort of way.  Crickets and frogs chant appreciatively of the previously day's showers, squirrels scamper about the branches overhead, and the pace is such that even a band of battered weary fugitives may slight enjoy.  Indeed, not a hint of any threat has come nigh, spirits are rising and their scraps and bruises are becoming less antagonistic.  Beth and Hale have taken to harmonizing on old Simon and Garfunkel melodies.  Could be they've been nipping at Karn's peach brandy reserves.  They start late in the morning to avoid the rush hour, stay out of sight till near the close of day and ride the open lanes wondering about the stars and enjoying moon's increasing light.
'Tis late afternoon when the gables of the Inn and the roof's articulate array of dormers first comes to view.  Election is made to wait till light of day has foreclosed allowing the more discreet shades of night embrace their objective.  Though ever so briefly, Leona is a known felon in this neighborhood and care must be observed.  Were she perceived as having found shelter there, her friends would be implicated and could forfeit of breath itself.  No stranger to this neck of the woods either, Karn's better kept from view also.  Though his disfavor is known to hardly any his fugitive status could be declared at any moment. 'Tis but a matter of how long Roux abides it advantageous to conceal his reproach of those who dare to dissent.  For internal political assassinations are a sport that bodes ill even of one's faithful allies.
There seems abundant merriment for a country way stop this time of evening.  Music seeps from within offering a curious incentive to any wandering by.  Several carts and even a coach are to be seen in the vicinity, some special occasion, a wedding perhaps?  Yet still, a gathering until this hour feels out of place for country folk, as most need be up at dawn and off to their fields or flocks.  Leona and Karn approach a lean-to stacked with firewood near the rear kitchen door.  Hale and Beth stay with the cart awaiting an all clear.  "I doubt I'm as easily recognized as you," Leona surmises.  "I'll check in."
As a clock's pendulum would venture from one extreme to the next, no less shall this game of fortunes sway to and fro.  Shackled kitchen knave one week, business manager the next, Art's position  has turned around nicely.
Others as well.  Once the lowly Wannabee of less regard than sweepings from the floor, he too now advanced as newly installed auditor for it seems there's been a recent opening.  He himself reinvented of late to overcome the negative image projected by his former mentor, he's gone so far as even to paying for his own ale.  And thus, no less enticed to the vicinity as any other by a radical new concept known as Happy Hour.  Nature's call has surely spared his life tonight, for his late evening entrance to enjoy a nightcap has been slight delayed.  Seeking the privacy of shadow to relieve himself, his presence alongside an out building adjacent the Inn is handily concealed.  Clear sight provided of those congregating just behind afforded by a kitchen window's light.  Though faces come not to view, he harbors vivid recollection of a certain voice that flings iron pots with deadly precision, his own good health to pursue.  Any honorable man, having found again the evildoer who had maimed a good friend would surely stand forth, call out to challenge, then charge headlong into the fray.  But, by prior invitation that for breakfast he should remain and find portions of himself then served upon toast, unsettling, one could say.  Wiser though, he thinks to quietly abide unseen and preserve all his parts verily intact.  Besides, a shinny gold sovereign might he to gain rather than have his liver this villainous wench to extract!
Opening the rear door a bit apprehensively, Leona peeks into the kitchen.  The clatter of pots and pans is in full swing.  Even so, Edie hears the familiar squeak of the worn hinges and turns about taking notice of the intruder.  "And what's this?" she challenges, as her eyes brighten and a great smile comes to be.  "Well, aren't you a wonder, Ev! summon the Dork," Edie shakes her finger wildly toward the main room.  "The maker of morons has come again."  The young lad who tends the stoves, one of Jagat's own, immediately retreats to a distant corner.  He's heard the tale of the Tax man's disfavor and thinks it better not to stand too near.
Leona's quick to restrain the kitchen maid's enthusiasm, laying a finger cross her lips to invoke both caution and quiet.  She gathers the two stout little ladies together for a quick conference.  "A lot has happened," she pleads.  "Better then none of the customers know I'm here."
They both nod their understanding.  After all, this is not the first secret they've kept on her behalf.  "What's happened to your face, child?"  Ev observes quietly, touching the softer back of her fingers to Leona's cheek.
"Just a bump, it's fine now.  Where's Art?  He's still here isn't he?"  Edie nods a yes.  "Good, it was past time he did something right.  Ask him to come back here, but don't tell him why."  Edie scampers off to retrieve the Dork, while Ev rescues a crude wire basket of French fries from a kettle of boiling lard.  Leona samples one from a heap upon the counter; not bad actually, especially for any harboring a serious addiction to bacon.  Art's applying his marketing skills fully intent on whipping the Brobose into the area's first fast food, cappuccino cafe, dance hall and brothel with a liquor license.
Edie saunters over to Art with the coyness of a secret agent sent upon a covert mission.  He's presently organizing the next set by a group of local minstrels.  They've contracted to entertain the guests until the last call in exchange for a copper and a hardy measure of ale.  Their tempo leaning seriously toward the medieval, Art endeavors to explain his theory of jazz/Gothic.  Free of his shackles and better attired than when last he toiled for his fair Leona, he looks to have settled in quite well.
Cloe's prancing about serving up finger-food and ale.  The concept of French frying has opened a whole new world; in addition to 'taters there are breaded pieces of chicken, venison and catfish.  It's just that everything tastes like bacon.
There are three travelers staying the night, all elderly gentlemen of moderate means.  Six locals still dally about, merchants of one sort or another--which is to say, those having others designated to rise early and toil in their stead.  The new atmosphere at the Brobose has become a rural novelty.  Art is in league with two of these fellows on various business activities.  Indeed, he has inquired of dearest Cloe, that perchance she may know of other lovely young ladies likewise so inclined as to privately entertain the gentlemen folk.
"Master Art," Edie, standing tall upon her toes whispers in his ear.  "Your presence is requested in the kitchen, sir."  He hesitates for a moment to wonder why such a formal tone.  Something's up, for there appears a twinkle in her eye.
"A moment with these gentlemen, if I may?" he entreats with a note of political savvy.  "Then I am at your beck and call, darling."  Oh my, how she and Ev love to hear his sweet nothings; he's learned quickly how to ply them both and have his way.
Edie moves off to let Klena know her fugitive friend is on the premises.  Though he holds no ill feelings, word of this does not fare well with Jagat Bose, proprietor and master of this tiny domain.  His first concern is to scan the guests to see if any may have been present on the lady's previous visit.  Thankfully, there would seem none about that might recall her face.  Then, a cautious eye over his shoulder toward the kitchen where all are cackling as a brood of hens.  Have they no concern of what consequence her presence might invoke?  And a gold piece no less to be had of it.  Back to his patrons then for a second glance.  Be there any half as bold or so obnoxious as the former auditor who might make sport of a maiden in man's attire?  Neither fools, drunkards, nor lads thinking themselves excessively possessed of brass are to be seen.  Perhaps he may yet have a peaceful ending to this cautious state of affairs.
Klena offers a welcoming hug to her friend, thought lost.  Her customary sober expression replaced by a glowing smile.  "I see ya been roughhousing again."  They embrace.
"Yeah, I've had better days," Leona admits, "but things are quiet at the moment."
"We heard nothing of thee after the constables left.  All the gossip finds its way here.  The lack of it concerning you was a relief in a way."
"Whatever came of that jackass I hit with the kettle?"
"Constables carried him out and heaved him into a wagon.  We never heard another word of it.  That wart on a toad's ass ya ran off, he's taken over the auditor's duties.  We've only seen him once since.  Cloe came in through the back corner door carrying a chamber pot.  The expression he took on, I thought he peed himself, looked as if Death had tapped him on the shoulder!  Didn't stay to finish his pint, and he paid for it too!" she muses, "Just sort of slithered away.  Far as I've heard he ain't given nobody trouble.  I think you straightened him out fer us."
"Some friends are waiting outside," Leona injects. "I'd like to get them settled into a room if you have one."
"Bring'em in, we have space.  It would be the tower room, I'll have it readied."
"Do you know Karn of Orchard?"
"Lord Karn... Indeed... a good friend of Jagat's--both of us I'd like to think.  They played as children.  Jag's father was squire to them of Orchard, nearly fifty years faithfully rendered to their service.  This Inn was his father's reward."
"He's with me, too."
"Here, Lord Karn, now!  There was word he'd been hurt, a hunting accident or something.  What have ya been up to now?  Gather ya friends in while I tell Jag of Lord Karn's arrival."
Having recognized Leona's voice, Art comes on the scene somewhat apprehensively, hoping his partner's temperament has cooled since last they met.  Time it's said can heal all things, but he knows his X has a very long memory and its only been two weeks.  "Hey, what's up?" he ventures cautiously.
"Beth and Hale are with me."
"Whoa! Great! where they at?"
"Out back.  Give me a minute to get them in here, then we have to talk."
Jagat converges on their fond reunion, somewhat confused as to why the Lord of Orchard might be found in his kitchen.  "Lord Karn, milady.  You say he is here--where?"
"Out back keeping watch," Leona replies, as though wealthy landowners were common as stable boys.
Jagat rushes out to make sense of the situation.  Leona follows, but does not join in for the social pleasantries, being more concerned with her anxious and very tired friends.  Art is left to wonder, not so much who or what has brought a Lord of the land to the kitchen door, but whether he might entice Leona's VIP to try a French fry.  Could be an opportunity afoot.
"Art's still here," Leona advises Hale.  "Everything's cool.  I've got a room for you two.  Nobody here knows you guys, so shouldn't be any problems.  Go on in.  Art will get you settled.  Tell him I'll be a while yet.  I need to get these animals put up."
"What about you?" Beth pleads.  "Don't you ever get tired?"
"Hey, we are still on high alert."  Beth raises her crossbow and nods.  "Good girl.  It's best I stay out of sight as much as possible.  Too many people around here know Karn and some know me.  I don't want to put the Innkeeper and his wife at risk.  They could end up in a world of shit on my account.  Karn and I will stay in the barn."
Beth smiles, "Ahaaa!"
"Cool it!"  Leona advises.
"Hey, you're running out of opportunities you know.  I would try to find somewhere else to hide your little pet snake though.  I could see it as a turnoff for some guys."
"Bird!  Oh shit, I completely forgot."  Her hand instinctively rises to her breasts.  "I've lost him!"
"I'm not surprised," Beth complains, "riding on that wagon seat all night would rattle the wax out of your ears."
"I can't believe I just forgot him.  I'm sure he wasn't with me when Stick bound up my ribs."
"Probably got tired of all your banging around, you know.  Even a snake has limits," Beth clarifies most assuredly.  "Slithered off to a safer neighborhood to find a nice little lady snake... and settle down."
"The explosion!  I'll bet that's when he got lost.  Damn, I hope he's all right."
"Be gooodddd," Beth coos with a devilish smirk.  "See ya later."
"Yeah, maybe after the crowd clears out I'll come in for a brew."
"Is Art coming with us?"  Hale asks.
"Don't know yet, it's his call.  But I won't be swinging by this way again."  Hale turns toward the door.  Leona catches his arm for a serious afterthought.  "Talk to him; he's got off the track here, way off.  Maybe he'll listen to you.  But know this... and make sure he understands, In the morning I'm leaving, with or without."
Beth and Hale mosey off toward the light of the open doorway.  Once out of earshot, Hale inquires in a low cautious tone, "Why you trying to fix her up with Karn?  What about Art?"
"She needs some release, and soon.  I think Art's skipped his turn."
"No way!" Hale insists.
"Yeah, well then what the hell is he doing here while she's getting her ass whipped all over town?  And don't let him talk you into joining any of his bullshit ventures.  I'm not going to end up on the dessert cart at the kennel, got it?  Where Leo goes, I'm going, too."
Hale keeps nodding yes to every few words.  Prior experience has shown her tone is getting dangerously close to the flash point.  That's when she starts anticipating the answers to her own questions and gets madder at each imagined reply.  Unless he drops it or changes the subject to interior decorating, it's all going to be his fault--just because.
Jagat and Karn have locked in an enthusiastic bear hug.  "Looks as though you've taken a fall," Jagat surmises.  "Rumor had you lost, milord.  'Tis good to see you well."
"The kindling had been stacked, my friend.  I was only hours from being as the soot rising from your hearth."
"I don't understand.  There was word you were hunting, lost for a while in the mountains, injured!"
"More so lost in the dungeons of the Keep."  Jagat's expression becomes more confounded.  "Allow me tend the horses so the others may join their friends, them we'll talk of that scoundrel Roux."
"Why do they wait out in the dark?
"Our commander demands we remain ever cautious, ready to move on the snap of a twig."
"Commander? the wench with the temper?"  Jagat presumes.  Karn nods.  "Looks to me she has the team in hand and your friends come nigh.  This is confusing, milord.  Perhaps I misunderstand?"
The former Master of Orchard turns as Hale and Beth step into the glow of the open doorway, both carry crossbows, locked and loaded.  "You two are going to get spoiled," he teases with a smile.  "These folks can actually cook."  Art ushers his friends in, all the while eyeing their weapons as though they were dragging dead skunks along by their tails.
Karn's thoughts return to Leona.  "What do you know of her, this maiden who heaves iron pot and lightning bolts about?"
"She doth not suffer fools... nor auditors lightly.  Yesterday I think it was, we found another of his teeth.  I'm sure you've heard the tale of our auditor's undoing.  I'm told there was a bounty.  I take it you've paid her way free and she's bound to your service now."
"Somewhat," Karn offers quietly.
"Take care, friend... I've not seen more rage in man nor beast than she can muster.  Caution also, it seems not to dull her wit.  Most wenches so incised tend suddenly to lack of wisdom, know you this, calm and deadly she remains."
"Yes, I've noticed that, too.  This lad, the one bound to you, what of him?"
"He's well educated, clever with his words, learns fast, very smart in the ways of commerce, but dumb as a twit when it comes to common sense.  Talks of games a lot and dangerous exploits--I think most of them if not all are in his dreams.  Doubtful he could defend himself from a gander, two would have him up a tree."  Jagat chuckles, "They appear an inconsistency, turned 'round backward."
Karn half smiles, nodding his agreement.  "I much prefer them as they are.  I was not joking about the Keep."
"How so milord?" 
"Trust that at times those calling themselves friend would sell your life for a copper.  Bredon, formerly Lord of Kains Bridge, has done so with my confidence.  Henceforth you may call him Lord of Orchard also, least till he an I meet again."
"Lord Bredon has brought you low?  Are you now then Lord of Kains Bridge?"
"I'm less than a thief and least of all forgiven... nor released to my freedom of Roux's kindness.  'Twas that wild maiden now tending the horses paid my way free.  Tricked her way into the Keep to reclaim the little pixie and her lad there.  She alone mind you, not one accomplice to her aid.  Fortunately, I happened to be in her path.  The boy's leg was injured and she had need of a cart driver.  I assure you, I was pleased to offer my services.  For that, she granted my life back to me."  Jagat's face is turning pale.  "I allowed you mislead yourself a moment ago.  'Tis not she in my service, but I in hers; and I am sworn to the death on this matter." 
 "There was word... of strange happenings at the Keep," Jagat says inquisitively "but none are sure of what sort."
"Her doings, destroyed the gates then sealed it up again."
"What?" Jagat questions.  
"Her cunning has proven Roux a fool," Karn assures.  "He himself and a hundred at arms seek us out even as we speak.  Counting not 40 maybe 50 he's already lost in the attempt," Karn adds, in a tone so casual as to speak of swatting flies.
"You jest," Jagat smiles slyly, "surely!"
"Not a single word is folly, my friend."
 If ever a man could feel his hair turning gray, certainly this stifling sensation now rising up the back of Jagat's neck is that.  "You say 40 of His Lordship's troops... disposed?  Is there an uprising?" Jagat whispers.  "Is the Keep under siege?"
"Neither!" Karn responds quietly.
"How could such a toll be inflicted?"
"When that maiden's provoked this business of flinging chamber pots is child's play, I assure you."
Jagat sits upon the ground; his mind reels with possibilities.  "There have always been a few who spoke of revolt--very few, and very quietly.  Do the people side with her against Roux?"
Karn drops to one knee to console his distraught friend.  "None I know of.  As I am told, all this began when a clay crock was dropped and broken.  I can only suppose something was hiding in that vessel.  It's loose now, and whatever it is it's lit a pyre under the House of Roux."
"She's a sorceress... or worse, a demon!"
"No! I've been over all this ground before.  Though she possesses knowledge uncommon to any I know and constructs her strategies very carefully, I think not.  Neither would a witch toil in pain as she does nor bleed nearly so much."
"You must be tired, milord, and hungry.  Come in, eat, we will make sense of all this." 
"Good friend," Karn continues, raising a hand to bid him hold.  "I tell you again.  I'm a fugitive, you could be hanged and Klena also if you are seen to give aid of any kind."
"I'll send the guests away, close the Inn."
"No! I would stay the night in your loft, out of sight."
"Milord, I --"
"Be not a fool.  If any ask of me, say that I was here, acted strangely and withdrew, you know not where.  As yet, no official proclamation of my crimes or escape has been declared, thus none may rightly fault you.  Time you tend your guests now and I the mounts to see them ready for a quick departure."
"As you would, milord.  The kitchen maids are trusted; I will have food brought out."
--
Seeing the last of them disperse, the Wannabee slinks closer from his hiding place to a shuttered kitchen window, enough so now that voices may be overheard.  Adding a gold piece to his purse would delight to no end and provide a fitting retribution for the pain and insults he's suffered.  This time of night, he surmises two hours at least would be needed to reach the nearest den of constables.  Surely they would demand equal shares of his reward to assist in this villain's capture.  Longer in transit, but wiser that the matter be confided directly to His Lordship's keeper of the watch.  Thus, may he alone claim it all.  Far safer too, for by that all responsibilities fall upon others and he need not participate further in the venture.  Though linger here he must even if all the night to learn their intentions.
--
