Deep within the barn's confines, Leona's secured a lamp and uncovered her abandoned belongings.  "Might I assist milady?" Karn asks.
"My friend Art owes Jagat money for a previous indiscretion.  I was looking here amongst my things for trade goods to that end.  Whether he decides to come along or not at least then he'll be free of debt,  A clean slate as they say where I'm from."  
"Your debts are mine.  How much is owed?" 
"Two silver on Art's behalf and the loan of four coppers to stake my getaway after the chamber pot incident.  I have two coppers, but I need to keep some grocery money."
"Pittance!  I've that in hand," he produces a purse and fills his palm with silver.  "This is rightfully yours anyway."
"Mine," she demurs.  "How is it you... I mean we, came by this treasure?"
"I filched it from our guests--a small tariff for our tutoring in the hazards of Squillets."
"Never crossed my mind," she chuckles at the sincerity of his humor.  "I think your sense of jest is sharpening too."
"Sons of a noblemen are never found without coin.  Were they set upon and had nothing to pay, they'd have serious consequences.  'Tis the duty of every scoundrel to steal from the rich.  Natural as breathing."
"Speak for yourself, sir," She teases in a snooty tone; "I'll not be called a scoundrel, if you please."
Karn lowers his eyes and recants.  "I beg your pardon, milady."
Poor Leona, what is she to do?  Her eyes close and she exhales in a huff.  Darn! Beth could get away with this, why can't I?  "Good sir," She counters, "do the girls hereabout never tease a gentlemen?  'Twas jest, take me not seriously lest there are serious matters at hand.  You should have countered.  Something like, I had to take their silver, for they had no common sense to offer."  She smiles and fidgets apologetically.  "You see, I think it fair to presume that when a lady teases she expects the same in return."  Karn nods with a smile.  "We are not strangers, nor in the company of kings here.  I'm Leona, no chaste maiden.  You are Karn, no longer lord of the land... and the field between us is level, sir.  Now, let's get these animals settled in and fed."
An eloquent invitation for a roll in the hay?  Surely not, but then is such play not the way this sport is fought?  Opportunities to test the game's validity are fading fast away.  If ever it shall be, 'twill be tonight, for their ways must part come morning's first light.
As Lord and Lady of the barn toy at the dearest and most formidable game of all, at the Inn Beth announces her intentions in the simplest of terms.  "I'm gonna crash!  See ya."  Dragging herself up the stair, she is soon forgotten, at least by Art.
The coast now clear of witnesses, with the ardor of a used car salesman, Art is quick to the pitch.  For that which misery dearly loves, 'tis company he desires also.  "Hey dude, you'll hang in here with me right?"  Hale cringes, its Beth's prophecy coming to life.  Art continues enthusiastically as though the scrapes, bandages and Hale's leg splints are passing fads of fashion.  "I got a lead on some monks up in the hills who are making cheese.  Think pizza!" he exclaims.  "You can be my regional manager."
Hale sobers the occasion with a gentle reminder, "You know Leo wants to buzz out of here in the morning, right?"
"Yeah, but ya see, she never gets the big picture."
"If I were you buddy, I wouldn't piss her off right now.  She's kind of revved up, ya know?  There's more than a few back the way we just came, crossed Leo, she burned them down man.  I shit you not.  If King Kong came through that door right now," Hale nods toward the Inn's entrance, "she'd make a rug out of him."
"Yeah, she ruined some guy in here couple weeks ago, tried to put the arm on her.  Probably still doesn't know what hit'em."
"Right now, us three and that other guy, Karn, we're on the top dog's hit list.  Look... I know you like to disagree with Leo, even if it's just for the hell of it.  But I think she has some valid points here, dude.  Top dog is really pissed."
When Hale agrees with Leona, Art knows it's time to change his strategy and regroup.  "So, is this big dude making it with Leo or--"
"No, I don't think so.  They do make a good team though, keep each other's backs.  He's cool, I like him.  Saved our asses a couple times."
Art motions to Cloe; she scoots right to his side.
"Couple tankards, Hon, very important meeting here."  She winks and zooms toward the bar.  "Okay huh!  Got quite a reputation, too."
"I'm not asking, so don't tell me, okay.  'Cause soon as Beth spots her she'll be on my case.  I gotta be able to look her in the eye and say, far as I know Art's been true blue."  Hale glances around like a paranoid shoplifter, "If you got something cooking, none of my business ya know, but I wouldn't let Leo get wind of it, could be a bad time to break up.  So, why you hanging around here anyway?  How come you're not running with Leo?"
"Guy who owns this place, we sort of owe him some money.  Figured I'd hang around, work it off while Leo checked things out.  Yeah, we sort of threw our cash together in a little business deal, it bombed, but it's cool, no problem.  Leo wanted to take off and hook up with you guys.  I agreed to stay, you know, kind of like collateral, till she could dig up some local coin."
"Hey, right!  That explains it.  I mean, you know, Beth was getting on your case a little about not being around to back Leo up, and well... ah never mind."
"So," Art inquires casually, "you guys find any treasures or anything?"
"No, the pottery barn we started out with, we got ripped off like the first day.  Since then it's been straight downhill, a free fall actually.  This is a rough town.  Like I said, I think Leo's planning to move on in the morning, you gotta come with us."
"Dude... there's a fortune on the table here--we're talking gold, not script.  Listen, I've just about got Jag talked into putting up the dough for another building around back, like an old west saloon.  These fools love to gamble.  I could get odds on whether the sun will come up tomorrow.  Damn, I wish I had the notebooks from my statistics course."  Art hesitates for a moment to check Hale's reaction.  His attentive silence is a good sign.  Proceeding in hushed tones to heighten the sense of secrecy, he produces a sketch.  "I figure the kitchen, the sit-down dining, I'm thinking like dinner theater, okay, the band here maybe, and the guest rooms around here, right?  All the gambling's in the new building to keep things discreet, quiet, without disturbing the sensitive types.  We'll set up a burger and pizza in there... on second thought maybe that ought to be separate for the kids.  You know, like a McDonald's play room.  Anyway, then I'm thinking maybe Cloe, that's the foxy barmaid, I could set her and a couple of her girlfriends up on the second floor.  And there's a mineral spring I got my eye on, back in the valley.   So I'm thinking maybe a private little health spa where the gentry could unwind.  Hey, and you know how popular bottled water is?"
"I haven't seen any bottles," Hale cautions.
"At this stage," Art assures, "I'm not sweating the details."  This being neither the time nor place for delusions of grandeur, Hale's rapidly coming to realize his buddy has totally lost it.  He doesn't seem to be smashed or stoned, but his brain chemistry is definitely out of balance.  Art just keeps rambling, it's like Economics 101 overload, the grandest plans yet to come.  "I'm telling ya, Hale.  This place could turn into a Vegas.  Once everything's set up and the coin's rolling in, I'm going south till I find some weed.  It's got to be down there somewhere, set up like a plantation.  Would it be great or what?"
"You weren't listening before.  I'm telling ya, there's a whole army out there gunning for us."  Hale begins rubbing his face, desperately hoping to stroke just the right nerve and launch a brilliant counter strategy.  "I've seem them and they're not in a good mood, buddy.  You know Leo isn't going to go for this, and we both know Beth is going to follow her.  I can't just let her wander off into the sunset.  She needs me!"
"I need ya on my ticket too, buddy.  We gotta swing the girls our way."
"Sorry man," Hale concludes as he rises.  "Been a long day, catch ya in the morning.  Think about it hard, 'cause Leo says it's a one-time offer."
Now tapping lightly at Lady Beth's chamber door, Sir Hale announces with reserve, "it's me, hon."  Not but a moment passes before the latch is heard to drop and the door's edge parts from its stout lofty jamb to welcome her brave knight.  Their castle on this cool evening is small and quaint.  The ceiling slopes sharply from four feet above the floor at the outset to a lofty twelve at the pinnacle opposite.  Nestled about midway a single dormer, quite tall and narrow, the shutters of its small glass-less window are open.  A coarse, heavy curtain flops in unison with the rustling leaves.  Of simple decor this private place: a bed, a chair, and a night stand with a water pitcher and basin.  Oh yes, and a mighty chamber pot to stand guard that no tax collector comes near.  The bed's small but suitable for those that each to the other's touch is welcome.  Thick and billowy, a patchwork quilt thereupon, in earthly shades of brown and green to keep them from the crisp evening chill.  Candles, there are three, scattered here and there that each other they may see.  Such small flames, yet their glow warms every surface it lights upon.  Particularly, the soft, subtle, inviting curves and flaxen mane of his Beth, fairest damsel of them all.
Unknown to either, while this simple spell envelops their thoughts, an ambitious moth has found its way into their chamber.  The impassioned insect orbits a candle's flame in anticipation of nirvana.  A perilous journey, the transition is swift.  For the embrace of a candle's light is not so kind as an electric lamp about which they may flutter and be forewarned.  Thankfully, fate's deed is done quite literally in a flash.  Say not this creature was a fool, nor it has found death aside of its desires.  For who would dare to suppose the final dream of a moth is any less than all of ours.  Men have oft done much the same, knowing full well the risk they assume against what treasure they may gain.  What difference then, of Hale caressing his sweet Beth or the moth her loving flame.  Are not both appropriately consumed in ways very much the same?  No palace this, their humble abode, nor fortress mighty to their defense.  But were their bed of the coarsest straw or bound of satins and trimmed in lace, doubtless those consumed as they would care nonetheless.  For 'tis each desiring of the other, as the moth adored her fiery mate.  Now they as well, consumed of passion, that both dare tempt the hand of fate.  A fairy's tale, a fantasy's game, this moment, so intimate and sublime; are they not then as one might wish, in essence, bound by state of mind?
The minstrels have consumed their paychecks and drifted away into the countryside.  The kitchen crew is practicing the fine art of scullery in all its dreary delight.  Jagat's tallying the day's receipts, significantly enhanced one might add by Art's flowering skills.  Hale and Beth are fast asleep, or whatever!  And not but a single customer remains.  He, thinking himself clever as any rocket scientist in subtle negotiation with Cloe; and she, considering an apprenticeship in the local astronaut training program.  Also, lest we forget, the Wannabee remains at his post.  Crouching just outside the kitchen window, that golden coin upon Leona's head dancing whimsically in his dreams.  He remains blissfully unaware of current events whereby that pittance has been redoubled over again nearly seven times.  Just as well perhaps, for him at least, as such a sum might incite a level of foolishness well beyond the limits of his health care provider's insurance plan.
Before presenting the next day's options to her reluctant, presumed partner.  Leona takes Klena aside to reconcile Art's outstanding debts.
As might be expected she declines. "No!  We owe you so much more for the life of our friend."
"In truth, my purpose was purely selfish," Leona asserts.  "There was no thought of others," she insists, though knowing full well otherwise.  "Please, you settled my friend's debt in good coin and saved me much grief, it's only right I do the same."  Leona casts an insistent eye and folds Klena's hand around the silver pieces.  "My imposition on Karn's behalf was more of circumstance and suitably discharged in kind by your noble undertaking to keep Art from harm's way."  An honorable person must concede always that intangible debts should not be mingled with those of coin.
Art's no slacker, at least to his own ends.  He's just concluded a grueling 16-hour day of deal-making, micromanaging, and product development--in his mind the equal of fighting evildoers, seducing maidens and freeing the oppressed.  Floating now into the kitchen to nibble on leftovers, he makes eye contact with his former business partner and CEO of the committee to piss off Lord Roux.  The moment of truth has arrived, she motions him come nigh.  Art's debt having been paid, Mrs. Bose concludes there are topics of a private nature they wish to address.  As many things yet require her touch before the sun rises on the morrow, she bids them good night and takes her leave.
"What happened to the side of your face?"
"Things are heating up," Leona advises.
"Where's your new friend?"
"Trying to get some sleep."
"What's his angle?"
"Lifesaver and tour guide, and I might add thoughts of abandoning people at his own peril seem not to plague his thoughts."
Art picks up on her sarcasm, but chooses not to engage the subject.  "Did you get a room yet or are you staying with him?"
"Not with him," Leona clarifies, "but I'll be in the barn.  If something happens, I don't want to get caught in here.  Barns are easier to get free of."
Art shrugs his apparent understanding, thinking it yet another subject not to dwell upon.  "Looks like your limping, too.
"Some mutt thought I had nice legs, wanted to see if they tasted good as they looked.  If there is such a place, I hope he's in doggie hell now.  Be assured I sent him on his way in lots of little pieces."
Hale was right, she's pissed.  "What do you think of the fries?  These are the regular.  I'm going to work up an extra crispy and a hot and spicy.  Going to try burgers next.  Found a guy who grows tomatoes.  If I can put some ketchup together I'll own this town.  What else is in ketchup?"
"We are... if we get caught, all of us, and if not that our new nick name will be the Dog Food Quartet 'cause we will be fed to his dogs, on the hoof.
"On the hoof?"
"That's slang for alive and kicking.  I think you've misplaced the objective here.  We're not playing Monopoly... the prize isn't an IPO with stock options.  It's your ass, keeping your head on your shoulders, waking up another day, have you got that?"
"Come on Leo... the potential here is unlimited."
"Oh shit... stay then!  Your tab's been paid, do what you want.  Hot and spicy, great idea, but in the morning we're gone."
Art wrinkles up his expression as though some great mystery has been laid at his feet. "Gone where?"
"To search out the exit and finish this game before it finishes me.  There's a shit storm coming down the road, Art.  They all have sharp knives and pointed sticks, and they're running with a pack of dogs that will eat gravel and nails if they're told to.  We've got to get out of Dodge, understand?  Do you remember the game at all?"
"Ya, but--"
"But my ass!  Have you asked anyone for a clue yet?"
"Well yeah, sure... but, I didn't understand it exactly."
"Maybe I will.  What did they say?"
"Didn't make sense," dismissing her challenge with a shrug.  "I just let it slide.  Something about a treasure cave... it was last week."
"Don't be insulting.  If someone had pointed to the ground and said, 'treasure right there,' you'd have dug a hole half way to China by now.  You're not even a good bull shiter any more."  Ev and Edie have learned to ignore just about anything.  They go about the rub-a-dub scrubbing of their pots and the salvaging of leftovers as though this were a minor lover's spat, but neither miss a word.  Leona places both hands to her face and exhales in frustration.  "Look, I got you into this and I'm trying to get you out.  But you've got to contribute.  With Beth and Hale on board I've priorities now, we're out of here at dawn.  If you're coming, get your shit together tonight.  If not, remember this, to get Beth and Hale loose I stomped on this guys balls.  They connect you to me... in any way, even the slightest suspicion, you're the ketchup."  Her ultimatum sends Art on his way in a sobering state of mind.
Ev attempts to lift the spirits, "Cup a tea, milady?"
"Yes, that would be nice, thank you."
Tea and honeyed cornmeal cakes are soon before her, served up with a generous helping of concern.  "Is the dork misbehaving again?  Would there be anything we might help ya with, dear?"
"I've inquired to many," she sighs.  "But nary a one knows the House of Iris."
"The gals look to each other with sorrowful expressions, shaking their heads negatively in unison.
"Or anyplace having to do with rainbows," she continues.
"Rainbows!  Well now, there was a sisterhood of that calling," Edie advises with glee.  To this ray of hope Leona perks up, teacup and honey cake in hand.  "Long gone they are now u'm thinking," Edie continues on a downbeat.
"I don't think it's important that I speak with any of them," Leona qualifies. "Only that I find the place where they were."
"Me dear Mom took me there once," Edie admits with a sly glance.  "Threatened she'd leave me if I didn't soon mend my ways.  And them being the sort didn't like men folk, not at all!  There was sure to be no lads about that place to tickle a maiden's fancy," she adds with am mischievous smile.  "Them days lads was sparse, was bad enough ya couldn't hardly find'em anywhere."  Sweeping half a century of cobwebs from Edie's recollections, separating fact from fable and interpreting her directions was a chore.  In the midst of the confusion Leona dashes out to the barn, there to retrieve the map Art had drawn from the old woman's descriptions at the game's onset.  Hesitating for a moment, she wonders if Karn has fallen asleep.  The unpleasant task of their parting yet remains.  She has not a clue--will he resist or welcome the opportunity, for she is likely the more desired prize of the two?
With Art's sketch now to guide, much of Edie's childhood memories are clarified.  In essence, she would have them returning to the general local where first they began, some two days west of the Brobose.  Then as now, the population in the subject area was scant, roads were few and villages far between.  In all likelihood such will favor her pursuits.  A prevalent deception of the gaming world is to hide a treasure where the search first began.  Most will likely assume a quest not end at its inception.  Thus, the tendency of those who seek to quickly disperse protects the prize.  This also confirms the wisdom of brother Jahnis, "home is where you began".  With that she has at last defined a hard target.
His patience amply rewarded as well, the Wannabee's off to expose their plans and earn his golden parachute.
With this good fortune to stir her dreams, Leona retreats to the barn.  Much of the hay is fresh cut and still sweetly scented, reminiscent of times past when she first explored the secrets of her grandfather's barn.  Awkward as it may be with what they've come through, still Karn must be informed their ways are better parted.  He's chosen a resting-place at the rear of the loft about midway within the building.  Near at hand a small door for loading hay from the back of a wagon.  A concealed and speedy exit should unwelcome visitors rush from the loft accesses at either end.  A fair amount of fodder has accumulated there below to soften an emergency departure.  Only the faintest traces of the new moon's light have found their way to his bed.  Without his voice to guide, likely she could not have found her way.
"Do you trust me, sir?"  Leona inquires, a serious cord lingering with her words.
A tone, he suspects, implies more than the words themselves.  "Yes, with my life."
"Then trust that I know what can and cannot be... and I know we cannot.  In the morning I and my friends must go our way... and you yours, separately.  Swear to me you will not follow."
"This is a difficult task you've set as I've come to value your company."
"Please! I beg you trust my judgment"
"If I've learned nothing else 'tis your course once set shall not be swayed.  I so swear."
"I would also ask of you a last favor."
"As you would, milady."
"Stick, the fellow who provided the fresh team, when it's convenient, seek him out.  If you can spare him some coin for me.  It would have been so easy had he chosen to cash me in, but he didn't.  I feel I owe him at least the price that was on my head."
"Would anything else please milady before we part?"
A silent moment of reflection passes, then, she replies softly, "Well... now that you mention it!"
--
Before morning a fair amount of straw has found its way between the planks of the loft and settled to the floor.  Thus, one might suspect both had spent a restless night.  Leona, in anticipation of her journeys end; and Karn, perhaps distraught at her request their partnership be dissolved.  Or perchance 'twas a stormy night and the building shuttered under the strain of howling winds.  There are many reasons straw might be dislodged so from above, these are but two.  Only the invited or those not ask to leave, speaking now of the doves nesting in the rafters above, may say for sure.  For certainly, it would be improper were any but they, and thus not I who should speculate upon or compromise The Lady of Durer's privacy.
Cool and cloudy appears the forecast as Lady Beth and her knight ponder the breakfast menu Ev has just recited.  Hale's the easier to please, a heap of each will do.  But Beth, ever concerned of her architecture and wishing not a single ounce be out of place, is back to calorie counting, whatever they are.  Art's not to be seen as yet.  Though somewhat misled in his goals at the moment, Hale feels a need to defend his buddy's position, at least so far as Beth's obvious misunderstandings.  "You've got it all wrong about Art," Hale informs his fair lady.  "You need to cut him some slack.  I don't think you know the whole story.  He's stuck here, kind of like a deposit.  That's why --"
"Wanna bet!"  Uh-oh! Sir Hale knows such challenges are only based upon irrefutable evidence.  In other words, Leona herself has leveled the charge.  "Hon... I know you guys are a team, best buddies and all that.  But, you know how creative Art can be, especially when it comes to rearranging facts and misplacing details.  I got the unabridged version.  On this occasion your buddy's been a total dick-head!  He's not even on probation, there's no going back, he's off the team."
"Ah come on.  They always work it out; they need each other."
"They! get real will ya.  I don't ever remember a 'they' kind of relationship.  Really stepped on his twinkler this time."  Beth drops the bomb without further explanation, but it's as much a contrived last-ditch diplomatic effort as the truth.  Art's shenanigans have always been forgiven or at least courteously ignored.  Sadly, 'tis a narrative he's come to rely upon.  If Hale can be made to appreciate Leo is drop-dead serious, maybe he can wake his buddy up before it's too late.  "You wanna do Art a really big favor, make him understand this is it, his last chance.
Leona's composure fares noticeably lighter this dew-laden morning.  Beth, ever so inquisitive, is quick to notice.  The stage was set and opportunity at hand, has she done the deed, the doves will never tell.  It would be so like Beth to tease, But she asks instead with only a smile, so coy and yet distinct.  Leona knows what inquiry her friend has made and appreciates it was discreet.  As might a faint breeze sigh, thus known to those alone who've crossed its silent path.  That no untruth might need be told nor chance of whispered innuendo overheard.  Such things as these, better left to lie.  Leona takes her friend aside, drawing near to whisper.  Beth's tickled, the payoff, a confirmation at last, but 'tis not what she thought to hear.
"Karn's not coming," Beth repeats dismayingly.  "After all this?"
"He's not one of the original players," Leona defends.  "You know he can't come back with us."
"So?  He could still tag along."
"Yeah, and what if we arrive at the exit point in the middle of a confrontation?  We fight our way in because once there we could escape, but he can not follow.  He'd be there to support us and we'd have no option but to abandon him.  I won't chance that.  I refuse to put anyone in that position.  What if it's not a game?"
"Are you still on that?"
"Beth... I honestly can't tell... especially right now.
Beth, now playing the devil's advocate, inquires coyly.  "Maybe if Art decides to stay, would you trade him for Art if you could?"
"If that were possible, it's not a game... is it?  If I thought not... I'd give it some damn serious consideration, but I want it to be a game 'cause if it's not we've got big problems.  So, that option's not on the table... just yet... and I don't want to talk about it again, okay?"
"Fiddlesticks," Beth exclaims with a pout.  Speaking of the devil, here comes one now, Arther, self appointed CEO of MICROREALM INC.  Though somewhat timid in his approach for such a high level VIP, but nonetheless reporting for duty.  Deep down, Beth knows pushing Hale to sway Art from his foolish antics was the right thing to do, even if it did botch her matchmaking mischief.  On the other hand, neither does she harbor any guilt of encouraging her best friend to put a different slant on the meaning of fantasy.  Could have been interesting, the clever grin of a Cheshire cat slinking across her face.
In parting, Leona takes Klena aside, "If any ask of us, don't deny it.  None will inquire lest they already know, so it makes no difference, you understand?  They're trying to catch you in a lie," she warns.  "Tell them that because of what happened last time I was here you feared for your life and felt it unwise not to cooperate."
Beth has curled up in her nest of down and Art is about to begin his apprenticeship as cart driver.  Handshakes and hugs a plenty have primed all for their last glimpse of each other.  As this mysterious group of new friends slips away into the morning mist, Karn shares his thoughts with Jagat.  "I fear for her... and her friends."
"Take heart, milord," Jagat consoles.  "From what I've seen and what you've told me, I well imagine 'tis a wolverine that parts of our company, the foolish rabbit chasing after."

Chapter-15

FIND THE WAY HOME: A HOLE IN THE GROUND,
A HOLE IN THE AIR,
I CARE NOT WHICH SO LONG AS IT'S THERE.

Half a day along, the village hosting the dragon chaser's convention comes again to view.  Sleepy and sparse of grand activities now, alas it seems the crowds and hype of that noble undertaking have run out of free food and excuses to avoid their chores.  A great amount of debris remains along the roadside.  For these folk, the economic impact was surely on a par with the likes of Hoboken hosting the Olympics.  Locating the business hub is a simple matter, one need only follow the constant pinging of the iron smith's hammer.  There, adjacent to the sprawling barn accompanying his forge, one encounters an assemblage of open-ended shanties, storage sheds and temporary sheltered stalls.  Spread thereabout generous quantities of produce along with potions, pet ferrets, goats and implements of every endeavor, honorable and otherwise.  Four walls of coarse wooden planks and a floor of straw define the village tavern.  So much thatch heaped thereupon as to resemble a haystack with four large double wide doors.  Basic, simple and practical, atmosphere seems not their forte.  Several varieties of high octane hooch their bill of fare, spiced with dragon tales and generous portions of country lore, that being remarkably similar in many ways to the steaming cow pies in the pens around back next to the chicken coops.
Arriving as they have at the height of the afternoon rush hour, the final frantic spurt of jabber and haggling is at its peak before the market closes for the day.  On an encouraging note, no civil authorities appear to be present.  Most sellers are re-packing their wares, or having done so, gathered around the food court--a cluster of stalls with cooking pits and stone ovens.  Only one diehard continues to vie for new, unengaged customers.  He dances about with all sorts of vivid expressions upon his face while tapping out a rhythm on several earthenware crocks.  Two young maidens all in smiles are quite taken by his antics, and so long as they stay, likely so shall he.
An energetic gaggle of children have gathered about a puppeteer's stage anxiously awaiting the main event of their entire day.  Their attention's hopelessly held fast by a colorfully dressed lad who prances about playing a tune upon his flute.  "Ha!"  Several jump and explode into giggles as a funny little character has suddenly appeared as though to peek from between the stage's drawn curtains.  Slowly it scans the audience of youngsters, all of whom have become wide-eyed and absolutely silent in anticipation.  The marionette waves to the children, then, just as quickly disappears amid a flourish of silly laugher.  Their restless chatter and frolic begins anew and the flautist resumes his antics while behind the tiny stage preparation continues.
Transients customarily find themselves having at least half a strike against them.  Leona has cautioned all to avoid anything even remotely suggesting of conflict, wagers or alcohol.  Even so, the very nature of their transportation precludes a low profile.  The smith is first to wonder, why two horses for a cart so small as that?   Stranger still, a peasant's transport carried upon costly springs of iron and such large wheels too?  They could easily bridge a rut that would cause most wagons to flounder.  Not to mention, that which is painted to remain well hidden in the forest stands out like a sore thumb without the company of trees and shadow.  Everything about it reeks of military surplus though no such concept has yet come to be.  Leona takes note of their curiosity, but feels confident having their escape mechanism immediately at hand is wiser than parking it out of sight where it might be pilfered.
She can practically hear the wheels turning in Art's head as they scope out the village.  This is his first exposure to the population beyond the Brobose Inn.  Likely he envisions a strip mall with an adjacent medical annex right across from the condos.  A not too out-of-the-way spot is chosen to disembark.  Leona takes Hale aside.  "Here's how it shakes out," she explains.  "If I leave Beth here she'll attract too much attention.  Guys start flocking around, showing off at each other's expense, next thing ya know we have a minor riot."  Hale concedes the probability with a nod.  "I can't trust Art here alone and I need to check the place out firsthand.  Then there's still the question of your knee.  I know it feels better, but wandering around on foot for several hours isn't going to improve it.  So you and Art have got the watch."
"No problem," he replies in a confident tone one could attribute to a soldier with a mission.
"Feed and water the horses.  Keep mine tethered to the back of the cart so it will follow if you have to take off.  We don't want people to think we feel threatened, so keep the bows out of sight, but handy.  If Art tries to wander away, remind him his ass is grass if he abandons me again.
Beth is sprucing up for her first public appearance; whereas Art can see there's a discussion in progress from which he feels excluded.  He decides to crash the conference.
"Looks like a cool little town," he beams.  "Are we going to stay for a while?
"I've been here before; there are no rooms available.  I want to be at least a couple hours out of here before we settle in for the night.  You and Hale stay with wheels."
"Ah shit! I want to look around, too."
"Don't start!  This is recon, not sight-seeing.  I want you right here," she insists.  "Beth and I are going to ask around and gather up some takeout.  Be ready to leave in a rush."  She hands Art the dagger and boot knife confiscated from Doran back at the hunting lodge.  "These are sharp as razors, don't play with them.  Keep them handy, you may find them useful before this is over with."
"Knives?"
"Art," she cautions quietly, "stay here... don't cross me!"
Lady Beth looks quite chic in trousers, basic fur, leather, and pheasant feathers.  Among her new appointments a pair of soft doeskin gloves.  With great effort and these to aid she can set the crossbow string on her own.  Now with a tensed crossbow slung over her shoulder, in spite of her pint size, menacing chic is perhaps the more appropriate classification.  Leona motions her come nigh, adding a silver-handled dagger to her belt.  "For close quarters, leave the dart in your bag.  Have you got a couple extra?"  She flashes three dainty leather-clad fingers and a smile.  Locked, but not loaded, the ladies are off to seek the House of Iris.
Beth spots a group of Adonis-class lads, and they in turn have taken an interest in her effervescent maidenly qualities.  The trousers originally fitted to suit a lad of perhaps age 14 and drawn tight about her waist are a standout feature.  Likely as not, they've failed to notice the somewhat out-of-place projectile-transporting device in her company.  As though to gain a measure of permission to raid the cookie jar, she nudges Leona.  "There are some guys; I'll ask them, okay?"
"No!" Their eyes lock.
"How's come?" she flashes back.
"They're at least three generations removed from what we need to know.  Your assignment is the grandmothers and Medicare types.  I'll work the geezers."
She sharpens her focus on Leona and mumbles.  "Bummer!" 
"Whatever!  You know we can't play around here, this isn't downtown Atlanta.  Your opening line is: 'Did they catch the dragon?'  Everyone should have something to say about that.  Once you break the ice, BS your way into the topic of choice, which is?"
"Sisters of the Rainbow!"
"Right, or?"
"The House of Iris," Beth frowns sarcastically.
"Let's rock and roll!"
During the course of their inquiries, everyone being an expert now, much is learned about the art of dragon-hunting.  Aside from the unfortunate mutt, however, it seems no further sign of the creature surfaced.  Nearly all activities were abandoned when the large, wagon-mounted acid tank self-destructed.  Apparently the vent atop the vessel became clogged allowing pressure to build from within causing it to fracture.  Fortunately the iron bands held the crock together long enough for the deadly fluid to seep slowly from the cracks.  
As to the House of Iris, only one old soul harbored any recollection at all, declaring with absolute certainly that the group had disbanded at least forty or fifty years ago.
For lack of disposable plates the takeout idea is abandoned.  Thus, the guys have been rescued from the fringes, cart and all brought around to the open-air food court.  Roast duck with carrots, sweet potatoes and onions the main course; supplemented with fresh black bread, an apple pie baked on the spot and a fair measure of the local ale.  At this rate Hale's hard-won slimmed-down physique will remain only as one of Beth's brief, but fond memories.  Pity Art also, who dreams of peddling French fries and burgers.  How misdirected that he wishes to cast this coarse, but unspoiled world into the muck which would evolve into fast food?
Nothing like traveling unpaved roads upon a primitive cart to appreciate the hazards of overeating.  An hour of belching beyond the village they happen upon the crumbling skeleton of the failed acid transport.  The crock has settled amid what remains of the wagon from which it once threatened all who dared come near.  Heavy oak planks have been reduced to mush by the corrosive fluid.  Not but the skeletons of axles and wheels endure, flanking either side of the giant ceramic jar.  Thick bands once encircling the vessel have unraveled and fallen away as though struck by a cutting torch.  None care even to salvage what metal remains for fear their hands would catch fire at the touch of it.  Surrounding foliage has been scorched to a distorted lifeless brown tangle.  One can see clearly which path the wind had chosen when the meltdown occurred.  A thirty-foot swath of crops has withered for a hundred feet along the deadly vapor's course.  Only technology gone wrong dares produce such an ominous memento.  Fortunately, the vile broth has been swallowed and neutralized by the ever accommodating earth.  Had the flow reached a nearby creek, those country folk downstream and their livestock would have suffered tragically.  Bureaucratic folly has no peer and no concern of its pawns.
A thicket heavily burdened beneath a canopy of rambling grapevines conceals the travelers this night.  Art considers the lot of his friends to be suffering acute paranoia, but then, his has been a sheltered life.  Constant watchfulness and this business of spending the night hidden like a rabbit in the brier patch, seems extreme.  For fear of nightmares, Beth has skirted any detailed narration of Roux's hospitality.  Thus deprived, Art fails to appreciate his traveling companion's concern.
Before the watch is assigned, Art receives a refresher course on crossbow mechanics, stern warnings as to the consequences of failing to perform his duties and a firm reminder he and Leona are hereafter just friends.  In essence, amorous advances in the late hours will be treated less than cordially.  Oh yes, and also the proper procedure for calming the horses should they become alarmed by the presence of wolves during the night.
"Wolves... did you say wolves?" he repeats.  "It's just--"
"A game," Leona consoles with a sarcastic smile.
"Yeah!"
"Hope you're right."
A curious thing to say, he wonders.  The thought of Art watching her back imparts not a warm and fuzzy feeling.  She will no doubt sleep poorly because of it.  Thus, he's assigned the first cycle, being more or less an extension of the day's activities.  She and Hale will take the second and third respectfully, Beth the last, as she has been catching kitten naps all day anyway.  Each shall abide two turns of the hourglass before the breakfast tea is set to boiling.
Always pleased to announce a new sunrise, the birds serenade as remnants of roast duck serve for breakfast.  Soon again upon their fated course they chance upon an old codger, white of beard, thin as his walking stick, weathered and worn as a favorite pair of shoes that hardly dare take another step.  He trudges along the roadside at the pace of a snail on a sight-seeing holiday.  Leona offers this country gentlemen wishes of a good day, benefit of their transport and an apple.  He's quick to accept, whereupon the guys are enlisted to boost him up and set him upon the tailgate.  A merry chatterbox soon proves he and in his eyes an endless sparkle of glee.  Stories and proverbs from the mundane to the intriguing flow like Champaign and tantalize nonetheless.  Beth's delighted, he's more entertaining than late-night talk TV.  All is served in a spicy dialect with occasional chuckles from one whose entire agenda is but to rise for another day.
Still, with his vast array of local lore, he had not the slightest recollection of that which they seek.  And so it is, least till his misadventures turn to tales of a great house upon a hill occupied only by wild wenches.  "Did everything themselves.  Any fella would come 'round they'd sling stones at'em."  As a young lad he would sneak up to their castle, cautiously climb a trusty oak adjacent to the wall and watch while they danced naked around a great bonfire when the moon came full.  "Always had flowers in their hair and 'least one of'em playing on reed pipes, even when they tended their fields.  Everyone thought'em shy as mice," he relates with coy mischievous delight.  "Some called'em witches, too.  Chased me out'a their orchard more than once, tell ya for sure, biggest sweetest apples I ever seen."
"Hey Leo!" Beth calls out excitedly.  "Didn't you say this rainbow place was strictly sorority, no guys allowed?"  A spark of good fortune this, for it seems Beth has turned a card in their favor, and thus, an excellent excuse to take a dinner break.  For surely time has come to wine and dine this cheery old fellow like the royalty he is, while carefully cultivating his cobweb laced memories for clues to their objective.
These maidens, it turns out were a major highlight of his youth.  As one boldly recalling their very first kiss the old fellow recites details likely long forgotten by those to whom they were not but an oddity.  Still clearly can he discern the outline of those forbidding parapets against a starlit sky, the subtle lute and drumbeats from within, and the smoke of their evening fires aglow with swirling sparks as it rose into view above those enticing walls.  Irresistibly it pulled upon his imagination, subtle invitations no inquiring lad could deny.  Thus, were the ethereal images of naked maidens frolicking in the moon's soft glow forever thereupon bestowed.  Witches perchance or forest nymphs, hidden form all but those bold enough there to go, reserved as it were for the youthful eyes of this beholder of dreams yet to know.  Adolescence curiosity or a voyeur some might say, but was it that he dared not to tell, or thus beguiled and so enticed he could not turn away?  So long as they dwelled within, their secrets to himself he kept, till they had gone far away, a loss so great the young lad wept.  Never were they forgotten though, not even as he slept, and when at last their confidence he dared betray, none would take him seriously nor believe a word he'd say.  Their castle, if indeed it was, a memory steeped in sweet white wine, residing atop a wooded bluff that none but those who magic seek might find.  'Tis there it remains to this very day, tending an old fellow's fantasies that they dull not nor ever slip away.  Quietly sleeping, these precious thoughts, until again he's come upon this near forgotten road.  Where Iris, Olympia's enticing maiden of the rainbow has come to set her humble abode.
Portions of cornmeal, rice, a share of brandy and the finest apples remaining of their inventory are presented in appreciation of his valuable consultation.  Soon thereafter he takes his leave, going by way of a footpath none but he has ever seen, to no apparent destination aside of the forest--so splendid, dark and green.
Now knowing their objective to be on high ground south of the main road, they proceed enthusiastically seeking two stone pillars.  These presumably the height of a man, or at least so they were 70 years ago.  About noon the next day the approach comes to their attention.  Nearly undetectable except by those possessed of an old man's remembrance, and of course, with life and limb at risk.  All that survives of the access road are two out-of-place parallel drainage ruts, these likely the result of runoff following wagon tracks over the many years it existed.  But for the old storyteller, none would take note of two insignificant heaps of rock now almost indistinguishable beneath a carpet of vines and fallen leaves.  Any space once cleared then neglected is by default subject to the unwritten law of weeds, which states:  Ever place a seed may find, in due time, a weed shall grow.  Thus, upon rich forest earth long since unattended, the sun's light has spawned an impassable array of heavy brush and eager stout young trees.  The adjacent woodland itself is more manageable as the canopy having blocked most of the light has disallowed any major accumulation of heavy brush.  Non-the-less 'tis an arduous trek for the cart from roadside to ruins through the forest proper.  They are obliged to zigzag and backtrack if the cart is to follow, which it must, or risk betraying their location were if left at the roadside.  The way in, being as well the way out, presents an uncomfortable last-stand situation were they discovered at their task.
They behold not quite the spectacle one would anticipate from the old gentlemen's description.  Though obviously a grand undertaking, the primary construction material is something akin to adobe mud bricks.  What stone was used appears the gathered natural variety, most of which has been incorporated as pavers for the courtyard or parapet caps to protect the surrounding perimeter wall from erosion.  Even so, great portions of the construction have dissolved and crumbled, some areas reduced to mounds of earth and gravel.  Much of what remains vertical has been transformed into micro gardens covered with mosses and grass.  Hale has managed the cart to within twenty yards of a large opening in the wall.  If ever there were gates, nothing yet remains.  A great clump of multiflora rose has risen in their stead.  So dense and tangled are the briers their transport may not pass further lest they invest half the day to hack their way through.
This House of Iris chimes a familiar tone.  Almost as soon as the remnants come to view Leona recognizes it as the ruin Art discovered while supposedly searching for their misplaced steed.  Though of no concern then, a hostile merger with the forest is under way.  They disembark, wading into the dense thorny foliage.  Announcing displeasure at this invasion of their turf, a flock of crows hasten into the forest upon outstretched ebony sails.
"We've got about two hours of reasonable light," Leona estimates.  "I'm going to take a quick look around.  Leave the horses hitched till I get back.  Art, you round up some kindling--nothing damp, we don't want any smoke.  Bring it in here behind the wall so the fire won't be broadcasting our location.  Hale, you and Beth start laying out the canopy.  Keep an eyes and ears toward the road."
"On the cart or the ground?" Hale inquires judiciously. 
"The ground within the walls," she clarifies.  "This has got to be the place, so we're going to be here as long as it takes.  May as well be comfortable."  Taking notice that Art is having a deja-vu moment, she preempts before he can ask.  "Yes!  We've been here before.  You dug up part of the backyard, remember?"
Art quietly cusses the clouds for a moment then returns a sarcastic expression.  "Hey, you know, aft--"
"I don't wanna hear it," she quietly reminds.  "Just be glad you got back in one piece.  The game has to play out.  If it hadn't gone the way it did, Beth and Hale would have been screwed big time.  Besides, lacking an interface with the local population there would be no clues to tell us what we were searching for.  So for now just deal with the wood, okay?"  He frowns and exits to gather kindling wisely without attempting further comment. 
For her part now, within her own mind she must secure the ruin.  Immediate concerns: is this really the place they seek?  Is it defensible?  What are the escape options if they need be quick away?  Keeping the perimeter wall just in sight, she sets her mare at a trot and rides in a wide sweep through the surrounding forest.  Squirrels bark as they bound away and scoot up their favorite oak into the canopy's refuge.
She's grateful for their trust and acceptance, considering she's taken to assigning duties as one issues commands rather than requests to the best of friends.  A fierce sense of survival has pervaded her identity and she fears it may have become tainted with arrogance.  Though none question, nor aside of Art, ever object, still behind this lady's piercing eyes there lingers concern they may lament.
Within the ruin, trees erupt from beneath the courtyard's paving, some rising 40 feet from where they've sprouted.  Heavy stone slabs have been gradually pushed aside like a child's toy building blocks.  Segments remain of an archway once spanning the entry portal, they jut out toward each other from either side atop the wall.  Faint traces of applied colors may still be seen thereupon.  A different one to each of several concentric rings in the same relationship as those of the spectrum.  They've found the end of their rainbow, not so yet the elusive pot of gold.
Leona scales a ragged breach in the wall; the bricks softened by exposure to the elements crumble under the slightest pressure.  Certainly persistence is one of her virtues and she soon gains the high ground.  Fruit trees don't grow nearly as tall as the pines and oaks of the forest.  Thus, her perch affords a fine view over what remains of the forsaken brier infested orchard planted on the adjacent slope.  The gypsy's wagon she and Art awoke in at the game's onset still sits amid the meadow just beyond.  There appears a child in attendance now, and a dog, and the faint glimmer of a cooking fire to keep them.
The front court is perhaps 50 yards wide and 70 or 80 from the gateway to the hermitage.  The centerpiece is an open cistern surrounded by a thick stone wall about two feet high.  At first it appears as a large rectangular bowl of guacamole.  Closer examination reveals the surface to be an entanglement with millions of tiny floating plants two leaf plants  Somewhere within its depths there must exist a spring as water trickles from overflows on either side into thoroughly clogged drainage basins.  In fact, the spring's location is probably what determined the building site.  Gardens of moss sprouting from between the paving stones are very appreciative of the little plants which have overpowered the drains allowing the excess to dampen their domain.  A wide sweep across the surface to clear a view is quickly overwhelmed when the plants rush back upon the wake to fill every gap.  The quick glimpse afforded by her effort reveals a world steeped in darkest emerald green.  Clear and ten to twelve feet from the dense blanket of green floating upon the surface to a dark mat of decaying sediment covering the bottom.  Disturbing the surface allows rear beams of shimmering light to flood through her momentary observation portal, an unknown phenomenon in this cloistered world.  Startled by her intrusion and though unseen, crayfish scurry away backward causing little clouds of silt to rise in their wake.  
A collapsed drainage conduit just below the paving appears to have routed any overflow to a series of shallow rectangular pits.  Reminiscent of Roman style plumbing, these could have been for bathing.  Now filled of windblown sediment and organic debris the basins present a brackish paradise for mosquitoes, tadpoles and dragonflies.  Even cattails have found their way upon the wind, a tribute to nature's relentless quest that no opportunity shall remain unfulfilled.  The shaded, ever damp area between the basins and adjacent wall has sprouted a fine crop of toadstools--these of a sort dispensed only by orange and purple stripped Cheshire cats.  Some stand eight inches tall, slender oblong domes of pale apricot hue with fringes of faintest lavender upon stout irregular brown trunks.  Beth has found them entrancing.  For a boutique darling she has taken considerable interest in Mother Nature's workings of late.
"Bet you could get a fortune for those on the west coast," she remarks as Leona approaches.
"Don't even think about it," her guardian cautions, "this is not a remake of 'Alice in Wonderland'".
"Definitely not my cup of tea," Beth assures.  "This place is freaky enough without blowing your mind."
Thick round stone slabs raised upon pedestals stand about twenty feet from the cistern, one adjacent to each side.  Care and wisdom are shown in the construction of their supports, as stones the weight of these, once raised, are better done with forevermore.  Altars, birdbaths perhaps or dining tables--which might they be?  Each now hosts thick accumulations of decomposing leaves, moss, and tufts of clover.
Thirty yards beyond the cistern are the remains of a large simple building, fifty feet across and sixty or more in length.  Walls nearly twenty feet high run along the sides, then rise more than thirty feet at the ends to what had been the roof's peak.  No longer protected thereby, the thick mud-brick confines will soon dissolve just as those skirting the courtyard have.  What remains of the doors has come to not under a relentless siege of termites and wood bores.  Leona ventures in.  No interior walls remain, only two rows of closely spaced brick columns dividing the space into three corridors.  A single wide opening in the far wall appears the only other exist.  Few of the main roof beams yet prevail, poles in fact and likely of locus.  They still gallantly span from wall to column then cantilevered over top toward what had been the roof's ridge.  All else has come loose and collapsed into the interior.  Being of cedar, the poles that had crossed between the beams as purloins remain strewn about like so much spaghetti.  Insects sorely detest the fragrant red wood; they will have no part in its demise.  Remnants of wooden mezzanines, once upheld between the walls and the interior columns appear to have extended along either side for the entire length of the building.  Sleeping rooms one might imagine, now but a dense heap of crumbling debris scattered the length on either side of the perimeter.  Slits about four feet high and six inches wide in the wall's upper portion would appear to have served as windows.  As there are none at the ground floor level, one could suppose they had security issues.  Aside from the few flecks of paint observed on the remains of the archway, adornments there are not.  The ruin would be adequate in its dimensions to support from 40 to 50 individuals.  Might one imagine this a place populated entirely by females where vanity did not exist?
Hale joins Leona to report their status.  "Not much left, is there?" he observes casually.
"Mostly dirt," Leona admits with a sigh.
"Tent's up, tea's on, notice anyone else around?"
She shakes her head negatively, "not even a hint of a fire."  They advance through the doorway at the structure's far end.  This exits into the rear court where Art had conducted his treasure-hunting expedition.  The area warrants further scrutiny now for much more than plunder is at risk.  Two heavy low stone slabs are the prominent features, their top faces worked flat and smooth.  One yet has a stout weathered locust post embedded into the center and a slight circular depression worn into the surface.  Likely the post once hosted an axle and grinding wheel.  The other stone is undercut along two opposite sides and has a basin scooped from its center.  There within a deeper circular ring has been carefully fashioned; a trough leads from there to the edge.  Probably the foundation of a fruit press for cider and wine.  A roof then to keep then dry, a wall thereabout to keep them safe, a fine spring to keep them clean, their daily bread, and a cup of wine--mechanisms of a life so simple, yet when among friends no less divine.
Art and Beth join them.  "Don't we have a magic spell or something for this?"  Beth pleads.  "I mean really, isn't that what all this is about anyway?  Who's in charge of the magic here, huh?"
"I haven't seen any yet," Leona admits, "except maybe my blade, and I'm not really sure about that.  I figured it must be your turn," she teases, casting a smirk to Beth.
"Me?  No one told me we were taking turns."  She points with her thumb.  "Art's the one who always gets into the magic stuff." 
"Yeah, I thought so too," Leona agrees.  Both the girls look in Art's direction; he declines to comment.  "Must be Hale then," Leona continues.
"Trust me, he's not... weellll sometimes!" Beth concedes, coyly.  "But that's different."
Leona smiles at Beth's quick pickup and ever teasing implications.  The crew retreats to the tent where Leona then flatly states the findings of her impromptu survey.  "Guys, bottom line, I don't think we have any abracadabra up our collective sleeves for this situation."
"Bummer," Beth mumbles as she daintily dispenses tea.
Art contemplates another cup of the clear amberish liquid.  "Tea again," he grumbles.
Leona casts a sarcastic glance his way.  An ever present tension prevails.  "I don't like it much either, would have preferred Red Bulls" she concedes. "Needed something with caffeine and this stuff was the closes thing to an upper I could find.  Next Wi-Fi expresso bar, we'll pull over and get you some coffee."
"That'd be nice," Beth adds with a yearning drawl, "and a cake donut, too, umm."  Leona immediately refocuses her attention on Beth.  "But I like tea, too," Beth quickly defends.  Art glances toward Hale for backup.  Beth notices and fires a preemptive glance across Hale's bow.  Though at times he may seem not, Hale's no fool, he sips his tea and replies with only a smile.
"Okay, enough about the tea and our shortage of wizard's work.  Shall we give logic a go?"  The others shrug in apparent agreement.  "The good news first.  A couple fellows I met told me home was where you first began.  These guys were like monks, so their input could be taken from a philosophical point of view.  But as I just mentioned, the wagon Art and I started out in is sitting in the field just down the hill, other side of the orchard a ways.  So this is pretty close to where we started and kind of backs up their contribution.  When the rules were explained, I got the feeling the route back was the same for all of us.  The bad news is, if you take what they said literally, this spot may only work for me and Art.  I hope not, but we have to consider that the answer could be relative to the person asking the question."  She looks despairingly toward Beth.  "And you guys came in at a different point."
Alarms begin to sound as unpleasant images stream across Beth's mind.  The secure comforting feeling of Leona's presence dissipates like a flash of steam.  Prospects that she and Hale may need to find their way back to the pottery shop and search out their own personal exit is terrifying at best.  She looks about to burst into tears.  Hale has detected the soft quick ratcheting of her breathing and takes firm hold of her for whatever good it may do.  Failing to realize how seriously Beth has come to rely upon even the most casual of her observations; Leona appears to have just about scared her half to death with a passing thought.  "Hold on, I didn't mean to be so morbid," she consoles, then quickly backpedaling.  "Look on the bright side.  It could just as well mean there's more than one exit for all of us."  She grabs Beth's hand and squeezes.  "I'm not going anywhere without you," she assures.
"I know," Beth mutters softly; 
"Remember the little old gal at the prison, the one who brought you the apple?"  Beth nods with a cautious glance, as to remind, don't forget the guys are listening.  "When I asked, she pointed us both to this place.  She didn't say I had to go north and you had to go south, right?"
"I'll buy that.  Okay, so now what's the bad news?"  Leona hesitates. "Come on, I'm cool," Beth insists.  "Let's hear it."
"I think it was more an observation than a clue, but the old Alchemist that helped me with the counterfeiting said he thought I was already home, like this was it."
"Wait a minute," Hale intrudes.  "The deal was we got round-trip tickets, right?"
"Pretty much the way I took it, too.  So let's finish this."
Beth wrinkles her nose with an inquisitive look.  "What counterfeiting?"
"Thought I told you; I paid the ransom.  Gold-plated lead counterfeits; they looked really good.  Invested three actual gold coins to make them too.  No one caught me on it, but the bastards still wouldn't let both you guys loose.  Local technology isn't exactly up to speed, believe me it was a rush.  That's why I was so close to the wire getting back."
Beth stomps her foot harshly, turns round, and whacks Hale on the shoulder hard as she can.  "See!" she squeaks adamantly.  Hale cringes expecting another swat, looks guilty as sin, and appears to be changing color.  Apparently while vacationing in the hoosegow there was an unresolved discussion which the matter of counterfeiting has somehow clarified, and Beth's just had the last word.  Nothing like whooping up on Hale to quell a panic attack.  There future together may be bright, but Hale's is probably going to be a little black and blue too.  Beth returns her undivided attention to Leona with an assuring expression.
"I'm not even going to ask," Leona muses.  Dusk is upon them; thus, the ruin has fallen into heavy shadows.  Little good would come of beginning the investigation now as important elements could easily be overlooked.  What remains of their day is allocated to boiling the rice and beans for dinner and planning the morning's assault.
"Okay guys listen up," Leona abides compellingly.  "First solid hint comes from the little old gal I confiscated from those clowns that tried to con Art.  She said, 'Look to yourself then take one step more.'  I know... sounds funky, but I have to imagine it means something solid... tangible, physical--something that looks the same to all of us.  At least for starters, we need to dismiss the psycho babble and take a hard-target approach.  Discussion please... what does it mean?"
"Look to yourself, a picture," Hale suggests with a shrug.
"No such thing as photography around here yet," Leona counters.  "So, It would need to be art."
"Huh, what?"  Art responds, not surprisingly, as though having just rejoined them from another planet.
"Not you... I mean artwork like a painting," Leona clarifies, following up with a sip of stiff tea to wash the thought down.  "But that would require a picture of all ten players, right?  'Cause any one of us could find it."
Everyone else must be nearby then," Beth proposes, "but I don't think I've seen any of the other players besides us, which is kind of spooky.  Or maybe their just not recognizable, I don't know."
"How about a reflection," Hale continues, "like a mirror?"
"Perfect!" Leona exclaims.  "Hale, you're on it, dude; that would suit anyone, and everyone, and any combination, too."
"I haven't seen any mirrors... not one."  Beth imparts from the safety of Hale's embrace, her eyes rising as to console rather than disagree.
"Glass," Hale persists, "a window maybe?"
"Okay, that works too.  Doesn't need to be silvered to be reflective," Leona adds.  "Your on a roll, dude, don't stop now."
"And you can see beyond it," he adds cleverly.  "To take one more step you crash through."  He now looks to the treasure cradled within his arms, pleased to have contributed so wisely on her behalf.  Beth smiles back and squiggles a bit further into his embrace.
'Tis things few and far between, however, that rate a perfect from Leona these days.  "Good thought, trouble is there's very little glass out there," she assures.  "Aside from the windows at Karn's lodge all I've seen are a few bottles.  I suspect flat sheets are real high-dollar stuff.  Not impossible, but a real long shot.  If there was ever any glass here I'm thinking they would have taken it with them."
Art finally antes up, drawing upon fond memories of the last time he saw his own face.  "Could it be like that copper pot you polished up?  Couldn't see beyond it though."
"Good call," Leona pointing her trigger finger in his direction as proper acknowledgment.  "It could mean to see beyond the reflection, like behind it, over your shoulder.  Not past it, like a  step backwards, maybe.  Any item of metal with a smooth finish could produce the image we need.  Even a hard flat stone like marble... or porcelain.  You know, like fired in a kiln.  That's pretty common stuff in this neighborhood."
Based upon Art's input, she suddenly finds herself sharing Beth's paranoia of moments just past.  For some days considerable thought has been dispatched to these few simple clues, but the skillet has until now evaded her list of options.  The two drenched travelers could have hit it right on the head.  "Home is where you first began."  If that were exactly correct, we're still a quarter mile off the mark.  What if the exit portal is concealed precisely where each person started.  For Art and I then, somehow contrived within the gypsy's wagon.  Even more provoking, could the required image be as Art suggested, the one visited upon the copper skillet I bartered for room and board?  What irony, if the key to this riddle has been consigned among Klena's prized kitchen utensils.  I might need to fetch it back while the others kept watch on the wagon to assure it wasn't lost.  Reoccupied as it seems now.  That could be tricky business.  Crap!  Splitting the group is the worst possible choice.  Who among the other three could I trust to make a critical call?  We're so close, I'm sure of it, and now this doubt.  Properly devised this charade could become an endless labyrinth of options.  Round and round we go again, a labor hopeless as the cat intent upon catching its tail.  Forever condemned to spin in circles, yet never win the prize.  The only clue out of place was Hemmil's "you are home," he said.  Maybe there was something to that.  Her thoughts spiral even further downward.  With a twitch of the imagination, a wicked scenario invades, a tragic plot remembered of late night TV.  Comatose forevermore, the victim of an accident has conjured a fantasy from bits and pieces of memories.  Where do such villains as these dwell that a thought sets them free to pounce upon those in doubt?
Beth's voice rescues Leona from her momentary self-imposed exile.  "Leo, you still with us?"  Back to the game she must go, ready, willing, and on the surface utterly confident that none should detect even the slightest doubt.
"Right... just thinking."  Thus, relieved for the time being at least, that were she in a coma, better this fantasy than no thoughts at all.
"Maybe it works like Aladdin's Lamp, Beth adds gingerly.  You polish it up to see your face and get the genie instead."  She exclaims. "How cool would that be?"
Leona smiles, pleased to see Beth is back in the game, her fears of abandonment set aside, hopefully forgotten.  She continues as the unofficial moderator "Only other hint implies that whatever it is we're looking for somehow lies with the stars.  That's it, that's all we've got."
"Meaning it's in the sky?"  Hale inquires in a bewildering tone, "a constellation?  I'm totally lost when you get into that stuff."
"Doubt it.  I've thought about this a lot," Leona consoles.  "If you argue the fine points, it includes everything between the horizons.  So I've been trying to narrow it down, look at it with an average-Joe mentality.  Like what would people from here in this time period take it to mean?  Simply put, it places the stars directly overhead.  So I read it as parallel with the horizon, flat, level, horizontal, whatever."  Silent glances are passed back and forth.  "I'm open to an argument; anything you've got.  Come on guys... I need some feedback."  She scans the crew, "Nothing?"
"Has to be on the ground then?" Beth anticipates reluctantly.
"Or a roof," Hale's quick to add, "or even the ceiling."
Art points out the failing of his theory, there being neither a roof nor ceiling present.  No harm done, most important both have contributed and Hale's logic is sound.  Indeed, other roofs may not be dismissed, such as that of that wagon sitting so innocently down in the meadow.
"You said polished stone could work.  How about the floor under all that trash in there?  I've a bad feeling," Art grumbles; "we're going to need picks and shovels." 
"Why so unhappy?"  Leona questions. "Couple weeks ago you were anxious to dig the whole place up.  So, now you get your chance."
"Hey!" Beth exclaims, delightfully wide-eyed.  "What about our wanted posters?  You said there was one of you, too."
"Good thought."  Leona bolts for the cart to search them out before the onset of night has put the idea aside till morning.  Alas, both are casualties of the downpour encountered on their way to Karn's lodge, neither now more than a blur.  Passing them around inspires no further theories.  "I'm positive there was nothing in the background at all."
"Anyway, getting too dark now.  Something we all need to face up to," Leona cautions.  "Roux is out there, he's not going to give it up, he can't afford to and we're kind of exposed being in here on foot.  There's too much perimeter to keep watch, it would take all of us and we really need to concentrate on finding our exit point.  If Roux shows up, there's no place to hide and the cart's useless and there's no way we can defend this place.  If  shit happens grab a weapon and make for the high ground.
Come morning, first thing, I want to feed and water the mounts so they're ready to go.  We only have two saddles.  I think I can handle the gray bare back and it's the huskiest, best choice for riding double.  That means, Beth, your with me 'caus we're the lightest combination.  The saddles go on the two browns.  Mounts will be tied off in a small clearing I noticed about 200 feet up the hill.  Art, you and Hale on the browns and you may need to hang back some to help Hale mount up otherwise he won't stand a chance.
So, Anyone spots trouble holler out loud and clear and just go, there's no looking back.  Beth, if we're separated don't hesitate, get to the mounts and haul ass, understand?"  Leona aims a sharp eye in Beth's direction for a positive nod.  "Understand," she repeats.  Beth knows she will not relent till she gets the answer she wants, Beth concedes with a positive nod.  "When the smoke settles, those who get away can work their way back later.  Someone gets hurt, can't make it up the hill, game is over for them.  You must accept the loss and keep moving.  I'm gonna cut one of the stirrups from the left side of one saddle and rig it up on the gray.  Art you have some riding experience so the one with the missing stirrup should be yours 'cause I think it's better Hale have both.  I know it's not much of a plan, but under the circumstances it's the only back up I can muster.  On this discouraging note they crash for the evening, hopeful the coming day will shed more than sunlight upon their dilemma.
The rising sun provides an interesting fragment of excitement when Beth screams, having discovered she's been sharing her space with a black snake.  The sleek reptile was likely searching for a field mouse and finding Beth's blanket a suitably cozy place to spend the night settled in proving beyond the shadow of a doubt that what you don't know really won't hurt you.  In her enthusiasm to allow bygones to be gone, she practically climbs Hale like a tree.  There seems no end to the variety of good uses she's found for that lad.
Art is quick to their rescue with a 20-pound anti-snake bolder.  Wisely, the serpent has chosen to hide from the commotion in the ruffled blanket rather than attempt a run for it across open terrain.  Fortunately for the harmless snake, Art had the good sense not to ruin Beth's blanket by squashing the frightened critter.  Leona joins the fray and insisting Art stand down immediately and follows with a condensed resume extolling the virtues of black snakes.  Taking hold of the blanket's edge, she snaps it off the ground with a quick jerk.  Thus, propelling one very excited little mouse into a perfect triple backward somersault.  The rodent bounces once, rolls over twice, and hits the bricks with all four wheels in hyper drive warp speed.
"Mice too!" Beth squeaks breathlessly.  The snake thus revealed and only about half the size Beth remembered remains absolutely still in the hope no will notice.  Not even a flicker of the tongue does it dare.  Even were the ground covered with coal 'tis not likely an item one would missed.  Leona and the reptile stare at each other for a few moments then she gives it an encouraging nudge with a twig.  Conceding the jig's up, it slithers off to take refuge in a nearby rubble pile.  "You know it takes real nerve," she commends, "to be still when you're surrounded by four 60-foot tall aliens."
Excavation and demolition were not counted among the contingencies Leona planned for.  Resources lending themselves to such tasks are limited; backs are to be freely expended, fingernails held in reserve.  "We need to round up some flat boards to make do as shovels," she advises grimly.
"Bet this place has been picked over a hundred times," Art surmises brilliantly, knowing this will be his second go at it in less than two weeks.
"Since you already started poking around in the back, you and Hale finish that area out.  Don't be random, be systematic and careful.  We only want to do this once.  Beth and I will check the perimeter outside the walls for signs of other foundations or anything that might have been a trash pit.  I doubt they discarded much, but if any metal or glass has survived the trash pickers, I'm thinking that's where we'll find it."
"Any chance there's a basement under this place?"  Hale speculates.
"Construction's too basic.  Supporting a stone floor like this above another space would require quite an effort.  Doesn't strike me they had that kind of capability.  A root cellar maybe, and if there is it's probably out back where you guys will be.  For now, lets deal with what we can see."  Leona squints and tilts her head as having a second thought.  "Escape tunnel is a possibility though, and it could come in handy.  Keep an eye out for any ground depressions, anything that looks like it's sinking.  Hopefully it won't turn out to be graves."  Beth emits a discomforting moan.  "I presume the final step back is of a magical nature," Leona continues.  "So a tunnel probably wouldn't be the actual exit, more like the way to the way out.  I don't think we need something three-dimensional exactly.  There has to be some point where thickness no longer counts, one side is here, the other is where we want to be."
"Like a time warp," Hale implies.
"Yeah," Beth concurs immediately.  "Think Sci-fi channel reruns."
"Okay, so we're looking for something reflective and most likely flat on the floor or ground," Leona summarizes.  "Let's find it so we can get the hell outta here."
They disperse immersed in high-octane enthusiasm.  Every loose stone is prodded or rolled aside, every crevice invaded and every square inch of more than half the floor within the building's walls cleared of debris and carefully scrutinized.
 By way of diversions--that is any excuse to take a break; box turtles are fair game as they are not exactly an aggressive sort.  Upon Hale's approach, the shy reptile has recluses itself within the first line of turtle defense.  Cloistered safely there within, it's probably wondering more of why gravity seems so suddenly amiss than what dangers lurk outside of its shell as Hale transports it like a child might pretend to fly a toy airplane.  Round and round he goes in up-side-down curls and loppy loops as he approaches, anxious to present his humble offering to the maiden of his fancy.  "Careful!" he cautions in a sarcastic tone, "could be an attack turtle."  Beth wrinkles her nose and points authoritatively toward the ground, not wishing to make personal hands-on contact just yet.  Whereupon Hale places his gift at her feet, then backs away, his head bowed, as would a servant humbly depart from his queen.  City girls don't get much exposure to real animals--that is, beyond cats and dogs or the occasional glimpse of a squirrel.  This has become a grand opportunity for Beth to expand her horizons, becoming quite the naturalist in fact.  She sits herself down and patiently awaits an opportunity to convene a summit.  In due time the front of the shell begins to lower with a hissing sound and a little green beak sort of nose cautiously presents itself.
"Well, it's not a snapper," Leona advises.  "But I still wouldn't put that little pinkie of yours in front of its face; I think they like worms."  Beth and her new object of interest are like a pair of vaudeville comedians working on their act.  Confident she can outrun the creature were it to give chase she leans nearer the ground to get a better look.  Soon as her big bright eyes meet the beady little red ones peeking from within there's a huff of smelly turtle BO and the shell whooshes shut again.  Beth feels slighted, a genuine southern bell being snubbed by a self-propelled pebble is surely the low point of the entire local social scene.  Not the sort to be put off by a mere turtle, she digs in, determined to await the fearsome critter's reappearance.  Turtles, even when they're in a hurry, always seem caught in a perpetual slow-motion video.  As such they are naturally availed of considerable patience, much more so than Beth could ever hope to muster.  After about 3 minutes she calls it a draw and disengages.  When next she takes notice of Hale's offering, the creature's in four wheel turtle over drive, stretching it's neck forward far as it can like a long distance runner grasping for the finish line.  With several mighty strides in a final burst of speed the exhausted little fellow's tail flips up into the air as it nose dives over the edge, disappearing into one of the murky bogs fed by the cistern's overflow.  This surely the most exciting local remake of the 'Great Escape' yet.  
Dusk of day finds them a weary lot.  Art's never done so much physical labor in one continuous shift.  Leona peers upward toward what little remains of the roof structure.  She's considering attempting the ascent to get a better view; perhaps something not obvious from the ground might be revealed from above.  All the day's efforts have yielded nothing, not a single device in their favor lest it be worn gray fieldstone they unknowingly seek.  Though the air is cool everyone is soaked with perspiration.  Listless, the clouds of dust attending their labors has attached itself to damp clothing and skin sure as iron filings would seek a magnet.  None may claim another has shirked their duty as the proof is plain to see.  All are equally filthy from top to bottom, encrusted within a plaster combined of sweat and grime.  Tomorrow's not a holiday, but likely all shall wish it so.  Come morning the strains of their labors shall be much in evidence by way of muscles seemingly at odds with their owners.
All need a thorough dousing before retiring.  As one might suspect and chivalry demand's the ladies are first.  Securing blankets and the water pail to their faithful service while the guys putter with the fire they proceed to the spa.  The cistern's surface may not be breached that thousands of tiny plants fail to accompany each bucket of cool water.  Thankfully they're eager to float to the surface and so for the most part easily swept aside.  Bright once more and attending a calm sky speckled with countless flecks of light, the moon dares watch as these two young damsels disrobe.  All the stars have come too and lend their soft cool light well upon these maidenly forms.  One then the other frolics and twirls about while the second of them, standing upon the cistern's wall, pours water over the other's head.
