That near the pool's surface has been warmed during the day to serve these nymphs, but still it brings a tantalizing chill when cast upon bodies now hidden from the sun's warmth.  A pair of fairest Titania's own handmaidens could make no more provocative sport of an autumn's early evening.  An owl trumpets his approval and a chorus of crickets would seem to agree.  Surely were there fairies hiding in the wood, they, so enticed, would come forth to join in such delight.
The lads watch without comment, Art as much of frustration as Hale anticipating Lady Beth's return.  Wrapped in blankets, their clothes in hand, the ladies come now to the fire's radiant glow.  The lads are next and soon thereafter off they go.
Beth acts unconcerned of the guy's activities, coyly stirring their pot of rice, least till she hears water splashing about.  She looks to Leona like a puppy begging to be let out and allowed play.  Leona returns a sarcastic pout.  "Go on, I don't care."  Beth slinks to the edge of the crumbling doorway to watch, her interest no less than that of the lads just a moment before.  She nods insistently toward Leona for her to join.  Devilish little deeds so desire company to justify their doing.  "Pervert!" Leona teases with a smile as she waves off the invitation.
"Come onnnn," Beth insists. "Art's got such a cute little ass," she adds ever so quietly.
Leona declines, preferring to concern herself with the dismal results of their labors.  The lads return draping their soaked clothing over tripods of saplings arranged around the fire.  Hale and Beth share a blanket, their antics and giggles challenge the other couple to get over their differences and snuggle up.  But Art and Leona are taking separate blankets this year.  'Tis deeds alone that count, as words are but a spoken thought.  Thus, for all the words ever spoken and of all those promises ever made, will a single grain of sand move not.  His lack of support in the meadow that early morn has cooled her feelings far beyond what any word might hope to thaw.
"Everyone makes a little misjudgment once in a while," Art pleads quietly.
"Bullshit!  It's not like we met yesterday."  Her gaze sharp as a razor.  "Situations like that people don't just abandon each other.  Either be quiet or get lost."  Ouch! Hale cringes.
Next morning, only the birds have retained their enthusiasm toward the beginning of another day.  For there seems a lot more friction in the movements of everyone's parts.  When Art attempts to rise, he tumbles back to the ground, reeling into a painful ball.  "Holly shittt," he exclaims agonizingly.  "Ummmm!"  Rocking back and forth he grasps at his calf, rubbing and kneading to gain some relief "Ahhh... damnnnn!"  Muscle tissue within his right calf is contracting, twisting itself into a knot hard as any block of wood and the more he attempts to ease it the tighter it becomes.  Thus, a charley horse is born, Art's first, the body's retribution for sacrifices demanded of it the previous day.  Both the girls imagine he's been bitten by some venomous creature, but Hale recognizes the symptoms immediately.  He comes to his buddy's rescue.  Grabbing the toes of Art's foot, he pushes them back toward his knee.  A useful tactic learned at football practice which can help relieve this sort of involuntary muscular contraction.
"You gotta relax, man," he instructs sympathetically.  "I know it ain't easy, but it's the only way.  It'll just keep getting tighter if you don't."  A suggestion akin to advising someone who is underwater drowning that the best approach is to exhale.  Nearly an hour passes before Art's able to stand again; even then his mobility is hindered by a cautious limp.  Once experienced, especially for the newly initiated, anticipating a relapse can be frightful, like treading upon defective land mines.  Spasms of this nature begin with a subtle telltale twitch; a second's delay in pulling the toes back can yield a truly painful reward and once it starts time is the only remedy.
Leona's stock of dried goods is hardy but essentially tasteless.  In a supplementary capacity Hale has taken to forays into what remains of the orchard to retrieve apples.  Years of neglect and a generous supply of unpicked fruit have seeded a tangled thicket.  Though fruit-bearing trees willingly offer their treasures to any who care to have them and so one would think they are better repaid for such kindness, but no, for they are a sorely tormented lot.  Much preferred by wood borers, those trees remaining in a tortured defensive posture; their bark frayed, coarse, and covered with gobs of sticky sap oozing from numerous insect-inflicted wounds.
Such is a tricky domain, even for the sure-footed, not wise then for one nursing a buggered knee.  Hale soon comes hobbling back to the camp, a knurled branch to supplement his effort.  Fresh sap can be slippery stuff, especially dangerous when mixed with deceptively brittle limbs and the laws of gravity.  He has in fact seriously re-injured his knee, opened a cut across his forehead, sprained one wrist and staved several fingers.  You know it's got to be bad because he didn't bring back any apples.  "What happened?" Beth pleads, rushing to his aid.
"Fell out of a tree," he admits shyly.
"A tree!"  Leona exclaims in a disbelieving tone.
Beth deadpans, "great!" raising a hand to her forehead.  "You know Leo's gonna court-martial your ass."
"Sorry."  He excuses apologetically.
"I'm sure."  Beth offers sarcastically, "this is lousy timing, hon."
"Yeah I know.  Think I screwed up my wrist, too," he admits, wondering if he'll be shot before or after the hanging.
Totally exasperated, Leona closes her eyes and hisses.  "Why, of all things were you climbing trees with that bungled knee?"
"Apples!"
"Of course, it was a dumb question.  This is payback for creating an apple junkie."
Breakfast tea has yet to be poured and already 100% of their real manpower is disabled.  And that's the good news.  For truth be told, His Lordship and company are just now coming to a cautious, quiet halt along the roadway.  Hardly 600 yards separate Roux's storm troopers from where Hale stands at this moment.  And though they may seem the voracious pursuers in this matter, a superior, aggressive lot, unswayed by adversity, these attributes exist mostly within Roux's imagination.  Lurking just beneath their helmets are intimate visions of scorching fireballs and recollections of a thunderous force which fell upon the Keep sweeping everything in its path aside.  And now, upon all else, rumors of demonious man-eating Squillets at the beck and call of their quarry, all of which have come to gnaw painfully upon their confidence.  Boldness then does not attend their arsenal of weaponry, nor have they great faith in those sending them forth as having brilliant strategies beyond the vengeful whims of an excessive compulsive master.
Counted now among them is the Wannabee, cautiously harboring some rather unpleasant memories of his own including some rather unsightly damage to his face that has yet to heal.  Anxious as ever though to claim his coins and enjoy some retribution for the slanders heaved upon his good character, not to mention the loss of several teeth and no slight portion of his jaw.  There also, good Pious idles about, disfigured servant and slave of Rueshaba the singed, who yet labors for her own revenge.  And last, but not least, faithful Escheloson, Roux's sorcerer, somewhat less confident than ever he's been and still deaf as a grape.  Thus does the end game draw nigh as all concerned prepare to lay siege upon what remains of the House of Iris.  Eager are they as to a banquet, for each the chance to carve up this wench who dares play at fantasy games though a kingdom were at stake.
Scouts have verified their objective's presence whereupon Roux and his commanders now plot the escapee's demise.  All have been sternly notified, the wench who invaded his apartments shall be taken alive no matter the inconvenience to life and limb.  For Lord Roux dearly wishes that scenario be replayed to a different tune.  The others may freely choose to be dog fodder or fight here and now to the death, he cares not which path they choose.
Speaking of the hounds, they are being held half a mile to the rear, well fed and their transport covered to keep them calm and quiet so as not to risk alerting the quarry to their impending disaster.
Aware of the ruin's particulars, they've come well prepared, multitudes of short ladders at their disposal to quickly top the walls.  Four separate squads are to advance on either flank with portions circling toward the rear, thus assuring none within may slip into the forest undetected.  Once in position they are to scale the perimeter wall from both sides and the back.  Thus confined, the rebels are encouraged to make for the front exit where Roux himself awaits with forty of his trusty men.
Back within the ruins of the hermitage Beth consoles her number one while Leona, noticeably discouraged, again binds splints around his leg.  Saturating a cloth with some of her home-brewed spirits, she sways it to and fro through the air several times.  Evaporating rapidly, the alcohol cools the cloth well below the air temperature.  "Let's see if we can get the swelling down some for starters."  She applies it to Hale's knee, covering it with another dry cloth as insulation.
"Oh that's nice!" Hale purrs with a sigh.  "Owe ya another one, Leo, really sorry about this."
"When it warms, wave it back and forth a couple of times to cool it again.  Art, how you doing?  Can you stand?"
"Yeah, but I still don't have any leverage and I'm not going anywhere in a hurry."
Depressed and somewhat unfocused, she nods her understanding while gazing out into the courtyard.  A trickle of water overflows the cistern, hardly enough that the spillways remain damp.  The excess glistens upon the stones, then, seeps into the abundance of mosses advancing upon its course.  "You... stupid... shit!" she exclaims.
"Huh!  Who?" Beth inquires, sounding like a new species of owl.
"Not you... me."  Leona turns toward Beth while ardently pointing toward the cistern.  "How dumb could I be and still able to boil water?  It's that pond," she declares endearingly.  "I mean, how hard is that to figure?  There are only two things here, dirt and that pond.  Dirt ain't going to get it.  What really makes rainbows?  Water! and a perfect reflector?"
"Water!" Beth chirps with glee.
"Right, and no matter where or how you place it, water always seeks to be perfectly level, which is to say facing the sky.  That's got to be it, I think we're home."
"What about all that green stuff?"
"To hide it, otherwise it would give itself away.  We would have picked up on a reflection right off.  The water's still there, but as they say, out of sight out of mind."
"Know what else?" Beth reminds.  "Didn't she say, 'in the garden?'  So how come we've been doing all this house cleaning?  The garden wouldn't be in here, and we--."
"Why didn't you say something sooner?"  Leona asks, throwing her arms aside.
"I just, ummm... I don't know."
"Pond idea sounds good," Hale agrees.  Maybe we could rig up a snorkel and check it out."
"Even the posters," Leona further concludes.  "It was water erased our pictures, they were gone just as we intend to be.  We need to skim the surface is all, see what's going on under there.  Isn't anybody paying attention to the cable movies?  The secrete passage is always under water."
"Meets the requirement to go a step beyond the image, too," Art concludes.  "Anything below the surface qualifies as beyond the image; if the exit's under the water everything fits."
"You want us to just jump in, then what?"  Beth asks in a curious tone.  "How deep is it?  You know, water's mostly like a place to get a tan.  I never actually get wet."
"No problem," Leona volunteers.  "Soon as we clear the surface some, I'm in there."
Even as Roux's men emerge from the forest all around them, Leona and her friends speculate enthusiastically as to what secrets the pool may hold.  The advancing soldiers keep a watchful eye toward the upper edges of the ruin's crumbling perimeter wall.  A large contingent takes up position just outside the gateway.  Roux along with several of his commanders, his sorcerer Escheloson and the Wannabee have stationed themselves at a collapsed portion of the front courtyard wall, a seemingly safe position from which to observe and coordinate the attack.  What brick and stone yet remains intact on either side of the breach will afford protection to the VIP's.  For 'tis likely when trapped His Lordship's delight may take to wielding thunder balls once more.  Pious has slipped away to inform his master of current events and pray she reward him kindly for services faithfully executed.
Word's passed to the rear elements, the front now being secure, time has come to flush the game from their hiding places.  This lot is not so laced and bound up in metal scales as the others are, for if their effort is to prevail, stealth is key.  Given that task, such precautions of life and limb would tingle and squeak foretelling of their advance.  With a hand signal their commander orders them up the ladders so as to slip quietly over the ramparts and drop light as one may into the brush within the perimeter walls.  Many slink cautiously toward the building's rear doorway.  Lesser numbers advance along both sides of the ruin.
"Don't we have to wait till tonight?" Hale mumbles while struggling to contain a scoop of rice.
"Tonight! why?" Leona inquires curiously.
"Lay with the stars, wasn't that the clue?  They don't come out until it gets dark."
Leona takes a tiny nip off the end of her little fingernail and looks toward Beth with a puzzled grin.
Beth shrugs and smiles back, "I know... but I like him anyway."
"What?" Hale demands.
Leona points toward the sky.  "Day or night, Hale, they're up there."
"Well yeah, but... ah... never mind."
"You need to get away from the TV for a while, the laugh track is ruining your thought process."
Art catches sight of someone approaching the far end of the building "Hey!  Who was that?  I just saw some guy in back."
"The grim reaper," Leona advises stressfully, "we get cornered in here we're dead."  She grabs Hale.  "Art give me a hand."  Art takes hold of the other arm and between them they jerk Hale to his feet.  "Straight for the pond, go... before they cut us off."  Hale's paid heed to at least some of her instructions, a crossbow still slung over his shoulder, locked and loaded.  "Beth, your bow, get moving." Leona commands, snatching up her leather carry bag, the closest thing to a shield at hand.
"What if there's nothing in there but water?"  Beth dismays aloud.
"Just go!  It's a one-way trip;" she cautions morbidly.  "If it doesn't work just hold onto something and accept that we've lost.  Don't come back to the surface, it'll be better than the dogs."
A dozen men have entered from the ruin's rear portal; they advance slowly side by each.  Though not sheathed in iron and mail, each carries a heavy shield to keep him from an archer's venom.  First to challenge their advance is a stout bearded lad, shield and blade in hand.  Boldly he strides into the doorway before them, a moment more and there stands another at his side.  Art hesitates.  With Hale in toe and lacking any type of weapon there's no way he's going to charge headlong into these two goons.  Leona snatches up the ax.  She whirls around fast as she can using herself as a counterbalance and sends it swirling toward the doorway like a discus.
Six pounds of lopsided sharp spinning iron is not to be taken lightly, nor is the adrenaline-saturated feline following close behind.  The ax is deflected by one fellow's shield, the blow sending him backwards, off balance, and for a few critical moments out of play.  His partner crouches into a defensive posture.  On the advance Leona hooks the toe of her boot under the edge of a piece of wood half buried in the dust, heaving it forward.  The one standing pat, now forced to guard his eyes from the oncoming sand and debris.  They are vulnerable and she's upon them; both near instantly rendered to lesser portions than once they were.  Her blade's inscription is not an idle boast, for shields presented in their defense are shredded as were they cardboard.  Dirty pool, unfair, perhaps even dishonorable, so what!  Leona's conscience has been on hold since the affair at the keep's guard shack.  Besides, crimes are better confessed but once after all the killing is done.  With the dawn, a bad day has begun and any who dare stand in her path are going to get their fair share of it.
With the exit cleared, Beth leads off, crossbow at the ready.  Hale and Art follow at a brisk limp while Leona assumes the rear guard, facing off against those advancing through the ruin.
As the escapees move toward the pool, Roux's men exit the hermitage, forming up across the front.  A seemingly endless flow joins their ranks coming around from both sides of the ruin.  Having seen the mess she's made of the two capable fellows who conspired to block her exit, all hesitate to press forward.  After all, Roux has ordered she be captured and there is no mandate to engage.  The plan requires only that they continue herding the escapees toward the trap at the front.  Even so, two ambitious fellows have moved up on the right flank.  Only Beth with a single dart stands between them and the guys hobbling toward the edge of the cistern.  Roux feels himself imperious decked out in thirty pounds of his finest armor for the occasion.  Golden boars, wolves, and stags adorn the ironwork, with strips of oiled leather strategically fashioned therein to belie embarrassing squeaks, all generously padded so as not to chafe his tender hide.  Fifty more of his troops are spread across the opposite end of the courtyard closing on the far side of the cistern.  His trap perfectly executed, feelings of absolute sovereignty well up sparking his appetite for blood.  Restraint is difficult.  He could order an all out charge and have them slaughtered within a few moments, but 'tis a treat to be savored not gobbled up.  A few moments more and they shall be so confined as to stand back to back with nary a step more to take.
Hale and Art have all but reached the cistern.  Beth holds those on the right flank at bay, more by fierce disposition than the single dart at her disposal.  They tease and harass from the safety of their shields.  But the price she demands is a clear shot and she refuses to invest her projectile for anything less.  Retreating as far as the elevated stone pedestal, Leona yet remains about twenty feet from the cistern facing off against forty somewhat hesitant troops.
As Hale and Art are not protected by royal decree, a couple scrappy sorts on the left flank have decided to take the initiative.  They advance quickly with pikes, perchance to earn rewards of coin or good favor were they the first to draw blood and secure this hapless pair of rogues.
Much to Roux's surprise, Art turns his back to the advancing troops, stoops, locks his arms around Hale's knees.  He then stands, heaving his buddy over the low wall headlong into the green goop.  Hale's belly flop sends a tidal wave over Art and Beth.
What's this? Roux laments.  Have they concocted a suicide pact to deny me?  Is there a way unseen by which they might escape?  The unexpected splash and ensuing recoil distract those two advancing against the lads with pikes.  Art's slashed, cut as one blade slides by just below his ribs, so sharp in fact he's completely unaware of its intrusion.  The second lancer is distracted such that his thrust is driven savagely into the low stone wall where Hale stood but a moment ago.  The shattering staff mortifies Art.  He turns to find these glory hounds far too near for comfort.  They actually attacked him while his back was turned.  This game really sucks, he concludes.  Instinctively sidestepping a second thrust by the fellow he still hasn't realized wounded him.  I don't even have a weapon, he comes to realize.  This is totally unfair! 
Beth's attention has likewise been misplaced by Hale's graceful departure, encouraging those whom she had faced to play their hand.  Both advance quickly intent on catching hold of their prize's menacing crossbow.  The first is near at arm's reach by the time their venture's discovered.  The closer fellow begins to turn away in a retreat.  Panic is not an option for Beth, neither is there time to evade their advance.  Raising her sights she looses the dart.  So little resistance does the throat offer a projectile of this velocity that it passes straight through the first lad's windpipe and settles squarely several inches into the collar bone of the eager fellow next in line.  She follows the shot with a merciless assault; using the spent crossbow to batter both to the ground, not that they needed any further discouragement.  Half dozen brave fellows sprint in her direction now--not to aid their fallen comrades, but eager to claim their duly forfeit prize.
Meanwhile, Art has managed to grab the front of the lance he's just barely avoided, yanking it toward him and bringing the owner close enough to offer a full roundhouse knuckle sandwich as reward for his skullduggery.  Wow! Does that hurt or what?  Thinking he may have just broken his hand.  His adversary concedes ownership of the weapon.  He can get another pointed stick anytime so why make a big deal out of it?  Besides he's already laid claim to fame and fortune by cutting the guy wide open.  Once Art takes possession, his first order of business is bringing the pointed end around to his defense.  In so doing, and not by accident, the flat side of the blade catches the previous owner alongside the head with a frightful whack.
Though the second attacker's thrust missed Hale, shattering his lance's blade, there remains a fair portion of ragged yet capable metal.  Art blocks the fellow's second attempt, jamming the oncoming pike downward against the stone paving with his newly confiscated lance.  As it skids by he jumps on the end, splintering the wooden shaft and binding it against the ground.  Using his opponent's disabled pike as a guide rail for his own blade, he swipes it upward directly into the fellow's arm.  Though Art hesitates to actually  stab his assailants, there seems little remorse at pounding on their heads in a good sportsman sort of way with his new stick.  More painful I'm sure is a sustained verbal assault that would hurt anyone's feelings.  Enveloped by the excitement, fueled by a healthy injection of adrenaline and the need to keep moving, Art remains dangerously unaware his side has been slashed wide opened, though nothing important has fallen out yet.
Several of His Lordship's archers take note of the whopping their associates are getting and assume to remedy these misdeeds.  Art has backed against the low cistern wall, his retreat encouraged by the impact of a broad-head now protruding from his abdomen.  Dull, numbing at first, strange, and acutely sharp all at the same time, his lance no longer matters; he allows it drop.  In short order, another penetrates his right forearm and a third grazes the side of his face slashing off most of his ear.  No less, however, is his concern at discovering the ground is covered with blood--his in fact, streaming freely from the deep incision across his side.  The bleeding has been disguised up till now by the soaking he incurred when Hale was heaved into the pool.  How much more could there be?  His trouser leg is completely saturated and there appears an unrealistic amount spreading across the ground.  The little plants expelled from the cistern are floating away upon it.  Being cut to ribbons is serious business.  For whatever it's worth he needs to get into the water and quickly.  The past three seconds have seen him reduced to a dead man waiting to die.  This no different than any other bad dream when snarling monsters approach, no matter how hard you try, you just can't seem to move.  In this case he can move if he wants to, but the fact is, even the slightest attempt is rewarded with excruciatingly sharp pain within his gut.  Even breathing becomes a very cautious, calculated event for one thus impaled.  Essentially he is helpless. 
Roux's attention is locked onto the pool's surface.  When Hale fails to reappear, as people who breathe routinely do under such circumstances, he turns to Escheloson for an explanation.  "Where's he gone?" Roux demands.  "Work your magic.  The lad who went into the water, where's he gone?"  The sorcerer can see something has distressed His Lordship, but can't make out the words too clearly.  Aghast at the thought the pool might offer them pardon, Roux becomes very anxious.  "Now, take them," Roux shouts.  "They must not enter the pool."
Some people never seem able to take a hint, but Beth knows when it's time to leave a party.  Hopping up onto the cistern wall and simultaneously retreating toward Art, she howls, "Leo come on, we're out of here, Art, let's go!"  She draws a deep breath in anticipation of her impending dunking.   A quick glance toward Art changes her priorities.  "Holy crap!"  Beth scampers over behind the lad.  Stooping down, she places both arms around just below his hips and lifts for all she's worth while pushing off backward from the rear edge of the wall.  It's a strain, and doubtful she could achieve it more than once, but the top heavy configuration allows her to drag him into the pool over top of herself.  He lets out quite a howl, but it was for his own good.  The effect is that of a brick landing in a kettle of pea soup.  The frothing blanket of green surges back closing over them like an impenetrable door.  If it had been Hale she could have never executed the lift.  Safe away they are at last.
Theoretically, the contest has concluded with Hale declared the official winner, he being the first to return.  Beth takes second as she hit the water a moment before Art.  That is, at least so far as those in the game room are concerned.  However, this fantasy plays solely within the workings of Leona's mind.  Thus, 'tis her perspective alone sets the pace here and now.  The king and queen of the prom take the floor, 'tis the last dance and the band plays on.
Those six who were attempting to recapture Beth, as an unintended consequence, have outflanked Leona, effectively placing themselves between her and the cistern.  Her only ally now is the stone pedestal marginally protecting her back.  Charging into their position will encourage the others to close quickly from behind.  She would be overwhelmed by sheer numbers.  Several cautiously advance from the ruin even now with pikes.  Such extended reach weapons afford a fair measure of safety from her blade.  Enchanted though it may be, it does not fly, and at best may reach only eighteen inches beyond her hand.
Ever morbid Pious has rejoined the crowd, an unlikely bent-over hag in drab dark robes at his side.  The old woman watches Leona's every move carefully, every expression, every sound, every glance.  What is the secret of her fire?  "Why does she endure this?"  Rueshaba hisses, pulling on Pious' robes like a child wanting attention.  "Fighting with sticks, why not use your fire?  Let me see it done."
"They're getting away," Roux exclaims, grabbing one of his commanders by the arm and shoving him toward the fray.  "Alive, I want her alive," he warns more than commands.  "See to it."
So that's why the bowmen haven't made a porcupine of my hide.  Certainly she harbors no such obligations on their behalf.
One card, the joker yet remains to play, her last grenade patiently awaiting the call to arms.  Very indiscriminate devices these, not the sort to pick and choose between friend and foe.  In the open and at close quarters her risk is no less than any of theirs.  Better this than dog chow.  Unfortunately they can not be thrown, for being made of ceramic if the shell cracks open on impact the charge will flash and fizzle away, more or less harmlessly.  Based upon her reputation and the nightmares of those with previous experience, anything this witch does is seriously suspect.  She strikes the fuse and sets the smoldering crock atop the heavy stone pedestal at her back.  She shouts an 'I dare you' glance at her antagonizes and smiles.  This particular group of troops are wary of such deeds.  What beast is summoned to her cause, what plague descends at her beck and call?  Unnerving quiet and stillness settle upon her adversaries, they as one unable to watch its eminent advance, awaiting the stroke of a guillotine.  None dare speculate, but a solitary owl. "Who... who?" it warns without a care.  Taunting them, break ranks, back away, but any with the audacity to retreat would at least be hanged.  'Tis between a Roux and a hard place they stand.  Leona is quietly counting, for whom her demon may seek is not the question, but only when.
Being as one intimately acquainted with Leona's sense of humor, Escheloson's eyes sharpen upon the foreboding crock.  A device as this bodes ill of past events, his ears screaming still in testament to such clever jest.  "Milord, take heed," he stutters.  Twirling his cloak about himself and dropping into a protective heap.  All look to the cowering sorcerer.  Great concern comes upon each furrowed brow and a wicked sense of impending doom creeps up many a spine just now.  Roux, not the least among them, laments to himself of this foolish quest.  He dare not so much as draw down his visor now, for the faintest sign of concern would scatter the ranks in panic.  Finally, it's Roux who must remain defiant and steadfast.  A worthy test of his grit is past due and shall soon descend upon them all.
On silent count of seven Leona ducks below the heavy stone slab, shielding her eyes and ears and rendering herself defenseless, come what may.  If the grenade fails to detonate she is lost.  If the blast topples the slab she may be crushed or trapped beneath it.  Shielded yes, but still a mere twenty inches from grown zero.  Such a concussion risks her sense of balance and the ability to navigate one's way to the cistern.  Hard partying is great merriment, but a toll is unavoidable and this 'twill be nothing akin to a hangover.
An ear-piercing thunderclap erupts amid a hail of lead fragments.  With the pedestal as an elevated deflector, those in attendance are presented a circular, chest-high shotgun blast.  Slight of their number in the forefront are spared the bloodletting.  Though pawns they may have been, for more than a few the game has ended.  Those still able to retreat do so while many of their comrades squirm about upon the pavement as though they are remnants from a nest of singed bag worm caterpillars.
Roux has toppled from his regal perch, more of surprise than the result of damage.  The worst of his injuries, a few scratches and pings rendered to his fine portable fortification.  Though mobility is restrained of those so encumbered when heaved to the ground, his fortunate commanders are quick to have him upright and back in the fray.  One of the officers not so lucky.  Having a pellet through his cheek and out the back of his neck, is upon his knees in the midst of dying.  Two have struck Pious the Pale without consequence.  The witch is quick to extract them and cauterize his wounds with not a drop of blood to be spent.  She looks curiously upon the warm bloody pellets laying in her palm, then casts them aside.   
Shaken, yet still functional, Leona sprints toward the cistern.  Two adversaries yet remain able and upright between her and the pool.  Of these, upon her advance one withdraws, he being fully convinced fate has granted him another day and wishing not to tempt it further.  She engages the last obstacle, a stubborn beanpole of a fellow who has made the less wise choice to stand in her way.  His blade sheared at the first strike, the lower quarter of his shield and a slash across his thigh with the next.  And that a kindness, for just as easily she could have taken off his head.  Wiser now than just before, he stands down and with heavy breathing bids her go upon her way.
Roux can see his opportunity to torment is slipping away, but perhaps yet there is a chance to kill.  He commandeers a crossbow from one of his captains, freeing the dart in contradiction to his own decree.  Leona has one foot on the cistern's wall and bounds upward as the spirited little javelin strikes her squarely in the back.  Both arms sprout outward like wings when it strikes, the impact tipping her forward headlong into the comforting emerald porridge.
Those still alert and quick of eye perchance took note of something reflective that trickled as it seemed to fall from the sky.  "Ah!" the old crone Rueshaba exclaims.  "What have trolls to do with this?  Why do they intercede?"  Exasperated at the turn of events, she grabs Pious' arm and grits her teeth.  "The fire," she demands, "where is your fire?"  Poor old Pious lets out a mournful wail; in her unsettled state she has crushed his wrist--the good one that is.  All part of a days work, he concedes sadly.
'Tis no less a distressing morning also for the Crayfish who lounge about the silt in the cistern's lowest depths.  Their solitude rudely disturbed thrice now by great particles of debris falling from their sky into this normally serene world.  At times a heavy thunderstorm has churned the pool's surface to the point of speculation, but nothing to compare with recent events.  Rumors the sky is falling are becoming rampant.  Thus, nearly all have taken refuge under sturdy clumps of sediment or loose stones.  Even docile salamanders who care little but to watch and wait are now within moss-shrouded crevices, hiding as not to risk their fate.  Yet another comes crashing down upon them now.  Trailed of a great frothing infusion, tiny green surface dwellers swirling in delight, dancing they amid a seething broth of bubbles glistening bright.  Slowly, but half a revolution does she turn along the way, though time has chosen to tally not the moments of this precarious day.  With fanfare not and motionless as one forever meant to stay, settling upon the cistern's floor, there at last content to lay.  The murky sediment is soft, the water cool, pleasant in fact for those of late without a care, a lady of Durer bold enough to stay the course that none other would dare.
The iron dart has preceded her arrival, and as she rests there in the sediment.  Its razor-sharp point seized to the face of a large hexagonal coin.  Deceiving this coin, its appearance that of gold.  Were it thus, however, the dart surely would have gone half the way through and remain securely embedded deep within her back.  A timely gift, the talisman of a stout gruffy fellow, rendered up in appreciation that he and his brothers have secured honorable closure.  As they must consumed of fire be, and so, a thread once thought loose is tightly bound of the weaver's tapestry.  Good favor now returned in timely fashion from enemies come to part as may only friends; as they were turned to ash and thus, allowed upon the winds.  A gift to one who might otherwise have just now joined with them.
Leona's eyes are open.  She can see numerous dark silhouettes cast upon the pool's clouded green surface; they bob about around the perimeter like spectators peering into a tiny submerged coliseum.
Roux and those of his entourage still capable approach the cistern.  Feeling confident his shot has found its mark, he wishes to savor her demise, perhaps at least the wench still struggles for breath.  He commands his sorcerer, or rather shouts intensely into the fellow's ear.  "Clear this slime away, I would know her fate."  Escheloson points a finger to the offending greens and begins twirling it about.  The movement soon includes his wrist, then his forearm in ever increasing circles.  A small whirlwind commences, sucking up the plants as a dust devil would draw up leaves from the ground.  Away it goes, leaving the pool's surface crystal clear and allowing light of day reach into the depths.
Approaching the pool's edge, Rueshaba peers into the water contentedly.  "See how she teases?  Like a worm-baited hook.  Come closer she invites, just as she bid to me.  Sleeping there in the forest as though with not a hint of my approach."  Morbid sarcasm tinges her every word.  "All the while enticing, come closer.  I will not bite thee; I am helpless in your presence."  None but Pious acknowledges the withered old crone's presence in the least.  Others hear only a raspy murmuring one might think the rustling of dry leaves.  For only those she's bound or hexed need be privileged of her whereabouts.
Were she not dispelled of the possible consequence, Rueshaba could enter the pool herself, for she is one of the original ten and thus entitled to exit via any available portal.  Strangely enough, Leona wouldn't even object, for she knows nothing of this witch.  Never have they met either as friend nor foe.  'Twas Bird's impression singed fiercely into Rueshaba's mind that holds her now at bay--thus her ardent desire to comprehend the fire she may need defense of again someday.  Alas, it can never be, for Bird has left the game that Leona might choose a second card when that critical debt at the prison's gate came due.
Staring back at her observers, Leona blinks several times.  An arm moves, then her head and shoulders as though attempting to relieve some discomfort of the neck.  Thoughts are random, still muddled by the explosion.  Where are the others?  Why am I still here?  She considers.  Were they part of some grand illusion or are they safely returned?  And if that, is it my duty now to remain?
"She lives!" Roux mumbles in a disbelieving but delighted tone.  He grabs the Wannabee, "Well lad, why do you hesitate?  Earn your purse!  Drag her up here to me."  A hundred in gold is a powerful incentive--retirement in grand style in fact.  He's upon the wall without hesitation.  Taking hold of his nose he drops into the water.  Passing through the pool's surface by the uninvited is not a journey without a toll, however.  For 'tis now they learn that animate entities, who are not predisposed of such transitions, quietly disintegrate at the horizontal boundary between this world and the next.  With not the slightest struggle, he is transformed, fizzling away like a giant Alka-Seltzer into a myriad of tiny bubbles.
Though still flat upon her back, Leona has instinctively drawn a dagger.  Having observed the Wannabee's misguided adventure, she smiles.  No more deserving a fellow could draw such an appropriate lot.  Thoughts come in an orderly fashion now.  Why have I not floated to the surface? she questions.  I'm not a fish, but there's no apparent need to breathe?  Have I not been struck a killing blow?  Am I dead or dying here, finally?  All that remains of her friends is Hale's weapon.  The wooden stock bobs slightly as it attempts to rise against the iron bow's weight.  Are the others safe, or had they gone the way of that fool just now?  Their clothing isn't floating around in the pool as does his.  She can see the dart laying in the silt nearby and at first imagines it to have passed clean through her chest.  What's this?  Retrieving the projectile, she separates the nearly punctured coin from its deadly companion with a twist.
The pool continues to effervesce violently as remnants of the Wannabee bob to the surface and dissolve.  In short order, only his clothes and shoes remain, floating aimlessly overhead.  Still in proper order mind you, but now completely devoid of Sir Wannabee.  Many of those to witness his strange dissolution step back from the edge.  The wiser of them casually slip to the rear.  'Tis better to be out of sight, and thus out of His Lordship's thoughts when things strange as this occur.  Any with the slightest disfavor to his credit might be the next chosen for some experimental mission that perchance the Wannabee's fate was a tragic fluke where the next fool might prevail.
Roux is disappointed at the fate of his stool pigeon.  He grabs Escheloson's robes and demands.  "What magic does she curse upon me now?"
The Sorcerer places his palm near the water's surface.  "'Tis not water, milord, but a boundary; there beyond is a realm to which none here may pass."
"No!" he shouts, pointing ominously to one of his commanders.  "I will not be denied.  Chains, gather chains and grapples, be quick!"
Though Leona's trials continue within the workings of fantasy's jest, views hinting of reality now serve us best.  All the guest's candles have been extinguished, and that special one presiding upon the orator's podium relit.  Thus, is reality invited once again to Mark's chamber of guile and wit.
Hale's ecstatic at being declared the official victor.  Sanaia has presented him with a heavy trophy bearing the likeness of a proud and mighty warrior.  Not to mention gift certificates for a half keg and a dozen party-size pizzas from one of their favorite campus eateries.  Pittance in fact, as someday he may discover his shinny trophy is 319 ounces troy of 24K solid gold.  He's in Hale heaven, dancing playfully with his loving consort the Lady Beth.  Both fully appreciate his success was based entirely upon logistical convenience.  What matters is that as a group they fared well.  Leona's pleased twice over, at least that portion of her remaining for sake of appearance here among her friends.  If indeed they ever left, they are safely returned to the world where they belong.  And of the other, thus absent from the cool menacing waters where the Lady of Durer doth yet dwell.
The other players have gracefully conceded; either the clues eluded them or they had no genuine desire to exit after all.  Turns out there were departure points in the vicinity of each player which any could have used.  The Harlot had nearly found her way entirely upon her own.  It was the spring Art was planning to bottle.  Roux's alter ego, the yuppie male, is a bit dismayed at being whipped by the country bumpkins.  He excuses the loss to becoming bored of such trivial entertainment.  Revelations exposing his true character have doomed Art in Leona's eyes.  When they part company on this occasion, it shall be the last time they see each other for many years to come.  Risking most of all is an arrogant young woman who harbors an ill-conceived notion that filching a sample of the scented wax from her candle is a harmless deed.  She intends to have it duplicated at a posh perfume shop where they concoct supposed one-of-a-kind fragrances to their customer's specifications.  Perhaps she will name it Essence of Rueshaba or Witches Brew.  Either might be appropriate as certainly her future is now very much at risk.  
Light of the new day has been withheld from the room so as not to deter the game's continuation.  None suspect the duration thus far in excess of nineteen hours.  But the piper must have his due.  Thus, a bit of jet lag is forthcoming to all.
While their guests chatter, rethinking strategies which might have served them better, Mark and Sanaia slip away to the spell room.  None but they are aware that within Leona's mind the contest proceeds at a devious pace.  "Why does she persist?"  Mark inquires with reserved concern.
"Could be she feels the need to resolve matters yet unattended.  Consider what she's learned of late.  Her friends are out of harm's reach, she has slight at risk knowing escape is but a thought away, and all but our villains are forbidden to enter the pool.  Thus, one might wonder, is she the sort to hold a grudge?"
"The candles have been extinguished.  How does she proceed?"
"Momentum perhaps.  This charade was as much her doing as ours.  We only guided and even then ever so slightly.  Have you never awoken from a dream, moments later closed your eyes and resumed where you left off?  The places and characters have been well defined within her thoughts.  There are rules you know, rules that bind both the enchanter and the enchanted.  So long as she abides of them, she may play as she will.  You could say she's dreaming with one eye open."
"For what purpose?"
"From flecks of image I've noticed it may well be the fate of the Lord of Orchard and those at the Inn she frequented.  One concerned as she, might ask, will they simply cease to be or will this villain return to take vengeance upon those who came to her aid?"
"She yet believes her circumstance real?"
"The thoughts behind her deeds are clouded, each has its place, neither one the same."  Sanaia nods with a consoling smile.  "Tend to your guests, sir, lest they become restless."  "I shall keep watch over your treasure while she tempts her demons and plays out her fantasies."
To the Minnon's stone once more, the open book which has come to be Leona's imagination.  There, Roux yet exists, thoroughly annoyed as always.  Impatiently, he curses everything that comes to mind while his commanders seek some means of extracting his prize from her lair.  Several hefty stones have been conscripted from the ruin and securely arranged into a ramp, this to allow one encumbered of armor easy access to the top of the cistern's wall.  There are more than a few who dare to wish he would topple into the water and fizzle away.  In spite of the Wannabee's uncommon demise, the pool's perimeter offers standing room only for the throng of observers yet able to enjoy the show.  One would think having suffered near thirty more of their country men dead or seriously set aside this very morn, that the devices of a certain feline might discourage such curiosity.  Banners snap and twirl overhead in the breeze accompanied by an ominous assortment of sharp knives upon sticks.  Hushed speculation abounds as to where the other escapees may have gotten off to and why this perpetual thorn in Roux's side has not.  Speak of the devil, he spies an unusually long-handled pike, the end thoughtfully constructed like a frog's gig of opposing hooked blades.  "There!" he points.  "You... come here with your pole."  Calling the lad forth, he eagerly snatches the weapon, this being a task he chooses not to assign.  "What of this?" he inquires of his sorcerer, as though a plea for complicity.
"So far as it may reach, milord," Escheloson assures.  Telling his master what will please him most, though he dearly wishes Roux would stop tormenting this witch.  Ill at ease he too watches, knowing 'tis folly with no good end to reach across such boundaries.  She being safe away within her own realm now, no telling what his disrespectful prodding may unleash.  Such details aside, Roux stands atop the cistern's containment with visions of revenge muddling his judgment.  His community standing is at stake here and in no small way.  He shall have his due, the cost be damned.  Lowering the blade into the water to get a bearing on his quarry, he raised his arm to thrust the pike downward as one might address an unsuspecting catfish.  Unsuspecting, think ye not, for indeed she has invited, in fact counted on his treachery.
"Caution milord," advises the wary sorcerer.  "What goes forth may come nigh as well."  A point well taken as Leona reaches out for the crossbow Hale has so graciously left behind.  She rises to a sitting position, brings it to bear at arm's length and sets the projectile in motion.  The dart is swift and the pool's surface now but six feet from the point of demarcation.  Armor, though adequate to sustain a crossbow's dart from most any direction in a combat situation it is sadly deficient when addressed from below ground level.  Of necessity, the leaves of iron are attached like shingles; otherwise his suit would prove so rigid as to preclude usefulness.  Rising from such a low angle, the sheets of armor actually guide the projectile to the first available junction.  Though not at full power due to the pool's fluid characteristics, the iron dart still slips easily between the overlapping plates.  It unites wickedly with His Lordship's person several inches below the navel and advances far enough to sample his breakfast.  Stunned, he rises on the tips of his toes, releasing the pike to find its own way.  Leona must roll slightly to avoid the barbed blade which plunges itself into the silt.  Lord Roux himself soon follows.  Knowing of the Wannabee's demise, he nearly dies of anticipation as the pool's surface races toward his face.  Alas, the cool water proves more refreshing than not.  Those nearby turn away or raise shields in defense of his wake, but none come to harm of it.
"Ah haaaa," Rueshaba cackles with delight.  "Ya can always count on an ass to act like an ass, and a witch to guard her secrets."  Pious nods his agreement diplomatically.  "Why waste fire to do the work of a pointed stick?" she adds with a disappointing growl.
One brilliant lad, soaked by His Lordship's untimely inclination to bathe, comes to a brilliant conclusion.  "The curse is lifted."  Fool that he is or thinking himself immortal, whichever, he gallantly plunges his arm into the pool.  At times enlightenment can prove a painful business.  As now for example with the hasty withdrawal of a fizzling stump accompanied by much audible regret and a serious rethinking of his previous theory.  A fine testament at least to Escheloson's wisdom and potent deterrent to any possessed of common sense and thinking to aid His Lordship in this, his well earned moment of despair.
For one clad of iron, Roux sinks very slowly, remaining quite rigid also.  As for any so impaled, as was Art, any attempt at movement would likely be at quite a premium.  Velvety wisps of red blend with pool's fluid as he approaches touchdown.  Ironic!  An entire legion of troops but a few feet away, yet not a one dare come to his service.  With Leona's guidance he's found the way home, like it or not.  She backs up several feet to allow him a private parking space, whereupon he manages an impressively stable landing upon all fours.  His arrival incites little more fanfare than a cloud of sediment.  Countless tiny streams of excited air bubbles escaping through the many seams of his armor glisten as they rise in the subdued light adding a sense of eloquence to His impending demise.
Watching, waiting, all is quiet and still.  Is this contest finally done then?  No!  Roux's head rises slowly and turns toward Leona as that of the aimless castle ghost who comes to life again and again.  And now a gauntlet of iron scales also, rises unsteadily from the debris.  Reaching out he takes hold of Leona's left forearm.  Precise and quick her response, she drives a wafer-thin dagger to the hilt through one of the eye slots of his visor.  Roux shutters, the lifeless armor collapsing face-first into the silt.  There's no need to pry his death grip from her arm; she has vanished.
"Did you see?" Rueshaba hisses as she prods Pious with a bony elbow.  "It was a very personal disagreement, one she chose to resolve by her own hand.  That is why she burned him not.  Reprimand is all that was deserved of my deed.  A third party assassin was I, a common hireling in her eyes.  He was different.  She lured him on until they alone were face to face and he helpless as a worm.  Oh, wicked woman who are you?  I shall forever wish to know."  She turns her attention to Pious and points a knurled finger.  "You should be pleased I've taken you under my wing before she thought to seek you out.  I cursed her bones, but they no longer do I seek.  Or rather someday it may she who digs mine up."
--
Enticements and diversions are hastily provided to keep his guests and allow Mark's anxious return to the spell room.  "Do we have a conclusion yet?" he asserts warily.
"She's slain her demon in spite of us," Sanaia informs, turning to Mark with a smile.  "And by this she has won sovereignty."
Mark's eyes light up.  "What do you say?"
"Play is by the rules of the Games Regal," Sanaia reminds, "is it not?  Having slain the sponsoring lord and master in single combat imparts all that was his... to her.  Interesting possibility, don't you agree? 
Marwyn hesitates for a moment to consider Sanaia's theory.  "Her experiences were a fabrication, there is no city to be had, their never was.  All was a self-deception, even more of her doing than ours."
"My point exactly!  Would you not allow the detail of it was extraordinary.  Unlike anything I've ever seen," Sanaia assures with a smile, "and I've seen more than a few, sir."
"It simply can not be."
I'm not sure the Minnon would agree.  But there is more.  She slew him on this side of the boundary, here in her world, not ours!  And she need not have done so, it was premeditated."
"That's... interesting.  Does this complicate our task?
"A little perhaps!  His headache will persist for a while.  If he visits a physician a scan may reveal that she partially lobotomized him.  His personality is likely to change some, for the better I think.
But, by all accounts your lady's back with us now.  She's let it go willingly and we alone possess the memories of her trials and exploits.  Are we done with the Minnon then?"  Marwyn nods affirmatively.  Waving a hand, Sanaia speaks in tongues unfamiliar to Marwyn.  With her words the glow wanes from the mouths and eyes of those snared within the ancient stone's embrace.  A breeze wisps through the room.  All the air within the chamber seemingly drawn into the cubical mass of coal-like substance as it fades again to an unimpressive dull black.  "Let us rejoin our guests," Sanaia suggests, "there is something of which you need be aware."  Both proceed to the game room to wish their visitors a safe trip home.  "Look to your former regal lord their, see how his lady attempts to comfort his eye.  I assure you also he has developed a rather annoying hangover, as they say, but I think it not of the wine he's been consuming.  When time permits you should review the last few minutes of her memories."
Hale, still riding high on his victory and glowing from ear to ear, rushes to Marwyn.  "Great game man, everybody's going to love this."  Hale exclaims joyously while shaking Marwyn's hand.  "You got a winner, dude, thanks for inviting us."  Hale retreats to join those at the buffet for a nightcap, though actually it's well past lunch time.
Let me tease you a bit, Sir," Sanaia suggests.  Marwyn nods.  "Is Lavare real?"
Marwyn squints, as to say how strange a question is that.  "Of course!"  He assures forthwith.
"And we as citizens there may proceed back and forth within the rules of Regal play, or as now with special permissions.  Yet none of either place may follow with us lest they fail in the passing and never be seen again.  And none here, but those of our own kind, even know from where we've come.  What difference then that this maiden has been able to venture back and forth, nearly at will in spite of us, to another world of neither place?  A fine one at that, too, entirely of fantasy that we helped her create.  One so fine in fact she seemed unable to assure herself which was real though she was aware of the other!  Confer with your three villains.  They are experienced, my binding here deceived them not for a moment, ask them what they though of hers.  So again, is Lavare real!  Or is it thus because we think so, as did she of this contrived fantasy just now?  Could we, thinking ourselves citizens of Lavare, be confounded of some clever paradox!"
"You know I'm but a pawn."
"Yes," She smiles, "and I too in this regard.  But still I dare, who's game are we really playing here?  There are many similarities between our position here relative to our world, and hers there, relative to here.  Could we the players be and she the game master, sir?"
His task complete, or so he thinks, Marwyn chooses to dismiss Sanaia's bewildering theories and at last draws a welcome breath of relief. He hastens to rejoin his guests fully confident that were Leona drawn back into his world, she would not arrive ill equipped.  The conversation is still lively though signs of fatigue are apparent.  Surveys attesting to the game's merits or the short falls thereof are dispensed to each player for return at their convenience.  With a yawn, Art announces the time to be slightly after four.  Everyone presumes that to be AM until Sanaia slides the vestibule doors aside.
  "Is that the sun?" exclaims the yuppie formerly known as Lord Roux with a recoil.  The light's impact upon his eyes not a kind jester to the thumping discomfort behind his brow.
"Sure looks like it," confirms his royal mate.
He looks at his watch.  "It's Saturday afternoon.  Oh man... are we late.  You gotta drive, my head's pounding."  They rush out to their Vet and zoom away without so much as a fare-thee-well.
The punks exchange gleeful smiles.  "Wow!" they quietly pronounce in unison, then, bid their hosts a fine day.  The girl follows her knight or jester as the case may be, holding ever so dearly onto his little finger.
Aren't we supposed to be at your cousin's barbecue around six... today?"  The former tax collector inquires of his vamp.  She nods.  He sighs, "Going to be a long afternoon."  She nods again.  He turns toward Sanaia and nods.  "Interesting... see ya."
Hale can't stop yawning now that he realizes what time it is.  "I suppose you wanna stop and get a burger," Beth presumes.
"Not really," he barely manages in the midst of a mighty inhale.
Nibbling non-aggressively at the tip of her trigger finger.  "Can I have that in writing?" Beth muses.
Mark observes Leona to be noticeably calmer than during the game.  This he feels an assurance her thoughts are once again in proper order.  Though something is on her mind, for she dallies about conspicuously while the others take their leave.  A small debt yet remains and she hopes to balance the account before departing.  When the coast is clear she approaches Mark.  "Earlier, when I met your pet, while I was snooping around your weapons collection, remember?"
"I assure you, your curiosity was not offensive," Mark quietly reaffirms. 
"Anyway, I sort of, well actually... I did promise your owl a treat, if that's okay with you?"
"Treats are the joy of Ulik's day."
"What do you think he might like?" she asks discreetly.
Glancing toward the remains of the buffet, Mark advises, "Someone appears to have rejected the pepperoni from their pizza.  I have a feeling he would like that a lot."
"Great... I was afraid I'd need to round up an unfortunate mouse or something."  Leona rescues the abandoned sausage, bending each slice over double to provide an accessible edge and neatly arranging them on a clean paper plate.  The moment she turns back toward Mark Ulik swoops out of the darkened hall behind the podium.  Gliding low across the floor, then throwing his wings up like sails, he rises gracefully to Mark's extended arm.  Presenting her offering with a courtly smile and gracious nod, Ulik accepts, delicately gathering up the slices with ease.
He's become too fond of spicy leftovers to bother the mice anymore.  "Whooo... Who-Whooo!" comes a seemingly appropriate response, as he turns his head and blinks.
"Lucky for them, those talons are ferocious.  Doesn't that hurt?"
"Something the size of my arm he can manage a good tight grip.  You wouldn't want him to perch on your shoulder though; there he might tend to dig in a little more... to feel secure."
"Well," she yawns, "oh! excuse me, better get rolling, crew's tired and anxious to get home."  Holding up the survey form, she assures, "I'll get this in the mail back to you on Monday.  Enjoyed your game, I think it'll fly.  Maybe we'll see ya around."  On her way out she casts an inquisitive eye toward those curious sliding doors.  Is it the library or armory that lies beyond? she wonders.  Truly a temptation to peek in and see for sure, but she resists.
'Tis done now, and with the departure of their beguiled guests illusion also begins to seek equilibrium.  The gracious Victorian fades, giving way to a tragically deteriorated wood frame house.  Even the lead plumbing's been stripped away by vandals to the local scrap yard and not a single door nor pane of glass remains intact.  That which was the room of spells has come to be a flimsy lean-too attached at the rear, the roof having collapsed long ago rendering the interior a mildewed ruin.  Though nary the boldest insect dared show its face there from dusk of yesterday till now.  A battered station wagon, the hood propped against its fender, sits alongside where just moments before a jaguar was perceived to be.  The exquisite grounds are now revealed as a haphazard tangle of weeds and ornery briers but for a mowed area which granted the visitors unrestrained access.  Stone sculptures have changed into rusting appliances and random heaps of rubbish litter the landscape.  Aside from the two, tall strategically placed bronze lamps that initiated the guise, the wondrous portal and surrounding walls are now only remnants of a crumbling wooden picket fence.  Though still very agile for one approaching her eighty-sixth year, Sanaia has withered a bit, too.  Mark, Ulik, and the Minnon's stone, the only constants of this deception remain as they were and truly are.  Majesty it seems is a simple matter of perception.  For thus, might a shard of broken glass in just the right light sparkle well as any diamond or star would dare entice?  Nine shinny black Chevy Suburbans have arrived and it's not a raid by the CIA.  A crew of husky fellows carrying crates emerge.  They will gather the two lamps and carefully pack the Minnon and it's base for the journey back to Lavare.  Dozens of security personnel and others with special talents emerge from the surrounding areas like termites from the wood work and converge upon the caravan.
"She would serve her city well if it comes to that," Sanaia remarks judiciously.  "There are few who would strike a promise to a bird and far less who would keep it.  I like this child.  Only a single flaw do I notice for one on such a course."  Mark turns a curious eye to await her valued opinion.  "I fear she's too loyal to her friends to be a politician.  She need learn that lies are deadlier than a knife in the back."  Sanaia passes the box of enchanted candles to Marwyn.  None of their guests took exception of the oddity that none had melted.
Hale and Beth have curled up amongst the battle accessories for the return trip.  "Hale, you ever considered letting your beard and mustache grow in?" Leona suggests.  "Judging from the shadow, might look good."  Turning her eyes to Beth, "What do ya think?"
Beth draws back to take a look.  "Maybe... be scratchy for a while, but I might make the sacrifice.  Huummm... Could be interesting once it got soft."
"What brought that up?" Art asks.
"Just a thought.  Let's get home, I'm so used up."

Chapter-16

THE REAL PRIZE, DURER, YET UNCLAIMED;
DARE SHE RISK THE DEADLIER GAME?

Having reviewed the Minnon's chronicle of events, the Henzec Tribunal has concluded Leona quite capable as to the matter of her safety within Lavare; questions of her willingness to relocate being set aside for the moment.  "Sadly mismanaged, as has been the case these past twenty years," The Nobleman of Equity concludes, "The House of Durer would benefit and likely prosper under the leadership of one possessing the level of determination she's demonstrated."  Is she then to be allowed to continue upon her present course toiling in the arts' of alchemy a stranger to herself as much as we?  Or do we set upon a path that she be conscripted as Lady of Durer, likely against her will, and that having been demonstrated to be a formidable obstacle?  We must ask ourselves; is the good of the realm a higher calling than the good of the maiden."
Grave questions these, perchance quite literally for some.  Lack of a monarch has not improved the city's lot.  Upon mandate of this very court the good citizens of Durer are subjugated by the constant bickering of three adjoining kingdoms in the name of providing a necessary civil authority.  At times these supposed good faith administrators have come to the point of proposing a physical division of the city itself including even the ramparts and gates.  Though all is not but wars of words, bloodless combat where character assassinations and underhanded politics have replaced the customary slaughter of good men.  Besides, they know the Henzecs would not allow outright bloodshed.  Of course there are occasionally fatal accidents.  Goals are difficult to define when the future is misguided so; loyalties become subverted unto frivolity and trust is reduced to the need for one's personal survival.  Thus, the good citizens of Durer languish under the yokes of waste and egomania.  However, with Leona's appearance and now the Minnon's nonpartisan intervention, questions as yet unresolved and shrouded beneath 20 years of dust are bubbling to the surface again.
Perceived to have the last word in such matters, the tribunal's decisions are considered absolute.  However, as Sanaia had warned, 'other interested parties' have come into this matter.  The omen of which is sleeping peacefully on a dried leaf confined within a quartz sphere.  Said bubble firmly secured atop a pedestal forged of extraordinary restraining elements.  This amidst six very sober robed figures pledged to sacrifice whatever is required to contain it.  Each of them chant in rhythmic whispers while meditating to soothe the little demon bound therewithin.  A creature perceived by its surrogate mother to be a bird, and thus so named, but that more of unrealized expectations than a misunderstanding of species.  And really, what one chooses to call this tiny creature matters not.  The question at hand being rather how has it come to be part of this riddle of Durer.
Marwyn's presence has been requested to clarify some loose ends--at least, this he expects.  On his left the sphere and its apparently volatile contents and to his right a small table.  Thereupon the medallion given up by the troll, Patch, in Leona's defense, and remarkably, her sword also.  Marwyn looks to the weapon with concern.  Aside from the medallion, thought lost within the workings of the spell, this is an element of Leona's memories made real; something that should not rightly exist.  The task assigned to him is complete, and admirably so.  Not only has he found the heir of Durer as requested, but also produced reasonable evidence to support her probable survival were she to return.
"Marwyn of Cereta... what do you know of that?" the Lord of Consequence inquires, pointing to Leona's pet.
"As a child I recall stories of tiny dragons who were thought able to set fires."  Marwyn continues with a cautious reserve.  "They were the delight of every storyteller.  I had never seen one until it appeared on the maiden's fingertip and even then I had no idea it was the creature of lore."
"Few have," implies the Judge of Sorrows.  "For nearly none so unfortunate have come away to tell the tale.  A dragon bites, you see.  They're about the size of a goat, strut around like large peacocks.  Golden brown, sometimes bluish, and they screech a lot, very annoying, something akin to a blue jay.  And very rare, too, but completely tame by comparison."  Pointing toward Bird, he continues.  "That, however, by definition is more a sort of demon; theoretically something which does not exist, they make no sound, they incinerate."
"By definition?"  Marwyn repeats inquiringly.
"They are the only known creature within the realm that does not abide the laws of nature.  You saw what happened when the witch tried to take the girl as she slept."
"Oh yes!" Marwyn admits with a sober tone of respect.  "Only then did I realized what it might be.  My learned associate, the sorceress Sanaia, immediately became aware something was out of place when it first appeared.  We dared not unravel the spell.  That is, the Minnon stood in her place and was aware of what was happening, but the maiden herself really didn't know.  Had we crossed the line and pulled her back it might have caused harm to the lady's mental disposition later."  Marwyn glances discreetly toward the demon he's somehow called forth.
"Be at ease, lad," the Nobleman of Equity assures.  "There is no plague come upon us.  Very slight is their number at our lever of the realm.  They blend peacefully with other small creatures and go unnoticed unless they are challenged, a cat or snake usually.  Fears arise only when some good citizen happens to witness the event.  Next thing, don't you know, everyone's off to drinking in excess and hunting dragons for a few days."
The Lord of Consequence rephrases his question; perhaps another approach might bring to mind some subtle clue as to why the demon's involvement.  "Her memories imply the creature hatched from an abandoned egg she found and assumed to be that of a bird.  Did you notice anything unusual as to how this came about?"
"I presumed it arose from one of the acquired memories used to construct the challenge.  Perhaps the witch herself actually had such an experience.  How is that done, the fire, if I may ask?"
"You may not," the Lord of Consequence admonishes, then clears his throat.  "Their origin and purpose is not a matter for discussion.  'Tis better thought to allow the sorcerers and such of our world to speculate than to confirm anything they suppose to be true."
Marwyn humbly nods his understanding.  "I beg your pardon, Milords.  Have I offended someone by my choice of means to resolve the lady's identity?"
"None are displeased with your efforts, sir.  You've done very well."
The Nobleman of Equity shrugs his shoulders slightly.  "We failed to anticipate your approach might reveal this little skeleton of a sort we've been hiding in our closet for these many years."
"I would care to know, how does she control it?"  the Judge of sorrows implores quietly.
"I don't believe she can," Marwyn informs.  "She appears to have no capacity in matters of sorcery.  They seem as a child and a puppy."
"A puppy!"  The inquiring judge turns to his associate, the Nobleman of Equity.  "One must be the master and the other thereby enticed.  Folly I think to imagine they stand eye to eye," he concludes smugly.
When the judge's attention returns, Marwyn continues defensibly.  "She never called upon it, even at the most perilous of times.  Milords, I truly believe she no understanding of what it was."
"In fact, that was duly noted, but Fate does not err in such ways."  The Lord of Consequence confides, somewhat frustrated, clasping his hands together and pointing with both forefingers.  "Which brings us to our dilemma.  What meaning should be attributed to the appearance of this extraordinary puppy?  And what are we to suppose with the delivery of this sword and demon here to us?  We thought perhaps you might know."
"Not I, Milords."
"There were occasions when she was enticed to abandon her world stay in the domain of her thoughts." implies the Lord of Consequence.  "Was this your doing?"
"Quite the opposite, Milords.  I prearranged the confrontation with the three trolls, thinking it best to have done with her trials quickly and simply."  Marwyn admits somewhat hesitantly.  "All other circumstances, as far as I know, were the free workings of the players themselves.  She was tormented constantly by doubt, never sure which path was real."
"A citizen of the realm she is," reminds the Judge of Sorrows.  "And this entire matter being the result of Regal Game play, thus say I, her obligations are subject to our jurisdiction no matter where she resides at this time.  Being completely unaware of the world of her origin is not an acceptable defense, but even more the reason to enlighten.  Lacking proper license as well, which is granted solely to those playing the Games Regal, her presence in sanctuary violates protocols of every sort.  I appreciate certainly great influence was employed to accomplish the child's departure, but her origin is now known and may not be ignored.  Under these circumstances, I submit none may harbor doubt of this.  To Lavare and the court of Durer she must return."
Marwyn's sad-of-eye expression inspires not hope, either for himself or the maiden who's feet he held to the fire.  The Lord of Consequence replies to his advocate's silence with only a great exhalation.  Why do the all-knowing inquire of me?  Marwyn wonders, perplexed of their apparent dilemma.  Surely they know that which has happened was meant to be.
"One last thing, lad.  What of this witch... Rueshaba?  How exactly did you come upon such an idea?"  The Lord of Consequence questions with notable reserve as one not wishing to raise undue alarm by his tone of voice.  "That has become a very sticky point, my boy.  Frankly, we were astonished to find that this particular crone had been invited into your plot.  Why include so lethal an adversary?  In fact, we are advised that even under these circumstances she might have caused harm, even so far as death to this maiden who has come under our protection.  What were you thinking, lad?"
Yes, and more important," The Nobleman of Equity intercedes, "exactly how did you acquire that candle?  No one, and I repeat no one is aware of her location.  Even we do not know where Rueshaba is kept!  So, how do you?"
Marwyn is caught entirely off guard by their assertion.  "Milords," he pleads "I was given to understand the candle was provided under your direction."
All the judges are taken aback at Marwyn's disclosure.
"Milords, I beg your pardon, I did not recognize the messenger, but the ring you gave verified the instrument's seal to be authentic.  Thus, as I'm sworn to uphold your instructions I was obligated, without question, to assign the candle to one of the participants."  Marwyn retrieves the document and the silver flask from his pouch and places them along with his ring upon the solicitor's evidence tray; whereupon all are presented to the judges for their scrutiny.
"We are subverted," The Judge of Sorrows whispers to his colleagues, pointing to the seals on the document.  "How can this be?  Who has the power to wage such deceit?  Marwyn, If ever you see this messenger or whomever he is again, point him out, pounce upon him if you must that we may know with whom he conspires."
"Sanaia was also hesitant to install this witch."  Marwyn continues, "but she was bound to do as I bid just as was I to you, thus it was done.  We both were aware of how deadly the candle was that is why I've gathered all that remained and brought it with me back to Lavare."
"Could Rueshaba have been intended as an assassin?"  The Nobleman of Equity proposes.
"Prior to its doing," proclaims an embittered Judge of Consequence, "all knowledge of this venture was confined to this room.  This very room I say!" he shouts, pounding his fist upon the bench.  "Everyone that could have known shall be put to the Minnon, everyone... including myself, the trader must be found out.  I swear I'll boil'em in oil," he barks. "if I have to carry the wood myself."  The good judge affirming his declaration with a final firm wrap to the bench.  "Bam!"
Never has Marwyn known a judge's composure to unravel in the least let alone to this.
"Indeed, this suggests of the same vile business that begun this dilemma in the first place,"  the Judge of Sorrows continues sorrowfully.
"Gentlemen," The Nobleman of Equity proposes, bowing his head slightly and spreading both arms as to ask for calm.  "Let us finish with the concern at hand that we may retire and better address these treacheries."  He motions to someone as yet unseen behind Marwyn.
A tall willowy fellow with the devil's own smile and a gleam in his eye to match steps up alongside Marwyn.  A few cautious silent moments pass as though a stage is being set before the curtain may be drawn away.  Marwyn knows that within the realm of theater there is but comedy and tragedy and these sober fellows seldom laugh.  Nodding graciously to their visitor, the Lord of Consequence addresses Marwyn.  "The demon has been sanctioned a laurel honorably taken and must be returned to the maiden along with her weapon, the troll's coin... and her memories."
"Her memories!"
"Yes... do I sense a question?"
"Milord, what need has a queen for a demon?"
"Whatever need she chooses.  This matter has risen beyond our authority."  The judge turns his gaze toward their svelte visitor.  "Solicitor," He acknowledges with a respectful nod, "this is the lad whom you seek."  Words Marwyn halfway expected, but had hopped not to hear.
"Marwyn of Cereta," the Solicitor recites: "you are hereby bound without recourse to entice by whatever means, Leona of the House of Durer, that she join the conflict Regal.  As you tormented, now you shall nurture; as you deceived, now you shall guide and protect.  Thus, shall you remain in her service as advocate until she has participated from start to finish in five sanctioned Regal Games and during such course accumulated no less than three kilos of rewards.  Then may she petition to take the House of Durer.  'Till such is done, sir, or death... do you part."  He smiles and extends his hand.  Marwyn accepts with a nod and a firm grip.  "Fare thee well, for you are one of us now, brother."  He consoles, handing Marwyn the scroll and bowing slightly, then stepping backward till he's merged with the dark surroundings.
Marwyn glances at the document knowing absolutely 'tis not an offer one may refuse.  Raising his eyes to the somber judges, he dares to plead.  "Milords, the girl is proven capable, she is by all accounts the rightful heir, and thus the solution to your great dilemma, yet now you condemn this once a treasure to such risks of life and limb?"
"At first this may seem harsh," smiles the Lord of Consequence, "but 'tis not a sentence to labor in the mines.  More an opportunity," he encourages optimistically, "one of a magnitude upon which I dare not speculate.  And... like you, we also must do as we are instructed."
"Lad, it has to be you," the Nobleman of Equity adds.  "You are the only one she might trust.  May I advise you be truthful about your involvement.  Tell her everything, but allude cautiously if at all to the events of this moment that the task not discourage.  She may not come to appreciate what you've done, not at first, but I think it wise she know you relationship is honest and truthful for the most part.  This maiden is of good stock.  Were it not so she would have bashed her paramour with the copper pot for betraying her or simply abandoned him, but in the end she risked much to see him safe away."
"At Durer her calling would be not the formulation of potions and neither may she disrupt Lavare's balance with devices like those she created during her trials.  That point must be very clearly instilled." reminds the Judge of Sorrows, "but to rule.  Rule is not divinely acquired as some in sanctuary would proclaim; wisdom and certain talents are necessary, yet still it is a learned skill.  As any smith acquaints himself with the ways of iron she need serve an apprenticeship. Learn how much heat to apply that the metal bend to her will, not break nor melt."
The judges rise and walk into the darkness.  One to another may be perceived under his breath, "We must discover this traitor before he succeeds."  The six solemn folk concerned that Bird remain contentedly napping shudder when Marwyn haphazardly gathers up Leona's puppy.
