One thrusts his hands beneath Marwyn's should the protective sphere slip from his grasp.  Marwyn's taken the position that whoever's fabricated this caper has a leash on his new master's pet as well.
--
Considering the game's disruption, it's taken Leona three nights to get back into a normal sleeping schedule.  Beth didn't make it to class at all on Monday and remained in uncontrollable yawn-mode all the day following.  Each afternoon Leona replays the events of getting lost between the library and armory and remaining ever confounded as to what actually happened.  Now though, she sleeps peacefully watching several youngsters, of which she may be one, at play in her dreams.  They maneuver their toy trucks over a pile of coarse river sand beneath a massive old apple tree.  A contingent of large black ants diligently trudge across the tricky dunes to reach the trunk.  Their determination is admirable among the huge creatures at play, for at any moment one or all of them could be crushed, buried or swept away without a thought.  Once there, as those who've come upon an oasis, each meticulously acquires a tiny bobble of sap hidden beneath the bark.  Then again they risk the giant's wrath to carry their treasures away as gracious offerings to their queen.  In truth, the children care not.  But for Leona, who wonders intently upon how they find the way back to their underground fortress.  Somewhere safe, as she is now, beyond the play desert's edge.
Curtains flutter as a breeze slips through her open window; moonlight fills the room.  Thereupon these gossamer beams faint image of Sanaia comes to be, quietly watching, bearing gifts of the most delicately woven filigree.

Memories, like a scant gray fleck of down,
Lost among the ashes of a day,
Or the shy snowflake,
Unnoticed in a swirling winter's play.

Carefully hidden, ever secure,
That none might wonder astray.
Though sold by some, and yet
By others freely given away.

I've borrowed a few of yours;
Now let them once again be known.
Concealed no longer by royal decree,
Thus, time has come they've found a home.

Extracted now for you to recall,
Freed from the Minnon's stone.
Each carefully hidden there deep within,
Though never but yours to own.

Kept safe while games you thought to play.
Now I bid thee pleasant dreams
Until the light of day,
When all shall come again nevermore to fade away.

Sanaia places the troll's pierced coin on Leona's dresser.  This shall do to stir your thoughts should you think of them as but dreams gone astray.  Sanaia's translucent image blends with the shadows and is gone.
Leona flops over assuming another subconsciously comfy position merrily mingled with her favorite skimpy cotton blanket.  First rays of the morning's sun are beginning to seep through the trees and flicker about on the living room wall.  Within a few minutes light begins to creep through the bathroom window behind the shower curtain, thus, faintly illuminating the hall.  Leona, fast asleep though she may be is becoming ever more restless.  At the moment she's got one of her pillows locked in a bear hug, but it seems to be counterattacking, getting the best of her it would seem.  Outnumbered three to one by these man-eating marshmallows, likely she would be pinned were it not for a desperate Mongolian toehold upon one corner of her fitted sheet.  Mismatched crystal saltshakers acquired from local flea markets have been lined up across the middle frame of her bedroom window.  Early, when the sun comes nearly horizontal across the landscape, the first beams strike these head-on.  The sharply cut prisms thus project small irregular rainbows all about the room--a pleasant way to greet the morning, but most often missed for lack of early AM enthusiasm.  On this occasion, there shall be no lazy avoidance however, for with the light the Minnon's secrets shall come to mind.  Every feathered creature thereabout seems to know, each chirping and twittering anxiously to herald the coming event.
Her bedroom seemingly bursts into pyrotechnics, no less a display so grand as Buckingham Palace on the wedding night of an English king.  Leona's eyes flash wide open; she bolts upright, her mind racing through the meadows, gateways, and battles of another world.  Memories flood into her head; reality is dissolving surely as a torrent of boiling water would melt the icicles of a winter's frozen morn.  Twenty-three highly eventful days have just been added to her life within a fraction of a second.  She collapses back into the soft fuzzy consoling arms of her blanket, staring helplessly at the freeform spectrums gliding wistfully across her bedroom ceiling.  Her pillows take this as a declaration of surrender and gracefully relent 'least till slumber overtakes her again when they may choose to re-engage as ruthless foes.
Cautious be ye, the illusion dweller, as self-deception heeds neither restraint nor bounds and thus, possesses of no manners either.  For once loose, as a word spoken, such fabrics as those spun within the mind may never again be completely contained.  Temporary insanity is not to be taken lightly, particularly for one seeking a degree in the sciences.  Those so inclined must endeavor to keep their mind fodder in order; at all costs, quite separate from reality.  Just now, for Leona, that critical boundary has evaporated.  And what of logic?  Pouf!  Out the window with that, too.  Fortunate this awakening has occurred within the privacy of her own chambers, else some might think the lady vexed.
Much intense thought and a very long cooling shower later finds diagrams of Roux's Keep, Karn's hunting lodge, and Hemmil's laboratory strewn across her desk.  Lists of names, places, and events have been cut and pasted into chronological order as she attempts to rebuild the experience.  There are a few individuals on campus suspected of having adventures of this caliber on a regular basis, but Leona dwells not among their ranks.  Chemistry has always been a potential vocation, never a means of entertainment, or enlightenment, as some might plead.  Granted, if someone's passing a joint around she might take a hit, but no chartreuse mushrooms or biosynthetics.
Where did this medieval shit storm come from then? she wonders precariously.  It has to have been drugs.  A light flashes on in one of those seldom visited corners of the mind where suspicions quietly lurk.  That bastard wasn't testing a game, he was testing some new breed of LSD.  The game was a con... set up to create a rich environment, she surmises confidently.  With the others grounded, the target would always have a firm basis in reality.  They would play the game straight up and fuel the victim's fantasies.  That's it, gotta be!  'Cause if everyone got whacked out of their mind... the whole experience would become a blur.  "Right!" she reassures again, as those grasping at straws tend to do.  But why the hell did he pick me?  "Seems there were better choices among the available subjects," she mumbles, her emotions becoming more verbal.  "If that prick was trying to launch a rumor, he picked the wrong spokesman.  You bastard," she sputters adamantly, pounding her fist upon an innocent coffee table.  "You bastard, what did you do to me?"
Well, that explains everything.  Sure, except how could I have possibly found out Beth's pregnant?  But is she really?  Could be humoring me, just playing along.  Doubt it though... wouldn't be her idea of a joke--way too volatile.  Raising the troll's nearly punctured hexagonal coin to view, she further interrogates.  "Okay, so... where the hell did this come from?  Fiddlesticks!"
In her efforts to apply some rationale to the perceived events, she hasn't left the apartment nor answered the phone for three days now.  And, she's running out of cereal. Leona inquires.

Right-handed from day one, though suddenly that nub is completely out of sight while her left paw takes over every little duty.  "So what's up?  You haven't been to class and I've called a dozen times.  I think your machine's on the blink.  You okay?  Are ya hiding out for some reason, or did you and Art make up big time?"

"Yeah, you can't be that far off course."  Beth is getting impatient, but Leona just doesn't see the ring.  Between single girls, failing to notice the unscheduled appearance of a diamond is akin to missing a local Richter scale 6 earthquake.

"A little, Yeah, 'cause I was in two places at once... and they were like 700 years apart."  Leona motions broadly toward the accumulation of papers scattered about the room.  "Look at this," she stammers woefully.  "Like, I've accounted for almost three weeks.  And except for a few minutes, none of it occurred in that fancy room where the rest of you were playing the game."  Her voice rises notably.  "I mean... I was there, but I wasn't, ya know?"  Beth's rosy disposition has cooled to concern; she shrugs ever so slightly in cautious agreement.  "Where'd all this come from?"  Leona continues in a searching tone, "and where'd it go?  I was all over the countryside, like sixty or eighty miles anyway.  And there were hundreds of people, and this jackass was chasing us all over the place.  And it all had to happen in that one night.  Three weeks in one night?  Can't be... so what happened?  I mean, Shit!  Where the hell was I, and how'd I get there?"  
"You're starting to make me nervous here," Beth cautions, retreating to her favorite repose--a frumpy, overstuffed old chair which nearly swallows anyone brave enough to enter its grasp.  Thereafter, hardly a word dares she contribute while Leona relates the impossible dream.  Delicately so at that, bypassing gory details which might betray themselves as signs of total paranoia.  Two hours, several Diet Cokes and a pint of tequila later, the tale's interrupted by another subtle knocking at the door.
"I'll get it," Beth volunteers.  "It's probably my betrothed.  Told him I'd be here."  Beth's glee at the thought of having Hale confirm their engagement with his own words turns to awe.  A stout, smartly appointed fellow with a coal black beard and impeccable manner presents himself with a courteous bow. A burgundy stretch limousine graciously awaits at the curb, the driver standing at attention adjacent the opposing passenger doors.

Beth's imagination is wandering all over the possibilities as she fakes aloofness, calm, and composure.  "Ah... No, she's... I'll get her... don't move."  Beth soon reappears with a cautious Leona in tow.

Beth is aglow with curiosity.  "Milady... Oh boy!"  A whole litter of puppies could not be more enthusiastic at the prospect of a prim-rib dinner.  "No way that's from Art," she presumes aloud. Wistinn's Greyhound stop is also the local hardware store, diner and Laundromat. The old cheapskate would rather replace every screw and bolt in that thing at a premium than buy a new one.  I expect he'll stop to shoot the bull with his buddy, Albert, so he won't be about till dinner.

Frisky as ever.  She'll be pleased as peaches to see you.  Some times Pap will try to get by if the syrup bottle is empty.  She'll paw the ground and focus those big eyes right on his, like, 'haven't you forgotten something?'  If someone ever went through our trash," Granny teases, "with all the empty corn syrup bottles we through out, they'd be thinking we must serve up a pan cake breakfast for all the neighbors every morning."

"Not really, be assured, every thread of every fabric is connected... in some small way."
The drive home is laced with small talk and a welcome view of the countryside.  Upon arrival, Leona is quick to snatch a couple apples from the spring house, then upon her way to the barn. Several fond hugs and words of admiration later and they are off at a fine pace to revisit the landscape so familiar to both.
Upon her return Leona is treated to a hefty slice of a favorite, homemade black walnut cake piled high with orange flavored dream whip, not icing.  It's great, but a sure sign she is being primed for a duzy.  Granny waits till she's finished off her treat, then, drops the bomb.
"We've had a visit... from your friend, Marwyn."

"Leona's taken aback by these seemingly absurd revelations, presuming Mark has somehow covertly influenced Granny's thoughts as he did hers. This world is much larger than ours.  With so many places to be one could easily lose themselves."

Leona graciously excuses herself and retreats to the porch, the shallower one on windward side of the house where the swing hangs.  Probably her favorite place in the whole world.  Here she would sit swaddled in Grandpa's heavy rain coat to endure the wrath of oncoming thunder storms, to seek solace within the chaos.  Sheets of rain would fill the air and lightning infused the mist swirling about the countryside with the musk of ozone.  It smelled so clean and pure and it cleared the mind also.  Though her face would be splashed and her hair soaked, all the rest of her remained warm and dry and protected.  Clarity, that's what she needs most right now to unravel this tangle of Marwyn inspired nonsense.  
I can't believe that guy actually came out here.  How does he even know where I live?  What the hell is his story?  And why involve Granny?  Sounds like she's on the same train I've been riding the last couple days and this Mark character is always near by.  He must be some kind of hypnotist.  And how do we get from my parent's skiing accident to an invasion scenario?  This is bullshit, but where did that damned coin come from?  That's the one glitch of logic here.  I can hold it in my hand, there's no doubt it's genuine.  I remember exactly where I saw it, laying there beside me in the water, But how does something real fall out of a dream?  Fiddlesticks!
 Granny imagines her adopted grand daughter has discounted recent events as some extravagant fraud, and who could blame her, really?  She phones Darian, her husband and co-conspirator to let him know the disclosure, as expected, has not gone well.  He's strategically positioned himself in Macon where he hopes to enlist the assistance of Albert, a wise and trusted old friend.  The only one he knows who might understand the gateway's complex abilities.
"Endless questions... yes... and I don't think she believes a word of it.  No... would you?  No, she's out on the swing.  I don't think she'll believe us... Yes.  Right now, considering I've just admitted lying to her for twenty years we no longer have much creditability, you know?  Not unless we can provide a rational explanation of how the gateway functions.  No, no, and I don't understand it either.  If you think you can trust him with our situation.  It's up to you.  But we dare not allow someone to provide a false interpretation; you know how technically oriented she's become."  When you return... okay.  We need milk by the way, yes, and Swiss cheese."
Tall grass sways hypnotically in the fields adjacent to the house.  The comforting hum of locust have set Leona's mind at least somewhat at ease.  Pap's apple brandy is sweet, fizzy and docile as a light wine, but there's a one-glass limit tonight.  The last thing she needs right now is a buzz.
All this bullshit, especially about my parents.  I've got to find this Marwyn bastard; he's going to get his head flattened.  What could he possibly have to gain by turning everything upside down like this?
When their ever-enlightening conversation resumes, Leona attempts to blend as many real events into the picture as possible.  From Granny's perspective, Lavare, but for the total lack of religion, appears to be on par with Europe of about the thirteenth century.  Is it an eerie coincidence that the same approximate time and place should be the setting of her recent unexplainable memories?  Likely as not, she surmises a conspiracy is afoot, but how and to what end?
Pap's old sedan rumbling up the driveway is a welcome sight.  She is anxious to get his take on these revelations  He has his friend Albert in tow, big man, middle fifties, a jolly Saint Nick sort with a fuzzy beard, lots of snow white hair and a friendly disarming personality.  They manage a cordial, pass the peas, would you like another roll type of dinner with not a word of Lavare or Marwyn.  All retire to the screened porch for the main event.  Dark now, an evening breeze and a chorus of katydids have joined the locust for this evenings entertainment.  Much to everyone's delight, a round of Pap's applejack and ice cream is forthcoming.  On this occasion, much as she loves the stuff, Leona declines in favor of coffee, strong and black.  The coming discussion is not concerning the latest phase in heavy metal music addressed in round-table fashion at an off-campus pub.  If someone intends to rethink the theory of relativity this evening she prefers her thoughts be unclouded. 
"Darian tells me you'd like to know what makes the world go round," Albert says with a disarming smile she recalls from last time she visited Santa Claus.  "Maybe I can help ya out some."
"Yes, I'd appreciate that," Leona replies sincerely.  "Truly I would."
"Albert, like us, was a player of the games Regal," Pap confides.  "Retired about twelve years or there abouts."  Albert nods, raising his glass in agreement.  "Prior to that calling he was apprentice to one of Lavare's most achieved alchemists.  And of late, he has toiled trying to understand how the mechanisms of this world and ours relate."
"I know what the gateway between our worlds accomplishes," Albert advises shyly, "but not what powers the shift.  Only those who built the device could say for certain what force allows it to work.  However, none know who they were," he admits regretfully.  I've heard to close the portal one need only move a large stone, but not in the sense it would block an opening.  An extreme measure, for once done, most agree it could never be undone.   Thus, my explanation will be somewhat coarse, presented as similarities more than fact of what you would deem physics."
"Before we start," Leona inquires, "may I ask a question?"
"I am at your service, milady."  Albert responds graciously with a respectful nod.
"How big is this other world--I mean like, compared to this one?"
"I had exactly the same personal curiosity when first I crossed and realized how large this realm is.  'Twas thus, I undertook to measure the realm as best I could.  No small task, it required several years within the course of my exploits as a player of the games.  This world, shaped as the path over the surface of a sphere, is boundless.  One may go in any direction full circle back to his point of origin.  The realm differs significantly, for it is contained within a boundary.  'Tis called by some, the mist, or the fog, but most and perhaps more appropriately refer to it as the soft wall.  Man being such a curious creature, many have challenged the boundary as the inquisitive always do, searching for the greener pastures of legend I presume.  Few have found their way back and all who have tell the same tale.  There is day and night though neither the sun nor moon can be seen and the day time is very dark by comparison.  There is rain and snow at times and one claimed to have come upon a vast area of still waters, but none have ever found as much as a single blade of grass.  The air is cool and very damp.  At the brightest clearest times one may see no further than twenty paces.  Aside from the occasional unpicked bones of the long lost, they being man and beast alike, only barren rocky ground or endless sand has been found.  I've concluded the area within the boundary as five to six times the size of your domain of California.  A great salt water sea which includes several large islands and many small ones comprises about a third of that."
"It's not an entire planet then," Leona confirms, "as we know this world to be?"
"'Tis not, but I feel certain it exists somewhere on this same plane."
"There is no way something that size could exist on earth and not be known," Leona counters.
"I understand your concern and I assure, I shall address it in due course, milady."
Leona smiles and nods her agreement.
"Lavare," Albert continues, "is comprised of thirty six independent domains or city states, each with a principal city of between ten and twenty thousand residents and each ruled by a single family, as was yours, Durer.  I would estimate there are three to four times as many more citizens scattered about in small villages and towns, giving us a population of about two and a half million in total.  The general consensus is that our world was created and is watched over by a grand sorcerer, but none know where he abides.  After much thought upon the subject I can not say that I disagree.  The boundary then, one could suspect, is meant to secure his domain from invaders.  And yes, it is a hindrance that neither may anyone leave but soon to perish."
"A sorcerer, not a king?"
"Correct, known by two names I've just recently found out, either Inquisitor or Benefactor depending upon the company one keeps.  Though we have no central government as you know it here.  There are no taxes, but there are rules imposed upon each domains' principals and the wise abide them.  
'Some of the families are a bit heavy handed, but in general 'tis a very civil society we have, really, not the Feudal world you might suspect as it came to be in Europe.  Unresolvable disputes within a ruling family commonly result in exile rather than the lopping off heads.  Each domain imposes its own taxes and laws, and all have accepted Lavare's standards of commerce encouraging much trade between the cities.  Usually each village has a constable to keep the peace.  Towns and lesser cities, a person of higher authority who's principal duty is tax collection, unfortunately, for the most part their selection is by appointment and since another of their responsibilities is dispute resolution the party paying the higher bribe will be found in the right.  No ruling family of any domain is permitted to sustain a force at arms of more than 222 men."
"Not much of an army."
"True, but thus, like it or not, the cities must remain much more tolerant as one can not effectively invade another.  Hence, there is no need of military alliances.  And so, that artful craft so popular throughout the Europe you know, of trading off ones children to secure guarantees against anther's aggressive actions is mute.  Make you no mistake, milady, 'tis not perfect.  There is still more than enough intrigue and treachery to go around, but it remains internal, family business as it may be said.  Outright war between domains, however, has long been off the table, both as a practical matter and more so because it simply is not permitted.
There are very few who spend their days in a dungeon, very few, for there is little if any waste of resources or manpower in our world.  Aside of murderers, generally all who run afoul of fair practices or the well being of the citizens spend their days on public works projects until they come to appreciate the error of their ways.  Murderers and other similarly vile individuals are consigned to the mines, a very unpleasant place.  
Slavery is forbidden, though one may bond themselves to another to make good a debt or more generally to learn a useful trade, but each may speak only for themselves in this regard as none are permitted to bind another.  There will always be scoundrels, and I'm sorry to say bribes are prevalent, but we try to discourage it well as we can."  
"How does one get to Lave?"
"First let me say, only those people and material objects that came from Lavare are permitted to return; in fact required under certain rules of the games.  Though many of the game players are very creative in their attempts to slip by with a little contraband," he chuckles.  "You may wonder then, why there are not many more of Lavare's citizens here about.  One may only move from this place or the other and back at a single point, the gateway.  Only those with license may do so, but with one notable exception, you!"  
"Me!  Why me?" 
That question is one I have no answer for.  Shall I begin then as to how it might exist and yet remain unknown?"  Nods of approval go round the porch.  "Very good, now then, let us think of each elemental kind of material, iron or sulfur and the like as a different house.  There are only a few kinds of brick to construct these from.  Milady, you would know the principal components as neutrons, electrons and protons.  I'm sure you also appreciate by stacking these bricks up in different ways, you get all these different kinds of material, the house of iron, the house of sulfur and so forth.  Same bricks, lots of possibilities and each having a distinct electrical quality."  Leona nods her understanding.  Albert replies with a smile, "Very good.  Keep in mind, electrical qualities also possess that which you call a frequency or resonance.  There is a house for example called hydrogen.  Just two bricks, but to build this house and put things in prospective, let's say with normal-sized common red fired clay bricks; they would be laid many thousands of feet apart.  Though there is a vast empty space between these two bricks, yet they make a perfect hydrogen house every time, and a very sturdy one at that."  Albert pauses, looking to Leona.  She affirms again with a cautious nod, as one listening for the catch in a bar room con.
"That immense space," Albert continues, "is not wasted, milady.  Now let us think upon another relationship, which at the time of its understanding was unbelievable to even the most learned of this world.  For who could imagine thousands of different radio and TV energies could fill the sky at the same time?  Piled one upon another, flying in all directions, but mind you, without conflict.  All exist in the same space, yet they totally ignore each other as though each is in their very own private world.  This is possible  simply because each is different, as the alchemists of this world would say, in frequency.
When one is selected by establishing a resonance, all others are excluded.  The receiver, a TV for example, refuses to recognize any but the one to which it has been tuned.  Doesn't mean the others are not there, but from the TV's point of view, resonant to only one specific frequency, all others fail to exist.  If you choose to view another channel, you must first change the receiving mechanism to recognize a different frequency.  The former image vanishes and a new comes to be.  It was there all along... but you neither saw nor heard it because the quality of frequency did not match or resonate to your specific selection.  All those you see not, still exist in the same space, waiting for you to call them forth.  Though they remain all around you, you may not interact with the others in any way.
All things of this realm," Albert continues; "have a uniformly cooperative resonance or frequency which interacts to create the materials around us now.  You could say... they are all on the same channel.  The population of this world is content to deal only with those materials with which they, like the TV, are in tune.  So... to them and their instruments any non-resonant materials are undetectable and thus do not exist.  Consider the more practical situation which is all around us.  Human eyes may only perceive light within a specific range of frequencies.  Yet though they exist, only with instruments may humans see the inferred and ultra violet spectrums.  They've always existed, but they did not, not until recently on the scale of evolution."
All this is clear as freshly stirred mud from Granny's point of view.  She's quite content with the fact of it's being; the why and how of it matters less to her than a broken egg.  Stay the course she will, however, listening attentively till the cows come home.  Anything to provide Leona a smidgen of confidence in the sincerity of their effort.  For this night shall forever alter the course this young lady had perceived of her life.
Albert closes his eyes, wishing for a moment to dedicate all his senses to the last drops of his brandy.  He inhales the vapors accumulated within his glass slowly, then settles back with a great yawn.  Pap is quick to offer his guest a refill, but Albert threatens to fall asleep if he partakes of one more sip.  This being an inconvenient time to nap, the brandy is officially retired for this evening.
Pap is appropriately wise in the ways of alchemy and much more so because of his tenure on this side of the boundary.  He's been Leona's tutor, taking great pains to sharpen her interests and inquisitive nature since her eyes first glimpsed the light of day.  Yet try as he may, Albert's explanations are far beyond his understanding.  His knowledge acquired entirely within the realm, is of a practical everyday nature and thus, lacks any concept of basic atomic particles.  Few of Lavare even imagine of such things.  Only this side of the gateway offers such knowledge and license to cross may only be had by those chosen to play the games.  Few of these become enamored with advancing their education, for this world offers many more exciting distractions for the rich and adventurous.
Though all science within Lavare is classified as alchemy, Albert's apprenticeship there would be better thought of as astrology and astronomy.  He is the rare bird, having had enough adventure while a participant of the games that he now seeks the rewards of knowledge.  Over these past twenty two years he has earned a doctorate in astral physics and is now well upon his way toward a master's in astronomy. 
After another immense yawn he continues his simplified dissertation of heretofore unthought-of phenomenon.  "Now, imagine the frequency or resonance element of the electrical characteristic of our bricks could be altered.  Think of it as a change in shape," he explains with a coy smile and a wink.  "It remains a brick, still possessed of all the qualities of a brick, but because the shape is now slightly different it will no longer fit together with other bricks even of the same material.  The natural order of things forbids a house to be built with different sized bricks--in this case, that is, bricks of a different resonance.  From where the new bricks stand, the old ones have ceased to exist just as the tuner refuses to recognize a signal to which it is no longer tuned.  So now we have two identical bricks, but for lack of a matching resonance they exist in two different places.  Any house build of these new bricks, though of the same plan and size and all else, may not exist in a community of homes constructed of the other bricks.  Think now of a community as being a compound of any material, just as the compounds of basic alchemy.  Only houses of like bricks, that is those of the same resonance may join to form a community.  Like the radio signals of different frequencies, you and all things relevant to you must be of the same order, identical in resonance or frequency to exist in this world."
Albert challenges, spreading both arms as to indicate their present surroundings. "Thus, all things not of compatible frequency must of necessity exist in another.  Just as the radio signals are completely transparent to each other, the new bricks will not acknowledge each other, join with each other, obstruct each other, see each other, or touch each other though they are kin in every way but one, matching electrical frequency.  The shift, due to the change of frequency allows them to fit between the others, to exist in all that empty space we previously examined.  They dare to be in almost the same place at the same time because each specific resonance has it's own level of existence, and all the materials with that same exact electrical characteristic must exist there also, for they simply may not be anywhere else."
"It seems a violation," Leona objects, "of the basic understanding; two things may not occupy the same space at the same time.  I mean, TV, cell phone and the entire electromagnetic spectrum in fact, are way different from solid matter.  They only seem to pass through each other because they're so very small and there's a tremendous amount of unoccupied space out there."
"Absolutely," Albert assures, tapping his finger upon the table top.  "Not only out there but right here too, from the point of view of mass this wood plank hardly exists at all.  Probably not even one billionth of one percent solid, but I defy you to push your finger through it."
"Huummm!"  The best response she can muster.
"Do you recall those two bricks making up the house of hydrogen and the vast space--mind you, on our scale--separating them?  There is a hypothesis which has been employed in many film entertainment's, the infamous black hole that draws everything closer and closer until it's been drawn into the phenomenon itself.  This is well accepted to be factual though it can not be seen aside of it's influence on other bodies.  Based upon that theorem, if you could remove all the space between all the particles of all the atoms comprising this entire planet, reducing it as it would be within a black hole, though the weight of it would be the same, the planet would shrink to the size of a golf ball.  Must be a lot of empty space there, yet even so, you may not push your hand through this table top unless you can alter the resonance of one or the other in which case one will no longer exist relative to the other.  Then the hand may pass until it encounters something with a resonance matching its own, something solid from that new point of view.  The realm of which we speak and many others of various natures and qualities exist within that massive void.  The systems are not in precisely the same space they are side by side.  The space between them is regulated, held constant if you will, by the difference in their basic frequency.  These brick houses are really very uncluttered.  If the change of frequency were only to shift the new brick a distance equal to the stride of a man, in our relative relationship hundreds of worlds to coexist in the same space, yet each remain unknown to any other until they are tuned in.  One of this realm's great alchemists has surmised bricks or matter and light or TV signals, that is wave form energies, are but two variations of the same thing.  E=mc squared are his words to describe their relationship.  Others have contemplated all I've told you to be possible, they fail only in the means to verify their hypothesis.  Anti-matter, backward stars, black holes as I've mentioned, one must have faith.  Astronomers have only evidence of these devices, but no hard fact of the sort one may touch or see.  That the alchemists of this realm have not the means to detect another existing in the same space is hardly cause to dismiss it, milady."
"I've never heard of anything like this," Leona insists; "not a hint, not a theory, nothing."
"Aside of valences, your training in the elements is of a different nature, more in the working of things around us than how the bricks came to be.  May I suggest a second major in physics."
Leona roles her eyes back and chuckles.
"Coexistence is not an uncommon arrangement limited solely to radio signals.  For a moment let us revisit light.  That portion which men can see may not penetrate the thinnest of veils.  Yet the slower forms, though they are not known to the eye, can be felt and pass easily through barriers the light of day may not.  They are but different frequencies of the same thing.  Some are tuned to the eye, others are known commonly to us only by their touch--as you say, infrared or heat.  And yet others, X-rays for example are not known to man at all except by uncommon means, film esposure for example.  In the eyes of an x-ray only very limited portions of you exist, all else is ignored.  Consider, If there was an entire world of objects and beings that existed on the level of X-rays here around us right now, who would know of it?  There would be nothing a human could see or touch, yet they are here, and they the least of them."  Leona shrouds her face in her hands.  Albert's arguments sound plausible and have a realistic basis in known relationships.  However, the thought entire worlds with living beings could exist within each other and remain totally unknown is still beyond her grasps.  Her fingertips drop slowly to find a respite upon the bridge of her nose.  Albert and company are all looking her way for a sign of understanding.  Their assorted pensive, almost forgiving smiles seem to say 'admit it dear, you don't know it all.  You're just another narrow-minded dummy like the rest of us.'  Warm cozy feelings of logic and fact are crumbling.  Albert has slowly undermined them like sand castles facing the rising tide.  She flops back into the couch, raising her eyes to the slow hypnotic ceiling fan.
"I'm listening.  Don't stop now or I'll loose it."
"A good night's resting may clear some of your conflicts," Albert assures.  "There's always tomorrow, milady."
"Sleep... tonight, are you kidding?  Go for it!  I want to hear it all tonight."
"As you wish, milady.  The gateway is a channel not unlike a tunnel which passes through an otherwise impregnable boundary separating two different frequencies.  All the bricks on one side are slightly different in exactly the same way as those on the opposing end.  When you pass through it's like changing TV channels, you are returned to a different resonance.  Every particle, or shall we say brick passing through experiences a very slight altering of its base frequency from that of this world to that which allows it to exist in the other, the world from which you and I came.  This alteration is slight, but still it must go forward in a slow gentle way, every single brick of every house uniformly adjusted at the same time and rate.  If not, you would be undone, scattered randomly throughout many different realms with no way to rebuild the community that was once you.  This would be the fate of anything objectionable attempting to pass from one realm into the other.  For you may be sure, every gate of consequence has a gate keeper.  The journey is quite long, looping back, ending at its beginning and it can not be expedited.  Like a cake, if you want it to be proper you must wait till it's done baking.  You will exit at the same point you entered.  In passing, your senses and perceptions are adjusted.  Reset to a different standard, like changing the capacitance of a radio's tuner.  When you exit, you will be out of tune with the bricks remaining at the entry.  Your point of departure will cease to exist.  You've changed the channel; same TV but a different program.  One that fits in the spaces between the things formally obstructing you.  'Tis the best I dare make of it, milady."
"Wow! talk about slipping into the shadows," Leona suggests while shaking her head slightly, "hell of a concept."
"Curious, your mention of another realm, the underworld, as Lavareins would call it.  Though just as far removed from here as there, the zealots, and there are many, willingly stake all they hold dear upon the existence of those two intriguing opposites.  Though I doubt any have been to either yet many here about claim to possess first hand knowledge of both and so propagate grand expectations to further their theologies.  A narrow minded lot for one of such magnitude, so easily swayed with but a promise or a threat." Albert muses.  Leona is not sure what Albert's talking about until he clarifies with an equally astonishing revelation.
"You see," he adds calmly, "In Lavare it's widely held by many of the scholarly and more curious that death inspires but a shift much like that of passing through the portal."  Under certain unique circumstances the eye has talents one might not suspect.  Hence, those who claim to see vestiges of those defined as the dead. 
If indeed these places do exist I suspect they are those who occupy the supposed lost space between the two, as some would say, the first level of Purgatory.  Thus, it follows that at the onset of their passage for a time their frequency would be so very close to that at their point of departure they may be able to look back for a while.  Some may even choose to linger, revisiting of a sort to reflect upon their most recent deeds before the shift becomes too profound.  Thus, the threshold across Purgatory's first domain might be breached whereupon the recently demised become somewhat visible to those who remain at the initial resonance.  Think of it as looking into a portal just as someone else has begun to pass through.
Leona interrupts, "I prefer we not complicate the current dilemma with the possibility ghosts are real, 'least till I get a handle on what we've covered so far."
"Sorry, got off the subject," Albert admits. apologetically.  "I tend to ramble on somewhat at times."
Shaking her head slowly, "I've never bothered much about the laws of physics, wasn't exactly my cup of tea your know.  This is just so different than what I've always considered as pretty much indisputable."
"You speak of the laws men assume define physics, milady.  Men did not make these places; one should not confuse the laws of the universe with the theories of men.  I fear, even the wisest of men have much yet to learn.  There are magnitudes of order among the basic particles of which man is not yet aware."  Conceding with a gracious nod, she accepts the old fellow's caveat.
I think I follow the principle... Basically, sort of.  It's just hard to accept so many radical new ideas in one afternoon.  At school they tend to ease you into things like this.  It'll take a while, I'm sure you understand."
"It required over nine years" Albert admits, "for I myself to catch these secrets, yet still I cannot say what is done to cause the change of frequency."
"If I seem reluctant, believe me, I intend no disrespect.  Given the complexity of what you've presented, I can think of no clearer way to state the principles.  And you've actually come across this gate personally, right?"
"Oh yes!  Many times while active in the games.  This world is the sanctuary of active players, the hideout, as they say in your cowboy entertainments."
"Granny, you too, right, you and Pap both have traveled by way of this tunnel?"
"Yes dear, so have you.  Last time we crossed was when we brought you.  It was a violation though.  Sadly, we dare not return."
Leona looks to her supposed guardians, then Albert, and shrugs her shoulders.  "It's a lot to think about; I just have to sort things out, you know."  Addressing Albert, she inquires, "Do you happen to know this Marwyn fellow?"
"I do not."
"You'll be staying tonight, right?"  She glances toward Granny for confirmation.
"Oh yes, without a doubt.  Pap's certainly not driving to Macon again tonight."
"Good!  You know, in case I have a question."  Leona smiles and excuses herself.  The sandman is surprisingly quick to sweep her away for someone with alternate universes on her mind.
Up with the chickens, as any good country gal, but in no great hurry to rise.  She lies there to ponder last evening's revelations.  When she comes into the kitchen, there's Albert finishing off a platter of Granny's French toast and peach preserves, so it couldn't have been a dream.  A few cloudy issues have risen.  Leona waits till he's finished then pounces on the break between servings.  "A question, if I may?"
"As many as you like, milady."
"Just this one, well, maybe two.  If your world is completely independent of this one, how is it humans have evolved in exactly the same way?"
"Very good, milady," he smiles.  "Of these things I'm not sure, but I strongly suspect Lavare's population did not evolve as the human race has from some distant past.  As a maker of songs might apply new words to an old melody, I believe Lavare is a copy and that once made it was allowed to proceed at its own isolated pace.  A small portion of humankind, essentially extended families or clans from central and western Europe--complete with all the associated geography, plants, animals, even the pesky insects--duplicated, then shifted as I explained to hide it from this world.  I feel certain all things in Lavare had beginnings here.  The population having not common, but identical ancestors in this world long ago."
Leona stands silently; she must stop asking questions.  For the answers are invariably more questions.  Albert's reply, though simple as dirt, is at once alarming, fascinating, totally frustrating, and gravely contrary to the interests of society.  If his theory is correct, how many other worlds drawn from the human experience might exist and under whose absolute control?
  "Think of it as duplicating a portion of a large computer file," Albert continues.  "The original remains subject to update over the normal course of events, but the copy is held separate, unaffected by the mishaps constantly reshaping the original.  In this case, led upon a separate path, allowed as it were to grow at its own pace in a protected environment.  I see concern in your eyes, milady.  Technology and to a greater extent religions do not by some estimates provide the most fertile environment to preserve the good character of mankind."
"A copy!  What a concept... save as, rename Lavare, click!  Wow, that would take a lot of RAM.  How long, I mean how far back does Lavare's history go?"
Albert ponders quietly; a question simple as this should not befuddle one well versed as he.  "I must endeavor to separate lore from fact.  I would venture not quite seven centuries.  Thus, the copy, as you say, would have been fashioned about 600AD  The first cities, those of the great bridge, Orna and Dialyn, they are older.  Some time after they were destroyed the realm as I know it came to be.  More thought is required of this, milady.  I shall send word when I've come upon a reliable answer."
"Well, I asked for it," she concedes to herself.
"Bear in mind," Albert cautions, "if you return to Lavare much of what you've learned here will be of little or no use for lack of means.  Creating such means may well be prohibited."
"Not sure I follow," Leona questions cautiously, "prohibited?"
"I suspect progress of a technological nature is stifled somewhat in Lavare, as a parent might keep too many sweets from a child."
"Humans are inventive by nature," Leona suggests with a squint, "they always try to improve their circumstances, it's the character of the beast."
"One new idea quickly leads to the next and then another and so on, thus begets progress.  Tell me, when a new technology or material is developed here, generally what's the first application?"
After some thought, "weaponization," Leona ventures hesitantly.
"Exactly.  Thus, an arms race ensues which in turn demands anti weapons and so forth like the cat chasing it's tail until someone amasses a military superiority, the aphrodisiac of greedy and power hungry men.  Eventually there is a glorious waste of lives and resources accompanied by a lot of pain and misery for the benefit of a very few.  And yes, something new and usually better rises from the ashes, but what of the suffering and destruction required of such a process.  Your mind holds a vast amount of information that could be devastating to Lavare's population.  Apparently, if you wish, you will be permitted to pass through the boundary.  If that store of knowledge is allowed to accompany you, you must hold it in strict confidence.  Please always consider the future implications of even the simplest tweak of status quo.  You could destroy Lavare," Albert suggests coldly, "with but a slip of your tongue, milady.
Consider, in this world there are communities, tribes if you will, who had not progressed since their beginning until some religious zealot discovers their hiding place and destroys a thousand years of their beliefs or a venture capitalist arrived with cleavers and shot guns to tip the balance of power to his ends."  
"If I go, your point shall remain clearly upon my mind, sir."
"I mean no disrespect, but I must remind, every domain in our realm has precise boundaries that none may violate.  Unlike the assembly of pretentious politicians they call the United Nations, Lavare's equivalent actually has authority to destroy and engagement is not precluded by long discussions or economic sanctions."
"The day of the Inquisitor," Pap suggests.
"Yes," Albert concurs, "the only annual holiday in Lavare.  'Tis said a force of 6000 once crossed to invade a neighboring city.  That would have been about... 362 years ago, yes.  Their incinerated remains were found piled before the invading city's gates at sun rise.  A granite monolith accompanied their corpses with a list of the instigators and their penance.  Everyone so named had to present themselves either to be burned or to dig graves until they dropped dead.  Any who failed to come forth voluntarily were to be sought out and executed along with all their blood relatives no matter of age or gender for the preceding four generations.  As the story goes it took eleven months.  Then having done so those who survived dug their own graves and were executed.  Everything was forfeit from their families.  The relatives were formed into a long caravan and they were required to wonder from city to city through out Lavare for the next thirty years telling the tale and reading off all the manes of the men at arms, their commanders and those responsible.  It would have been a vile business, but it made an indisputable point.  As one might propose around here, an occurrence of biblical proportions.  The ruling families of every other city were then convened to select a new house to rule the vanquished city.  No one since has violated the doctrine.  If conflict does arise of so extreme a nature that a judicial forum can not find resolve, the parties may petition for total indemnity.  By this, both must submit to death; their only satisfaction derived in that each strikes the blow to the other simultaneously.  If one survives he is immediately slain by the family of the other." 
"Wow!  That is going to take more than a day to sink in.  Pap has your number, right, in case I need to follow up."
Albert nods affirmatively and smiles.  
"Thank you so much, more than I can say, really.  We shall meet again I'm sure.  Good day, sir."  She nods respectfully and retreats. 
As Leona disappears into the hallway Albert turns to Granny.  "I hope I haven't upset the cart this time."
"I think not; she's a very resilient sort--her mother's daughter."  Granny nods affirmatively with a slight smile.  "She'll sort it out."
After breakfast Albert scores several loaves of raisin bread, a jug of applejack and many appreciative thanks for his insights.
Once Pap and Albert depart, Granny ventures to Leona's sanctuary bearing gifts.
"Are you all right, dear?"
"More or less."
The tone of her reply sounds muffled.  "May I come in?"
"Yeah, but I'm not hungry, okay?"  Granny finds Leona has wrapped herself in a sheet from head to toe, apparently trying to hide from the confusion enveloping her thoughts at the moment.  She appears not unlike a large caterpillar hiding in plain sight within its protective cocoon.  Granny carefully sets a flat chest about two feet square upon the bed.
"If I believe even half of what Albert has said," comes a muffled voice, "it turns the whole world upside down.  I mean completely!"  As she attempts to curl up her foot bumps the heavy wooden chest.  "Um! What's that?" she continues to muffle while feeling around with her toes.
"Lythiria... your mother, entrusted me with these things.  It's time you had them."  With such provocation, it doesn't take long for the reclusive insect to emerge.  
"Huh!"
Wood of deep honey-colored burl, the grain swirls and dances, appearing as tiny clouds solidified beneath a pool of glass.  On the upper left are dragonflies, at lower right a large somber frog watches their playful flight from among lily pads and cattails.  Below the water's surface an assortment of small whimsical fish and at the bottom among snail shells and leaves the shy salamanders and crayfish hide.  All are realistically detailed of embossed silver and colored with hints of transparent glaze, 'tis more the work of a jeweler than craftsman.  "Beautiful... it's Oriental," says the moth, now wide awake and free of her cocoon.  Leona looks into her guardian's eyes docilely, "This isn't just words anymore," she admits in an astonished whisper.  "This changes everything.  The cities Albert spoke of this morning, the ones that were destroyed, I knew about them and the bridge, too."
"Yes, I'm sure it will all come together in good time, but for now don't try to open this box yet.  The latches have been poisoned.  That would be a terrible undoing of twenty years' effort."
"Poisoned?  That is a lot of effort."
"Yes, you were."
"Oh!" she chuckles lightly.  "Can I touch it?"
"So long as you avoid the latches, for one unknowing would surely prick a finger.  The venom was very potent and could remain so to this day."
Leona begins outlining the ornamentation with her fingertip.  Her eyes close and begin to well up, soon coming to tears.  "I always wondered how could there not have been even a single picture," she blubbers, "at least one.  But there couldn't, there was no such thing as a camera."  Once recomposed, which requires a cup of steaming cocoa with double marshmallows, she begins Survival in the Realm 101.   A fully accreted crash course for up and coming princesses of Durer.
"Chances are the venom has lost its usefulness by now," Granny mutters, "but 'tis not a gamble I wish to take."  She lifts one of the silver latches with the aid of a letter opener.  Several tiny barbs suddenly jut out from holes in the face plate and just as quickly retract to patiently await the next victim.  "Did you see them?  Each one stings independently"
"Yes... fast aren't they?"
"Just a dab of the venom allowed to dry before they are reset and none would survive that bite.  It may be cleaned away with grain alcohol, but very cautiously, my dear.  Each time you close the lid the poison devices are reset unless you disarm them while it's open.  When the latches are closed the mechanism is rearmed."  Once unlatched, sliding the salamander ornament on the top upward and pushing the frog to the right allows the lid to pop free of the internal catches.  An ear-piercing chime rings out from within.  Leona shutters.  "An alarm," Granny advises, "to inform of its being opened when the chest is not within sight."
"Clever!" Leona remarks quietly, as she catches her first glimpse of things Durerish. 
Her mentor resets the spring-loaded hammer which is released simultaneously via the latch mechanism.  "You must reset the alarm manually each time."
Within are two highly detailed bracelets of a lustrous grayish-green metal.  The glaring faces of demons with wicked little horns and fangs smile therefrom.  The eyes are tiny stones, yellow they appear at times, but then from a different perspective green.  Fangs project outward slightly from their open mouths.  Cautions are in order, for they are both weapons and shields.  "The teeth are hollow and may be laced with poison.  A backhanded move would allow them to bite or gore an adversary.  They're padded and the metal is highly tempered, heavy enough to deflect an assassin's blade."  A fine dagger complements the bracelets.  Both blade and quillons are of a metal black as night and not at all reflective.  Crisscrossed leather thongs are tightly bound around the hilt that it may be firmly gripped and the finial is a tapered spike.  No fashionable embellishment, this is a weapon of practical consequence.  Her mentor points out several shallow grooves set back from the cutting edges.  "These hollows are to accommodate poisons also," she informs.  "There is considerable danger in carrying a poisoned blade, my dear.  I suggest that option remain as a last resort.  If ever you choose to render it deadly you must allow it to dry for several hours.  Then wipe the blade clean with natural alcohol before replacing it in the sheath.  Otherwise you risk poisoning the scabbard as well, such an oversight could prove a fatal mistake.  Only the latches of the chest have ever been rendered deadly," she emphasizes.  Silver demons cling to an oiled leather scabbard for the blade's keeping.  "A lady should always have a honed edge at her disposal," Granny suggests with a bashful smile, "if for nothing more than slicing her daily bread."  Unscrewing the finial from the hilt's end discloses a long piece of flint and a slip of parchment.  A matrix of letters is scribed thereupon.  "These are friends of Durer... sworn to assist any lawful heir to the death.  The names are in reverse, being every third letter in the vertical columns."  The number of letters in each column are not divisible by three, however.  They are intended to be read as a single column beginning at the top, backwards from right to left.  When you reach the end continue back to the first as before by threes three times over.  By so doing it will reveal the entire message.  This she confides almost in a whisper as one suspecting spies may be lurking near.
"I remember... you had some arrow heads with grooves like those along the edges," Leona reminds timidly.  "You kept them sort of reserved."
"Yes dear, they are designed to carry poisons and yes... I still have them."
"And there were some others I thought strange, the shaft had been thinned just behind the head."  
"That was so the head would snap free on impact.  So long as the shaft and head are one the arrow might be extracted even against the barbs.  Or, for non critical wounds pushed through.  Neither is desirable.  This is also why you never put an edge on the backside of the blades.  It would be easier to withdraw if it could cut itself free of the wound as one pulled it out."
"That's really devious."
"Make no mistake, my dear, the art of conflict is serious business.  To take it lightly is the last error you will make.  After we retired from the games Pap and I choose to stay.  My position was that of a personal security guard and all the shafts I carried had but one aspiration.  In the place where we come from when you face your enemy you strike hard and never check your swing.  There may be only one opportunity and seldom more than one survivor."
Closing her eyes, Leona exhales softly while considering the seriousness of this conversation.  The most profound advise the average young lady receives from a parent is an explanation of and the associated warnings regarding the consequences of sex.  Even on top of everything else, killing people seems so out of vogue in the world she's come to know.
Two tokens are included, each within it's own fine round wooden case.  Leona's informed the thin copper one is so "as not to hinder your stride.  For it is to be kept in your boot so you will never be without a coin to pay the ferryman... should ever you meet."  The other, gold with the face of an old man crudely stamped over the mintage.  "This may be exchanged for council with the Oracle of Serophia, if ever she might be found."  Leona smiles at the thought; the box is like a treasure chest from an as-yet-unwritten fairy tale.
Depressing the alarm gong and applying a firm twist lets it loose; hidden there beneath a large heavy ring of a polished reddish-gray metal.  Spurs set with tiny garnets grace either side of the crown which is but a thick raised flat segmented disk with eight symbols inscribed about its perimeter.  "This was your father's ring.  Raising either of the jewels on the sides allows you to turn the crown thus," she illustrates.  "When the fifth marking on the crown aligns with this groove," she indicates. "The elements have now come into the proper arrangement.  At this point you must raise the jewel again but this time hold it in the raised position while you rotate the crown further."  As Granny rotates the crown various portions of the flat face rise to form a stepped three-dimensional design.  "This you remember as the name of your city, Durer, has five letters and your name, Leona, has five also.  Let the jewel slip back and it will secure the pattern.  In so doing you create a reversed mold from which a key may be made.  Impressing the crown into wax and then having the wax shape cast into metal will construct the key to your future.  It will open locks certifying to your place in the House of Durer.  If you let go of the crown while still holding the jewel, the crown will spin back of its own accord and the key's pattern will disappear back into the flat surface.  Be sure whomever makes the key only makes one.  Stay with him throughout the process to assure this.
Keep it hidden from friend and foe alike.  Both the curious and those who might wish to steal your heritage would normally think the crown must be turned till it stops.  Never proceed past the fifth symbol.  Anyone who does will trigger a set of barbs so as to prick their finger.  They retract quickly as did those guarding the latches, this allows the crown slip forward to the first mark.  You see, the crown may only be turned in one direction.  When the crown is turned to the fifth mark it winds the trap, continuing further releases the barbs if the jewel is not held up against the spring.  By this the ring's treachery is concealed that it may bite again and again, hence giving the impression 'tis cursed.  In Lavare, even fools dally not with things cursed.  I would advise the barbs be poisoned, made to kill, but that decision is for you alone."
"I think I've misunderstood something," Leona whispers.  "When you said Durer was my father's city, I took that to mean he lived there.  But this ring and all--they must have been wealthy.  Where do I fit into the food chain?"
"I believe you to be the last remaining of the House of Durer.  Hence, you are not a Lady of Durer, my dear, you are The Lady of Durer.  In accord with the laws of the realm your father's city is now granted to you, milady, in its entirety."
"The whole city?"
"Yes, and the surrounding lands, thousands of square miles I would think.  Durer sits at the edge of the sea and includes several small islands.  It is very pleasant there; I miss it so.  Whatever lands your citizens occupy they do so at your pleasure.  There is very little private ownership in land, only your father's dearest friends were granted title to lands.  But the people are not slaves and should never be thought of as such.  Among other things this ring is also the key to the city's treasury.  I'm told 'tis the only way to open it without causing its loss.  In Lavare, by special arrangement, things may be protected by disappearances, that is to say if their security is violated they disappear.  As I remember there were four gates.  Without this ring the last three are traps.  I can not be sure of this because I was never allowed to pass beyond the first."
Leona's voice has begun to quake.  Another cup of cocoa shall be needed soon if she's to hold a steady course.  "Wait... yesterday my biggest responsibility was carrying out the trash before it got rank, now your telling me I have to worry about a whole country!  Come on," she entreats while pacing about randomly. "I mean, this is getting totally out of hand."
"That can not be helped, dear," she alludes quietly.  "I assure you 'Tis not the place of common folk to cross the boundary without license as you were allowed to do.  Such deeds require considerable influence.  If you return, though, great caution is in order, for many things may go astray in a house left unattended for so long."
"Yes, I'm sure they have.  My real name, is it Leona?"
"Yes, it was your grandmother's also."
"Good," she smiles, "I like it... I wouldn't wanna have to change it."
Two soft leather pouches are tucked firmly in the corner of the chest.  Leona looses the drawstring of the larger; a king's ransom in emeralds topples into her palm and scatters across the bed linen's.  They're cool and heavy.  She looks inquisitively to her guardian.  "As I said dear, you have resources available if you wish to avoid this business."  She gathers the dark green gems back into the pouch and exchanges it for the other.  The second pouch has four compartments, each securing a small enameled bronze vial.  Granny places her hand upon Leona's.  "Don't open these."
"They're not perfumes, are they?"
"No dear, they are your poisons... for the dragon's teeth, the latch, your dagger, or whatever the need be.  The vial with a single dimple is tasteless and lacks aroma; it remains potent for three days after having dried.  The one with two dimples is said to lie in wait for up to ten years.  The third, with the ridge around its middle is their antidote.  Enough for three occasions, it must be administered within minutes and it will leave you seriously weakened for several hours, perhaps even days.  The last, with two ridges, and probably the most valuable, will cause you to vomit violently.  Handy, should someone slip venom into your food.  If you expel the poison before taking the antidote it will encourage a speedy recovery.  These are serious compositions, take care not to touch the venom's.  Either will kill within minutes if consumed; thrice as quickly if by way of blood.  By touch, it depends upon how much skin area contacts the poison, from several hours to weeks.  Keep the antidotes with you always, for if a sharp wrenching pain rises up in your bowels just after eating or drinking, 'tis likely someone is trying to take your life."
"You people call this a game?"
"In your circumstance, I dare say this business is more complicated.  Poisons are not used in the games except in the most extreme of conditions.  But they are the principle weapon of politics, and that... my dear... is the game you are fated to play."
"I take it this is why we spent so much time camping out all around the country, always it seemed just to find stuff like jimsonweed and belladonna?"
"Yes, one must learn to tell friend from foe, all do not carry a weapon.  Even the wrong sort of kindling for your fire can be fatal."
"Oleander!"
"Yes," Granny smiles, "you remembered."
"My allowance depended on it," Leona reminds.
"Some day also may your life."  Leona nods respectfully.  "As heir to a city, particularly one with the conflicted politics that I've heard have taken root in Durer, you must remain watchful and be prepared to fight fire with fire.  I feel your mother has provided these things for your protection, not to encourage you join in the games.  They are very serious and dangerous competitions.  The participants, as once was I, seek rewards and recognition.  As heir to the estates of Durer you have no need of either.  All you could gain from such risk is license to use the gateway."
Three flat boxes yet remain to be explored, the first of dark mahogany with silver clasps and corner embellishments.  Lying therein upon a bed of light-brown colored silk, four necklaces, four sets ear rings, and four finger rings.  All are made of the same lustrous reddish-gray metal as her father's ring.  The settings are of smooth simple designs, not the least overbearing as one might expect the garnish of royalty to be.  A single gem allotted to each, opaque, blue and dark are they.  Portraits of animals, one upon each: with glaring fangs, a bear has fear to sow, calm and sly a leopard leers, that into the dark one should not go, an owl, nocturnal master of the sky, clever of all things wise to know, and the wild boar, the fourth of them, ever-defiant his tusks to show.  "These are the jewels of your court, my dear, they are political and well known." Granny advisers.  "Each set is meant to communicate your mood at the moment without the need of words.  More for the company of visitors, petitioners or your advisors.  And sometimes when you yourself visit others and wish to convey a statement."
 Much smaller and thinner the next, constructed of burled black walnut.  Granny smiles.  "These say not a word, my dear, aside of adore me.  They are more for those rear social occasions when among friends."  Within a chain of intertwined serpents set with small fiery opals.  Therefrom a delicate fairy-like female fashioned of chrysophase dangles.  Her wings those of dragonfly, golden filigree laced of translucent blue and green plique-a-jour.  Arms out stretched, she smiles, seemingly to welcome this new Lady of Durer.  'Tis love at first sight when Leona beholds the luxurious nymph.  Svelte maidens made from pink coral with wings of silver wrapped about their shoulders like those of a sleeping bat dangle upside down from the ear pieces.  Any of these would not be out of place among the finest works of Fouquet or Lalique.
A thin box about twelve inches square is the last of her mother's gifts.  Overlaid of gold it depicts views of a large elegant building tooled into the metal on both faces--at last the treasure she has yearned for.  Not a box, but a folded picture frame containing four miniature paintings, portraits of her illusive family.
No amount of cocoa is likely to calm her this time.  Granny quietly departs leaving the Lady of Durer to her tears.  Before her adopted granddaughter is to be seen again, the sun will have gone, for she has wept all the day long until night descended to cool the air and allow her to sleep.
Come morning Leona sheepishly enters the kitchen looking as one set upon by exhaustion.
"There you are dear, feeling better I hope.  Are you hungry?
"They look so young, my brothers," she says, still very sad of eye.
"Ten and twelve I think they were.  Cup of tea dear?"
"Is there any chance they could be alive?"
"Your eldest brother was among several young lads felled by collapsing masonry.  They were prying stones loose form the old battlements and dropping them upon the invaders.  Apparently someone forced a stone free that should better have been ignored causing a portion of the bulwark to give way.  Of the younger, Wythnor, I cannot say."
"Do you think I look like mom?"
"Yes dear," she smiles, "very much so."
"There was a slip of paper tucked behind one of my brother's pictures with several drawings."
"Oh yes.  Those are your brother's tattoos.  You need to remember those images should anyone ever approach you and claim to be Wythnor.  Aside of Pap and myself only your immediate family was aware of them.  By now they would have faded and stretched which will lend to their authenticity should anyone come forth.  They are at the small of his back and between his shoulder blades." 
"What happened," Leona begs, "what caused it?"
"No one really understood why such a thing could happen.  Times had been good, gates had become a formality and ramparts an obsolete tradition.  Obviously the attack was well planned, but why?  The House of Durer had no warning nor even slight reason to be concerned of it's security.  It really wasn't much of a siege; the invaders numbered less than two hundred at the front, but the city gates were wide open.  Half again as many easily breached the rear portal for there were only four men to secure it.  They had no colors nor livery, by all accounts a dastardly lot of murdering scoundrels.
Your father along with what troops were available rushed into the midst of those entering by the main gate.  They were sadly outnumbered... and ill prepared, but he refused to pull back.  I saw them being overrun.
Darian and I were with a handful of archers hastily assigned to the main hall's parapet.  Our task was to prevent the intruders from crossing the courtyard toward the main residence.  And we cut down thirty and more, but once the opposing sides were intermingled there was little we could do to support your father's group without striking down our own.  Soon thereafter we were summoned to the queen's chambers.  You were then but four days old.  She bid us carry you off, and assured arrangements had been made to allow us pass the gateway.  On the sixth day next we intended to take our leave and travel south to Darian's village and so it was most of our things were already in his cart.  The city's defenses were crumbling, for no one was prepared for it.  We barely got you away.  Your mother herself had taken up arms.  She along with the palace guard saw us safely into the countryside and beyond the walls.  We were cautioned not to return unless sent for, then they turned back toward Durer.  I've heard nothing since of her fate.  Everyone has chosen to forget the trials of Durer rather than admit such a vile deed was ever done."
"Nothing is such a big word, so full of meaning.  Some would say the worst news is better than nothing at all.  Under the circumstance I prefer to think otherwise."
"Yes, as long as you keep them alive in your memories, dear, anything becomes possible."
"There's so much to consider.  It's not like I exactly doubted your friend Albert, but words don't seem to mean much anymore.  Everything is becoming borderline bull shit--you can't believe anything you hear or even much of what you see, especially on the tube.  Technology's washing reality down the drain.  I know many, Art for example, who tend to exaggerate without limits.  It becomes so common they begin to believe it themselves.  I mean like at school, the guys are so full of crap that after while you disregard everything."
Granny starts to hum, and a silly smile comes upon her face.  "Boys have always been that way, dear," she assures.  "Matters not upon which side of the gateway they reside.  They will devise any foolishness to entice a maiden to a quiet loft."
Leona laughs quietly.  "Yea, well, I mean before I saw the box I could dismiss much of what Albert said as imaginative daydreaming.  But not  now.  I wish I could bop into the library or Google the web, but   Albert's world, yours, and mine I guess, it's not on the map.  It would be like checking the yellow pages for a Martian travel agency."
"The world you're from is real and I dare say a better place than this in many ways; I miss the simplicity of home.  So few of this place do or mean what they say.  As you say, words have no value here, even when they write them down and put their mark to it.  There are liars in Durer, too, but--and remember this--their words may not be written.  Where we come from an evil man takes pride in his deeds and may always be found near his keep.  Here they hide among forests of lawyers, within the shadows of corporations and behind no end of those repulsive pre-recorded messages.  I hate those things," she confides softly.  "Nothing but cowards, not a one dares come upon the field to answer a challenge.  And look at what they excuse for coin.  How can green paper be of value when there's paper to be had everywhere.  For pittance the news boy leaves a stack on my doorstep every morning.  Paper," she shrugs with a sarcastic smile, "in exchange for a man's good labor?  I think not.  Faith and trust are qualities bestowed upon worthy men, good iron, or a fine steed, not paper, it's an insult."
Granny's prophesies of doom, dire as they seem, tend to lighten the atmosphere considering the seriousness of personal matters now at hand.  "It's going to get worse, you know," Leona teases.  "Soon they'll gather up all the paper, too, leave you with nothing but an account number."
"Oh dear!  Well, Pap and I keep our coin close at hand.  You know where I mean.  If ever anything happens you be sure to come and get it, dear."
"I'm only making fun," Leona assures, "but seriously... about Lavare... I need to know everything--all the details, no stone unturned."
"I doubt my memories are a fair gauge to measure the realm as it is now, for many things have surely changed.  But come and sit.  We shall have a stout cup of tea and look beneath every stone I know.  Perhaps time has come to venture home and see for thyself, just a thought, dear.  Caution though, for once there, you may not be permitted to return."
Which way then is a lady to go?  The high road as heir to fame and fortune, accompanied by pageantry and large numbers of straight faced fellows with dark suits and sunglasses?  Or perhaps the low road, a common traveler of whom none might take notice.  Or as Granny hinted, no road at all, just disappear.  For the time being at least, zero plus seven days, she has managed the road back to her apartment.
Something dire therein awaits, still and quiet, a presence which may not be denied.  Yes, I see you there.  Her attention focuses upon the infamous package, the one delivered like a summons by personal courier.  Patiently, almost smiling back as it silently shouts to none but her, 'I dare you.'  Treasure chest, Pandora's box, or Trojan horse, which is it to be?  No less ominous that envelope so eloquently attached, it begs to be touched, tampered with.  No longer a game, this business has taken on aspects of Russian roulette.  The question now is how many of the cylinder's chambers carry live rounds?  Whether by design or trick of fate, breaking the invitation's seal will surely topple the first domino in a sequence without end.  Appropriately, the first of these is called Marwyn.  For are they not bound though unknowingly so by the Inquisitors three: these Judges of Sorrows, Lords of Consequence, and Noblemen of Equity?  A union, somewhat one-sided, though it may be.  Constrained not by license, exchange of rings, or legality, as it would typically, but nonetheless till a kingdom is taken or death dares to set good Marwyn free.  Thus, let the courtship begin; and how better than with a love letter then?  Marwyn's challenge is accepted and she reads:
"If it please, milady; I shall present myself at this occasion to answer any inquiry regarding your most recent gaming experience."  That's nice, but experience hardly covers it.  "I beg you accept my sincere apologies for the pretext of our meeting was somewhat shallow.  I assure, however, all was for good cause."  How sweet, taken to the brink of insanity for my own good.  "I sincerely hope any inconveniences that arose may be set aside."  Oh yes, we will get to that, Mister.  "By this, you are cordially invited to join a group of individuals with similar interests.  This is a social occasion, your attendance obligates you not in any way to participate in further enterprise.  Being one not familiar with our customs I have taken the liberty of providing attire befitting a lady representing the House of Durer.  These things are a gift, yours to do with as you will.  Thus, by accepting, you are not compelled in any way to attend."  Oh sure!  "As transportation must be pre-arranged confirmation is necessary prior to 9 PM on Thursday, the ninth day of October by calling 017-081-265-1793."  Four days!  No return address!  You bastards don't trust me, do you?  "Should you choose to accept, I've taken the liberty of enclosing the invitation which must be presented upon the coachman's arrival and again to the manor's gate keeper for entry.  Please join with us.
Ever your servant,
Marwyn of Cereta"

 Leona of Durer, and none other,
 to consider a challenge as set forth by
