Layers of creamy beige satin embraced of snow white ribbon are carefully undone, folded and set aside.  If nothing else Granny could refashion the wrapping into a fine evening dress.  There beneath, a lustrous sturdy box the color of strong tea and scented of honeysuckle.  Below generous layers of tissue the first to view is a burgundy velvet gown so deep of hue as to inhale all the light within the room.  Below the gown a hooded cape of dark indigo.  Blossoming black vines adorned of blue, plum and peach randomly unfurl upward from the hem.
Nestled thereupon an enameled, white pearlescent case and of course, there within a dagger sharp enough to draw blood with but a glance.  Apparently, no maiden of the realm is ever to be thought defenseless.  The blade is double-edged and displays narrow grooves parallel to each of the cutting edges certifying to the tool's deadly authenticity.  Wrapping the blade with fabric to be sure it remains soaked for an extended time, she trickles the grain alcohol left over from the new year's eve punch across the cloth and wipes it dry most carefully, then burns the cloth out of doors.  Broad, smooth quillons of heavy grayish metal curve forward as they diverge from the hilt and transform into the heads of demons akin to that residing upon the sheath.  Coarse tapered leather strapping is wound about the hilt creating ridges to assure a firm grip and a stout contoured pummel displaying the profile portrait of a mountain lion crowns the dagger.  This, as practical an instrument for the purpose at hand as any may be.  Dark artfully tooled leather compliments the sheath including the face of a demon not unlike those of her mother's bracelets.  Attached thereto a wide belt of silver links with a buckle akin to the paw of a large cat that the curved talons may engage any of the links.
Two pair of oxblood toned shoes are tucked in the box's corners, one set low cut, the others rising above the ankles, both comfortable as a glove and thankfully flats.  Fact is, she feels clumsy in heels and these all the better if the need be to make haste.
Also within the enameled case a necklace, the chain composed of interlocking silver scorpions.  The central embellishment is a beveled silver rectangle an inch wide and about three inches long with a black star sapphire the size of a robin's egg at the lower end.  Certainly none may call her sponsor a cheapskate.
Though strapless, the low-cut décolletage suits her stature very well.  Try as she will, wiggling and twisting about, the frock refuses to slip.  She cannot but wonder if someone hasn't been taking measurements while she slept.  All in all, quite an impressive enticement--for a first blind date, and if this keeps up she'll soon have the finest collection of museum quality daggers in Atlanta.
Next day finds her, of all places, browsing the local sexy lingerie shop.  There to secure the antonym of her typical restraints, a provocative new push-up.  If I'm going to step out wearing a fitted gown in this town, she teases herself, may as well get all the mileage I can.

A binder's yellow flame so bright
Need not attend us here,
This no lucid trick of fantasy's delight,
Though as such it might appear.

Nor slumber's unwitting diversions, dreams of friends,
Favorite places lost nor sad but welcome tear.
Neither clever ploy nor honey drop
Required to lure the unsuspecting near.

No need of magic's spell to bemuse,
Seduce, beguile or bind.
For all who attend this grand event
Do so free of spirit, guilt and mind.

'Tis wealth and glory these robust youth pursue.
Adventure dressed unto the nines;
Intoxicating as any opiate
Or the finest most exquisite wines.

No ordinary tournament this
As none who've failed surely would attest;
But clever enticement to join the Games Regal,
The ultimate of any challenge or moral quest.

Now, in that enchanted flame's stead
Ten thousand candles lend their soft warm glow.
They, to bathe this near illusion beyond those things
Ordinary folk have come to know.

'Tis the Olympics of Lavare, held thrice each year,
To which these players boldly go.
A contest of stamina, will and cold iron 
That one may avoid death's final blow.

Advance ye lads, fair maidens
And sorcerers if now you dare;
Come forth all who would filch treasure
From a noble's guarded lair.

No sportsman these, but more of thieves,
Or the stuff of gladiators, this lot.
Come to ply body and spirit against all odds
With fervent hope they not be caught.

Life and limb, flesh and bone,
They wager against a prize of gold.
'Tis high the cost of glory in this town,
Or one's desire they not grow old.

A fraternity unique are they,
This brotherhood of expectations high.
The best among the best no doubt,
Yet surely some will die.

Spectators, no, there are none;
For play is seldom till dark of night.
So all is hidden from you or I,
That slip quietly away they might.

Shadow and sorcery they employ,
Their clever deeds to conceal.
Steely nerves and slight of hand required
Of those who dare from a Lord to steal.

But, every charade does not succeed;
Though all attempt to hide from watchful eye.
At times their only reward is some will bleed,
And yes, surely some will die.

Chosen to play the Games Regal
The dream and ultimate honor of every lad;
As for him the maidens fair and lovely coo,
Though his character's surely that of a cad.

Imperative to secure this brand of fame and glory,
Disdain of authority, quickness of wit and blade.
One might think of them as fools a wager to make
Of life and limb by all accounts a fair trade.

For these contests, so deadly and sly,
Discretion rules in every way.
Lest one be found in dire straits
Or in a dungeon by end of yonder day.

And after every trick has played
And every fraud's surprise;
New songs will they sing to herald daring escape
Or regret of sad demise.

Others may but shed a tear
And only wonder why,
For certainly some are bruised and maimed,
And surely some will die.

Twenty-one days they stand at odds,
Though friends they may have been;
But not so now till the bell tolls
To say this conflict's come to end.

Till then man's laws mean not to those so engaged
As only to rules of the Regal Game must they abide.
And from the game's appointed master,
None however clever may think to trick or hide.

The mines or dungeons for some of those
Unfortunately cornered and caught;
And others, well, certain deeds are pardonable,
But some surely are not.

For only then are weapons to their sheath again
That all may cast charade and disguise aside.
Finally safe to count their coin, 
But Yes... some have probably died.

So come ye lads, brave and bold,
Rise to this challenge anew.
Invited are you one and all, thrill-seekers,
Plunderers, even those with vengeance to pursue.

Hence the stage is redesigned,
New settings, new players, and new plot.
For those who dare, a garden party
Or gypsy's wedding 'tis not.

The final guest appears just now,
Perhaps a little late,
But was there not good cause
That she should hesitate?

Valets pull the grand bronze doors aside;
Thus, might one dare to speculate?
Who comes among this noble lot,
Observer, consort, or worthy candidate?

Enter fair Leona now,
Reluctant maiden of Durer,
Shy, but confident her stride,
Eloquent, refined and enticingly mature.

With not a curious glance to any,
Across the room thus does she glide.
Adorned of exquisite dark velours,
Though not as many here consumed of pride.

Trimmed of silk brocade and sapphire black
With only instinct as her guide.
Curious eyes may watch and question,
Who is this and is she qualified?

And if so, shall this wicked sport
Now seduce another bride?
Hence, let the Games Regal commence,
For the last of them's arrived.

And she no victim of demure,
With unseen demons by her side;
That none about might know for sure
Why more than fate dares be her guide.

But remember always too,
Conflict demands strong wills collide.
Be it for greed or noble cause,
And so, one must surely die!
--
The ratio of males to females, that being on the order of five to one, suggests this is not a social event.  Much to their credit, there's not one among them with an ounce of their person out of alignment.  The gentlemen are not body-builders, constructed to hurl boulders at their foes, but the well-tuned and agile sort, those more inclined of an aerial ballet.  Apparently speed and dexterity serve better here than brute force.  Retreat, discretion, and concealment, prim tools of their trade, that one might delight in their prize and return to steal another day.  For what the ladies lack in numbers they more than compensate in appearance; nothing less than striking, though frail fashion models be they not, but rather rock climbers or long distance runners.  Their range of chic compares favorably with the most daring attire of Hollywood's starlets or any diva rising within the pop music industry.  Slinky, form-fitted satins of the 20's appear a two-to-one favorite over the more audacious see-throughs.  Leona's garments are less provocative than most.  How strange she thought at first, that a dagger should be included among the accessories provided for a social event.  But it seems not, as blades of every sort are quite the rage with this set.  One and all the guests display them conspicuously as the officers at a military ball might to indicate rank.  Sparkling bobbles of the sort popular among the wealthy do not attend this clique.  These folk more inclined to ornaments fashioned of artfully crafted metals and earthly-colored stones, designs akin to signatures, symbols of noble houses or cults perhaps.  Rarely is a diamond to be seen; and if so, 'tis neither faceted nor polished, but raw as the ground gave it up.
Melodies of rural 13th-century England and Scotland twirl softly about the space while mimes and jesters play to the guests.  An air of carnival pervades, but the business soon to be presented is more akin to matters of life and death.  Leona cautiously mingles with the crowd; she notes her presence attracts the attention of several.  Though none address her directly, gracious nods and smiles are silently granted and returned in kind.  These fellows are not on the make.  Considering Albert's estimate of the realm's size, the ethnic diversity is surprising.
Fairy tale, the decor; combined with the atmosphere and fashions it would have the Oscars look mundane.  Thirty yards the width at least and four times that its length, the hall is immense.  The ceiling's apex is eighty feet above where grandiose hammer beam trusses support arrays of beveled glass skylights.  Groups of windows forty feet tall separated by wide stone pilasters face a lake along the one side.  Enticing bas-reliefs, both male and female, are exquisitely cut into each.  The wall opposite flaunts elevated granite promenades, one atop the other.  At one end of the room, an inferno rages within a stone hearth about the size of her apartment, but with a much higher ceiling.  Bronze griffins act as andirons; they are half again taller than she.  One would imagine the room soon overheated, but in fact the pyre draws a cool evening breeze from windows facing the lake at the opposite end.  Lighting is soft, discreet, warm in fact.  No electric lamps are to be seen.  Rather thousands of candles grace the walls, dangle from above on twenty foot wide chandeliers, and sit about the room on free-standing candelabras twice as tall as a man.  There are many private gathering spots: several chairs or couches, a low table of stone in their midst and a lavish floral arrangement upon each.  The floor appears to be a dark grayish granite with bluish flecks of pearlescents.  No expense has been spared; neither Hollywood hoax nor con man's charade does it appear to be.  Both plastic and plaster would seem to be forbidden here.  But caution, for the once bitten are twice shy, is this another of Marwyn's hoaxes, a daydream or reality?
Not the slightest hint of cigarette smoke taints the air.  Rather, discreet wisps of almond and eucalyptus mingle with the distinct fragrances of tallow and leather.  Of cell phones, there are none.  Nor does anyone care of the time, for neither is a watch to be seen.  Rolex and Cartier would be abhorred at the thought they were not being duly represented among a crowd such as this.  When in Rome she knows the drill.  Her own time-accounting device soon coyly disappears.
Venturing out onto the balcony, though it runs the length of the hall, she's surprised to find there are very few to keep her company.  Large cradles of open ironwork mounted atop tapered, fluted iron posts light the way with live flames that seem to boil over the tops.  The air is cool and the lake still, reflecting perfectly the ghostly sky above.  A werewolf's moon framed by sharp ragged clouds dares to tease the imagination.  The lake appears a great pit with the moon's twin settled into the bottom--beautiful, unique, eerie, and foreboding, all at once.
Aside from a gathering of elderly gentlemen that appears to be of an administrative nature there are at least 200 in attendance.  Occupying center stage near one end of the hall is a highly detailed model of a kingdom including several walled cities not unlike that encountered at Mark's charade, but much larger.  Behind the model is a raised speaker's podium.  Several yards adjacent a long narrow table with a dozen stacks of documents.
Now comes a butler prancing in her direction with the moves of a ballet dancer.  He bows eloquently and offers a choice from Old Frothingslosh to the green fairy.  At first she declines, but then upon second thought, "Something sweet, no alcohol, juice... grape maybe?"  After all, everyone has a drink in hand, and as with her watch, when in Rome, be as they.
"Any special sort, milady, white, red, blue, sparkling or not?  All are fresh," he advises, "none older than this morning's dew."
There seems no end to their desire to accommodate.  The limo for example, arrived promptly at the appointed hour, and certainly anyone would assume the affair somewhere in Atlanta proper.  But, one must presume nothing so far as people from other worlds are concerned.  In fact, she was delivered to the airport where her private helicopter complete with a personal stewardess awaited.  Just one of the simple pleasures of deposed royalty, but still quite a rush.  The clever French art house comedy presented on a four-foot LCD screen was a lovely diversion to occupy the nearly two hours before arriving--no telling where.  Her best guess, given the flight's duration between three and four hundred miles from where she began.  Always one to be prepared, she never leaves the house for a party or club with less than a twenty in case there's a misunderstanding and she need catch a taxi home; ha ha!
A private chamber of snow-white stone, not very large, octagonal in shape.  At each junction of every two walls a molded balustrade rises, arching over, and widening to form the eight-sided ceiling dome.  At their coming together, a long thin sliver of stone dangles from a heavy chain of folded iron links.  'Tis a cousin to the Minnon and a caution to any standing there beneath; for to tell a lie would have it set free and fall upon your head.  In seven of the walls a slender niche, within each sits a wooden staff.  Old and worn as their master they are and yet trusted and wise as well.  Keys of knowledge and earthly delight, some whisper of good fortune, others dare mumble the tidings of hell.  Upon these the old Cleric relies for her daily bread, or as the case may be a hefty pouch of fine soft gold.  None wiser to be found the rumors have said, yet there are some, were the truth to be told.  In the eighth wall not but a simple door and from without now comes a knock.  'Tis Marwyn, here to visit this wise old rock--she being the self-same crone who certified fair Leona as A Lady of Durer.  She bids him enter, greeting the young gentlemen with a skittish but generous smile.  "Your lady has come," she congratulates in her smooth froggy tone.  "She may no more resist than the tides would dare deny the moon."  A sphere of light floats above the palm of her hand; Bird sleeps contentedly therein.  Tilting her head slightly that one might think her crossed.  She sharpens her gaze upon Mr. Marwyn.  "Why has this come to me?"
"She found it.  I am instructed to return it as an enticement for her to join the game."
"She found it?" the Cleric muses.  "I dare think otherwise!  These are not found, dear boy... they find.  And those whom they have found are seldom happy to greet them."
"Yes, I've seen what it's capable of, but the maiden has no idea, nor is she to be told.  No one, or so say they all, understands why or how this has come to be.  She considers it her pet and it's to be left at that."
"I'm missing something here; where did she find it?"
"During the inquiry."
"In her thoughts!"  The Cleric holds the sphere up to Marwyn's inspection.  "Are you saying this is a thought made real, that she conjured this demon?  Impossible, she couldn't!  That girl has not a single charmed hair upon her head."
Marwyn shrugs unknowingly.  "Tell me what words will please you and I'll say them."
"Hummm!" The sly old crone murmurs in deep concentration.  "In all my years this is the first one I've ever seen, though I've always known what they would look like.  I am surprised at how small they are though.  I've seen larger grasshoppers.  Tricky, this business you've gotten into.  A contest within a contest I think.  Like wheels within a wheel, things can get to turning backwards and moving forward at the same time."
"I've had that feeling lately," Marwyn concedes.
"Some pets can be quite obnoxious.  I hope this little devil has not a temper.  A shame, if half this evening's guests end up as over-cooked barbecue."  She motions her servant come nigh, twirling her wrist and pointing a finger toward Marwyn.  "Would you care to try some fruit... before I set it loose?"  Marwyn hesitates for a moment, then, exhales in a frustrated fashion.  "Sit down, lad.  You look tired."  He plants himself in an over stuffed-leather chair and secures a single grape from her servant's tray.
"'Tis not of my doing," Marwyn advises contentiously.  "I can only imagine the tribunal has considered the risks and deemed it a necessary venture."
"They are wise old birds... most of the time."
"She knows of her heritage now," Marwyn laments.  She could try to demand the House of Durer be granted to her, but I fear they will not allow it.  
"Twenty years that city has floundered in a sea of fools," the Cleric reminds.  "To anchor it once more shall be no simple task."
"I've been instructed to convince her it would be greatly in her favor to explore and learn for a while, that time is needed to become familiar with the customs of Lavare and the principals of the game.  When in fact I've been commanded to escort her through five games from start to finish and Myrina's been chosen as the first because it was the city used as the basis of her trials.  I find it rather curious that Myrina's game is about to begin at so convenient a time given the Henzecs provided me with the primary antagonist who just happens to be Lord of Myrina. "
"Obviously it has been their intent, or someone else's  all along.  And to be sure there are places more cordial than Myrina for such lessons."
"Yes, I know."
"As I am told, 23 days were consumed for the inquiry, and it was done in less than one!"
"Yes, took longer than expected," Marwyn concedes, "much longer.  It was quite a duel.  Have you seen it?"
"No, that would never be permitted.  You must have stood by all the while pouring cool water over her head," the Cleric retorts, selecting a peach from her ever-present basket of fruit.  "Lest the poor girls mind may have melted."
"At times I feared it might, but she stayed the course and prevailed. There were many deviations and inconsistencies.  More than once she moved from the game's playing field to conscious reality, then went back into the game.  Most notably, when the conflict ended, she actually extending the game, by her own will mind you, until she slew the player who had tormented her friends.  There for a while Sanaia felt the Minon had lost control of her memories.  It was like cold worm soup."
"Hummm," the Cleric chuckles lightly, "you've got a bag of bones here from some creature I've not seen before."
"I've been sworn to the death on this task.  The Henzecs keep pulling me in deeper and deeper."
"Of course they have, they tend to be somewhat mellow dramatic."
"It was not the Henzecs," Mark is quick to qualify.
"Who then?"
"I've no idea."
"But after I was conscripted he said 'welcome brother, you are one of us now.'"
"Ohhh...  You are coming up in the world, lad," she smiles.  "This is better than American heart break TV!"
 "The weapon's another paradox.  I've been instructed to return it as well; have it with me here today.  Must weight thirty kilos though, I don't understand how they expect it to be of any use.  I've four times her strength and with both hands I could not wield it effectively."
"Was she able to defend herself with it during your game?"
"Defend, attack, pretty much chop anything to pieces."
"Since I'm not charging you for this consultation, I would consider it a personal favor were I able to see this weapon, perhaps touch it."
"No one's instructed me otherwise, so yes.  I'll tell the master at arms to bring it to you.  Sanaia believes it may be the name of a spell or even a being, but in solid form.  Probably something associated with Rueshaba's memories."
"Rueshaba, the witch?  She was part of this pot of stew you cooked up?"
"Yea, though no one seems to know why."
"I'll tell you why, someone was trying to assassinate the child or intended to drive her mad while she was confined within your game.  With that upon my plate, now I think I can tell you why this little bugger has come into play," pointing to Bird, "to protect her."
"This is so far beyond the edge of my puddle," Mark submits.  "Other than my familiarity with Lavare and the games I have nothing to contribute."
"Without a reliable guide one is lost.  Being lost can be an adventure, but more often than not it is dangerous.  As I mentioned, she knows nothing of Lavare, your are her life line.  And also because you've broken the ice as they say here, she knows you and therefore is more likely to trust you as opposed to some total stranger.  Though weather you play the pawn or the knight I can not say."
"Yes I know," he frowns, "but I didn't really need to hear it out loud, thank you. 
Thus, now they would have her play through no less than five games.  Myrina it happens is the first to offer a challenge.  Most do well to come away from there with just their hide.  Hardly a fortnight has passed since they would not dare to put her in harm's way."  His voice rises.  "Now they demand she be cast into a pit of vipers, bound and blindfolded as it were.  I fail to appreciate this radical change in expectations.  Perhaps there is some wisdom in this approach of which I am not privileged to understand."  His declaration thus presented, Marwyn snatches another grape as though it might calm his rising concerns.  "Durer is not scheduled to host a game for over three years so I'm taking her across a month early to visit Durer as merchants or something.  When the game starts we'll cross the borders rather than enter from the portal. What might you tell me of some one called the Benefactor?"  Marwyn adds as it were a casual afterthought."
"I have my doubts the Benefactor could be thought of as a someone.  I've heard the realm is his... or her creation," she advises solemnly.  "A fantasy, like a child's playground.  In essence a very complicated game for whomever's amusement.  Come to think of it," holding forth Bird's enclosure, "'tis the most likely source of your wicked little friend here."
Mulling over the Cleric's revelations does not a happy Marwyn make.  He throws his hands aside.  "Great, now, I learn we are all but fools conscripted to sing and dance about for the entertainment of who knows what.  Well then, why be concerned?  I've competed in the games, I'm employed by the Henzec tribunal no less, or was.  I'm not even sure at the moment, but all in all I consider myself privileged well above the average commoner.  So, why have I never heard this before?"  Marwyn asks, shaking his head in dismay.
"I suspect 'tis because you have never asked quite the right question.  And surely you have, but by another name.  Everyone knows of the day the six thousand met the Inquisitor, a harsh lesson to be sure."  Marwyn nods his understanding.  "Some prefer a more honorable title, thus, the Benefactor.  I can not make an absolute pronouncement, but well I think both are the same.  Besides, now you may better stand in the shoes of your ward.  For what she has recently discovered is your disquiet times a thousand."
"But... never mind, I've no choice but to move in whatever direction they point.  Best now I join the activities before my charge does or says something less than diplomatic and my head is summoned to a silver platter."
"Her nature is cautious, if you can guide her away from harm she will find her way.  Doubtless more bumps and scratches are to be had, but the lessons learned are better taught by experience so as not to be soon forgotten."  Nodding respectfully Mark departs to guide his ward the fair Leona toward the throne of Durer.  
Within the great hall a stout elderly Gentleman of mirthful demeanor ascends the spiral stair to the podium behind the model.  Were it not for his grandiose robes one could imagine him about to auction off used cars, or address his audience as voters.  Snapping his thumbnail against a chime sends a chord, though slight, echoing throughout the vast hall well above the din of conversation.  Nearly all in attendance are at once silent and move toward his presence.  Those few enjoying the outdoor verandah stream attentively back into the room.  Some prefer a measure of discretion, distancing themselves from the crowd.  Others flock toward the podium, anxious as children drawn to the call of a puppeteer.  "Hear ye, Hear ye, Hear ye," he announces slowly in a deep thunderous tone.  "I am Simous, counselor unto The House of Myrina and servant of the Games Regal.  Milord Tyrilym solicits you one and all to risk life, limb, sanity, and decorum, in pursuit of the utmost enterprise.  Come now to Myrina," he regales.  "Challenge the lord of the lands himself to every contest of cunning, skill, and fervor.  Thus, you are hereby invited to the 1109th Games Regal, sanctioned blood sport of Lavare."  He bows graciously to the crowd's vigorously applause.  "Twelve treasures guarded by riddles and deception of half a talent every one, hidden for the clever or lucky.  Seek and ye shall find," he entices with outstretched arms.  "Six treasures more, hidden and guarded by alchemist's trickery; each of these two full talents of fine gold.  Patiently, they await those of you with craft and wit at your command.  Three treasures yet in addition to these," he continues, his orations and gestures those of a sideshow barker.  "Of five talents their equal, precious gems and wizard's things these be, so small and light of weight you could have them away in your soup pot.  Now hear ye this and mark me well," he entices with coy smile while stroking his beard.  "For the best of it is yet to be known.  These... are unguarded."  A grave silence falls upon the guests for a few moments while the gravity of this disclosure settles in.  "Not man nor beast... nor engineer's devices... nor wizard's curse, to keep any of you from them."  All the while he points imposingly at different individuals among the guests whom he surmises to be hanging upon his every word.
If kindling melodrama is his task, well he has done of it.  Never have such considerable prizes been offered unattended, particularly of such convenient size and weight.  Whereas five talents of gold would be more than any two men could carry off, the equal in gems was only wishful thinking till now.  He bows solemnly to the assembly.  With this revelation the attendees offer a horrendous clamor of applause and good tidings.  Every corner of the hall is abuzz with speculation.  Excitement of this level has not been seen since Lord Hilgh offered the hand of his youngest daughter.  In truth she was no prize, but a life of luxury with title to boot allows that certain amenities may be overlooked.  Such enticement will have many who would have otherwise avoided Lord Tyrilym's infamous hospitality ante up their entry fee.
"Is there no end to milord's generosity?" he proclaims enthusiastically.  "In full view... a prince's ransom to tempt all who dare, a treasure being of itself twenty talents.  I am bound to say as well, all eleven hundred and forty kilos are coin now and forevermore.  There being not a man to keep you from it, but take heed for 'tis guarded by witches work of spells and demons and beasts one may abhor."    
By and by," he dares to entice in a soft subdued tone of voice, "perchance even a kingdom to be taken for those among you possessing a will of iron, or a death wish."  He spreads his arms with a smile and turns up the volume.  "Twenty one talents of purest gold carried off thus far by those with the courage to impose upon Milord Tyrilym's generosity and now this the greatest horde of treasure as never offered before.  I summon health and good fortune to all and bid ye farewell."  He exits with a gracious bow of theatrical proportions.
A sober fellow, tall and pale, and every stitch of his clothes black as night rises to the podium.  Long faced, pole thin and hollow of cheek is he with dark deep set eyes.  If there's an undertaker in their midst, surely this is he.  "The afore are facts, so say I, Temon of Andreanar, auditor of the realm."
One of the guests rises, "Good Sir Temon;" he motions.  "I would have an accounting, two cycles if you please, good sir."
"Then know ye this as well," Temon answers in deathly serious undertone.  "Of one hundred and thirty six who have ventured to Myrina, twenty one have perished, twenty two are maimed, eleven lost, who knows where, and nineteen to this day remain.  Four of those, their freedom to regain, allegiance have they sworn to a new lord and master, Tyrilym is his name.  Thus, severed are the ties that bind; hence are they no longer friends of your kind.  For now in service to his domain they hunt players of the Regal Game.  One hundred eighty stand at arms his realm to defend, not conscripts these nor country lads, but troops trained in every way to rend.  Twenty-one spies has he at large, discrete as shadow upon the wind, hence seamlessly with others they to blend.  Carefully placed to confound, seduce, and detect the likes of you, my friend.
Talk about a party pooper, one could imagine the grim reaper is peering over his shoulder?  Still, as Temon the pale descends from the podium a fair number of guests collect various of the gaming documents and disperse to study the finer points of Lord Tyrilym's proposition.  Once the crowd has subsided, Leona casually gathers one of each.  With Simou's presentation and Temon's thought-provoking summation, nearly every aspect of life as she had understood it has dissolved into a cloud of fantasies.
Fine soft leather now welcomes the Lady of Durer as she snuggles into one of the couches to unravel the mysterious Games Regal.  She is pleased to note a specific accord within the Rules Of Engagement prohibits the use of dogs in any way 'to guard or defend treasures nor to seek out, restrain, or attack' those engaged of Lord Tyrilym's gracious hospitality.  Likewise, summery executions are, though not entirely excluded, at least frowned upon.
--
Elsewhere upon the premises, grand as they may be, and entirely unconcerned of dogs, barking, biting, or otherwise, as for them this event is a purely social opportunity.  Thus, three lovely ladies, slender, tall and proud, sip wine and muse of days past as they scrutinize the crowd.
One to Another says "This game brings an odd lot into our midst."
Thus Another to the Other confides, "These are the lions among us.  I'm told those faint of heart are quickly devoured there; 'tis not a place to dally about as one without a care."
But now the Other reminds the first, "I've heard the lack of ransoms are the worst, for he prefers them stay as not.  And you know there are always a few get caught.  When you add what's paid to play, I expect Tyrilym's gain is more than he is due.  Mind what his counselor said of coins," the Other laments to both her friends, One and Another.  "There were four, they the first ever to reach the prince's ransom.  Tyrilym, clever bastard that he is, had it all smelted to a single bar," she boasts demurely over her shoulder with appropriate pout.  "He was called to task for his device; 'twas only fair considering what those four lads had at risk.  One to his end came, another damaged so; he probably thought the slain fellow the luckier of the two.  And the others earned rock dust to butter their bread; six months in the mines I've heard it said before decree of the Henzec's released them from their dread."
"I remember now," Another to the One confides.  "Quite an uproar came of that.  The widow petitioned for judgment, shame she didn't get a bit.  Hereafter, by royal edict, treasure must be of common coin that even a child might have away with it."
"Everyone thought the deed so foul," the Other to Another decries, "but none could rightly fault the scoundrel's whim.  For never had he said his prize to be of coin as every other's always been."
One quickly presumes, with a sly snicker, "I'd wager these unguarded treasures are penance for that deceit and much to Tyrilym's royal chagrin."
While three lovely ladies, all prim and polished very nice, debate the integrity of Lord Tyrilym's clever device, all about them hum like bees and tap upon Myrina's drum.  And at last to Leona's rescue a familiar face has come.
--
"Albert! Hey!  Leona's eyes brighten.  "Please sir, join me for a moment."  She taps the adjoining cushion and nods.  "I feel like a minnow that's hopped out of its fish bowl."
"I'm pleased to find you here, milady.  These are your countrymen, no need to feel uneasy."
"Quite a step-up compared to the crowd beer and pretzel guzzlers I usually run with."
"Within Lavare players are considered celebrities.  This is their gathering place, a neutral ground.  Some are retirees like myself.  Others are not actually players--administrators and entertainers for example--and usually some guests by special permission, minglers and sparklers they're called, but none of those may venture beyond the courtyard walls.  Only players are permitted to come and go at will."
"Does that mean, now that I'm here I'm stuck?"  Leona asks in a cautious tone.
"I doubt your freedom is in question, milady," Albert assures.  "You were invited.  Had you been summoned, you would have been escorted."
"Good to know," she nods with a smile.  "Haven't spotted my host yet though, or whatever Mr. Marwyn is exactly.  If someone asks me what I'm doing here, I'd have to fake it 'cause I'm really not sure." 
"When the time is appropriate," Albert consoles, "he will step forth, I'm certain."  "May I be so bold as to advise?"
"Yes, please!"
"A stranger in any established group tends to incite curiosity.  No doubt some who consider it their duty to know of everyone's business will eventually approach.  Refer to yourself as a guest--as my guest if you wish.  Here I am known as Arbosa of Loudes; tell any who ask, you are a friend of mine and leave it at that.  Such statement would not be a falsehood.  Among these folk, mention of your standing within the House of Durer may not serve your best interest just yet.  I would encourage that fine point be kept to oneself for now."
"I wouldn't dare! I mean theoretically... I'm a fugitive, right.  No, I just want to watch and learn," she purrs softly.  "Are you going to enter this treasure hunt tonight?"
"Not I," he admits, motioning toward the room at large.  "I leave such fun and games to these young roughnecks now.  From time to time I come to visit old friends.  We lie to each other a lot.  All in good jest you may be sure: how much we still can drink, how many fair maidens we have seduced of late, and other foolishness as might suit the day.  Every time we meet the adventures become more dangerous and the treasures more splendid.  In the world you know, I think they call it a bowling league."
Leona chuckles at Albert's analogy, then inquires.  "By the way, where are we?
"A very private place in North Carolina, about eighteen thousand acres as I recall."
"Okay... and what is a talent?"
 "How best to explain a talent?  yes... by your standards a very old unit of measurement, but one we of Lavare still employ.  It would translate to a bit over thirty kilograms or about sixty seven pounds as you would know it."
"Of course, yes," she agrees, considering for a moment with a notable exhale.  At $1500 an once, $18k a pound... that's over 12 million bucks! Holly shit!  
"Arboso, my friend" is heard above the ambient din of conversation from across the room.  It draws Albert's attention.  He acknowledges with raised tankard.
"A well meaning old friend," Albert advises, "who always consumes more ale than he should.  May I be excused, milady.  I need to console him or he will get louder."
"Oh sure, I mean yes, of course."  with that she nods and Albert graciously responds in kind and departs.
Three lovely ladies, clever, sly and getting quite mellow, sip their wine and wonder, "do we know that old fellow?  Arbosa of Loudes could he be?" a gentleman known both far and wide.  A sorcerer of fame is he, a man of wisdom, resources and great pride.  Masterful champion of the Games Regal, some claim to have seen unicorns prance at his side.  One, Another, or the Other would gladly consider his consort to be.  Thus, guaranteeing a life of comforts, serenity and pure luxury.  "A hundred talents he's carried off, payment so 'tis said, a Queen's misery to alleviate, but likely more to warm her bed.  Who then is this wench currying favor this night?"  Fortuity may be knocking here, if an introduction were contrived just right.
Three lovely ladies, so sleek and well attired, sip their wine as they devise, plot and conspire.  The Games Regal not the only sport afoot, nor all that may be gained by a clever liar.  If perchance they could meet this stranger's infamous confidant, too.  
Thus, Another to the Other inquires, "This quiet one over there is new.  All to herself, so nonchalant, Who might she be?  With such influential friends to flaunt that all about may see?"
To which the Other replies.  "Go... look into her eyes, see what secrets lie within.  Then come tell us that we may also make good sport of him."
"'Tis no fool, he whom you might beguile... take care," One to Another cautions with a slight tone of despair.  "For I should not so much enjoy your company were you soon a toad or spider to be."  Another to the One nods, then saunters off, an introduction to pursue so discreetly.  Alas, to her dismay, watching as her quarry chances to slip away.  Yet one must persist, for such opportunity may come again another day.
Three lovely ladies, rejoined as once within, they sip their wine, speculate and ponder of things that might have been.  Another to the Other regales, "She is called Leona of Guthrie, but her ornaments are unmistakably of Durer."  From our discourse, compared to us, one could think of her quite pure.  But, that trinket about her throat befits no less a queen, a sapphire the likes of witch I've never seen.  And queens are hardly less sullied than such as we.  Thus, I suppose we must bide our time, hence to wait and see.
"How strange," the Other infers, "I'm thinking that's a place I'd like to see.  For Guthrie is the kingdom of winds, a land which is only thought to be.  And Durer, though once it was, has long since ceased to be."
To which Another replies, "Not pretentious at all, quite friendly in fact, allowed me look into her eyes, then gazed into mine right back.  But the cloak keeps her secrets safely hidden from spies that nosy folk like us might not twist them into lies."
Now the Other adds with caution, "Wary I would be, for she has fairly warned.  Leona is a Durerish name and joined with Guthrie thus is born 'She Lion of the Winds.'  Not the likes of whom I'd care to scorn.
One may not but speculate, "Perhaps Arbosa is sire to this shy dear, or with such resource to tender, husband to this wench, I fear?"
"Envy her that cloak I do," remarks Another, "looks soft and warm as could be.  These slinky fabrics we three favor torment with chill constantly.  I'd trade her in a moment for that garment, then fast as I could off I'd flee.  She's one of the few here about who begs not to show her hind end for every he to see.  I'm wearing furs next time, that's it, you'll see; comfort, respect and dignity, that shall be the new me."
The Other to the One turns with a beam while Another glides off to embrace the crowd.  The Other confide, "not to be mean.  But, for crying out loud.  Why it is she thinks we three are invited to these social events.  I doubt such favor would continue if we strutted about wearing tents."
I've always suspected it has much to do with the fine form of our breasts and behinds," One discreetly laments.  While the Other arches her back and wiggles her bum to assure a smile of her friend's flattering comments.
Three lovely ladies, One, Another and of course the Other, now a bit more subtle, yet still their thoughts befuddled.  They conjure schemes of intrigue and motion an attendant to their aid.  "Wine my friend... bring us more wine, that we may continue this blatant charade."  Their spirits thus artfully piqued, these three shes seductively prance, the Other, quite unconcerned of any but One and Another as playfully they dance.  To and fro they cavort like nymphs off amongst a secluded wood.  Some might even boldly join in, if without notice only they could, but the serious business at hand assuredly precludes that they would.  The three lovely ladies frolic more so enticing than any the mimes might dare to provide.  Thus, their dubious reputations reinforced and assurance of future summons at best implied.  Least so long as they not present themselves concealed among furs or tents, yet of that infamous chill, still Another laments.  
Their garments elegant though of relatively simple taste.  Thus, somewhat inconspicuous as one might say of two gentlemen who have kept well to the room's extremities.  Neither has spoken to any other than themselves aside of the brief cordiality to passers-by.  Nor do they seem particularly interested in the challenge for which this gathering has been convened.  With but one curious exception, both follow every step Leona has taken since the moment those grand doors parted that she might enter the room.  The one is large, a fit and muscular fellow, a body guard if you will, an assassin in fact and one of the very best money can buy.  Though, beyond his seemingly natural talents for dispatching specified individuals, not very bright.  Sazrin he is called and his duty here today is to protect the interests of the other gentlemen, an accomplished sorcerer who very much resembles the classic stage image of Faust.
Sazrin knows his employer only as Um and for all intents and purposes that shall suffice.  Though not exactly the approved dress code, yet neither specifically forbidden, the weapons both carry are most certainly poisoned.
"A great inquiry is made of it when someone on this side is slain," Um advises quietly as he and Sazrin observe Leona's activities.  "If the Henzec's agent can entice her to cross it will be made a simpler matter.  As a player, all will accept without doubt that she has willingly placed herself at risk.  Becoming some what of a fugitive actually.  Death is a common hazard during the course of such entertainments.  There may even be a reward, thus, none could blame a citizen who took interest?"  Um turns to his accomplice, looking deep into his eyes to see if their is any hint of remorse or hesitation.  "I assure you," he asserts confidently, "no one would suppose it otherwise."  All the while Um knowing his hit man is ignorant of Leona's status as Heir to the House of Durer.  Or, that the premeditated murder of one of her standing would probably earn the culprit a slow torturous ending between the rack and pinion.  A broad, massive stone gear that's rolled over a flat ribbed oak plank to mangle the limbs of anyone anchored there between.  Though, if he succeeds, 'tis more likely he would succumb to poisoned drink precluding any risk of interrogation which might disclose his association with Um.
"We should be off now to prepare."  Um and his associate exit discreetly leaving the players to their games.
A boisterous comment catches Leona's ear, in tone of voice she never again thought to hear.  Still, solace may be found in that it might be heard at all; thus, her attention's drawn to a gathering across the hall.  Three stout fellows, rude, crude and short, each of them a gentlemen of his own sort.  Beards and locks trimmed smartly for this evening's event, they sip rye whisky though it were spring water laced with peppermint.  Fine dark Italian suits and pin-striped silken shirts, tailored to each the same in every way.  Stout chests strut out like peacocks, elegant amulets of wizard's work to display.  But wait... for one appears but a chain alone with a broken clasp, alas something has gone astray.  Could they be those she slew within her game of fantasy?  That they exist at all further confounds this plague of mysteries.  Which was it then, she begs to know, to what vague place did she really go?  Wondrous visions of fantasy or cruel displaced reality?  How does a coin pierced in a dream find its way to my bed table?  A relief to see they've fared so well, and each remains quite able.  The sleuth, she edges closer now, in hope their amulets would dare the truth to tell, that this confounding fog of mind might at last dispel.  'Tis as she feared; was it a dream or not?  They were with her there; the self-same three she fought.  Two still display a golden talisman the like of which deflected a crossbow's dart.  The third of them's given up his treasure, no less a token from the heart.  Shared with the wench who cut him down then labored doggedly all the day that they might be consumed of fire and properly sent upon their way.  Albert spoke of purgatory; did I miss an important point?  Was I in their dream, too?  Will they remember me as well?  Had the pyre not been fulfilled, would they be here now, or lost and wandering still?
Sagen's first to recognize; thus, cautiously does he inform.  "Brothers, we have company," his tone as much to warn.  Unconcerned of his dismay, for her task is not to scorn.  She steps forth, a debt to repay, that both are nevermore forlorn.  "Beg your pardon," she pleads of Patch.  "I've found something you may have mislaid."  She extends her palm, therein the amulet graciously rendered to her aid.  "If by chance again we meet I hope the circumstance more cordial than when first our paths crossed.  Such a shame were either of us to be forever lost."  They but nod in due respect.  Now does she slip away, as further words would be misspent and complicate this play.
The talisman's come full circle now.  Indeed it seemed an obligation and she's pleased the opportunity arose.  Even more, that it was smoothly accomplished.  She quietly returns to those most intriguing documents gathered earlier, 'Tenets of Barter and Ransom,' the next of her lessons.
Very shortly, she's distracted again, this time by a child-like snicker; a suppressed giggle comes next to tease.  The engaging little Pixie, or whatever, who enticed her to have her fortune read, pops into view at the far side of the table.  "Hello!"  Leona exclaims delightedly, quite surprised at her appearance.  "I remember you," Leona muses, but failing to look nearly so serious as she tries to sound.  "You're the little devil got me into all this."  The woman-child beams a mischievous grin.  "Have you still got my penny?"  Nodding an unmistakable yes, the darling's expression transforms into a gleeful smile so big there's hardly space enough for her dimples.  "I thought so; never give it back, will you?"  A quirky tight-lipped "no," her silent response to this challenge.  'Tis not the penny itself you see, but the fact it was given willingly, for now, however slight it may be, there is hint of a binding between these shes.
Shyly shrugging her shoulders, the child slowly raises both hands into view.  She appears to be holding a fish bowl hidden beneath a heavy herringbone cloth woven of browns and greens.  Gently upon the table the little mischief maker places the round object; her wings flutter amid a flurry of giggles and she dashes away without further ado.  The spherical shape begins to melt, more and more until it has completely disappeared allowing the cover settle flat upon the table.  Flat that is, except for a small bump nuzzling its way about there beneath, searching it seems to find a way out from under.  The energetic lump reaches the edge, hesitates for a moment, then a tiny pointed head peeks out to see where he might be.
"Bird! You little rascal!" Leona exclaims in a hushed but excited whisper.  "Where have you been?  I'm sorry... things just got so out of hand.  How could you be here though?"  Her tone of voice becomes even more subdued, or perhaps frightened.  With Bird's appearance boundaries are becoming blurred again.  Abstracts pose a serious burden upon those possessing an analytical nature.  "Are you real, too?  Was none of it a dream... or has it never really ended?"
She places an inviting finger near her repatriated friend.  Bird is quick to jump aboard.  Raising her little pet to eye level, one might think to reminisce of their adventures.  Bird nuzzles the underside of his chin back and forth on her fingertip, as much to say 'missed you, too,' then cocks his head first to one side, then the other--his way of sizing up the new environment.  "Have I stepped across the line again?"  She confides to her tiny gray confident, seemingly unconcerned someone might think it strange she's conversing with little more than a bug.  "I swear, I can't tell the difference."
The sudden, unscheduled demise of a glass refocuses Leona's attention on the surroundings.  Bird knows an opportunity when it's presented, jumps to her gown and quickly disappears, knowing exactly where to hide when something's gone amiss.  Neither is he shy in the least about it.  One could imagine the little rascal's pleased with the remodeled accommodations.
"Oh shit!  You little pecker," she hisses, glancing around to see if anyone might have noticed Bird's maneuver.  "Hey!  That was only allowed because it was a game, an imaginary game may I remind.  So it didn't count.  You can't do that for real."  She bashfully surveys the vicinity once more; no one's attention appears drawn to her activities.  "You're embarrassing me; I don't even know these people."  She cautiously replaces her disbelieving expression with a casual smile, total denial being her best defense.   Ha! No! you're mistaken; that didn't really happen.  After all, at least until proven otherwise, this is not another imagined state of being.  Anyway, cheap thrills are to be avoided in public.  "Don't you dare peek out of there," she quietly admonishes.  "You hear me?  I need time to work this out."
In defense of talking to lizards, uncommon though it may seen.  What child do you know who may resist and upon the slightest 'wolf' of their new pet fails not to beam?  I beg you consider also the old maid or wealthy widow, can you think of one that does not share the blame?  What difference, be it cat, canary, demon or pampered pup, do they not all serve as the same?  Unconditional love when times are tough or gentle distraction to keep one from going insane.
Temon the Pale's somber voice breaks the air again, stirring her back to the task at hand.  "Hear ye, Hear ye!  Players of the Games Regal," he announces.  "Your judge for the contest at Myrina, the esteemed Keal of Thormoney, now bids you join him at the gateway."  The room's buzz falls silent as the guests migrate toward Temon's voice.
A double-extra-large noble-looking sort in his 70's stands at Temon's side.  His robes of the deepest blue, and very tastefully trimmed of scarlet, burgundy and a white so bright one could imagine it electrified.  Golden laurels entwine a hardy crop of curly graying locks, and in his grasp a blade no less impressive than those of Arthurian legend.  A Roman senator at least, if not Caesar himself.  He acknowledges the gathering with a slight slow nod.  "I am Keal of Thormoney and I am master of this game," he announces in a deep authoritative tone.  "To all now before me, I swear under pain of death to execute fair and just the articles of play presented forthwith.  I have arbitrated thirty-two events and still my head remains upon my shoulders," he jokes morbidly with a wave of his hand.  "Be ye nobleman, knight, knave, or maiden most fair, skullduggery will not be tolerated.  I shall be the judge of your deeds as the Henzecs are of mine."  That said, he alights gently upon a throne crafted of solid tourmaline; this amidst a long, narrow, semicircular table which has just risen up out of the floor.  With an assuring smile, he spreads his arms and continues.  "Who then among you will cast their lot this night against the perils of Myrina?"
Leona mingles with those near the far end of the table, all the while trying to detect some hint of this amazing gateway reputed to be so near.
By ones and twos they come forth to pay their dues.  Two spry lads, twins perhaps with strawberry blond hair are the first, matching Armani suits, ruffled French shirts of lavender, sunglasses, and fedoras, with two swords to each strapped diagonally across their backs.  They bow respectfully, one placing an investment-size gold brick upon the table.  Drawing their swords in unison and pointing them skyward, "Aye!" they affirm.  
Amazons, one could imagine, beautiful creatures built like gazelles and attired in artfully translucent gowns.  They toast each other with golden goblets, then, lay them on their sides, coins spill out.  They nod and salute the game master with raised daggers.  "Aye, home to Myrina."
Two children excitedly approach; at first impression, neither could be more than thirteen, but to deceive is the game's calling.  Given her own trials of late, neither the unenlightened nor the unprepared earn an opportunity to approach this table.   Each drops a leather purse of coin upon the table as a child might dispense with toys in which they've lost interest.  "We've come to play in Myrina, sir" the little girl teases gleefully.  Thus, it continues by one's and two's as a rich broth of over forty vie for Lord Tyrilym's trinkets particularly those by all accounts unguarded and light of weight.
Only Cirq De Sole could muster so unique a crew as these, and likely none more agile nor daring.  Not the most fearsome lot as against a sovereign force of arms, but 'tis seldom strength that deals the killing card.  Stealth, illusion, concealment and retreat by far and away the weapons of choice.  And yet still one or two who would part a sponsoring noble of his wealth on the strength of boundless arrogance alone.
As the ranks of interested players dwindle, the crowd begins to drift back to their socializing, not the least of which is daring one another to reconsider and take on the infamous Lord Tyrilym.
When all seems done, a hooded figure steps to the table adjacent her position and places a leather pouch of coin upon table.  One hand moves from beneath his cape presenting Leona the scabbard of her sword; the tip of which is carefully supported by an especially constructed pedestal strapped to his knee.  This because the weight of it would otherwise be unbearable.  If she takes hold and he is thus obliged to release his grip, he is really not sure of what will happen.  With the other he pulls the hood back revealing himself to be the scalawag she has been patiently waiting for.  He lowers his eyes.  "Your blade, milady."
"So... there you are," she responds in a monotone akin to the rumbling that might precede a volcanic disturbance.  "You've got balls offering me a knife after the stunts you've pulled."
Always curious of a lover's quarrel, game master Keal allows his attention drift toward Marwyn's back and Leona, he nods and smiles.  Leona notices, returns a slight but gracious nod and refocuses sharply upon her antagonist.
"Your trials were necessary, milady.  They have granted you entry here among your kind.  If you would know the reason for your being, come now to Myrina and glimpse your world?"
Slowly she withdraws the blade; thereupon, the ominous inscription remains.  Her gaze begs to ask if she might take a serious swing at this fellow.  Marwyn is at once perplexed and relieved that she can do so without it crashing to the floor.
"Was I drugged?" she inquires.
"No; your thoughts and deeds had to be genuine.  Your state was more hypnotic in nature."
"There were two games... weren't there?"  I was the only one playing both; is that correct?" 
"Yes!"
"And do you intend to mislead me again?"  She inquires as much to warn as ask.
"No, from this moment on I shall be honest and truthful in every matter."
"Swear to it, here and now before all these good people as witnesses"
"I do so swear, milady."
Leona turns her attention toward the game master, Marwyn takes note and follows suit.
The game master nods, "Your oath to this maiden is duly noted, sir."
Leona nods her appreciation of the game master's acknowledgment and returns her attention to Marwyn.  "Then I would know."  Without breaking eye contact she raises the blade over her head.  "Aye!"

So Ends
The Beginning

Congratulations, It's a long story and in this world of acronym laced texting and Twitter, finishing is an accomplishment.  I hope you've enjoyed rummaging around in my day dreams for a while. 

A common element of fairy tales are rhymes.  I have incorporated several here and there to add a hint of spice.  I hope you have found these diversions interesting and for those who have, something extra of a sort.  Moth Tales, my first attempt, which is not related to the story line in Fantasy Games in any way is included below.

MOTH TAILS


Warm water and clean linens
With much good spirit allowed,
As an expectant young mother
Labors to bear her first child.

At least so,
Till the room's light began to grow dim,
Strangely paling, evermore,
From the confines there within.

A great storm of dark clouds
Was thought to encroach,
Hence, one did rush toward a window
To view of its approach.

"It's turning black!" the woman gasped;
"The sun... it's fading from the sky!"
"Bring lamps," the midwife cries out in dismay;
"Light we must have or this child could die!"

Yet, all stood fast,
For none could but watch,
While this most noble of tasks
The heavens have chosen to debauch.

One fearful maiden whimpered,
Then, could not but to cry,
While the moon's silhouette
Stole all light from on high.

Total eclipse,
Surely the Grim Reaper's deed.
A token that man and beast alike
Should caution and take heed.

For among them, never a one 
Had seen such foreboding sight,
That of midday's sky
Seemingly withering into night.

Thus, came they to wonder,
How might this task succeed?
As never more for bright of day
Was there of greater need.

Why does the sun forsake the sky
That cottony clouds turn now to soot?
Lest some wicked curse there's been
Or evil deed come underfoot.

"Banish this cloak of night," one demurs
With trembling word, as more to scold than plead.
"The time has come," begs another;
"Let not her gift be lost nor this gentlewoman bleed."

But, still the room came black as pitch
That none could more than fumble about.
For lack of flint and candle's wick
This cause may soon be lost, no doubt.

The frightened mother-to-be
Drew tense and cautious breath.
So delicate her circumstance
Was she scared near half to death.

Yet, resolute did she remain
Till that ominous shadow quietly slipped by.
And there, now with her mother,
So calmly, a new born child did lie.

Such stillness overtook the room,
One could hear another's heartbeat.
Each to the other duly nodded,
As those who caution wisely might entreat.

Sorcery was at hand, they feared,
And all wished to remain quite discreet.
One young lady milled about aimlessly,
Paying strict attention to her feet.

The midwife sighed,
Then, fainted dead away;
Whereas none among the others
Dared a word to say.

For they knew such departures
Are better left to lay;
With any thought of disquiet
Held silent till another day.

Now, as the chamber brightened anew
The child began to wail.
And every morn at first glimpse of dawn,
Her eyes yet closed, again would she rebel.

Screaming till windows were shuttered tight,
With curtains veiled to block the light.
Lest she'd rage as by demons possessed
Against each new day's coming bright.

A child opposed to all that glowed,
However dim or slight.
Terrified unto hysterics
By all but the frail moon's light.

Hence, those who came unto her presence
So as not to stir a fright,
One veiled candle only
Dared they to ignite.

Thus, a young maiden came to be,
Pale her skin and hair.
Both the color of ivory,
For the sun she could not bear.

Six years would pass
While cloistered there she remained;
Hidden in the darkness
As the bat sealed in its cave, thus restrained

Collateral she was in fact,
Against a debt as yet unpaid.
The hand of destiny, the finger of fate,
Being not of those you may evade.

Her bed no less a coffin,
Her room no less a grave,
Held prisoner there,
As one unto the dark of night forevermore a slave.

Yet, always adjacent the shutters,
Though forlorn and melancholy,
Condemned, only but to listen
While the other children folly.

They played and laughed
In a place she was forbidden to go,
That inviting space 'tween dawn and dusk
Where demon light did glow.

Perhaps an owl was she meant to be?
Left alone, far removed from society.
A life laid waste, abandoned,
In some gnarled old forgotten tree.

Hidden there, shrouded by the night,
As would an outcast entity,
With naught but chill of darkness
And crickets to keep company.

Though solitude may be sublime for some,
As I, 'tis seldom so for a child.
How unconcerned her world's become,
To one so innocent, yet, invariably wild.

Late evening oft would find the waif
Standing upon her table;
The confining shrouds to unlatch
Whenever she was able.

Thus, to admit pale light of moon
To this dark reclusive fable.
A dismal, otherworldly place,
So sad, bleak, and unstable.

Wondering where, they, her only friends came from,
And even more, curious as to where they'd go.
Perhaps as she, off to hide from the coming dawn,
They too, banished by the sun's warm glow.

This radiant solace reserved to others,
That none among her kind may know.
Expelled, forced to withdraw and cloak their eyes,
Ever to seek he whose name is shadow.

With naught but this chamber's dismal despair
And her portal's bounded view,
Dreams are confused, uninspiring,
Difficult to construe.

The subtle rhythmic sounds of night
Her frequent lullaby.
This lithe pale damsel's tears
Faint prayer to wish this world goodbye.

One night, while a lonely vigil,
Gazing into dark and moonless sky,
Came a stranger's voice, "Sabrinnaaa!"
So soft and warm to ply.

There seemed such comforting of presence,
Alas, faint tear came to eye.
Then, appeared so fair a maiden,
A noble sorceress none dare defy.

Deep emerald was milady's cloak,
Adorned of long, translucent, elegant trains.
Fluttering softly thereabout
As though swift breeze constantly remains.

Opalescent jewels
Emitted gentle radiance of greenish hue,
Her staff of icy splinters
Topped with flame of azure blue.

Garlands of tiny stars
Woven through endless manes of pitch black hair,
Crescent moons upon flowing sleeves
Danced whimsically with naught a care.

Purple mantles upon her shoulders,
An exalted status to proclaim.
None graced of such a presence,
But short breath dare they retain.

So dark her eyes one could imagine,
Perhaps, indeed, they were not there.
Might this at last death's angel be?
For others, cause of great despair.

"I am Selene," she whispered gently;
"We've met before, there... in the sky.
To stir the winds with cool of night, 
Thus, mistress of the seas, am I.

To grind the rocks of shore to sand 
With relentless caress of tides, do I.
For waves are born of my command;
Though soft pale light of night, am I.

Spark to set a lover's soul to flame,   
Then softly calm with morning's dew, shall I.
Almost every night I've shown myself to thee;
Muse of wolves... dear child... the moon am I."

Your mother, too, oh yes... I knew her well,
Though she would prefer it not.
For of her own words, with your conception,
Was she then bound and caught.

Indeed... she did abandon thee, long, long ago,
Even though as now you are... then, were you not.
Thus, are you the pledged,
The child first born... your lot!

Now, time has come for favors granted
That I may solicit my fee.
For the passions humans know, you see,
Are denied to such as me.

My daughters are born of foolish women,
As your mother came to be.
Look into the heavens, my dear...
What there do you see?

Each star, a frivolous request
I've granted... come into reality,
Ill-considered promises...
Souls willingly forfeit to me.

Some imposed upon others,
Whom as you... were yet to be.
Indeed, at that moment of darkness, 
'Twas I... came safe to deliver thee.

To the sky then... raise your eyes,
To all those trivial dreams made real,
Exchanged for the spirits of children,
Yet innocent, pure, and genteel."

Visions of fairies the moon's maiden form weaves,
Each resplendent of revelry, merriment, and jest.
"Festivity unending I promise to thee,"
Enticed pale lips at their best.

Thus, did Selene lure the little munchkin
As young lovers she would beguile.
The innocent her willing consorts
Come the onset of their trial.

Of moonbeams she narrates,
Implied, though false covenants of privacy.
That one, by touch alone, 
May ignite cautious first spark of intimacy.

"I am that by which shadow is transformed
Unto paramour's delight.
Teasing as it does with subtle reflection
And fine pale droplets of light.

The aphrodisiac from the sky,
A potion which never fails to incite.
Just faint enough that amorous adventurers
Will dare as only lovers might.

Thus, allowing one may seek another
Beyond the shadows of twilight.
The blood boils, the mind reels,
Every touch the further to excite.

I, to render the veil of darkness translucent,
As also that of a bride to be;
Ploy to keep her near,
Yet only within clear sight of he.

Thus hidden, so to tease,
That subtle promise just beyond,
All the better one to pursue 
Before first glimpse of coming dawn."

Hypnotic illusions these,
Though, not entirely forthright.
Yet, as from perspectives
Few mortals could hope to recite.

"Forsake the golden sphere,
So hot and painfully bright;
A face one dare not look upon
Without risk of harming sight.

Come away,"
Dares she fervently her victim to excite,
"Hereafter, 
Acknowledge only my faint, cool, silvery light.

Accept temptation's warm discomforting guise
On this calm and private night.
Dance among my gossamer rays...
Embrace that ecstasy which is flight."

Seduced was she, as few may resist at once
The splendor of dreams and domains where poets play.
The child beams at such possibility,
But yet, with slight dismay.

For in the dark, she wonders,
"However shall I find my way?
Can you help me please?"
With big, bright, hopeful eyes she prays.

Weeping tiny tears with sighs,
How could one not be charmed, thus swayed?
Selene, quick to assure,
That fair maiden's passage be not delayed.

"Life shall be short though sweet for thee,
A week... ten days at best.
But, as I am, so ye shall be, reborn again constantly, 
Then, all of winter's days to rest.

With warmth of spring to emerge anew,
As of my court a royal guest.
With those first to bloom of golden hue, 
Come forth... resume your noble quest.
 
From harm's way to keep you safe,
Wings to glide upon luminous breeze.
Appended of long elegant trains, are they,
Ever thereafter you to follow, shall these.

Of soft warm ermine, a fine coat 
Will I also fashion for thee.
By this, night's chill to keep at bay.
And golden tiaras too, of delicate filigree.

If bats come near or spiders leer
From clever unseen web,
Their presence you shall sense,
Thus, to avoid unwelcome dread.

Your eyes will glow as those of a demon
Far removed from grace,
Ever when light being not of mine
Is shown upon your face.

And if a mortal glimpses thee,
So to Wonder, 'Could this delight a pixie be?
Or vivid figment of imagination
By that last pint of ale now set free?'

Faint recollection of the Brothers Grimm
Muddled with memories of those grown old,
Pleasant thoughts from childhood days,
Now come again to tease so bold.

Not so, say I, for truth be told,
'Tis good fortune no less of worth 
As having one's palm crossed with gold
Or of fine company be filled with mirth.

'Twas the moon's handmaiden,
So thought provoking her flight.
For a Luna Moth their path has crossed,
Such rare and enchanting sight.

An image for those who brave the dark.
Be it of their need to flee
Or desire with another in the meadow to lie, 
Homage to fairest Aphrodite. 

Of persimmon and birch,
A broth I've prepared for you,
Spiced with blossoms of twilight
And spark of magic too.

All this afloat in a goblet of silver 
Filled with clear sweet morning's dew.
Dear, pale, lovely maiden... drink,
That my gifts to thee may I imbue.

Bid you sleep, perchance to dream... now I do, 
For there alone are covenants as these fulfilled.
That place of quiet where all may blend,
Ferment and be appropriately distilled.

Allow that my enchantments
Guide your spirit and forevermore your soul ignite,
Draw near," Selene entices softly;
"Be as one upon the winds with me this very night.

Caution though, for of my children
Some are swayed when first do they awake.
Led astray by desires once they possessed
To discreet, but unfortunate mistake.

Be not as those to seek nirvana,
Pleasures brief as the moth drawn toward open flame.
As oft many a frivolous maiden dares,
Thinking naught to lose, ah! but love to gain.

There to perish in a flash,
With only ash then to remain.
Though, I think not such creature was a fool,
Nor has found death aside of passionate refrain.

For each desiring of the other, as do lovers,
The wayward moth no less adored her fiery mate.
Cast not your spirit upon elusive whims,
Tempt not thus the merciless hand of fate."

Be it instinctive or playful charade,
Her noble guest to delight.
The young maiden concedes with a smile,
Curling herself into blankets snug and tight.

A giggle, a stretch, and a yawn,
Then fast asleep was she, as any child might.
Soon to come, a sparkling clarity
And fellowship with the night.

The wonder of metamorphosis
Like the wave of a magic wand,
Thus, to banish all which was
Before first glimpse dawn.

This, so complete a reformation 
As the pyre exacts from those who've gone.
Labors no less inspired than those of Merlin
Among the mists of fabled Avalon.

Now, much as the caterpillar
Embraced of silken cocoon,
Hidden safely there within,
Her entire being is consumed.

Calm, precious silence, lovely stillness,
Tears dried at last,
With reservation not,
A child thus steps beyond the looking glass.

Finally at peace with destiny,
Her spirit gracefully exhumed.
A pale and awkward grub transformed,
Then, taking flight to please the moon.

By this, all she has come to know,
Now does she forswear.
Recant of every thought, banished,
Never again to despair.

Selene embraces her new consort,
As to a bride, the groom endows his vows with rings.
"To the house of the moon, thee I welcome,
Thus, my mark now set upon your wings.

We are one, you and I,
Henceforth, my night shall be your day.
With subtle wisp of image
Now to thee I show the way.

Noble carnivores will howl
While crickets chirp to entertain,
A thousand fireflies shall twinkle
As they dance in choreographed refrain.

Choruses of frogs and echo of whippoorwill,
Artistically added to these,
With katydids and wind to whisper
Among the surf of shuffling leaves.

Mingle with scent of wild rose,
Milkweed, and hummingbird's delight,
Blend by whirling breeze
To pique your paramour's appetite.

Upon restless brook, trickle of spring
And still pools of water alike,
My reflection shall cavort, 
As thus, for thee I set aside the veils of night.

With peril not, be off,
The deepest wood to navigate.
Wheresoever thou desire, you may go,
Be not as those who hesitate.

Dew-laden architectures of forest and field,
Delicate, yet held so tight.
Jewels bound up by arachnid's handiwork,
Ever glistening beneath my wondering light.

Whether these tiny droplets of moisture,
The delicate lacewing to excite.
Led astray with tragic consequence, 
That now sad eulogy need we recite.

Or among the fountains of fabled Shalimar,
That strands of pearls shimmer even mid-of-night. 
Rows of tiny moon lit crescents reflected,
Her lover to assure, entice and delight.

Thus, a Moorish Princess from afar,
Her Persian paramour glimpse of endearing sight.
The most lethal tool at a lady's command,
image, irresistible as the vampire's bite.

Not a place exists upon this world,
However well hidden, nor too far;
That my embrace may not seek you out,
No matter when, nor where you are.

For I have been since time began
And still shall be when it comes to an end,
That not remains but dust, vapor,
And the souls of mankind to attend.
 
Some my light to follow, love will find,
yet others not but sorrow or despair.
Never may I say which, for 'tis with free will
That each their own path must they declare.

'My sphere lingers 'tween dusk and dawn, 
For the passionate, ever the realm of delight.
How exquisite this place we dwell...
Forgiving and ethereal is the night."

A forlorn mother now greets the day,
Bewilderment her plight.
Fearful is she to recall her promise
To the moon that fateful night.

Scorched there upon the headboard
Of her child's cold and vacant bed,
Only the crescent mark of the moon
Now remains instead.

"My firstborn," foolishly she pledged,
"Is yours I promise tonight;
If that handsome rogue
You can entice to my bed forthright."

And with that, she got her wish,
With no regard of the vow dared she to recite.
Conspirators now are they,
This frivolous wench and luminous orb of night.

Forevermore bound by spark of lust,
Upon seeing the lad judged to be her heart's delight.
Though, to condemn an innocent, how sad,
For such vile deed this woman had not the right.

But, once her ill-considered bargain was struck,
Deceived and hopelessly seduced was he.
The moon, thus inspired, quick to beguile,
So as not to lose her fee.

The wench at once appearing
As no less the finest of tapestries;
Her form dripping of honey, sweet and golden,
Never mind the sting of bees.

A reflective cloth, satin smooth,
Woven from hypnotic threads of light;
One composed that no lad could be but smitten
Of such enchanting sight.

To sway the thoughts of men,
For the moon, a task so slight.
With trifle of disguise and quick of hand
To deceive as any sorceress might.

By such tricks
Oft are the paths of mortals thus revised,
And sadly... daughters spirited away
From before their mother's eyes.

Even the seas dare not resist 
This lucent sphere's devise;
Thus, upon maidenly shores each night
The tides dare not but rise.

Her precious little darling
Has emerged and taken flight.
The child's destiny sealed long before
By her own mother's portentous slight.

Wishing now to recant,
She gazes into a ghostly sky,
Little more to comfort
Than tears of saddened eye.

"Woe is me,"
She risks regretfully to sigh;
"I've given my only true love away...
With naught a word goodbye."

The father, elsewhere, long since gone,
To seek his separate destiny.
For the bargain had no stipulation
He remain her faithful mate eternally.

Thus, all gained of their affair
Is forever lost, or better said, set free.
The woman's debt now fully discharged
By this most precious and uncommon fee.

None would believe her ramblings,
Hence, many came to think her mad.
"Taken by the moon! Ha!
What fool's delight, how desperate and sad."

Such poor attempt to excuse this loss;
The fragile maiden once entrusted to her care.
A child now run away, no doubt,
Her fate at last she to dare.

And though she knows it not,
Her daughter has visited in midst of night.
Perhaps to stir her mother's dreams,
Perhaps to watch their flight.

Gliding through an unshuttered window,
Circling an uncluttered room,
There to find her mother, as once was she,
Hopelessly constrained of doom.

One should avoid promises
They intend not solemnly to keep.
Even those flares of passion dare incite,
However bold or deep.

As by such foolish jest
Many have come to error.
Unto desire's yoke, indentured,
Thus, all logic to impair.

Slain not by Cupid's arrow,
Then, left exposed unto despair.
Evermore in grief to languish,
Apt penance for what they dare.

Of their own accord, those so cursed, 
Each night in lieu of dreams, to weep;
Nor better the thought of such requite
When light of dawn next they to greet.

For love is not to trifle with,
And to the gods... a promise must you keep.
Thus, Remember always this tale of woe,
Or naught but lunacy your reward for such deceit.
